name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the Council and the Commission on the latvian Presidency's balance sheet. I would like to make it clear that there is no catch-the-eye procedure and no blue cards on this point.

name: Laimdota Straujuma
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President of the European Parliament, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. Mr President of the European Commission, I would like to begin by congratulating the Rapporteur Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. Dear Commissioners, First of all, I would like to thank President Schulz for his good cooperation. It is a great honour for me to return to the European Parliament after six months of very intensive work to discuss the work done by the Latvian Presidency. The past period has been a very challenging and dynamic time for Europe, as well as a great responsibility and unique experience for Latvia. Latvia put forward three priorities: a competitive Europe, a digital Europe and an involved Europe. Life brought its own corrections. Terrorist attacks and the humanitarian crisis at Europe's borders required immediate action by the European Union. At the moment, however, all thoughts are on Greece. Although Latvia had to lead the Work of the Council of the European Union in a climate of turmoil and uncertainty, I can be proud of my country, which has successfully run for its first presidency after 10 years of membership of the European Union. We have succeeded in implementing our strategic priorities. I would like to point out in particular that the activities of our Presidency have been permeable of the involvement of civil society and social dialogue. Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. During the preparation of the Presidency and in the course of this process, we have remained in intensive dialogue with the European Parliament. It has made an inavertiable contribution to the successful Latvian Presidency. I am convinced that it is only in the institutions that, through cooperation and working together, that we in the European Union can achieve results, succeed and promote citizens' trust. On behalf of the Latvian Presidency, I would like to thank the European Parliament for its excellent cooperation during the Presidency. Good and constructive cooperation has enabled us to advance the priority issues and day-to-day work pragmatically and effectively, as well as to respond quickly to new challenges and crises. Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. Together with the European Commission and the European Parliament, we have worked resolutely on legislation. We have made good progress in many areas, reached substantial agreements and achieved concrete results. Today, looking back, I would like to highlight the most important achievements of the Presidency. Achievements that benefit every European citizen. Firstly, the European Fund for Strategic Investments We managed to reach an agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments in record time. Already this summer, the Fund will start work on attracting investment to the European economy. I would like to thank the European Parliament and the European Commission for their intensive work on this very important issue for Europe. Secondly, the Energy Union We have laid the foundations for a European Energy Union aimed at strengthening the EU's energy independence and a common energy policy in the European Union. In our work, we focused on the need to ensure stable and affordable energy prices for consumers, more choice in the energy market and clearer information on energy suppliers. The Latvian Presidency achieved substantial decision-making in the creation of the European Energy Union, contributing to the transition to a low-carbon economy, thereby enhaning the EU's energy independence. The Latvian Presidency reached an agreement on the submission of EU commitments to reduce climate change after 2020, ensuring a timely EU contribution to the preparation of the Paris Climate Conference. Thirdly, the Digital Single Market We agree that we must go hand in hand with the development of digital technologies in order to be able to adapt society to the digital age. We have therefore agreed on actions that will contribute to the increasing use of digital solutions in business. These will be aspects of digital data access and security, as well as the provision of digital skills. The Latvian Presidency paid particular attention to exploiting the potential of the European digital economy. Further developing the Digital Single Market is crucial for the European Union's competitiveness, growth and employment. The Latvian Presidency made every effort to ensure that the legislation essential to the completion of the Digital Single Market is progressed. I am pleased with the general approach adopted in the Council on the proposal for a Data Protection Regulation, which allowed negotiations to be launched with the European Parliament on 24 June. Data protection is an essential condition for the successful development of the Digital Single Market and the protection of citizens' fundamental rights. In the last few days of the Presidency, we reached agreement on a proposal for a single market for telecommunications, which provides for the abolition of roaming surcharges and for open internet access. This important achievement of our Presidency will benefit every citizen, as the agreement provides for a substantial reduction in roaming charges as early as 30 April next year. We also agreed with the European Parliament on the general principles for the Network and Information Security Directive. I hope that, once the proposal has been clarified, we will soon have a framework at our disposal that will provide better protection against cyber-attacks. Fourthly, migration has become one of the most pressing issues in the European Union in recent months. In accordance with the guidelines approved by the European Council, the Council has made progress in preventing the loss of life in the Mediterranean, combating criminal networks of smugglers, strengthening cooperation with countries of origin and transit, and helping the Member States of the European Union, which are under the greatest migratory pressure. The issue of migration is very complex. A sustainable solution can only be possible within the framework of a targeted, comprehensive and balanced approach, which is systematically implemented step by step. It is very important to ensure that the proposed solution is supported by all the Member States of the European Union. We need to strike a balance between solidarity and responsibility, which are an essential part of the European Union's migration policy. Protection must be provided to those who need it. However, safeguards in themselves will not be sufficient. They must go hand in hand with an effective system for returning irregular migrants. Fifthly, security Security challenges have led us to reassess our understanding of both the Internal and External Security of the European Union. During the Latvian Presidency, the Council has done a great deal to strengthen the internal security of the European Union. In June, the European Union's Interior Ministers approved the renewed Internal Security Strategy of the European Union. As a a follow-up, priorities for the next five years are to raise the fight against terrorism and radicalisation, organised crime and cybercrime, and draw attention to the new security challenges we face, including hybrid threats. The events of recent weeks have once again recalled the terrorist threat facing the European Union. I would like to remind you that we have kept our promise to agree on a Data Protection Pack in the Council. We hope that an agreement on the European Union's passenger name record will be reached by the end of this year. I appreciate the review of the European Union's security strategy by the High Representative, the Vice-President of the Commission. Sixthly, the Eastern Partnership We are pleased that the Riga Summit confirmed the stable relations of the European Union with the countries of the Eastern Partnership. At the same time, in view of the development of a differentiated approach, maintaining the unity of the Eastern Partnership will be an important task in the future development phase of the Eastern Partnership. Together with the European Parliament, the Latvian Presidency succeeded in reaching an agreement on macro-financial support for Ukraine. We are pleased that the EU has remained united on Russia, reiterating the importance of fulfilling the Minsk agreement commitments. I would also like to point out that, during our Presidency, Central Asia has returned to the active agenda of the European Union. The European Union should not underestimate the importance of this region. Seventhly, the transatlantic trade and investment partnership for boosting economic growth also has an important role to play in external trade and attracting investment. I therefore believe that the timely conclusion of negotiations between the European Union and the US on a comprehensive and mutually beneficial Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership Agreement, which you will be discussing very soon, is very important. We look forward to the European Parliament's support at the conclusion of the treaty, because the transatlantic partnership has not only an economic but also a geopolitical role. Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. Together with the European Parliament, we have also worked very other legislative initiatives that are important for Europe's competitiveness, growth and employment. We are pleased that we highlighted issues that have received less attention as a result of the economic and financial crisis, namely the sustainability and quality of jobs, income adequacy, career prospects, a secure transition from one job to another. I would like to mention in particular the promotion of youth employment here. We have reached an agreement to speed up the allocation of European Union funding to the Youth Employment Initiative. Already this year, €1 billion will be available for the initiative to support up to 650 000 young people each year. I would like to mention the new rules that will promote the interoperability and safety of European railways, to the benefit of both passengers and industry. Innovation will also facilitate and protect the agreement reached on the reform of the trade mark system. The new rules will provide better consumer protection and clearer conditions for tour operators for package travel. Also agreed in the fields of agriculture, health and other areas. I am pleased that on 25 June the European Parliament, the European Commission and the Council launched negotiations on a new institutional agreement. This is a unique opportunity for the Institutions of the European Union to improve the decision-making process. European citizens expect an effective and well-functioning European Union, and it is our common responsibility to ensure this. Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. The Latvian Presidency has been working effectively to build a competitive, digital, engaging and secure Europe. We worked with you, Martin, and members of the European Parliament. We worked in close cooperation with the Commission and Jean-Claude. I hope that our pragmatism has helped to lay solid foundations for the success of the issues during the next Presidencies. With a well-done sense of work, Latvia has transferred the council's leadership to Luxembourg. I wish them luck and success. We live in an increasingly dynamic and interconnected world. It will continue to create new opportunities and new challenges. Therefore, it is only resolutely and working together for all the European institutions that the European Union will succeed. Thank you again for your attention and also thank you for your cooperation!

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Mr President, Madam Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to pay tribute to the work of the Latvian Presidency. This was, as you said, Madam Prime Minister, the first presidency of Latvia. For a first presidency, what an experience and what a performance! Thank you on behalf of Europe! (Applause) Those who do not like Europe are unable to give compliments to those who serve it! I think you have done an exemplary job and I want to congratulate you on that. In particular, I would like to thank you for taking a number of proposals that the Commission had introduced just before the start, or during your presidency, particularly with regard to the investment plan. What a great job that has been done between the Presidency, and therefore the Council, and the European Parliament, to carry out this ambitious project in a few months. In paying tribute to you, I also pay tribute to Parliament, which has been able to respond when necessary.  Led by an ambitious presidency, the Commission has not hesitated to present a series of proposals - you have just mentioned a few - namely the energy union, the capital markets union and the digital union. All this was possible because the Commission felt carried by the ambitions of the Presidency.  I would also like to salute your negotiating skills. It is true that since the Lisbon Treaty came into force, the role of prime ministers and foreign ministers has changed somewhat. There is a permanent presidency of the Council, so the Prime Minister does not have to preside over the European Councils, the High Representative, who chairs the Council on Foreign Relations, and a permanent presidency of the Eurogroup, so the finance ministers are somewhat relieved of their work. I would have loved to have been able to live my last presidency - as Prime Minister of Luxembourg - under these conditions. I have indeed chaired the European Council, the Ecofin, the Eurogroup, and I am therefore aware of the constraints, honours and misfortunes of a presidency.  You have done so elegantly and I would like to pay tribute to your many negotiating skills and salute the exemplary and elegant work that was done by your permanent representative. We are geniuses, we prime ministers preside over, but without those who do the real work, we suck, so we must also pay tribute to the high... (Applause) I would like to pay tribute here to the Latvian civil service. She's excellent.  Tonight we will have another European Council on Greece. Ich wurde dazu gerne einige Worte - einige schnelle Worte - sagen. Ich lese in der 'berregionalen deutschen Press: "Juncker ist abgetaucht." Ich warne vor jeder Art der Vorfreude. Ich habe mich weder Sonntagabend noch gestern zum griechischen Referendum ge-u-ert. Es muss manchmal auch erlaubt sein - und dasselbe Verhalten tete einigen anderen gut, auch den Zwischenrufern -, nachzudenken, bevor man das Wort ergreift. Ich bin nicht abgetaucht. Ich rede zum ersten Mal in Sachen griechisches Referendum vor dem European Parlament. Yesterday ist der Ort der Demokratie! (Beifall) Schnelle Interviews in der Presse ersetzen keine Debatte im European Parlament. Entweder man respektiert das European Parlament, oder man gibt schnelle Interviews. Ich bin hier im Parlament, denn hier habe ich Verantwortung zu tragen, und hier habe ich Bericht zu erstatten. (Beifall) Ich mechte Folgendes sagen: Man hat - ich mechte nicht damit beginnen, aber ich beginne trotzdem damit - die Rolle der Europeischen Kommission in Sachen Griechenland in einigen Mitgliedstaaten heftigst kritisiert, vornehmlich in denen, die dieselbe Sprache sprechen wie die, die ich. Entweder mechte das Parlament eine politische Kommission haben, und dann muss diese sich auch in politicis 'u'ern derfen, oder das Parlament und andere mechten eine Kommission haben, die sich aus hohen Beamten zusammensetzt. Ich bin kein hoher Beamter, ich bin ein politischer Verantwortungstrom. (Beifall) Ich fànde es trotzdem erstaunlich, wenn sich in Sachen Griechenland und zur Zukunft der Eurozone jeder 'u'ern darf, nur nicht der President der Kommission. Ich weary mir den Mund nicht von anderen verbieten. Ich bin yesterday gew-hlt. Das Gleiche gilt - das mechte ich sofort hinzuf-gen - auch fer das Europeische Parlament und den Presidenten des Europeischen Parlaments. Der President of the European Parlaments nimmt regelm-ig an den Sitzungen das Europeischen Rates teil und tr-gt die Stimmungen und Befindlichkeiten, die Einsch-tzungen des Europ-ischen Parlaments vor, und er tut das in sehr angenehmer - wenn auch nicht immer fàr jeden angenehmer - Art und Weise. Die Vorstellung, dass der President of the European Parlaments in den Rat kommt, vortr-gt, rausgeht und den Mund h-lt, bis er wieder vorgelassen wird, ist eine hirnrissige Vorstellung. Das European Parlament ist kein Papiertiger und hat sich auch zwischen den Europ-ischen Ràten 'ber die Dinge, um die es in Europa geht, zu 'u'ern. Ich bin dem President of the European Parlaments dankbar, dass er sich sehr oft im Namen des Europeischen Parlaments - wenn auch nicht immer durch sein Mandat abgedeckt, das bin ich auch nicht immer - manchmal forsch, manchmal eindringlich, manchmal zuredend, manchmal erkl-rend in die Debatte eingemischt hat. Das European Parlament ist kein Papiertiger, und der President of the European Parlaments ist kein Bettvorleger. Er hat das zu tun, was er getan hat. (Beifall) Jetzt haben wir heute Abend einen weiteren European Rat in Sachen Griechenland - gut so! Jetzt sagt jeder: Wir messen das Votum der Griechen respektieren. Das kills ich auch. Aber ich wurde auch das Votum der griechischen Wàhler und Wàhlerinnen, der Bàrgerinnen gerne verstehen. Man hat dem griechischen Volk eine Frage vorgelegt, die sich nicht stellt, weil man zu einem Votum einen Textvorschlag ... (Zwischenruf: No is the answer!) Ich konnte Sie jetzt mal fragen, mir im Detail zu erklàren, welche Frage eigentlich vorgelegt wurde. Aber so weit mechte ich den Spao yesterday nicht treiben. (Zwischenrufe) Ja, Ja. Ich gehe davon aus. Dass die jetzt ihr Màtchen abgek-hlt haben, und dann kunnen wir in der Debatte weitermachen.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen! You can certainly make heckling. But you cannot take the floor on your own. We have nothing against your heckling. Above all, we have been missing you, Mr Coburn, for a few weeks now. Mr Juncker, you can now continue.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Mr President of the Commission. I don't like to be interrupted. But sometimes I like to be interrupted by those who interrupt me all the time. I really like that. I wanted to say that we need to have a hard conversation about what it means to respect the greek vote. That is why the question of what the Greeks said 'no' to is important. The majority of the Greek people said 'no' to a text proposal from the three institutions, which was long outdated when it was put to the vote. I was in intensive negotiations with the Greek Government and the Greek Prime Minister until Thursday last week, and the Greek Prime Minister is well aware that what was put to the Greek people to vote was not up to date. In this respect, I will be asking the Greek Prime Minister this evening – and I have already done so tonight – to present me with a statement on the Greek vote. After all, the question on which the vote was taken no longer arises, and everyone in charge of the negotiation process knows that. Now, however, it is not so much a matter of right-handedness. We have to put our little ego and also my big ego between brackets and now deal with the situation we find. The situation is that I am still thinking – and I will think so until the end of the days: my petitum is, my will is to prevent a Grexit. I am against a Grexit! (Applause) There are some in the European Union who are openly or hiddenly pushing for Greece to leave the eurozone. I have a life experience. The life experience is that the simple answers are usually the wrong answers. I am against simple answers. There are no easy answers in Europe. Europe is the constant struggle for compromise solutions, and that is also the task that the European Commission has set itself. We continue to take on this task. I would like Greece, this great Greek nation, not to have the impression that we want to throw them and, with it, the Greeks out of the European monetary union or the European Union. No one should want to throw out the Greeks! (Applause) Because that is the case, the European Commission will endeavour to restart negotiations with Greece. What kind of European Union would this be in which people suddenly stop talking to each other? If the European nations stop talking to each other, then we are heading towards the end of the European Union. I believe that the hour has now come for those who sit down at the table again with reason and reason, even with their hearts and souls from time to time, because without feelings it is not possible. I very much regretted the fact that the Greek delegation has left the negotiating table. This is not what we are doing in Europe! In Europe, negotiations take place until the last millisecond. The Greek Government did not do that, and that was a serious mistake.  (Applause) It is a European matter of course that we are now reunited around the table, and we must try to find a solution. This solution will not be possible today. And if there were a solution today, it would again be too simple a solution. Today, however, we will pave the way for us to put things right in a common dialogue and in mutual understanding and also in mutual tolerance. This also means that rhetorical rearmament must be put to a rapid, abrupt end. I do not accept – and I say this here in the place of European democracy – that the representatives of the institutions – and I do not accept this at all for the Commission and its President – are being called terrorists by the Greek government. This is not a way of dealing with it in Europe!  (Applause) Everyone has made a fair effort, the Commission more than others. If everyone had worked as hard as the Commission and its President, we would not be in the position we are in now. So we will meet again tonight and we will try to get things going in negotiations without rhetorical noise in such a way that we can reach an amicable solution. In any case, the European Commission, with all due respect for what the Greeks have said, wants to know what this vote means. It is not a 'no' to Europe, I am told. It is not a 'no' to the euro, I am told. It cannot be a 'no' to the proposals made by the institutions, because they were no longer on the table. So I would like a vote from the Greek Prime Minister. The ball is clearly in the Greek government's camp. The The Greek Government must explain today in Brussels how it intends to make progress in this situation. In any case, the European Commission and its President are prepared to do everything possible to ensure that we reach an agreement at intervals that are acceptable. The Greeks and Europeans can rely on the European Commission! (Applause)

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for his excellent work and for his excellent work. I would like to begin by thanking the Presidency for the work that has been done.  Roaming, data protection, energy, the Eastern Partnership and, above all, the Investment Pact that has been adopted: a proud track record that has been presented. Congratulations and also personally to Prime Minister Straujuma a heartfelt thank you for the clear course, for the firm hand, but also for the human way. The first three rows also show what modern government we have in Latvia: they are only women in the first three rows. Congratulations on this modern presidency! Yes, Mrs Harms, we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats also have 50% women in the Bureau. So congratulations, that's a great record. We must apologise for talking a lot about Greece today. But you will certainly understand this, and we can build a bridge, namely the bridge that Latvia has also had difficult times: a few years ago, a 14% fall in gross domestic product. Latvia had the courage to change, had the courage to leave, including cuts in the state budget, and massive cuts in the state budget. Today, Latvia contributes to European growth with 2% growth. They're back. That is why the first thing I want to say is that we can call it austerity or whatever you want to call it. But if Europe is unwilling to reform internally, if we are not able to put our national budgets in order, then this continent will not have a good future, and Latvia is a good example of how to get it right. Secondly, I would like to take up the debate on democracy that we now have. What did we learn on Sunday? 61% of Greeks oppose further cuts. Is that so surprising? What if we vote in Finland? When the people of Finland say: we are no longer prepared to provide our tax money for the rescue of Greece or other states in Europe? Is this a bad democracy, because they are evil and do not want to provide money? What have we learned? We have learned that there are national perspectives. Yes, but that does not help us in Europe.  Europe is the idea of going to the table and seeking compromises with each other. That is the idea: not provoked, not confrontational, but seeking compromises with each other. That is why Sunday was not a good day for Europe. A day when Europe has also suffered. This is demonstrated very strongly by the applause we then heard through the press releases from the right and the left: once again the extremists united in great unity, because it is against Europe. Ladies and gentlemen, there was a debate that this was an unfair deal. I would like to thank our President of the Commission because, in the many hours during which he negotiated with Tsipras and with the Greek representatives, he worked out a fair deal. There were no more pension cuts. There was a proposal to cut back on the military. There was an offer of a 35 billion investment package in the economy of Greece, in the future of Greece, for growth. The Greek Government has recklessly rejected this. So yes, it was a fair deal that was on the table. I say on behalf of my group that we do not have any imagination at the moment as to how we should go beyond these proposals, which were already on the table. We lack the imagination to put even more far-reaching proposals on the table now. Syriza's game is high-risk. We have found Greece in a difficult situation. Greece had made many cuts, had an economic downturn, which was certainly a heavy burden on the country, but in the last five months, unfortunately, the division has continued. The supply of medicines is on the table, the banks are closed, Greece is in a very difficult situation. Syriza, including Tsipras, is partly responsible for this.  Ladies and gentlemen, if we look at Greece today, it is a divided country. That is the record of a government policy of Tsipras and Syriza – not a good record for Greece. Last but not least, I would like to say that Europe, as we all know, is based on values, but it is also based on rules. Both aspects are important. The values are democracy and solidarity, and I believe that Europe is the benchmark in the world there. On the other hand, however, Europe also means respecting rules and laws. Respecting agreements, complying with agreed treaties: that too is Europe. We hope that we will be able to return in the next few years to this principle that rules must also apply.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Latvian Presidency must be given the opportunity to acknowledge that it has moved with good will, competence and gentlemanliness. Important results have been achieved and I am thinking in particular of the approval of the investment plan and the roaming measures. But at this time, there is no denying the feeling of concern that emerges in many citizens. Too many European summits have been successfully resolved; on immigration, the Commission presented an ambitious programme, but it was the Council that tried to distort it; the Member States, all of us, must assume our responsibilities to the full. Never before has Europe been faced with a decisive step. Nor do I believe that there is an alternative to the agreement between Greece and its creditors. Nor do I want to consider a lack of understanding, because not reaching an agreement would open the door to a disastrous scenario that would threaten not only the financial stability of the euro area, but also the future of Europe. I therefore fully share the position of Mr Juncker, whom I thank for his constructive commitment, and I say that we must use every second, to the last, to reach an agreement with the creditors. The result of the Greek vote, for me and for us Socialists and Democrats, is clear: the Greeks do not want to leave the euro. They want to negotiate an agreement that allows them to build a prospect of a dignified life. Governments, all the governments of the euro area, must listen to this message and make an effort to overcome the rigidities because the stakes are too high. To that Finance Minister who said yesterday that Grexit is the only option on the pitch, I say: be ware, we will oppose those who play in the wreck, the sorcerer's apprentices who play with the future of Europe. I say to Tsipras and his government that it is important that they make common sense proposals at the summit today. This is the time of responsibility for all. And the accusations made by a former Greek minister against creditors, calling them terrorists, are unacceptable.  It is very significant that all Greek parties have signed a unitary document to support the reasons for the agreement. On the basis of a new constructive approach, this evening's summit may pave the way for a bridge loan that will allow Greek citizens to breathe and create the conditions for long-term intervention by the State Rescue Fund. In the next few hours, we must avoid a banking panic: the Greek credit system must be put in a position to continue working. Dear President Schulz, dear Mr Juncker, dear President-in-Office of the Council, this is the time for action and solutions. I would like to remind all of us that a possible Greek exit from the eurozone would probably be a point of no return. Against the risk of disintegration, we need a jolt of pride and responsibility on the part of all to save Europe.

name: Roberts Zīle
text: ECR grupas vārdā. – Cienījamā premjerministres kundze, Komisijas prezident! Man ir uzticēts gods manas grupas vārdā pateikties Latvijas premjerministrei par lielisko darbu, un Vēbera kungs man īstenībā izņēma vārdus tieši no mutes, ka pirmajās trīs rindās šeit ir sievietes. Šī prezidentūra bija sekmīga tieši tāpēc, ka Latvijā, kā jūs redzat, pastāv dzimumu nevienlīdzība, un tāpēc šis panākums ir tāds, kāds viņš arī ir. Es gribētu teikt arī, ka mana kolēģe ļoti daudz teica labus vārdus par kultūras programmu un daudziem citiem pavisam tehniskiem un svarīgiem jautājumiem, kas parādīja, ka zeme, kura ir arī mana zeme un kurai ir šīs skaistās karoga krāsas, faktiski ir ļoti, ļoti būtiska Eiropas daudzveidībai. The Latvian Presidency has achieved significant progress in a number of aspects of the single market, which of course is a crucial political flagship for the ECR Group, like the Telecommunications Package, which can move forward the whole digital agenda. It is the same for data protection issues and also in other fields of the single market, like the Railway Package in the transport sector, and moves towards the Energy Union. So these achievements are moving Europe in a new direction, although the EFSI stands a little aside from this. Why? In my opinion, if Mr Juncker promises to do something in the six months, then it will be done, whichever Presidency it is, or it would be no Presidency at all. At the same time, I think the Juncker plan brings us new challenges. To be honest, I would not want to experience so-called ‘geographical neutrality’ towards investment turning into a ‘geographical concentration’ of projects in high—return places. But the real priority – and the milestone – of the Latvian Presidency was the Eastern Partnership Summit. Did it really deliver? Ukrainians and Georgians, who chose a risky way to move to a Western future, are disappointed. They feel left in the other sphere of influence. We have to admit that, if the majority of Europeans are not ready to have a heightened confrontation with Russia, then perhaps we have to choose slightly different priorities if we cannot help those new democracies like Ukraine and Georgia. Ending with the Greek deal, I agree that this has to be complex. It is not a simple idea, as the President of the Commission has said. But for Latvians, after the austerity programme, it is very important that it should be a fair deal.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, what Mr Juncker said is completely true. Let us keep a cool head and go back to common sense, because the number of irresponsible voices I have heard over the past two or three days about the Greek crisis is enormous. People are talking about a Grexit like it is nothing, whereas in reality we are not talking about Greece: we are talking about the possibility of having a healthy monetary union and of being capable, as a monetary union, of solving a problem like this. We are talking about a historic debt of EUR 300 billion – and that is in a monetary union with a gross domestic product of EUR 15 trillion. Nobody outside the European Union understands why we are not capable of managing it. That is the reality today, and so I fully support you. Let us get back to common sense and not start in different ways. There is also the International Monetary Fund, which first of all made a deal round the table and then two days later published a document saying that the deal is not sustainable. How responsible is that? I think, Mr Juncker, that we have to come up with a new approach. We have to recognise that the way we have been dealing with the Greek crisis up until now has not worked. A new approach – and this something that has been said by most of the political leaders in Europe – to me means that Mr Tsipras has to come forward with a credible, real reform package. This cannot just be a number of accounting measures such as we have on the table today, but rather it has to be real in-depth reform. That means ending the clientelistic system – there is nothing in the seven pages today – as well as ending the corruption in the country and downsizing the public sector. It is an enormous public sector, with 800 000 civil servants for the moment. The public banks must finally be broken up, and there must be a private financing sector. The markets must be opened up, and so on. That is the first thing. Let him come now. He has to deliver. He has run away from the negotiating table. Secondly, let us try to manage the debt in Europe together. If we had created a redemption fund a few years ago – and your idea of eurobonds – we would not have the problems we face today, and we would have a real instrument to govern this crisis. Finally, let us also prepare – because you never know what may happen – to help the Greeks. If we do not help the Greek Government, then at least the Commission should prepare a number of emergency programmes to directly help Greek citizens and Greek families if it is necessary in the coming weeks and coming months. Good luck for this evening.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report and for the In fact, I am very curious to see how Mr Tsipras represents Greece tonight.  But I think that is a great challenge to represent the 'no' and the 'yes' vote. After all, his first task is to reunite his country. Only a united Greece will be able to negotiate successfully in Brussels. I share much of the appeals to Mr Tsipras that have come in recent days. Today, however, I must also say that there are appeals to Angela Merkel in Germany, which I do not share at all.  That is why I think the tone that Jean-Claude Juncker has struck here is very good. If the Bild newspaper demands today that what we need is the iron chancellor, then I can only say: please do not! Then I would like the Germans to remember that if we had met iron European neighbours – again and again – we would not be this European nation, this Germany, which has a very special responsibility. Mr Juncker, I think the two issues are clear. It is the reforms on the one hand, which, incidentally, are also addressed in the IMF paper. The IMF paper does not only talk about the unsustainable debt situation. The IMF paper clearly calls for social reforms in Greece. On the other hand, the debt to Greece must be made sustainable. Madam President, I was so enthusiastic about your country because it is a country still under construction, with great problems, but with an incredible amount of European spirit. I would sometimes like these young Latvians, the young Baltics and the young Greeks to come to an understanding about what European democracy is, rather than drifting apart.  I believe that it is precisely the small countries and the new countries that must play a key role in this whole debate. I thank you for your Presidency and wish your country and Europe luck.

name: Paul Nuttall
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Madam Prime Minister said that the Latvian Presidency was a job well done. I cannot believe what I am hearing: this is Alice-through-the-looking-glass stuff. I could, as we say in England, gild the lily like all the rest of you, but I am from the north of England and we are quite famous for straight—talking and telling it how it is. So I will. The Latvian Presidency has been an unmitigated, unrivalled disaster. Let us just look at what has happened: Vladimir Putin continues to lead the European Union in a merry dance in Ukraine and there seems to be no let-up whatsoever. We have 500 000 migrants in the Mediterranean and another 500 000 waiting to come. Indeed, Eurojust admitted last night that ISIS are sending over jihadists onto our continent by boat. Finally, we have Greece, a country which could well leave the Euro. This has all happened on your watch, Madam Prime Minister: it is not a very good result, is it? In fact, I would go so far as to say that at least Nero fiddled while Rome burned, but you have done absolutely nothing while we watched the EU project fall to pieces. Finally, as a Eurosceptic, I would like to see Latvia extend their Presidency by another six months, because another half-a-year of this could see the whole EU fall to bits.

name: Gianluca Buonanno
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wish the outgoing Presidency well, but having three women does not mean that everything is going well: it is a bit of hypocrisy. There are good women and there are less good women; there are good men and there are less good men. It is not said that three women are better than three men. So, let's leave hypocrisy alone. As far as Mr Juncker is concerned, I see him here for the first time and I can talk to him and ask him questions. The first is, do you know how much a litre of milk costs? A pound of bread? A liter of gasoline? Because you always talk about big things, big figures, you're in the middle of banks, you're talking to multinationals, you've always lived with them: but people, people have more to do, they need more answers! So let me give you an example: this is the flag of Germany; this is the flag of Europe; I do not want to die a German: either There is Europe or there is Germany! Otherwise, if we go on like this, Europe becomes small, but Germany must also become small. We must make it smaller: it cannot claim to command Europe, because there was already one who wanted to take Europe with Nazism. We do not want economic Nazism now and therefore, in my opinion, we need to change the register a little.  And again, Mr Juncker, I wanted to ask you: where has the EUR 300 billion in investment gone? Or, there are two cards: this is the euro card and this is toilet paper. In my opinion, this is more important in Europe today, thanks to your work, because you are having Europe go to waste; you are not doing what interests the people and, therefore, you would be the first to resign. You should resign and apologise to Greece for what it has done and apologise to the whole of Europe, because you are sending it to collapse economically! People commit suicide, we are facing an economic disaster, there are illegal immigrants... and then what more do we want? The Martians?

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I am a representative of one of the second-tier countries of the European Union, one of the peripheral countries, and I therefore had great expectations for the Latvian Presidency. I had an interesting observation at this debate today that the colleague representing the Latvian Presidency speaks in exactly the same voice as Mr Juncker. Fortunately for us, he has not slapred anyone today, but he continues to press his mobile phone the whole time, so Juncker from the lucky Western country of Luxembourg, a wealthy country, and then I have noticed that other mainstream politicians are politicians from the lucky first-class EU Member States in the West. In this language, total alienation from the real problem of real people is common. You, as The Latvian Presidency, would have had a duty to account here for all the suffering and misery that is particularly affecting peripheral countries, former communist countries and southern states! You have not brought anything here, why you are fleeing your own country as economic refugees, from your country, from my country, but also from the much-talked about Greece today! What's going on, please? How long will there be a first-class and second-class Member State? You, as the Latvian Presidency, should have been talking about this emphatically, because that is what your own citizens and the citizens of my country would have expected.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Mr President, Madam Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to say at the end of this debate that those who, for no reason, insult the Latvian Presidency are wrong. The Latvian Presidency has done an excellent job, and I am falsely against these stupid, unfounded and unjustified attacks. This is a country that... (Applause) Let us now return to the subject we are dealing with today, namely Greece.  I would like to reiterate the Commission's willingness to do everything in its way to reaching an agreement. Let us not forget that the euro area consists not of a single democracy, but of nineteen democracies, that we must also look after the interests of the whole area and respect the wishes expressed by the other eighteen democracies. One democracy is worth no more than another. A citizen is a citizen. (Applause) Finally, stop this chatter about the fact that I sometimes look at my phone. I'm texting, as they say in English, with the Greek Prime Minister. I do not know if you have the opportunity to do the same, but I have to do that today. I'm doing my job. So stop this stupid chatter that has no reason to be. Moreover, to give the Commission and Europe the image that we would be there in our gilded lounges, that we would not look closely at the living conditions of our citizens is absurdity, of basic populism, of unhealthy demagoguery. I talk to Greek citizens every week. I am not only speaking to the Greek government and the Greek political parties, I am talking to Greek citizens and I am among those who have been most concerned with the living and working conditions of the citizens of Greece. Therefore, do not give the impression that we would be far from these citizens or those of other countries. To deal very closely with the daily reality of Greek citizens, I do not forget the daily reality of many others. There is unemployment all over Europe. There is poverty all over Europe. There are minimum social wages below the Greek minimum social wage. There are living standards below the Greek standard of living and many other Member States are also crossing poverty line. We must therefore see the whole reality and not indulge in the pleasure of some demagogic remarks. Will not wallow in this kind of populism and demagoguery. Let us do everything to help the Greek citizens, many of whom live in poverty, but let us not forget the others. We are here to serve and Greece and Europe. Let us not forget Greece, but let us not forget the rest of Europe. (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr De Masi, I would like to thank Mr De Masi for his excellent You have to put your sign around correctly, otherwise it will be called IXO. (Laughter) (Interruption) Mrs Straujuma, before I give you the floor again, I would like to say, on behalf of what I believe is an overwhelming majority of this House, that we thank you for the tremendous personal commitment you have made during your Presidency. I say this to you on behalf of our institution, because it is certainly a very big challenge for small countries to lead the presidency of the Union. I would like to say to you that the way in which you have conducted it has been exemplary. Thank you very much for that! (Applause)

name: Laimdota Straujuma
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. I had the pleasure of discussing here the contribution of our Presidency. At the same time, I am very well aware that Greece is the key issue today, and Greece has taken over all our minds, and it is undeniable that the situation in Greece has affected the European agenda. As a Presidency, we have supported targeted efforts to achieve a positive outcome for the euro area and Greece negotiations. Today, the finance ministers of the euro area meet a short time later. I, too, will go straight from the European Parliament to Brussels to take part in the extraordinary Eurosam summit and, as Jean-Claude said, we will all look forward to Greece's proposals and vision of the common path between Greece and the European Union. Remembering the latvian crisis management path, the main thing is the common will of each country and its people to organize their country. And time, repeat again— and time! Every moment of uncertainty brings additional losses. And that is why I very much hope that greece's new finance minister and the Greek Prime Minister will bring us really constructive proposals. Finally, I would like to thank the European Parliament and the European Commission once again. Together, we have managed to find solutions to key items on the European Union's agenda. And I sincerely hope that Europe became more familiar with the small Nordic country Latvia during this semester, our traditions and culture, our working capacity and perseverance. Thank you again and goodbye to the next time!

name: Εμμανουήλ Γλέζος (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, "First of all, I would like to say falsely, stranger, / asking for a tyrant's death: for he does not come to a man, but a free city. Both of these texts are my answer to both the Latvian mandate and the whole of Parliament and to you personally, Dear President. (applause)

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I welcome the Latvian Presidency of the Council of the European Union. Latvia, which is not a great Member State of the European Union, has provided an active, professional and individualised service to the Presidency of the Council. I have clearly seen the Eastern European theme and interest in central and eastern Europe. I particularly welcome initiatives highlighting transatlantic cooperation. Such a strong accent was the Transatlantic Legislators' Dialogue (TLD) meeting in Riga at the end of the semester. I hope that these emphasises will also continue during the next Presidency under the close group cooperation of the Italy-Latvia-Luxembourg Troika.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. – I would like to congratulate the Latvian presidency for reaching the agreement with the EP on the European fund for strategic investments (EFSI), enabling new investments to begin already this summer, and helping to boost economic growth. I am pleased, together with my colleagues that it managed to reach a general approach on the data protection regulation, as well as provisional agreement with the Parliament on abolishing roaming and open internet access. Moreover, it also managed to agree with the Parliament on the main principles for the directive on network and information security (NIS). Finally, I believe that a key highlight of Latvia’s presidency, in view of the country’s position, was the Eastern Partnership summit in May, where the EU met with its Eastern counterparts. Latvia can be proud of the way it has handled its work and the progress it has made on many fronts.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa Latvia, taking over the six-month rotating presidency from Italy, had a real challenge ahead of it. From 1 January, after the slogan "A competitive, digital, committed Europe", it has had to deal with the deepening conflict in Ukraine, the financial crisis in Greece and the increasing migration of people in the Mediterranean.  These priority events may have distracted from stimulating economic growth in the Eu countries, but this has not happened. During the six-month Presidency, nearly 1,500 meetings were held at various levels in Brussels and Luxembourg and around 200 meetings in Latvia aimed at increasing the competitiveness of the EU economy. The strengthening of the EU single market, in particular the EU's digital and telecommunications market, has been successful in reaching a deadline for the official abolition of roaming charges.  In the framework of energy policy, the Latvian Presidency has started work on the concept of creating a European Energy Union. I myself, as the EP's main rapporteur in the negotiations on the so-called small claims procedure and the trade mark package, rate our cooperation as fair and efficient. It was the first time that a country with the Presidency of the Council of the EU had been negotiated among the Member States on so many important topics. In my 11 years of observing other Presidencies from the perspective of a Member of the European Parliament, I can safely consider this to be a success and congratulate the work that has been done.

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE)
text: in writing. – Today the Latvian Prime Minister concludes the country’s first Presidency of the EU Council. Over the past six months, many priorities have been in the spotlight: the European Fund for Strategic Investments, energy policy, the Data Protection Regulation, the Eastern Partnership, roaming charges, immigration issues. Also developments in Ukraine and Russia, terrorism, and the financial crisis in Greece. The Latvian Presidency has proven to be highly efficient and pragmatic. During the past months, they have concluded very difficult negotiations on Juncker’s investment package, the Market Stability Reserve, ILUC (Indirect Land Use Change) and the Telecoms Single Market Regulation. This would not have been possible without the dedicated, well prepared and professional approach of the Latvian Presidency. It has been a very valuable experience for Latvia. I am proud of my country and its people for such a successful performance.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. – Latvia is a country that serves as the best example of how to recover from deep economic crisis, pursue responsible fiscal and economic policies, and pay back debts in time. They have shown that with political will and people’s reason and trust, one can go from deepest recession to highest economic growth. And they have behaved as responsibly and reasonably also during the last six months. I am very pleased to see the successes of the Latvian EU Presidency. Having had to adapt to terrorist attacks and ever growing security concerns in the EU close neighbourhood, Latvia did not lose the grip on what had to be done in the EU. In the very last days of the presidency they achieved agreements on ending the roaming fees by 2017 and an important breakthrough on the Network and Information Society Directive that will serve as a basis for protecting our critical information systems and infrastructures. An agreement on Strategic Investment Funds was on the table in record time. Also, a long desired agreement on a Data Protection Directive was agreed on. The Energy Union and Digital Single Market are on the track. In my view Latvia has lived up to the expectation of a small and efficient Member State bringing steady progress into many processes.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. – Today we take stock of the Latvian Presidency, which officially began on 1 January 2015 and ended on 30 June 2015. I would just like to dwell on the three main priorities of the outgoing Presidency, as expressed by Prime Minister Straujuma. I believe that the Latvian Presidency has failed to advance the objectives of both the famously competitive Europe and the Digital Europe. Furthermore, the Union's presence on the international stage falls short of the important ambitions of the peoples of Europe for an EU of peace and international cooperation. Also, in relation to Greece, the Latvian Presidency followed the beaten button of the memorial policies that turned my country into a social cemetery, with armies of unemployed people, with thousands of shops closed, with youth unemployment hitting red. A monument to failure, then, by the Latvian Presidency, deservedly taking the baton from the equally failed Greek Presidency.

name: David McAllister (PPE)
text: in writing. –  Members of the European Parliament and United States Congress held their 76th Inter-Parliamentary Meeting of the Transatlantic Legislators’ Dialogue in Riga on 27 and 28 June. We discussed ways to deepen and strengthen our relationship, and in particular to increase readiness to jointly address the diverse set of global security, economic and environmental challenges that the nations currently face.  We exchanged views in three working sessions:  1. Achieving growth and jobs through trade. It was highlighted that TTIP should be an ambitious, balanced and comprehensive agreement. Ambitious approaches on public market access for defined services, mutual recognition of professional qualifications and mobility for professionals and individuals between the nations were discussed. Furthermore, the importance of energy issues was upheld in the negotiations.  2. Cooperating for energy security. Major global challenges to energy security were discussed. The tremendous potential of the United States in this case was highlighted, whilst European energy security was regarded as a solid framework for cooperation amongst Member States.  3. Reinforcing security and defence cooperation. It was reaffirmed that the key is a strategic partnership. Intensifying our cooperation on foreign and security policy in recent times was appreciated.

name: Marek Plura (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa I would like to thank the Latvian Presidency for its commitment to the development of a sustainable and inclusive European labour market. I would particularly like to emphasise the Presidency's work to improve the situation of young people and people with disabilities. I congratulate the Presidency on the well-prepared high-level meeting and conference on disability held in Riga in May. I am convinced that the conclusions of this meeting will have a significant impact on the future implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and thus contribute to improving the situation of this group of EU citizens.  I hope that the Luxembourg Presidency will continue to work equally to enable people with disabilities to fully realise their potential and exercise their civil rights.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. – From the beginning of the parliamentary term, I have referred to the urgency of following up the regulations on fisheries in the deep sea of the international waters of the North-East Atlantic. This document was proposed by the European Commission in 2012, was adopted in plenary in the previous parliamentary term and since then there has been no progress in the trilogue that should have been followed. The Latvian Presidency is now over and I note that, once again, there has been no progress. I therefore must once again emphasize the importance of this regulation in reducing the pressure of deep-sea trawls on sensitive cold coral populations. Coral-structured habitats are crucial for maintaining marine biodiversity and provide ecological services relevant to fish sources. For the sustainable exploitation of marine biological resources and the conservation of species and habitats in the North-East Atlantic, this regulation is urgently needed.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – A number of achievements have been highlighted by the Representative of the Latvian Presidency and we have heard many words of praise for the last six months. I would now like to highlight one element that is unsustainable to me: the issue of the derecing of roaming charges. Back in 2013, the European Commission foresked the introduction of roaming charges, which was adopted by a large majority in the European Parliament last year. This would have led to the elimination of roaming charges at the end of this year, but the European Council, which is the member state's government, torpedoed the decision with the assistance of the Latvian Presidency and ultimately pushed for a sliding, gradual phase-out as a compromise solution. It is certainly to be welcomed that, at the end of the negotiations between the Latvian Presidency and the European Parliament, an agreement was reached on the final abolition of roaming charges, but as a Social Democrat it is impermissible that national governments (including the Orban government, which professed to be an unorthodox overhead reducer) would have given in to the influential lobby of influential countries rather than fully sided with European consumers. As a European Democrat, I can only wholeheartedly support a decision that reduces people's burdens as quickly and meaningfully as possible, while at the same time making Europe competitive in a time of digital world revolution. And this is only part of it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Laimdota Straujuma presented in January this year her priorities of the Latvian Presidency of the Council of the EU. In addition to the usual vain words about "defending European values", he highlighted the recording of passenger data as one of the Presidency's priorities. It also stressed the need to continue to support economic growth as well as the implementation of the digital single market. At the end of the semester, it is clear that the balance sheet to be taken is deeply scarce. And it is scarce because it persists in the same recessive policies and in the same so-called market-oriented solutions. In this way, we will continue to do so, because what Europe needs is investment, and if the private sector is not in a position to do so, let the Member States do so, and it is a pity that we will continue in recession for many more years.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Bernd Lange's report on behalf of the Committee on International Trade with the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) (2014/2228(INI) (A8-0175/2015).

name: Bernd Lange
text: Rapporteur. Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. If you look around the global economy, you have to say that we are very similar in a process of globalisation and that our companies, our workers, are in global value chains.  Shaping this process is our democratic task here in the European Parliament: to set standards and rules, to respect the interests of workers and citizens. This is different from previous classic trade agreements, it was just about tariffs. Now it is indeed a question of standards, of rules, and that is why, ladies and gentlemen, a basic requirement for setting standards and rules is that the most fundamental transparency is possible in the negotiations, otherwise we will not be able to play a serious part in shaping them. This is a central demand in the resolution: to be as transparent as possible and also to involve civil society in the context of the discussion. Because it is not about tariffs, it is about sensitive important things.  That is why we are also making a resolution, because I do believe that this is the time of the parliaments and not just of the negotiators, but that we decide what – for us – are principles for standard-setting and rule-setting. If you look at the resolution, it becomes very clear. We want to make it clear that trade agreements must ensure principles of data protection, that our values of data protection must be safeguarded in trade agreements and in the actions of companies. We want to make it clear that our tradition of services of general interest – service in general, in the economic interest – has nothing to do with trade agreements. It is our regional responsibility, for example, how water supply is organised.  We want to make it clear that the issue of services only has to be entered in a trade agreement if it is described positively, that is to say, it starts with positive lists. We want to make it clear that the right of legislation, the right to regulate by no regulatory committees or anything else, or by private arbitration courts, can be called into question. So a clear set of rules for a trade agreement. In particular, it is a question of putting workers in reasonable conditions so that we have fair competition in trade, based on quality and efficiency, and not on social dumping and environmental dumping. That is why you find a strong chapter in the resolution on safeguarding workers' rights. Ladies and gentlemen, I am not sure that we will eventually achieve this. It can also fail, and we must always be aware of this. We will decide on an agreement at the end of the day. But those who do not argue, who do not start, have already lost. If you fight, you can lose. But if you don't do anything, you've already lost. That is why let us argue for a good agreement.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, TTIP is a broad negotiation. It covers traditional trade issues but also many other issues, from medical devices regulation and financial services to sustainable development. To get it right, we need the engagement of the whole of this Parliament, and this resolution is proving that engagement. The fact that 14 committees in addition to the Committee on International Trade were all active, proves that Members are very engaged in this and has enabled the whole Parliament to take part in discussions, in deliberations and in getting to know all the details of this agreement. When President Juncker came here to present the agenda for his Commission last July, he made clear that TTIP was one of his core priorities, and this House at that time voted very strongly for his agenda. Why? Because TTIP is an essential part of the Commission’s strategy to open markets around the world. We are doing that not to benefit a small few, but in order to create opportunities for the whole of Europe: the people of Europe, the consumers of Europe, the entrepreneurs of Europe. One in seven people in Europe have a job thanks to exports around the world. Those jobs are highly skilled and better paid than average. 4.7 million of those jobs are linked to exports to the US. TTIP would help increase that number. It would also make goods cheaper and more varied for consumers, and it would help to make our small and medium-sized companies more competitive. They would find it easier to export and to get their imported components and raw materials more cheaply. Those are solid economic advantages. We cannot afford to turn our backs on them now or in the future. Second, TTIP is also a strategic alliance with the country that most closely shares Europe’s commitment to core values and to a high level of protection of people and of the environment in our regulation. We need an ally like this to shape the globalisation we see deepening before our eyes every day. We are more affected by economic and political decisions made in other countries than ever before. We particularly need an ally, because we know that the strength of our voice in the world is, in relative terms, decreasing. TTIP guarantees that partnership with America for the future, and we cannot afford to turn our backs on that either. There is, honourable Members, as you know, an unprecedented debate about this agreement. That is a good thing. I respect people who have doubts and questions, across the continent and within this House. I take those concerns very seriously and have engaged a lot with national parliaments, with this Parliament, with NGOs, with civil society and other stakeholders to listen and to try to understand their concerns. I hope that all these people see the changes that we have made in order to take account of their views. Since last November, I have opened up these negotiations to unprecedented public scrutiny. I have put EU negotiating proposals on the internet and increased the access of Members of this Parliament and representatives of the Member States to the process. I have visited 14 national parliaments so far to exchange and open channels. I am happy to say that TTIP is the world’s most transparent bilateral free trade negotiation. We have also made clear where we stand on public services such as public health and water concessions. This is a concern I have heard very frequently. I have, together with Ambassador Froman, the US Trade Representative, made a joint statement: the EU and the US are fully united around a crystal-clear vision that nothing in TTIP will change the fact that only Member States choose how their public services should be organised. We have also made it very clear where we stand on regulation. I have put the proposal on cooperating with the US online, and it says that there will be no limitations on the power of this Parliament or any national parliament or of European governments. We want the benefits of shared expertise and we want opportunities for our people. That is all. I have made proposals for a deep reform of investment protection. The result is a completely new approach. We still want to foster job-creating investment but we are proposing a new system that sets down the right to regulate in black and white: a new system that takes us away from the private arbitration tribunals of the past. Instead, we want a future in which disputes are decided in an international investment court, by judges and with a right of appeal. TTIP will be a step towards that goal, not the final result. It is an essential step, given the role of the US as a global investor. Parliament’s resolution is a vital step in those negotiations, but it is certainly not the end of our conversation. The Commission will continue to be flexible and to take account of Members’ views. Beyond investment, we also have important proposals to discuss how best to protect labour and environmental rights and digital commerce. There will be many more issues to debate over the course of these talks, which are far from over. These negotiations are far reaching, and a lot of work is still needed. I will continue to push the US on our offensive interests, including on public procurement, where we expect an ambitious proposal, but also on services, energy and geographical indications, to mention just a few examples. Parliament’s resolution will provide a vital basis for that conversation. It will also be vital for the negotiations themselves. Having Parliament’s priorities so clearly established helps the Commission explain why we need to tackle them in the final agreement. So allow me to thank you for the work done, to look forward to the debate that we are about to have, and to pledge my full cooperation with Parliament as we jointly push for the results that Europeans need: a TTIP that leads to jobs, growth and investment while protecting our values and our democracies.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon
text: Drafts member of the Opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Mr President, the TTE negotiations are being held at a crucial moment from a foreign policy perspective. The United States pays increasing political and military attention to the Asia-Pacific region, while negotiating the partnership agreement with eleven countries in the region. The ATCI will rebalance this situation. It will be an anchor of our relations with the United States in the face of its drift to the Pacific. It is therefore of high political importance, beyond its economic and commercial dimension. The challenges we face in our Eastern and Mediterranean neighborhoods are another additional reason to now strengthen our ties with the United States, our natural ally. On the other hand, since the European and AMERICAN economies still occupy an important place in the world, TSC rules will have a good chance of projecting globally, of becoming global. If we do not do them now, it will be the so-called emerging powers that will soon develop them, according to their values and interests. But TTE should not be an end point. In the future, we must conclude with the United States a political agreement, which strengthens our ties and establishes much-needed bilateral consultation and concertation frameworks in the context of a globalized, multipolar and very complex world.

name: Arne Lietz
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. Thank you very much, Mr President. As called for in my opinion in the Committee on Development on TTIP, I highlight three important aspects. The first is workers' rights and good work, which is enshrined in the eight ILO core labour standards. Enforcing and ratifying the TTIP agreement, as well as other trade agreements, is the key to good work around the world. The second aspect is the principle of policy coherence for development. This must also be enshrined in the TTIP, because trade and development cannot be separated.  A third aspect is Commissioner Malmström's announcement to present an analysis of the impact of TTIP on developing countries and on future sustainable development goals. This is to be produced by an independent institution and to make complex connections comprehensible. There is still far too little information on this. The Commission must deliver on this, as was called for by a large majority of the opinion on a non-partisan way. I would also like to thank Bernd Lange and his team for the hard work they have done on this resolution. Thank you very much.

name: Jeppe Kofod
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. – Mr President, in the debate it sounds way too often like TTIP is an end in itself, but that is absolutely not the case. I think the world’s biggest trade and investment partnership should be a means, a tool to ensure jobs and prosperity for all Europeans and Americans. But fundamentally, it is also a unique opportunity for the EU and US – the dominant forces of the western world – to ensure that trade and investment rules are based on our democratic values and control in a situation of increased competition from non-democratic powers in an ever more globalised world. So the choice of this Parliament is very simple: if we want, we can start taking back democratic control of economic globalisation. The Lange resolution, with its focus on labour rights, democratic values, high standards, sustainability and a clear ‘no’ to the old ISDS system, is crucially important. It should therefore be adopted if this Parliament wants to make a real difference. We all know that there are politicians in this Parliament who will reject any TTIP agreement. This is no solution; we should adopt a strong resolution, and I think we have it in front of us. I look forward to adopting it tomorrow.

name: Marian Harkin
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Mr President, first of all, I want to thank Bernd Lange for his considerable efforts in engaging with all the opinion—giving committees. Secondly, I want to say to the very many citizens who contacted me that we are not deciding on TTIP today. This is our third opportunity. We had two reports in the last parliament, but this is our third opportunity for Parliament to lay down our principles and our requirements for a sustainable TTIP. In the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, we clearly laid out our requirements for TTIP. We want to ensure that labour, environmental and social standards are enforceable. We want to guarantee the rights of Member States to legislate, organise, fund and regulate all public services, and we want the explicit exclusion of public services from the deal. We aim for full and effective implementation and enforcement of the fundamental ILO Conventions and the ILO Decent Work Agenda. Finally, we were very clear on our rejection of the Investor State Dispute Settlement (ISDS) with our rejection of any form of private arbitration courts in TTIP.

name: Bart Staes
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety – There is concern within the Environment Committee about the potential impact of TTIP on environmental, public health and food safety policy areas. Already, in our legislative work, we are feeling the pressure of TTIP. I am thinking, among other things, of the debate on the treatment of lactic acid beef or the debate on cloning meat. Rapporteur Lange took many of our opinions. Our basic principles and standards, including the precautionary principle, should not be affected. No concessions also on the implementation of REACH, hormones, clone meat or genetically modified organisms. No TTIP on water supply or public health. Nevertheless, ladies and gentlemen, improvements are possible, hence the nine amendments I tabled. The Environment Committee also spoke out against the ISDS mechanism in TTIP. The proposed compromise is not satisfactory in this regard. That is why I support amendments 27 or 40 that want ISDS from TTIP. Finally, I would like to thank Mr Lange for the good cooperation of the past few months.

name: Jerzy Buzek
text: draft opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – I thank rapporteur Bernd Lange for the very clear and open negotiations between the Committees of the European Parliament, between the drafts of the opinion. This has allowed us to create, I think, a good reputation with the participation of all parliament's committees.  I would like to emphasise only three very specific things: we will not win this agreement if energy prices on both sides of the Atlantic are so very different. We certainly need to open up the US market to export liquefied gas to Europe, because that gives us a chance, but at the same time we on the European continent need to reflect on the mark-up on all energy prices on our continent. These mark-up is much higher than on the American continent, which puts us at a disadvantage. The second point is the difference between CO2 emissions on both sides of the Atlantic. Industries such as the steel and chemical industries must be protected for a long time to come. And the third point: small and medium-sized companies, and access to public procurement on the American side, would be useful for a separate chapter on this subject.  We all need to get on with promoting TTIP on the European continent – our citizens still don't know enough about it and can't be 70 000.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Mr President, we want a smart TTIP. I will read every line to make sure it is so, and I would like to ask my colleagues to start thinking globally about the TTIP negotiations. In this debate today, let us focus on the important strategic questions about TTIP and Europe. How will we benefit from international trade if we fail to act on TTIP? What will happen to European standards as China rises if we are not part of the global decision-making process? What will happen to the 31 million jobs that depend directly on exports, and will Europe continue to have to get its energy sources from authoritarian governments? A smart TTIP is a tool to address all these questions. TTIP is more than just an economic agreement: it is a geopolitical agreement. While making us stronger economically, it will help to confirm us as leaders in the world. I believe it would be an unacceptable mistake to miss this chance.

name: Wim van de Camp
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Bernd Lange, but certainly the EPP shadow rapporteur, Mrs Quisthoudt, for their work. In the Transport Committee, ISDS was also a very big problem, but I hope that we can solve this with the new compromise amendment. The transport sector is very important in TTIP. Europe has major interests in the maritime sector, and I hope that the Commissioner and her staff can break open the maritime sector in the US. We don't want to abolish the Jones Act, we want to change it. A little milder. I also call attention to the Buy American Act – everyone knows this subject, I do not go into it – and to the safety procedures in the automotive industry. Finally, Mr President, a question. Aviation is excluded. Will that continue or will we still have an opening, given recent developments?

name: Paolo De Castro
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, agriculture is an essential and sensitive part of the TTIP negotiations. The consequences of the Russian embargo have clearly demonstrated the geopolitical importance of agriculture, the need for access to multiple agricultural markets and the need for reliable trading partners.
