The Committee on Agriculture is calling for an ambitious and balanced outcome to the negotiations, which will improve the access of our agri-food products to the US market. At the same time, however, European standards on food safety, human health, animal welfare, environmental protection and consumer protection must not be called into question. TTIP must be an opportunity to set high standards globally.  Europe has offensive interests in the agri-food sector, Mrs Malmström, with a surplus of around EUR 6 billion. There is still a lot of room for growth in the export of European products to the American market, particularly quality products, and that is why TTIP must be an opportunity to stop the indiscriminate use of European geographical brands.

name: James Nicholson
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. – Mr President, TTIP is estimated to be worth GBP 100 billion to the European Union. This would provide immense opportunities in my own constituency, and indeed right across Europe. But no trade negotiations are without risk. That is why we must have appropriate safeguards. Right from the start I have said that agriculture should not be used as a bargaining chip in any negotiations with the United States, and in writing the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development on TTIP, my main focus was to put the retention of European food standards at the top of the agenda. I am pleased that the report highlights the importance of geographical indicators (GIs). My colleagues from Italy and France may have many more GIs than I do in my part of the world, but producers of products with GIs certainly realise the value these have and recognise the benefits of their protection in any free trade. TTIP also has great potential export opportunities for many sectors, and especially for the dairy sector in agriculture, due in no small part to the sheer size of the US marketplace. We must have a fair and balanced TTIP that protects vulnerable sectors, protects public service and allows the maximum use of the opportunities of a closer trade relationship with the United States.

name: Helga Trüpel
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which On the part of the Committee on Culture, Youth, Youth, Public Transport, I would like to say that culture and the media are special goods.  They are not commodities like others, but they are carriers of meaning and meaning, and therefore they should be regulated differently and not liberalised in the same way as other services.  That is why we have called for the Member States to continue to have the right to regulate and promote audiovisual media, and to do so in a future-proof manner, in other words, in a technology-neutral way, in other words, also in the digital world.  The Committee on Culture insists that a legally binding clause stipulates that these services will not be attacked by the TTIP. Then we want to make sure that book price fixing applies to books, but also to the free press, and that it will not be affected by the TTIP. What is also very important is that we do not want education to be affected, that member states continue to have the opportunity to promote educational institutions and also to regulate objectives in this area. Most importantly, American educational institutions must adhere to the same standards as European ones, so that there is no distortion of competition. Cultural subsidies must not be attacked by TTIP. All these points must be clearly regulated in the TTIP, so that there is no misunderstanding.

name: Dietmar Köster
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The report addresses the concerns of many European citizens. There is a clear commitment, for example, to the ILO core labour standards. This is above all the merit of S&D. However, the key weakness in this report remains the treatment of the arbitral tribunals. We do not need parallel justice to protect corporate investment. Arbitration courts break with the rule of law of any democracy: a right that applies equally to all. This must continue to be the case in the future. Otherwise, the profit interests of a few large companies will be safeguarded under international law. The original Amendment No 27 takes up the position of the Committee on Legal Affairs and The Committee on Legal Affairs, therefore, to oppose any form of arbitration. And we should all agree with Amendment No 27 or those that are identical in content – in the spirit of the European rule of law and social democracy.

name: Esteban González Pons
text: Drafts member of the Opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. – Mr President, it is said that TTE will benefit only multinationals. That's not true. Multinationals are the only ones that don't need TTE. The ATCI needs the European economy to grow. Farmers need the TTE, so as not to pay thirty percent tariffs or to be able to sell oranges in the United States. Small and medium-sized enterprises, which cannot export, need the ATCI. Consumers need ATCI for more competition and lower prices. And workers need ATCI, because TTE is going to create jobs. TCE is going to create a million jobs in Europe, which we cannot give up. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, globalisation is a fact. Globalization is not a theory. Globalisation, today, is unstoppable and, or we try to Europeanise global markets by transmitting our values, transmitting our labour market, transmitting our protection system, or, over time, sooner or later, what globalisation will do is dissolve the European market. Either We Europeanize globalization or globalization will dissolve us. ATCI is just one more opportunity.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Petitions. – Mr President, I believe there are two vital objectives regarding TTIP. We have to reach a balanced trade agreement, but we also need to have mutual recognition of product standards or we have to work towards transatlantic standards. The Committee on Petitions received many petitions regarding TTIP. Citizens raised a number of concerns that we, as representatives, have to take seriously, most of them related to the quality of food imports, the rights of EU citizens to digital self-determination, transparency, the economic impact, and protection of investors under the ISDS mechanism. I tried to underline the importance of the public consultations regarding TTIP, because this was the most important thing about these petitions, but I also tried to incorporate the accommodations of the Ombudsman regarding this dossier in the context of the Mobility Package and also in the context of establishing visa reciprocity for EU citizens of all Member States. I believe this is one of the key elements that is necessary in order to take full advantage of this agreement.

name: Godelieve Quisthoudt-Rowohl
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. What can we say today, which has not been repeated forever in recent weeks and months? We are spinning in circles instead of supporting our negotiators. Firstly, a great deal has happened in recent months. Significant progress has been made in the transparency of the conduct of negotiations and a noticeable increase in the Commission's willingness to engage in intensive dialogue with all stakeholders. A broad public debate has started, and it is more important than ever to communicate facts. In this context, for example, the joint statement that you have already mentioned, Mrs Malmström, and your commitment to the protection of public services were particularly welcome. We have a firm commitment that our standards will not be lowered in any area. That is why the European Parliament should send a strong signal of support. So, what exactly are we discussing in the public debate? There are so far few consolidated texts that produce reliable results. The discussion is very much based on the conjectures, uncertainties and fears of a number of citizens. Much is future music; Concrete work needs to be drawn up. That is why we see this resolution not only as a message to the negotiators, but also as a positive signal to our citizens. TTIP is an opportunity for Europe. Maybe not so much for my generation, but certainly for the generation of our children and our grandchildren. We must not squande this opportunity. If it is not possible to reach an agreement with a similar partner like the United States, then we can wrap up on trade policy. How can we ever come together with much different partners?  We fought hard in the negotiations on this text of the resolution. Overall, I believe that we have reached a good compromise. As the rapporteur spoke earlier of struggle: yes, it is true, Mr Rapporteur: we have fought, we have rallied together, but I think that, overall, we can support this text together. A final word on investment protection. We need a robust chapter on investment, because they are a stimulus for growth and jobs. And only effective use, only effective protection of investments, provides much-needed legal certainty for investors. I would particularly like to thank the members of my Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats. We worked very well together. Thank you for your support.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen! I must draw your attention to the following: we have about 60 speakers on the list of speakers in this debate. If we now take a blue card practically after or during each speech, we will certainly not get along with the list of speakers. This will mean that, in the end, ladies and gentlemen who have been invited to the list of speakers will not have their say. I do not think that is appropriate in this debate. Therefore, please do not be angry with me if I do not allow blue cards, because the number of speakers shows the full spectrum of the debate. (Interruption) That is what I decide, and I have now decided so. I shall carry out the list of speakers in this way.

name: David Martin
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr  President, I want to firstly join the many members who have already thanked Bernd Lange for his hard work on this report. There is a view in some quarters, inside and outside this House, that our handling of TTIP has not been our finest hour. I beg to differ. I think Parliament has fulfilled exactly the role that it should play. The rapporteur has performed a Herculean task in bringing together competing and sometimes contradictory views on a wide range of sensitive and emotive issues. In my view, and in the view of my Group, if this report is adopted by Parliament it will provide an excellent blueprint for a progressive TTIP that not only creates jobs but protects public services and the right to regulate, and defends labour and environmental standards. Even on the most sensitive issue – ISDS – we have made progress. I and my group remain opposed to ISDS, but nevertheless, look how far we have come. Firstly, the vast majority of this Parliament, and indeed the Commission, now  accept that the old-style ISDS is dead and unacceptable. The majority now accept that any investor protection must be transparent, must not limit the right to regulate, and must not undermine health, labour or environmental standards. That is indeed progress on where we were six months ago. In this report we have also made it clear that the sustainable development chapter must be binding and enforceable. We have demanded that the US sign and ratify core ILO conventions on workers’ rights; with this report we are also demanding, very clearly and explicitly, the full exemption of public services from the deal, regardless of how they are financed – and, as the rapporteur has said, that includes healthcare, education and water. We also acknowledge that TTIP is an opportunity to help set global standards. That does not mean (again, as others have said) simply accepting all US standards, and the report again makes it clear that GMOs, some food standards and chemicals are not up for grabs. Where we can agree, we should agree common standards with the United States, and again, as others have said, if we do not, it will be the global marketplace that sets those standards. Do we really believe that the human rights standards from Latin America, the labour standards from China, the environmental standards from other parts of Asia, will be up to our standards? Do we really want to be driven down by that part of the world when we could reach an agreement on common standards with the United States that – for all its faults – could drag it up the way, not down the way? My group has been explicit since the outset of the TTIP debate that we want a good TTIP but that we are ready to reject a bad TTIP, and we stand by that position. But this report, if it is accepted by Parliament and implemented by the negotiators, would create a Europe that helps to create jobs but ensures that European standards on workers’ rights and the environment are at the heart of our economic growth strategy. Commissioner, my recommendation to you would be, if Parliament adopts this report tomorrow, make sure your chief negotiator keeps it in his top pocket and refers to it every day during the negotiations. (Applause)

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we have seen your considerable power in being able to cancel a debate on a vote adjourned last plenary. Might I suggest to you that you use that power to extend the time of this debate to allow blue-card questions to be put to speakers so that we have a real debate, rather than expose this Parliament as a talking shop?

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent I do not have the power to cancel debates. This was decided here in plenary by a majority. In this respect, this statement was incorrect. Secondly, we have already moved voting time to 1 p.m. This debate has already been extended by one hour. Normally, the vote should take place at 12 noon. We have moved it to 1 p.m. so that as many speakers as possible can speak. That is why, for once, I ask you to do without blue cards. We have 60 speakers. You certainly do not want your fellow Members to have to be removed from the list of speakers at the end.

name: Emma McClarkin
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, for me this report is about the potential opportunities that arise from striking a deal with one of our closest allies. This deal can bring us the growth that we so desire, cutting red tape and reducing tariffs, so that our businesses of all sizes can flourish in a truly transatlantic marketplace. In turn, the consumer wins, being able to choose from a wide range of products at a cheaper price, while the taxpayer gains from further competition if procurement is opened up too. As we are all too aware, this is not the only debate taking place this week. We will be discussing the situation in Greece, a Member State that has fallen on hard times in one of the worst economic downturns we have ever known. But we cannot on the one hand condemn the situation there, scrambling to find a resolution to the problem, and, on the other, strike down TTIP. If we are to have any hope of overcoming this crisis, we must be outward-looking. Other parts of the world are making progress while Europe lags behind. As the Trans-Pacific Partnership nears conclusion with the signing of the Trade Promotion Authority in the US, Europe should lead the global trade agenda and not be led by it. This is not just an option for us: we must do this to catch up. This includes leadership on the thorny issue of investment protection. We have taken part in numerous debates over recent months, and I do not recall having heard anyone deny that ISDS requires change. We must have a dispute settlement mechanism that is transparent and accountable and offers the opportunity to appeal. The compromise agreement that we have on the table takes this into account, and the need for reform is there for investment protection within TTIP. But let us be clear: Europe is desperate for investment, and with that must come some form of investment protection. I, like my group, remain committed to the promotion of free trade to free and empower people the world over. We need to get further down the road of negotiations with the US to see what it is possible to achieve if the EU has any opportunity to prove that it is truly open for business.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, there is not a Member in this House who did not contribute to this resolution on TTIP, informed by the daily discussions with citizens, civil society organisations, SMEs and companies. Their many wishes, but also concerns, are reflected in this intensive stocktaking. Is it a perfect text for our group? No, but it is important that this House sends a strong message to the negotiators, and cooperation requires some compromise. I would like to remind our Socialist and Democrat friends of that as well. The text we have agreed maps out what we believe a good TTIP should look like. I am sure it is not the last debate we will have on TTIP and the state of play of the negotiations, which will probably last years more. We call on you, Commissioner, to get clear results from the US side, as results are the best way to demystify and clarify, while not, of course, replacing transparency initiatives, which we also encourage you to take more of. Concretely, we need market access for EU companies in the US, government procurement at all levels, and an end to protectionist measures that seriously restrict the space for our businesses, notably in the transport sector. We need benefits for SMEs so they can more easily expand business across the Atlantic. Most growth in the global economy is foreseen as coming outside of Europe. We are happy to see developing economies succeed, but we must avoid a race to the bottom and do not believe in development and growth at any cost without respect for people and the planet. Our environmental, food safety, labour and other standards are cherished and cannot be lowered. We will also remind you of your commitments on public services. It is key that Europe lead in strengthening rules-based trade globally. We need progress in finding a solution to the outdated ISDS mechanism which, frankly, has no fans left. I support your plans for an international court and hope the Member States and other countries, including the US, can be convinced that this is the way forward. A lot of work remains to be done on the road to a good result from the negotiations. I hope we can all intensify our outreach and discussions to engage with stakeholders so that we have a well-informed and interactive debate.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Supporters of TTIP like to argue that the agreement is necessary because the global economy has changed. It is true, it has changed and it is changing. But from all geopolitical and geoeconomic angles, TTIP is the wrong answer. It is not only naive, but wrong, to want to set standards against the rest of the world. We do not need a confrontational alliance against China, India, Russia. Instead, we must shape our world together with these partners. To this end, trade policy must also be supported multilaterally and democratically. However, TTIP is not only a confrontation externally, but also internally. Citizens see your plans for regulatory cooperation as an attack. What you call barriers to trade are, in fact, democratic achievements. Corporations may not like this, but the legal rules and standards are important for our companies. Hence our rejection of ISDS in principle. That is why We are also in the 'yes' to Amendment No 27. Hence our fight for good work, for healthy food, for the preservation of rural areas, for municipal services, for binding sustainability chapters and against TTIP. My group is re-presenting important arguments from opinions from committees in this Parliament to the House with amendments. We believe, ladies and gentlemen, that much of this work must be reflected in the resolution as a benchmark for the future evaluation of the negotiations. Commissioner, use the time of summer to rethink your trading strategy! The negotiating approaches to TTIP, CETA and TiSA no longer correspond to the current and prospective tasks for the promotion of regional trade, for combating exploitation in global production chains, for combating environmental dumping. To do this, start a democratic process with the citizens of the EU, with their organisations and parliaments, with our partner countries in a common future. And take advantage of the millions of speeches made by citizens in the EU and the US in this regard!

name: Yannick Jadot
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are well aware that this negotiation is not a negotiation on free trade , there is already free trade with the United States, but that it is a negotiation on our democratic spaces and on our ability to decide again the society in which we want to live.  Commissioner, you say you are consulting with the citizens, but listen to them! When you look at them, 97% of them refuse the arbitral tribunals. You say you speak on behalf of the employees, but listen to the employees! Employees do not want arbitration tribunals. They are very critical of TAFTA. You say you speak for consumers, but listen to consumers! Consumers do not want these private courts and they are very critical of the transatlantic partnership. Listen to cities, listen to regions, listen to parliaments! Stop consulting them and just do what you want to do in the name of an agenda that is a big business agenda.  Finally, for the past three weeks, this Parliament has begun to listen to European society. He was divided, and a new knight appeared in this debate: the knight Schulz who, using the internal regulation, because he did not know how this Parliament was going to vote, postponed the vote. He also acted by creating an amendment today on the arbitration courts with the EPP group, forcing part of the Social Democratic Group. Mr Schulz, you have not only thrown Greek democracy into the technocrats, you also want to sell European democracy to big business. There is not a single economic argument in favour of ISDS! You know that perfectly well. There is not a single study that says ISDS encourages investment. We are constantly seeing American investment in Europe and European investment in the United States.  What is at issue here is a political position that seeks to transfer part of our sovereignty to multinational firms, to circumvent national jurisdictions that first want to protect social rights, health, the environment, public services, and to transfer that power to private courts.  Commissioner, you're not going to make us take butcher's knives for butter knives. Your reforms do not change a system that seeks to circumvent national jurisdictions. So, dear Social Democrat friends, don't let yourself be imposed on a position that is not yours. You have committed yourself for two years against the private courts. Vote for Amendment 27 and, finally, you can justify yourself to your constituents.

name: Tiziana Beghin
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, together with the American Government, the Commission is drawing up the biggest attack on the standards, safety and health of European citizens, the biggest fraud since the end of the Second World War and all this why? I ask the Commission: why do you want TTIP so much? All the independent studies, the truly independent ones, show that we Europeans will be poorer, with net income losses of up to EUR 5 000 per year per family; with fewer rights, because there will be over a million redundancies; More sick, because GMOs, cloned meat and hormone-treated meat will be legal, and less safe, because we will live in a world where the Euro-American mega-bloc will be opposed to the Chinese-Russian mega-bloc: a world of political, economic and commercial cold war rather than a world of cooperation. You say that, in order to relaunch investment, we need ISDS, that is, private justice for investors, but that is not true! Investment between the UNITED States and Europe is already EUR 3 000 billion even without ISDS and in european countries where it already exists, this system has given rise to EUR 30 billion in claims for compensation that are increasing every day.  How can you say that we will find growth again, when according to many studies there will be a fall in European net exports of at least 2% and a consequent fall in GDP? How dare you say that we will never change our standards when you, in order to facilitate TTIP, have already lifted the ban on the use of lactic acid on meat? And if TTIP doesn't reduce the safety of our food, why have you just withdrawn the bill to limit endocrine disruptors? I know why! Because that law would have blocked 40 percent of American food coming into Europe, and you couldn't afford it. You have sold the health of European citizens in the name of free trade.  How can you believe that a market like ours, where there are controls for 143 000 chemicals, is compatible with one where there are 6 controlled substances? How can you even think that this Treaty will help small and medium-sized enterprises when they mainly export to Europe, and this treaty will strangle intra-European trade precisely in order to promote intra-European trade with the United States? You want us to be anti-American, but that's not true. The United States is an ally of Europe, but that is not the problem here. The problem is in our house and it is the large European multinationals, American and beyond, that are taking advantage of TTIP to create the ideal world, indeed, sorry, the ideal market: a market of 800 million consumers without rights, without protection and without security.  But even more than that, it is you, dear gentlemen of the Commission, who should be a regulator who should protect the citizens and you are the waiters of the bankers and the multinationals. And you, Mr Schulz, should be a guarantor of impartiality: but you want to propose a shameful compromise, which will perhaps bring socialists and the people to an agreement, but which in fact says nothing and sells citizens' rights to international investors, pretending to protect them.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is not the corporations that elected us. And I hope that all of you will have the courage to demonstrate this because sooner or later you will respond to the citizens.

name: Marine Le Pen
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President Martin Schulz, at the last session of this Parliament in Strasbourg, you tried to prevent MePs from voting on the amendments tabled on the transatlantic treaty using an obscure parliamentary procedure. In fact, you were afraid that this Parliament would vote on amendments opposing this treaty. You have failed in your attempt, since in the end all the amendments will be put to a vote tomorrow before this House. But we will all remember that your attitude has revealed a profound contempt for democracy, even as your role as President of this Parliament commands the opposite attitude at every opportunity. You know, the same causes have the same effects. It is precisely this contempt and morgue that the Greeks have just sent you back to the face and, my God, this return of boomerang is doing us a great deal of good! But let's get back to the bottom of our case. We have in our hands a report from the European Parliament on the transatlantic treaty negotiations. Apart from a few amendments proposed by courageous Members of Parliament, this document is a vast sham. Parliament does not set a red line for the Commission on this very dangerous transatlantic treaty. Yet, as you know, this treaty is a bombshell. Our quality agriculture is in danger of disappearing if we allow the European farmer to compete head-on with the American agro-industrialists. They have no qualms about raising 40,000 cows in the Fair Oaks Farms building, injecting hormones into all live animals to grow faster, washing chlorine chickens, spreading Roundup on whole fields of Roundup Ready GMO. Is that what you want? Bringing our agriculture back to this level of quality, sinking the farmers who love their products, selling Europeans a food of increasingly poor quality, mixing white wine and red wine to make rosé?  Moreover, this document does not set any restrictions against the forced alignment of European standards with US standards imposed by the transatlantic treaty. This is outrageous, because the Americans do not have at all the same protective vision of standards as the Europeans, as the negotiators regularly tell us.  What will happen once the standards are aligned? There's nothing left! To change a standard, and therefore consumer protection, a nation will have to get the approval of the Member States of the European Union and the United States, so to speak never. On the other hand, any multinational, supposedly aggrieved in its financial interests, will be able to summon that nation to a private court. This famous arbitration tribunal is made up of specialized business lawyers, and there will of course be many conflicts of interest. It is therefore the superiority of a private justice system in perpetual conflict of interest over a public and independent justice that you want to organize.  It will be a mortal blow, one more, to democracy. Worse, this transatlantic treaty will create a single market between the United States and the European Union, thus dismantling the European project of which you are one of the most convinced ideologues. This whole text is just a broad statement of intent to cover this Parliament against the harmful consequences of TTIP! Gentlemen, the Europeans did not elect you to cover you or to lie down, they elected you to represent them and to defend them! This document is below everything! Apart from a few amendments opposing the transatlantic treaty, we will therefore fight it with all our might.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – The free trade agreement negotiated between the EU and the United States is detrimental to Europe because the partners are not economically in the same league. In fact, it is about broadening the rights of multinationals. Global companies can sue countries for lost profits in a specially designed court. The greatest danger is the relaxation of strict EU food safety standards and the marketing of food made from genetically modified plants and meat from hormone-treated animals. According to the welcome message on the EP's website, I quote: "The European Parliament is the only directly elected body in the European Union. The 751 Members of the European Parliament represent you, the citizens." If you really represent citizens here and not the interests of global companies, then this agreement must be permanently taken off the agenda.

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the President-in-House for the work she has done Globalisation is taking place. We in the European People's Party do not just want to let them happen, we want to shape them. That is why we are in principle in favour of trade agreements that are binding under international law. We have had almost only good experiences with our several dozen existing agreements. That is why we also support the TTIP negotiations. That is why we are calling on those opponents who are unsettling people and running questionable campaigns: stop doing so and finally face a debate based on facts and not spread half-truths and lies. We want better market access for our businesses in America. But we do not want arbitrary removal of rules, standards and standards. We want to abolish tariffs where possible and sensible, and not to jeopardise jobs in industry and agriculture. We want better market access for our service providers, for film producers, for architects and media professionals in the USA, but we do not want to jeopardise art, culture, cultural promotion, public service broadcasting, education or book price fixing in Europe. We want better access to the public procurement market, but we do not want anyone to have to endure any restrictions on local services of general interest.  We want companies and investors in America to be protected and have meaningful litigation options in the event of a dispute. We do not want taxpayers to be arbitrarily asked to pay. We want better cooperation between governments, administrations and standard-setters on both sides of the Atlantic, but no restrictions on us as democratically elected and legitimate legislators. We want better opportunities for our farmers, winegrowers and food producers, not a lowering of food safety standards. That is what TTIP is all about for us. However, Mrs Harms and Mr Jadot, this has happened several times now: someone from your group is speaking, right-wing and left-wing populists are clapping, and many of your own group colleagues are not clapping and looking to the ground in shame. I suggest that you reconsider what you are doing here and with whom you are doing things together.

name: Victor Boștinaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, our objective is to achieve the best possible agreement, not an ideal agreement, because ideal agreements exist only in Tommaso Campanella or in Thomas Morus, 'Utopia'; a possible agreement, which will benefit all citizens of the European Union, which will guarantee equal rights to national and foreign investors and an agreement that will be subject to high social, environmental and health standards, as well as transparency. The resolution to be voted on is very important because it defines the fundamental lines that the Commission must follow in the negotiations, which are essential points for which the Socialists Group is deeply committed and without achieving which it will be very difficult to vote for this agreement. But I also invite you all to distinguish between truth and deeds today, on the one hand, and propaganda and manipulation, on the other. The resolution calls for compliance with high social and environmental standards, the explicit exclusion of public services from the content of this agreement. The objective of our text is to ensure the competitiveness of European businesses, be they multinationals or small and medium-sized enterprises, and to encourage foreign investment, which we are so short of in the Union.  It is absolutely crucial to ask the Commission for a proposal for a permanent investor-state dispute settlement mechanism to replace the private arbitration services currently available - the old ASDS system. A mechanism that is subject to democratic principles, democratic control with independent judges in public processes and also allows for appeal. This is exactly the compromise that my colleague Bernd Lange will propose. TTIP can and must be a new generation of trade agreement between two states, two global actors with integrated economies that can ensure a common system of high standards for future trade agreements. If we don't create those standards, others will. And, please, take a moment's look at the Trans-Pacific partnership, at the Schengen initiative, look at the Asian Bank for Infrastructure and Investment, to understand that Europe cannot afford the isolation that those who vehemently oppose this agreement are proposing.  And I say one more thing: TTIP can be a response to the current security challenges by introducing an energy chapter for common benefits. And colleagues who say "China opposes TTIP" tell them that this is false! Maybe you haven't talked to Chinese officials! China encourages TTIP, as it encourages a bilateral investment agreement, as a first stage for a future trade and investment agreement between the two parties.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the European Union has not had much success. It cannot solve the refugee crisis, the quotas it has devised have pitted only individual states against each other. And even the single currency, which was supposed to be the sealant of the European Union, is proving to be a failure, as something that pits European nations against each other, as the eurozone crisis shows. In this situation, we urgently need some positive signal. I believe that successful negotiations on TTIP can be this positive signal and it is not just about economic benefits, it is also about geopolitics. It must be shown that Europe and the United States of America are two sides of the same coin, that they are two parts of Euro-Atlantic civilization, that they are to play together, not against each other, both securityly, politically, and economically. We need to start behaving rationally, prejudice must be put aside, and we must confront the wave of ideological anti-Americanism that is rolling through Europe, whether it comes from the left or the right. Europe needs this treaty more than the United States. After all, if it isn't, Americans can turn to the Pacific. They will have their Trans-Pacific Treaty, Europe will have nothing, at most we will have a reputation in the world as an incompetent organisation that cannot even negotiate a trade agreement. I believe that common sense will prevail in the European Parliament this time, many times in the past, so I will be happy to see that this time it will be.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE).
text: Madam President, there are two fundamental reasons for me which explain the mistrust - justified indeed - of public opinion with regard to this trade agreement.  The first of these is not only transparency, it is that, in essence, peoples and public opinion have not been involved in the debate. They don't know what's going on. I regret that the Heads of State and Government have given the Commission a mandate to negotiate without first having had debates in their own Member States. I hope that national parliaments will have the opportunity to endorse, or not give it, approval to this agreement. It's very important. The second reason is that public opinion rightly feels that we are not fighting on equal terms with the United States, that we are not playing an equal game with the United States, and that the Americans are better defending the interests of the Americans than the Europeans are defending the interests of the Europeans. If we just take the issue of public procurement, we are saying that we want U.S. government procurement to be open. U.S. government contracts are reserved for small and medium-sized U.S. companies. The Americans are right to do that. The Europeans should do it.  Therefore, I ask you, and I ask us, to face these two substantive reasons which are largely at the root of legitimately expressed doubts and concerns.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I congratulate you, gentlemen of the Grand Coalition, because, after hijacking this institution a few weeks ago, it seems that you have already reached a deal and then you let us debate and vote. The President of the European Parliament, Mr Schulz, has had to bring order to those who rightly doubt the goodness of TTE. With a commitment that is a big lie, he is born dead, because they know better than I do that the United States does not accept a public court instead of the ISDS. They said it. They try to wash their faces, but they keep selling democracy, including their own seats. They also talk about geopolitical importance, but do you know what they've achieved? Let Russia and the rest of the BRICS start doing the same. You have opened the door to a commercial battle that will take us down to the competition. Very clever of you! In the end, I ask the socialist colleagues to vote with their voters in mind, who have put them there, because no socialist would really support this treaty. Consider independent predictions, such as Mr Capaldo's, which explain the enormous attack on the workers involved in this treaty. Read it, get unheded before you vote. Don't fail the workers, because they're supposed to be on their side... (The Chairperson interrupts the speaker)

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her At last we have the debate on TTIP, and finally we have the vote on TTIP. But we could have had that last month, because the arguments have been on the table for a while. The President, who is unfortunately no longer here, wanted to have time to clap together two positions which simply do not fit together. After all, it is not really difficult: either you are in favour of the possibility for investors to sue states, or you are against it. That is what the issue of ISDS is all about. And all my fellow Members have been able to form an opinion on this over the last few months, even over the last few years. But instead, the president has proposed a formula compromise that is actually more satire than politics. Instead of proposing an investor-state lawsuit, the president calls for a mechanism for lawsuits between investors and states. This reminds me, frankly, of the People's Front of Judea. But people want a clear statement. We must make it clear what we stand for or against. If you're in favour of investor-state lawsuits, you should say that and represent it to the outside world and not just tinker around like that. We still have time to express a very clear opinion here in this House. You can all decide: are you in favour of investor-state lawsuits, or are you in favour of democracy not being undermined, not being undermined? That is the decision we make in the House. I hope you have been able to put all your arguments to the table recently.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, first of all, trade should be about economic benefits, not political goals, and yet the Commission persistently wants to exploit trade agreements in the course of its political agenda. I refer you to Commissioner Malström’s statement at the confirmation hearings when she said, in prepared remarks, that ‘trade is a powerful foreign policy tool; it must support Europe’s wider international goals’. The intention is that Member States are to be forced to barter – trade away their sovereignty – in order to support the EU’s vanity foreign policy. The EU should not manipulate the UK’s trade, nor that of any other Member State, in order to promote the political pretensions of a wannabe European superstate, not with any trade agreement and not with ISDS either. Now to the detail: first, the British National Health Service (NHS). The British Labour Party has spent months – years even – falsely accusing our party of wanting to privatise the NHS. Incidentally, in these false accusations, they have been consistently and disgracefully aided and abetted by the BBC. But in the Committee on International Trade (INTA), UKIP was the only British political party to table amendments that would have fully and properly protected the NHS. It was the S&D Group, of which the Labour Party is a principal component, that saw to it that no one got to vote on our amendments which protected the NHS. UKIP stands up for the NHS, even as the British Labour Party does not and fails to do so. I have to make a potentially embarrassing personal confession, which is this: on a personal level, I rather like President Schulz. However, his exploitation of the rules to delay the vote on the amendments in last month’s plenary was not President Schulz’s finest hour, and I very much hope that this does not happen again. But we are getting to vote on the amendments tomorrow, and I urge Members to support our EFD amendments. These require, very simply, that the Commission does not use TTIP to establish a global regulatory regime, nor as a device to advance the foreign policy goals of the EU, nor to set up a parallel system that would undermine national courts and national legal systems through the much-mentioned ISDS. Above all, our amendments require the Commission to exclude specifically our British National Health Service from TTIP in its entirety.

name: Franz Obermayer (NI).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her When the TTIP report is before us today, we really have to ask ourselves: why not immediately? In the end, only three amendments have been omitted. It is probably not so much the number of amendments that have been decisive, but the fear of criticism and fear and the fear of a possible defeat in the vote, which has led our Bureau to postpone the vote to a later date. But what are we warning about? Nothing has changed. There will continue to be no transparency in the negotiation process, investor protection will remain an element of the agreement, and the privatisation of public infrastructure will remain in place despite reassuring words. The list can be continued at will, from unresolved issues relating to the implementation of the ban on the import of cloned meat to regulatory cooperation, which will degrade our Member States to recipients of orders and will make self-determination in the legislative field almost impossible for them. The end of our small-scale Alpine European agriculture can also be well illustrated. Our European alpine mountain farmers supply the world's best raw milk, obtained from cows whose health far exceeds that of their American counterparts. This can be easily determined by the different germ load in the milk. Our miners will probably not be able to keep up with this in terms of price, and thanks to ttip, this fight will be lost, and their existence will probably also perish. Ladies and gentlemen, I can therefore only appeal not to be deceived by this smear. Do not believe that the reasons for the content were decisive for the postponed vote! It is about supporting your citizens, of opposing the free trade agreement and of voting against this report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Madam President, the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) is the most serious effort that has been made between the European Union and the United States to develop, become competitive economies and prosper the people. New principles and rules will also be laid down in international trade. Mrs Clinton said that this relationship is a NATO trade agreement, i.e. a corresponding trade agreement such as the military agreement. That is why we must be very careful in negotiating with the Americans. These must be done transparently, which the Americans do not seem to want, and that must be of concern to us. We must ensure that we have the necessary information, especially in terms of service provision, but also to secure personal data. We must not allow this agreement to develop into an imposition of the interests of multinational companies. Nor should we give individuals public services such as energy, water and hospitals. We must not remove the institutional obstacles that prohibit the uncontrolled profitability of multinational companies. Finally, this agreement must not be made in order to manipulate the peoples... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we must not be wrong about the debate today. It is not a question of voting for or against the transatlantic partnership. It is a matter of forcefully reminding negotiators of the substantive principles that they must respect. This agreement must be negotiated in a spirit of mutual benefit, but we will not accept it at any cost. I want to remind us here of our red lines. We will be uncompromising on the protection of our cultural diversity, including the exclusion of audiovisual services from the negotiations, as well as on our choices of society. We will not accept any weakening of our social, health and environmental standards. Public services will also have to be excluded from the negotiations. We must also protect our agriculture, including by excluding sensitive agricultural products and by fully respecting our geographical indications.  Another key condition is the opening of US markets, particularly public procurement, particularly for SMEs.  With regard to ISDS, we reject this mechanism as it exists today. We will only accept a dispute settlement mechanism if it is profoundly reformed and respects democratic principles. It must be transparent, include an appeal mechanism, operate with judges free of influence and, above all, not question the right of states to regulate.  We have heard the concerns of the citizens and the negotiators must know that we will not accept this agreement if it does not comply with these conditions.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, TTIP is an opportunity, perhaps the last for Europe, to be a leading player in the global world and to regulate globalisation. This is the most important challenge we have and we cannot waste it. The European Parliament is the only institution that can intervene to ensure that the negotiations are conducted with the utmost consideration of citizens' concerns about the possible risks if there is no good agreement. It is the challenge that we as an institution cannot miss. That is why we need to express ourselves and support this report, which highlights and underlines all these concerns. And it does so by declining on the substance what transparency means to us, respect for environmental and food standards, work, consumer safety, respect for cultural diversity and the protection of public services. It does not wink at the only protest that takes applause but is not constructive: instead it enters into the substance with realism, placing very clear stakes against distortions and iniquities that un regulated globalisation can cause. It is a good report and that is why we must support it strongly and we must do so because the crisis we are experiencing at this very moment is also, and above all, a crisis of confidence in the institutions. Today there is an automatic equation where everything proposed by the institutions, perceived as establishment, is necessarily negative.  We must break this mechanism because it leads us to the destruction of the democratic structure which, however imperfect, is the best possible form of european government that we have. We must exercise our role as decision-makers to the full and courageously and therefore express ourselves, by adopting the report, because if we do not do so, if we do not set certain conditions, if we do not set priorities, but at the same time give a push for the negotiations to continue, others will fill the gap that we are leaving. And if the square, real or virtual, on the one hand, or corporations, on the other, take the place of the institutions, democracy, whether you like it or not, is at risk.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Lange report contains the phrase 'preventing fiscal dumping'. "Preventing fiscal dumping" aims at tax harmonisation.  National tax systems, however, have historically grown and are based on national tax morality. Neither peoples nor their tax morals can be harmonized. Tax policy is a central part of the national shaping of society and the economy. For reasons of subsidiarity, neither our trading partners nor the EU must decide on national taxes.  Tax harmonisation cannot therefore be part of a free trade agreement. The phrase 'autonomy in fiscal policy', on the other hand, is in line with the spirit of the European Treaties. I would therefore ask you to vote in favour of the amendment 'Autonomy in fiscal policy'. Thank you very much.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to express my pleasure at the fact that we are now getting to vote on the TTIP agreement. I believe that we are also coming to an agreement. Parliament's unified line will facilitate Commissioner Malmström's work to move forward. Having listened to this debate, I have felt that both the extreme right and the extreme left must have read a different report from this Lange report. Such wonderful things have been raised. I hope, however, that we will stick to this Lange report and, on that basis, we will then vote today.  One good speech was by Mrs Schaake. He said very important things about me in this regard. However, there is one point I would like to raise myself. I am a little concerned about geographical indications and the fact that they may have gained undue weight. I hope that this will not mean that, for example, when it comes to imports relating to agricultural products, we will have to be too flexible. We have to take care of ourselves, but we need to see a big picture, too. The most important thing about the big picture is that we can achieve growth and this agreement can give it. Good luck and success to Commissioner Malmström. Lycka till for further negotiations.

name: Anne-Marie Mineur (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I should like to address my fellow MEPs and remind them of whom they represent. It is not Business Europe or the American Chamber of Commerce, whose agenda is the basis for this agreement. It is not the lawyers, who are benefiting from an exploding number of ISDS cases. Nor is it the companies, which will be writing and rewriting our democratic laws. Instead, you represent the 2.3 million people who have signed the European Citizens’ Initiative to stop TTIP. It is the 150 000 people who have contributed to the public consultation on ISDS, and who were 97% negative on the whole idea. It is the hundreds and thousands of people who are now writing letters and emails to you to stop TTIP and ISDS. It is the people you were talking to when you were canvassing. It is the people who voted for you. You are a democratically-elected representative. Vote no to TTIP and no to ISDS.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I believe that TTIP will be damaging to the interests of my constituents in Wales, and that is why I take this opportunity to voice my opposition to it. I am grateful to the many thousands of constituents who have contacted me with their concerns that TTIP threatens our public services and health care, our jobs, environmental and food standards, small businesses and – an issue which is vital for Wales – minority languages and cultures. I am opposed to ISTS, or any similar process under another name, which gives foreign investors rights to take legal action against elected governments, rights which are not granted to anyone else. TTIP is about power and profit; it is not about people. We need a real and open debate about what kind of trade deal we want, a trade deal that will benefit – not threaten – our democracy, standards and values.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for My own party is cautiously in favour of a trade agreement. We believe that it will strengthen Swedish industry through the removal of both customs duties and other existing barriers to trade. But the agreement contains a number of factors, which makes it very complex. It is also difficult to assess exactly how all these factors will affect Sweden. Instead of finding common rules for all sectors, we think it is better to target those sectors where there is a good chance of agreeing common rules. However, we are strongly opposed to the ISDS clavie. We must be able to strengthen both labour law and the environment in Sweden without risking being sued for it by disgruntled investors, and therefore we are strongly opposed to ISDS. Finally, how are you going to regulate imports so that the single market in europe is not destroyed, and what do you say about studies showing that exports from the EU will fall?

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on Sunday the Greek people voted and decided, and since Sunday, everything has changed: nothing will be the same again. The European Parliament must understand this too! Ladies and gentlemen, you must understand that TTIP is another treaty made against our economies and our citizens, against our agriculture and our businesses. Today, we Members, representing 500 million citizens, should approve or reject a 100-page report with hundreds of recommendations to the Commission and then hope that the Commission will listen. Unfortunately, there are few people in charge of Europe who have the Commission, the ECB and the Monetary Fund in their hands: few people who have imposed a monstrous and unsuccessful model of Europe.  We must not approve new treaties, but we must rewrite the old treaties – Lisbon, Maastricht, Dublin, Schengen, Basel – which have made the European Union an instrument of destruction and ruin for our peoples. We need to review the euro system, which was the beginning of the end of the European dream. We must have courage, raise our heads and without fear fight together to change this European Soviet Union, as the Greek people courageously did.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). Madam President, the transatlantic agreement is being prepared through intense opposition from the European Union and the United States. It is the economic NATO, which is as unpopular and barbaric as the military. It seeks to strengthen Euro-Atlantic monopolies vis-à-vis competitors such as Russia, China and elsewhere.  A single economic area means common rules that are hardening: the abolition of tariffs, the restriction of the movement of capital and goods, the liberalisation of markets, privatisation culminating in the investor-state dispute settlement mechanism (ISDS) aimed at improving the profitability of multinationals. And all this goes along with the ironiest rule: escalating the unpopular attack, hitting wages, social security, social rights, commercialising social goods, undermining food security, painful consequences for poor middle-age farmers and the self-employed. The euro-one-way party amendments for individual improvements not only do not change its character but mislead and legitimise it. TTIP doesn't change. To raise the peoples to abort it and reverse the path of development it serves.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that it is important, in the first place, to make a reasoning as to what TTIP is going to represent.  Today we are moving towards a global agreement which sees Asia on the one hand and Europe on the other. I believe that, in order to write the rules of trade policy, we need to participate without ideological prejudice and, above all, without demagogy. I think it is essential to quote a figure: growth in Italy and Europe is 10 %, it is 1%. I believe that 90% is the perspective, that global figure on which we must, if necessary, prepare ourselves.  Our small and medium-sized enterprises must be equipped to have a dimension that allows them to participate in a process of internationalisation. We must protect and trace our food safety, we must produce geographical indications, that is, we must be able to participate while ensuring that our quality is protected and guaranteed.  I support a path of reasoning: TTIP is not necessarily and in any case but TTIP is certainly a great extraordinary, strategic and commercial opportunity that we cannot avoid.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Madam President, first of all I would like to say to those in this Parliament who regard any criticism of the single ultraliberal thought as populist that they are falling into a form of authoritarianism. As the Commission prepares to open a tenth round of negotiations, concerns are mounting. And they are not only rising among some NGOs and trade unions, they are also swelling among judges, doctors, SMEs or farmers. There are none so deaf as those who will not hear! We have decided to hear these concerns and to make a number of demands in this resolution. I would like to thank Bernd Lange for relaying them in order to encourage sustainable economic, social and environmental development in Europe today.  However, this resolution does not take into account the categorical refusal that has been expressed with regard to ISDS. Commissioner, you conducted a consultation that resulted in a rejection of ISDS at more than 90%. Yet you are trying to put a number of reforms on the table. We do not want these reforms. We simply want to say, through this resolution, that public courts and tribunals have jurisdiction to protect investments. Any other project that would advocate ISDS would not be acceptable.

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: – One in 7 jobs or a total of 31 million jobs in Europe are already linked to Europe's trade with the rest of the world. Then you'd think, let's strengthen that. Let us focus on more trade, on more jobs, on more and better products for our consumers, on more opportunities for our businesses. But unfortunately, apparently some parties choose to scare. They screwed up the debate. Today, let us use this Parliament to give certainty to our consumers and our businesses once again. This Parliament will decide today what will and will not be negotiated. In this way, we get strong and fair trade, not at any price, but with a good protection. More innovation, more investment, more purchasing power for everyone. If you prefer to be stuck in protectionism, the european consumer will be particularly concerned. A good TTIP agreement will not be the solution to all our problems, but it will be a serious boost for our European economy.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, we need to increase the European presence in international markets to ensure that our return to growth is sustainable. Moreover, I regret the misinformation campaign against TTIP. No agreement has been reached yet and much of what is being said is getting ahead of events for purely ideological reasons. That is why I support the opening of negotiations to reach a deal for TTIP. I would like to point out four issues that will decide my vote. First, consumer protection and European food safety standards must be maintained, making clear – as your Commissioner said in the joint statement with Ambassador Froman – that public services are excluded from TTIP. Second, European SMEs must be helped to increase their exports by lowering non-tariff barriers. Third, American public procurement must be open to European enterprises and, fourth, there must be a reformed ISDS that gives juridical safety to investments, based on the Malmström proposal for an international public court for investments, which is the right idea for me. So, good luck with this Christmas tree.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we say 'OXI' to TTIP for many reasons. I would like to mention just one of them: democracy, the value of which the Greek people reminded us of last Sunday; He reminded you of the Commission, reminded the President of the European Parliament, Mr Schulz, that I feel unworthy to sit in that chair because of the role he played on the Greek affair and the role he played on TTIP. For democracy, because you are well aware, Commissioner, that regulatory cooperation or the new generation OF ISDS are in fact a Trojan horse of multinationals, they are a way of making investors' rights prevail over citizens' rights. And in the name of democracy, because what you call non-tariff barriers is actually labour law, the precautionary principle, the right to health. We have studies showing that TTIP would lead to more than 600 000 new unemployed people in Europe, a new and further shift in income from wages to capital. We have endless reasons for saying 'OXI' to TTIP but, above all, I would like to ask you, Commissioner, in the name of democracy, are you prepared to put TTIP to a referendum? Otherwise we ask that they be suspended.... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Claude Turmes (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The TTIP is not a dispute between Europe and the US or against the US. The proposed trade agreement is more about the rights of citizens in Europe and the United States, the rights of local, regional, national, European and American representatives on the one hand and multinationals on the other. Private arbitration would strengthen the rights of corporations and weaken those of citizens and their elected representatives. That is why we reject them. The planned cooperation on laws, standards and standards also risks weakening the European standards for the environment, animal welfare, consumer protection, labour law and safety at work. As an MEP who tries to put the protection of citizens, the environment and workers at the forefront of his work, I do not want, and I have no desire, to make an extra round with American and – through the back door – with European corporations before any European legislation. That is why we are very sceptical about this TTIP agreement.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I have a simple decision to make when it comes to TTIP. I am very much in love with free trade between Europe and the United States of America. I'm all for cell removal.  On the other hand, I am very strongly opposed to the ISDS agreement being part of the treaty. What's the idea of companies suing states for thwarted investments? States, of course, are supposed to compete for investors, but not pander in this way by offering them easy compensation at the taxpayer's expense. States are supposed to compete for investors with low taxes, they're supposed to compete for investors with a functioning justice system, but not like this. That is why I will vote in favour of the treaty if it is free trade and does not include the ISDS arbitration clause. I'm all for free trade, but against this TTIP.

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF).
text: – Madam President, my constituents in the UK have been in touch with me in massive numbers to voice their opposition to TTIP. This Parliament needs to understand the strength of opposition to this deal in the UK. For far too long, the European Parliament and the European Union have pushed through proposals that people simply do not want. Even the European Constitution – the Lisbon Treaty, which was rejected by voters when they were consulted – was pushed through in the same anti—democratic way. I did not come to the European Parliament expecting to side with the Left in this Chamber, but I do so on TTIP for good reasons. In my country, the privatisation of health care by different governments has been a disaster. In the ENF Group, we say no to TTIP in the interest of big Brussels and big business. We say no to a deal that is not in the best interest of patients, voters or individual Member States. I am not here to represent the private interests who want to force through a TTIP which suits them. I am here to represent all those in the EU and Britain who say no to trade deals which are negotiated in secrecy by the European Union, and yes to a Europe of free and sovereign nations.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for We are now negotiating a free trade agreement between the EU and the US. The world's largest free trade agreement that could become the world's best free trade agreement for jobs and growth. That's why I get depressed when I hear the debate here. What a low self-esteem you have. You're just talking about what you don't want in the agreement, not what you want to include. But that is because, on the far-right edge and the far-left edge, you do not like the United States, and you do not like free trade, and that is why you hate the idea of a free trade agreement with the United States and now you try to throw gravel into the machinery. It is sad to see how the Social Democrats choose to dance after the right-wing and left wing. Investment protection has been turned into a red light, but it is frankly like Don Quixote's fight against windmills. It is not a question of restricting democracy. It is also a question of states respecting fundamental principles of law. Not to discriminate, expropriate or break the agreements entered into. All the President scans that. We are now negotiating an EU-US free trade agreement – the world's largest free trade agreement that could become the world's best free trade agreement for jobs and growth. That's why I get depressed when I hear the debate here. What a low self-esteem you have! You're just talking about what you don't want in the agreement, not what you want to include. But that is because, on the far-right and the far-left wing, you do not like the United States, and you do not like free trade, and that is why you hate the idea of a free trade agreement with the United States, and now you are trying to throw gravel into the machinery. It is sad to see, I think, how the Social Democrats choose to dance after the pipe of the right and left. Investment protection has been turned into a red light, but it is, frankly, like Don Quixote's fight against windmills. It is not a question of restricting democracy. It is also a question of states respecting fundamental principles of law. Not to discriminate, expropriate or break the agreements entered into. It shows all settled court cases. I challenged my colleagues to give me a single legal case that has restricted democracy, but I got nothing. Because it's ghosts, it's myths, it's windmills. No, the left's opposition to investment protection says very little about the problems of investment protection, but it unfortunately says a great deal about what legal principles the extreme right and the extreme left are willing to violate in order to realize their political utopias. That is precisely why we need investment protection, and that is why I will vote in favour of an ambitious agreement with the UNITED States with strong investment protection.

name: Joachim Schuster (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the Today, we are discussing the requirements of the European Parliament for the negotiations on the TTIP agreement with the United States. We are not deciding on the TTIP today, but we are giving the Commission what Parliament can accept as a result of the negotiations and what it cannot accept. It has been possible to take up many of the points that have been critically discussed by the public and to convert them into requirements for the Commission. I would like to highlight two points in particular. Firstly, we expect the agreements to establish workers' rights at a high level. This means, among other things, that all ILO core labour standards must be signed and adhered to. And it must be ensured that workers' rights are also enforceable. In other words, there must be a dispute settlement mechanism in which workers' rights can be ensonashed. These provisions are so important to us because it is a contribution to the fact that international competition does not lead to social and wage dumping. Secondly, I believe that this resolution makes it clear that the EP rejects the previous private arbitration tribunals, the ISDS, because this system violates the rule of law and democratic principles. The report presented places demands on the negotiations with the United States, but of course these requirements also apply to agreements which are about to be submitted to Parliament for ratification. It would be implausible to pretend that the proposed agreement with Canada and that with Singapore had nothing to do with our discussion on TTIP. In other words, according to all that is known so far about these agreements, neither the agreement with Canada nor that with Singapore can be approved, partly because the protection of workers' rights is not sufficiently guaranteed and partly because an ISDS is proposed that does not meet our requirements for investment protection. The Commission should take into account that the European Parliament also takes its position seriously and makes it the basis for decisions on the ratification of agreements.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: "I want a common zone of security and cooperation from California to the Black Sea. Such a zone is particularly needed by my region – Central and Eastern Europe – both a military and an economic American presence. I care about a lot of specific provisions, but I believe that the ESDS – a mechanism known in my region's bilateral transatlantic agreements – should be retained in TTIP. It increases the cohesion of the European Union, increases the competitive advantages of Central and Eastern Europe in transatlantic relations. We should, especially after the tragedy of Greece, look more favourably at transatlantic mechanisms and exercise a little more humility in assessing the effectiveness of European solutions.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I do not think there is anybody in this House who wishes to have a bad TTIP, or an unbalanced TTIP, or to lower the standards. I am sure the Commission has no other interests either. I should also say that we should have more confidence in our negotiations and in our ability to monitor and control. This brings me to the conclusion and to the view that the main reason why we differ, why we see and hear all these arguments, is that we just have different perceptions. We have different perceptions on free trade, current geopolitics and so on. So I think this is a fair assessment, and if that is the case, I think we should say so. I have listened very carefully to the Commissioner. Madam Commissioner, I have understood you very well and I have full confidence in what you have said. In fact, I would like to say one important final thing. Nobody in this House has said today, on the basis of this or that agreement, that we have reason to be concerned. Why? Because there is no similar agreement from the past that would justify some of the arguments that we are hearing on the far left or far right. The reality is that there would be only positive... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, first of all I would like to thank President Schulz for his contributions over the past few days to the political life of Greece. He said until he was ready to appoint a government of technocrats, which would replace the elected government. Even in the best times of colonialism we had not seen such interventions. And I want to thank him for showing the perception of democracy that also exists in this agreement that we are discussing, where instead of governments and peoples some politicians and basically multinational companies will decide.  There are discussions and we do not yet know the American proposals and we may never know them; There'll be mutants. Will there be a Republic? Mr . Schulz will not be here to ask him but you should know that after thirty years, colleagues who will vote in favour, your children may ask you what you voted for thirty years ago and you will not have what to tell them... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, we are the democratic arm of the EU institutions. Our job is to stand up for citizens and to tell you what they want, and I can tell you very clearly: they do not want TTIP. Well over 2 million have already petitioned the Commission to stop negotiating in their name. The only reason there are not more of them is that many people still do not know what TTIP is. TTIP is a threat to our public services and our democratic rights. It threatens to undermine the standards we fought for in areas such as air quality, water quality, safe food and animal welfare. It threatens the livelihoods of farmers in the South—West of the UK and across Europe. More trade is not the solution to our problems. It is a way to allow corporations to take control of more of our economy, and that is why they are driving this agenda. As a continent we are currently facing massive crises in Greece, with migrants in the Mediterranean, with conflict in the Middle East and Ukraine and with climate change. These are the problems we should be focusing on rather than wasting money on negotiations for a treaty that only serves corporations.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: I see congressman playing a blue card. Congressman, I would like to thank you for your We made the decision at the beginning of the debate that there is no blue card option, so we will keep the time frame. Please accept it.

name: Artis Pabriks (PPE).
text: – Madam President, TTIP is a unique chance to proactively shape European sustainable economic development and increase our geopolitical stability by shaping our continents – the United States and Europe – which are drifting apart. TTIP will also help small enterprises, increase our exports, create jobs and help to decrease poverty. It will actually strengthen our global values, and TTIP should also be concluded because exactly like this we can defend our national interests of Europe. TTIP should not and will not solve all our interests, and therefore it should not be treated as such. And because of this, I am also telling the opponents of TTIP or ISDS that if you want to be respected, please do not use your arguments which are based on lies or on wrong data, because otherwise it is very difficult to earn respect. We can eternally collect treaties or referendums saying that people are against something, but in the recent referendum on Greece we could see that maybe only 5% really understood what they were voting for. As a comparison, I would say that in my country, Latvia, which is poorer than Greece, I could easily make a referendum in the autumn not to lend money to somebody who is not respecting the rules. We shall respect the rules and we shall conclude such agreements if you really want to make a better life for our continent. Finally, I hope that political games will not also decrease the chance to conclude agreements such as CETA just because we do not like Americans.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I too, first of all, thank Mr Lange for his hard and hard work. And I want to start by stating two things: I believe that the market economy is the best way to ensure economic progress with a social state that corrects its failures and redistributes fairly, and I believe that international trade stimulates growth and employment. I respect those who do not believe in the market economy, in trade as an instrument that facilitates growth, and even those who believe that the United States is on the other side of the iron curtain.
