But, of course, these approaches do not respond to the principles of European social democracy. The objective of the TTE negotiations is to stimulate trade and investment between both sides of the Atlantic. It is currently at almost one billion euros a year and we do not have a treaty regulating how it is traded. And it is as important what is traded as how the goods that are traded are produced and how they are traded. The ATCI aims to achieve regulatory cooperation that will enable small and medium-sized enterprises to better access the US market better by not having to comply with two different regulations. That is why I support the negotiation of an agreement, but the Socialists will not support any agreement. We advocate an agreement that serves to promote the principles and values we share, to ensure the standards of protection we enjoy. To serve as a reference at the international level and to benefit citizens. I support the motion for a resolution which we are going to vote on tomorrow, which clearly sets out the European Parliament's position on negotiators in the main areas of TIC, meeting most of the demands of my group, the S&D Group, I support this resolution, because it strengthens labour rights, because it will end the current ISDS, based on private arbitration. We've taken a step forward, but it's not enough. We have a long way to go in this direction. I support this motion for a resolution, because it requires the United States to ratify international environmental agreements and because it guarantees the exclusion of public services. In short, I support this motion for a resolution because I want the European Parliament to influence and have the capacity to reach a good agreement.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I have to say that I see remarkable parallels between the debate on TTIP and the debate on the usefulness of the common European currency, the euro.  Because in both cases you find that there is a great fear, which is constantly being stoked and instrumentalized, a fear of changing anything in the status quo.  But we also need to think about what makes sense. Just as it makes sense for each country to have its own currency and not many different countries to have a common one, so it makes sense that goods and services can be traded freely.  That is why it makes no sense at all to always stoke these diffuse fears – against the repression of consumer protection or the repression of workers' rights or similar matters – these are things that must then of course be discussed, but which must not affect the fundamental principle of free trade.  The only thing that is really essential, and which again reveals typical European thinking, is the attempt to implement common uniform protection for investment projects. There is no legal basis for this in the European Treaties. Each country should be able to have its own rules and that, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The fact that the world's two largest economies, including democracies, are contracting with each other is something fundamentally good, and should not be so controversial and prompt so many completely unnuanced statements as we have heard here today. To the thousands of citizens in Sweden who have sent me worried e-mails, I would like to point out that the standards and values that we cherish in the EU should in no way be sacrificed or lowered by TTIP. In addition, products that do not meet the EU's high standards will not in future be approved on the European market. This also applies, of course, to hormone-treated beef or chlorine-bleached chickens, which have made headlines. It is important for the EU and the US to take the opportunity together to set the bar high for the defence of fundamental values relating to democracy, environmental security, the market economy and human rights, which are a matter of course for both our countries and should form the basis of global standards. I think it is quite fantastic that we have a Commissioner who has stood up and fought for this, and in a transparent way, and for that I would like to thank you.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, the determination here to get us to vote on a text in favour of the draft transatlantic treaty is more than suspect, at a time when new revelations show that our governments, heads of state and business are being listened to by North American leaders. This should have already led us to suspend the negotiations.  Moreover, the transatlantic project is an anti-European project because it will merge our economies into a vast single market called free trade, where multinationals will be the masters of the game, against states and peoples. We must not let what is being proposed to us take precedence over human rights.  This debate must come out of here, be focused on the European public square, and people must be consulted.

name: Michel Reimon (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I wonder why the proponents of TTIP are so little concrete when it comes to the benefits and mention only general benefits. Let us make it concrete: what are the advantages of Europe? In 2008, the US strictly regulated financial market products, and in Europe they are still unregulated. The TTIP is intended to break up the US financial market, and European banks and insurance companies should be able to sell their poorly regulated products well over there. This is a great advantage for our banks, but not for US consumers.  Fracking oil must not be exported from the UNITED States. The TTIP is intended to be able to import cheap oil into Europe. This is an advantage for European industry, unfortunately not for our environment. It should be said that much of the additional exports generated by TTIP are oil tankers crossing the Atlantic – that is what it is all about.  And thirdly, US public procurement is protected and local procurement. Europe's industry wants to break this up and open it up to European corporations. I do not know whether this is in the interests of American consumers. I do not believe that we as a Parliament should stand up for this. This is not about the United States against Europe, but about big corporations against everyone else.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab TTIP is an agreement that has a very broad scope and deals with many issues. So I will narrow down my speech to one or two of them: namely, who is to be the beneficiary of this agreement? I am astonded to hear statements here claiming that the beneficiaries will be banks, corporations, multinationals, cross-border companies.  I would like to say that, in my opinion, the main beneficiary of this agreement will be small and medium-sized enterprises, companies which represent 97-98% of all companies operating in the European Union and employ 60-70% of the workforce in each Member State. These companies do not have money, they do not have lawyers' staffs, access to international law firms. These companies have difficulties in trading, and therefore also in creating new jobs. For whom? – For Europeans, so these are the companies for which we are acting, slowly negotiating for this agreement. This agreement is needed by ordinary people, not just banks, the management of big corporations. Here you are talking about complete nonsense that cannot be accepted.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D).
text: Madam President, if we are to play our full role as European parliamentarians, I believe that we must be able to send a clear message to the Commission, which is negotiating on behalf of the European Union and which, admittedly, is surprisingly naïve when it comes to free trade, and sometimes - I must say - a form of blindness and naive logic. We must also send a clear message to our fellow citizens who have repeatedly seized on this subject and expressed a number of doubts and fears, often legitimate.  Bernd Lange's resolution is ambitious and, in many respects, it is ambitious, not least because Mr Lange is keen to reassure and protect workers and consumers, but it still contains too many ambiguous formulas, too many sophisticated formulas, too many complicated formulas which, in the end, we cannot be reassured.  On ISDS, we are not reassured and we must make it clear: we do not want a private arbitration system. Let's choose a public system. On public services, we are not reassured either. There are too many ambiguities. We need a real positive list that clearly excludes a number of sectors from liberalisation. Finally, on regulatory cooperation, we are not sufficiently reassured, because there are risks of harmonization from below. That is why we need to be clearer and more determined... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab TTIP raises, as we know, many public concerns and cannot be underestimated. It also raises many hopes in economic circles, including among small and medium-sized enterprises. However, the Union's negotiators should not forget that this agreement, if it is to be concluded, should benefit the union as a whole, that is to say, all the countries of the Union, rich and poorer, that the Union is a union of economically diverse countries. Certain protection periods will certainly be needed, for example the protection of the Polish chemical industry. The protection of product geographical indications is important. It is important to guarantee a level playing field for small and medium-sized enterprises, including by terminating the visa requirement for citizens of certain Union countries. By the way, it is also worth considering how long the ESDS is to be applied in trade relations between the Countries of the Union. If these and similar issues are not resolved, this agreement will only increase europe's division into a highly industrialised centre and a lag behind labour supply periphery.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I am in favour of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership. We need a good deal with the United States.  However, the investment protection mechanism envisaged as part of the agreement raises more questions than offers solutions. I refuse to believe that there are currently shortcomings in the re legal protection systems of the United States and EU Member States that require such an investment protection mechanism. If there are so many shortcomings, then there are serious problems with the rule of law as a whole.  There is currently thousands of billions of euros worth of trade between the UNITED States and the EU. Investors on both sides are either reckless or they are counting on fair treatment. It is hard to imagine why democratic communities would hand over power to private actors in this way when designed. I hope that a solution will be found to this issue and an agreement will be reached. I wish Commissioner Malmström strength and good luck. This is a big and important issue and the investment protection agreement is the most problematic point.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, this was a significant opportunity for the European Parliament. Millions of people across Europe have mobilised and they have asked this Parliament to defend democracy, the environment, workers’ rights, public services and our farming community by rejecting the Commission’s current approach to TTIP. This Parliament has missed that opportunity. This report, and the actions of the Office of the President and of the larger groups, have positioned the European Parliament not as the democratic voice of the people of Europe but rather as a very expensive rubber stamp for the Commission’s agenda. Make no mistake about it: opposition to the TTIP  deal that will undermine the very fabric of our communities is only going to grow in the time ahead. MEPs have now got to decide whether we are on the side of the people of Europe or on the side of vested corporate interests. I know what side I am on, and the people of Ireland and the people of Europe are going to be looking very closely to see what side other MEPs are on.

name: Max Andersson (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I was going to say a few words about the ACTA agreement, because it seems that history is about to be repeated. The ACTA agreement was a trade agreement negotiated during the last parliamentary term, and, as with TTIP, it started with a unanimous decision by the Member States. Public opinion in Parliament looked very positive; it seemed that it was a matter of course that the agreement should go through. But the longer the negotiations progressed, the more the criticism grew from scientists and from popular movements. The Commission published a document saying that everything was just myths. "Ten myths about ACTA" was called the document, which of course turned out to be incorrect. When it came time to vote, public opinion had awakened in earnest. Civil society mobilised and Parliament's groups took a stand against the ACTA agreement. The votes, 3 years ago last Saturday: 478 no and 39 yes. If the Commission does not listen, the TTIP agreement will go the same way.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I can only make it woodcut. Firstly, I wanted to say that I think it is great to see clearly once again how right-wing and left-wing radicals in Greece are in close cooperation on all issues in the TTIP. It shows where the opponents of democracy stand. The second is that we must see that this Treaty brings benefits to us. Free trade has always brought benefits. But it must be regulated in a sensible way. This has to do with jobs and the prosperity of our citizens. I am sure, Mrs Malmström, that it will be negotiated in such a way that our standards do not fall. This Parliament will not ratify any treaty in which this Parliament or the American Congress will relinquish its rights to set standards, both current and future. I assume that this will be taken into account in the negotiations. That is how I have always understood you. So: no lowering of standards! I am also sure that French film funding and the promotion of The German city theatre, such as the safeguarding of services of general interest such as water, will not be negotiated and will not be jeopardised. This, too, seems clear to me. These are all rumours that are being spread, which have nothing to do with reality. I am in favour of a medium-sized company that is discriminated against by American legislation against American companies being protected and not subject to an American legal process that it cannot pay for. That is why the issue of non-discrimination is crucial. The proposal that is now in the document that we negotiated with Mr Langen, and also in which direction you are moving, seems to me to be a way of ensuring that these arbitrations are governed by clear definitions, by the involvement of professional judges, and in this way the concerns are no longer present and these parliaments cannot be undermined.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to welcome the work of our rapporteur Bernd Lange, who is presenting an excellent draft report which deserves clear support from this House. And it deserves support because it contains firm demands for a good agreement in the TTIP: safeguarding social and labour rights, protecting the environment, food security and consumer rights, protecting public services, transparency of negotiations and, not least, the end of the private arbitration system, isds. All this is in this resolution.  It must be acknowledged that isds has raised legitimate abuses and concerns. But in order for the debate to be serious, we must also recognise that what is proposed to this plenary is the end of the private ISDS, as we know it. What is proposed is a completely new, public, transparent system, not with lawyers appointed by private investors, but with professional judges appointed by states and an appeal body. And that makes all the difference.  This report addresses a clear message to the negotiators: there will only be TTIP if these requirements are met. And that's why it's an important step towards a good ttip deal.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: – I basically agree with trade agreements because it is better for countries to trade with each other than if they were to wage wars. That is why I also basically welcome the TTIP agreement between the US and the European Union, but I have some serious reservations. Firstly, it is a lack of transparency. I have been criticising this for a long time. I think that the text of the agreement should have been published a long time ago so that all the groups concerned could have their say, and I think that this is precisely the water on the mill to the opponents of TTIP. Secondly, it is the introduction of new and further regulations. TTIP should primarily serve to remove administrative barriers, but introduces new barriers and regulations in several places. And thirdly, they are attempts to harmonise taxes. A low tax burden is a fully legitimate comparative advantage for Member States, and tax harmonisation means increasing their taxes. On the contrary, TTIP should guarantee autonomy in tax policy.

name: Charles Goerens (ALDE).
text: Madam President, how could investor-state disputes be resolved under the transatlantic partnership? Proposals and precedents exist.  Let us take the example of the World Trade Organization. If conflicting situations arise between two or more of its members, disputes can be resolved at the level of its dispute resolution body. It would not be up to anyone to question the authority of this arbitration body. Everyone accepts this forum because it is an offshoot of our states and it is institutional in nature.  Why, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, could we not draw inspiration from this example which works very well at the multilateral level? This should also be the case in a bilateral framework.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, thank you very much for the opportunity to speak here. Several MEPs from the EPP speak about lies: Mr Pabriks spoke about lies, Mr Caspary spoke about half-truths and then we had a Spanish MEP, Mr González, talking about a million new jobs. Well, if we want to talk about the truth, let us tell the truth. Our Minister with responsibility for this area, Richard Bruton, invited MEPs to a breakfast to discuss this issue. In the invitation he informed us that this agreement, if successful, would lead to an increase in growth of 0.5% GDP per year above what is now predicted. I asked him whether this was over one year – now remember we are talking about telling lies and telling the truth here – and he said yes. I asked him twice if it was over one year and he said yes. I asked him a third time and he said yes. That is a lie: the predicted growth is between now and 2027. It is not definite; it is the most ambitious scenario. Stick to the truth. Lies will not work here, Richard.

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The Ppe-DE Group, Mr von der GUE, will be true. But the truth is that experience has also shown that all the trade agreements we have concluded so far have led to more jobs and more economic growth in Europe. That is why Mr Pons was quite right to point out that, in our view, TTIP is not only a strategic decision for closer cooperation with democracy, with which we have much more in common than with many other democracies in the world, but also as a contribution to economic growth. Madam President, I believe that the Commission, with its transparency initiative, has greatly improved these negotiations, taken very much with its citizens in the European Union.  But these citizens, ladies and gentlemen, are not just consumers. I myself am a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Consumer protection is important. But the citizens are also employees – some even work for large corporations that do not have a good reputation here in this House. But they also earn their money there, and they earn the wages they deserve everywhere, and that is good wages everywhere in Europe.  That is why we want to ensure that this remains a development that will be a decision for all citizens of the European Union that goes in favour of these people in Europe. The European Commission has a mandate that goes in this direction. We want to strengthen this mandate with the resolution. I hope that all Members, including those who have spoken beforehand, will keep this objective. We want good standards for the people of Europe, and that will be possible with TTIP.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: – TTIP is more than a trade treaty. It is the creation of a single market between the EU and the US. Within the EU, we are still grappling with social problems. So we need to be vigilant about a new market adventure with a superpower like the US. , if public services such as education and health are excluded, and if there are no private ISDS tribunals for which investors can sue countries. We need to be clear: no ISDS in TTIP. Investors, like everyone else, can appeal to national public justice. International business does not need its own legal system outside the democratic rule of law. At the same time, we prevent states from influencing states and rules that we democratically enact through claims. Only a resolution that says very clearly: 'we do not need ISDS and we do not want it', can count on my support.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the creation of a free trade zone between Europe and the United States carries with it unprecedented economic potential. But one should not run away from the fact that it brings some challenges and even threats to the European way of life. Pretending that these challenges and threats do not exist opens the space for the fears of our citizens, but also for those irresponsible individuals and groups who use such intense feelings very opportunistically for the purpose of their own political gain, not caring for general progress. Therefore, I believe that it is in this home that we should work to reduce tensions instead of creating them. I will personally do everything in my power to objectively inform the citizens of Croatia about all aspects of this agreement, and I would like to see this approach with other fellow members.  This is about our future and the future of our children. Let us not dismiss it lightly, but also observe uncritically how others create it for us.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, we are therefore guiding the Commission in its work on a very important issue. Always, whenever borders have been opened to international trade and protectionism has been broken, peoples and societies have always benefited. There was an organization that said that any protectionism and protectionist measure is an attack on society. And, interestingly, it was the Trotskyists, who, as you will understand, are very distant from what we liberals and Democrats think and what this Parliament thinks. Then what you have to do is get it right. And that is where the role of this Parliament and the work of the Commissioner are involved. We are certainly confident that false debates, like the famous international court, will not deviate from what is important, because the first thing — as Mr Goerens has said, and here I support it — has one solution: an easy technical and democratic solution.

name: Rina Ronja Kari (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President! As the many popular protests have shown, there are major problems with the TTIP negotiations. Firstly, the crux of the agreement is that when something is approved somewhere, it must also be automatically approved elsewhere. This means that once the United States has approved a chemical, then we must also accept it in the European Union, even though we may be concerned about the health or environmental consequences. This undermines our democratic right to protect consumers. Secondly, multinationals have the right to sue democratically elected governments, regardless of whether there are small adjustments to the ISDS. Thirdly, TTIP will mean even more liberalisation of public tasks. And I could go on! Dear friends! More than 2.3 million Europeans have written and asked us to reject this agreement. Let us now show them that we are actually listening to them, both today and tomorrow.

name: Franck Proust (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, where we are here in this Chamber we have the sound in stereo. Whether it comes from the far right or the extreme left, the discourse is the same. End of our independence, end of our model of society. We are close to hearing that this will, in fact, be the end of the world.  However, you have to look at the outside world to understand the value of the negotiations. Asia, America, the Pacific and, recently, Africa are joining forces to confront globalization together, while in Europe we have populist movements that call for withdrawal. You overestimate the United States, but above all you underestimate Europe. Is this being patriotic? Is this being an alterglobalist? Negotiating is not selling one's soul, it is on the contrary an opportunity to put on the table what is wrong, not while being vigilant. You can negotiate, but not at any price. It is distressing to see all those who seek to give the TTIP a liability, when it has no past. Negotiating with the Americans means defending our multinationals in the face of Barack Obama's choice to change rules, it is defending our SMEs to open public markets for them, it is defending our know-how to allow companies to shine our gastronomy, especially French. It is also, ladies and gentlemen, to defend our consumers and fellow citizens by ensuring that they have a hegemony over international norms in a sometimes ferocious globalization. That is why I want to discuss and negotiate concretely instead of palaver. The pedagogy work of Mrs Malmstrom is necessary and makes me think that we can no longer afford to be ineffective... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Madam President, these negotiations could present a unique opportunity to re-regulate globalisation and promote the high standards on which the European Union prides itself, and they could offer a means of creating jobs and growth in regions like my own where we urgently need them. Trade is a tool: it is neither good nor bad. It all depends on the level of the rules set out in trade agreements, and Labour MEPs have set out exactly what we would like to see in a future TTIP deal: a full exclusion of public services, regardless of how they are provided, organised or financed; protection of our standards and our democracies; and no ISDS or special systems for foreign investors. We delivered the first two in the Trade Committee, but we did not deliver the third, and that is why Labour MEPs will reject ISDS unambiguously tomorrow. This resolution’s only purpose is to steer the Commission. A fudge on ISDS will not do this; it will not deliver a TTIP that we will be able to support in the future.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, this report presents the TTIP project, namely the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, as an opportunity for more growth and strengthening of the labour market. But the truth is that the profits from TTIP are uncertain and the threats to Greece and Greek citizens are certain. Concerns in the agricultural, environmental and social sectors are multiple. We will recall that the United States has not signed the most important international conventions on organic pollutants. TTIP endangers various Greek agricultural products that are registered as PDO, i.e. Designation of Origin Products, exported to the USA, and we risk being filled in Europe with genetically modified foods. Moreover, TTIP completely deregulates the European agricultural market and Greek olive oil will be irreparably affected. Finally, TTIP abolishes the existing system of judicial protection and the American multinationals in fact enjoy a heterogeneous right, and they can even appeal against the Member States of the European Union to special arbitration courts by bringing actions for damages of hundreds of millions of euros. Euro.

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We have been talking about Greece here this morning. What is missing from the country? There is a lack of economic growth, a lack of jobs, a lack of prospects for young people. What does such a country need, what do the other countries need, where the situation in which we have a social crisis is comparable? They need growth. They need economic growth that can create new jobs and prospects. TTIP is a growth programme without public debt. Those who are against TTIP are also opposed to young people in all those countries where the situation is as difficult as it is at the moment.  Then some here say: yes, that benefits large companies. Of course, it is useful for large companies to reduce tariffs, to reduce bureaucracy. But it also benefits medium-sized enterprises. It also benefits farmers who can export their oranges to the United States, as a Spanish colleague rightly pointed out. It is good for consumers if there are more products and services at lower prices. In other words, it will benefit society as a whole if we successfully negotiate this agreement to the end.  I find it debunking that the far-right and the far-left are making common cause here, and I particularly regret that the Greens are not closing in on this truly extremist attack on our growth prospects.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, something is puzzling me about this debate. Firstly, as Mr Schwab said, we have had free-trade agreements, which obviously are about economic growth and progress. Yet we have been led to believe that a free-trade agreement with the biggest power in the world would actually not create jobs and growth. This is mindboggling. Secondly, we are asked to reject TTIP now as if it were a fait accompli, when in actual fact it says right up there: negotiations for TTIP. That is no fait accompli – it is a work in progress. So let us have faith in our negotiators, let them deal with the issues we are concerned about. In my country, we are very concerned, as Mr Nicholson pointed out, that maybe agriculture might become a bargaining chip. We do not want that to happen. ISDS is a big issue, but Commissioner Malmström’s proposals are a major step forward compared with what we have had in the past. I say, like mature people, let us vote on TTIP when we have TTIP to vote on.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, all too often and deliberately, today's debate and the vote on the Lange resolution with the final vote on TTIP have been confused. Today we are not approving TTIP. The Commission is conducting a negotiation, which will be long and difficult and the outcome of which is not a foregone conclusion. There will therefore be a time when we should say yes or no to a treaty: that moment has not yet arrived. At an important stage in the negotiations, the resolution clearly sets out our priorities: protecting geographical indications, access to the US market for our small and medium-sized enterprises, overcoming old ISDS and protecting our social, health and environmental standards. These are some of our conditions for achieveing, for Europe, for its growth and its competitiveness. What is at stake is not just a trade agreement but a rewriting of the rules of globalisation. Who but Europe will be able to redefine the parameters of fairer globalisation that respects everyone's social and environmental rights? A good TTIP can be an important piece of it. Faced with this challenge, the European Parliament, like Europe, can choose whether to play as a protagonist or remain silent, while waiting for others to decide for us. Europe's concerns, desires and hopes are clearly expressed in Mr Lange's report. Tempus fugit: it is up to us to choose whether to keep up with history or condemn ourselves to oblivion.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for We will not decide on TTIP tomorrow.  We decide on the clarification, the deepening, on changes to the mandate given by the European Parliament. That is right and proper, because we, as the Chamber of Citizens, are responding to the questions and concerns of the citizens. That is why I also support the compromise for reformed investor protection and appeal to my colleagues from the Social Democrats and the Greens to inform about the facts, about the compromises, about the common commitment to a free trade agreement and to end the shadow boxing. They build images of enemies that do not correspond to reality. The report takes away fears, and you are still cheerfully moving on – that is a pity. We want to regulate globalisation and work for a global economic and social order. We in the European Parliament have the last word, and this will not be spoken today, but in two years' time at the earliest.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to thank Mr Lange for his work. I think there has been a proposal for a correct resolution. We would all have liked a few more things to have been collected, but I think it is a good motion for a resolution and a good starting point for this Parliament. In my opinion, I think it is essential for Parliament to show what its approach is in the negotiating process being carried out. I want there to be a resolution and not for any. Especially since it's not just one more trade treaty. No. It has a geopolitical component, which many Members have evidently highlighted, and for the first time, negotiation focuses not on tariffs, but on convergence or harmonisation of rules. That's why it's very important. Europe has a great interest in its agri-food system and that is why it is important, Mrs Malmstrom, that the rules be protected and clear; reflected in the agri-food system, quality protection with appellations of origin and PGIs – it is a great opportunity – environmental sustainability, agri-food security and our productive model. And, of course, I would like to make it clear, very clear, from the Social Democratic Group, that I reject the private dispute settlement courts, not only in TTE, but in all the treaties in which they are collected.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – Madam President, in the years to come 90% of world growth and demand will be generated outside the European Union. That is why the European Union must remain open and needs trade agreements. We all know that today trade is no longer only about tariffs: it is about standards, sustainable development and consumer safety. It requires different, much more complex, agreements. We need agreements that would open new markets, increase investment opportunities, make trade cheaper, easier and faster, set common rules on technical and sanitary standards, make the trade environment predictable, and also provide for a joint commitment in areas that affect trade, such as intellectual property rights, competition, and public procurement rules. TTIP’s role is also to launch a progressive elimination of barriers to investment, and that is why we also need protection for our European investors, legal certainty and transparency, and a generally secure investment environment. That is why we need to push forward with the negotiations and conclude them sooner rather than later.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a year ago we were having a debate in this House on the transatlantic partnership to affirm our willingness to exercise our duty of vigilance and our power of influence in a firm way throughout the negotiations. On this occasion, we had clearly expressed Parliament's priorities and red lines about this agreement: transparency, scrupulous respect for all the laws and collective preferences that underpin our European social model, the highest standards in environmental, public health, food security, social rights and fundamental rights, the protection of our geographical indications. , our public services and cultural diversity and, finally, the exclusion of private arbitration to settle investor-state disputes. The resolution before us echoes many of these concerns and I would like to sincerely thank our colleague Bernd Lange for the excellent work he has done.  However, this text is not sufficient, as it remains unclear on the issue of ISDS. However, no compromise can be envisaged on this major issue. Therefore, I call on us to vote clearly in favour of Amendment 27, which is being proposed to us. For me, national courts have perfect jurisdiction to rule on disputes between investors and states.  ISDS is not necessary, either in the short term or in the long term, and its use must be excluded, as requested by European citizens, trade unions and associations. It's imperative!

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, the agreement must be mutually beneficial for all, especially small and medium-sized businesses. It represents a historic chance for us - to set the high standards on the global stage. I believe that energy should be part of this agreement. The European Union really needs to diversify its energy supply. Unilateral visa restrictions for citizens of Bulgaria, Romania, Poland, Cyprus and Croatia are discriminatory and should be lifted. Many myths and false claims are spreading, although we do not yet have a text agreed between the two parties. These speculations must be dispelled and ensure that environmental protection standards, the health of European citizens and the right of states to regulate in the public interest are not compromised. It is a pity the use of ideological opposition by populists, nationalists and communists, and the leading absolute distortion of the debate about the potential benefits and risks of the agreement. I am convinced that the European Parliament will only support the future agreement if it meets the interests of citizens and their voice is heard.

name: Goffredo Maria Bettini (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, never before have we been in the balance with our European future. We are paying for insufficient unity and a frightening weakness in politics. We seem to be under siege. Terrorism, refugees, slow growth, mutual isolation between us and Russia and, finally, the upheaval of Greece, with uncertain and dangerous results after the referendums. The TTIP resolution proposed here is a positive blow. A silent European Parliament would have been a further negative signal. Today we are not making a final decision: we are giving guidelines to the negotiators. The landing achieved, thanks in particular to the constancy, intelligence and firmness of President Lange, I consider it a victory also of the Socialists, their vision and their fundamental principles. TTIP is not good or bad. It is not a fetish, a myth, a symbol: it is a measure that can become, if it is done wrong, harmful, if done well, precious. There is no need to make beautiful souls, or worse hide behind ideologies. The merit and substance of the document we approve contains the defence of fundamental standards on the environment and the protection of workers, the health of citizens and human rights. We know that there are different views in this Parliament on ISDS, but I am not interested in the feedback of the other groups, their ... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE).
text: –Madam President, I do not think you have rightly pronounced my name, and that is why I did not stand up.  It seems undeniable to me that the agreement with the United States will have obvious advantages for both sides of the Atlantic, which will objectively translate into more jobs, more production, more choice for consumers and also new opportunities for citizens, especially for younger people. That is why I believe it is essential to respect the difficult balance reached in INTA with regard to the common position of the European Parliament that we are discussing here today.  We know that our fellow Europeancitizens and our American partners are following with interest the debate we are doing here today. I would therefore like to stress the importance of defending designations of origin and geographical indications in the framework of this agreement, but always, always, with a view to wider protection at global level. It is that many of our European traditions are linked to our territory, which is, of course, diverse. In addition, they represent relevant sources of income and population fixation in the territory in various regions of the Union. I welcome, finally, the inclusion of the protection of geographical indications in the text of the recommendation and I hope that these principles will never be forgotten by the negotiating team and the European Commission.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: Thank you, Congressman, and I apologize to you for mis-inging your name.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE).
text: – Madam President, colleagues, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent work. It is said that the ostrich, the bird, places its head in the sand in the event of a threat so that it does not see this danger. Similarly, perhaps there are politicians, especially in the extreme flank of this house, who, fearing globalisation, are somehow now trying to pretend that they can somehow simply prevent it by the willpower. But what is the fact? The fact is that globalisation happens, whether someone likes it or not. So what do we do? We should act in such a way that we, Europe, are the drivers of globalisation, not the rear-racers. And together with the United States, we control more than half of the world's gross domestic product. This means that, by creating a strong transatlantic trade agreement, Europe would not be the one who would suffer any threat, but would be the rule-setter of the game. Colleagues, let us support the creation of this Treaty. Thank you!

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – This agreement is one of the answers to a changing world. I think it is right that we pay particular attention and a high degree of transparency to such an important and ambitious project with long-term implications for transatlantic cooperation.  I am not surprised that the general public is so intensely interested in this agreement and requires political and legal guarantees to maintain standards related to health, food, the environment and culture. I find it too little to insist on maintaining the standards in question. The common ambition should be to improve such standards through a common regulatory framework for the good of the people.  It is not only about increased trade volumes and geostratetic interest, but also about the quality of the goods on which the quality of our lives depends.  I am pleased that we have made progress with regard to the system for resolving disputes between investors and countries, which is extremely important both for the protection of investors and for the protection of the public interest with regard to the private interest.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, at a time when growth and job creation must be our top priority, we have an instrument like TTE which will undoubtedly boost growth and job creation in all the countries of the European Union, without exception. And if there is one sector that will benefit from this agreement, it is undoubtedly that of small and medium-sized enterprises, genuine drivers of job creation in the European Union. But moreover, if we are to be globally relevant, if we want our standards and values to be a global benchmark, we need to act together with the United States. It is therefore important that the resolution we are debating today and that we are going to vote on has majority support, so that our Commissioner and the whole College of Commissioners have the political support that gives them the strength to negotiate with the United States.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We Europeans should seize the opportunity to negotiate a fair free trade agreement with the United States of America. I believe that the removal of trade barriers, the removal of tariffs and the development of common technical standards can only be beneficial for both sides. But we should also make it clear to our American negotiating partners what cannot be done with us Europeans. In this respect, I am very grateful for the resolution, Mr Lange. Thank you for your months of work, which you have also put into the resolution. Thank you to all colleagues. I think it is important to show that we do not want to lower our standards and that, above all, we also want a system change at ISDS. We want to move away from private arbitration to the establishment of an international bilateral commercial court. I trust, Commissioner, in your conduct of the negotiations and wish you good luck, our support, and work with the Americans on a constructive new proposal that goes straight away from the arbitral tribunals towards an international commercial justice system, then you also have our full support.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I take today's debate as a debate on a resolution adopted by the INTA Committee that needs to help negotiators continue on this very important agreement. I don't think we Europeans should miss this opportunity, but of course we are sensitive, that our citizens want to know more information. It is up to us parliamentarians who have the right to see the documents – I have visited the room where documents can be read several times – to transparently approach our citizens what this is all about because ignorance is the greatest fear. Out of ignorance, these oppositions are always born. Therefore, I am also in favor of taking into account GMO products, public services, water, medical services – everything that adheses our citizens, especially employees and the labour market. So I think we need to support the negotiators, that this is an agreement of a strategic character - it is not only trade but will abolish some tariffs, but it will bring much more to Europe, small and medium-sized entrepreneurs, jobs. Therefore, I am in for an agreement, but, of course, with equal bargaining with the Americans.

name: Thomas Mann (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The transatlantic economic area can only bring prosperity to both sides if it is properly designed with balance, transparency and equal footing. In the European Parliament, 15 committees have drawn up opinions and taken into account many doubts of concerned citizens. My amendments were adopted in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs – for example, that EU standards must not be watered down or overridden: workers' rights, social security, vocational training, social dialogue. If the areas are at risk, we must be informed without delay in order to bring about change. ILO core labour standards, such as freedom of association or the right to collective bargaining, must be in place. The United States has not committed to them, but has not ratified them. I very much welcome the compromise in the Lange report. I am against private arbitration courts and in favour of the establishment of a European Court of Arbitration: responsible, constitutionally compliant with the rule of law procedures that cannot be overridd. We must seize the opportunity, Madam President, in contrast to slogans from the unholy alliance of right-wing radicals and left-wing radicals in this House.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I think that we need to draw attention to a point that is not technical, but which is political: it is essential that it is essential to have an agreement between the European Union and the United States in the context of current globalisation. It is the only way that the values that we have in terms of human rights, first but environmentally, in terms of labour rights, and which are shared values, even when they have some differences, can be imposed in the framework of globalisation. And so what is at stake here, much more than a technical standard or a gain here or a gain there, is a real political agreement of great importance.  Then I would like to say that I am quite satisfied with the progress that has been made in the issue of conflict resolution, but that I would be much happier if we were able or to have set up a permanent arbitral tribunal, proper to that institution, or to create a judicial institution just for this agreement. I think we would gain in transparency and I think we would gain confidence in the legal order.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – TTIP is the largest, but only one of many agreements that already exist in the world today and which aim everywhere to be the same: to improve cooperation and to achieve benefits for all parties. Europe is thus offered the opportunity for new economic momentum, for new jobs. And it wouldn't be wise to turn down such a one-off opportunity. However, TTIP is not only an economic agreement, it is also a geopolitical, strategic arrangement between two parties that cherish similar or equal values. I am very pleased that the political groups have also managed to reach agreement on one of the key issues that has bothered us all, on the way in which disputes are resolved. And of course I support a better ISDS that will be fairer and protect our investors. The European economy depends on external growth and it is right that we should offer it a new opportunity with TTIP.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Lange told us it is worth a fight. I would say it is mandatory for it to be concluded and implemented – with all the safeguards, of course – because it is a unique opportunity to take control of globalisation and base it on democratic safeguards. If we miss this opportunity, hiding behind a multitude of details and protectionist requirements, the next chance is not certain to come. Today the crucial issue is not TTIP; the crucial issue is to finally come out of sluggish economic growth. And TTIP helps us to do this, because it means an economic boost, more jobs, more trade and more SME opportunities. It is the best incentive for innovation, competitiveness and completing our own single market, and therefore complaining about poor growth and unemployment while at the same time rejecting TTIP is hypocritical and runs against the very basic principles of the European Union.

name: Lara Comi (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, TTIP can represent a trade agreement with great potential and benefits for the European market and for European businesses, both economic and commercial, growth and employment benefits: that is the objective for us. But at the same time also facilitate the entry into the American market many of our economic realities, make our companies, our European products more competitive, especially those of excellence, what we actually define from made in Italy to Made in Europe. And that must be one of our priorities. My hope is that through this agreement we can offer good opportunities for our small and medium-sized enterprises. Everything we are doing in this Parliament is aimed at small and medium-sized enterprises, from the Small Business Act to everything we have passed and approve every day. I am also referring to the agricultural market and, above all, to the objective of identifying the appropriate rules for the indication of origin of products for the proper protection of our consumers. This is a focal point for us.

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE).
text: Madam President! TTIP is good for growth and for more jobs in Europe, and I am not going to take the time to repeat what many of my PPE colleagues have already said today. The european single market has proved its worth and created jobs. TTIP is a mirror of the internal market and I would like to draw attention to the debate we had over ten years ago in 2002 when we decided to include ten new Eastern European countries in the European Union. At the time, many western European countries were also concerned about workers' rights, unequal competition, high hourly wages and expensive energy prices. But what exactly happened? It has happened, of course, that, for example, the European Parliament has not been able to take part in this. Poland has tripled its GDP per capita and an expensive country such as Denmark has increased exports from 10 to 19 billion. We were not outcompeted by cheap energy prices; we were not outcompeted by cheap hourly wages. So this is a question of whether we want more trade and more jobs. Now is the time to set the standards for 800 million consumers, standards that Chinese and Indians and others must adhere to.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – Congratulations to my colleague Lange on the resolution. TTIP is vital to the continued existence and development of the European Union. We all know that economic power is key to this. If we are more economically strong, we will be more easily able to neutralise some of the Other Weaknesses of the European Union, such as weak energy sources, poor demographic trends, rising security risks, a governance crisis, the european Union's declining strength in international policy, etc. and TTIP is a great opportunity for economic revitalisation, for jobs, for greater competitiveness.  Removing trade and investment barriers will bring welfare to both European and Us businesses and households. Europe in particular will gain. I wonder why some MEPs are against these well-beings of the European Union. I have an answer, but not time to explain.  Dear! The EU accounts for only 7% of the world's population. If we do not create optimal conditions for management, we will be even more weak and vulnerable in the future.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner, I would have liked more reason in today's discussions and less passion and cheap politicism. Anyone who does not want a trade agreement between two big markets does not think they want the good of citizens. No businessman would ignore a trade agreement! Any trade and investment agreement must be negotiated and not rejected! We are actually giving a mandate to the Commission and the Commissioner for Negotiation today and we are not voting on an agreement! Here's intoxication and manipulation in many Member States! Petitioners don't know what we're voting for today! We have a duty, during the negotiation, to go back to our countries and explain to citizens what we want with this agreement.  In my country I have made a public debate with secret ballot. Commissioner, the citizens of Romania want this agreement, but I want you to negotiate it with transparency, to ensure harmonisation of product standards, to ensure access to the market for SMEs and, obviously, without a private court. That is why I believe that we, now, should stand in solidarity as the European Parliament and give a fair mandate to the Commissioner and the Committee for Negotiation. And I also want, as a Romanian, to ask you, Commissioner, that Romanians also benefit from the removal of visas for the United States.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I will support this negotiating mandate because we need this agreement soon, with a more transparent negotiation and democratic control. We set ourselves the standards that will govern trade and work in the world, and we prefer them to look like ours. This agreement brings us closer to this goal. TSC also favours SMEs, which offer 80% of employment and do not have the means and alliances of multinationals to operate in Europe and the United States. Market opening will stimulate competition. The agreement will promote internationalization, new strategic alliances between companies, another way of collaborating and competing and the emergence of new opportunities. We share the red lines we put on the negotiators and we need to defend European standards. And we want to replace the fear, doubts, particular interests and rejection that the agreement raises at both ends of the House with trust, and get a good deal. With TTE we will confirm that in Europe we practice innovation and take care of knowledge. And Europe has to be an actor, a leader in the global world, and this is the way... (The Chairperson interrupts the speaker)

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, in Greece, the Syriza Government called a referendum to consult the people on the measures that the European institutions intend to impose on them. A lesson in democracy that some should learn from. For example, the People's Party, the Socialist Party, CiU, UPyD and the PNV voted against the United Left's proposal for the ATCI to submit to a referendum in the Spanish state. They also despise the outcome of the European Commission's consultation on isDS, with 97% rejection of these arbitration tribunals where multinationals will be able to denounce States. And today, the People's Group and the Socialist Group, today, the Conservatives and the Social Democrats agree on a make-up version of this ISDS, ignoring the views of citizens. What's your problem with democracy?

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – We have heard several times today what efforts are made to/against the adoption of the agreement. I would, of course, say that we have heard that this agreement should not reduce standards, but I think that in the European Union we must strive to raise standards in many areas, including the environment, social security, in the field of work. I would also like to draw attention to the ratification by the US of only two of the eight fundamental fundamental conventions in the area of fundamental rights and the EU to all eight. And the US has not even ratified the most basic international documents in the field of fundamental social rights, such as the European Social Charter of the Council of Europe or the UN International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights.  And it is precisely these standards that can then constitute that obstacle that will lead to the use of different mechanisms against Member States as an obstacle to capital in obtaining even greater profits. And that is why we are also drawing attention to this aspect, which must be extremely important, and that is why we are also asking the US to sign and to accede to all these international agreements, which are fundamental.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, mystification, deceit, anti-democratic fraud: only in this way can we call this so-called free trade treaty, which is the wildest and most aggressive triumph of hyperliberalism; a weapon that in one fell swoop aims to erase decades of European struggles for workers' rights, health, food safety and the environment. There is not a single serious and independent study to ensure employment growth. Moreover, you offend these rights by calling them non-tariff barriers, while we regard them as democratic barriers. Commissioner, you and all of you have simply ignored the word of the citizens: 97% said no to ISDS, no to private arbitration, no. Yet try again to propine it in disguise, precisely by making sure that the right of all is attacked by the profit of the few. This is no longer democracy: this is 'Schulzcracy', ladies and gentlemen, listen to the voice of small businessmen, farmers and workers, listen to the voice of your conscience, have courage and say no.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – We see it on the Greek issue, and here in the TTIP debate we see that the European Union is not as abhorrent to anything as it is to the opinions of the people and to real democracy. Nevertheless, I am now quoting from a letter quoted by 50 Hungarian public figures: "We demand the suspension of negotiations on the transatlantic trade pact, the final rejection of this dirty deal. We expect meps delegated by the Hungarian Government, the National Assembly and the Hungarian electorate to do their utmost not to bring into force this trade deal that will supply nation states to multinationals." It should be acknowledged that you need to hear people's voices. In doing so, the Hungarian people joined a civil movement of 2.3 million European citizens already composing 477 European organisations called Stop TTIP. I also encourage my fellow Hungarians and our European friends to join this initiative as many people as possible.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to respond to some of the objections that have been raised here, but what I consider to be the most fundamental is the lack of trust. It seems to me that, in the negotiations to be undertaked by the European Commission, our own confidence in this Commission that it will negotiate an agreement that is acceptable to the Member States, to the Europeans, is lacking. At the same time, trust with the United States of America is lacking, as if it were not our most natural partner, as if it were not our partner who shares our own values. I do not know with whom else some of my colleagues would like to negotiate a free trade agreement, whether with Russia or with China, whether these countries adequately represent the values on which we can rely with the United States of America. I would therefore call for us to have more faith in the institutions that we choose and which are to have our confidence that they will negotiate a balanced and good agreement on both sides. I firmly believe in her.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, considering the latest developments in negotiations for the TTIP, I would like to express my pleasure that the report contains important demands, namely strong protection of labour rights and ratification of the International Labour Organisation conventions, high environmental standards, protection of public services and also protection of our food and health safety standards. I consider that this is a unique opportunity for the European Parliament to have a strong position in the negotiations between the European Union and the United States by setting up important standards on international trade. I congratulate the rapporteur on the compromise negotiated to oblige the Commission to exclude ISDS from the trade agreement, and I support the compromise amendment which replaces the ISDS with a new public, democratic and transparent system that functions on an appellate mechanism where private interests cannot undermine public policy objectives. TTIP is a huge opportunity, a necessity.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, sometimes the European Union – you and the Commission – are accused of debating things that are not really of relevance to the citizens. I think this debate has proven that this has not been the case today. We are debating something that many people around the European Union and elsewhere actually do care about and follow very closely. It is clear that there are many concerns. I also meet citizens who have concerns and who share them with me. But I also want to remind you that overall a majority of European citizens support those negotiations. They might not be as vocal as those who are against, but their voice is also important. That is also democracy. Let me answer some of the questions. There was a question from the Committee on Development (DEVE) on the impact of TTIP on developing countries. We are doing a study on this in the Commission, and it will be published later this autumn. The preliminary results show there is actually very little impact on our neighbours and on developing countries, but we can come back to that once it is published. Regarding GMOs, our legislation will not change. What is prohibited in Europe today will remain prohibited; we will not change our laws on consumer protection; REACH standards will not be lowered, and we will stick very strongly to our precautionary principle. On ISDS, this is a chance we have together to reform an old system. That system dates from the 1950s. You represent – all of you but one – countries who have many of these bilateral agreements already. You might like them, you might not like them, but they exist and we have to face that. So this is an opportunity to really get rid of an old—fashioned system to create something new – something that clearly spells out that states have the right to regulate in order to protect their citizens. This can never be called into question. That brings procedures which are transparent and open, with court-like systems, judges and a system of appeal, leading to an international court – starting with TTIP but moving towards an international court. This is something that is being discussed all over the world. We have the highest number of these – more than 3 000 agreements. So let us take the chance – the world is watching us – to reform this system and create something really new. We can jointly show leadership here.  I also want to address the audiovisual issue. The Committee on Culture and Education (CULT) raised this. Liberalisation of the audiovisual sector is excluded from the mandate, as you know. Book pricing is not up for negotiation, and TTIP will not impose any obligation on any Member State to provide financial support to culture industries. There is also the question of jobs. Of course there are many studies being published in this regard. Most of them point in the same direction. This House – you – in September 2014, less than a year ago, published a paper with an in-depth analysis of the expected impact of TTIP on EU Member States. There was a hearing in the Committee on International Trade (INTA). It underlines that several studies generally confirm the trend that TTIP is expected to lead to benefits for the European Union as a whole, and the results are largely convergent. There are one or two divergent studies, but they use a different methodology. However, in your study you also say that the model used by the Commission in its impact assessment, and by others, is the most appropriate. We are also accused of not listening to concerns. Well, transparency has increased, thanks to your concerns and those of many others. We are about to reform the old ISDS system dramatically. We have made clear statements with the United States on public services. We are highlighting the need for SMEs, because they will be the big winners on this. We will continue to engage with you and others. Let me also remind you that the mandate to negotiate TTIP has been given by 28 countries unanimously and endorsed by this House as well. Why? Because Member States are convinced – and I think a majority of you are convinced – that trade agreements are good for Europe. 90% of growth in the coming years will come from outside Europe. We need to be there. Despite seeing light at the end of the tunnel in the economic crisis, we are still not out of it. We need jobs. We need growth. We need investments. There are many ways to do this, but TTIP and the other trade agreements that we are negotiating are a part of that struggle. Member States, and you, are closely involved in those negotiations now and in the months to come. When I and my team negotiate, we will never – nor will the Member States and nor will you – accept a TTIP that will lower protection for people or for the environment. Nobody will accept a TTIP that will restrict our right to provide new protections in the future. Nobody will accept a TTIP that gives companies unfair rights through secret tribunals. Nobody will accept a TTIP that will undermine Europe’s proud tradition of providing high-quality public services for our people. Instead we want a partnership – efficient, creating opportunities for European workers, consumers and SMEs – that allows us in Europe to be the shaper of globalisation, not a passive observer; a partnership based on close cooperation between this Parliament, national parliaments, Member States, the Commission and lots of stakeholders out there. Your resolution is forward—looking, and if it is voted through – as I hope it will be tomorrow – that will help to give a clear platform for TTIP. It helps us to negotiate an ambitious, comprehensive and balanced agreement. This is what it is all about. This is what we want to deliver for Europe. (Applause)

name: n/a
text: Thank you very much, and I would like to apologise to the Commissioner for making such a noise. I understand that a vote will be held soon, but I ask my fellow Members to wait patiently. I'd like to give the floor to the rapporter, Mr. Lange, to conclude the debate.

name: Bernd Lange
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to make three points at the end of this debate. Firstly, the resolution is not a resolution on ISDS. We have raised a whole range of issues in the resolution, which addresses the European values that we want to see implemented in a trade treaty. So, ladies and gentlemen, look at the resolution. It is a very broad resolution on cultural diversity, on services of general interest, on services, on data protection, on workers' rights. ISDS seems to me to have become something of a symbol. I would also ask those who are very critical of this to perceive a development. I share the criticism of private arbitration tribunals – no question. But I have not heard anyone in the debate today defending private arbitration courts. I firmly believe that private arbitration courts are dead and no longer belong in commercial contracts. We must enforce this in the TTIP, but also, of course, in the 1 300 existing bilateral trade agreements concluded in the Member States. This will not be an easy task to reconcile with the partner countries. Let us work together to impose a new system that complies with the rule of law. This requires a lot of strength. I have heard many fears – formulated in the subjunctive, because of course no one knows exactly what will come out at the end of the day. We want to discuss this very moment and adopt the resolution tomorrow, so that the concerns and needs do not become a reality. We want to make it clear where we stand. This is not a firlefanz, but a clear mandate for the European Commission, with which we will assess – when there is a text – whether we can accept this text or not. Ladies and gentlemen, not only defend something defensively, but sometimes you can also make improvements! We should also argue about this, for example on workers' rights. If it becomes a bad agreement, we will reject it. If it becomes a good one that is in line with our ideas, we will agree to it. Ladies and gentlemen, I have worked very inclusively. Fourteen committees have delivered opinions, and many of my fellow Members have tabled amendments. I want us to send out a strong signal together. I know that not everyone is 100% satisfied with a compromise, nor can it be. But if we take Parliament's institutional role seriously, ladies and gentlemen, I would ask everyone, perhaps one or the other, to throw one or the other overboard concerns and to vote together tomorrow for a strong signal!

name: elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Wednesday 8.7.2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The Lange Report still leaves many of the main problems with TTIP unaddressed. Both the ISDS and the so-called compromise are deeply flawed. The report does not do enough to protect public services in the Member States. I am supportive of free trade, but this agreement as it stands appears to be a corporatist trade agreement. Furthermore, I deplore the manner in which – at every stage – transparency has been a pipedream, and debate even in this chamber has been suppressed.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I have received more emails from my constituents on the subject of TTIP than on any other in the 11 years that I have been an MEP. Few people realise that the UK’s trade policy was surrendered to the EU when we joined in 1973. The main concern of my constituents is that the proposed ISDS mechanism would enable foreign corporations to take our government to court if it failed to comply with a TTIP requirement. This would not be in a civil court of law subject to the law of contract, but rather in a secret tribunal if government policy were to infringe TTIP. In particular my constituent concerns, which I share, are that areas such as the NHS could be opened up to private international companies; and this could not be altered later even if a democratically elected government chose to change the policy. Whether this will or will not be included in the final treaty remains to be seen, but from my point of view I will oppose TTIP because UK trade policy should be decided by the UK Government and not the European Union.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Commission has been negotiating with the US since July 2013 this partnership which could create the largest free trade area in the world. Previous trade agreements between the EU and the US have shown significant benefits for the European economy, trade and investment, generating new jobs and growth. Now, however, we are talking about a partnership that could create the largest free trade area in the world.  The report follows on to the resolutions adopted in the previous legislature in October 2012 and May 2013 on negotiations with the United States on trade and investment. Despite the many critical voices among the European public on the agreement under negotiation, I have chosen to support this report, which calls for more transparency from the Commission on negotiations, an agreement that respects European values, stimulates sustainable growth and contributes to the well-being of all citizens, improving the ISDS mechanism (investor-state dispute resolution) and also emphasising the geopolitical importance of concluding such a partnership.  The partnership must take into account both economic challenges, economic interests and citizens' concerns.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – Tomorrow we finally vote on this report. I have consistently called for major amendment of the report to ensure that our public services, food, health, environmental and labour standards in Scotland are protected. I also reject any form of ISDS and I want a clear exemption for Scotland’s NHS. With an overwhelming mandate from the many thousands of constituents I have heard from, I will vote for radical amendments, in line with the position set out by SNP members at our recent conference. As an SNP MEP, I remain pro-democracy, not anti-trade. For Scotland, the USA is our largest trading partner outside the EU. Therefore, I sincerely hope that the Commission and Council will listen to the serious concerns surrounding TTIP, all of which have been made crystal clear in the recent round of political wrangling in Strasbourg and Brussels. The language used in President Schulz’s so-called compromise on ISDS is unacceptable, allowing for a new mechanism for dispute resolution that we simply do not need. We already have law courts. This approach exemplifies the report’s failure to categorically exclude Scotland’s NHS and public services from TTIP negotiations, despite endless assurances from the European Commission, and others, to this effect.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - The TTIP debate is not a debate that will immediately result in a vote, but is, today, a debate by the European Parliament to send a clear message to the European Commission on our views. TTIP is basically a document that aims to regulate through legal mechanisms what has been on the scene for years: globalization! It is important to bear in mind that globalization is happening without having legal regulations that will follow the reality of the time in which we live. TTIP is also a chance for many large and small businesses that have competitive products and services. I believe that Croatian companies will also have their interest in a new even bigger market because it has been shown that by joining the European Union, a huge market has been opened for our companies that have significantly increased exports.  As the market of the Member States of the European Union has become an opportunity that is successfully used to increase employment in Croatia, so can it be with a new large market that offers entry into the US market. Also, there is a new attractiveness that tourism gets. What we definitely need to regulate through TTIP is the protection of European interests that go from agriculture policy and environmental protection through public sector interests to cultural policy. In this context, the European Commission should take into account these specificities in the negotiations with the US in all negotiations.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – It raises doubts about the transparent functioning of the EU, which has been taking place in the EU institutions in recent months in relation to TTIP. Yet the story got off to an encouraging start: last year, the Commission launched a social debate on the fta dispute settlement mechanism, where 97% of the more than 150,000 people involved said no to ISDS, in support of the EU not to give foreign investors prerogatives over national governments or authorities. In a few months, the European Civil Initiative 'Stop TTIP' has collected more than two million signatures in 14 Member States, obliging the Commission to give a formal response to a motion calling for the halt to the TTIP negotiations and the abandonment of ISDS, which the European Parliament must also hear. But there seems to be too much business interests at stake for EU citizens to decide. The two largest ep factions, the EPP and S&D, have had Parliament adopt a report which, by rewritten the original proposal, has not clearly rejected isds, and in fact the Socialists are preparing to support the Commission's pro-ISDS position with a repackaging ploy that is set out as a compromise.
