On the basis of the above, it rightly arises in the supporters of European democracy: where is the point in the TTIP negotiations where citizens' views on business interests become unavoidable and who are represented by those who are preparing to adopt rules contrary to the views of European citizens?

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. – The US Free Trade Agreement, which offers clear benefits to Europe and Hungary, has been held captive for months by political sentiment and hysteria around the investor-state dispute settlement mechanism. Calm down, fellow Members. The dispute settlement mechanism will not destroy our planet, it will not disrupt the European legal order, nor will multinationals force us to eat genetically modified burgers from now on. This becomes clear from the Commission's public negotiating mandate. This means that there is no room for secrecy in relation to the future dispute settlement mechanism and that the independence of the arbitr courts must be guaranteed. The dispute settlement mechanism should not compel any Member State to legislate contrary to the interests of its citizens. Investors cannot force us to grow GM foods, to weaken the environment or to weaken the rights of workers or consumers. Conscious misinterpretation, on the other hand, causes serious harm to the European and Hungarian people. If there is no US Free Trade Agreement, European and Hungarian families could lose 160,000 HUF a year in savings. If there is no agreement, Europe will Hungary 30,000 jobs, and russia's energy dependency will remain on the eastern edge of Europe. If there is no agreement, no economic North Atlantic alliance of 850 million, Europe's place in the world economy will continue to weaken. If there is no agreement, one day we will find ourselves being dictated by Asia and Latin America. Those who create political hysteria should do so with a thorough balance sheet of the above.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. – Great goals in history require great strides and vision. Strides and vision have led to things like the European Union. What we need is the next big thing in the economy. The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) is this big thing, far from just a trade deal. This is an agreement between the two most powerful democracies in the world, between the two largest consumer markets and financial systems. TTIP is the shortcut to investment, jobs and opportunities for small and medium-sized businesses in Europe. To get there, we have to break down a few myths and tell a few truths. Behind-the-scenes deals are not possible - Member States will have the last word. Compromises in online security cannot be made – the protection of personal data is a fundamental right in the EU. Only Member States can decide whether their health systems will be public or private. TTIP was created for small and medium-sized enterprises - 99% of companies in Europe. A new market will be opened for young entrepreneurs, non-tariff barriers (red tape) will be eased, e-commerce will be strengthened. This is no time for populism on the subject of TTIP. Populism leads to situations like in Greece. It is time for sober economic solutions, for a vision and for the future of Europe.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. – The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (DP) is crucial for the future development of EU-US relations. This agreement also has significant political and security implications. In the current world, strong cooperation between the EU and the US is very important and therefore a new agreement must also be reached as soon as possible. The EU-US Free Trade Agreement must help to promote economic growth. The agreement must help to increase our international competitiveness and create new opportunities for EU companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, and to support the creation of quality jobs for European citizens and to bring direct benefits to European consumers. A free trade agreement would create a European-US free trade area with the highest opportunities.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Rarely has a trade partnership negotiation raised so many fears. And for good reason: the draft transatlantic treaty puts two very different markets and two very different economic and social models in competition. We cannot accept that the harmonisation of European standards should be reduced!  While I am not opposed to the principle of negotiation with the United States, the mere fact that the negotiators do not completely exclude business-to-state dispute arbitration tribunals from discussions leads me to object. Both the United States and Europe have powerful jurisdictional tools that make any ISDS system redundant.  Priority must be given to strengthening European unity and establishing economic and social governance to boost investment and employment. In a multipolar world, the European Union must negotiate on an equal footing with the United States, but also with China, Latin America or Africa.  I stand for a human Europe in a more equitable world. Unfortunately, this is not the vision of the resolution proposed to us for adoption. It aims to indicate the "red lines" of the TTIP negotiation, but fails to protect all European standards.

name: Algirdas Saudargas (PPE)
text: Writing. – I would like to stress that the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, a comprehensive free trade and investment agreement, is a major recent eu-US project. The successful implementation of this partnership will give new impetus to transatlantic trade, thus contributing to sustainable economic growth, job creation, greater international competitiveness and direct benefits for EU and US citizens and businesses. I believe that transparent negotiations will lead to a balanced, comprehensive, ambitious trade and investment agreement that will benefit both sides. However, it is important to ensure that access to US markets is not at the expense of high standards in the EU in various areas. I particularly support the inclusion of a separate chapter on energy in the agreement. I believe that closer cooperation is needed in the fields of energy research, development and innovation, the promotion of high standards of sustainability and energy efficiency of energy production, and low-carbon and environmentally friendly technologies.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The strong alliance that in this House supports neoliberal policy is very interested in the adopt of ttip and does not hesitate to present arguments that are completely departing from reality. So far, we know that the European Union and the United States are negotiating a high level of transfer of sovereignty of peoples to large transnational corporations. Many of the reforms made with the argument of competitiveness (labour reforms, agrarian policy, abandonment of dairy policy) are already in line to repair the ground for this great agreement which, if we allow it, will turn us into people without rights and slaves of multinationals. Those and those who support this treaty, and will vote yes, will deepen the submission of people's rights to the interests of capital. We are faced with an agreement that attacks democracy, the precautionary principle, public services, labour rights, small and medium-sized farms, small and medium-sized enterprises, and which keeps producers and producers away from their local and proximity markets. For these reasons, among others, I will vote against this agreement and ask for the immediate suspension of negotiations.

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – The Trans-Atlantic Trade and Investment Partnership is more than a traditional trade deal and the current negotiating position that MEPs have access to is not a text I could support. Commerce and democracy are not mutually exclusive, nor should they ever be traded against each other. This opinion must send a clear statement to the Commission that this is the case or it serves no purpose. The Commission must understand that the fear of lowering standards through regulatory harmonisation expressed by citizens from across Europe is not irrational and must be addressed. The proposal to create a separate legal mechanism to protect investors is completely unacceptable. As a lawyer I am deeply worried by this because companies can and will take advantage of any avenues that are open to them. That the Scottish Government is currently before the European Court of Justice defending its policies against the challenge of the Scotch Whisky Association shows that investors already have numerous avenues to defend themselves. The SNP could support TTIP but only if it creates trade without compromising European standards, the Scottish NHS or the democratic accountability of the Scottish Parliament.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – TTIP can become an important tool in regulating globalisation processes and improving the EU's international competitiveness, but this requires a number of legal, political and economic framework conditions. For this reason, the European Parliament must exercise active political control and control throughout the process of negotiating TTIP, and its activities should not be confined to a future final vote. This could be the guarantee that the agreement will ultimately generate real European jobs and growth, without prejudice to EU labour, social, environmental and consumer protection standards. In implementing the negotiating directives developed jointly with the Member States and the EP, commission representatives must also take this complex conditionality into account and enforce it, as this gives the agreement its meaning for European interests. I believe that the isds mechanism so far, as well as the solution to eradicate the opaque methods of abuse that surround it, essentially the creation of a new public system of transparent and democratic control, deserve support, because this will give the Commission a clear negotiating framework for the next round of negotiations, which is in The European interest.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The resolution does not go far enough and some red lines are broken, including the rejection of the ISDS. As it stands, PS-SPA delegations will vote against the TTIP resolution. To say the least, TTIP divides the European Parliament, with each paragraph the subject of fierce political battles.  For us, the presence of an ISDS mechanism is inconceivable! The compromise put on the table is a very bad signal. The proposed text is in the direction of a cosmetic improvement of the current ISDS system and misses the essential message: national public courts must be the only guarantors of investment protection.  At a time when states such as France are announcing their opposition to the agreement with Canada as long as there is an ISDS, the position reflected in this compromise seems all the more incomprehensible.  The vote on this resolution is a test and gives an idea of what might happen at the end of the negotiations. At that time, each elected official will have to take responsibility and be held accountable in the event of a vote against the public interest. In any case, our Socialist delegation will be uncompromising and reject any free trade agreement that could endanger the general interest of European citizens.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. – This report is a follow-up to the resolutions adopted during parliament's last parliamentary term on transatlantic trade and investment negotiations. The aim of this was to provide as detailed information as possible and to enable members of the various parliamentary committees to contribute to this important process. MEPs have the greatest influence on the final version of trade agreements between the EU and third countries. The Agreement may enter into force only if Parliament agrees. The rejection of the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (TSC) ACTA) has shown that Parliament is very responsible in its role in trade and foreign policy. In the light of the many critical opinions expressed by the European public and the low public acceptance of the agreement negotiated, Parliament should strive for maximum transparency in order to ensure that only a good agreement is adopted that respects European values, promotes sustainable growth and contributes to the well-being of all citizens. Let us also not forget the very important issue for Europeans, the visa requirement. Visa facilitation for European service and goods suppliers is one of the key elements for exploiting the full potential of the contract. The negotiations also require increased political pressure to ensure full reciprocity of the visa requirement and a uniform, anti-discrimination approach to all citizens of EU Member States. The Commission should also promote the highest global human rights standards, decent work and universal access to quality public services during the negotiations.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – Beyond addressing the many crises it faces, the EU is interested in the medium term in strengthening sustainable economic growth and creating new jobs, especially for young people. The EU is constantly interested in promoting its core values. To achieve these goals, we need allies.  Beyond the multiple divergences and beyond the obvious fact that the United States of America is also a competitor of the EU, the reality shows us that it is also Europe's natural ally in global competition. In the extremely tense and complicated international context, emerging economies in Asia are overvalued. Analysts appreciate their spectacular economic growth, but is it sustainable? Partnership with these economies is important for Europe. But do we share the same values? I believe that TTIP is a necessary tool for a Europe that is planning its future. I think the analysts on the other side of the Atlantic who advise us every day - now, for example, making the apologia of Grexit - represent American interests that are not necessarily in harmony with our own goals, but I also believe that the differences between us are less important than anything that binds us. The outcome of the TTIP negotiations must take into account the opinion of the EP, because only in this way will the treaty be ratified.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. The debate on TTIP and trade relations with the United States is an important issue, an issue that we parliamentarians need to know and evaluate correctly. I therefore welcome this report, which calls for transatlantic agreements to protect our excellent productions, the high quality standards of our products, workers' rights and the protection of personal data. A report that also sends out an important signal on a much debated issue such as ISDS: I would like to reiterate this here too, the ISDS system must be replaced by a new public system of dispute resolution between investors and states, subject to democratic principles and control; justice must be the same for all. Of course we must be vigilant, certainly those who are dealing with it will have to take good account of the issues that we are expressing today through this vote; I am sure that, at the end of the negotiations, we will have an advanced trading system that will bring important results for our economy. On the basis of what happens and the text that will be presented, we will assess our final vote.

name: Syed Kamall (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I wonder if, just before we start the vote, I could raise a point of order, or information, or a point of remembrance. Today we commemorate the 10th anniversary of the 7/7 terror attacks in London, and I hope this whole Chamber will join together with the eight London MEPs from all political parties in paying tribute to those who lost their lives and their families; the servicemen and women who saved lives and assisted the injured; and the people who next day went back to work in defiance of those who sought to divide us through acts of terror. Today, I hope this Chamber will agree that we stand here united and resolute in defending pluralism, diversity and freedom. We stand shoulder to shoulder with the people of London to show these terrorists who seek to undermine us that we will never allow their fear to win through, and that we will walk together with the people of London. (Applause)

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D).
text: – Madam President, as Mr Kamall said, 10 years ago we had the 7/7 attacks in London. Fifty-two people were murdered and there were over 700 casualties. They were not all UK citizens; there were also other citizens of Europe and beyond. It is really important in these troubled times to take a moment to remember all those affected by this and other atrocities, and to reflect on the common values that will continue to unite us. (Applause)

name: La Présidente. –

name: Igor Šoltes
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) has evaluated the credentials of Bettina Michelle Jakobsen, the Council’s nominee for membership of the Court of Auditors, and heard Ms Jakobsen at the Committee’s meeting of 17 June. Ms Jakobsen’s career and her professional background as an auditor, including serving as Assistant Auditor-General in Denmark since 2005, are truly excellent. They demonstrate her technical competence, her professional commitment and her full independence. These are all qualities which I believe should become the standard for nominees. Apart from that, with our positive vote, Bettina Jakobsen will be only the fifth female Member of the European Court of Auditors in its current composition. That means that the Member States also need to make further strong efforts to achieve a more gender-balanced institution. Ms Jakobsen’s hearing before the CONT Committee demonstrated her commitment to good cooperation between the European Court of Auditors and the European Parliament in general and with the CONT Committee in particular. This cooperation must be based on mutual respect and understanding of the importance of effective European Union spending and policy management. At this opportunity, allow me to highlight that I fully support the initiative to update the questionnaire addressed to nominees to ensure an even more comprehensive insight into nominees’ careers, independence and possible conflicts of interests. In the CONT Committee, we fully support the European Court of Auditors’ ambitions to increase its focus on performance and value-for-money audits and to work more closely with the European Parliament and other stakeholders when establishing its reports programme, to help ensure the relevance of its work. As a former Auditor-General myself, it is with deep respect for Ms Jakobsen’s professional background and with full support for her candidacy, as expressed by the CONT Committee, that I ask this House to follow the CONT Committee’s recommendation and vote ‘yes’ to Ms Bettina Michelle Jakobsen being appointed the new Danish Member of the European Court of Auditors.

And, therefore, all the more reason for this recommendation to be approved.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. With regard to the appointment of my colleague Bettina Michelle Jakobsen as a member of the Court of Auditors, I would like to express my heartfelt congratulations and closeness to wishing her a successful career in this matter, and i therefore express a favourable opinion on this appointment.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report proposes the appointment of a member of the Court of Auditors, Bettina Michelle Jakobsen. Ms. Jakobsen's resume seems perfect for this position: she was for 25 years assistant auditor in the Citizens' Chamber responsible for carrying out controls in key areas related to citizens in various ministries, and then held positions in international institutions. She also responded to a questionnaire highlighting her qualities, objectivity and impartiality. Nevertheless, I deny any jurisdiction to this supranational Court of Auditors which undermines the free sovereignty of peoples and I have therefore decided to abstain in the vote of this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal for a decision on the proposed appointment of Bettina Michelle Jakobsen as a member of the Court of Auditors based on a rich professional experience that serves as the best evidence of why she was nominated for this high office. The same opinion was taken by the Committee on Budgetary Control on 17 June 2015, when a hearing of the Council candidate for membership in the Court of Auditors was held, which was assessed positively.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ At a session of the Committee on Budgetary Control on 17 June 2015, a hearing of the Candidate of the Council for Membership in the Court of Auditors was held. The Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the candidate's qualifications as excellent, as discussed by the unanimous support of the Committee for her appointment.  The candidate proposed has enviable professional experience in the three main types of public sector audits – financial, compliance and efficiency audits. She was employed by the International Committee of Auditors for NATO in Brussels, as the first woman in the post. She was also a representative of the International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions and is currently a candidate chairwoman of the INTOSAI Professional Standards Committee and is working on the development of international standards of SUPREME AUDIT INSTITUTIONS aimed at promoting independent and effective auditing. It also has experience of membership of three international audit committees – the Audit Committee of the Council of Europe in Strasbourg, the Audit Committee of the European Investment Fund and the Audit Committee of the European Investment Bank in Luxembourg. Consequently, I support the appointment of Mrs Betinne Michelle Jakobsen as a member of the COURT of Auditors of the EU, since it is apparent from the attached CV of the candidate and the replies provided during the committee hearing that she is an expert.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Bettina Michelle Jakobsen's candidacy to join the European Court of Auditors, for her profile and experience.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The hearing held by the Committee on Budgetary Control to Bettina Michelle Jakobsen, proposed by the Council as a member of the Court of Auditors, assessed, by means of a questionnaire, aspects of her professional experience and sought to assess the impartiality and independence of the candidate, in accordance with Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which, in respect of the members of the Court of Auditors , determines that "they must offer all guarantees of independence." The committee responsible gave its assent to the danish candidate's appointment and assessed the professional experience and guarantees of independence given, I voted in favour of the report in order to convey the positive opinion of the consultation held by the European Parliament.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the appointment of Bettina Michelle Jakobsen to the post of member of the Court of Auditors. Established in 1977, the Court of Auditors aims to monitor accounts and improve the financial management of the European Union and in this sense, the appointment of its members has been governed by criteria of competence and independence. All the data submitted for this option, including the replies to the questionnaire for candidates for members of the Court of Auditors and their Curriculum Vitae, supported my decision. In addition, the Committee on Budgetary Control heard the applicant and assessed her qualifications, in particular as to the conditions laid down in Article 286 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported, like the quasi-unanimity of MEPs, the appointment of Bettina Michelle Jakobsen as a member of the Court of Auditors in view of her competence for the office. She has more than 25 years of experience in the control of public finances and has been responsible for several years for the annual reports on the financial control of Danish public accounts to the Public Accounts Committee of the Danish Parliament. Its tasks will certainly include the mission to publish the Court's special reports more quickly and to make them more relevant in the same way as its annual report. In this way, the European Court of Auditors will be able to fully play its role as external monitor independent of the EU budget to uncover fraud and strengthen the proper management of European funds. It will be up to the European Parliament to fulfil its full political role and to supervise EU funds as effectively as possible.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. Since the Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the qualifications and heard bettina Michelle Jakobsen, there is no reason to vote against her nominee for membership of the Court of Auditors.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the appointment of Bettina Michelle Jakobsen as a new member of the Court of Auditors. Her training and proven experience is undoubtedly trained for the position.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Ms Bettina Michelle Jakobsen was nominated as a new Danish member of the European Court of Auditors following the death of Henrik Otbo on 1 February this year in Luxembourg. Ms. Jakobsen has 25 years of experience as a lawyer and auditor. She currently serves as Assistant Auditor General in Denmark, responsible for drafting reports to the Public Accounts Committee on the Control of Public Accounts. His candidacy was unanimously accepted by the groups.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the sudden death last February of The Member of the Court of Auditors and former Danish Auditor General Henrik Otbo - an invaluable loss for the European Court of Auditors in general, as well as for his former colleagues of the Danish Court of Auditors and, of course, for his family and friends was proposed as a new Danish member for the European Court of Auditors Bettina Michelle Jakobsen , lawyer and auditor with 25 years of experience. In view of her academic background and career path, the Committee on Budgetary Control has positively assessed the qualifications of the candidate for the post, in particular as to the conditions laid down in Article 286(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and has given its assent. With no reason to support the appointment in question, I voted in favour of this decision.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the appointment of Mrs Jakobsen on the consideration that her academic and professional career as well as the guarantees of independence which she was able to assert during the hearing in the European Parliament on 17 June correspond to the responsibilities to be assumed at the Court of Auditors, replacing the well-deserved Mr Otbo. In addition, I consider it positive that its incorporation favourably corrects gender balance in the team of auditors.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Ms Jakobsen’s extensive experience in public sector auditing makes her a very suitable candidate for appointment to the Court of Auditors. I am pleased that this will contribute to gender balance amongst ECA members, which has not yet been reached.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of adopting the resolution appointing Bettina Michelle Jakobsen as a Member of the Court of Auditors, taking into account the positive opinion of the EKR.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this Bettina Michell Jakobsen Nomination Report as a member of the Court of Auditors in view of her professional and international experience and previous tasks involving financial audit, compliance audit, region performance audit and other tasks that make her qualified to perform the duties of a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Ms Jakobsen’s extensive experience in public sector auditing makes her a very suitable candidate for appointment to the Court of Auditors. I am pleased that this will contribute to gender balance amongst ECA members, which has not yet been reached.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the report on the proposed appointment of Bettina Michelle Jakobsen as a member of the Court of Auditors in view of her previous positions: - Assistant Auditor General (pay grade 39), Danish National Audit Office, - Assistant Auditor General (pay grade 38), Danish National Audit Office, - Director (pay grade 37), Danish National Audit Office, - Auditor, International Committee of Auditors for NATO, NATO headquarters, Brussels , Belgium, - Special Adviser, Danish National Office for Revizia, - Head of Department, Danish National Audit Office, - Administrator, Copenhagen City Council. Bettine Michelle Jakobsen was the first Danish national to be an Auditor on the International Committee of Auditors for NATO in Brussels. The position included financial, compliance auditing and performance audits of various NATO organisations and projects. It also included audits carried out on NATO infrastructure programmes (NSIP), which included frequent travel to all NATO member states, good knowledge of international audit and accounting standards, knowledge of English and French as working languages, and considerable practical and professional experience working in an international organisation.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the appointment, as I consider Bettina Michelle Jakobsen, given her career history, to be more than a sufficiently qualified candidate for the post.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the appointment of Bettina Michelle Jakobsen as a member of the Court of Auditors. At a hearing before the Committee on Budgetary Control, Bettine Michelle Jakobsen demonstrated that she has long-standing audit experience in the public sector and extensive knowledge of financial audits, compliance audits and performance audits. In her answers, she was clear, precise and consistent. I also voted in favour of the report in order to ensure that it will work to improve relations between the European Court of Auditors, national audit institutions and the European Parliament (Committee on Budgetary Control).

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is proposed to appoint another member of the Court of Auditors whose structure, function and role fully represent the system of power that led our country and many others to the current tragic situation.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Audit is an essential activity for the financial health of our companies today. At European Union level, where there are a multitude of financial programmes, audit work is of paramount importance in order to avoid any fraud or corruption that may arise. Therefore, the members of the Court of Auditors of the European Union must have extensive experience in the field, enabling them to have the most rigorous scrutiny of the good administration of European money. Mrs Bettina Michelle Jakobsen has this experience both nationally and internationally.  His work in NATO's Court of Auditors is a testament to his professionalism and competence in the field. Ms Jakobsen is also an independent and credible expert who has managed budgets at the level of a complex organisation.  At the hearings, Mrs Jakobsen proved, through her replies, that she is the right person for the job, giving appropriate importance to her relationship with the European Parliament. Last but not least, we need a woman in the Court of Auditors to balance the gender balance in this male-dominated area. For these reasons, I support the appointment of Ms Jakobsen as a Member of the European Court of Auditors.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the appointment of our colleague Jakobsen.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on Ms Bettina's proposed appointment of Michelle Jakobsen as a member of the Court of Auditors, given her outstanding professional experience as well as her experience in conducting public sector audits.  The ECA's reports are of great importance not only for the work of the European Parliament and the Committee on Budgetary Control, but also for beneficiaries of assistance to provide relevant and timely information on eu spending and obligations in the implementation and implementation of programmes and projects.   I believe that the proposed candidate meets the requirements for appointment as a member of the Court of Justice. I hereby support it and call for efforts to promote independent and effective auditing, full independence in the performance of its duties, and to maintain a zero tolerance rate for fraud and corruption cases in order to build the practice of sound financial management as strongly as possible.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the report on the appointment of a Member of the Court of Auditors. Mrs Bettina Michelle Jakobsen has been proposed as the new Danish member of the European Court of Auditors. She is a lawyer and auditor with more than 25 years of experience. She is currently an assistant auditor in Denmark, responsible for preparing the reports of the Public Accounts Committee on the audit of government accounts.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the appointment of Mrs Jakobsen on the consideration that her academic and professional career as well as the guarantees of independence which she was able to assert during the hearing in the European Parliament on 17 June correspond to the responsibilities to be assumed at the Court of Auditors, replacing the well-deserved Mr Otbo. In addition, I consider it positive that its incorporation favourably corrects gender balance in the team of auditors.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The report presents Bettina Michelle Jakobsen's candidacy for the position of member of the European Court of Auditors. As Deputy Auditor General at the head of the Citizens' Chamber, responsible for carrying out controls in the main areas related to citizens in various Danish ministries, she has more than 25 years of experience in public finance.  The report details her background, the positions she has held in her country, Denmark, but also internationally with NATO or the EIB, among others.  The report also includes responses to a questionnaire sent to her by the Committee on Budgetary Control regarding her previous duties and her vision and ambitions for the position to which she is appointed. In her responses, she states that control of public finances is an important element that can make a difference in the lives of citizens. The emphasis is on the fact that it intends to fulfil its functions by offering all possible guarantees of objectivity, neutrality and impartiality.  I abstained on this vote.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proper functioning of the European Court of Auditors is essential in an effective Community system. I voted in favour of mrs Jakobsen's appointment, in agreement with the position of the S&D Group.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the appointment of Mrs Jakobsen on the consideration that her academic and professional career as well as the guarantees of independence which she was able to assert during the hearing in the European Parliament on 17 June correspond to the responsibilities to be assumed at the Court of Auditors, replacing the well-deserved Mr Otbo. In addition, I consider it positive that its incorporation favourably corrects gender balance in the team of auditors.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the candidacy of Bettina Michelle Jakobsen for the Court of Auditors, she was unanimously supported by the CONT committee and she has a high professional profile and a high level of independence.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Having regard to Mrs Jakobsen's résumé, as well as her replies to the questionnaire and the outcome of the final vote in committee (18 votes in favour, none against and no abstention), I consider it appropriate to vote in favour of this appointment.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The person to be appointed is the Deputy Auditor-General to head the Citizens department, responsible for carrying out audits in the main areas related to citizens, i.e. the Ministry of Employment, the Ministry of Youth, Gender Equality, Integration and Social Affairs, the Ministry of Economic and Interior Affairs, the Ministry of Health, the Ministry of Ecclesiastical Affairs and the Ministry of Culture. Financial, compliance and results audits of six ministries, central government payments to municipalities and regional outcome audits. Management of four directors and about 50 staff members. Member of the management team of the National Audit Office of Denmark (Executive Board). We seem to have a proper profile.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Together with my group, I voted in favour of the appointment of Mrs Bettina Michelle Jakobsen as a Member of the Court of Auditors. She is excellently qualified for the post. That is consensus. She has previously held several similar roles at the Danish Court of Auditors and NATO. In addition, Ms Jakobsen was elected by the President of the Court of Auditors as Chair of the INTOSAI Committee for Technical Standards (PSC) and appointed by the European Investment Bank (EIB) as a member of the Audit Committee of the European Investment Fund (EIF) in Luxembourg. She will also do her new job very well.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the nomination of Bettina Michelle Jakobsen as a new member of the European Court of Auditors, as I believe that she will bring a lot of experience to this function from both the Danish and international audit environment. Her CV proves that she has a great education and qualifications for this position and more than twenty-five years of experience in the field of auditing. Mrs Jakobsen has convinced us that one of her key priorities is transparency, zero tolerance for corruption and fraud, and the continuous improvement and strengthening of the use of public resources. These are the key aspects that we need from the members of the European Court of Auditors.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite being a technical codification of existing legislative texts, it involves indirect ratification of WTO rules. Our commitment to the field of international trade goes through a different economic model that allows local production to generate employment throughout the territories of the planet. These regulations often have the effect of counterproductively restricting, in economic terms, public participation in the industrial development of countries for the sake of growth and employment generation. That is why, despite its technical nature, I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The rapporteur of the report was a member of my parliamentary group, the GUE/NGL. The report was a ‘codification’ report – a simple procedural move to roll new existing rules that are currently in the form of a Council Regulation and amendments into legislation. Politically the regulation relates to the Commission having control over the EU’s interaction with the World Trade Organisation. However, even if I may oppose any aspect of the content of the regulation, it is already in place. There was nothing in this report that included any of the content of the regulation. It was purely technical – a new Act to supersede existing rules, regulations and amendments without any change to the content.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft resolution would like each Member State to consult with the Union before concluding an international trade treaty. This is a new step towards further federalising the Union, in defiance of the sovereignty of the Member States.  Attached to a Europe of Nations, I hope that each Member State can remain free to conclude trade agreements, whether with other Member States or with third countries. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As I oppose the procedures which are to be codified under this resolution, it was consistent for me to vote against the resolution itself.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, because it is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Once again, there is an attempt to impose a "common trade policy" on us, which is driven by erroneous geopolitical considerations rather than the well-thought-out interests of our countries. I voted against this text, because I believe that each Member State must remain free to negotiate its own trade agreements which it deems beneficial to its people.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This is an outright codification of existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the need for a codification of existing texts amending Union procedures to ensure the exercise of Union rights in accordance with international trade rules, especially set by the WTO.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council to set out EU procedures for common trade policy in order to ensure the exercise by the Union of the rights conferred on it by the rules of international trade, in particular those established under the aegis of the World Trade Organisation (WTO).  In the Committee on Legal Affairs, our Members have indicated that each Member State should remain free to negotiate trade agreements itself without a decision of the European Union and it is under this principle that I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with europe's policies in the field of international trade policy. Increasingly, the EU is protecting the interests of large multinationals and not those of small producers who protect our excellence and, above all, quality. For these reasons, I did not intend to support the Maštálka report with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I have supported this report which contains the recommendations made by the Legal Services Advisory Group of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, and which is limited to pure and simple codification of existing texts, without any substantial amendment thereof.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the Consultative Working Party of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission decided by consensus that this proposal for a regulation establishing Community procedures in the field of the common commercial policy is intended solely to codify existing texts without changing their substance. This Regulation provides for European Union procedures in the field of the common commercial policy in order to ensure the exercise of the rights conferred on the European Union by international trade rules, in particular under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), which, in accordance with existing national obligations and procedures, are designed to take measures in respect of trade barriers affecting the European Union market in order to eliminate the damage caused by them. In addition, the Regulation provides that measures are to be taken in respect of barriers to trade affecting the market of a third country in order to eliminate the adverse effects on trade resulting there being.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In this case, as in the regulation on protection against harmful pricing of vessels, it is not a substantive change but a harmonisation of the 1994 record, so my support for the document was not in question.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report "stopping EU procedures on common trade policy."  Indeed, I believe that each Member State must maintain the exercise of the rights conferred by the various rules laid down by international trade law.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The rapporteur of the report was a member of my parliamentary group, the GUE/NGL. The report was a ‘codification’ report – a simple procedural move to roll new existing rules that are currently in the form of a Council Regulation and amendments into legislation. Politically the regulation relates to the Commission having control over the EU’s interaction with the World Trade Organisation. However, even if I may oppose any aspect of the content of the regulation, it is already in place. There was nothing in this report that included any of the content of the regulation. It was purely technical – a new Act to supersede existing rules, regulations and amendments without any change to the content.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe that the codification of legislative and regulatory texts dealing with the exercise of Union rights in the field of international trade rules is necessary, as a matter of legal certainty, and is, to a certain extent, in line with the Commission's new 'Better Lawmaking' policy.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to amend the regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the adoption of Union procedures in the field of the common commercial policy with a view to ensuring the exercise by the Union of the rights conferred on it by the rules of international trade, in particular those established under the aegis of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), because the exclusive codification of this regulation is intended. The World Trade Organisation (WTO) is an international organisation that oversees a large number of agreements defining 'trade rules' between Member States. The WTO is the successor to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and operates towards the reduction and abolition of international trade barriers. In view of the fact that the Consultative Working Party on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission considers that the proposal in question is limited to a simple codification of the existing texts, without any substantive changes thereto, I believe that this report should be supported in order to better function the unification and uniformisation process.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. This is a purely codification measure, but it relates to a text whose content I do not agree with. The EU must completely review the regulations governing international trade that are killing Made in Italy and the Italian manufacturing economy.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Making legislation simple and accessible is a priority for the European institutions. As such, codification allows different regulations dealing with the same subject to be grouped into a single text in order to facilitate its application. I voted in favour of this report on the co-operation of the Union's exercise of its rights under the rules of international trade.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down the Union's procedures in the field of the common commercial policy.  It is of the utmost importance that the EU is able to ensure the stability of international trade agreements, and this must be done by means of appropriate instruments such as: – rules defining the framework for the exercise of UNION rights in certain specific situations; – rebalancing measures, including by suspending concessions in cases where the third country concerned does not make appropriate adjustments; - effective communication and exchange of views between the Commission, on the one hand, and the European Parliament and the Council, on the other.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote was merely concerned with technical matters and it was not connected to the content but was instead concerned with codification. This is important as if you do not codify the text the former several amended versions of the texts stay. Codification, is, in a nutshell a simplification. Any proposal that provides greater legal clarity and transparency should be welcomed as it is the complex nature of such texts which frequently leads to unnecessary legal challenges often at the taxpayers’ expense Politically the regulation relates to the Commission having control over the EU’s interaction with the World Trade Organisation. However, even if I may oppose any aspect of the content of the regulation, it is already in place. There was nothing in this report that included any of the content of the regulation. It was purely technical – and therefore, I voted in favour because it increases transparency and leads to better legislation.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As I oppose the procedures which are to be codified under this resolution, it was consistent for me to vote against the resolution itself.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the Inter-institutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on an accelerated working method for official codification of legislative texts, the Consultative Working Party met to examine the amended proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council codifying Council Regulation (EC) No 3286/94 of 22 December 1994 laying down Community procedures in the field of the common commercial policy in order to ensure the exercise of the Community’s rights under international trade rules, in particular those established under the auspices of the World Trade Organization and agreed that the proposal is a straightforward codification of existing texts, without any change in their substance. The aim of this exercise is to make a law that has been frequently amended to be clear and transparent. I therefore, voted in favour of this Report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Jiří Maštálkala's report verifies that the Commission's proposal is limited to a mere codification of existing texts, without any substantial changes, so I voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. The report aims to establish procedures "to ensure the exercise by the Union of the rights conferred on it by the rules of international trade, in particular those established under the aegis of the WTO." As a matter of principle, I oppose Article 3 of the EU Treaty, which stipulates that trade policy would be an exclusive competence of the European Union, the only interlocutor internally and externally being the Commission, which, as a negotiator, represents the 28 states. They, under the treaties, do not have the right to attend the negotiations and, where they are present (WTO, etc.), they can speak only on national and non-European terms. This stripping of Member States' trade sovereignty prevents each nation from pursuing policies in the interests of their businesses, industries or citizens. Denying the possibility for each Member State to negotiate the necessary or strategic trade agreements for its country is a denial of freedom and development on which it would be necessary to return by renegotiating the treaties. So I voted against this report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is important that this report concerns an amended proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down Union procedures in the field of the common commercial policy to ensure the exercise of the Union's rights under the rules of international trade, in particular those adopted within the framework of the World Trade Organisation.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the amended proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down Union procedures in the field of the common commercial policy in order to ensure the exercise of the Union's rights under international trade rules, in particular those established under the auspices of the WTO. This proposal is limited to a mere codification of existing texts, without any substantial changes.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the amended proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down union procedures in the field of the common commercial policy. Taking into account the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on better lawmaking, which aims to speed up the official codification of legislative texts and whereas the Advisory Group, composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, meeting on 26 February 2015, concluded that the proposal in question does not intend to amend the existing texts but merely codifies them , I welcome the proposal.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the Jiří Maštálka Report on the amended proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council establishing Union procedures in the field of the common commercial policy to ensure the exercise by the Union of its rights under international trade rules, in particular those laid down under the auspices of the coming World Trade Organisation (by requirement of clarity and rationality) to codify Council Regulation No 3286/94. In view of an amendment introduced in the meantime to the initial proposal, the Commission has decided to submit – in accordance with Article 293(2) of the TFEU Treaty , an amended proposal for codification of the regulation in question which fully preserves the content of the codified acts.  The act in question comes on the path of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 between the Commission, the Council and Parliament, which establishes an accelerated procedure that can be used for the rapid adoption of codified acts.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Maštálka's report because the proposal in question is limited to a mere codification of existing texts without any substantial changes.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am voting in favour of this report but insist that European citizens are given the necessary information about the negotiations taking place for the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership. The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership is a series of trade negotiations being carried out between the EU and US and this will directly affect the European citizens. It is very important that these negotiations do not decrease EU standards but ensure that these are safeguarded for the best of European citizens.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite being a technical codification of existing legislative texts, it involves indirect ratification of WTO rules. Our commitment to the field of international trade goes through a different economic model that allows local production to generate employment throughout the territories of the planet. These regulations often have the effect of counterproductively restricting, in economic terms, public participation in the industrial development of countries for the sake of growth and employment generation. That is why, despite its technical nature, I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution deals with the amended proposal which lays down Union procedures in the field of the common commercial policy in order to ensure the exercise of the Union’s rights under international trade rules. The proposal in question contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance. Hence as this is a simple procedural exercise I have voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to codify Council Regulation (EC) 3286/94 of 22 December 1994, which stops EU procedures for common trade policy with a view to ensuring the Community exercises its rights under the rules of international trade, particularly those established under the aegis of the World Trade Organization (WTO). The legislation provides that when the Union, which has a complaint on behalf of a European industry, a complaint on behalf of European companies or a request from a Member State to initiate proceedings in the area of common trade policy, follows formal international procedures for consultation or dispute resolution, decisions on the engagement, conduct and closure of these procedures are taken by the European Commission after informing the co-legislators. Considering that this text proposes a simple codification of the existing legislation without substantial amendments, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The text codifies some European trade rules. The European Commission will now be able to initiate, conduct and close international dispute resolution procedures once it hears a complaint from European companies. This new procedure will improve the coherence and effectiveness of European trade policy, the EU's exclusive competence. Member States will, of course, be informed.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the amended proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council to set out EU procedures on a common trade policy to ensure the exercise by the Union of the rights conferred on it by the rules of international trade, in particular those established under the aegis of the World Trade Organisation. Throughout my first year in office, I reaffirmed the principles that condition my political commitment. As a French Member of the European Parliament, I represent my country and its interests in a union without limits. That is why I reaffirm by my vote the desire to keep the national sovereignty of the Member States intact. I believe that trade agreements must be negotiated by only the States concerned, capable of defining the compromises that serve the interests of the peoples concerned. The Union must not be the centrepiece of these negotiations and must stop its encroachment on national prerogatives.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the adoption of this report because it concerns merely a simple and straightforward codification of existing texts. In my opinion, streamlining the European legal framework is very important in light of our commitment to the rules of subsidiarity and proportionality and improved understanding for citizens.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report, as it merely seeks to codify existing legislation without the possibility of amending it. The existing legislation is empty and we do not agree with it in its entirety.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution, because I believe that each Member State must remain free to negotiate trade agreements as it sees fit, without going through the European Union.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this proposal as it is subject to a clear and simple codification of the texts already in force without changing their substance. The proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishes the European Union's procedures in the field of the common commercial policy with a view to ensuring and applying European Union rights in the light of international trade rules, with emphasis on those established under the auspices of the WTO, as well as taking into account the opinion of the European Economic and Social Committee of December 2014 and taking into account the opinion of the Consultative Working Party of the European Parliament's Legal Services , the Council and the European Commission.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report. Although this is a mere codification, we are talking about the trade policy that it is, and it has been a disaster for my country.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. – My vote is against the report, as it merely seeks to codify existing legislation without the possibility of amending it. The existing legislation is empty and I do not agree with it in its entirety.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal since the proposal in question contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the amended proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down Union procedures in the field of the common commercial policy in order to ensure the exercise of the Union's rights under international trade rules, in particular those established under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation. The common commercial policy must be based on uniform principles, especially as regards trade defence: this requirement is all the more acute at a time when the EU is negotiating several bilateral trade agreements with important trading partners. Enabling European companies and businesses to report directly to the Commission cases of prejudice and obstacles to international trade found, and immediately, goes in the direction of a Europe that treats the interests of its companies and Its Member States in a uniform manner.  Finally, I believe it is important to codify this regulation, which creates a certain and enforceable procedure throughout the EU for complaints and procedures for resolving international trade disputes, in which the European Commission assumes the role of representative of the interests of the whole European Union.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the exercise of the Union's rights under international trade rules, because this rather technical dossier modernises the basic agreements for international negotiations and also strengthens, in part, the position of the European Parliament.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Maštálka report, given it simply concerns a codification to take into account changes in rules (already accepted by the EU) by the WTO in international trade.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, the purpose of which is the codification of overlapping rules but which preserves, in any event, the content of the previous acts. Voting is not connected to any express content and only expresses formal will.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report alongside my colleagues in the Socialist and Democrats Group. This report is a simple codification to recognise account changes in rules by the WTO that have already been accepted by the EU.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the Union's rights under international trade rules. I believe that the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing Union procedures in the field of the common commercial policy in order to ensure the security and efficiency of the work of the EU institutions, in particular those established under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation (WTO).

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, the purpose of which is the codification of overlapping rules but which preserves, in any event, the content of the previous acts. Voting is not connected to any express content and only expresses formal will.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒in 2012 I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the amended proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council establishing Union common trade policy procedures to ensure the exercise of Union law under international trade rules, in particular those established under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation, as the proposal goes towards codifying existing texts without substantive changes. Simplification leads to clearer acts that make them more accessible to citizens and easier to find and understand. It is important to enable citizens to access their rights without difficulty and to reduce the need for research work.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote against this report on the union's exercise of its rights under the rules of international trade. This draft resolution greatly changes the diplomatic rules of the Member States. Thus, each Member State of the Union would be obliged to seek the opinion of the Union before concluding an international treaty. This proposal goes against the direct national sovereignty of the Member States: they must remain free to conduct their diplomatic relations as they see fit, even if, and above all, the Union's diplomacy goes against their interests. Such an encroachment on the freedom and sovereignty of the Member States is absolutely unacceptable, especially since there is a good chance that this resolution will damage the economies of some Eu countries.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Ji-Maetelka's report on the Union's exercise of its rights under the rules of international trade. This text, which is essentially technical, simplifies the various European and international legislations by bringing together the relevant legislation into a single corpus. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the legislative resolution suspending the Union's common trade policy procedures to ensure the exercise by the Union of the rights conferred on it by the rules of international trade, in particular those established under the aegis of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). This vote is the result of an accelerated procedure for simplifying and clarifying the law and does not affect the legal consequences of the original version.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This is a mere codification of existing legal texts for the exercise of Community rights under international trade rules, in particular under the arrangements agreed within the WTO. It is not a change in content, neither an improvement nor a deterioration, so I am abstaining from voting.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. According to the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, this proposal is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes. This subject concerns the amended proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down the Union's procedures in the field of the common commercial policy in order to ensure the exercise of the Union's rights under international trade rules, in particular those established under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation. I have therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. Each Member State should remain free to negotiate trade agreements on its own, as it sees fit, without going through the European Union. Vote: AGAINST

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I believe that each Member State should remain free to negotiate trade agreements itself as it sees fit, without going through the European Union.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it. The aim of this report is to give the European Union prerogatives to negotiate on trade policy. This, of course, is in line with the proposed guardianship of the Member States, which must increasingly follow the decisions taken by the European institutions. As a sovereignist, I cannot support such a project. Member States must be able to freely negotiate any trade agreement according to their interests.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite being a technical codification of existing legislative texts, it involves indirect ratification of WTO rules. Our commitment to the field of international trade goes through a different economic model that allows local production to generate employment throughout the territories of the planet. These regulations often have the effect of counterproductively restricting, in economic terms, public participation in the industrial development of countries for the sake of growth and employment generation. That is why, despite its technical nature, I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. In June 2014, the Commission presented a proposal to adhere the EU's Common Trade Policy ( PCC) to the set of international standards stipulated by the World Trade Organization. I am voting in favour of this initiative as it aims to bring our rules into tune into the international legislative framework, which will undoubtedly contribute to the better functioning of the global trading system.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour as this is merely a consolidation of the existing text and does not change the original legislation.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. On the proposal of the European Commission to parliament and the Council on amendments to the Regulation establishing union procedures in the area of common trade policy in order to ensure the exercise of Union law under international trade rules, in particular those established under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation, MeP Jiří Maštálka drafted an opinion on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs.  Since the legal services approved the codification of the already existing text and confirmed that the amendments would not affect the content of the document, I supported Representative Maštálko's opinion that the amendments be adopted.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in line with my political party line and my convictions: the international trade that has become so important today must be developed in accordance with strict EU rules and principles, the effectiveness of which has been proven over the years.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The subject of the proposal is the unification of the existing legislation. Clear and more systematic codification will contribute to clearer regulation, easier work with the text of the regulation and thus to a better understanding and interpretation of the content of the regulation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the amended proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down Union procedures in the field of the common commercial policy to ensure the exercise of the Union's rights under the rules of international trade, in particular those adopted within the framework of the World Trade Organisation, because the Advisory Group, which consists of the respective legal services of the European Parliament , the Council and the Commission, found by mutual agreement that the proposal does indeed constitute merely codification of existing texts, without modifying their substance.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. It regulates the EU's common trade policy procedures, allowing the EU to exercise its "rights" in international trade. We formally oppose this text, because trade agreements and their negotiations should be the responsibility of the Member States and not of the European Union.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal which is a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Votes in favour of the amended proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the exercise of Union rights in the context of international trade rules. The proposal establishes Community procedures in the field of the common commercial policy to ensure the effective exercise of Union rights within the framework of international trade rules; with particular regard to those established under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation. The common commercial policy is, in fact, based on uniform principles, particularly as regards trade defence, and on a transparent legal mechanism aimed at overcoming the barriers to trade adopted by third countries.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal is based on a mere codification of existing texts, without making the same substantive changes. Aware that simplifying the texts promotes their interpretability, I have decided to support this report.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting because this proposal is a mere codification of existing legal texts on the exercise of the Community's rights under international trade rules, in particular those agreed within the framework of the World Trade Organisation, without any substantive changes.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The purpose of this proposal is to codify the EU Trade Rights Regulation. This is a purely technical report. Nevertheless, since the regulation is codified with the main purpose of "reacting to barriers to trade", I vote against this text which favours the most forceful liberalism.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft resolution would require each Member State to go through the European Union before concluding an international treaty. We see very clearly that this is an attempt to unify, to federalise the Union even more. This will in no way benefit the economies of Member States, which are already struggling to compete internationally. It is also clear that this kind of proposal violates and reduces the national sovereignty of each member state. States must remain free of the trade agreements it concludes, whether european partners or not. In order to protect the sovereignty of each member state and not to add a burden to the economies of European countries, I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the amended proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council establishing Union procedures in the field of the common commercial policy to ensure the exercise by the Union of its rights under international trade rules, in particular those laid down within the framework of the World Trade Organisation. The purpose of the proposal in question is to codify the existing texts, without substantive amendments, which, from the point of view of legislative technique, with a view to simplifying existing legal rules, deserves my agreement.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal for Exercise of the Union’s rights under international trade rules, which is only a technical adjustment and fully preserves the content of the act being codified.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Consolidated eu legislation already in force without any substantive amendment.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The text is the codification of Regulation (EC) 3286/94, which gives the European Union power over trade negotiations. In particular, it provides that in the event of litigation (complaint on behalf of an INDUSTRY or companies in the Union, or a request from a Member State to initiate proceedings in the area of common trade policy), the Commission may decide to initiate or close the procedure on its own, simply informing the Member States. The French patriots are in defence of national sovereignty in this matter and therefore cannot support this text.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since this proposal is based on the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments, this report has my vote in favour. Council Regulation (EC) No 3286/94 of 22 December 1994 establishing Union procedures in the field of the common commercial policy to ensure the exercise by the Union of its rights under international trade rules, in particular those laid down under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation, has already been subject to numerous amendments. As I argue that legislation must be clear and simple, I argue that the codification of that law is the best way to ensure legal certainty and proximity to citizens.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report entitled "Exercise by the Union of rights conferred on it by the rules of international trade" aims to establish the common trade policy that the European Union must provide under its exclusive powers of international trade. I am in complete opposition to the common trade policy, which is merely a submission to the globalist logic, and considering that it is up to each Member State to freely determine the trade policy it must follow, I have decided to vote against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which is part of a group of codification files, and is simply a codification to take into account changes in rules (already accepted by the EU) by the WTO in international trade.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this purely technical text, relating to the union's exercise of its rights under the rules of international trade. It is a codification of the existing texts on the procedures for the Union's common trade policy in relation to the rules of international trade and in particular those defined under the aegis of the World Trade Organisation.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing.
