Having regard to the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on an accelerated working method for the official codification of legislative texts, we welcome without delay this proposal on the Union's procedures in the field of the common commercial policy, in order to ensure the exercise of the Union's rights under international trade rules, in particular those established under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation.  In the course of its examination, the Advisory Group concluded by common accord that the proposal was limited to a mere codification of the existing texts and did not make any substantial changes. We therefore call on our President to forward it to the Commission and the national parliaments as soon as possible.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union attaches great importance to the simplification and clear formulation of Community legislation, so that it becomes more comprehensible and accessible to citizens. This objective cannot be achieved as long as the countless provisions, amended on several occasions and often substantially, remain scattered, forcing those who wish to consult them to seek them both in the original act and in the acts of amendment.  The purpose of this proposal is therefore to initiate the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 3286/94 of 22 December 1994 laying down Community procedures in the field of the common commercial policy in order to ensure the exercise of the Union's rights under international trade rules, in particular those established under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation. In view of the above considerations, and since this is a technical report which does not introduce any innovation in content, but confines itself to a mere codification of the existing texts, I thought it appropriate to support it with a vote in favour.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted for this Commission proposal that complies with the recommendations of the Consultative Working Party of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ Chaith mise vóta i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo. Bhí an rapóirtéir mar pháirt de mo ghrúpa, GUE/NGL. Tuarascáil chódaíochta a bhí ann – céim nós imeachta chun na rialacha atá i bhfeidhm i láthair na huaire a chódú mar rialachán ón gComhairle agus leasuithe orthu a bhogadh go reachtaíocht. Go polaitiúil, tá baint ag an rialachán seo leis an gCoimisiún agus an chumhacht atá aige maidir leis an mbaint atá ag AE leis an Eagraíocht Dhomhanda Trádála. É sin ráite, cé go bhfuilim i gcoinne gnéithe den rialachán, tá na gnéithe sin i bhfeidhm cheana féin. Ní raibh rud ar bith sa tuarascáil seo a bhain le hábhar an rialacháin féin. Tuarascáil theicniúil a bhí ann: gníomh nua chun gabháil in ionad na rialacha atá i bhfeidhm faoi láthair; an gníomh sin a bheith i bhfoirm rialacháin agus leasuithe air, gan athrú ar bith ar an ábhar.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because it is a mere summary of the existing codifications, which should serve to exercise the Community's rights under international trade rules (in particular those agreed within the framework of the World Trade Organisation). Furthermore, no substantive changes have been made.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The proposal is limited to the codification of existing legislation without any substantive changes.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The main objective of the negotiations is to put development at the heart of the world trading system. The negotiators' conclusions should help strengthen developing states' capacity to make profits in international trade and thus help them fight poverty.  The EU supported the launch of such a broad and ambitious round of negotiations, as this seemed to be the only way to enable all actors to achieve economic growth and the benefits of development, while accepting the necessary compromises. Therefore, I supported this report.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, entitled "Exercise by the Union of rights under the rules of international trade", aims to set the common trade policy that the European Union must follow under its powers of international trade. I am opposed to the allocation of these powers and I strongly oppose the common trade policy, which is merely a submission to globalist logic. I believe that it is up to each Member State to freely determine the trade policy it intends to implement. I have therefore decided to vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The aim of the European Union Common Trade Policy Mechanism is to provide a procedural tool when union institutions are required to respond to trade barriers adopted or applied by third countries that harm or have a detrimental effect on trade, provided that there is a right of action in relation to those barriers under the applicable international trade rules. In accordance with the amended proposal for this Regulation, it is the Commission's duty to act in relation to trade barriers adopted or applied by third countries, within the framework of international and Union law and obligations, only where the Union's interest is at risk. When assessing this interest, the Commission should pay due attention to the views of all interested parties to the proceedings. Therefore, I support the rapporteur's proposal to ensure the exercise of Union law under international trade rules, in particular those established under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation, by setting out union procedures in the area of common trade policy.  This importance was also recognized by the Republic of Croatia, which, with the adoption of the Law on Amendments to the Trade Act, enabled the application of the acquis of the European Union in the field of trade policy and, accordingly, established the State Office for Trade Policy, as the competent body for the implementation of trade policy.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The primary objectives of the EU and the World Trade Organisation (WTO) are effective trade protection for all entities involved in international trade. It is undeniable that the Common Trade Policy must be based on uniform principles. In addition to the detailed European regulation in this area, the rules laid down under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation and those laid down in the annexes to the WTO Agreement are highlighted in particular. The purpose of the amendments to the Common Trade Policy Community Procedures Regulation is to establish more effective procedures to ensure the effective exercise of all Union law in accordance with international trade rules and therefore this Regulation has exceptional political significance for market freedoms within the EU. Those procedures shall apply in particular during the initiation and conduct of international dispute resolution procedures in the area of common trade policy. The objective of this Regulation is also to ensure an effective response to trade barriers affecting the EU market with a view to eliminating the damage caused and to trade barriers that have an impact on the third country market with a view to eliminating the resulting adverse effects on trade.  From all of the above, I support the amended proposal for a Regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the establishment of Community procedures in the area of common trade policy.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted to codify the EU's Common Trade Policy Procedures Regulation to ensure that the Union exercises its rights under international trade rules, including those established by the World Trade Organisation (WTO). This procedure clarifies and simplifies the legislation.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. The rapporteur approves the codification of the texts in Council Regulation (EC) No 3286/94 of 22 December 1994 on union procedures in the field of the common commercial policy. Considering the favourable opinion given to the proposal amended by Parliament's Advisory Group on Legal Services and also considering that the amendments to the proposal are based on a pure and simple codification of the existing texts, without substantive changes to the legislative text, I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution in question.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report written by Ji-Maetelka on behalf of the Legal Committee on the exercise by the Union of rights conferred on it by the rules of international trade.  This is a new regulation that follows the advisory work of the respective legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission. And even if this is an outright codification of the existing texts, without any modification of their substance, it is important to recall certain facts, since the proper application of the common trade policy is in particular that of the rules of the World Trade Organization. While I, as a liberal, am sensitive to a barrier-free world that promotes trade, including trade, I still express some concern about the lack of major reforms in many international institutions. Some deserve much more than a refreshment. This is particularly the case for the WTO, which is unable to conclude the Doha Round, which began in 2001, and to regulate world trade at the beginning of the 21st century.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission has delivered a positive opinion and considers that this proposal is limited to the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments to the texts, there is no reason to vote against.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I have supported this report which contains the recommendations made by the Legal Services Advisory Group of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, as it is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without any substantial amendment thereof.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposed regulation setting out EU procedures for common trade policy to ensure the exercise by the Union of the rights conferred on it by the rules of international trade, in particular those established under the aegis of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). This proposed regulation is limited to an outright codification of existing texts and therefore makes no change in their substance. This lack of change was confirmed by the European Parliament's Legal Services Advisory Group.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this legislative resolution on the amended proposal for a Regulation establishing various Eu procedures in the field of the common commercial policy. The main objective is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 3286/94 of 22 December 1994 with a view to ensuring the exercise by the Union of its rights under international trade rules, in particular those laid down under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). This is a procedure in which the European Parliament decides in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure and on an equal footing with the Council. The common commercial policy must be governed by standardisation criteria, and the codification of this Regulation has established procedures ensuring the effective exercise of Union rights under international trade rules, in particular by introducing a transparent legal mechanism, which Member States may use where there are barriers or damage to trade by third countries.  It should also be noted, as a positive aspect of clarity and rationality, the clarification that the codification of this Regulation has brought on the powers of the Commission, as well as the procedures for examination and consultation.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr McDerman's report. Mastalka on the exercise of the Union's rights in the context of international trade rules, the proposal in question is limited to a mere codification of existing texts, without any substantial changes.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote against because it is a purely codification measure relating to a Regulation that I consider to be inadequate overall.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, the purpose of which is the codification of overlapping rules but which preserves, in any event, the content of the previous acts. Voting is not connected to any express content and only expresses formal will.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the exercise of Union rights in the context of international trade rules, as this is a simple codification of existing legislative texts, without any substantial changes.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this group of codification files, as it is simply a codification to take into account changes in rules (already accepted by the EU) by the WTO in international trade.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of adopting a resolution on the amended proposal for a regulation of the EP and the Council laying down Union procedures in the field of the common commercial policy aimed at the application of Union rights under the rules of international trade, in particular those rules which were drawn up under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation, since the proposal proposed a clear and simple codification of the existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft legislative resolution of the EP on the amended proposal for a regulation of the EP and the Council laying down Union procedures in the field of the common commercial policy with a view to the application of Union rights under the rules of international trade, in particular those established under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation. Since, in the opinion of the Consultative Working Party of the Legal Services of the EP, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question contains only a clear and simple codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance, the European Parliament adopted the Commission's proposal in accordance with the recommendations of the Consultative Working Party of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission at first reading.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 International trade is a successful tool for generating growth and jobs. I therefore support respect for all EU and WTO principles in the area of trade protection.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the Report on the amended proposal for a Regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the establishment of Union procedures in the area of common trade policy in order to ensure the exercise of Union law under international trade rules, in particular those established under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation, as the proposal is adapted to the opinions and recommendations of the advisory legal services of the European Commission, Parliament and Council.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report codifying international trade rules as these clarify the EU’s rights under international trade rules.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the draft report on the amended proposal for a Regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the establishment of Union common trade policy procedures to ensure the exercise of Union law under international trade rules, in particular those established under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation (codified text).  On 26 February 2015, the Advisory Working Group, which is made up of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, met for the purpose of verifying this Commission proposal. At this meeting, the amendment to the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council of Coding was verified, Council Regulations (EC) No 2013/2013. 3286/94 of 22 December 1994, setting out Community common trade policy procedures to ensure the exercise of Community rights under international trade rules, in particular those under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation. The Advisory Working Group concluded that the proposal was simply to encrypt existing texts, without changing their substance.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as it only aims to codify the texts currently in force.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The codification of texts should be an opportunity to re-evaluate their content in substance and not only by type.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The institutional construction of the European Communities has, since their founding, been a form of support for free trade between Member States. On the basis of this principle, the European Union has made a key contribution to the creation of the World Trade Organisation, a forum for regulating trade relations based on free trade worldwide. In this area, however, there are also a number of obstacles raised by some third countries affecting the commercial interests of the European Union.  In order to overcome these obstacles, the European Council adopted Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. in order to give European producers and Member States the right to challenge unfair practices in relation to free trade. The Regulation complies with trade dispute settlement practices established in the WTO.  That document, however, has become insufficient in the current context of the EU's institutional development. It is therefore necessary to adopt this resolution, which codifies the Council Regulation in an up-to-date form, thereby giving it new legitimacy before the Union's trading partners and, in general, to WTO members.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council setting out the Union's procedures for the common trade policy to ensure the exercise by the Union of the rights conferred on it by the rules of international trade, in particular those established under the aegis of the World Trade Organisation.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The regulation allows for the use of EU procedures in its common commercial policy with the aim to ensure that the EU makes full use of its rights under international trade rules, especially those of the World Trade Organization. It deals particularly with rules that concern obstacles to trade affecting the EU market and those impacting the market of third countries. I voted in favour of the regulation because I believe that a consistent and unified approach will bring more clarity and facilitate international dispute settlement for the EU industries and enterprises as well as individual Member States.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ In order to ensure trade protection for the international market and for third country markets, continuous work is needed to level and modify the principles that protect the common trade policy, while also making adjustments to the flows of international trade.  I would like to stress that the Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, must consistently act in relation to trade barriers and oversee the application of European law, and within the framework of international law and obligations where the Union's interest is at risk, prevent adverse effects or repair the consequences of damage resulting from adverse effects on trade.  However, since in this case it is a direct codification of the text of the Regulation on Union procedures in the area of common trade policy, without changing the content, I voted in favour.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The report aims at the adoption of an amended proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down procedures in the field of a common commercial policy towards the guarantee of the Union's rights under international trade rules, in particular those agreed within the Framework of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). The actuality and the necessary amendments make the adoption of the report very important, which is why I supported this report.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, the purpose of which is the codification of overlapping rules but which preserves, in any event, the content of the previous acts. Voting is not connected to any express content and only expresses formal will.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Each Member State must remain free to negotiate trade agreements on its own, as it sees fit, without going through the European Union. I therefore object to this text.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, the purpose of which is the codification of overlapping rules but which preserves, in any event, the content of the previous acts. Voting is not connected to any express content and only expresses formal will.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report for the sake of greater legal certainty.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In view of the view that the advisory group on the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission consider that the proposal in question is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without any substantial amendment thereof, I consider it positive to vote in favour of that report so that it can be approved at first reading.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite being a technical codification of existing legislative texts, it involves indirect ratification of WTO rules. Our commitment to the field of international trade goes through a different economic model that allows local production to generate employment throughout the territories of the planet. These regulations often have the effect of counterproductively restricting, in economic terms, public participation in the industrial development of countries for the sake of growth and employment generation. That is why, despite its technical nature, I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report codifies Council Regulation (EEC) No 3286/94 of 22 December 1994, which lays down Union procedures in the field of the common commercial policy to ensure the exercise by the Union of its rights under international trade rules, in particular those established under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation.   The principle of simplification is accepted, but we do not fail to condemn the liberalisation of world trade, i.e. the opening up of markets to competition between countries with huge disparities in levels of economic development, as well as its consequences: increasing poverty and inequalities worldwide, attacking workers' achievements and sovereignty of peoples, the appropriation by large multinationals of natural resources and biodiversity, environmental destruction, increased unemployment and the ruin of millions of small farmers.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have abstained from voting because this proposal is a mere codification of existing legal texts on the exercise of the Community's rights under international trade rules, in particular those agreed within the framework of the World Trade Organisation, without any substantive changes.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this report is the codification of Council Regulation (EEC) No 3286/94 of 22 December 1994, which lays down European Union procedures in the field of the common trade policy to ensure the exercise by the EU of its rights under international trade rules, in particular those established under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation.  We reject the liberalisation of world trade, that is, the opening up of markets to competition between countries with huge disparities in levels of economic development, with all the consequences that arise: increased poverty and inequalities worldwide, the attack on workers' achievements and the sovereignty of peoples, the appropriation by large multinationals of natural resources and biodiversity, environmental destruction, increased unemployment, the ruin of millions of small farmers and the question of sovereignty and food security. Thus, although this proposal is to be restricted to a pure and simple codification of the existing texts, we voted against it.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a legal act aimed at protecting the European shipbuilding industry, in serious crisis due to the European Commission's action in the field of competition. This report identifies the problems of public support policies in the sector while they are being severely pursued by the European Commission. The shipbuilding sector is a strategic industrial sector for employment in many European regions and it is therefore necessary to identify problems in international competition as well as problems with internal persecution of public participation. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The report's recital 5 provides protection for Member States' shipyards from unfair competition from third countries that acquire vessels at a particularly low price. French shipyards have suffered particularly from these practices, which is why we must pay particular attention to them. This industry remains one of the jewels of our domestic production and we absolutely must protect it. For this reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Once again, this is a matter which should be within the remit of individual sovereign nations, not the European Union.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, because it is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Far from perfect, this report is nevertheless going in the right direction and I therefore voted for it. This is to protect The shipyards of the Member States from competition from certain countries over vessels acquired at low prices.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This is an outright codification of existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report on the european Parliament and council's proposal for a regulation on defence against harmful price practices in shipbuilding is to codify the regime protecting Member States' shipyards from competition from certain countries over ships acquired at paltry prices. This report is a good move in the right direction, as it wants to provide protection, even relative, for French shipyards, since the proposed directive states that the European Union must react by taking strict measures against any vessel that has been subject to harmful price practices whose sale below normal value is causing harm to the industry of the Countries of the European Union. I have decided to vote for this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 In this period of crisis affecting all Italian and European production sectors, I believe that this measure is defending the European shipbuilding sector by trying to protect it from the possible speculation that may take place during the sales negotiations. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I have supported this report which contains the recommendations made by the Legal Services Advisory Group of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, and which is limited to pure and simple codification of existing texts, without any substantial amendment thereof.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, in which the Consultative Working Party of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission decided by consensus that this proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against harmful pricing of ships is intended solely to codify existing texts without changing their substance. The importance of this Regulation is that it is desirable to establish clear and detailed guidelines on factors which may be relevant for determining whether the injuriously priced sale has caused material injury or threatens to cause injury. In demonstrating that the specific level of the selling price has caused injury to the European Union industry, it is necessary to draw attention to other factors, in particular the prevailing conditions on the EU market. In addition, it is necessary to define the procedural and substantive conditions for the lodging of a complaint concerning a injurious price, as well as to the extent to which such a complaint should be supported by the EU industry and what information on the buyer of the vessel, injurious pricing, the injury caused and the reasons for its occurrence should be indicated in such a complaint. It is also necessary to establish a procedure whereby interested parties should be informed of the information requested by the authorities. Interested parties should be given wide opportunities to provide all necessary evidence and to defend their interests.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. As the Regulation on protection against harmful pricing of vessels is only a codification of the 1996 Regulation and there are virtually no substantive changes, as the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission have also found, I did not have any problems with the support of the new regulation.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on defence against harmful price practices in shipbuilding. The purpose of this codification is to protect European shipyards from low-cost vessels. The text can thus offer relative protection for French shipyards, which are fighting against unfair competition. Thus, it stipulates that "the Union must take action against any vessel that has been subject to harmful price practices whose sale below normal value is detrimental to the EU industry."

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe that the codification of legislative and regulatory texts dealing with the defence against injurious pricing practices in the vandita of ships is necessary, as a matter of legal certainty, and is, to a certain extent, in line with the Commission's new better regulation policy.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The rules in question are relating to the regulation of the sale of certain types of ships in order to prevent speculation relating to the selling price, which could disadvantage the Union industry.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Proposing effective and transparent regulations is one of the main objectives of European co-legislators. With this in mind, codification allows different laws dealing with the same subject to be grouped within a text. This makes it easier and more accessible. I voted in favour of this report on codification on defence against harmful price practices in shipbuilding.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on defence against injurious pricing practices in the sale of ships. In this case, the proposal is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes. The drafting of a code on injurious pricing practices in the shipbuilding sector stems from the need to provide effective defence instruments against sales of ships at prices below normal value, so that this is a market distorting factor. It is therefore desirable to establish clear and detailed guidelines on the factors which are relevant in order to determine whether the sale at injurious prices has caused serious injury or threatens to cause injury. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote was merely concerned with technical matters and it was not connected to the content but was instead concerned with codification. This is important as if you do not codify the text the former several amended versions of the texts stay. Codification, is, in a nutshell a simplification. Any proposal that provides greater legal clarity and transparency should be welcomed as it’s the complex nature of such texts which frequently leads to unnecessary legal challenges often at the taxpayers’ expense Therefore, I voted in favour because it increases transparency and better legislation.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Once again, this is a matter which should be within the remit of individual sovereign nations, not the European Union.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report taking over the Commission proposal as adapted to the recommendations of the Consultative Working Party of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission. The purpose of this proposal is to undertake a codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 385/96 of 29 January 1996 on protection against injurious pricing of vessels. The new Regulation will supersede the various acts incorporated in it; this proposal fully preserves the content of the acts being codified and hence it does no more than bring them together with only such formal amendments as are required by the codification exercise itself. The aim of this exercise is to make a law that has been frequently amended to be clear and transparent.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the defence against injurious pricing practices in the sale of ships drafted by my colleague Jiří Maštálka, which verifies that the Commission's proposal is limited to a mere codification of existing texts, without any substantial changes.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the european Parliament and the Council's proposal for a regulation on defence against harmful price practices in shipbuilding. This provision would protect The shipyards of the Member States from unfair competition by third countries in this area. With these major projects, such as the one in Saint-Nazaire, France is indeed particularly targeted by such measures. The proposed directive recognises the need for the Union to take action against any vessel that has been subject to harmful price practices, such as selling below its normal value. Considering that this measure amounts to a relative protection of European industries, I could only vote in favour of this text.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on defence against injurious pricing practices in the sale of ships. This proposal is limited to a mere codification of existing texts, without any substantial changes.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which is purely technical in nature, because defence against price policies that do not facilitate competitive participation in the market has always been a pillar to which my party refers and my efforts in this regard aim to support the Italian economy in Europe and in the world.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ At the heart of this report is an attack on allegedly unfair pricing in shipbuilding, which I view as an attack on the free market.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the meeting of 13-14 October on the proposal to defend against injurious pricing practices in the sale of ships, the Advisory Group composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded by common accord that the proposal is a mere codification of existing texts without any particular amendment. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report outlines that the Consultative Working Party consisting of the respective legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed that the proposal is a straightforward codification of existing texts, without any change in their substance. Codification of agreements that have been amended on multiple occasions is important so as to ensure that they are accessible and clear to citizens. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a legal act aimed at protecting the European shipbuilding industry, in serious crisis due to the European Commission's action in the field of competition. This report identifies the problems of public support policies in the sector while they are being severely pursued by the European Commission. The shipbuilding sector is a strategic industrial sector for employment in many European regions and it is therefore necessary to identify problems in international competition as well as problems with internal persecution of public participation. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal in question contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts relating to the injurious pricing of vessels without any change in their substance. Hence as this is a simple procedural exercise I have voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report codifies Regulation (EC) 385/96 on defence against harmful price practices in shipbuilding. Considering that this report proposes a simple codification of existing legislation without substantial amendments, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. In the interests of clarity and transparency of the law, the European Parliament has codified the defence regulation against harmful price practices in shipbuilding. Since the shipbuilding sector is governed by its own provisions, in particular to combat unfair competition, the aim was to bring together in a new single text the different rules distributed in several legislative acts. This will simplify European law, which is too often a matter of experts.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on defence against harmful price practices in shipbuilding. My vote is in the direction of greater protection of the French naval market. It is about restoring fairness and fairness in the workplace. Many non-European countries manufacture ships that they resell for much cheaper, while minimizing workers' conditions. We must recall the quality of the French shipyard and our determination to improve the standard of living of its employees. While competition can be beneficial, it becomes toxic when it is unfair. This is why non-European practices must not influence French practices, which guarantee respect for the worker.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report, as it merely seeks to codify existing legislation without the possibility of amending it. The existing legislation is empty and we do not agree with it in its entirety.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Codification is a means of simplifying and clarifying Union law in order to make it more accessible and easier for ordinary citizens to understand. This objective cannot be achieved as long as there is a scattering of numerous provisions, amended on several occasions, often substantially, which requires a reading of both the original act and the acts amending it. Thus, an analysis work is necessary to identify the current rules, based on the comparison of a multiplicity of different acts. For this reason, and in order to ensure the clarity and transparency of the law, it is necessary to codify the rules which have been frequently changed.  The purpose of this report is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 385/96 of 29 January 1996 on the defence against the practice of prices harmful to the sale of ships. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. The report fully preserves the content of the codified acts, but merely gathers them and only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself. In the case of an eminently technical procedure and with no disagreement in principle with the basic act, we voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against the setting of injured prices for vessels. The European Commission's proposal has been modified in line with the recommendations of the Consultative Working Party of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the European Commission, and the proposal in question contains a clear and simple codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report. This codification does not lead to any substantial change in the rules for the sale of certain types of ships.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 My vote is against the report, as it merely seeks to codify existing legislation without the possibility of amending it. The existing legislation is empty and I do not agree with it in its entirety.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal as it contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Maštálka's report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on defence against injurious pricing practices in the sale of ships. I believe, in fact, that the legislative simplification of the Union's legislative acts is essential, given the increasing competences of the Union and the proliferation of European legislation. European citizens have the right to simple and transparent access to EU law, without having to seek legislation of interest within a number of scattered legislative texts. The codification of Council Regulation No 395/96 on unfair commercial behaviour in the sale of ships, on which the legal services of the three institutions agree, is a step in the right direction. Formal changes that are minimal do not change the content of the legislation, but make life easier for EU citizens and technical operators working under EU law.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. As rapporteur for my group on labour law for seafarers and MEP from the Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania region, I voted today in favour of the report on protection against injurious pricing in shipbuilding, because this approach prevents social dumping and ensures fair competition in shipbuilding.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Maštálka report, given that it simply concerns a codification to take into account changes in the pricing of vessels.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, the purpose of which is the codification of overlapping rules but which preserves, in any event, the content of the previous acts.  Voting is not connected to any express content and only expresses formal will.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report alongside my colleagues in the Socialist and Democrats Group. This report is a simple codification to take into account changes in the pricing of vessels.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on protection against harmful costing of ships. This report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against harmful pricing of ships aims only to codify existing texts without changing their substance, thereby ensuring their safety. I believe that ensuring the security of legislation is very important, especially with the rapid development of information technologies.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, the purpose of which is the codification of overlapping rules but which preserves, in any event, the content of the previous acts.  Voting is not connected to any express content and only expresses formal will.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on protection against harmful pricing of vessels, as codification does not change acts in substance, but becomes clearer and more accessible to citizens. The European Union must ensure that it can find and understand its legal acts more easily and efficiently, and codification is heading in this direction. In this context, I support an agreement allowing for an accelerated process for the swift adoption of codified acts and for Commission staff to codify acts after a maximum of ten amendments. The scattering of provisions in various acts leads to the need for swift adoption of codified acts to make the provisions more accessible and certain.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote in the report on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on defence against harmful price practices in shipbuilding. Recital 5 offers protection to The shipyards of the Member States against unfair competition from third countries that acquire vessels at a particularly low price. French shipyards have suffered particularly from these practices, which is why we must pay particular attention to them. This industry remains one of the jewels of our domestic production and we absolutely must protect it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I was previously against the original law, and this amendment further attacks the free market by regulating shipbuilding pricing, and it should not be the role of the European Union to regulate markets or interfere. Therefore I voted against this amendment.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Ji-Maetelka's report on the defence against harmful price practices in shipbuilding. This essentially technical text simplifies the various European and international legislations by bringing together the relevant legislation into a single corpus. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution of 7 July 2015 on the european Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on defence against harmful price practices in shipbuilding. This vote is the result of an accelerated procedure for simplifying and clarifying the law and does not affect the legal consequences of the original version.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This is a pure codification of the existing legal texts to protect against harmful pricing in shipbuilding, without any changes in content. Since there is no substantial change in the law, I abstain.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. According to the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, this proposal is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes. This is the subject of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against injurious pricing practices in the sale of ships. I have therefore decided to support the report.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of the proposed codification is to protect Member States' shipyards from competition from certain countries over vessels acquired at low prices. The adaptation of the initial recital No. 5 may offer relative protection for French shipyards. Indeed, the proposed directive stipulates that "the Union must take action against any vessel that has been subject to harmful price practices whose sale below normal value is detrimental to THE EU industry". Vote: FOR, because this text will protect at least partially the French shipbuilding.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it seeks to protect Member States' shipyards from unfair competition from some third countries.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. This report deals with protection against harmful shipbuilding pricing practices. Agreeing with the spirit and content of the report, I voted in favour.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a legal act aimed at protecting the European shipbuilding industry, in serious crisis due to the European Commission's action in the field of competition. This report identifies the problems of public support policies in the sector while they are being severely pursued by the European Commission. The shipbuilding sector is a strategic industrial sector for employment in many European regions and it is therefore necessary to identify problems in international competition as well as problems with internal persecution of public participation. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 As in the previous report, this is only a codification of the existing text, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. On the proposal of the European Commission to parliament and the Council on amendments to the Regulation on protection against harmful designation of vessels, Mep Jiří Maštálka drafted an opinion on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs.  This Regulation defines the rules for determining the price of a vessel that damages the customer and the compensation to the shipyard for each vessel with a harmfully shaped price whose sale to a customer outside the vessel's country of origin causes damage. I supported the Report as it is a codification of text without significant changes, approved by the advisory groups of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Cases where the price of a ship is artificially lowered cause damage to entire branches of the world economy. This report strengthens the new defence mechanisms, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on defence against injurious ship pricing, because the Advisory Group, which consists of the respective legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, has found by mutual agreement that the proposal does indeed constitute merely codification of existing texts, without modifying their substance.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text. The introduction of this text will protect The shipyards of the Member States from competition from certain countries that manufacture and sell vessels below market value. The French shipyards will be protected in this way, and we are delighted.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal which is a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of Parliament and of the Council on defence against injurious pricing practices in the sale of ships. The aim of this proposal is, in fact, to provide legal instruments capable of inhibiting the sale of ships at prices below normal value, in order to protect the Community principles of competition and the free market.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I also abstained from this vote, as it is, in turn, a mere codification of the existing legal texts to protect against harmful pricing in shipbuilding without any substantive changes.

name: Jean-Luc
text: Mélenchon (GUE/NGL), in writing. The purpose of this proposal is to codify the Defence Against Harmful Price Practices Regulation in Shipbuilding. The purpose of this regulation is to provide an effective means of protecting against ship sales below their normal value. This led to the adoption of a code of price-damaging practice in shipbuilding: the shipbuilding agreement, which is itself based on the anti-dumping agreement (1994). This is a purely technical report. Nevertheless, it brings together the customs tools necessary to establish solidarity protectionism in the shipbuilding sector. I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Considering 5 offers protection to Shipyards in Member States against unfair competition from third countries that acquire vessels at a particularly low price. French shipyards have suffered particularly from these practices, which is why we must pay particular attention to them. This industry remains one of the jewels of our domestic production and we absolutely must protect it. I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As stated above, I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of Parliament and the Council on the defence against the practice of prices harmful to the sale of ships. The purpose of the proposal in question is to codify the existing texts, without substantive amendments, which, from the point of view of legislative technique, with a view to simplifying existing legal rules, deserves my agreement.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal for the protection against injurious pricing of vessels, which is only a technical adjustment and fully preserves the content of the act being codified.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The unfair competition generated by the opening of borders exposes our shipbuilding industry to social and fiscal dumping by foreign countries, as well as inequalities in production and security standards. We support this proposal, which allows measures to be taken against vessels acquired under financial conditions that harm our national shipyards.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that this proposal is based on the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments, this report has my vote in favour. I advocate simplification and clarification of EU legislation as a principle of legal certainty, proximity to citizens and easy access.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report on the european Parliament and Council's proposal for a regulation on defence against harmful price practices in shipbuilding is to codify the regime protecting Member States' shipyards from competition from certain countries over vessels acquired at paltry prices. I have decided to vote in favour of this text since it confers even relative protection for French shipyards, since the proposal for a directive states that the European Union must react by taking strict measures against any vessel that has been subject to harmful price practices whose sale below normal value is causing harm to the industry of the countries of the European Union.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which is another codification file, and is simply a codification to take into account changes in the pricing of vessels.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this technical text, relating to the defence of the Union against harmful price practices in shipbuilding. It is a codification of existing texts following the accelerated inter-institutional procedure of simplification and clarification of the law. The codified version of the text, drawn up by the legal services of the Commission, the Council and Parliament, carries exactly the same legal consequences as the original version.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on an accelerated working method for the official codification of legislative texts, we welcome without delay this proposal on defence against injurious pricing practices in the sale of ships. In the course of its examination, the Advisory Group concluded, by common accord, that the proposal is limited to a mere codification of existing texts and does not make any substantial changes. We therefore call on our President to forward it to the Commission and the national parliaments as soon as possible.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Codification of provisions that have undergone frequent changes over time is necessary if Community legislation is to be fully in line with the principles of clarity and transparency. In this respect, the purpose of this proposal is to initiate the codification of Regulation (EC) No 358/96 of 29 January 1996 on protection against injurious pricing practices in the sale of ships. In view of the above considerations and since this is a technical report which does not introduce any innovation in its content, I have decided to welcome it.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for the Commission’s recommendations of the Consultative Working Party of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supports the work done by the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, which have recoded the provisions on protection against injurious pricing practices in the field of shipbuilding.  This recoding of the provisions is a normal procedural step, but very important when we talk about documents that have been adopted and modified many times over time. This procedure brings clarity and transparency to legislation and helps European citizens better understand the measures in place. This principle of clarity and transparency in legislation is a very important one in law and in a democratic society, and that is why I voted for this report.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report, as this report is also a summary of the existing legal texts on protection against shipbuilding pricing, without any substantive changes.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The proposal is limited to the codification of existing legislation without any substantive changes.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the defence against injurious pricing practices in the sale of ships, I am in favour because the proposal is a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Council Regulation No 385/96/EEC on protection against harmful vessel pricing was adopted on 29 January 1996 and has been amended on several occasions. Back in 1987, the Commission established a rule that, after a dozen amendments to a particular act, it must be codified, thus contributing to greater certainty of the correct application of the act.  The basic Regulation was amended in the part relating to the frameworks of the Shipbuilding Agreement, which found that due to the specific characteristics of transactions when purchasing ships, countervailing and anti-dumping duties were not applied in practice. The need to provide effective means of protection against the sale of vessels below their normal value causing damage has led to the drafting of the Code of Harmful Pricing for Shipbuilding, which together with the Basic Principles constitutes Annex III. The Shipbuilding Agreement. In order to maintain the balance of rights and obligations established by the Shipbuilding Agreement, the Union shall take measures against any vessel with a detrimental price whose sale below normal value causes damage to the Union industry.  As it is an act whose role is to protect against harmful pricing of vessels, and because of the interests of Croatian shipbuilding as well as the need to apply it properly both in the EU and among stakeholders on which this Regulation has a legal effect, I consider the proposed codification necessary because it contributes to greater legal certainty.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to propose better protection of Member States' shipyards from unfair competition from certain countries over low-cost acquired vessels. The adaptation of the initial recital 5, in particular, can partly protect French shipyards. Indeed, the text stipulates that 'the Union must take action against any vessel that has been the subject of harmful price practices whose sale below normal value is causing harm to the EU industry'. For once, therefore, the European Union is concerned about protecting an important industry. That is why, not wanting to miss such a rare opportunity, I am in favour of this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The purpose of this proposal is to codify Council Regulation(EC)No.385/96 on protection against harmful vessel pricing. This proposal fully transfers the content of codifying acts and consolidates them into a single act only with those formal amendments necessary for codification. This Regulation was preceded by the drafting of the Code of Harmful Pricing for Shipbuilding, allowing for an effective way of protecting against the sale of vessels below their normal value. The importance of this Regulation is in striking a balance of rights and obligations established by the Shipbuilding Agreement and measures relating to the prohibition of harmful pricing below normal value which ultimately causes harm to the Union industry based on clear evidence and objective testing. Therefore, I support the rapporteur's proposal to protect the customer from harmful pricing of vessels and indirectly the economy of the European Union through European Union measures. Compensation for harmful pricing may be imposed on the shipyard for any vessel with a detrimental price whose sale to a customer outside the vessel's country of origin causes damage.  In order for the Regulation to come to life in its implementation, I see great importance in implementing appropriate price adjustments of differences affecting price comparability, including differences in terms and benefits of sales, contractual penalties, taxes, sales levels, quantities, physical characteristics and any other differences that also have an impact on price comparability.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Consideration of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on codifying Council Regulation (EC) No 2012 385/96 as of 29 January 1996 on protection against harmful design of vessel prices led to the unanimous conclusion of the Advisory Working Group that this proposal constitutes a direct codification of existing texts without significant changes. The importance of this Regulation is that it contributes to the smooth running of vessel trade and the protection of the Union's manufacturing industry in the economically important field of shipbuilding, but also to the protection of consumers as an important value that the EU wholeheartedly propagates. Consequently, I support this draft because I consider such a regulation to be extremely necessary.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I have expressed my support for the codification of the Defence Regulation against harmful price practices in shipbuilding. This procedure helps to simplify and clarify the text, without altering its legal consequences.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. The sale of ships at harmful prices threatens the European Union industry, which is still recovering from the past effects of dumping and subsidising. In this regard, and in view of the particular nature of the trade in ships, which escapes ordinary anti-dumping measures, it is essential to codify Council Directive (EC) No 385/96 of 29 January 1996 on the defence against the practice of indulging prices in the sale of ships. This report aims to adopt the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments to the legislative text. For the foregoing, and in accordance with the approval given to the speciality report by the Advisory Group on Legal Services, I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report prepared by Ji-Maetelka on behalf of the Legal Committee on a new regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the defence against harmful price practices in shipbuilding. Of course, this is a regulation of relative scope since it is limited to a codification of existing texts, without altering their substance, nevertheless a historical reminder is necessary. In December 1994, the Commission on European Communities of yesteryear and the governments of the Republic of Korea, the United States, Finland, Japan, Norway and Sweden adopted an agreement within the OECD on the normal conditions of competition in the shipbuilding industry, an agreement that covered about 80% of the global market, which is highly Asian oriented. 21 years later, the trend has intensified: China becoming the world's leading manufacturer ahead of South Korea with more than 40% of the construction delivered in the merchant navy, with the European Union essentially building passenger ships. It is this map of specialisation, with for example the rise of the manufacture of pleasure boats, that Europe will have to play in order not to stay docked.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission has delivered a positive opinion and considers that this proposal is limited to the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments to the texts, there is no reason to vote against or even to abstain.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I have supported this report which contains the recommendations made by the Legal Services Advisory Group of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, as it is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without any substantial amendment thereof.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposed regulation on defence against harmful price practices in shipbuilding, the aim of which was to codify this regulation. This new regulation will replace the various acts incorporated into it. I am motivated by the fact that the Legal Services Advisory Group of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission believes that the proposal in question is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr McDerman's report. Mastalka on the defence against injurious pricing practices in the sale of ships, the proposal in question is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour because it is a simple intervention to codify and adapt previous regulations, but they do not affect their content.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, the purpose of which is the codification of overlapping rules but which preserves, in any event, the content of the previous acts.  Voting is not connected to any express content and only expresses formal will.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a legal act aimed at protecting the European shipbuilding industry, in serious crisis due to the European Commission's action in the field of competition. This report identifies the problems of public support policies in the sector while they are being severely pursued by the European Commission. The shipbuilding sector is a strategic industrial sector for employment in many European regions and it is therefore necessary to identify problems in international competition as well as problems with internal persecution of public participation. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on defence against injurious pricing practices in the sale of ships, as it is limited to a mere codification of existing legislative texts, without introducing any substantial changes.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this codification, as it is simply a codification to take into account changes in the pricing of vessels.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour as the proposal only proposed a direct codification of existing and existing texts, without any change in their substance.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I agree with the Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on protection against harmful pricing of vessels, since the proposal is adapted to the opinions and recommendations of the advisory legal services of the European Commission, Parliament and Council.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it codifies the protection against injurious pricing of vessels.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the draft report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on protection against harmful design of vessel prices (codified text).  Taking into account the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on the accelerated method of work for the formal codification of legislative texts, in particular its point 4, the advisory working group composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission met on 14 October and 13 November 2014 and, inter alia, considered that proposal submitted by the Commission. At these meetings, consideration of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on codifying Council Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013 385/96 as of 29 January 1996 on protection against harmful design of vessel prices led to the unanimous conclusion of the Advisory Working Group that the proposal constituted a direct codification of existing texts without substantive changes.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The codification of texts should be an opportunity to re-evaluate their content in substance and not only by type.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is one of the world's leading producers in shipbuilding. In the face of current competition on the world market in this area, the European institutions need to protect the conduct of this activity within the Union. Unfortunately, existing regulations within the World Trade Organisation, inherited from the defunct GATT, do not ensure adequate compensation for builders in the case of injury caused by dumping practices in a number of countries or even in the Member States.  Regulation (EEC) No 2081/9 Council Regulation (EC) No 385/96 comes to fill this existing legislative gap at global and European level, regulating ship pricing practices, at least at European Union level. Where injury to producers in the European ship industry is due to be caused by the imposition of duties, countermeasures and equivalent measures on manufacturers who do not comply with the relevant regulations. This is a well-deserved protection for the shipbuilding industry against unfair competition practices. However, the Council Regulation must be codified in line with the new legislative requirements of the European institutions, in particular the European Parliament.  I believe that the adoption of this report will strengthen European regulations in this area and safeguard the shipbuilding industry, which is so necessary for the European Union.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I have spoken in favour of the european Parliament and the Council's proposal for a regulation on defence against harmful price practices in shipbuilding. It should be remembered that the proposal in question is limited to an outright codification of existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Selling of vessels at a lower price than the normal value harms the EU industry and its producers and I therefore voted in favour of this resolution. The regulation makes it possible for the European Commission to launch an investigation and impose charges on the builders of injuriously priced vessels, which should deter them from setting uncompetitive export prices. I fully support the need to set out precise and transparent rules on the calculation of the normal value and the export price voiced in the resolution.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively on the proposal for a regulation to protect against harmful pricing of vessels which also constitutes direct codification of existing texts without substantive changes.  Shipbuilding is a sector that requires continuous technological development and innovation as fundamental preconditions for competitiveness growth. As a representative from a country where maritime affairs and shipbuilding have a long tradition, in which shipbuilding represents a very important industrial sector with exports of 10% to 15%, I hold the Shipbuilding Agreement particularly important.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The European Parliament has adopted the Commission proposal as adapted in accordance with the recommendations of the Consultative Group, which relate in particular to substantive changes. The proposal aims to protect against harmful pricing by vessels. I supported this report.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, the purpose of which is the codification of overlapping rules but which preserves, in any event, the content of the previous acts.  Voting is not connected to any express content and only expresses formal will.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of the proposed codification is to protect Member States' shipyards from competition from certain countries over vessels acquired at low prices. The adaptation of the initial recital 5 may offer relative protection for French shipyards. Indeed, the proposed directive stipulates that "the Union must take action against any vessel that has been subject to harmful price practices whose sale below normal value is detrimental to THE EU industry". I voted for this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The codified proposal contains a simple codification of existing texts without any substantive amendments, and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, the purpose of which is the codification of overlapping rules but which preserves, in any event, the content of the previous acts.  Voting is not connected to any express content and only expresses formal will.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to ensure a fair naval policy without unjustified oversteer.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In view of the view that the advisory group on the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission consider that the proposal in question is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without any substantial amendment thereof, I consider it positive to vote in favour of that report so that it can be approved at first reading.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a legal act aimed at protecting the European shipbuilding industry, in serious crisis due to the European Commission's action in the field of competition. This report identifies the problems of public support policies in the sector while they are being severely pursued by the European Commission. The shipbuilding sector is a strategic industrial sector for employment in many European regions and it is therefore necessary to identify problems in international competition as well as problems with internal persecution of public participation. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Simplification and clarification of EU law cannot be achieved as long as there is a dispersion of numerous provisions, amended on several occasions, often substantially, which requires a reading of both the original act and the acts amending it.  On 1 April 1987, the Commission decided to instruct its services to codify all normative acts after a maximum of ten amendments have occurred.   The purpose of this report is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 385/96 of 29 January 1996 on the defence against the practice of prices harmful to the sale of ships. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained in them. The report fully preserves the content of the codified acts, but merely gathers them and only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have abstained from this vote too, as it is, in turn, a mere codification of the existing legal texts to protect against harmful pricing in shipbuilding without any substantive changes.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Codification is a means of simplifying and clarifying EU law. This objective cannot be achieved as long as there is a scattering of numerous provisions, amended on several occasions, often substantially, which requires a reading of both the original act and the acts amending it.
