Thus, considerable analysis work is needed to identify the current rules, based on the comparison of a multiplicity of different acts. For this reason, and in order to ensure the clarity and transparency of the law, it is necessary to codify the rules which have been frequently changed. On 1 April 1987, the European Commission decided to instruct its services to codify all regulatory acts after a maximum of ten amendments have occurred.   The purpose of this report is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 385/96 of 29 January 1996 on the defence against the practice of prices harmful to the sale of ships. The report fully preserves the content of the codified acts, but merely gathers them and only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself. We voted in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting approval to the Council Decision granting fishing opportunities in EU waters to fishing vessels flying Venezuela's flag off the coast of French Guiana because it establishes a legislative framework suitable for de facto fishing in that area. Venezuelan vessels have been allowed to fish off French Guiana for decades on the condition that some of the catch be landed at local ports. However, there is no international fisheries agreement between the EU and Venezuela. That is why this new framework is necessary which obliges Venezuela to respect the compensation associated with this proposal and to respect European legislation in relation, for example, to fish stocks that may be fish, type of fishing gear, vessel tracking devices, catch reporting, maximum number of authorised fishing vessels and proportion of catches landed in the ports of French Guiana.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The links between Venezuelan fishermen and french canneries in Guyana are very close. This report recommends authorising fishing, in return for which 75% of the fishing product will be processed on French territory. The fishing potential off Guyana is indeed particularly important, but remains underexploited to this day. Finally, the agreement also aims to reduce illegal fishing by Venezuelan fishermen. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote as there are conflicting interests here: this vote will set a precedent for non-EU flagged vessels fishing in EU waters.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, because this decision makes it possible to sustain the processing industry in French Guiana, which depends in part on the exploitation by Venezuelan fishing vessels of the living natural resources of the exclusive economic zone off the coast. Given the economic and social importance of this activity in the region, Venezuelan fishing vessels have been allowed to fish for several decades provided that some of the fishing is landed in Guyanese ports.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to resolve the institutional conflict caused by disagreement over the precise legal basis.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. After lengthy negotiations, it is a matter of allowing Venezuelan fishing vessels to enter the waters of French Guiana. But this authorization is not without consideration: thus, Martinique ships will now be able to catch snapper or tuna off the coast of Venezuela. In addition, 75% of the fish caught by Venezuelan ships will be landed in Guyana for processing. In fact, there are ancient links between Venezuelan fishermen and French canneries in Guyana. It will be argued that Guyana, the French department, should be able to develop its own fishery and take advantage of its important fishing potential, which includes various species of shrimp and 200 species of fish. However, the counterparties seem to me to be satisfactory for the time being, notably limiting illegal fishing by Venezuelans. That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The processing industry in French Guiana depends in part on the exploitation by Venezuelan fishing vessels of the living natural resources of the exclusive economic zone off the coast. As a long as, Venezuelan fishing vessels have been allowed to fish for several decades provided that part of the fishing is landed in Guyanese ports. To legally formalise this situation, the Commission has put forward a proposal in which the European Union is committed to ceding fishing rights to Venezuelan vessels in accordance with EU regulations on the preservation and management of fishing stocks. After a legal debate on the role of the European Parliament, the declaration is submitted to its binding opinion. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the project declaring the granting of fishing opportunities in EU waters to Venezuelan-flagged fishing vessels in the exclusive economic zone off French Guiana because the processing industry depends in part on the continuity of those vessels and, although cooperation with Venezuela does not conform to the EU legal framework , ships have authority and activity. The legal solution to the declarations under which the commitment to the principles of the CFP is signed seems therefore correct.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on fishing opportunities in European Union waters for Venezuelan-flagged fishing vessels off the coast of French Guiana is to allow access for Venezuelan fishing vessels into french Guiana waters (41 in 2013) 12 miles beyond the coast and leaving fish processing in French Guiana. However, this report was slowed down by the conflict between Parliament and the Council, since the Council had initially adopted this agreement without consulting Parliament. In return, Martinique fishing vessels have the opportunity to fish some fish off the coast of Venezuela. Guyana has significant fishing potential that is still under-exploited and deserves to develop its own fishery. As it stands, however, there are counterparties and these limit illegal fishing by Venezuelans, especially since there are historical links between Venezuelan fishermen and French canneries in Guyana. So I voted for this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text being voted on is acceptable and balanced, a good compromise that guarantees the fishing rights of Guyana French, part of the overseas countries and territories of the European Union, compared to Venezuela; for these reasons I voted in favour of him

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Venezuelan fishing vessels have been fishing in Community waters off the coast of French Guiana for decades. In practice, fishing was authorised but without an international fisheries agreement within the meaning of Council Regulation (EC) No 1006/2008.  In this case, the Council opted for a unilateral Declaration, with binding legal effects under international law, which it adopted in Council Decision 2012/19/EU of 16 December 2011 approving, on behalf of the European Union, the Declaration on the granting of fishing opportunities in EU waters to fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of French Guiana.  However, in the absence of codecision, the Commission and Parliament denounced this Declaration before the COURT of Justice of the EU, which would annul it, although maintaining it with effect until the entry into force of a new Decision, which is what is now being raised and which has received my vote in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this recommendation for the granting of fishing opportunities in an exclusive economic zone adjacent to the french guiana coast for fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela.  The processing industry in French Guiana depends in part on the use of living natural resources in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of French Guiana by Venezuelan fishing vessels. As these activities are economic and socially important in the region, Venezuelan fishing vessels have been authorised to fish in the area for many decades, but the proportion of catches must be landed in french ports of Guiana. Landings and processing of fishery products are therefore an important source of income and job creation in French Guiana. In the absence of an international fisheries agreement between the EU and Venezuela, cooperation between the two parties is not subject to the requirements of the Union's legal order. In practice, however, Venezuelan fishing vessels are allowed to operate. In this context, the Commission has tabled a proposal in which the European Union has undertaken to transfer the right of fishing to Venezuelan vessels. The legal solution found, i.e. the Council Declaration submitted for approval by the European Parliament stating compliance with legally binding European Union acts on the conservation and management of fishery resources (common fisheries policy and other rules), is an appropriate solution, as these fishing activities are small in scale.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the recommendations as they dictate a more appropriate legislative solution in the field of fishing in bilateral relations between French Guya (which is considered eu territory) and the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela. Since landing and manufacturing is the most important recruiter in French Guya, it is also necessary to define the legal obligations of both countries accordingly. Given that Venezuela takes due account of the agreements reached in this area, no major complications are expected.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this Recommendation of members, and it is about the activities of Venezuelan-flagged ships that have been carried out for several decades. The proposal provides for an appropriate legal basis and authorised ships must comply with legal provisions; of the stocks of the target fish, the type of fishing gear, the vessel tracking device, the reporting of catches, as well as the proportion of catches to be lowered at the ports of French Guiana.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe that it manages to balance the political and legal aspect very well: it is essential, on the one hand, that vessels flying the Venezuelan flag continue to fish in the waters of the EEZ of Guyana French, thereby supporting its economy and, on the other hand, that the agreement conferring this right is ratified by the European Parliament.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Fishing vessels flying the flag of Venezuela have been allowed to operate in the exclusive economic zone (EEZ) of the French overseas department of Guyana for several decades. The processing industry in Guyana French depends on this fishing activity. European law requires an international fisheries agreement in issuing fishing authorisations to third-country vessels in EU waters, so we are in agreement. Authorised vessels must comply with the provisions of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) specifying, among other things, the fish stocks that can be targeted, the type of fishing gear, the vessel control devices, the reporting of catches and the percentage of catches to be landed in ports in Guyana French. The agreement provides for the authorisation of a limited number of vessels to fish, provided that European law is complied with. The partnership agreements that the EU enters into with third countries must respect the principles of sustainability that our community has set itself with the approval of the common fisheries policy. Thanks to the judgment of the Court of Justice, which ruled on this partnership in November 2014, the European Parliament can act as guardian of the CFP as co-legislator in the approval of these agreements.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. This measure should succeed in restricting illegal fishing by Venezuelan vessels.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The landing and processing of fish products is a significant source of income and employment for French Guiana. For several decades, Venezuelan fishing vessels have been allowed to fish in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of this region. The condition of the licence to fish is that part of the fishery be landed in Guyanese ports. After an institutional conflict, the Court invalidated the Council's position, which had ruled without waiting for Parliament's approval. This report completes the approval process for the Commission's new proposal with the appropriate legal basis (Article 43, paragraph 2, and Article 218, paragraph 6, point a) of the FUE Treaty. The approval of this agreement supports the activity in the French department of Guyana.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision approving the declaration on the granting of fishing opportunities in EU waters to Venezuelan vessels off the coast of Eastern French.  The landing and processing of fishery products is an important source of resources and jobs for Guyana French, but cooperation with Venezuela must be in line with the requirements of the Union's legal system. In this context, the Commission has presented a proposal in which the European Union undertakes to cede the right to fish to Venezuelan vessels, which is an option adapted to the small size of the fishing activity in question. After a period of suspension due to the judicial process before the Court of Justice of the European Union, and resolved an institutional conflict, its approval is therefore necessary. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote as there are conflicting interests here: this vote will set a precedent for non-EU flagged vessels fishing in EU waters.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal to allow fishing vessels flying the flag of Venezuela the opportunity to fish off the coast of French Guiana. This proposal follows a pending legal disagreement with the Council on the correct legal basis for this decision. The legal solution found – a declaration to be made by the Council, with the approval of the European Parliament – is appropriate for the small-scale fishing in question. This will now provide the fishing carried on in this area, and whose regular activity was not affected by this delay, with the appropriate framework.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour as this has been in use for years and has been confirmed without creating any particular problems.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to allow Venezuelan fishing vessels to access the waters of French Guiana.  In addition to historical ties between Venezuelan fishermen and French canneries, the agreement provides a profitable counterparty for French interests: martinique vessels will have the opportunity to fish for snapper or tuna off Venezuela. In addition, 75% of the fish caught by Venezuelan ships are landed in Guyana for processing, creating a real dynamic for our local businesses. Although Guyana should be able to develop its own fishery, the counterparties provided in the agreement are fruitful for the local industry.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I think the approach as it emerged from the discussion of the recommendation on the draft Council decision approving the European Union's declaration on the granting of fishing opportunities in Union waters to fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivian Republic of Venezuela in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of French Guiana, and I am voting in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of granting fishing opportunities in EU waters for vessels flying the flag of Venezuela off the coast of Guyana French. The processing industry established in Guyana French depends in part on the exploitation by Venezuelan vessels of the biological natural resources of its exclusive economic zone (EEZ).  In view of the economic and social importance of activity in the region, these vessels have been authorized to fish for several decades, provided that a certain proportion of catches are landed in local ports. The landing and processing of fishery products is therefore an important source of resources and jobs for Guyana French.  However, since the EU has no international fisheries agreement with Venezuela, cooperation with that country is not in line with the requirements of the EU legal order. In practice, however, the activity of Venezuelan fishing vessels is authorised. With this proposal, presented by the Commission, the European Union is committed to surrendering the right to fish to Venezuelan vessels.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote in favour of giving vessels from the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela the opportunity to fish in the EEZ of Guyana French is linked to a strictly economic principle: fish products are the primary source of resources for Guyana French. In order for this agreement to become binding not only as a practice but also from a legislative point of view, and since the European Union does not yet have an official agreement with Venezuela, I am voting for an official proposal for cooperation and exploitation of the fish stock off the coast of Guyana French. In practice, the activities of Venezuelan fishing vessels are authorised, but it is good that the rights and duties of their respective actors should be precisely and transparently inno sned. This is done through the conclusion of an agreement between the Republic of Venezuela and the European Union.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The manufacturing industry installed in French Guiana depends in part on the exploitation of living natural resources from its Exclusive Economic Zone (EES). As there is no international EU agreement with Venezuela on fisheries, cooperation is not in line with the European legal system. To this end, the Commission has proposed an EU commitment on the handing over of the right to fish for Venezuelan vessels. The legal solution found - a statement to be made by the Council with the approval of the European Parliament - appears appropriate to the small scale of the activity in question. The declaration takes shape under Decision No 2012/19/EU, but the Council amended the legal basis by transforming Parliament into an advisory body rather than a body to which it needed to seek approval. Parliament and the Commission have taken action before the Court of Justice of the European Union, which has stated that Parliament's decision is not only consultative but binding in that its approval is required. Once the institutional conflict has been resolved, i support this recommendation, that the procedure for approving this proposal should be completed as soon as possible, thereby giving the appropriate framework for fishing activity in this region.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Ferreira's recommendation because it essentially concerns the conclusion of an agreement between Guyana French and Venezuelan vessels, giving them the right to fish in the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ). Although there is no international agreement with Venezuela on fisheries, the landing and processing of fishery products is a source of resources and job creation for Eastern French. Furthermore, Venezuelan vessels, which have been authorised to fish in these waters for several decades, have always fulfilled the condition of divesting a certain quota of catches by landing them in local ports.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This declaration will give access to Venezuelan fishing vessels to operate in EU waters off the coast of the French department of Guiana. The disagreement over the correct legal basis has now been resolved so I will be voting in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting approval to the Council Decision granting fishing opportunities in EU waters to fishing vessels flying Venezuela's flag off the coast of French Guiana because it establishes a legislative framework suitable for de facto fishing in that area. Venezuelan vessels have been allowed to fish off French Guiana for decades on the condition that some of the catch be landed at local ports. However, there is no international fisheries agreement between the EU and Venezuela. That is why this new framework is necessary which obliges Venezuela to respect the compensation associated with this proposal and to respect European legislation in relation, for example, to fish stocks that may be fish, type of fishing gear, vessel tracking devices, catch reporting, maximum number of authorised fishing vessels and proportion of catches landed in the ports of French Guiana.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The processing industry based in French Guiana depends in part on the exploitation of living natural resources in its Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) by Venezuelan vessels. Given the economic and social importance of this activity in the region, fishing has been authorised for these vessels for decades, with the proviso that part of the catch is landed in local ports. The landing and processing of fishery products therefore represent an important source of income and jobs for French Guiana. However there is no international agreement between the EU and Venezuela on fisheries, thus cooperation with this country was not in line with the requirements of Community law. The legal basis of this agreement has now been solved and Venezuela is acting in accordance with European regulations so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes to approve the Council's decision allowing Venezuelan-flagged vessels to operate in the waters of French Guiana, provided that part of the fishing is landed in Guyanese ports. Venezuela has also complied with EU legislation with regard to fishing declarations, the maximum number of fishing vessels allowed and the percentage of catches to be landed, the preservation of target fish stocks and respect for the types of fishing gear. Considering that such an authorisation is of economic and social importance and allows the maintenance of employment and activity in French Guiana, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The waters of French Guiana have rich fisheries resources. However, the processing industry of this territory depends on landings by Venezuelan ships. This is why a fishing agreement has been in place for several decades between the European Union and Venezuela, allowing Venezuelan fishermen to access the waters of the exclusive economic zone off French Guiana. With this vote, we validated the continuation of such a partnership.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Venezuelan fishing vessels have for several decades been authorised to fish off the coast of Guyana French provided that a certain share of catches are landed in local ports. This practice is of enormous economic and social importance to the region as the landing and processing of fishery products is a source of resources and jobs. Since the European Union has no international fisheries agreement with Venezuela, cooperation with that country has never been in line with the requirements of the EU legal system. That is why I voted in favour of the European Commission's proposal to cede the right to fish to Venezuelan vessels.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Venezuelan-flagged vessels may be allowed to fish off the coast of Guyana, provided they comply with EU regulations on the conservation and management of fisheries resources. Ensuring the continuity of fishing activities is vital to the processing industry of French Guiana, which is dependent on landings by Venezuelan vessels. The economy of Guyana, Europe's outermost region, is poorly diversified and relies largely on the maritime sector. So we have to be particularly vigilant about that.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation to allocate fishing opportunities in European Union waters to fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela, in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of French Guiana. On the one hand, it is a question of taking into account the local realities between French Guiana and Venezuela, which have been cooperating for many years. On the other hand, there is a need to understand the interest of the French in this agreement. If Venezuela has access to European waters, fishermen in French Guiana will be able to exploit certain resources off the coast of Venezuela. These are common-sense measures designed to serve the interests of everyone. Thus, French fishing boats will be able to access species not present in their waters. Finally, this agreement could contribute to the intensification of port activities in French Guiana.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement is unlike typical Fisheries Partnership Agreements and in legal terms is not an International Fisheries Agreement but instead, a Council Declaration allowing the transfer of fishing rights to Venezuelan vessels in the waters of French Guiana – a French overseas department. This agreement has no budgetary or funding implications.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the recommendation, as such involvement is not acceptable.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the report on fishing rights for Venezuelan fishing vessels. It is also clear from this report that, in order to maintain marine fish stocks, the European Union is being forced to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. 30% of the earth's seas are overfished and marine fish stocks are at risk. Justified steps to maintain them will result in a continuous and significant reduction in the amount of marine fish fish fished. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for sea fishing. Efforts should already be made to clearly define the concept and regulation of freshwater aquaculture.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The manufacturing industry of French Guiana depends in part on the exploitation of the natural resources of its EES by the fishing fleet of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela. This is a situation of mutual benefit that has been going on and on for decades, with the landing of part of the catches in local ports, which guarantee an important source of income and job creation in the region. This permission is in practice, despite the absence of an international agreement between the EU and the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela, a situation dragged down by an institutional conflict promoted by the Council on the legal basis for the operation of the Venezuelan fleet in French Guiana waters, which should have long been overcome. It should be noted that the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela has been complying with the counterparts associated with this proposal, in particular with respect to EU regulations, in particular with regard to stocks of target species, types of fishing gear, vessel tracking devices, catch declarations, maximum number of authorised vessels and proportion of catches unloaded in Ports of French Guiana. We regret that the Council's position has determined the excessive postponement of the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Landing and processing of fishery products is an important source of resources and jobs for French Guiana. However, Venezuelan vessels, which have been authorised fishing for several decades, are often used to fulfil this activity, provided that landings take place in local ports. However, there is no international fisheries agreement between the EU and Venezuela. There has been an institutional dispute throughout the process, which consisted solely of disagreement on the legal basis, and I therefore support the procedure for approving this proposal as quickly as possible in order to obtain an appropriate legal framework for fishing activity in the area.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report. This measure aims to limit illegal fishing by Venezuelan vessels in the waters of Guyana (Department French).

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This Recommendation attempts to involve all EU institutions in the process of concluding any trade agreement between a Member State and a third State.  I am voting against the recommendation, as this involvement is not acceptable.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The processing industry based in French Guiana depends in part on the exploitation of living natural resources in its Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) by Venezuelan vessels. Given the economic and social importance of this activity in the region, fishing has been authorised for these vessels for decades, with the proviso that part of the catch is landed in local ports. The landing and processing of fishery products therefore represent an important source of income and jobs for French Guiana. I voted in favour of the Commission proposal for an EU commitment on the transfer of fishing rights to Venezuelan vessels.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text which confirms an ancient practice between Venezuelan fishermen and French canneries in Guyana. The aim is to allow access by Venezuelan fishing vessels to the waters of French Guiana, 12 miles beyond the coast. In return, fish processing is carried out in French Guiana (75% of the fish caught by Venezuelan ships) and French vessels in Martinique have the opportunity to catch snapper or tuna off Venezuela. Guyana has significant fishing potential, with various species of shrimp and 200 species of fish. It is regrettable that this potential is currently under-exploited, but Venezuela's counterparties are sufficient to justify the fisheries agreement with that country, especially since this agreement also limits illegal fishing in our maritime area.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Recommendation which calls for the granting of authorisation to fish venezuelan vessels in the terms in which it has been done so far: complying with countervailing measures and European legislation in this area (species, fishing gear, vessel monitoring devices, notifications, number of vessels, volume of fishing and proportion of catch to be landed in French Guiana). The processing industry based in French Guiana depends in part on the exploitation of the natural resources of the exclusive economic zone (EEZ) by Venezuela's fishing vessels. Given the socio-economic importance of this activity in the region, these vessels have been authorized to work for decades, with the consideration that some of the catches are landed at local ports. The landing and processing of fisheries products therefore represent an important source of resources and employment for French Guiana.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, like my colleagues in the Labour Party, voted in favour of this report. This report grants fishing opportunities for fishing vessels from the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela off the coast of French Guiana, and outlines the conditions of such.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution of fishing opportunities in EU waters for fishing vessels flying the flag of Venezuela off the coast of French Guiana. In my opinion, the Council continues to act reluctantly to accept the European Parliament’s competences in the field of fisheries under the Lisbon Treaty. Nevertheless, the European Court of Justice supported the European Commission and the Parliament’s claims. The report is to be considered as a crucial step to end the long-standing competence conflict existing between the two co-legislators and to unblock the ‘frozen’ negotiation process where no fisheries management plan has been able to be adopted during the last 5 years.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is a reminder that the EU’s interests in fisheries extend well beyond the waters of the European continent. It is essential that fishing in all waters belonging to EU Member States is conducted with legal certainty and I therefore voted in favour of Mr Ferreira’s report.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Recommendation which calls for the granting of authorisation to fish venezuelan vessels in the terms in which it has been done so far: complying with countervailing measures and European legislation in this area (species, fishing gear, vessel monitoring devices, notifications, number of vessels, volume of fishing and proportion of catch to be landed in French Guiana). The processing industry based in French Guiana depends in part on the exploitation of the natural resources of the exclusive economic zone (EEZ) by Venezuela's fishing vessels. Given the socio-economic importance of this activity in the region, these vessels have been authorized to work for decades, with the consideration that some of the catches are landed at local ports. The landing and processing of fisheries products therefore represent an important source of resources and employment for French Guiana.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this document aimed at protecting the socio-economic activity of French Guiana, in relation to the granting of the exploitation of natural resources by Venezuelan fishing vessels.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Recommendation on the Council's draft decision on authorisation, on behalf of the European Union, the Declaration on the Authorisation of Fishing Opportunities in EU waters to fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivar Republic of Venezuela in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of French Guiana, as a long-standing agreement regarding fish catching in this area already existed and only needed to be legally adapted from the point of view of community law.   Given that the European Court of Justice, in agreement with the European Commission and Parliament, has adopted a new opinion and resolved existing legal issues in which vessels under the flag of the Bolivar Republic of Venezuela are to comply with certain rules of harvesting, activities in the economic zone off the coast of French Guiana should start as soon as possible so as not to adversely affect fishing activities contributing to income and working conditions in this area by repaying this decision.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote for the report on fishing opportunities in European Union waters for Venezuelan-flagged fishing vessels off the coast of French Guiana. The links between Venezuelan fishermen and french canneries in Guyana are very close. The aim is, as it stands, to authorise fishing, in return for which the product of the fishery will be largely, to the tune of 75%, processed on French territory. The fishing potential off Guyana is indeed particularly important, but remains underexploited for the time being. Finally, the agreement also aims to reduce illegal fishing by Venezuelans.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This will create a precedent for EU boats to fish in non-EU waters, and therefore I must abstain, given our campaign to leave the European Union.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Joo Ferreira's report on fishing opportunities in European Union waters for Venezuelan vessels off the coast of French Guiana. This report authorizes Venezuelan-flagged vessels to fish off the coast of French Guiana. This agreement is already in force in France and allows a win-win situation between Venezuelan fishermen and Guyanese ports by validating a legal format that will allow better coverage of the situation by international law. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the approval, on behalf of the European Union, of the declaration on the allocation of fishing opportunities in European Union waters to fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela, in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of French Guiana. Indeed, this allocation benefits both parties, especially for the maintenance of employment and activity in Guyana.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This is a formal decision to legally allow Venezuelan fishermen to fish off the coast of French Guiana. Given the importance of fishing for these fishermen and the lack of negative aspects of codifying this status quo, I am voting in favour of this motion.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr João Ferreira's report on the fishing opportunities in EU waters for vessels flying the flag of Venezuela off the coast of Eastern French. With this draft report, the European Union has undertaken to cede the right to fish to Venezuelan vessels, given that in practice the activity of Venezuelan fishing vessels has been authorised for several decades and given the economic importance of fishing in this region.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. Background: ancient links exist between Venezuelan fishermen and French canneries in French Guiana. It should be noted that an institutional conflict between the Council and Parliament slowed down the adoption of this report: the Council had initially adopted this agreement without consulting Parliament, contrary to the principle of co-decision on fisheries agreements. Purpose: to allow access of Venezuelan fishing vessels in the waters of French Guiana (41 in 2013), 12 miles beyond the coast, the processing of fish being done in French Guiana. Counterparts: the possibility for Martinique vessels to catch snapper or tuna off the coast of Venezuela. 75% of the fish caught by Venezuelan ships are landed in Guyana for processing. Problem: Guyana has significant fishing potential, with various species of shrimp and 200 species of fish, which is currently underexploited. Recommendation: for. Explanation of vote: Guyana, The French department, should be able to develop its own fishing. Nevertheless, the counterparties do exist and limit illegal fishing by Venezuelans.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for it. The purpose of the project is to allow Venezuelan ships to fish in the waters of French Guiana within a well-defined radius. A large part of the fish caught (75%) will be transformed into French Guiana. In return, Martinique fishing boats will in turn be able to fish certain species off the coast of Venezuela. There have long been economic relations between The Venezuelan fishery and the processing industries of French Guiana. The negative side of the project is that Guyana has significant fisheries resources that it does not exploit as it could because of a lack of material resources. We regret its inability to develop its own fishery and thus access important resources on its own. But the agreement provided for by this text regulates and frames a practice already under way and therefore limits illegal fishing. In addition, the counterparties are real and correct.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting approval to the Council Decision granting fishing opportunities in EU waters to fishing vessels flying Venezuela's flag off the coast of French Guiana because it establishes a legislative framework suitable for de facto fishing in that area. Venezuelan vessels have been allowed to fish off French Guiana for decades on the condition that some of the catch be landed at local ports. However, there is no international fisheries agreement between the EU and Venezuela. That is why this new framework is necessary which obliges Venezuela to respect the compensation associated with this proposal and to respect European legislation in relation, for example, to fish stocks that may be fish, type of fishing gear, vessel tracking devices, catch reporting, maximum number of authorised fishing vessels and proportion of catches landed in the ports of French Guiana.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained because I believe that this is a Matter for France and therefore Parliament should not take a position on it.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported The Ferriere Report approving the Declaration on the Authorisation of Fishing Opportunities in EU waters to fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivar Republic of Venezuela in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of French Guiana.  The 2008 Regulation on the authorisation of fishing for vessels from third countries presupposes the existence of an international fisheries agreement, but the EU has not concluded such a contract with Venezuela due to institutional conflicts. Now that conflicts have been resolved and bearing in mind that fishing is the main activity in these areas, it is important to allow the signing of the Statement as soon as possible, as Venezuela is ready to comply with all European Union fishing regulations such as reporting on catches and types of fishing gear.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. This is another case of eu territories' collaboration with third countries. Historically a part of Europe is located in South America (French Guiana) The report will open up new possibilities for the international fishing industry. I voted for it.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, by resolution, approves the declaration concerning fishing in French Guiana's waters by vessels of the Republic of Venezuela, which represents an important source of resources and jobs. This procedure and declaration is in line with the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union and replaces an international agreement which does not exist between the EU and Venezuela or is otherwise dealt with in the Community legal order.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision approving, by the European Union, the declaration granting fishing opportunities in Union waters to fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivian Republic of Venezuela, in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of French Guiana, because this recommendation welcomes the right to fish on Venezuelan register vessels in Union waters.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this balanced text that allows Venezuelan fishing boats to come and fish in French territorial waters. 75% of these fish are landed in Guyana for processing. In exchange, Martinique ships will have the opportunity to fish off the coast of Venezuela. France wins on both fronts of the transformation of Venezuelan fishing and fishing off Venezuela.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The fish processing industry based in French Guiana depends in part on the exploitation of living natural resources in its Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) by Venezuelan vessels. Given the economic and social importance of this activity in the region, fishing has been authorised for these vessels for decades, with the proviso that part of the catch is landed in local ports. The landing and processing of fishery products therefore represent an important source of income and jobs for French Guiana. However, as there is no international agreement between the EU and Venezuela on fisheries this has been happening outside EU law. This welcome proposal regularises the situation.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision approving, on behalf of the European Union, the declaration on the granting of fishing opportunities in EU waters to vessels flying the flag of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela, in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of Guyana French. In this respect, account is taken of the fact that fishing and processing of fish products in this region play an important economic and social role.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Guyana's processing industry sector French benefits greatly from the exploitation by Venezuelan vessels of the biological natural resources present in its exclusive economic zone (EEZ). In view of the economic and social importance of activity within the region, these vessels have been allowed to fish for several decades. This situation, however, is not adequately standard. In fact, at least for the time being, the European Union has not concluded any international fisheries agreement with Venezuela. To remedy this, the European Commission has presented a proposal through which the European Union undertakes to cede the right to fish to Venezuelan vessels. I have chosen to vote in favour of the text of the recommendation because I believe that it is desirable to establish an appropriate legal framework to be the background to this specific context.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I am in favour of the Declaration on the granting of fishing opportunities in EU waters to fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of French Guiana, as I think it is a good way to successfully resolve an activity that has been taking place until now , but thus acquires a sound legal basis.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This proposal has received my support, as it is a formal decision allowing Venezuelan fishermen to fish off the coast of French Guiana.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report as fishing vessels flying the flag of Venezuela have been authorised to operate in the exclusive economic zone (EEZ) of the French overseas department of Guiana for several decades. In light of this fact, the EU has decided to grant fishing authorisations to a limited number of fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela. These vessels will be entitled to fish in that part of the exclusive economic zone off the coast of French Guiana that lies more than 12 nautical miles from the base lines.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The processing industry in French Guiana depends in part on the exploitation by Venezuelan fishing vessels of the living natural resources of the exclusive economic zone off the coast. Given the economic and social importance of this activity in the region, Venezuelan fishing vessels have been allowed to fish for several decades provided that some of the fishing is landed in Guyanese ports. However, in the absence of an international agreement between the European Union and Venezuela in the area of fisheries, this practice conflicts with the legal order of the European Union. To remedy this, the Council submits for approval to the European Parliament a declaration in which the European Union commits to ceding fishing rights to Venezuelan vessels. The text aims to approve this agreement as soon as possible in order to comply with European Union law. In favour of wider cooperation between France and Venezuela, I can only welcome this agreement, I vote for it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The links between Venezuelan fishermen and french canneries in Guyana are very close. The aim is, as it stands, to authorise fishing, in return for which the fishing product will be largely processed on French territory, to the tune of 75%. The fishing potential off Guyana is indeed particularly important, but remains underexploited for the time being. Finally, the agreement also aims to reduce illegal fishing by Venezuelans. I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the economic and social importance of the activity in the region, fishing has been allowed to Venezuelan vessels for several decades, with the counterpart that part of the catches are landed in local ports.  The landing and processing of fishery products thus represents an important source of resources and jobs for French Guiana. Hence my assent.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the Fishing opportunities in EU waters for fishing vessels flying the flag of Venezuela off the coast of French Guiana, which authorises fishing vessels flying the flag of Venezuela to operate in the exclusive economic zone (EEZ) of the French overseas department of Guiana for several decades. I believe that this opportunity will help people and the processing industry in French Guiana that are heavily dependent on fishing activities from that region.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Venezuelan fishing vessels have been fishing in EU waters off the coast of French Guiana for decades, in exchange for uneating part of the catch at local ports. The unloading and processing of fishery products is a major source of income and jobs in French Guiana. However, since there is no international fisheries agreement between the EU and Venezuela, this situation contradicts the requirements of the Community legal order. The proposal put forward aims at a legal settlement of this situation.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Ideally, Guyana should be able to make full use of the available fisheries resources in these waters through the development of its fishing activity. However, and to the extent that the vast majority of fish caught are landed and processed in Guyana, thus supporting national industrial activity, we agree with this proposal to allow Venezuelan vessels to fish off the French coast. In addition, this proposal may limit illegal fishing already practiced in these waters.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The report on fishing opportunities in European Union waters for Venezuelan-flagged fishing vessels off the coast of French Guiana by Joel Ferreira aims to allow Venezuelan vessels to fish in the territorial waters of French Guiana 12 miles beyond the coast while leaving the processing of the fishing product in French Guiana. The counterpart to this access to Guyanese exclusive areas is the permission left to Martinique vessels to fish off the Venezuelan coast. A number of safeguards are proposed to limit illegal fishing. However, Guyana has untapped fisheries resources and deserves to develop its close fishing. This report was marked by the conflict between the Council and Parliament, since parliament had forgotten to be consulted. As a result, the process was slowed down. I voted for this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which supports the request to approve the Declaration addressed to the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela on the granting of fishing opportunities in EU waters to fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of the French Guiana on behalf of the European Union.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text regarding the fishing possibilities of Venezuelan vessels off the coast of French Guiana. The processing of fish products is of great economic and social importance in French Guiana. This is why Venezuelan fishermen are allowed to fish in this maritime zone provided that part of the fishing is landed in Guyanese ports. These fishing opportunities allow employment and activity to continue in Guyana.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this draft resolution, which has become necessary since the processing industry established in Guyana French depends in part on the exploitation by Venezuelan vessels of the natural biological resources of its exclusive economic zone.  Given the economic and social importance of activity in the region, Venezuelan fishing vessels had been authorized to fish for several decades, provided that a certain share of catches were landed in the ports of Eastern French. In view of the absence of international fisheries agreements between the European Union and Venezuela, we whole much support this measure, which aims intelligently to create a framework for regulating this practice.  We in the European Union are therefore committed to surrendering the right to fish to Venezuelan vessels, provided that venezuelan vessels comply with Community legislation on the conservation and management of fish stocks, with particular reference to the common fisheries policy (CFP) regulatory framework. It was also important, in giving our assent to the measure, that the resolution will have no financial implications for the Community budget.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Guyana's processing industry French depends in part on venezuelan vessels exploiting the natural biological resources of its exclusive economic zone (EEZ). In view of the economic and social importance of activity in the region, these vessels have been authorized to fish for several decades, provided that a certain proportion of catches are landed in local ports. The landing and processing of fishery products is therefore an important source of resources and jobs for Guyana French. However, as the EU has no international fisheries agreement with Venezuela, cooperation with that country is not in line with the requirements of the EU legal order. In this context, the Commission has presented a proposal in which the European Union undertakes to cede the right to fish to Venezuelan vessels. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: n/a
text: in writing. – I have voted for this declaration granting fishing opportunities in EU waters to fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of French Guiana according to the evaluation made in the report.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report by vote because it concerns a fisheries agreement between the EU and Venezuela, entering the register of new types of international agreements based on the common fisheries policy. Unfortunately, this agreement was blocked for a period of three years due to institutional disagreements between the European Parliament and the Council on the legislation applicable to these agreements. However, once the procedures have been clarified by the Court of Justice of the European Union, I do not believe that this agreement is affecting the interests of European citizens in French Guiana, but it helps the local economy while respecting EU law and its objectives.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report as it ensures the survival and livelihood of Venezuelan fishermen, while not endangering the small-scale fishing off the coast of French Guiana.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on fishing opportunities for fishing vessels flying the flag of the Republic of Venezuela in the EEZ off French Guiana. This agreement endorses and regulates a practice that has existed for many years, in perfect collaboration and complementarity of Guyana's fisheries. In addition, the agreement provides for the obligation to disembark in Guyana, which is a very important contribution for Guyana's processing industries and therefore contributes to economic activity and employment in Guyana.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported.  The french guiana processing industry depends in part on the fishing for living resources by Venezuelan fishing vessels in the coastal exclusive economic zone. Given the economic and social importance of such fishing in the region, Venezuelan fishing vessels have been allowed to fish for decades, provided that part of the catches are landed in the ports of Guyana. Landing and processing of fish is therefore an important source of income and employment for French Guiana. However, in the event of no international fisheries agreement between the European Union and Venezuela, bilateral cooperation is not in the framework of the Union legal order. In practice, however, venezuelan fishing vessels are allowed to take action. The EU statement therefore provides a legal basis for Venezuela's actions. Venezuela has complied with relevant EU rules, such as fish stocks, gear types, vessel localisation equipment, catch declaration, maximum number of authorised fishing vessels and percentage of catches landed in French Guiana ports.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking into account the economic and social importance of activity in the region, these vessels have been authorised to fish for several decades, provided that a certain share of catches is landed in local ports. I am in favour of this.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This act authorizes the European Union to fish in EU waters for fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivar Republic of Venezuela along the economic zone of the Coast of French Guiana.  As the EU does not have an international fisheries treaty with Venezuela concluded, access to Venezuelan vessels sailing in EU waters off the shores of French Guiana was ensured by a Council declaration annulled by the European Court of Justice on 26 November 2014 due to disagreements on the legal basis of the act. As the legal basis for this authorisation has since been addressed, this act gives the authorisation of fishing opportunities for a number of Venezuelan fishing vessels. Fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivar Republic of Venezuela have limited activities exclusively in the economic zone off the coast of French Guiana with the obligation to comply with the rules of the Common Fisheries Policy of the European Union, i.e. conservation and control of measurements and other provisions relating to fishing in the area, including limits on the maximum number and proportion of catches.  I supported this proposal because of the economic importance of fishing and reciprocity for the people of Venezuela and French Guiana, but also for the mutual trade relations between the EU and Venezuela.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The report on fishing opportunities in European Union waters for Venezuelan-flagged fishing vessels off the coast of French Guiana aims to allow Venezuelan vessels to fish in the territorial waters of French Guiana, 12 miles beyond the coast, while leaving the processing of the fishing product in French Guiana. The counterpart to this access to the exclusive French areas of Guyana is the permission given to French vessels in Martinique to fish off the Venezuelan coast. A number of safeguards are proposed to try to limit illegal fishing. However, Guyana has untapped fisheries resources and deserves to develop its close fishing. This report was marked by a conflict between the Council and Parliament, since it had been forgotten to consult the latter (i.e. its importance in the minds of some). I voted for this report, which will benefit my compatriots in Guyana, although I think it is up to France alone to negotiate and sign this type of agreement itself.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support the proposal for a draft Council decision on authorisation, on behalf of the European Union, of the Declaration on the Authorisation of Fishing Opportunities in EU waters to fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivar Republic of Venezuela in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of French Guiana. Given that fisheries and the processing industry of fish products are an important source of income for the populations of French Guiana, and this issue has not been adequately regulated by international legislation until now, although in practice access to ships was allowed, I agree with the rapporteur's proposal to adopt this statement.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The french Guiana-based manufacturing industry depends in part on the exploitation of living natural resources in its exclusive economic zone (EEC) by Venezuelan vessels. Given the economic and social importance of this activity in the region, fishing has been allowed for their vessels for decades, with some catches remaining in local ports. Accordingly, a large part of the local population is employed precisely in this activity. As there is no international treaty between the EU and Venezuela on fisheries, such cooperation is not in line with Union law, although in practice fishing is allowed there.  Acting towards resolving this situation, the Commission has made a proposal on the transfer of fishing rights to Venezuelan vessels with a specific adaptation corresponding to smaller-scale fishing. I believe that the approval process for this draft should be completed in as short a time as possible. It should also be noted that Venezuela respects all concessions related to this proposal, in particular the part of its activities in accordance with European regulations. I support this blueprint.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the conflict between the European Union and Venezuela over the exploitation of fisheries off the coast of French Guiana, the European Commission has proposed a commitment to cede the right to fishing to Venezuelan vessels. I voted in favour of this report which endorses the Commission's proposal authorising the activity of Venezuelan fishing vessels in the EU's territorial waters. This decision is all the more important because the processing industry in French Guiana depends heavily on the activity of Venezuelan ships.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft resolution of the European Parliament (EP) agrees on the adoption of the Declaration on the granting of fishing opportunities in European Union (EU) waters to vessels from Venezuela in the Exclusive Economic Zone off French Guiana. This declaration took shape in Decision No 2012/19/EU, whereby the Council took Parliament as an advisory body, rather than a body to which it needed to seek approval. In order to resolve this institutional conflict, the Commission and the European Parliament have taken action before the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU), which, assessing the cases, gave a favourable ruling to Parliament's position, confirming that decisions on the conclusion of fisheries agreements are fully covered by the EU Functioning Treaty. As a result of the CJEU's interpretation, the EP's decision is not only consultative but binding, and the EP's approval is therefore indispensable. In this regard, the Commission resubmits the declaration to Parliament, and once in line with the requirements of the Community legal system and also taking into account that Venezuela has been respecting the considerations associated with the proposal, I voted in favour of the above-mentioned legislative proposal.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted positively on the european Union's allocation of fishing opportunities to vessels flying the flag of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela in the Exclusive Economic Zone off the coast of French Guiana on the grounds that Venezuela has been respecting all the numerous counterparts associated with this proposal. With no international EU agreement with Venezuela on fisheries, I support the idea that this activity needs to be given a stable framework to regulate this cooperation, which is an essential aspect for job creation and the growth of economic activity in French Guiana.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Venezuelan fishing vessels have been fishing in Community waters off the coast of French Guiana for decades. In practice, fishing was authorised but without an international fisheries agreement within the meaning of Council Regulation (EC) No 1006/2008.  In this case, the Council opted for a unilateral Declaration, with binding legal effects under international law, which it adopted in Council Decision 2012/19/EU of 16 December 2011 approving, on behalf of the European Union, the Declaration on the granting of fishing opportunities in EU waters to fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of French Guiana.  However, in the absence of codecision, the Commission and Parliament denounced this Declaration before the COURT of Justice of the EU, which would annul it, although maintaining it with effect until the entry into force of a new Decision, which is what is now being raised and which has received my vote in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Venezuelan-flagged fishing vessels have been allowed to operate in the exclusive economic zone of Guyana, the French overseas department, for several decades. However, given the economic and social importance of these fishing activities, and given that the Council and the Commission found it inappropriate to put an end to them, a different practice was followed: access by Venezuelan fishing vessels operating in EU waters off the coast of Guyana was thus granted in the form of a Council statement , in accordance with the jurisprudence of the International Court of Justice, produces legal effects in international law. The European Parliament yesterday issued a favourable opinion for this proposal to be approved as soon as possible, which is now possible by the resolution of the institutional conflict, which found its only source in disagreement on the exact legal basis. This will allow fishing activity in the area concerned, whose regularity has not been questioned by this delay, to fall within the appropriate legal framework.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. Venezuelan-flaunder fishing vessels have been allowed to operate in guyana's EEF for several decades, with the counterpart of part of the catches being landed at local ports. However, there is no international EU agreement with Venezuela on fisheries, and a legal solution must be adopted that meets the requirements of the Community legal order, in particular the Common Fisheries Policy, with regard to the conservation and management of fisheries resources. The solution found in the meantime was the adoption of an EU compromise proposal on the handing over of fishing rights to Venezuelan vessels, by means of a statement made by the Council, which did not have the approval of the European Parliament as required and was subsequently confirmed by decision of the CJEU. Given that decisions on the conclusion of external fisheries agreements need the approval of the European Parliament, it is urgent to resolve this legal institutional conflict through this legislative resolution, given the economic and social importance of these fishing activities and what they represent as a source of resources and jobs for French Guiana.  That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal on 'fishing opportunities in EU waters for vessels flying the flag of Venezuela off the coast of Guyana French', in which the European Union undertakes to cede the right to fish to Venezuelan vessels. It is precisely the exploitation by these vessels of the natural biological resources of guyana's exclusive economic zone (EEZ) French that feeds the processing industry established in this area.  Since the EU has no international fisheries agreement with Venezuela, cooperation with that country is not in line with the EU legal order, so the aim of the proposal before us is precisely to regulate this situation, even if in practice the activity of fishing vessels is still authorised.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Recommendation which calls for the granting of authorisation to fish venezuelan vessels in the terms in which it has been done so far: complying with countervailing measures and European legislation in this area (species, fishing gear, vessel monitoring devices, notifications, number of vessels, volume of fishing and proportion of catch to be landed in French Guiana). The processing industry based in French Guiana depends in part on the exploitation of the natural resources of the exclusive economic zone (EEZ) by Venezuela's fishing vessels. Given the socio-economic importance of this activity in the region, these vessels have been authorized to work for decades, with the consideration that some of the catches are landed at local ports. The landing and processing of fisheries products therefore represent an important source of resources and employment for French Guiana.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting approval to the Council Decision granting fishing opportunities in EU waters to fishing vessels flying Venezuela's flag off the coast of French Guiana because it establishes a legislative framework suitable for de facto fishing in that area. Venezuelan vessels have been allowed to fish off French Guiana for decades on the condition that some of the catch be landed at local ports. However, there is no international fisheries agreement between the EU and Venezuela. That is why this new framework is necessary which obliges Venezuela to respect the compensation associated with this proposal and to respect European legislation in relation, for example, to fish stocks that may be fish, type of fishing gear, vessel tracking devices, catch reporting, maximum number of authorised fishing vessels and proportion of catches landed in the ports of French Guiana.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 For several decades, vessels flying the flag of Venezuela have been allowed to operate in the exclusive economic zone of the French overseas department of Guyana. The European Union, however, has never concluded an international fisheries agreement with Venezuela. The Council statement, on which Parliament gave its approval, is not limited to granting fishing opportunities to Venezuelan vessels, but provides an international basis for making access to resources conditional on financial compensation and for requiring the vessels concerned to comply with a series of measures for the conservation and management of fish stocks. , as well as other European regulations such as the one on the obligation to land.  Given that the processing industry for fishery products established in Guyana French is currently heavily dependent on the catches of Venezuelan vessels and is an important source of resources and jobs, I have chosen to vote in favour of this recommendation.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In general terms, I support fisheries agreements between the European Union and third countries. In this agreement, in particular, I voted positively on the european Union's allocation of fishing opportunities to the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of French Guiana.  The European Union's understandings of third countries in fisheries are important for three types of reasons: they allow them to explore springs, thus contributing to food security; provide financial compensation for countries that have sovereignty over resources; and, finally, because they help structure the sustainable and responsible use of fisheries in general. Thanks to the strategy implemented by the European Union we are contributing to the fight against illegal, unregulated and unregulated fisheries, we are increasing monitoring efficiency and we are contributing to better understand the functioning of the oceans. Following the procedure for the adoption of this Fisheries Agreement, the Court of Justice of the European Union confirmed that decisions on the conclusion of external fisheries agreements need binding approval by the European Parliament. This was an important step towards clarifying and dignifying the role of the European institutions.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the request to approve the Declaration addressed to the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela on the granting of fishing opportunities in EU waters to fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of the French Guiana on behalf of the European Union.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. The processing industry located in French Guiana depends partly on the use of living natural resources from its exclusive economic zone by Venezuelan vessels. This should also provide an appropriate framework for fishing activities carried out in the economic zone of French Guiana by Venezuelan vessels. The creation of such a framework would translate the right of fishing to Venezuelan vessels.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The manufacturing industry in French Guya is partly dependent on the exploitation of living natural resources by Venezuelan fishing vessels. This activity is of exceptional economic and social importance to the region and venezuelan fishing vessels have been authorised to fish for decades, provided that part of the catch is landing in Guyanic ports. The landing and processing of fishery products is therefore an important source of revenue and jobs in French Guya. An appropriate international fisheries agreement has not been concluded between the European Union and Venezuela, but fishing by Venezuelan vessels has been allowed in practice. The Commission has submitted a proposal for an EU commitment to recognise the right to fish for Venezuelan vessels. The authorisation procedure for fishing should be completed as soon as possible in order to ensure that fisheries in the area have an appropriate legal framework. In this context, it should be noted that Venezuela respects its agreements resulting from the proposal, in particular with regard to compliance with European legislation, for example with regard to target fish stocks, type of fishing gear, vessel tracking devices, fishing reporting, maximum allowable number of vessels and share of catches to be landed in ports of French Guya. As I consider it important to level the legal framework of hunting by Venezuela alongside French Guya, I supported the recommendation and voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the recommendation on the Council's draft decision to grant fishing opportunities in EU waters to fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivar Republic of Venezuela in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of French Guiana, as this is solely a matter of legalising legal agreement between the Bolivar Republic of Venezuela and the European Union. Fisheries in this zone is the main source of employment and income and contributes the most to the development of the economy. For these reasons, I believe that this proposal should be adopted, as it is at issue to formally confirm an agreement between the European Union and Venezuela that has existed for decades in the form of mutual understanding of what is important for economic development in the economic zone off the coast of French Guiana.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this declaration as it grants the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela fishing opportunities in EU waters to fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of the French Guiana on behalf of the European Union.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the Council's draft decision on authorisation, on behalf of the European Union, of the Declaration on the Authorisation of Fishing Opportunities to fishing vessels in EU waters flying the flag of the Bolivar Republic of Venezuela in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of French Guiana. This agreement would allow vessels flying the flag of the Bolivar Republic of Venezuela fishing opportunities in EU waters in a 12-nautical-mile strip off the coast of French Guiana. Also, the agreement has a positive impact on the economy and social activities of French Guiana, as significant catches from Venezuelan-flagged vessels end up in French Guiana's fish markets and give the possibility of employment to fishermen from French Guiana.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as I welcome the efforts to correct the current lack of regulation in fishing for Venezuela's vessels off the coast of French Guiana.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Agreements should be sought which promote the development of the Member States of the European Union, without prejudice to their national and economic interests.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Economic activities within the European Union are intended to generate the prosperity of European citizens. Within the EU territories, the maritime space bounded by the Exclusive Economic Zone plays a special role. Through fishing activity in the area, the development of sea areas is much needed.  French Guiana is an integral part of the EU as the overseas department of the French Republic. The fact that this region does not have the capacity to exploit the fisheries resources at its disposal on its own makes the activity of Venezuelan fishing boats decisive in generating economic profit in the area. Following the decision of the European Court of Justice of 26 November 2014, the access of Venezuelan fishing boats to the French Guiana's Exclusive Economic Zone and fishing quotas were regulated in accordance with the provisions of international law. However, this decision also strengthened the European Parliament's decision-making power in fisheries, representing an obvious progress and success of Parliament in institutional terms.  For these reasons, I support the adoption of this recommendation, which is intended to bring economic profit and generate jobs in a region that is an integral part of the European Union.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text.
