Specifically, to be quite honest, that Venezuela has complied with the counterparties arising from the proposal, namely that it has complied with European regulations with regard to, for example, target fish stocks, types of fishing gear, vessel tracking devices, fishing declarations, the maximum number of fishing vessels allowed and the percentage of catches to be landed in Guyanese ports.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which brings a legal solution to cooperation on fisheries between French Guiana and Venezuela that has been going on for decades, however without any international agreement between the EU and Venezuela. The processing of fishery products represents an important source of income and jobs for French Guiana. To some extent, its processing industry depends on fishing by Venezuelan vessels on condition that part of the catch is landed in local ports. This resolution aligns the agreement with the EU legislation and delivers an appropriate framework for fishing in this area.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒I supported this Council Declaration because I consider it to be in line with the needs of French Guiana, as the processing industry of that department depends in part on the exploitation of the resources of vessels from Venezuela in this economic zone. As this is an atypical fishing contract, the European Court of Justice ruled in 2014 that Venezuelan vessels must fish in accordance with the Common Fisheries Policy and respecting the sustainable exploitation of fishing resources, and an additional condition is that they have to leave part of the catches at the ports of French Guiana, which I consider to be an important source of income for that department.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. Fishing vessels flying the Venezuelan flag have been authorised for decades to operate in the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) of the French Overseas Operations Department. To this end, the EU has issued a limited number of fishing licences to fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela. These vessels will be able to carry out fishing activities in the EEZ off the coast of French Guya. Given the economic and social importance of the activities, access will be made available in the form of a Council declaration which, in accordance with the case-law of the International Criminal Court, is legally valid in accordance with international law. The declaration will therefore regulate the current situation and offer fishing activities in the area the possibility of carrying out activities, which is why I supported this report.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Recommendation which calls for the granting of authorisation to fish venezuelan vessels in the terms in which it has been done so far: complying with countervailing measures and European legislation in this area (species, fishing gear, vessel monitoring devices, notifications, number of vessels, volume of fishing and proportion of catch to be landed in French Guiana). The processing industry based in French Guiana depends in part on the exploitation of the natural resources of the exclusive economic zone (EEZ) by Venezuela's fishing vessels. Given the socio-economic importance of this activity in the region, these vessels have been authorized to work for decades, with the consideration that some of the catches are landed at local ports. The landing and processing of fisheries products therefore represent an important source of resources and employment for French Guiana.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Ancient links exist between Venezuelan fishermen and French canneries in French Guiana. It should be noted that an institutional conflict between the Council and Parliament slowed down the adoption of this report: the Council had initially adopted this agreement without consulting Parliament, contrary to the principle of co-decision on fisheries agreements. The purpose of this text is to allow access by Venezuelan fishing vessels into the waters of French Guiana, 12 miles beyond the coast; processing of fish in French Guiana. In return, there would be the possibility for Martinique vessels to fish for snapper or tuna off the coast of Venezuela. 75% of the fish caught by Venezuelan ships are landed in Guyana for processing. Guyana has significant fishing potential, with various species of shrimp and 200 species of fish, which is currently underexploited. Guyana, the French department, should be able to develop its own fishing. Nevertheless, the counterparties do exist and limit illegal fishing by Venezuelans. I am voting in favour of this text.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Recommendation which calls for the granting of authorisation to fish venezuelan vessels in the terms in which it has been done so far: complying with countervailing measures and European legislation in this area (species, fishing gear, vessel monitoring devices, notifications, number of vessels, volume of fishing and proportion of catch to be landed in French Guiana). The processing industry based in French Guiana depends in part on the exploitation of the natural resources of the exclusive economic zone (EEZ) by Venezuela's fishing vessels. Given the socio-economic importance of this activity in the region, these vessels have been authorized to work for decades, with the consideration that some of the catches are landed at local ports. The landing and processing of fisheries products therefore represent an important source of resources and employment for French Guiana.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this fisheries agreement which can be beneficial for both Venezuela and the EU.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the Council decision to grant fishing opportunities in EU waters to Venezuelan fishing vessels in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of French Guiana. Fishing activities in this region play a very important economic and social role: the processing industry in French Guiana is largely based on the fishing done by Venezuelan vessels in its waters. Although there is no international agreement between the EU and Venezuela on fisheries, in practice Venezuelan vessels have been allowed to fish in EU waters for decades. This is why it was important to give such activities a legal basis (to transfer the fishing rights to Venezuelan vessels) through a declaration to be made by the Council, with the approval of the European Parliament, which aligned the agreement with Union legislation.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The judgment of the Court of Justice of the EU of 26 November set out Council Decision 2012/19/EU, 16 December 2011 approving, on behalf of the EU, the Declaration on the Granting of Fishing Opportunities in EU Waters to fishing vessels flying the flag of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of French Guiana. The judgment states that in order to prevent the Venezuelan fleet from severing in the waters of the French Guiana Union, a new decision must be adopted, which is carried out by voting in favour of that act.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting approval to the Council Decision granting fishing opportunities in EU waters to fishing vessels flying Venezuela's flag off the coast of French Guiana because it establishes a legislative framework suitable for de facto fishing in that area. Venezuelan vessels have been allowed to fish off French Guiana for decades on the condition that some of the catch be landed at local ports. However, there is no international fisheries agreement between the EU and Venezuela. That is why this new framework is necessary which obliges Venezuela to respect the compensation associated with this proposal and to respect European legislation in relation, for example, to fish stocks that may be fish, type of fishing gear, vessel tracking devices, catch reporting, maximum number of authorised fishing vessels and proportion of catches landed in the ports of French Guiana.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement brings mutual benefits, as the landing and processing of fishery products is an important source of resources and jobs for French Guiana. It should be noted that the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela has been complying with all the considerations associated with this proposal and acting in accordance with European regulations, with regard to the target stocks of catch, the type of gear, the vessel tracking devices, the reporting of catches, the maximum number of authorised fishing vessels and the percentage of catches to be landed in the ports of French Guiana. What this activity is about is to give this activity a stable framework, since there has so far been no international agreement regulating this cooperation. It was not an unnecessary and inconsequential institutional conflict triggered by the Council and this issue could have been resolved for a long time.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This motion for a resolution is a mere codification of the existing legal texts on the protection against harmful pricing in shipbuilding, without any substantive changes. I would therefore have abstained.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the authorisation – on behalf of the European Union – of the declaration on the granting of fishing opportunities in EU waters to vessels flying the flag of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela, together with my group, in the exclusive economic zone off the coast of French Guiana. Venezuelan vessels and fishermen will now have to comply with the common fisheries policy for the conservation and management of fish stocks and other legislation. This agreement has no budgetary or financial implications and is therefore sustainable for the ECR Group.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Venezuelan fleet has been developing fishing activities in French Guiana waters for several decades. This results in mutual benefits, as the landing and processing of fishery products is an important source of resources and jobs for French Guiana. What this activity is about is to give this activity a stable framework, since there has so far been no international agreement regulating this cooperation. We voted in favour without further ado of this recommendation. It should be noted that the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela has been complying with all the considerations associated with this proposal and acting in accordance with European regulations, with regard to the target stocks of catch, the type of gear, the vessel tracking devices, the reporting of catches, the maximum number of authorised fishing vessels and the percentage of catches to be landed in the ports of French Guiana.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it entails the approval of the budget allocation of the surplus of the European budget during the 2014 financial year in the amount of EUR 1.4 billion. The interinstitutional agreement on the Budget of the European Union included the flexibility to allocate these unsosed margins in the financing of other items, which appears to be reflected in this amending budget. The report also reflects criticism of the Council for its lack of flexibility with countries in the worst economic situation in order to benefit from the European Union Solidarity Fund. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The EU budget for 2014 had a surplus of €1.435 billion. This amount is transferred to the 2015 budget by amending budget No 3, which has the advantage of requiring Member States to make a smaller contribution to the 2015 budget. I therefore welcome this correction.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The 2015 financial year is to record a surplus of EUR 1.435 billion carried over from the previous year. This postponement could reduce the contribution of Member States to the EU budget for the 2015 financial year. I abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ A budget surplus should be returned to the Member States rather than be spent by the European Union.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of ATM 3/2015, regretting that the budget surplus could not be reallocated to the payment of European unpaid debts.

name: Richard Ashworth (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ British Conservatives voted against Draft Amending Budget No.3/2015 (DAB3) relating to surplus for budgetary year 2014. While we fully support and welcome the return of surpluses to Member States through reduced contributions, we cannot support efforts by this house to undermine the financial regulation and create political links between this annual accounting exercise and the Commission’s demand for additional funding from Member States in order to finance DAB4/2015 (mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund). The Conservatives have always been clear that we want to see real budget discipline. Therefore we believe that the Commission should always try to finance the mobilisation of the solidarity fund by re-deployment. Instead we see here no effort by the Commission to find savings elsewhere in the EU Budget. The Rapporteur in today’s report establishes a link with DAB4/2015, pointing out that DAB3/2015 will reduce the share of GNI contributions from Member States and will therefore more than compensate their contribution to the financing of DAB4/2015. While Conservatives are in favour of adopting DAB3/2015, we will not support any efforts seeking to coerce Member States into accepting unconditionally the Commission’s demands for new money. For this reason, my colleagues and I voted against.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to include in the 2015 budget an overrun of EUR 1.4 billion for the financial year 2014. This amount would reduce Member States' contributions in 2015.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. It is proposed to record surpluses of 1.435 billion euros for the previous year for the 2015 financial year. Is. But then what is expected to reduce the contribution of Member States to the EU budget for the same financial year 2015?

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Parliament takes note of the Commission's draft amending budget No3/2015, which is only intended to include the 2014 surplus of EUR 1.435 billion in the 2015 budget. It recalls that the adoption of the draft amending budget No. 3/2015 will reduce the share of Member States' GNI contribution to the EU budget due to competition and that, therefore, their contribution to the financing of the draft amending budget No4/2015, subject to adoption at the same meeting, will more than be compensated. I voted in favour of this draft amending budget.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Last April, the Commission adopted the draft amending budget 3/2015. It covers the budgeting of the previous year's surplus as stipulated in Article 18 of the Financial Regulation of the General Budget of the European Union. The implementation of the 2014 budget left a surplus of 1.435 billion euros, which must therefore be included in the 2015 budget. This surplus stems in particular from late interest and fines (EUR 634 million) as well as a positive implementation of own resources (EUR 479 million). The adoption of this amending budget should reduce the contribution of Member States to the EU budget for the 2015 financial year. I have therefore decided to abstain on this vote on this last point, even if I do not approve of the European Union's budgetary policies.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mrs Gardiazabal Rubial's report is balanced and I support it, so I voted in favour of it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is critical of the Council's tendency not to respect its commitments to the countries in need which have met the necessary conditions in order to benefit from the European Union Solidarity Fund by mobilizing the additional resources provided for special instruments, but rather by drawing funds from other existing programmes.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because draft amending budget No 3/2015 aims to include an overrun in the 2015 budget for the financial year 2014. The European Parliament regrets the trend in the Council, instead of fulfilling its commitments to countries in need of assistance and which have fulfilled the conditions for mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund using the additional resources provided for under the specific measures to take away the money allocated to existing programmes. Parliament underlines its intention to adopt draft amending budget No 3/2015 and amending budget No 4/2015 as soon as possible, as presented by the Commission. We also endorse the Council's position on draft amending budget No 3/2015.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft arrea amendment No 3/2015 aims to put the surplus of EUR 1 435 million from the 2014 financial year into the 2015 budget. The main sources of surplus are the positive revenue statement of EUR 1 183 million on the revenue side, the unused amount of EUR 142 million on the expenditure side and the balance of exchange rate differences of EUR 110 million. On the revenue side, the two main components are interest and fines for late payment (EUR 634 million) and positive own resources (EUR 479 million). For Section III, the very low level of unused appropriations underlines the continued inadequacy of payment appropriations, which will also be one of the main challenges for the implementation of the 2015 budget. The adoption of draft araks no. 3/2015 will reduce by EUR 1 435 million the contribution from Member States to the EU budget based on gross national income (GNI). On the basis of the above, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. It is nice to support a communication that talks about budget surpluses, given that more and more countries are having problems with such balance sheet results. The 2015 budget includes a 2014 surplus of €1.435 billion. Unplanned revenue stems mainly from the element of default interest and the fine (EUR 634 million) and the positive result in own resources (EUR 479 million). This will also reduce member states' contributions and strengthen the financial situation in the EU Solidarity Fund.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of a resolution because I believe it is important that surpluses from previous budgets are carried over to the current budget so that the Union's resources can be used correctly and fully.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The draft amending budget aims to postpone the 2014 surplus of 1.435 billion euros in 2015. This consists of additional revenues amounting to EUR 1.183 billion, an under-performance of expenditure of 142 million euros and a foreign exchange difference of 110 million euros. This surplus will reduce member states' contribution to the EU budget for 2015.  We believe that the postponement of the surplus from the 2014 financial year to the 2015 budget makes perfect sense in view of the budgetary efforts requested from the Member States. We regret, however, that the Council is mobilizing additional resources instead of using existing funds for aid to countries in need. That is why I abstained.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The inclusion in the budget of the surplus for the previous year is in itself a technical fact. The very low rate of under-implementation underlines the permanent shortage of payment appropriations, which will remain one of the main problems in the implementation of the 2015 budget.  Parliament regretted the Council's tendency not to honour its commitments to countries in need which fulfil the conditions for mobilising the EUSF by unlocking additional resources, as provided for in the special instruments, and to decide instead to take money away from other programmes. PBR No 3 will largely compensate for Member States' contribution to the financing of PBR No 4/2015

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ A budget surplus should be returned to the Member States rather than be spent by the European Union.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the amending budget number 3/2015 for the total amount of the surplus amounting to EUR 1 435 million for budgetary year 2014 to be entered as revenue in the 2015 budget.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the amending budget which aims to enter in the 2015 budget the surplus resulting from the implementation of the 2014 financial year. This is EUR 1435 million mainly from a positive surplus on the revenue side. I strongly voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this draft amending budget, which aims to extend the surplus for the 2014 financial year to the 2015 budget, amounting to EUR 1,435 million. Of course, on the face of it, the draft amending budget as presented here would reduce the contribution of Member States to the EU budget for the 2015 financial year, which I welcome. However, there is a real problem with the permanent lack of payment appropriations, which, as the report points out, will remain a major problem when implementing the 2015 budget. Moreover, the surplus as contained in this draft amending budget 3/2015 shows that these two draft amending budgets for 2014, covering a total of seven EUSF interventions, could have been easily financed under the 2014 budget. This is another example of the mismanagement of the Union.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is important to mention that the main elements of this surplus constitute a positive result in revenues of EUR 1.183 billion, an unspended amount in expenses of EUR 142 million, and exchange rate differences of EUR 110 million. We note that this draft amending budget, as presented by the Commission, concerns only the incorporation into the budget of the surplus resulting in 2014, i.e. EUR 1.435 billion. We regret the Council's tendency not to honour its commitments to countries in an emergency that qualify for eusf mobilisation.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft amending budget, which aims to budgetise the surplus resulting from the implementation of the 2014 financial year, which amounts to EUR 1435 million.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote in favour of correcting and including in the 2015 budget the surplus for the financial year 2014 is supported by the fact that the balance data are in line with those of previous years. Indeed, at the end of 2014 there was a surplus of 1,431 million euros, due to revenue increased by 1,183 million euros, lower expenses of 142 million euros and a positive component on exchange rates. The accounting of the surplus is useful in reducing the contribution that Italy must pay to the European Union as a financing of its budget. The budget is at the heart of the EU system: directly or indirectly we all benefit from EU-funded activities. Economic growth, employment, social and cultural cohesion are all key themes of Community philosophy and principles and without a multiannual economic plan they are difficult to achieve.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 3/2015 aims to include in the 2015 budget the surplus for the financial year 2014, in the amount of EUR 1 435 million, in accordance with Article 18 of the Financial Regulation and the Council's position on it. I support this report and stress that its adoption will reduce the share of member states' GNI-based contributions to the Union budget by EUR 1 435 million and therefore more than offset its contribution to the financing of draft amending budget No 4/2015 related to the mobilisation of the EUSFs in favour of Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, with a total amount of EUR 66.5 million.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Just under half of this surplus is made up of fines and late payments from national governments, and thus directly from the pockets of taxpayers. It will be transferred to projects such as the European Solidarity Fund, which provide finance for many initiatives which I as a UKIP MEP do not support and do not wish British taxpayers’ money to be spent on.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report to enable entry of the surplus from the 2014 financial year in the 2015 budget. It is in the best interest of EU citizens for unused appropriations for the year 2014 to be transferred to subsequent years in order to contribute to the creation of jobs and growth.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it entails the approval of the budget allocation of the surplus of the European budget during the 2014 financial year in the amount of EUR 1.4 billion. The interinstitutional agreement on the Budget of the European Union included the flexibility to allocate these unsosed margins in the financing of other items, which appears to be reflected in this amending budget. The report also reflects criticism of the Council for its lack of flexibility with countries in the worst economic situation in order to benefit from the European Union Solidarity Fund. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This amending budget report relates to the 2014 budget surplus under Article 18 of the Financial Regulation. A total of EUR 1.435 billion will be reported as revenue in the 2015 budget, thereby reducing national contributions to the common budget. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. At the end of the 2014 financial year, the European Union budget posted a surplus of EUR 1.435 billion. The latter must be budgeted for fiscal 2015, so that funds can be reallocated to operating expenses or new investment projects. By this vote, we have validated such an operation.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. This agreement aims to budget the surplus resulting from the implementation of the 2014 budget year, as stipulated in the financial regulation applicable to the general BUDGET of the Union. This surplus of EUR 1,434,557,707.74 will be recorded as revenue for the 2015 budget and will proportionately reduce Member States' contributions.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of amending budget 3, which is only intended to include the 2014 surplus of EUR 1.435 billion in the 2015 budget, in accordance with Article 18 of the Financial Regulation and the Council's position. Approval of this amending budget by the budgetary authority will reduce the share of Member States' GNI contribution to the EU budget by the same amount.  However, I deplore the attitude of the Council, which has strongly insisted that payments relating to the intervention of the European Union Solidarity Fund be carried over to the 2015 budget for a total amount of EUR 126.7 million. It prefers to solicit funds from other programmes rather than mobilize the additional resources provided by the special instruments.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – Draft Ark No 3/2015 aims to put the surplus of EUR 1 435 million from the 2014 financial year into the 2015 budget. The main sources of surplus are the positive revenue statement of EUR 1 183 million on the revenue side, the unused amount of EUR 142 million on the expenditure side and the balance of exchange rate differences of EUR 110 million. On the revenue side, the two main components are interest and fines for late payment (EUR 634 million) and positive own resources (EUR 479 million). For Section III, the very low level of unused appropriations underlines the continued inadequacy of payment appropriations, which will also be one of the main challenges for the implementation of the 2015 budget. The adoption of draft araks no. 3/2015 will reduce by EUR 1 435 million the contribution from Member States to the EU budget based on gross national income (GNI). On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ While the report recommends that Parliament adopts DAB3/2015 which the ECR supports, it has also established a political link with DAB4/2015 (mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund). The report claims that by linking the adoption of DAB3 with DAB4/2015 Council will be unable to shift the payment requests related to the EUSF into the 2016 budget negotiations. It points out that DAB 3/2015 will reduce the share of GNI contributions from Member States and will therefore more than compensate their contribution to the financing of DAB 4/2015. The ECR is in favour of adopting DAB 3/2015 un-amended and will not accept any political linkage between DABs.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 There is nothing more normal than to spend budget surpluses in the accounting year concerned, on emergency payments or other liabilities or, if this is not allowed or simply time is not enough for them to be transferred to the next budgetary period and used there. I will therefore support this report, especially when it mentions the name of my country and that more Solidarity Fund funds will be mobilised for it. I will not go into detail here as to why my country needs these funds, but I will ask everyone here: please spend this money wisely, correctly and so that they can create more community added value.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report, as the transfer of the 2014 surplus to the 2015 PC is not carried out in targeted areas where there are real needs, but as a reserve of additional payments, which means that they will be given as they see fit and for the benefit of those in power.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft arrea amendment No 3/2015 aims to put the surplus of EUR 1 435 million from the 2014 financial year into the 2015 budget. The main sources of surplus are the positive revenue statement of EUR 1 183 million on the revenue side, the unused amount of EUR 142 million on the expenditure side and the balance of exchange rate differences of EUR 110 million. On the revenue side, the two main components are interest and fines for late payment (EUR 634 million) and positive own resources (EUR 479 million). For Section III, the very low level of unused appropriations underlines the continued inadequacy of payment appropriations, which will also be one of the main challenges for the implementation of the 2015 budget. The adoption of draft araks no. 3/2015 will reduce by EUR 1 435 million the contribution from Member States to the EU budget based on gross national income (GNI). On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote because the surplus is not used to reduce the contribution of the Member States.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a project of an eminently technical nature, with a view to introducing eur 1 435 million into the 2015 budget. Transfers between headings cannot be carried out due to the lack of flexibility of the EU budget imposed by the EU Treaties and the requirements of the Multiannual Financial Framework. Each year, although there is a budget deficit in some headings, there are others that, due to the lack of sufficient applications/applications or implementation problems, may show a surplus at the end of the year. If there is money that has not been spent on a heading in a given year, one of two situations can happen, either that money is deducted from the member states' contribution (indexed to GNI) or there is an effort to try to reintroduce it the following year into the EU budget. In practice, this figure will be used to partially reduce member states' contributions, when it could and should be used as a reinforcement, not by reducing these already insufficient contributions, particularly with regard to programmes where the lack of payment appropriations has been found: in social and environmental areas.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the Council's position on draft amending budget No 3/2015 for the financial year 2015 – inclusion of the surplus from the financial year 2014. The main components of this surplus are the positive result of the implementation of the budget on the revenue side of EUR 1 183 million. Further unspent expenditure of EUR 142 million, as well as exchange differences of EUR 110 million. I would like to stress that the adoption of this proposal will reduce the share of Member States' contributions to the EU budget by EUR 1 435 million, thus more than offsetting their contribution to the financing of draft amending budget No 4/2015.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is only a small technical adjustment with the budgetization of the surplus for the previous year which I welcome.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The transfer of the 2014 surplus to the 2015 PC is not carried out in targeted areas where there are real needs, but as a reserve of additional payments, which means that they will be given as they see fit and for the benefit of those in power. That is why my vote is against.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I approved the Council position on Draft amending budget No 3/2015.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft arrea amendment No 3/2015 aims to put the surplus of EUR 1 435 million from the 2014 financial year into the 2015 budget. The main sources of surplus are the positive revenue statement of EUR 1 183 million on the revenue side, the unused amount of EUR 142 million on the expenditure side and the balance of exchange rate differences of EUR 110 million. On the revenue side, the two main components are interest and fines for late payment (EUR 634 million) and positive own resources (EUR 479 million). For Section III, the very low level of unused appropriations underlines the continued inadequacy of payment appropriations, which will also be one of the main challenges for the implementation of the 2015 budget. The adoption of draft araks no. 3/2015 will reduce by EUR 1 435 million the contribution from Member States to the EU budget based on gross national income (GNI). On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. This draft amending budget No 3/2015 (PPR No 3/2015) concerns the budgeting of the surplus for the previous financial year in accordance with the provisions of the Financial Regulation. The implementation of the 2014 financial year shows a surplus of EUR 1 435 million. This surplus will reduce in line the contribution of Member States to the financing of the 2015 EU budget. In this context, it was important to support this PPR No 3/2015 as it introduces a general criticism of the Council's attitude not to fulfil its commitments to countries in need by mobilizing additional resources but to take money from existing programmes.  That is why we have linked PPR No 3/2105 and PPR No 4/2015 on the mobilisation of the European Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. In doing so, we have ensured that both reports are subject to a common timetable for adoption and that they are strictly politically linked.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the report on draft amending budget No 3/2015: budget surplus for 2014 today because I fundamentally lack the necessary transparency in the EU budget, reject hidden debts and cannot fully agree with all points when setting the focus of the supplementary budget.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I would like to congratulate rapporteur Eider Gardiazabal Rubial on her excellent work, which I myself, as a member of the Committee on Budgets, have been able to follow closely. The positive result of the vote only confirms the really impressive search for compromises with the Council and the Commission. This resulted in draft amending budget No 3/2015 to introduce a surplus of EUR 1 435 million into the 2015 budget. During the negotiations on the 2015 budget, the Council demanded that payments in draft amending budgets 5/2014 and 7/2014 relating to the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) be local to the 2015 budget of a total of EUR 126.7 million. It has rightly been pointed out that the appropriations for both draft amending budgets for 2014, covering a total of 7 cases of mobilisation of the EUSF, could easily have been managed in the 2014 budget for the surplus presented in the current draft amending budget No 3/2015. I would also like to draw attention to the Council's willingness not to honour its commitments to countries in need that have fulfilled the conditions for mobilising the EUSF by mobilising the additional resources provided for in the special instruments. A good sign for the future was that the Council did not apply this approach to draft amending budget No 4/2015.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Gardiazabal report given the budgeting of the surplus will diminish the global contribution of the Member States to the financing of the 2015 EU Budget.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this budgetary correction consisting of transfers between surpluses existing under certain budget headings for one year which can be reallocated for the next financial year, as a means of not losing that money (since if it is not reallocated, the budget for the next financial year falls in equal importance).

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the Council position on draft amending budget No 3/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, which includes a surplus for the financial year 2014. I believe that it is essential for the European Union, as such a large institution, to properly monitor its finances and to achieve a budgetary balance. This draft amending budget will contribute to the budgetary balance for 2015, which is important, given that the EU budget was in surplus in 2014.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. This report accounts for the EU's budget surplus in 2014 and enters it in the 2015 budget, reducing Member States' gross national income contributions to the Union budget by EUR 1 435 million.  Budgetary rectification is an eminently technical issue which, however, has taken on a political side given the criticism that the Socialists have made to the Council's frequent attitude of not fulfilling its commitments to countries in need for the mobilisation of additional resources, taking the money from existing programmes. To avoid this, this report has been linked to the report on draft amending budget No 4/2015 linking the deadlines of both and calling for the new budgetary needs of the ESF in 2015 to be covered by the contributions of the surplus of the previous financial year.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as this shows a solid implementation of the EU’s annual budget. The surplus will be recorded as revenue in the 2015 budget in the amount of EUR 1 435 million. It is welcome to note that the budgeting of this surplus will diminish the national GNI contributions of Member States to the EU budget.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report proposes that the budget surplus achieved in 2014 be carried over to 2015 and that the amount be included in the 2015 budget accordingly. While the rapporteur recommends that Parliament adopt EA No 3/2015, which is supported by the ECR Group, it also establishes a political link with EAW No 4/2015 (use of the European Union Solidarity Fund). The ECR Group is in favour of adopting EAW No 3/2015 without amendments and rejects any political links between the EAW. EAW No 3/2015 should be adopted without restrictions. A derogation would constitute an infringement of Article 18(1) of the Financial Regulation, which states that 'the balance of each financial year shall be entered in the budget for the following financial year as revenue or in the form of appropriations for payments, depending on whether the balance is a surplus or a shortfall'.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ A huge chunk of this ‘surplus’ comes from the fines and late payments of nation states – essentially the British taxpayer. It will be given to projects like the European Solidarity Fund which will include our money being spent on projects that UKIP supporters, like me, will fundamentally disagree with.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this budgetary correction consisting of transfers between surpluses existing under certain budget headings for one year which can be reallocated for the next financial year, as a means of not losing that money (since if it is not reallocated, the budget for the next financial year falls in equal importance).

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Vote in favour of this report on the allocation of the surplus for the 2014 financial year.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the Council's position on draft budget amendments No 2012/2013. 3/2015 of the European Union for the 2015 financial year - the introduction of surpluses from the 2014 financial year, as this allows for the payment of draft amendments No 2015 and 2015. 5/2014 and No. 7/2014 relating to the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund. I also support the fact that amending budget No. 3/2015 reduce member states' contribution from GNI to the Union budget. Changes to the budget must be made in accordance with fair and transparent financial principles in the form of ensuring the stability and efficiency of the Financial Mechanisms of the European Union.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The 2015 financial year is to record a surplus of EUR 1.435 billion from the previous year. This postponement could reduce the contribution of Member States to the EU budget for the 2015 financial year. I have decided to abstain.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote calls for money to be taken from Members States through fines and other sanctions to support things such as the European Solidarity Fund. I do not believe the European Union should have the ability to fine sovereign states and therefore I have voted against this amendment.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Eider Gardiazabal Rubial's report on budgeting the surplus for the 2014 financial year. The report budgets for a surplus of EUR 1.435 billion, which will be included in the 2015 budget and will reduce Member States' contributions to the EU budget. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the european Union's draft amending budget No. 3/2015 for the 2015 financial year. This resolution budgets the budget surplus for 2014 of EUR 1.435 billion, the same as reducing Member States' national contributions to the EU budget.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Money that has not been used will not be carried over to the new financial year, but will be reimbursed on a pro rata basis to the payers. I believe that there is a reason why the institutions work below their budget limit, so I am voting against a transfer.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal on the amending budget as it aims to budgetise the surplus resulting from the implementation of the 2014 financial year. Specifically, this draft amending budget (PBR) No 3/2015 presented by the Commission is intended solely to enter the surplus resulting from the implementation of the 2014 financial year, amounting to EUR 1,435 billion, in accordance with Article 18 of the Financial Regulation and the Council's position.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission adopted the draft amending budget 3/2015 on 15 April. It covers the budgeting of the previous year's surplus as stipulated in Article 18 of the Financial Regulation of the General Budget of the European Union. Indeed, the implementation of the 2014 budget has left a surplus of 1.435 billion euros, which must therefore be included in the 2015 budget. This surplus is mainly due to late interest and fines (EUR 634 million) as well as a positive implementation of own resources (EUR 479 million). The adoption of this amending budget would reduce the contribution of Member States to the EU budget for the 2015 financial year. I have therefore decided to abstain on this vote.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it entails the approval of the budget allocation of the surplus of the European budget during the 2014 financial year in the amount of EUR 1.4 billion. The interinstitutional agreement on the Budget of the European Union included the flexibility to allocate these unsosed margins in the financing of other items, which appears to be reflected in this amending budget. The report also reflects criticism of the Council for its lack of flexibility with countries in the worst economic situation in order to benefit from the European Union Solidarity Fund. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The purpose of the draft amending budget is to budget the surplus that resulted from the previous year's financial year, which amounts to EUR 1.435 million, and which must therefore enter as income in the 2015 budget. I vote in favour of the proposal and I must stress that, within the framework of the negotiations, the Council insisted on ceding the remuneration for the European Union Solidarity Fund, and that, thanks to such mobilisations, the Fund has been able to positively amend other funds as it did for aid to Romania , Bulgaria and Italy, affected by flooding.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The report proposes that the budget surplus achieved in 2014 be carried over to 2015 and that the amount be included in the 2015 budget accordingly. While the rapporteur recommends that Parliament adopt EA No 3/2015, which is supported by the ECR Group, it also establishes a political link with EAW No 4/2015 (use of the European Union Solidarity Fund). I am therefore in favour of adopting EAW No 3/2015 without amendments and reject any political links between the EAW. EAW No 3/2015 should be adopted without restrictions. A derogation would constitute an infringement of Article 18(1) of the Financial Regulation, which states that 'the balance of each financial year shall be entered in the budget for the following financial year as revenue or in the form of appropriations for payments, depending on whether the balance is a surplus or a shortfall'.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since I am generally in a good place for making the most economical use of taxpayers' money, I do not agree with the further redistribution of funds that have been saved in one year. This money is to be returned to the Member States.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The aim of the draft budget amendment is to transfer a surplus from the 2014 financial year to €1 435 million to the 2015 budget. The Report points out that this surplus stems from the positive realization of revenues, less realization of expenditures and exchange rate difference. On the revenue side, the increase refers to 2 components, which are: default interest and fines and positive realization of own funds. On the expenditure side, the funds in Part III are unused. However, it should be noted here that the amount with other institutions has increased. The shortfall in payment appropriations will remain a challenge in the implementation of the 2015 budget, due to the very high unused funds of Part III. It should be noted that the Council does not fulfil its obligations to countries that have met the conditions for mobilising EU Solidarity Fund funds by mobilising additional funds as envisaged, but is doing so by withholding money from other programmes. Such situations should be avoided in further projections, and such an error has already been avoided in draft budget amendments No 1000/2013. 4/2015 which is a positive shift. Consequently, I supported the draft budget change.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Tells us that what is left of the resources has been used effectively. I support the Member's report and voted in favour.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 3/2015 includes a surplus of EUR 1 435 million in the 2015 budget for the financial year 2014. This proposal will reduce the share of Member States' contributions to the Union budget according to the amount of GNI by this amount, thus more than offsetting their contribution to the financing of the draft next amending budget No 4/2015.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1/2012. 3/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015 – entry of the surplus for the financial year 2014, because the adoption of the draft amending budget No 1/2004 is a good one. 3/2015 will reduce the share of Member States' GNI-based contributions to the Union budget by EUR 1.435 billion.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal and would like to point out that the adoption of draft amending budget No 3/2015 will reduce the share of the GNI contributions from Member States to the Union budget by EUR 1 435 million and will therefore more than compensate for their contribution to the financing of draft amending budget No 4/2015.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Commission's proposal to the Council concerning draft amended budget No 3/2015 concerning the inclusion in the budget of the surplus resulting from the implementation of the 2014 budget. With this budget, the Commission has accounted for the surplus of the 2014 budget. I thought it appropriate to support the Commission's project, hoping for a dynamic and rapid solution, as the accounting of the surplus will mean a corresponding reduction in the overall contribution of the Member States to the financing of the EU budget.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 3/2015 aims to include in the 2015 budget the surplus resulting from the implementation of the 2014 financial year, amounting to 1.435 billion euros. I have chosen to vote in favour of this report, aware that the adoption of this budget will reduce the scope of the contributions to be paid by the Member States to the Community budget.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully support the criticism that this report makes to the Council for systematically not honouring its commitments to countries in difficulty and meeting the requirements for mobilising the European Solidarity Fund by mobilising additional resources as provided for by the 2014-2020 MFF, preferring to redeployment other lines of the budget. Although I regret that this amount is used to partially reduce member states' contributions, rather than using such appropriations to strengthen programmes more advantageously, I voted in favour of considering that it is better not to waste any money in any case.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. "U2012 My support for the proposal to record in the EU budget for 2015 the surplus for the 2014 financial year, amounting to EUR 1 435 million, which will enable some needs to be met, such as responding satisfactorily to countries that have experienced natural disasters.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This draft is rejected by me because the transfer of unused funds from 2014 to this year is contrary to the interests of the Member States and should be better paid out to net contributors.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this Draft Amending Budget which covers the budgeting of the surplus of the previous year. The implementation of the budget year 2014 shows a surplus of EUR 1 435 million. This surplus will diminish accordingly the contribution of Member States to the financing of the 2015 EU budget.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. As every year, it is proposed that Parliament postpone large budget surpluses (1.4 billion in 2014) while the European Union continues to rack up mountains of unpaid debts under its various programmes. These surpluses are the result of the savage austerity imposed over the year by the Council in managing revenues as unforeseen expenses. The report deplores this attitude of the Council, but still recommends voting in favour. All the conditions are thus created for this short-sighted management to continue. This creeping austerity is in addition to the cuts already made in the initial budgets. It is even more unacceptable, because it is practiced wildly behind the budgets voted by Parliament. Under the guise of deferring surpluses, the aim here is to validate the deliberate tendency not to spend what is planned. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The adoption of draft amending budget No 3/2015 will reduce the share of GNI-based contributions from Member States to the Union budget by EUR 1 435 million and therefore more than offset its contribution to the financing of draft amending budget No 4/2015. The two dossiers are subject to a common adoption timetable as they are closely linked from a political point of view. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Draft Amending Budget No 3 of 2015 (DAB 3/2015) that covers the budgeting of the surplus of the previous year of EUR 1 435 million. This surplus will diminish accordingly the contribution of Member States to the financing of the 2015 EU budget. The Council needs to honour its commitments towards countries in need by the mobilisation of additional resources, but rather taking money away from the existing programmes.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft submitted aims to include a surplus of EUR 1 435 million in the 2014 budget into the 2015 budget and thus make it spendable in 2015.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft amending budget acknowledges the surplus resulting from the implementation of the 2014 financial year, in this case EUR 1.43 billion, which is therefore recorded in the 2015 budget.  This budgeting of the surplus will reduce the overall contribution of Member States to the financing of the EU budget.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 3/2015 aims to include in the 2015 budget the surplus for the financial year 2014, amounting to EUR 1 435 million. As part of the budgetary negotiations for 2015, the Council insisted on the transfer of payments related to the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in amending budgets No 5/2014 and 7/2014 to the 2015 budget, totaling EUR 126.7 million. I believe that the Council must honour its commitments, especially with countries in need that fulfil the conditions for mobilising the EUSF by mobilising the additional resources provided for by the special instruments.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission adopted the draft amending budget 3/2015 on 15 April. It covers the budgeting of the previous year's surplus as stipulated in Article 18 of the Financial Regulation of the General Budget of the European Union. Indeed, the implementation of the 2014 budget has left a surplus of 1.435 billion euros, which must therefore be included in the 2015 budget. This surplus is mainly due to late interest and fines (EUR 634 million) as well as a positive implementation of own resources (EUR 479 million). The adoption of this amending budget would reduce the contribution of Member States to the EU budget for the 2015 financial year. I have therefore decided to abstain on this vote.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, DAB3 is intended to budget the surplus resulting from the implementation of the budget year 2014. As provided for in the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union. The implementation of the budget year 2014 shows a surplus of EUR 1 434 557 707.74 (excluding contributions from European Free Trade Association (EFTA) and European Economic Area (EEA)), which is therefore entered as revenue in the 2015 budget. The budgeting of the surplus will diminish accordingly the global contribution of the Member States to the financing of the 2015 EU Budget.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the draft amending budget 2015. It adds the budget surplus of EUR 1.4 billion in 2014 to the revenues of the 2015 budget and reduces the national contributions of Member States to the EU budget.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this draft amending budget which concerns the surplus resulting from the implementation of last year's financial year. This surplus, which would amount to EUR 1.435 billion, derives from EUR 1.183 billion in higher revenues, EUR 142 million in lower expenditure and EUR 110 million in exchange rate differences. Our support is dictated by the fact that this figure will be positively used to lighten the various contributions of the Member States to the European Union for 2015. This measure will also be closely linked from a political point of view with draft amending budget No 4/2015, which will allow a better use of the European Union Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, whose populations were affected in 2014 by natural disasters, specifically, heavy flooding phenomena.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft amending budget (PBR) No 3/2015 aims to enter in the budget the surplus resulting from the implementation of the 2014 financial year. Given that the adoption of this draft will reduce the share of GNI-based Member States' contributions to the Union budget by an amount of EUR 1 435 million and will therefore largely compensate for their contribution to the financing of draft amending budget No 4/2015, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour of the report.

name: n/a
text: in writing. – I have voted for the draft amending budget No 3/2015 to enter in the 2015 budget the surplus from the 2014 financial year, amounting to EUR 1 435 million.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I have spoken out against this report because I believe that unused money should not be overwritten for next year. Financial resources must be managed efficiently to prevent the EU budget from steadily inflating.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to transfer the 2014 budget surplus to the 2014 budget in the amount of EUR 1 435 million. The adoption of the draft amending budget will also reduce member states' contribution to the Union budget by EUR 1 435 million.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas draft amending budget No. Regulation (EEC) No 3/2015 aims to include in the 2015 budget the surplus resulting from the implementation of the 2014 financial year, which amounts to EUR 1.435 billion and which, in the context of the negotiations on the 2015 budget, the Council insisted on the transfer of payments relating to the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in draft amending budgets no. 5/2014 and 7/2014 to the 2015 budget for a total amount of EUR 126.7 million I am in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Goal of draft budget modification No. 3/2015 is the introduction of surpluses from the 2014 financial year into the 2015 budget. The implementation of the 2014 budget generated a surplus of EUR 1 434 557 707.74, which is therefore entered as revenue in the 2015 budget. This is the only subject of this draft budget change that had to be submitted within 15 days of the submission of the interim financial statement, which happened at the end of March 2015. The overall contribution of Member States to the financing of the EU budget for 2015 will be reduced in line with the introduction of a surplus in the budget, which is certainly a fact I welcome. As the Commission adopted a draft amendment to budget No 15 April 2015, 3/2015 and if the Council had adopted a position on this draft budget amendment on 19 June 2015 with as many as 27 votes in the vote of Croatia, and that the European Parliament accepts in its proposal for a resolution the Council's position on this draft budget amendment, I support this Report on the Council's position on the draft amendment to budget No 2015. 3/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015 - the introduction of a surplus from the 2014 financial year and call on the Commission, the Council and the Parliament to adopt such amendments through mutually constructive trilogue and swift reaction, thereby contributing to strengthening links between Member States.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission adopted the draft amending budget 3/2015 on 15 April. It covers the budgeting of the previous year's surplus, as stipulated in Article 18 of the Financial Regulation of the GENERAL Budget of the Union. The implementation of the 2014 budget left a surplus of 1.435 billion euros, which must naturally be included in the 2015 budget. This surplus is mainly due to late interest and fines (634 million euros) as well as a positive implementation of own resources (479 million euros). The adoption of this amending budget would reduce the contribution of Member States to the EU budget for the 2015 financial year. I preferred to abstain on this vote.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 Because the goal of the draft budget modification is No. 3/2015 introduction of surplus from the 2014 financial year in the amount of EUR 1 435 million in the 2015 budget and that this surplus mainly stems from the positive realisation of revenues in the amount of EUR 1 183 million, less realisation of expenditure in the amount of EUR 142 million and exchange rate differences of EUR 110 million, I support Parliament's expressed willingness to adopt as soon as possible the draft amendment to budget No 110 million. 3/2015 and draft budget amendment No. 4/2015 in line with the Commission's proposals.  I also agree with the position of the Rapporteur, who regrets the Council's propensity to fulfil its obligations to countries in need and which have met the conditions for mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund by mobilising additional funds as provided for in specific instruments but by withholding money from other programmes, and which welcomes, however, the fact that the Council has not taken this approach as regards the draft amendment to Budget No 1999/2013. 4/2015.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Taking into account the EU budget regulations, it is seen that the draft is intended to be included in the budget of the surplus resulting from the implementation of the 2014 budget in the amount of EUR 1 434 557 707.74, which does not include contributions from the European Free Trade Association and the European Economic Area, which is therefore entered as revenue in the 2015 budget. Member States' overall contribution to the financing of the 2015 EU budget will be reduced in line with the budget surplus. This overall reduction in Member States' contributions will also be influenced by updated forecasts of own resources (traditional own resources (TVS), value added tax (VAT) and gross national income (GNI)), including an updated UK correction amount to be available following a meeting of the Advisory Committee on Own Resources (ACOR) in May 2015. It should be recalled that during the negotiations on the 2015 budget, The Council insisted that payments related to the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund should be transferred from draft amendments to budget No 1009/2013. 5/2014 and No. 7/2014 in the 2015 budget totalling €126.7 million. Taking this into account, I support the proposed draft amendment.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the text on the budget surplus for the 2014 financial year. This surplus amounts to EUR 1.435 billion and contributes to a further reduction in the national contributions of member states.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft amending budget aims to include in the 2015 budget the surplus for the financial year 2014. The rapporteur considers, however, that the surplus submitted could have been paid under the 2014 budget to honour the Council's commitments to needy countries (7 cases in total) whose applications met the conditions for mobilising the additional resources provided for by the special instruments under the European Union Solidarity Fund.  Deploring the general trend towards reducing member states' per capita income-based contributions to the Union budget, I voted in favour of the report on the Council's position, which approves the budgeting of the 2014 surplus in the 2015 budget.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims to adopt the Council's position on draft amending budget No 3/2015. I voted in favour of this report because it only includes in the 2015 budget the surplus for the financial year 2014, amounting to EUR 1 435 million. The approval of this draft amending budget No. 3/2015 will offset its contribution to the financing of draft amending budget No 4/2015.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament today voted on the issue of unused funds in the previous year, under its budgetary prerogatives. We voted for Member States to be able to recover these amounts, which will therefore reduce their contribution to the EU budget. This time, the surplus - EUR 1.435 billion - seems to be in the trend of recent years, but only in appearance. Indeed, we already know that a significant part of the European Union's bills has not been paid. This is reflected in the surplus. 142 million euros could not be used, even if they were programmed. This is a very low underutilization of appropriations, a record in this area in reality. This worrying situation highlights the recurrent lack of money, which will remain a major problem during the implementation of the 2015 budget. While I supported this report, I would like to remind the Council of our firm objective of stabilizing, or even reducing, the amount of unpaid bills in 2015.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is critical of the Council's tendency not to respect its commitments to the countries in need which have met the necessary conditions in order to benefit from the European Union Solidarity Fund by mobilizing the additional resources provided for special instruments, but rather by drawing funds from other existing programmes.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the draft amending budget No. 3 in the general budget 2015 in order to adopt this draft amending budget. I stress that the budgeting of this surplus of 1.434 billion will reduce the contribution of Member States to the financing of the European Union budget. However, it should be noted that this overall decrease will be influenced by the updated forecasts for own resources (traditional own resources, value-added tax, gross national income).

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution on draft amending budget (POR) No 3/2015 aims to include in the Community budget 2015 the surplus resulting from the implementation of the 2014 budget year, amounting to EUR 1 435 million. It should also be noted that budgeting the surplus will reduce, to the same extent, the overall contribution of Member States to the financing of the EU budget 2015. More specifically, it will reduce the share of contributions based on the Gross National Income of the Member States to the Union budget by EUR 1 435 million. That is why I voted in favour of this draft resolution.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of draft amending budget (PBR) No 3/2015, which aims to budgetise the surplus resulting from the implementation of the 2014 financial year. The implementation of last year's financial year reveals a surplus of around EUR 1.435 billion, which can be moved from one budget line to another.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this budgetary correction consisting of transfers between surpluses existing under certain budget headings for one year which can be reallocated for the next financial year, as a means of not losing that money (since if it is not reallocated, the budget for the next financial year falls in equal importance).

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it entails the approval of the budget allocation of the surplus of the European budget during the 2014 financial year in the amount of EUR 1.4 billion. The interinstitutional agreement on the Budget of the European Union included the flexibility to allocate these unsosed margins in the financing of other items, which appears to be reflected in this amending budget. The report also reflects criticism of the Council for its lack of flexibility with countries in the worst economic situation in order to benefit from the European Union Solidarity Fund. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 3/2015 concerns the surplus for the 2014 financial year of €1.435 billion to be entered in the 2015 budget. Although this is a mere routine operation which should enable the Commission to return this surplus to the Member States in the form of a reduction in the share of contributions to be paid, the rapporteur wanted to establish a political link with draft amending budget No 4 on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund. Although I am in favour of adopting both draft amending budgets, I believe that the established distinction of the Financial Regulation must be respected. I have therefore decided to vote against this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as the surplus will help reduce Member State contributions.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the resolution in question was to include a surplus of EUR 1 435 million in the 2015 budget for the financial year 2014. These funds consist mainly of interest on late payments, fines and a positive result in the implementation of the EU's own resources, which is why I am in favour of realling this surplus to the 2015 budget. However, in line with the EKR's position, I could not agree to the automatic linking of this resolution to the EP resolution on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 4/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, which is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \ the objective of draft amending budget No 3/2015 is to include in the 2015 budget a surplus of EUR 1,435 million in the 2015 budget. The main elements of this surplus are the positive result of revenues of EUR 1 183 million, the unused expenditure of EUR 142 million and the exchange rate difference of EUR 110 million.  In the context of the 2015 budgetary negotiations, the Council proposed to transfer payments related to the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund in draft amending budgets No 5/2014 and No 7/2014 totalling EUR 126.7 million to the 2015 budget. Taking into account the surplus in draft amending budget No 3/2015, these two draft amending budgets of 2014, relating to a total of 7 cases of the EU Solidarity Fund, could be paid from the 2014 budget, which is why I voted in favour of Draft No 3/2015.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The report proposes that the budget surplus achieved in 2014 be carried over to 2015 and that the amount be included in the 2015 budget accordingly. While the rapporteur recommends that Parliament adopt EA No 3/2015, which is supported by the ECR Group, it also establishes a political link with EAW No 4/2015 (use of the European Union Solidarity Fund). The ECR Group is in favour of adopting EAW No 3/2015 without amendments and rejects any political links between the EAW. EAW No 3/2015 should be adopted without restrictions. A derogation would constitute an infringement of Article 18(1) of the Financial Regulation, which states that 'the balance of each financial year shall be entered in the budget for the following financial year as revenue or in the form of appropriations for payments, depending on whether the balance is a surplus or a shortfall'.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is important that we use the surplus of EUR 1 435 million for the development of the European Union.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support the proposal to amend budget No. 3/2015 - surplus from the 2014 financial year I agree with this draft report that the surplus of revenues from 2014, amounting to EUR 1 435 million, will be transferred to the 2015 budget.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the draft amending budget No 3 as it budgets the surplus resulting from the implementation of the budget year 2014, as provided for in the financial regulation applicable to the general budget of the EU, and will lead to reduced Member State contributions.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support this Draft Report as there are two main sources of increase on the revenue side: default interest and fines (EUR 634 million), surplus own resources (EUR 479 million) and that the current lack of payment appropriations is seen at a very high rate of non-use of Part III funds, focuses on the current lack of payment appropriations, which will continue to be a key challenge in the implementation of the 2015 budget. I must say that I do not agree with the fact that the Council is leaning towards the fact that it fulfils its obligations to countries in need of assistance and which meet the conditions for the activation of the EU Solidarity Fund by withholding money from other programmes rather than activating additional funds as provided for in specific instruments. I would like to stress that the adoption of the draft amendment to budget No 2013 will 3/2015 reduce the proportion of Member States' contributions from GNI to the Union budget by EUR 1 435 million, thus more than compensating for their contribution to the financing of draft amendments to budget No 1 435 million. 4/2015.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because I do not agree with the political regulation of the EU budget, which, moreover, leads to greater redistribution.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Council position on the draft amending budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 – the inclusion of the surplus from the financial year 2014. I agree that a positive result in revenue, unused expenditure and exchange rate differences should be included in the 2015 budget. I also support the rapporteur's view that, given the surplus, the 2014 budget could easily be paid for by the draft amending budget for 2014, which concerned a total of 7 examples of the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The transfer of the 2014 surplus to the 2015 PC is not carried out in targeted areas where there are real needs, but as a reserve of additional payments, which means that they will be given as they see fit and for the benefit of those in power.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Draft Amending Budget No 3 of 2015 (DAB 3/2015) covers a surplus of EUR 1 435 million in budget year 2014. The surplus results from interest on late payments and fines (EUR 634 million) a positive outturn on own resources (EUR 479 million), under spending in expenditure of EUR 142 million and exchange rate differences amounting to EUR 110 million. The adoption of DAB 3/2015 will accordingly reduce the contribution of Member States to the financing of the 2015 EU budget. Nonetheless, I would like to point out that the extra funds from DAB 3/2015 could have been used for increasing the resources for other programmes, particularly the EU’s Solidarity Fund (EUSF), which was created to assist Member States that need the mobilisation of additional funds. Although this was not done, I welcome the link established between DAB 3/2015 and DAB 4/2015, which is asking to mobilize EUR 66.5 million to Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, which were hit by floods in 2014. Adopting these two dossiers together guarantees a common calendar and fast deployment of needed funds to these countries. This is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the text. I regret, however, in general, the Council's tendency to honour its commitments to countries in need that meet the conditions for EUSF intervention by soliciting funds from existing programmes rather than mobilising the additional resources provided by the special instruments.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted against it, because although the No 3 Draft Budget Amendment Report provides for the return of surplus to Member States, which is based on late payments, penalties and positive outputs on my own resources from the 2014 financial year, I cannot support politicisation and efforts to redistribute funds to the detriment of creating a budget budget for the following year.
