As part of the 2015 budget negotiations, the Council insisted on the transfer of disbursements related to solidarity fund funds to draft amendments to budget No 2015. 5 and No. 7 in the amount of EUR 126.7 million, which would prevent the Council from transferring payment claims from the Solidarity Fund to negotiations on the 2016 budget.  I support the budget blueprint, but without the proposed changes and without politicisation in terms of benefiting from the link and at the expense of other budget nomenclatures.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the draft amending budget. The proposal is about a surplus from the 2014 financial year. The total amount of surplus to be reallocated to the financial year 2015 is EUR 1,435 million. This amount will mean a reduction in member states' national contributions to the EU budget.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this budgetary correction consisting of transfers between surpluses existing under certain budget headings for one year which can be reallocated for the next financial year, as a means of not losing that money (since if it is not reallocated, the budget for the next financial year falls in equal importance).

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The report proposes that the budget surplus achieved in 2014 be carried over to 2015 and that the amount be included in the 2015 budget accordingly. While the rapporteur recommends that Parliament adopt EA No 3/2015, which is supported by the ECR Group, it also establishes a political link with EAW No 4/2015 (use of the European Union Solidarity Fund). The ECR Group is in favour of adopting EAW No 3/2015 without amendments and rejects any political links between the EAW. EAW No 3/2015 should be adopted without restrictions. A derogation would constitute an infringement of Article 18(1) of the Financial Regulation, which states that 'the balance of each financial year shall be entered in the budget for the following financial year as revenue or in the form of appropriations for payments, depending on whether the balance is a surplus or a shortfall'.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this budgetary correction consisting of transfers between surpluses existing under certain budget headings for one year which can be reallocated for the next financial year, as a means of not losing that money (since if it is not reallocated, the budget for the next financial year falls in equal importance).

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the two technical corrections to the budget voted on in this House.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a decision which involves transferring the surplus of the 2014 budget to the 2015 budget, so I consider it appropriate to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it entails the approval of the budget allocation of the surplus of the European budget during the 2014 financial year in the amount of EUR 1.4 billion. The interinstitutional agreement on the Budget of the European Union included the flexibility to allocate these unsosed margins in the financing of other items, which appears to be reflected in this amending budget. The report also reflects criticism of the Council for its lack of flexibility with countries in the worst economic situation in order to benefit from the European Union Solidarity Fund. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft amending budget (POR) No 3/2015 is of a technical nature, with a view to introducing into the 2015 budget the surplus for the financial year 2014 amounting to EUR 1 435 million. As it is not possible to make transfers between headings due to the lack of flexibility of the EU budget imposed by the EU Treaties and the requirements of the MFF, each year, although there is a budget deficit in some headings, there are others that, due to the lack of sufficient applications/applications or implementation problems may present surplus at the end of the year.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This draft would have been rejected by me, since the transfer of unused funds from 2014 to this year is contrary to the interests of the Member States and should be better paid out to net contributors.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the Council's position on the draft EU amending budget for the 2015 financial year, which aims to include in the 2015 budget the surplus for the 2014 financial year, surplus amounting to EUR 1 435 million. The rapporteur expressed regret at the existence of a tendency in the Council not to honour its commitments to countries in a difficult situation which met the conditions for mobilising the EUSF, while noting that, in draft amending budget No 1 of the European Parliament and of the Council, the Commission should be informed that the Commission should take the necessary information. 4/2015, the Council did not follow this approach.  I welcome the fact that the report recalls that the Commission has presented, in addition to this draft amending budget, another draft amending budget, No 1 of the Annex to this Regulation. 4/2015, related to the mobilisation of the total amount of EUR 66.5 million for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy from the EUSF. The adoption of this draft amending budget will reduce by EUR 1 435 million the level of Member States' contributions to the Union budget, which are based on GNBs, and will therefore compensate for their contribution to the financing of draft amending budget No 14. 4/2015.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft amending budget (POR) No 3/2015 is of a technical nature, with a view to introducing in the 2015 budget the surplus for the financial year 2014 amounting to EUR 1 435 million. As it is not possible to make transfers between the rubrics due to the lack of flexibility of the EU budget imposed by the EU Treaties and the requirements of the MFF, there are headings which, due to the lack of sufficient applications/applications or implementation problems, may be surplus at the end of the year. The report criticises the Council's systematic position of not honouring its commitments to countries with needs and meeting the conditions for mobilising the EUSF by mobilising additional resources, as provided for in the 2014-2020 MFF agreement in relation to special instruments, opting for the reallocation of other budget lines. We voted for it.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it approves the budget amendment to provide significant assistance for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy to deal with the effects of flooding in the spring and summer of 2014. This report approves the provision of financial resources for the mobilisation of more than EUR 66 million of aid more than necessary to alleviate the damage of these natural disasters in these countries and to initiate the necessary reconstruction processes. The report also condemns the Council's uncompromising position in authorizing additional funds for these emergencies created by natural disasters and approves the use of 2014 margins. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The EU Solidarity Fund was launched in 2002. It is intended to provide effective and flexible response options to help Member States and countries that are candidates for EU membership in the event of natural disasters. I support the correction of the budget so that the countries of Romania, Bulgaria and Italy can benefit from the necessary funds.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, because I do not believe in the principle of this fund.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this necessary deliberation in view of the floods in this part of the European Union.

name: Richard Ashworth (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The British Conservatives voted against this proposal for Draft Amending Budget No 4 (DAB4), which seeks an additional EUR 66 million beyond the agreed Budget for 2015. While we support the principle and objectives of the EU Solidarity Fund, the Conservatives have been consistently clear that we want to see real budgetary restraint in the EU in order to avoid unaffordably high costs for Member States. Our view is that the Commission must always look first to reallocate funds from within existing agreed budgets, such as the EU Solidarity Fund, to meet emerging in-year payments, rather than coming straight to the Member States to request additional money. As the Commission has not made any effort to do this, my colleagues and I voted against this request.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. Draft amending budget No 4/2015 concerns the mobilisation of commitments and payment appropriations of EUR 66 505 850 from the EUSF due to the two floods in Romania in spring and summer 2014, due to the july-August 2014 restructuring plan. The floods in Bulgaria and the 2014-November floods have led to the death of the United States of America. floods in Italy.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This report accompanies the European Union Solidarity Fund's proposal to mobilise Romania, Bulgaria and Italy: these three countries, members of the European Union, experienced major floods during 2014. The mobilization of this Fund must be on the basis of point 11 of the inter-institutional agreement of 2 December 2013 and I have no reason to oppose it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This draft amending budget No. 4/2015 covers the intervention of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for a total of EUR 66,505,850 in commitment and payment appropriations, following two floods in the spring and summer of 2014 in Romania, with eur 8,495,950 in aid, floods in July and August 2014 in Bulgaria, with aid of EUR 1,983,600, and floods in October and November 2014 in Italy, i.e. EUR 56,026,300. These expenditure amounts, which cover situations related to natural disasters, are more than offset by the 2015 amending budget No. 3, which defers the 2014 surplus of EUR 1.435 billion to the 2015 budget. I approved of that point.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this draft amending budget to increase the European Union Solidarity Fund in order to help Bulgaria, Romania and Italy through the floods in spring-summer 2014, in July, August, October and November of the same year.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Last April, the draft amending budget No. 4 was adopted by the Commission. This is the budgetary counterpart of the intervention of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for a total amount of 66.5 million euros. It proposes to mobilise the Union Solidarity Fund in the wake of bad weather and floods in Romania, Italy and Bulgaria. This Fund, which is a special instrument, helps to support territories in difficulty following natural disasters, but I cannot help but note that a significant amount (403.9 million euros) of the Fund remained unutilized in 2014. I have therefore decided to abstain on this point.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Between October and November 2014 five regions of north-western Italy, Emilia-Romagna, Liguria, Lombardy, Piedmont and Tuscany, were affected by dramatic floods that caused enormous damage and as many as 11 victims. Thanks to this vote, EUR 56 million will be allocated to the reconstruction and support of our territories. That is why I voted in favour of draft budget 4/2015 for the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this correction of the 2015 budget to allow the mobilisation of EUR 66.5 million in commitment and payment appropriations from the European Union Solidarity Fund to be allocated to Romania (EUR 8.5 million), Bulgaria (2 million euros) and Italy (EUR 56 million). These aids will serve to repair some of the flood damage in Romania in the spring of 2014 affecting 30 of the 42 districts, causing damage to public and private infrastructure, households and agriculture worth EUR 167.9 million; flooding in Bulgaria in July and August 2014 where heavy rains caused destruction in public and private infrastructure, business, households and private goods, as well as in the agricultural sector of the northwest region for more than 79 million euros; and floods and landslides in five regions of northwestern Italy (Emilia-Romagna, Liguria, Lombardy, Piedmont and Tuscany) in October and November 2014, which caused severe destruction in public and private infrastructure, business, households and private goods, the agricultural sector and the environment, worth EUR 2.241 million.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the countries affected by floods need to be granted financial support from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) as soon as possible, given that the EUSF expresses solidarity with the people of the disaster-affected region. The European Parliament deplores the commitments made in the Council to countries where a major disaster has occurred and which, therefore, fulfil the conditions for mobilising the EUSF Fund, rather through the use of funds allocated to other programmes than by mobilising additional resources, as provided for in the specific measures. Parliament stresses that, in the current emergency situation of payments, it is not possible to use a source of funding other than that proposed by the Commission, as outlined in draft amending budget No 4/2015. It should be borne in mind that the EUSF is a specific instrument for which the corresponding appropriations are to be entered in the budget, without taking into account the relevant ceilings of the multiannual financial framework.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, by its decision today, takes note of draft budget amendment No 4/2015 submitted by the Commission and the Council's position on this. It underlines the need for the urgent release of financial assistance to countries affected by natural disasters through the EUSA, taking into account the solidarity shown by the eusa with the populations of the regions affected by the disaster. The European Parliament recalls that the adoption of a budget amendment no. 3/2015 will reduce the contribution from Member States to the EU budget based on gross national income (GNI) and therefore provides ample reparations for their contribution to the financing of a budget amendment 4/2015. It points out that, since they are closely linked from a political point of view, the two draft aragings will have to be adopted at the same time. On the basis of the above, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I was happy to support the amending budgets allowing the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund to be used for areas in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, which were badly affected by the floods of spring and autumn 2014. I come from an area that has been hit many times in floods, and I know very well what kind of catastrophe water can cause. I very much hope that the people of these regions will use the funds not only to rehabilitate the consequences, but also to provide the best possible flood defences.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is important for the Eu ropean Union to provide aid to those areas affected by natural disasters and to show solidarity and support for its citizens in difficulty.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1/2002. 4/2015 of the European Union for the 2015 financial year accompanying the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, as the urgent need for financial assistance through the EUSF to be provided to countries affected by natural disasters is underlined, bearing in mind that the EUSF is proof of solidarity with the population in disaster-hit regions. The draft amending budget refers to the mobilisation from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) of EUR 66 505 850 in commitment and payment appropriations in connection with two floods in Romania in the spring and summer of 2014, the total amount of aid applications amounting to EUR 8 495 950, the floods in Bulgaria in July and August 2014, the total amount of aid applications amounting to EUR 1 983 600, and the floods in Italy in October-November 2014, with the total amount of aid applications amounting to EUR 56 026 300.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour to allow the mobilisation of the EUSF for the 2014 floods in Romania, Bulgarie and Italy (for 56 million euros).

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of recent floods in Romania (spring and summer 2014), Bulgaria (summer 2014) and Italy (autumn 2014), the Commission has proposed the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund for these four countries. The report proposes to apply 2.5% of all direct damage in all four cases, as none of these countries has exceeded the thresholds for major natural disasters. I support the proposal because, in the case of regional natural disasters and disasters accepted in accordance with the principle of 'neighbouring eligible state', Member States must receive aid.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, because I do not believe in the principle of this fund.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of amending the EU budget in order to mobilise, for the first time this year, the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to two floods in Romania in spring and summer 2014, floods in Bulgaria in July and August 2014, and floods in Italy in October and November 2014 for an amount of EUR 66 505 850 in commitments and payments.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 EUSF assistance takes the form of a grant supplementing the public funds allocated by the beneficiary State, and serves to finance measures intended, in principle, to deal with non-insurable damage. It should also be added that the surplus in the 2014 budget and its budgetary correction have made it possible to reduce, in this specific case, the contribution from the Member States.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this draft amending budget, which takes into account the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy following the floods in these countries. This draft amending budget No. 4/2015 covers the EUSF's intervention amounting to EUR 66,505,850 in commitment and payment appropriations, following two floods in the spring and summer of 2014 in Romania, amounting to EUR 8,495,950, floods in July and August 2014 in Bulgaria, with aid of EUR 1,983,600, and floods in October and November 2014 in Italy, i.e. EUR 56,026,300. While I welcome this solidarity with other European nations, I deplore the fact that the rapporteur justifies a further contribution from the Member States by the fact that the adoption of the draft amending budget 3/2015 will reduce the share of the Member States' GNI contribution to the EU budget of EUR 1,435 million.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Concerns mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in relation to two floods in Romania, spring and summer 2014, floods in Bulgaria in July-August 2014, and floods in Italy in October-November 2014. The amount of aid applications is around EUR 56 million. We stress our basic position that there is always an urgent need to release financial assistance through the EUSE to the countries affected by natural disasters and the EUSE must show solidarity with them.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft amending budget concerning the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy for a total amount of EUR 66.5 million. Romania applied for aid of around €8.5 million for spring and summer 2014 floods, Bulgaria around €2 million for floods in July and August 2014, and Italy €56 million for floods in October and November 2014.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote today is in line with the commitment I have shown since the day after the flood: the EU is there and must help the affected territories. I witnessed a question tabled last autumn, the answer to which, according to which Liguria had not yet submitted the request, I warned the regional authorities at the time to give priority to the things that matter rather than to their election campaigns. I then rejoiced when the Commission formulated this proposal, which will also benefit Piedmont and Lombardy and Emilia Romagna because of the damage they have suffered, and today I could only confirm my support for the allocation of this sum. I hope that this will be used well.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 After examining draft amending budget No 4/2015 on the Solidarity Fund, I have decided to vote in favour. Indeed, I agree with the Commission's proposal to activate the Solidarity Fund in the cases envisaged and to enter the corresponding funding in the 2015 budget.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. It is in the best interest of EU citizens to release financial assistance through the European Union Solidarity Fund to the countries affected by these natural disasters. These funds will amount to EUR 66 505 850 which will be distributed according to the total damage caused in the affected countries. It also takes into consideration that the European Union Solidarity Fund shows solidarity with the population in the region hit by disaster.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote relates to the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy for a total amount of EUR 66.5 million in commitment and payment appropriations. It includes four cases: two floods in Romania in spring and summer 2014, one flood in Bulgaria in July/August 2014, and one flood in Italy in October/November 2014.  I believe in real solidarity with all Member States in need of assistance so I supported this resolution.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to ensure a rapid, efficient and flexible response by the Union to emergency situations in the Member States, such as natural disasters – floods, earthquakes, etc. With this fund, the EU wants to show solidarity with the people of disaster-hit regions. The EUSF provides financial assistance to countries affected by such natural disasters, and I believe that the EU's response must be swift precisely in order to enable the affected population and the public administration of the Member States to carry out the work necessary to return to normal.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The aim of this amending budget report is to authorise the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to the tune of EUR 66,505,850 to Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, as envisaged in the MURE-AN report, in order to counter the floods that took place in these countries, in the spring and summer of 2014 in Romania, in July and August 2014 in Bulgaria and in October/November 2014 in Italy. I also voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. During 2014, Italy, Bulgaria and Romania were affected by devastating floods. As a result, more than EUR 66.5 million will be allocated to them, out of the 500 million available annually to the European Union Solidarity Fund. The reconstruction work is colossal in Italy; the country will therefore benefit from the majority of the aid, i.e. EUR 56 million.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Following the floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, the Commission has received requests for financial assistance from these states under the European Union Solidarity Fund. These countries will receive aid of EUR 66,505,850. With these funds, the affected territories will be able to rebuild their infrastructure more quickly. In addition, the Fund is helping to streamline EU spending by reallocating funds originally planned for rural development programmes that have not been used.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this draft amending budget, which aims to cover the intervention of the European Union Solidarity Fund for a total of EUR 66,505,850 in commitment and payment appropriations, following two floods in the spring and summer of 2014 in Romania, i.e. EUR 8,495,950, floods in July and August 2014 in Bulgaria, eur 1,983,600, and floods in Bulgaria of EUR 1,983,600, and floods in Bulgaria, EUR 1,983,600. October and November 2014 in Italy - EUR 56,026,300. The purpose of this draft budget is therefore to formally include this budget adjustment in the 2015 budget. There is an urgent need to release, through the European Union Solidarity Fund, financial assistance for those countries hard hit by these natural disasters.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – With today's decision, the European Parliament takes note of the draft arrera act No 4/2015 submitted by the Commission and the Council's position on it. It underlines the need for the urgent release of financial assistance to countries affected by natural disasters through the EUSA, taking into account the solidarity shown by the eusa with the populations of the regions affected by the disaster. The European Parliament recalls that the adoption of a budget amendment No 3/2015 will reduce by EUR 1 435 the contribution from Member States to the EU budget based on gross national income (GNI) and therefore provides ample reparations for their contribution to the financing of a budget amendment 4/2015. It points out that, since they are politically closely linked, the two draft aragings will have to be adopted at the same time. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The ECR view is that the Commission must always look first to reallocate funds from within existing agreed budgets to meet emerging in-year payments, rather than coming to Member States to request additional money. For this principled reason the ECR will vote against.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Solidarity Fund is a mechanism for repairing damage caused by force majeure by force majeure. This is about disasters and accidents. The mechanism may not be very fair, as I have pointed out more than once. The mechanism may benefit richer countries at the expense of us poorer countries. But when we talk about overcoming damage from natural disasters, from accidents affecting the population of entire regions, we need to set an example of solidarity. Therefore, in such situations, first we need to help, and then argue here about methods and approaches.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report, as I remain convinced that the EU must be flexible when there are reasons for compensating countries affected by natural disasters.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, by its decision today, takes note of draft budget amendment No 4/2015 submitted by the Commission and the Council's position on this. It underlines the need for the urgent release of financial assistance to countries affected by natural disasters through the EUSA, taking into account the solidarity shown by the eusa with the populations of the regions affected by the disaster. The European Parliament recalls that the adoption of a budget amendment No 3/2015 will reduce by EUR 1 435 the contribution from Member States to the EU budget based on gross national income (GNI) and therefore provides ample reparations for their contribution to the financing of a budget amendment 4/2015. It points out that, since they are politically closely linked, the two draft aragings will have to be adopted at the same time. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to ensure that the Union can respond quickly, effectively and flexibly to emergencies and to show its solidarity with the people of disaster-affected regions up to a maximum annual amount of EUR 500 million. The adoption of this report represents Parliament's decision to mobilisation, for the first time this year, the European Union Solidarity Fund, due to flooding in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, and in particular concerns the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUF) amounting to EUR 66 505 850 in commitment and payment appropriations in relation to two floods in Romania in the spring and summer of 2014 , flooding in Bulgaria in July and August 2014 and flooding in Italy in October and November 2014.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote because it is in fact a quid pro quo in the European budgetary procedure.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 4/2015 refers to the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) amounting to EUR 66 505 850 to respond to the consequences of the floods in Romania, which occurred in spring and summer 2014: in Bulgaria in July and August 2014 in Italy in October and November 2014. This action implies a budgetary adjustment in the 2015 budget. The surplus accumulated in 2014 and presented in draft amending budget No. 3/2015 allows this adjustment without any problem. The objective of the amending budget is to formally include this budgetary adjustment in the 2015 budget. Of course, we voted in favour of this proposal. All solidarity is needed with the affected populations. The planned support is EUR 4 198 175 (floods in Romania, spring), EUR 4 297 775 (floods in Romania, summer), EUR 1 983 600 (Bulgaria), and EUR 56 026 300 (Italy). An increase in budget article 13 06 01 (EUSF for Member States) is to be expected by EUR 66 505 850, to be budgeted outside the MFF ceilings. In addition, EUR 403.9 million unused in 2014 can be used during 2015, while EUR 50 million has already been mobilised and included in the 2015 budget. 895.1 million are still available for EUSF mobilisations in 2015, which may prove insufficient.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the Council's position on draft amending budget No 4/2015 EU for the financial year 2015, which is annexed to the proposal to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. As this proposal covers the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund of EUR 66 505 850 in commitment and payment appropriations following two floods in Romania, floods in Bulgaria and Italy. It is our duty, through the EUSM, to provide financial assistance to countries affected by natural disasters, given the fact that the EUSRS is to show solidarity with the populations of regions affected by disasters.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of draft amending budget No 4/2015 for the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund amounting to EUR 66 505 850 for the 2014 floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU must be flexible when there are reasons to compensate countries affected by natural disasters, which is why my vote is in favour of mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy .

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Mobilisation of the EU solidarity Funds. In this area, the EU did the right thing and helped Member States when natural disasters occurred. Ensuring that regions which were completely devastated by floods are able to rebuild is an objective that the ECR and I support.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Draft amending budget No 4/2015 relates to the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for an amount of EUR 66 505 850 in commitment and payment appropriations in relation to two floods in Romania in spring and summer 2014, in respect of which applications for aid total EUR 8 495 950, floods in Bulgaria in July/August 2014, in respect of which applications for aid total EUR 1 983 600, and floods in Italy in October/November 2014, in respect of which applications for aid total EUR 56 026 300. I supported the urgent need to release financial assistance through the EUSF to the countries affected by these natural disasters, taking into consideration that the EUSF shows solidarity with the population in the region hit by disasters.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, by its decision today, takes note of draft budget amendment No 4/2015 submitted by the Commission and the Council's position on this. It underlines the need for the urgent release of financial assistance to countries affected by natural disasters through the EUSA, taking into account the solidarity shown by the eusa with the populations of the regions affected by the disaster. The European Parliament recalls that the adoption of a budget amendment No 3/2015 will reduce by EUR 1 435 the contribution from Member States to the EU budget based on gross national income (GNI) and therefore provides ample reparations for their contribution to the financing of a budget amendment 4/2015. It points out that, since they are politically closely linked, the two draft aragings will have to be adopted at the same time. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. The draft amending budget No 4 of 2015 (PPR No 4/2015) concerns the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, for a total amount of EUR 66.5 million in commitment and payment appropriations. It includes four cases: two floods in Romania in the spring and summer of 2014 whose aid applications amount to EUR 8.5 million, one flood in Bulgaria in July and August 2014, whose aid applications amount to EUR 2 million, and flooding in Italy in October and November 2014, whose aid applications total EUR 56 million. For these reasons it was important to support this report.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Gardiazabal report to mobilize the Solidarity Fund to assist Italy, Romania and Bulgaria recover from major floods. My constituency of the West Midlands is all too familiar with such natural disasters and knows well the importance of EU funding in ensuring a quick recovery. Although it is not ideal that the mobilisation of the funds in this instance increases the annual budget for 2015 into the margins, I can give my support given the MFF ceiling is not surpassed.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this amending budget aimed at mobilizing funds in that it is aimed at mitigating the dramatic effects of natural disasters in three European countries, in which it must continue as solidarity support between Member States.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I along with my fellow Labour MEPs voted in favour of this report on the Draft Amending Budget, which budgets for funds needed to finance a request to mobilise the EU solidarity fund in response to flooding in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Council position on draft amending budget No 4/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015 accompanying the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. I believe that countries affected by natural disasters need to be given financial support from the EUSF as soon as possible, given that the EUSF expresses solidarity with the people of the disaster-affected region. Floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy have caused serious damage to the economic industry and infrastructure of these countries, and EU support and assistance is essential for the normalisation of the situation following natural disasters.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it allows the commitment and payment appropriations for the mobilisation of EUR 66.5 million from the Solidarity Fund of the EU to deal with the economic destruction and loss caused by flooding in Romania (spring and summer 2014), Bulgaria (summer 2014) and Italy (autumn 2014). Apart from the mobilisation of EUSF resources, budgetary rectification is an eminently technical issue which, however, has taken on a political side given the criticism that the Socialists have made to the Council's frequent attitude of not fulfilling its commitments to countries in need for the mobilisation of additional resources, taking money from existing programmes. To avoid this, this report has been linked to report No 3/2015 on the 2014 surplus—linking the deadlines of both and calling for the new budgetary needs of the EUSF in 2015 to be met by the surplus contributions for the previous financial year.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the proposal to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund for applications concerning floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy for a total of EUR 66 505 850. This is an example of EU solidarity in action, and it is very positive to see such widespread support for this proposal in the European Parliament. However I would echo the resolution’s regret that there is a general tendency in Council not to honour its commitments to countries which have experienced major disasters and to fulfil the criteria of the EU Solidarity Fund by taking money away from other programmes rather than mobilising additional resources via special instruments. I am glad to see, however, that the Council did not follow this approach for this amending budget.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report proposes a supplementary budget for the EU Solidarity Fund due to the floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. The aid for solidarity itself is indisputable here. However, there are various options for how this aid should be paid for. The approval of a supplementary budget for this is critical in that the financial resources could also be saved in other budgetary areas. On the other hand, the EU Member States have the right to allocate additional funds to aid in solidarity to the three countries mentioned. Because of this situation, I abstained on this point.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this amending budget aimed at mobilizing funds in that it is aimed at mitigating the dramatic effects of natural disasters in three European countries, in which it must continue as solidarity support between Member States.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilisation of solidarity funds for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, funds called for alleviation of the devastation created by natural causes.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Council Position Report on draft budget amendment No 2012. 4/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, annexed to the proposal to activate the European Union Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, as I consider it necessary to assist countries where these natural disasters have caused major damage as soon as possible. The priority at the moment is assistance and solidarity to the affected regions in the countries mentioned and to express sympathy with the local population, so I agree that there should certainly be an acceptance of the draft budget change, in the form adopted by the Commission, and as described in that Report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote for this report on the European mobilisation of floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. Solidarity must be one of the watchwords between European countries and should logically support the action of this European Union, whose current functioning only fuels tensions between peoples. Romania, Bulgaria and Italy suffered severe flooding, for example, resulting in 11 victims in Italy. The economies of these three countries, particularly in agricultural territories, have been hit hard. It was therefore obvious to me to vote for this report and thus to express my sympathy, my support and my solidarity with these three countries.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ While I understand that this is for aid which could be used to help victims, the British public are already more than generous with donating funds to charitable causes when natural disasters occur. I do not believe foreign aid to be in the remit of the EU, so I voted against this proposal.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Eider Gardiazabal Rubial's report on the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. This fund will unlock the sum of 66.5 million euros following the severe floods suffered by these three countries, in order to help repair the damage caused. For this, an amending budget was necessary. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the European Union's draft amending budget No. 4/2015 for the 2015 financial year accompanying the European Union Solidarity Fund's (EUSF) proposal for intervention on behalf of Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. This resolution will enable the mobilization of 66 million euros in commitments and payments to deal with the floods that have taken place in these regions.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The terrible floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy have caused great damage which can have a lasting impact on the economic progress of the affected regions. The Solidarity Fund has been set up for such incidents, so I am voting in favour of the motion.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have given a favourable opinion on draft amending budget No 4/2015 concerning the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) amounting to EUR 66 505 850. This fund, which is also intended to support Romania and Bulgaria, amounts to EUR 8 495 950 and EUR 1 983 600 respectively, and provides eur 56 million for Italy, which saw five northern regions affected by severe floods in the previous year. These are concrete signals that the European Parliament is sending to Member States and to those in difficulty, due to disasters and natural disasters.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. The draft amending budget No. 4 was adopted by the Commission on 15 April 2015. This is the budgetary counterpart of the EUSF's intervention for a total amount of 66.5 million euros. It proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund in the wake of bad weather and floods in Romania, Italy and Bulgaria. As this Solidarity Fund is a special instrument within the meaning of the Multi-Year Financial Framework (MFF), the corresponding appropriations must be budgeted outside the CEILING ceilings. In addition, a substantial amount (403.9 million euros) of the Fund remained unutilized in 2014. I have therefore decided to abstain in this vote.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the report on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund for a total amount of EUR 66.5 million in commitment and payment appropriations in response to the devastation caused by floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy in 2014.  In all three cases, flooding caused significant losses to public and private infrastructure, businesses and private homes. It has also caused great damage to agriculture and the environment. In the difficult situation these countries find themselves in, it is necessary to maintain solidarity at European Union level.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The draft amending budget No 4 of 2015 (DAB 4/2015) concerns the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, totalling EUR 66.5 million in commitment and payment appropriations.  It includes four cases: two floods in Romania in the spring and summer of 2014 whose aid applications amount to EUR 8.5 million, one flood in Bulgaria in July and August 2014, whose aid applications amount to EUR 2 million, and flooding in Italy in October and November 2014, whose aid applications total EUR 56 million. Agreeing with these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it approves the budget amendment to provide significant assistance for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy to deal with the effects of flooding in the spring and summer of 2014. This report approves the provision of financial resources for the mobilisation of more than EUR 66 million of aid more than necessary to alleviate the damage of these natural disasters in these countries and to initiate the necessary reconstruction processes. The report also condemns the Council's uncompromising position in authorizing additional funds for these emergencies created by natural disasters and approves the use of 2014 margins. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The report proposes a supplementary budget for the EU Solidarity Fund due to the floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. The aid for solidarity itself is indisputable here. However, there are various options for how this aid should be paid for. The approval of a supplementary budget for this is critical in that the financial resources could also be saved in other budgetary areas. On the other hand, the EU Member States have the right to allocate additional funds to aid in solidarity to the three countries mentioned. Because of this situation, I abstained on this point.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the event of extraordinary natural disasters, I am in a vi need for solidarity between states and citizens. I agree that European states should help each other, but not with the EU Central Fund, which redistributes money.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. The principle of solidarity is the basis of the EU. The use of solidarity funds will improve the situation in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy after heavy rains. I voted for it.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 4/2015 allows eur 66 505 850 in assistance from the European Union Solidarity Fund to Member States affected by floods in 2014. The European Parliament warned the Council that these legitimate requests from Romania, Bulgaria and Italy could be addressed from the 2014 budget. The AIM of the EUSS is to provide solidarity assistance to EU countries in need so that this assistance is swift and effective.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the adoption report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1/2004. 4/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015 - accompanying the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy - because the adoption of draft amending budget No 1/2004 is not a good thing. 3/2015 will reduce the share of Member States' GNI-based contributions to the Union budget by EUR 1.435 billion.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Two floods in Romania in spring and summer 2014, floods in Bulgaria in July/August 2014, and floods in Italy in October/November 2014 had devastating consequences for the individuals and regions affected. With this release of financial assistance through the EUSF to the countries affected by these natural disasters we are showing solidarity with the population in the region hit by these disasters.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Votes in favour of draft adjusted budget No 4/2015 on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund in favour of Member States affected by the 2014 floods; Italy, Bulgaria and Romania for the total amount of €66,505,850 in commitment and payment appropriations entered in the 2015 budget. Whereas the EU Social Fund was set up in order to provide effective support to a Member State or a country in the process of accession, which is facing damage caused by natural disasters. Financial assistance to these regions affected by major natural disasters is considered to be of fundamental importance.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to support European countries affected by natural disasters. I have chosen to vote in favour of this document, which provides for a financial contribution of EUR 66 505 850 in support of Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, which were hit by severe floods at different times in 2014, as I believe it is important that The Member States do not miss an opportunity to demonstrate that they are faithful to the principle of solidarity.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy in 2014 need an EU response to help affected people. My support for the proposal to change the budget and to be able to contribute sufficient amounts, just over EUR 66 million, so that citizens and administrations can cope with the costs caused by this catastrophe.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This draft has received my approval, as it creates the framework for financial assistance to the affected regions.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Draft Amending Budget which accompanies the proposal for the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. The four natural disasters together amount to EUR 66.5 million. As the Solidarity Fund is a special instrument, the appropriations should be budgeted outside the corresponding MFF ceilings.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The systematic extensions affecting the Union Solidarity Fund show that it is under-provided from the outset even as natural disasters continue to multiply. The Fund is being sought here to provide financial assistance to Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, which experienced major floods in 2014. I am voting for this urgently needed aid for these three countries to enable them to rebuild their infrastructure. I regret, however, that Europe is not more committed to the danger that our modes of production pose to the human ecosystem. Causes should be treated rather than cured. The resurgence of floods is a direct result of productive and chemical agriculture whose dead soils "go to sea", in the words of agronomists Claude and Lydia Bourguignon. Rather than further liberalising agriculture in this direction, the European Union should engage in ecological planning vital to the future of humanity.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft amending budget No 4/2015 concerns the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) amounting to EUR 66 505 850 in commitment and payment appropriations following two floods in Romania in the spring and summer of 2014, totalling aid applications amounting to EUR 8 495 950 for floods in Bulgaria in July/August 2014, totalling aid applications amounting to EUR 1 983 600 and floods in Italy in October/November 2014, totalling aid applications amounting to EUR 56 026 300. I am in favour of approving this aid for the countries affected by these natural disasters, hence my sense of vote.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Romania, Bulgaria and Italy receiving EUR 66.5 million in total for compensation to cover part of the cost of emergency measures taken during the 2014 floods. The aid will now help the three countries to repair damage done to public and private infrastructure, private homes, businesses, agriculture, the environment, and cultural heritage by floods that hit Romania in the spring and summer, Bulgaria in the summer and Italy in the autumn of 2014.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft transfers the amount of the contribution from the EU Solidarity Fund discussed in the next section to alleviate flood damage in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy through the 2015 budget.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft amending budget covers the intervention of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for a total of 66 million euros in commitment and payment credits, following the floods in Romania on two occasions, as well as in Bulgaria and Italy. The Commission proposes to involve the EUSF for the four applications and to amend the 2015 budget by strengthening Article 13 06 01 (EU Solidarity Fund - Member States) due to competition. The French delegation of the ENF abstained.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The draft amending budget No. 4 was adopted by the Commission on 15 April 2015. This is the budgetary counterpart of the EUSF's intervention for a total amount of 66.5 million euros. It proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund in the wake of bad weather and floods in Romania, Italy and Bulgaria. As this Solidarity Fund is a special instrument within the meaning of the Multi-Year Financial Framework (MFF), the corresponding appropriations must be budgeted outside the CEILING ceilings. In addition, a substantial amount (403.9 million euros) of the Fund remained unutilized in 2014.  I have therefore decided to abstain in this vote.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of this draft amending budget, which concerns the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund for people affected by natural disasters. This measure mobilises a total of EUR 66.5 million allocated to the affected populations in the following four cases: two floods in Romania, in spring and summer 2014; a flood in Bulgaria in the summer of 2014 and a flood in Italy in autumn 2014.  8.5 million was allocated to Romania, 2 million to Bulgaria and 56 million to Italy. We note, once again, with great disappointment, the Council's tendency not to honour its commitments to countries that have been affected by major disasters by mobilising additional resources, as provided for in the special instruments, but by choosing instead to take money away from other programmes.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No. 4/2015 concerns the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) amounting to EUR 66 505 850 in commitment and payment appropriations in connection with two floods in Romania in spring and summer 2014 (aid amounting to EUR 8 49 5 950 EUR), the floods in Bulgaria in July and August 2014 (aid amounting to EUR 1 983 600), and the floods in Italy in October and November 2014 (aid amounting to EUR 56 026 300). Given the urgent need to provide financial assistance from the EUSF to countries affected by these natural disasters, I have decided to support this report.

name: n/a
text: in writing. – I have voted for the draft amending budget No 4/2015 that relates to the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in commitment and payment appropriations relating amongst others for two floods in Romania.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to provide solidarity assistance in the event of major natural disasters. In this case, it concerns the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. I voted in favour of the report because I believe that these countries must receive rapid financial assistance to overcome the damage caused by the weather.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which foresees the mobilization of the EUSF for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, following the particularly devastating floods of spring and summer 2014. An additional $66.5 million will be allocated to these Member States to cover part of the necessary expenditure as a result of the extensive damage that has been caused.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft amending budget for floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. Countries affected by natural disasters urgently need to be provided with financial assistance through the European Union Solidarity Fund. That's what the fund is for. The Council must fulfil its obligations to countries that have been hit by a major disaster and which fulfil the conditions for the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. With regard to the proposal to allocate funds to the state of Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, I can only express my admiration for the work done by Mr Rubial, as I am aware of the unease that the floods in my country have caused and I hope that these funds will compensate for all the difficulties that my fellow citizens have had to face. With regard to the situation in Italy and Romania in spring and summer 2014 and in Bulgaria following the floods in July/August 2014, I am in favour of allocating funds in accordance with the procedures laid down in the motion I voted on.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Commission's proposal for a draft amendment to budget No 2012 4 for 2015 includes the activation of the European Union Solidarity Fund of EUR 66 505 850 in commitment appropriations and payment appropriations. Activation refers to two floods in Romania, one in Bulgaria and one in Italy, i.e. the proposal aims to provide financial assistance to Romania, Bulgaria and Italy in response to floods between April and November 2014. I believe that financial assistance is extremely necessary for Member States affected by natural disasters to recover from all types of damages as soon as possible, and I welcome the Commission's proposal. Taking into account that on 15 April 2015 the Commission adopted and submitted to the Council a draft amendment to budget No 15. 4 for the 2015 general budget, the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council on the activation of the EU Solidarity Fund (floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy) and a position on draft amendments to budget No 1000/2016. 4/2015 adopted by the Council on 19 June 2015 and that the European Parliament accepts the Council's position in its proposal for a resolution, I support this Council Position Report and I am pleased that the appropriations will at least partially mitigate the severe consequences that disasters leave on living conditions, the natural environment and the economy.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The draft amending budget No. 4 was adopted by the Commission on 15 April 2015. This is the budgetary counterpart of the EUSF's intervention for a total amount of 66.5 million euros. It proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund after bad weather and floods in Romania, Italy and Bulgaria. This Solidarity Fund is a special instrument within the meaning of the Multi-Year Financial Framework (MFF) and the corresponding appropriations must be budgeted outside the CEILING ceilings. In addition, a substantial amount (403.9 million euros) of the Fund remained unutilized in 2014. I have decided to abstain in this vote.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ As the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to support and financially assist countries affected by natural disasters and taking into account that the European Union Solidarity Fund expresses solidarity with populations from regions affected by disasters, I support the decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund within the general budget of the European Union for the 2015 financial year in order to provide €66 505 850 in commitment appropriations and payment appropriations with two floods occurring in spring and summer 2014. in Romania, for which the total aid applications amount to EUR 8 495 950 and furthermore with the floods in Romania in July and August 2014, for which the total aid applications amount to EUR 1 983 600 and with floods in Italy occurring in October and November 2014 for which the total aid applications amount to EUR 56 026 300.  Member States need to show solidarity with each other when necessary and the Commission must assist them in doing so in order to spend the funds in the most equest and transparent way.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Taking into account that the European Union Solidarity Fund expresses solidarity with the population from regions affected by the disaster, it is essential to provide financial assistance to countries affected by the disaster from the Fund. Therefore, I also voted for the Council position report on draft budget amendments No 1000/2013. 4/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, relating to the activation of the European Union Solidarity Fund of EUR 66 505 850 in commitment appropriations and flood payment appropriations in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy in the second half of 2014.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the floods that hit Romania, Bulgaria and Italy in 2014, I voted in favour of using the Solidarity Fund for these countries to the tune of EUR 66,505,850. I support the use of this fund, which allows us to deal with certain emergencies and offers some flexibility to the European budget.

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund for the benefit of Bulgaria, Romania and Italy and granting aid to these countries to cope with the effects of last year's floods.  Bulgaria is one of the countries that has suffered extremely severely since the floods of the past year. In July and August 2014, heavy rainfall caused significant damage to public and private infrastructures. The disaster has shown that in such cases Member States need assistance quickly. Unfortunately, the procedure for triggering the Solidarity Fund can only be initiated when an application is submitted by the national authorities within 12 weeks of the occurrence of a disaster. I believe that the mechanisms for granting much-needed aid should be simplified and procedures shortened. People can't and don't have to wait more than a year for the money to get to them.  Thank you for your attention!

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text under consideration endorses the Council's position on draft amending budget No 4/2015 concerning the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to respond to major natural disasters in the Member States. The total amount of EUR 66 505 850 is intended to provide assistance to flood-affected populations in regions of Romania, Bulgaria and Italy and, the purpose of this proposal, is to formally include the contribution made to the budgetary adjustment in the 2015 budget. I voted in favour.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Support the draft amending budget No 4/2015, for the purpose of formally including the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) amounting to EUR 66 505 850 and in commitment and payment appropriations following two floods in Romania in the spring and summer of 2014, floods in Bulgaria in July/August 2014 and floods in Italy in October/November 2014 in the 2014 budget.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. In the second half of 2014, huge floods hit Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, causing extensive damage to public and private infrastructure, citizens' homes, agriculture, the environment and cultural heritage. It was in this regard that MEPs voted almost unanimously, 667 in favour and 31 against, to activate the European Solidarity Fund's aid for these three countries. A decision that confirms the Council's approval of aid, the majority of which, 56 million euros out of 66.5 million, will benefit the affected regions of Italy. This is the first decision to mobilise the Fund in 2015, which has a total endowment of 89,000,000 million euros to deal with the natural disasters that are multiplying in all seasons all over Europe. Since its inception in 2002, the EUSF has responded to more than 50 disasters, including floods, forest fires, earthquakes and storms, and provided more than EUR 3.5 billion in financial assistance. A concrete example of European solidarity whose absence is so decried by some.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this correction of the 2015 budget to allow the mobilisation of EUR 66.5 million in commitment and payment appropriations from the European Union Solidarity Fund to be allocated to Romania (EUR 8.5 million), Bulgaria (2 million euros) and Italy (EUR 56 million). These aids will serve to repair some of the flood damage in Romania in the spring of 2014 affecting 30 of the 42 districts, causing damage to public and private infrastructure, households and agriculture worth EUR 167.9 million; flooding in Bulgaria in July and August 2014 where heavy rains caused destruction in public and private infrastructure, business, households and private goods, as well as in the agricultural sector of the northwest region for more than 79 million euros; and floods and landslides in five regions of northwestern Italy (Emilia-Romagna, Liguria, Lombardy, Piedmont and Tuscany) in October and November 2014, which caused severe destruction in public and private infrastructure, business, households and private goods, the agricultural sector and the environment, worth EUR 2.241 million.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft amending budget No 4/2015 is intended for the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, amounting to EUR 66 505 850 in commitment and payment appropriations. This mobilisation follows a number of tragedies in three Member States: two floods in Romania in the spring and summer of 2014 (with aid applications amounting to EUR 8 495 950); floods in Bulgaria in July and August 2014 (with aid applications amounting to EUR 1 983 600); and floods in Italy in October and November 2014 (with aid applications amounting to EUR 56 026 300).  After the Commission's analysis of the four cases, in accordance with the legal criteria applicable in casu, the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund was proposed for each of the four cases relating to Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. Given the solidarity that the EUSF represents and the urgent need to release financial assistance to these three countries affected by natural disasters, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget number 4/2015 presented by the Committee on Budgets concerns the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for an amount of approximately EUR 66.5 million in commitment and payment appropriations in relation to emergency situations. It is through this fund that the EU shows effective solidarity with the populations of regions affected by disasters and natural disasters, not attributable to them. This year the stakes were particularly high for Italy, in fact, out of more than 66 million euros allocated to Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, 56 million will be used to help the Italian regions that in October and November 2014 suffered extensive damage due to floods. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour because it is aid for European citizens affected by natural disasters.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this amending budget aimed at mobilizing funds in that it is aimed at mitigating the dramatic effects of natural disasters in three European countries, in which it must continue as solidarity support between Member States.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it approves the budget amendment to provide significant assistance for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy to deal with the effects of flooding in the spring and summer of 2014. This report approves the provision of financial resources for the mobilisation of more than EUR 66 million of aid more than necessary to alleviate the damage of these natural disasters in these countries and to initiate the necessary reconstruction processes. The report also condemns the Council's uncompromising position in authorizing additional funds for these emergencies created by natural disasters and approves the use of 2014 margins. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 4/2015 to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to the amount of EUR 66 505 850 in response to the natural disasters that hit Romania, Bulgaria and Italy heavily in 2014. Between 9 October and 18 November 2014, heavy rains and consequent floods and landslides caused serious damage to public and private infrastructure, businesses, private homes and businesses in the Emilia-Romagna, Liguria, Lombardy, Piedmont and Tuscany regions and damaged the agricultural sector. I hope that the funds that will be mobilised will provide valuable support for reconstruction, helping our territories to get back on their feet and overcome the consequences of the floods.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ While I understand that this is for aid which could be used to help victims, the British public are already more than generous with donating funds to charitable causes when natural disasters occur. I do not believe foreign aid to be in the remit of the EU, so I voted against this proposal.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the case of the resolution on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 4/2015 EU for 2015, which was annexed to the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, I abstained. I welcome the aid for countries affected by natural disasters, in this case floods, as well as the use of the EUSRS. However, in this proposal, the mobilisation of the EUSG was clearly linked to the motion for a resolution of amending budget No 4/2015.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Related to the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund to mitigate the effects of the floods affecting Romania, Bulgaria and Italy in 2014, the Commission has also prepared draft amending budget No 4 for 2015 to finance the abovementioned use of the Solidarity Fund amounting to EUR 66 505 850.  Flooding has caused significant damage to public and private infrastructure in all three countries, businesses, private residences and the agricultural sector, and has claimed as many as 11 deaths in Italy. In such an emergency, the EU must respond quickly and ensure that the Member States affected receive appropriate assistance. It is therefore essential to mobilise funding through the EU Solidarity Fund in order to show solidarity with the people of the regions affected by the disasters. Since, in this case, the Council proposes to settle its obligations towards the countries concerned by using additional funds and not by withing money on other programmes, I was happy to support this draft amending budget.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the draft amending budget for the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, as reconstruction aid following the floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy in 2014. Of the PACKAGE OF EUR 66.5 million proposed by the Commission and now approved by Parliament, more than EUR 56 million will arrive in Italy, which will be distributed between Piedmont, Liguria, Tuscany, Emilia Romagna and Lombardy.  The appropriation allocated to Italy will serve to cover part of the costs of emergency interventions triggered by floods, to restore basic infrastructure and services, as well as to reimburse the costs of emergency and rescue operations and to meet in part those of reclamation in the disaster regions.  It is therefore an important measure long awaited by citizens and businesses who, in October and November 2014, due to the devastating rains, suffered serious damage from floods, landslides and landslides in the five Affected Italian regions. A rapid transfer of resources to the regional authorities is now desirable in order to launch plans for the reconstruction and security of the territory.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The report proposes a supplementary budget for the EU Solidarity Fund due to the floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. The aid for solidarity itself is indisputable here. However, there are various options for how this aid should be paid for. The approval of a supplementary budget for this is critical in that the financial resources could also be saved in other budgetary areas. On the other hand, the EU Member States have the right to allocate additional funds to aid in solidarity to the three countries mentioned.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Solidarity is manifested in difficult situations in the European Union that are not caused by human action. I therefore support the use of the fund for flood activities in these countries.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒u2012 I support draft budget amendment No. 4/2015: Activation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy taking into account the crisis and serious situation in the countries that have been hit. Members of the European Union have committed to show solidarity and provide financial assistance to countries experiencing natural disasters. I believe that swift assistance from other Member States is essential and of utmost importance.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I support the granting of solidarity aid in cases of major natural disasters or extraordinary regional disaster. The funding was part of the MFF agreement and does not go above the MFF ceiling. Furthermore, these margins exist for unforeseen disasters such as the floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this Draft Report as these are changes to budget No. 4/2015 relating to the launch of the European Union Solidarity Fund of EUR 66 505 850 in payment appropriations and commitments due to floods in Romania in spring and summer 2014, floods in Bulgaria in July/August 2014 and floods in Italy in October/November 2014.  I would like to stress that during the negotiations on the 2015 budget, the Council insisted that payments related to the activation of the EU Solidarity Fund, totalling EUR 126.7 million, be transferred from draft amendments to budget No 126.7 million. 5/2014 and No. 7/2014 in the 2015 budget I must say that I do not agree with the fact that the Council tends to fulfil its obligations to countries in need of assistance and which meet the conditions for activating the EU Solidarity Fund by withholding money from other programmes rather than by activating additional funds as provided for in specific instruments.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal in view of the damage caused by the flooding in those countries.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the report on the Council position on draft amending budget No 4/2015 for the financial year 2015, accompanying the proposal for the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. Romania, Bulgaria and Italy were hit by floods in 2014, which makes them eligible to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund of EUR 66 505 850. I therefore support the release of financial assistance through the EU Solidarity Fund to countries affected by these natural disasters, as draft amending budget No 4/2015 officially includes this budgetary adjustment in the 2015 budget.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU must be flexible when there are reasons to compensate countries affected by natural disasters.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Draft Amending Budget No 4 of 2015 (DAB 4/2015) relates to the mobilisation of the EU’s Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy for a total amount of EUR 66.5 million in commitment and payment appropriations. The EUSF provides relief to countries affected by natural disasters and shows solidarity with the population in regions hit by disasters. Given the surplus in the EU budget, as presented in Draft Amending Budget No 3/2015, seven EUSF cases could have easily been paid for from the 2014 budget. That is particularly important, as the EUSF aims to enable a rapid, efficient and flexible response to emergency situations. However, during the budgetary negotiations for 2015, the Council insisted on shifting the payments related to the mobilisation of the EUSF in Draft Amending budgets No 5/2014 and No 7/2014 to the 2015 budget for a total amount of EUR 126.7 million. While this approach has created a delay in the transfer of the funds, I welcome the link established between DAB 3/2015 and DAB 4/2015, since it will ensure the common adoption of these two dossiers and the mobilisation of the necessary resources to these countries. For this reason I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for this text. I deplore, however, the Council's tendency to honour its commitments to countries in need that qualify for EUSF intervention by soliciting funds from existing programmes rather than mobilising the additional resources provided by the special instruments.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this adjustment of the 2015 budget in order to support a quick response to the emergency situation faced by Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. These countries were hit by disastrous floods in spring and summer 2014. The amount of EUR 66.5 million in total that they will receive will help them repair part of the damage, both in the public and private sector.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The Solidarity Fund provides financial assistance to countries affected by natural disasters or provides assistance for unforeseen regional disasters. The principles and principles through which the reallocation of funds is carried out are clear and I believe that we must adhere to the basic regulations governing assistance from the Fund.
