However, the amendment of the draft budget relating to surplus funds achieved in 2014 seeks to shift it into amending the draft budget relating to the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund and includes payments for two floods in Romania, Bulgaria and flood payments in Italy. Despite the idea of the purpose of the funds to help disaster-affected areas, we must not move away from the requirement that the Union maintain budgetary constraints for which there are clear provisions. Ultimately, we are obliged to advocate for financial discipline that will protect Member States with a view to avoiding unnecessary high costs, especially for those countries that earn little gross national income. That's why I voted abstention.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the draft amending budget. The European Union Solidarity Fund is intended to respond swiftly to the Union in the event of a serious natural disaster affecting one or more of its members. In doing so, the Union shows solidarity with the affected areas. The Solidarity Fund can allo nowalys up to EUR 500 million per year. The report represents Parliament's decision to devote funds to help remove the aftermath of last year's floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy amounting to EUR 66 505 850.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this amending budget aimed at mobilizing funds in that it is aimed at mitigating the dramatic effects of natural disasters in three European countries, in which it must continue as solidarity support between Member States.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ European solidarity is important in times like this, so I support the Solidarity Fund of the European Union being used in relation to the floods in Romania (spring and summer of 2014 ), Bulgaria (summer 2014) and Italy (fall 2014). I wish the citizens affected can recover as soon as possible and that they can recover the routine of daily life.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this amending budget aimed at mobilizing funds in that it is aimed at mitigating the dramatic effects of natural disasters in three European countries, in which it must continue as solidarity support between Member States.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the two technical corrections to the budget voted on in this House.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This Fund aims to provide the EU with the means to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies, as well as to show solidarity with the people of disaster-affected regions such as the floods cited. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it approves the budget amendment to provide significant assistance for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy to deal with the effects of flooding in the spring and summer of 2014. This report approves the provision of financial resources for the mobilisation of more than EUR 66 million of aid more than necessary to alleviate the damage of these natural disasters in these countries and to initiate the necessary reconstruction processes. The report also condemns the Council's uncompromising position in authorizing additional funds for these emergencies created by natural disasters and approves the use of 2014 margins. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft Amending Budget No 4/2015 proposes financial assistance to address the consequences of two floods in Romania, which occurred in spring and summer 2014, and bulgaria in July and August 2014 and in Italy in October and November 2014. This action implies a budgetary adjustment in the 2015 budget.  Its objective is to formally include this budgetary adjustment in the 2015 budget, as the surplus accumulated in 2014 and presented in draft amending budget No 3/2015 allows this adjustment without any problem.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have voted in favour of this draft, as it creates the framework for financial assistance to the regions concerned.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have today approved the request to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund following several floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy during 2014. As far as my country, Italy, is concerned, these are rains, floods and landslides that affected 5 regions: Emilia-Romagna, Liguria, Lombardy, Piedmont and Tuscany, during the last October and November. In February 2015, the Italian authorities requested financial aid from the Solidarity Fund. Particularly in Liguria, where rivers have broken the embankments flooding bridges and roads and causing serious damage to the economic and productive sectors of many cities, including Genoa. A total of 11 people were killed and 3 000 displaced. Liguria has recorded the greatest damage and the total amount allocated to Italy amounts to EUR 56 million; this amount will partly cover the costs of emergency interventions triggered as a result of floods and will help to restore key infrastructure and services, as well as reimburse the costs of emergency and rescue operations and, in part, to meet the costs of clean-up operations in disaster regions.

name: Monica IONESCU (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Once again, the European Union achieves an excellent result, thanks to the allocation of these solidarity funds. We welcome this decision, which will allow communities affected by the bad weather of October-November 2014 to recover and be better equipped against the upcoming manifestations of bad weather. I now hope that all the money will be spent correctly and accounted for at the right time, but I am sure that the work will be carried out correctly and at the right time, as has already happened, for example, with the funds allocated to my region, Emilia Romagna, for the 2012 earthquake.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The financial aid we have agreed on is €4,198,175 (floods in Romania, spring), €4,297,775 (floods in Romania, summer), €1,983 600 (Bulgaria) and €56,026 300 (Italy). An increase in budget article 13 06 01 (EU Solidarity Fund for Member States) is expected to be expected by EUR 66 505 850, to be budgeted outside the ceilings of the Multiannual Financial Framework. In addition, unused €403.9 million in 2014 can be used during 2015, while €50 million has already been mobilised and included in the 2015 budget. €895.1 million is still available for EUSF mobilisations in 2015. We voted for it.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it mobilisations key aid on behalf of Romania, Bulgaria and Italy to deal with the effects of flooding in the spring and summer of 2014. The mobilization of more than EUR 66 million of aid is essential to alleviate the damage of these natural disasters in these countries as well as to initiate the necessary reconstruction processes. The report authorises the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, an absolutely necessary mobilisation in the face of such emergencies created by natural disasters. It is because of the absolute need for the need for the mobilisation of these funds that I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The EU Solidarity Fund was launched in 2002. It is intended to provide effective and flexible response options to support Member States and countries that are candidates for EU membership in the event of natural disasters. In 2014, Romania, Bulgaria and Italy were the victims of floods that assumed the magnitude of regional disasters. Many infrastructures have been damaged. The agricultural sector also suffered. A direct loss of EUR 340 million was incurred in Romania, EUR 79 million in Bulgaria and EUR 2.24 billion in Italy. Especially in difficult times, and especially in the case of crises through no fault of their own, it is important to show solidarity and to support each other. I therefore support the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund by Romania, Bulgaria and Italy.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. While Romania, Bulgaria and Italy have been victims of floods, I think it is important to help these countries. Solidarity with disaster-shaving Member States is one of the Union's natural roles in a vision of a Europe of Nations. Elected from the south-east of France, which regularly experiences heavy floods every year, I naturally express my sympathy and support to the people of these three countries. So I voted for this resolution.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, because I do not believe in the principle of this fund.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this necessary deliberation in view of the floods in this part of the European Union.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. Draft amending budget No 4/2015 concerns the mobilisation of commitments and payment appropriations of EUR 66 505 850 from the EUSF due to the two floods in Romania in spring and summer 2014, due to the july-August 2014 restructuring plan. The floods in Bulgaria and the 2014-November floods have led to the death of the United States of America. floods in Italy.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This report accompanies the European Union Solidarity Fund's proposal to mobilise Romania, Bulgaria and Italy: these three countries, members of the European Union, experienced major floods during 2014. The mobilization of this Solidarity Fund is only possible with the agreement of three-fifths of the Members of the European Parliament. I have therefore supported the granting of these aids, the total amounting to precisely EUR 66,505,850, of which EUR 56,026,300 is for Italy alone.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The Commission proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, which were flooded in the spring and summer of 2014, summer 2014 and autumn 2014, respectively. The total amount of the intervention is 65.5 million euros and is covered by the amending budget 4/2015. I voted in favour of that point.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. In order to assist Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, which have been the victims of flooding in their territories, it is necessary to mobilised the Solidarity Fund for a total of EUR 66 505 850, which is the calculation of the damage suffered. I therefore support draft amending budget No. 4/ 2015 to cover the above amount. That's why I voted for it.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this project is to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for a total of EUR 66.5 million following bad weather and innovations in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy during 2014. The total cost of direct damage is estimated at 172 million euros in Romania, 79.4 million in Bulgaria and finally 2.2 billion euros in Italy. However, none of the events reached the threshold of the "major disaster" (set at 3 billion euros) sufficient to appeal for compensation of 6% of the direct damages and these events were considered "regional disasters" entitled to compensation of up to 2.5% of the direct damage suffered. The amounts not spent by the Fund in 2014 (approximately EUR 409 million) cover the overall budget of EUR 66.5 million requested. I have therefore decided to vote in favour of this aid in order to support these hard-hit territories and populations.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Between October and November 2014 five regions of north-western Italy, Emilia-Romagna, Liguria, Lombardy, Piedmont and Tuscany, were affected by dramatic floods that caused enormous damage and unfortunately 11 victims. The text we are voting on allows eur 56 million from the EU Solidarity Fund to be allocated to these territories, which is why I voted in favour of the Mureșan report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilizing EUR 66.5 million in commitment and payment appropriations from the European Union Solidarity Fund to Romania (EUR 8.5 million), Bulgaria (EUR 2 million) and Italy (EUR 56 million). These aids will serve to repair some of the flood damage in Romania in the spring of 2014 affecting 30 of the 42 districts, causing damage to public and private infrastructure, households and agriculture worth EUR 167.9 million; flooding in Bulgaria in July and August 2014 where heavy rains caused destruction in public and private infrastructure, business, households and private goods, as well as in the agricultural sector of the northwest region for more than 79 million euros; and floods and landslides in five regions of northwestern Italy (Emilia-Romagna, Liguria, Lombardy, Piedmont and Tuscany) in October and November 2014, which caused severe destruction in public and private infrastructure, business, households and private goods, the agricultural sector and the environment, worth EUR 2.241 million.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which proposes the mobilisation of the European Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for romania, Bulgaria and Italy affected by floods. The aim of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the European Union to respond quickly, effectively and flexibly in disaster situations and to show solidarity with the population of disaster-stricken regions. Romania, Bulgaria and Italy have submitted applications for floods in their countries. The applications submitted were in line with the provisions of the EUSF Regulation and the Commission considered it necessary to provide support to these countries. That decision must now be approved by the European Parliament and the Council. Parliament's rapporteur recommends that the Commission's proposal for a decision be approved, which is annexed to this report.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes to use the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSA) on the basis of point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 in connection with the floods in Romania (spring and summer 2014), Bulgaria (summer 2014) and Italy (autumn 2013). The Commission has carried out a thorough examination of all four applications. In all four cases, the Commission proposes to take into account 2.5% of the total direct damage, as no region has reached the threshold for a 'major disaster'. This is the same as previous practice for regional disasters and disasters supported under the 'neighbouring country' provision. The total proposed use is EUR 66 505 850. On the basis of the above, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I also supported this report, which provides around €66 million in aid to three countries, most of which Italy, where the estimated damage amounted to more than €2 billion. Although the damage in the national scale did not exceed the required values in order to be classified as 'major natural disasters', it was certainly a regional disaster of a larger magnitude from a regional point of view. It is now in the countries mentioned that they are also investing more intensively in flood defences, otherwise a similar catastrophe can happen quickly.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of mobilising the Solidarity Fund for the floods that hit Romania (Spring and Summer), Bulgaria (Summer) and Italy (Autumn) in 2014, causing significant damage and casualties. In the Italian regions of Emilia-Romagna, Liguria, Lombardy, Piedmont and Tuscany, these events caused landslides and landslides, damaged private homes, agricultural activities and businesses, and claimed 11 lives. The European Commission proposes to allocate EUR 56 million to these territories. The Solidarity Fund to help support the populations of regions affected by natural disasters is a good example of the europe of solidarity and cohesiveness that we want.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is important for the Eu ropean Union to provide aid to those areas affected by natural disasters and to show solidarity and support for its citizens in difficulty.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the autumn-winter 2014 period, five regions of central and northern Italy (Liguria, Piedmont, Lombardy, Emilia-Romagna and Tuscany) were affected by severe weather phenomena that led to floods, landslides and large landslide areas. The damage to citizens' homes, public and private infrastructure, businesses, agricultural companies and the environmental assets of the affected territories has been very serious, in economic, tourist and, above all, human terms, causing victims and material consequences that are difficult to resolve in the short term. Events must be seen as a single major natural disaster.  The total direct damage, estimated at EUR 2,241 million, must be added to the considerable indirect damage under the criteria in force for regional disasters, since several NUTS 2 regions are affected and the damage caused in the five affected regions represents 1.84% of the weighted regional GDP, thus exceeding the threshold of 1.5%. The European Parliament must therefore mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund immediately, giving sufficient resources to deal with the damage suffered and to enable the areas that have been the subject of the floods to be secured.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Following the floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy in 2014, the European Union decided to mobilise the Solidarity Fund to help these countries to the tune of 66.5 million euros. The cost of the spring 2014 floods in Romania was estimated at 170 million euros, or 0.13% of GNI. Even if this amount is below the Solidarity Fund's mobilization threshold, which has been set at 0.6% of GDP in relative terms or EUR 3 billion in absolute terms, the relative provision of neighbouring countries covered by Article 2 allows these funds to be mobilised. The floods of the summer of 2014 cost Romania, Bulgaria and Italy 172 million euros, 80 million euros and 2.24 billion euros respectively. These amounts are below the required thresholds. However, applications were accepted, as the damage caused by these floods exceeds 1.5% of the GDP of the regions concerned. The Commission has decided to compensate these regions up to 2.5% of the cost of these natural disasters, which does not appear to be excessive. That is why I voted for this proposal.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission proposed to apply 2.5% of the total direct damage in all four cases, as none of them exceeded those thresholds for major natural disasters. This is in line with previous practice in the case of regional natural disasters and disasters accepted in accordance with the principle of 'neighbouring eligible state'. The first mobilisation decision in 2015 was to amend the 2015 budget by increasing the budget from Article 13 06 01 (European Union Solidarity Fund – Member States) by EUR 66 505 850 in both commitment appropriations and payment appropriations, to be entered in the budget outside the MFF ceilings. I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, as these floods have directly damaged public and private infrastructure, housing and agriculture, and financial assistance from the EUSF is vital, given the major natural disasters that have occurred throughout 2014.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of using the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for appropriations affecting Italy for the damage caused by the dramatic floods that affected five regions in autumn 2014, including Liguria. The amount of aid to Italy will be EUR 56 million.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The Solidarity Fund was set up to enable the Union to provide effective assistance to a Member State or a country in the process of joining in the event of a major natural disaster. Bulgaria, Romania and Italy were the victims of major floods during 2014. There was an urgent need to respond to provide appropriate support to the affected areas. Solidarity is one of the pillars on which the European Union has been built. The aim of this report is to make a financial contribution of EUR 66,505,850 divided between the three states. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund, in accordance with point 11 of the Inter-Institutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and sound financial management (floods in Romania , bulgaria and Italy).  With this measure, the first of its kind in 2015, Italy, Romania and Bulgaria will receive a contribution of 66.5 million euros from the European Union for the reconstruction of public and private homes and infrastructure following the severe floods suffered in 2014. The aid is covered by the European Solidarity Fund, set up in November 2002 to help victims of natural disasters in regions in need of financial support.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, because I do not believe in the principle of this fund.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This Report concerns the proposal by the Commission for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund concerning floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. The total proposed mobilisation would require an amendment to the budget 2015 by increasing budget line under the EU Solidarity Fund for Member States by EUR 66 505 850 in both commitment and payment appropriations, to be budgeted outside the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) ceilings. In parallel to the proposal to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund, the Commission has presented a draft amending budget No 4/2015 of 15 April 2015 in order to enter in the 2015 budget the corresponding commitment and payment appropriations. I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund allows the European Union to provide financial support to a Member State, an accession country or a region in the event of major natural disasters. Although it does not have the right rules, modalities and timing, it is still a useful support, which should also show the solidarity of the European Union. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I wanted to vote for the european Parliament and Council's proposal for a decision on the european Union Solidarity Fund's intervention on romania, Bulgaria and Italy, which have been affected by recent floods. These three countries have indeed made requests to this effect, which appear to be legitimate considering that: in April and May 2014, 30 of Romania's 42 constituencies were hit by floods, which resulted in direct damage to public and private infrastructure, private housing and agriculture to an estimated 167.9 million euros; that the country also experienced floods in the summer of 2014; whereas Bulgaria, during the same summer, was hit by floods whose direct damage was estimated by the Bulgarian authorities to the tune of 79.3 million euros; and that Italy itself experienced floods in the autumn of 2014 creating direct damage estimated by the Italian authorities to amount to 2,241 million euros. In view of this distress, it seems to me normal that solidarity between the peoples of Europe should play a role.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The floods that occurred last year in some regions of Romania, Bulgaria and five regions of north-western Italy caused extensive damage to the territories, affecting infrastructure, businesses and homes. Real natural disasters that have also occurred as a result of climate change; A phenomenon on which experts have been sounding the alarm for several years and on which action must be taken to mitigate its effects. I voted in favour of mobilising the Solidarity Fund so that the affected regions can receive the necessary financial resources for post-flood reconstruction. Since its inception in 2002, the Fund has already been used 67 times: a large number of cases, considering that there are often choices of land-use planning that are not environmentally sustainable.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is important that the Commission proposes mobilising the Solidarity Fund to cover countries such as Bulgaria, Romania and Italy that have suffered natural disasters. Romania has submitted two flood applications, Bulgaria has submitted a flood application, and Italy has also applied for floods. The total proposed mobilisation of the EUSE amounts to EUR 66,505,850. The Fund shall not exceed EUR 550 million. Euro.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund following the floods in Romania (spring and summer 2014), Bulgaria (summer 2014) and Italy (autumn 2014). After carrying out an in-depth examination of the aid applications, the Commission proposed the following amounts: EUR 8.5 million for the floods in Romania, EUR 2 million for Bulgaria and EUR 56 million for Italy, where nuts level 2 regions were particularly affected. Total aid granted amounts to EUR 66.5 million.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mobilising this fund is great news for Italy. Although it covers only a small part of the damage incurred, it is oxygen for the public finances of our local administrations, which will thus be able to help citizens who have suffered damage as a result of last autumn's natural disasters. I have followed, within the limits of my mandate, the procedure for this appropriation and I am pleased that, after only a few months, Parliament, with the help of my vote, approved the proposal.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to ensure rapid, effective and flexible aid to the population of a Member State, as well as countries negotiating their membership in the event of a major natural disaster.  This fund complements member states' public funds in emergency situations, including the urgent recovery of infrastructure, temporary accommodation and emergency services to meet the immediate needs of the population, as well as the clean-up of disaster-affected areas.  In 2014, Romania, Bulgaria and Italy were affected by heavy floods that caused heavy damage and damage in their respective countries. Following the disasters, the countries concerned requested assistance from the European Union Solidarity Fund.  I therefore supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 66 505 850 in appropriations for authorisation and payment under the European Union Solidarity Fund with a view to alleviating the pain, suffering and loss of persons affected by these disasters.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Solidarity Fund aims to enable the European Union to respond effectively and efficiently to situations of natural disasters that may occur in one or more of its Member States. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour, considering it necessary to mobilise funds in favour of Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, following the disasters that have affected them.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it mobilisations key aid on behalf of Romania, Bulgaria and Italy to deal with the effects of flooding in the spring and summer of 2014. The mobilization of more than EUR 66 million of aid is essential to alleviate the damage of these natural disasters in these countries as well as to initiate the necessary reconstruction processes. The report authorises the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, an absolutely necessary mobilisation in the face of such emergencies created by natural disasters. It is because of the absolute need for the need for the mobilisation of these funds that I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the amended budget proposal, but more generally I believe in the Solidarity Fund. It is a tool intended to provide a rapid, efficient and flexible response to emergency situations. All too often, however, the Council does not fully honour its commitments and leaves the Member States alone to cope with major disasters and natural disasters. This is an invitation, the umpteenth, to the Council to moderate the excesses of austerity and to change the policy of payments by delivering resources that face emergencies as quickly as possible and, precisely because of their nature, they must be available quickly. On the other hand, we would have at our disposal an instrument which is deprived of its own main function and, in short, unusable or useless.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund (set up to respond to major natural disasters and express European solidarity ) for a total amount of EUR 66.5 million in response to four floods in Italy, Romania and Bulgaria during 2014. In all four cases, there has been a considerable damage to public and private infrastructure, businesses, private homes and assets, the agricultural sector and the environment. As I believe in a Union which is based on unity and compassion I supported this report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in the context of floods in Romania (spring and summer 2014), Bulgaria (summer 2014) and Italy (from autumn 2014) under paragraph 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to help Italy, Romania and Bulgaria affected by natural disasters in 2014. The request for mobilization is to the tune of 66,505,850 euros, in order to compensate for the estimated direct damage. Considering that these requests for assistance meet the fund's mobilisation criteria and that European solidarity is at stake, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Union has a Solidarity Fund that allows individual assistance to certain Member States if needed. In this case, floods hit Italy, Romania and Bulgaria during 2014. This is why more than sixty-six million euros will be released for the benefit of these three countries, in order to compensate for the emergency measures they have taken with a view to reconstruction.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund against Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, countries affected by violent floods last year. In particular, in Italy five regions (Emilia Romagna, Liguria, Lombardy, Piedmont and Tuscany) from the beginning of October 2014 until mid-November of the same year were affected by floods and landslides that caused serious damage to public and private infrastructure, businesses, homes, the agricultural sector and caused 11 victims.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Following the floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, the Commission has received requests for financial assistance from these states under the European Union Solidarity Fund. These countries will receive aid of EUR 66,505,850. With these funds, the affected territories will be able to rebuild their infrastructure more quickly. The Fund also helps to streamline EU spending by reallocating funds originally planned for rural development programmes that have not been used.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for flood-ridding Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. As far as Romania is concerned, 30 of the 42 Romanian constituencies were hit by floods in the spring. In the summer, parts of the South-Vest Oltenia region were plagued by floods and landslides that caused damage to public and private infrastructure, businesses and the agricultural sector, as well as cultural heritage and private homes. Bulgaria, for its part, suffered heavy rainfall in the summer, causing considerable damage to public and private infrastructure, businesses, homes and private property, and the agricultural sector in the Severozapaden region.  Finally, five regions in northwestern Italy, including Tuscany, were hit in the summer by floods and landslides that caused considerable damage to public and private infrastructure, businesses, homes and private property, the agricultural sector and the environment, killing 11 people.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – On the basis of point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013, the Commission proposes to use the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSA) in connection with the floods in Romania (spring and summer 2014), Bulgaria (summer 2014) and Italy (autumn 2013). The Commission carried out a thorough examination of all four applications in accordance with Council Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002 establishing the European Union Solidarity Fund, as amended by Regulation (EU) No 661/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 May 2014, and in particular Articles 3, 4 and 4 the following. In all four cases, the Commission proposes to take into account 2.5% of the total direct damage, as no region has reached the threshold for a 'major disaster'. This is the same as previous practice for regional disasters and disasters supported under the 'neighbouring country' provision. The total proposed use is EUR 66 505 850. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although I have repeatedly highlighted the weaknesses of the methodology by which assistance from the Solidarity Fund is determined, this is a mechanism showing true solidarity between Member States. I can argue quite a lot about why some amounts are allocated to some and for others smaller, but this is the subject of a completely different debate. I use this case to urge everyone to think that there is no insurance against natural disasters. That is why we should not be able to help the affected regions, to help the people living there. It's our duty and it's a sign of true solidarity. The other is small grocery bills, which I don't even want to comment on.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report, as I maintain the view that the EU must be flexible when there are reasons for compensating countries affected by natural disasters.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. In 2002, as a result of severe flooding in Central Europe, the EU decided to set up the Solidarity Fund to intervene in cases of serious natural disasters, the basis of which was laid down in Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002. The priority of mobilizing the Solidarity Fund is to minimize the immediate and direct impact of natural disasters. The reform of the Regulation establishing this Fund with the aim of ensuring rapid and effective mobilisation entered into force on 28 June 2014 ensuring greater effectiveness and speed in the mobilisation of funds, as well as a simplification of the criteria in the aid request. Achieving rapid and effective goals is crucial to minimizing the impact of natural disasters. The speed with which such funds can be available to cover some of the rescue efforts, as well as to initiate the reconstruction and recovery of strategic infrastructure and services, will depend to a large extent on the economic and social recovery of regions affected by natural disasters.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, which accompanies the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Fund for Strategic Investments, amending Regulations No. 1291/2013 and 1316/2013, allows to start the EFSI, consoting the first guarantee tranche that amounts to 1 360 million euros. This sum has been collected by transfers of one entity to different programmes. Programmes that have been cut include the CEF (Connecting Europe Mechanism, 790 million), ITER (490 million), Horizon 2020 (70 million) and other smaller cuts. Although the resolution states that the realm of the Connecting Europe Mechanism and Horizon 2020 involves key programmes for employment and growth and, despite the intention to remedy them in the next annual budgetary procedures, it is hard to see how far this path can be taken. I voted against because the M5S is opposed to the EFSI setting precisely because of the way in which it raises guarantee funds.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, because it expresses solidarity in the event of a natural disaster with European countries.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report proposes mobilising the EUSF to respond to the consequences of the floods in Romania, which occurred in spring and summer 2014, bulgaria in July and August 2014, and in Italy in October and November 2014. This mobilisation requires a specific budgetary procedure and is therefore linked to the preparation and adoption of amending budget No 4/2015. The planned support is EUR 4,198,175 (floods in Romania, spring), EUR 4 297 775 (floods in Romania, summer), EUR 1 983 600 (Bulgaria), and EUR 56 026 300 (Italy). In the face of natural disasters, all solidarity is due to the affected populations. Naturally, we voted in favour of this report. However, it is important to stress the importance of supporting disaster prevention upstream of the activation of this Fund, following up on recommendations from the European Parliament, such as those contained in the Ferreira Report, adopted in September 2010, on a Community approach to the prevention of natural and man-made disasters.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as an act of solidarity to the citizens of Romania, Bulgaria and Italy.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Having still imprinted on the images of the disaster in Liguria I vote in favour of using the EU Solidarity Fund for Italy as well as for Romania and Bulgaria.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The EU must be flexible when there are reasons to compensate countries affected by natural disasters, so my vote is in favour of mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund: Floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it proposes to mobilisation the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to flooding in Romania (spring and summer 2014), Bulgaria (summer 2014) and Italy (autumn 2014) on the basis of paragraph 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013. This is the first mobilisation decision in 2015 and the total amount of the proposed aid, EUR 66.5 million, complies with the provisions on the EU Solidarity Fund's maximum limit, as set out in the Multiannual Financial Framework Regulation of EUR 541.2 million (i.e. EUR 500 million at 2011 prices).  In parallel with this proposal to mobilisation the EU Solidarity Fund, the Commission has submitted a draft amending budget (PPR No 4/2015 of 15 April 2015), with a view to entering in the 2015 budget the corresponding commitment and payment appropriations, as provided for in paragraph 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, we have given concrete help to the people of Europe suffering from terrible natural disasters. Among others, we have also allocated around EUR 56 million to Italy to reconstruct what was destroyed by last autumn's floods in Emilia Romagna, Liguria, Lombardy, Piedmont and Tuscany and to give concrete help to the families affected. This is the Europe we want, close to the weakest and aware that the problems of a Member State are problems of all the Member States, which must be tackled together. We hope that this approach will soon be adopted in many other areas too, first and first of all immigration.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund: floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, as for me European solidarity in the event of disasters is an important element of our coexistence and is important to the people.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this mobilisation of funds because it is aimed at mitigating the dramatic effects of natural disasters in three European countries, in what must continue as solidarity support between Member States.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I and fellow Socialist and Democrat MEPs voted in favour of this report. It was a request to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund in light severe flooding in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. The EU Solidarity Fund provides financial assistance to eligible states affected by major natural disasters.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in accordance with point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management (floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy).  This proposal will help us to show solidarity with the disaster-stricken populations of the regions of Romania, Bulgaria and Italy.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. For the Socialists, the European Union's first reason is the principle of solidarity. I voted in favour of this report to live up to this principle and allow the ESF to mobilize a total of EUR 66.5 million to cope with the economic destruction and loss caused by the floods in Romania (spring and summer 2014), Bulgaria (summer 2014) and Italy (autumn 2014). We have a moral and supportive duty to help each other and help those who are hit by adverse situations. Europe cannot allow accidental circumstances such as these to penalize or jeopardize territorial, economic or social cohesion in any Member State or throughout the EU. That is why we reaffirm our commitment to ensure joint and mutually supported harmonious development.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the proposal to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund for applications concerning floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy for a total of EUR 66 505 850. The purpose of this fund is to provide rapid, efficient and flexible responses to emergency situations and to show solidarity with the population of regions struck by disasters. While the value of damage for all applications was below the ‘major disaster’ threshold, damage was widespread across large regions of the countries affected, with direct damage to public and private infrastructure, private homes, businesses and in agriculture,  and all were eligible under ‘regional disaster’ criteria.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report represents the first time this year that the European Union Solidarity Fund is used. I voted in favour of this report. The floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy have caused enormous damage. The mobilisation of this fund demonstrates the EU’s show of solidarity with the populations affected by these disasters and allocates a significant amount of money to the concerned regions.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report proposes the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund due to the floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. This is a concern in the sense of mutual solidarity between the EU Member States. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this mobilisation of funds because it is aimed at mitigating the dramatic effects of natural disasters in three European countries, in what must continue as solidarity support between Member States.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council on the activation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in accordance with point 11. The Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation on budgetary issues and on good financial governance (floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy) as I believe that the disasters affecting the territories of the three countries have really harmed public and private infrastructure, homes, agriculture and the economy and cultural heritage.  Romania's 30 regions, notably the Oltenia region, were hit by floods in spring and summer 2014. Bulgaria's Severozapaden region, the Italian regions of Emilia-Romagna, Liguria, Lombardia, Piemonte and Toscana in autumn 2014 were also affected at almost the same time. These natural disasters have caused great damage, so I believe that the Solidarity Fund should definitely be activated, and in this case the budget should be amended in order to help damaged regions as soon as possible and make progress as efficiently as possible.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ While I understand that this is for aid, which could be used to help victims, the British public are already more than generous with donating funds to charitable causes when natural disasters occur. I do not believe foreign aid to be in the remit of the EU, so I voted against this proposal.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for the intervention of the European Union Solidarity Fund in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. The use of these funds will enable rapid and effective response to flood emergencies in these areas.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of Mr Muresan's report. The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to enable the Union to respond quickly, effectively and flexibly to emergency situations and to demonstrate its solidarity with the people of disaster-affected regions. The Commission proposes the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund following floods in Romania (spring and summer 2014), Bulgaria (summer 2014) and Italy (autumn 2014), on the basis of point 11 of the Inter-Institutional Agreement of 2 December 2013. A great sign of solidarity for European citizens, and in this case, for the most part to the Italian citizens of Lombardy, Piedmont, Liguria, Tuscany and Emilia Romagna.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this project is to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for a total of 66.5 million euros (in commitment and payment credits) following bad weather and floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy during 2014. These events have caused significant damage to public infrastructure, as well as to the real estate properties of individuals and businesses, and to the agricultural sector. The total cost of direct damage is estimated at 172 million euros in Romania, 79.4 in Bulgaria and finally 2.2 billion euros in Italy. However, none of the events reached the threshold of the "major disaster" (set at 3 billion euros) sufficient to appeal for compensation of 6% of direct damages. Indeed, the aid granted is progressive and increases when the damage is high. The four events were considered "regional disasters" as defined in Article 2, paragraph 3 of the Regulation, entitling them to compensation of up to 2.5% of the direct damages suffered. The amounts not spent by the Fund in 2014 cover the total amount of EUR 66.5 million requested. So I decided to vote in favour of this aid.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it mobilisations key aid on behalf of Romania, Bulgaria and Italy to deal with the effects of flooding in the spring and summer of 2014. The mobilization of more than EUR 66 million of aid is essential to alleviate the damage of these natural disasters in these countries as well as to initiate the necessary reconstruction processes. The report authorises the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, an absolutely necessary mobilisation in the face of such emergencies created by natural disasters. It is because of the absolute need for the need for the mobilisation of these funds that I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. Romania, Bulgaria and Italy have been severely flooded, which is why the Commission has proposed investing EUR 66 505 850 from the European Union Solidarity Fund. Concerned and aware of the personal and economic tragedies that the European citizens of these three countries have suffered, I believe that the Solidarity Fund must respond quickly to this catastrophe and therefore vote in favour of the proposal.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The report proposes the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund due to the floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. This is a concern in the sense of mutual solidarity between the EU Member States. I therefore support this demand.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. The European Union Solidarity Fund was created after a major flood in Central Europe in the summer of 2002 with the aim of assisting Member States in remediation of the effects of large-scale natural disasters. The fund has up to 500m euros a year at its disposal. I support MEP Siegfried Mureşan's report on the activation of the €66.5 million Fund to assist Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. These three Member States have requested assistance due to the severe floods that hit them in spring, summer and autumn 2014.  The Republic of Croatia, namely the eastern part, was also affected by the floods in the spring of 2014. This year, the Solidarity Fund allocated 8.9m euros to help the area, but the money is earmarked for remediation of public infrastructure, but not family homes, which according to official figures have destroyed more than 2,000. More and more, we are victims of natural disasters that cannot be prevented, so we need to discuss and design preventive systems that would reduce any damage.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. In the face of force majeure, we are all the same. Today we help Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, and tomorrow they will help us. I voted for it.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union allocates a maximum of €500 million each year (at 2011 prices) to the EU Solidarity Fund, which is used to deal with emergencies in disaster-affected countries. In 2014, the states of Romania, Bulgaria and Italy were affected by floods that damaged infrastructure, both public and private property. The Commission has examined these requests. Based on the eligibility of these countries' applications, EUR 66 505 850 will be allocated to damage reparations in order to mitigate the effects of flooding.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, in accordance with point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013, between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management because it is complete and documented as regards flood compensation in Romania , Bulgaria and Italy.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this mobilization, which will allow to allocate 66.2 million to Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, which have been victims of severe floods. These funds will enable them to help affected populations and safeguard their infrastructure.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Commission's proposal to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund for the people affected by last year's floods in Bulgaria Romania and Italy. The importance of the European contribution should be stressed, as well as of a timely response to emergency situations in the geographical areas mentioned above.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilizing the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to flooding in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy in 2014. This Fund is one of the most practical examples of the possibilities of working together and joining forces within the EU to respond to citizens when they need it most, such as when they are affected by natural disasters.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This draft has received my approval, as it is essential to compensate the affected regions. In the past, too, I have always supported proposals of this kind.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The systematic extensions affecting the Union Solidarity Fund show that it is under-provided from the outset even as natural disasters continue to multiply. The Fund is being sought here to provide financial assistance to Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, which experienced major floods in 2014. I am voting for this urgently needed aid for these three countries to enable them to rebuild their infrastructure. I regret, however, that Europe is not more committed to the danger that our modes of production pose to the human ecosystem. Causes should be treated rather than cured. The resurgence of floods is a direct result of productive and chemical agriculture whose dead soils "go to sea", in the words of agronomists Claude and Lydia Bourguignon. Rather than further liberalising agriculture in this direction, the European Union should engage in ecological planning vital to the future of humanity.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. While Romania, Bulgaria and Italy are victims of floods, I think it is important to help these countries. In my opinion, one of the roles of the European Union is precisely to help other states when they are suffering a natural disaster such as floods. I voted "for."

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, pursuant to paragraph 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and good financial management. This European Union solidarity fund enables the European Union to respond quickly and efficiently to major emergencies, expressing solidarity with the population of disaster-affected regions.  This mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund follows floods in Romania (spring and summer 2014), Bulgaria (summer 2014) and Italy (autumn 2014).

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Romania, Bulgaria and Italy receiving EUR 66.5 million in total for compensation to cover part of the cost of emergency measures taken during the 2014 floods. The aid will now help the three countries to repair damage done to public and private infrastructure, private homes, businesses, agriculture, the environment and cultural heritage by floods that hit Romania in the spring and summer, Bulgaria in the summer and Italy in the autumn of 2014.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Solidarity Fund aims to show solidarity with the population of disaster regions. Romania and Bulgaria have requested assistance from the Fund to mitigate the damage caused by the 2014 floods and Italy in 2013. The proposal proposes compensation of 2.5% of the total direct damage. I consider the proposal to be fair, so I voted in favour.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to enable the Union to respond rapidly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express its solidarity with the population of the regions affected by disasters. I am voting in favour of mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund following the floods in Romania (spring and summer 2014), Bulgaria (summer 2014) and Italy (autumn 2014), under paragraph 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013. Like the disaster with the Autonomous Region of Madeira on 20 February 2010, I believe that this mobilisation is extremely important for the economic and social recovery of the affected areas.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this project is to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for a total of 66.5 million euros (in commitment and payment credits) following bad weather and floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy during 2014. These events have caused significant damage to public infrastructure, as well as to the real estate properties of individuals and businesses, and to the agricultural sector. The total cost of direct damage is estimated at 172 million euros in Romania, 79.4 in Bulgaria and finally 2.2 billion euros in Italy.  However, none of the events reached the threshold of the "major disaster" (set at 3 billion euros) sufficient to appeal for compensation of 6% of the direct damages. Indeed, the aid granted is progressive and increases when the damage is high.  The four events were considered "regional disasters" as defined in Article 2, paragraph 3 of the Regulation, entitling them to compensation of up to 2.5% of the direct damages suffered. The amounts not spent by the Fund in 2014 cover the total amount of EUR 66.5 million requested. So I decided to vote in favour of this aid.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Labour have supported similar DABs and solidarity fund applications in the past. The mobilisation of EUSF relates to two floods in Romania, one in Bulgaria and one in Italy.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which will enable the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund to the tune of more than 66 million euros to help Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, where floods took place in 2014. The aim is to include the EUR 8.4 million allocated to Romania, the EUR 1.9 million allocated to Bulgaria and the EUR 56 million allocated to Italy in the draft 2015 amending budget.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Murean report on the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund following the floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. During 2014, these three countries suffered major floods, including Romania. These heavy rainfall and landslides have caused considerable damage to public and private infrastructure, businesses, homes and the agricultural sector. The mobilization of this Fund is yet another example of European solidarity among member countries suffering the consequences of unprecedented rainfall and climate change. The urgency was there, the European Union came to the aid of the affected populations and regions.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We strongly support this draft resolution, which has become necessary in order to approve the Commission's proposal to use the European Union Solidarity Fund for people affected by natural disasters. This measure, in line with PBR No 4/2015, mobilises a total of 66.5 million euros, allocated to the affected populations in the following four cases: two floods in Romania, in spring and summer 2014; a flood in Bulgaria in the summer of 2014 and a flood in Italy in autumn 2014.  8.5 million was allocated to Romania, 2 million to Bulgaria and 56 million to Italy. This is the first mobilisation decision of 2015 and the total amount of aid proposed above respects the ceiling for the European Union Solidarity Fund. In particular, I would like to mention the difficult situation in the regions of Emilia-Romagna, Liguria, Lombardy, Piedmont and Tuscany, which have been affected by floods and landslides that have caused serious damage to public and private infrastructure, businesses, private homes and goods and the agricultural sector, as well as causing 11 victims. The total direct damage estimated by the Italian authorities is EUR 2 241 million.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report examines the European Commission's proposal to mobilise the Union Solidarity Fund following floods in Romania (spring and summer 2014), Bulgaria (summer 2014) and Italy (autumn 2014), on the basis of point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013. This is the first decision to mobilise the 2015 Fund. The Fund may allocate up to EUR 895 million for this year. In this particular case, Romania, Bulgaria and Italy will receive EUR 66.5 million from the EU as reconstruction aid. As these appropriations will help the three countries repair the damage to public and private infrastructure, private housing, businesses, agriculture, the environment and cultural heritage caused by the floods, I have decided to support this report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund that takes into consideration two applications made by Romania concerning the floods that took place in Romania.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – In the summer of 2014, a number of European countries fell victim to floods. One of the most affected countries, along with Romania and Italy, was Bulgaria. In my country, they took the lives of dozens of citizens, destroyed basic infrastructure links and left many people without homes. I therefore welcome the allocation of 1.98 million euro to the the EU Solidarity Fund for flood damage in the Mizia region. This financial assistance will no doubt be useful in recovering the damage done to public and private infrastructure, including injured farms. However, I believe that the allocation of these funds is only a temporary solution to the problem. In order to avoid disasters of this type in the future, it is necessary to focus on the need for preventive measures. I am of the opinion that the culture of prevention should be nurtured from school. To this end, we need a clear commitment at institutional level and engagement of public opinion. Preparing a flood risk assessment is essential in order to avoid such tragedies in the future and to be able to protect European citizens and their property.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report and I welcome the votes of the other colleagues who have done so as well. It is very important that the people of the EU, in their time of need and especially when it comes to natural disasters such as floods, see that the Union is active in helping them. The EU Solidarity Fund was created just for such occurrences, and natural disasters in one state are now damaging the economies of all their neighbours, so it is good the EU was and will be able to help these countries.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. In this case, too, I voted in favour of mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund. Financial support in the event of a disaster is essential so that citizens in the affected country can return to their daily lives as quickly as possible.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to provide assistance from the European Union Solidarity Fund to Romania, Bulgaria and Italy in connection with the floods that have hit them. Countries affected by natural disasters must be helped through the European Union Solidarity Fund so that the inhabitants of these regions can quickly return to their earlier rhythm of life.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to the floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, I can only express my solidarity and express my condolences for what has happened. I am in favour of mobilising the Solidarity Fund for these peoples, who are dramatically asking for our support.

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome and welcome the mobilisation of this aid for the sinister in the three countries. The EU must stand in solidarity and come to the aid of The Member States when they suffer from natural disasters.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ At the end of July last year, Bulgaria and Romania were hit by a severe flood that claimed five lives. In November, a similar fate befallen Italy after severe weather when thousands of people lost their homes were evacuated. It is these situations when people are left without their loved ones and homes that require the existence of a particular fund that will react quickly. People need compassion and solidarity in those moments, but primarily material assistance. Therefore, the European Union Solidarity Fund (FSEU) was set up to respond effectively in these unpredictable situations. It was created in reaction to floods in Central Europe in the summer of 2002, since when it was used for 67 disasters including floods, forest fires, earthquakes, storms and droughts. Based on the requests of Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, the aid from the fund calculated on the basis of an estimate of the total damage amounts to EUR 66 505 850. Also, the importance of such a fund is unquestionable because the consequences of natural disasters need to be remedied as soon as possible in order to prevent further suffering of the victims.  Because of all of the above, and further prompted by last year's catastrophic floods in Croatia when the help of this fund helped the inhabitants of Posavina County to rebuild this area of Croatia, I supported this Decision with the desire to normalize the life of the affected inhabitants of Bulgaria, Romania and Italy as soon as possible.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this project is to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for a total of 66.5 million euros (in commitment and payment credits) following bad weather and floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy during 2014. These events caused significant damage to public infrastructure, private and business buildings, and agricultural structures. The total cost of direct damage is estimated at 172 million euros in Romania, 79.4 million euros in Bulgaria and 2.2 billion euros in Italy. However, none of these events exceeded the threshold of the "major disaster" (set at 3 billion euros), enough to appeal for compensation of 6% of the direct damages. Indeed, the aid granted is progressive and increases when the damage is high. The four events were considered "regional disasters" as defined in Article 2, paragraph 3, of the Regulation, entitling them to compensation of up to 2.5% of the direct damages suffered. The amounts not spent by the Fund in 2014 cover the total amount of EUR 66.5 million requested. So I decided to vote in favour of this aid.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ In addition to giving consent to changes to budget No. 4/2015 I support the decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund within the general budget of the European Union for the 2015 financial year to provide €66,505,850 in commitment appropriations and flood payment appropriations in Romania in spring and summer 2014; for which the total aid applications are EUR 8 495 950, july and August 2014 for which the total aid applications are EUR 1 983 600, and the floods in Italy that occurred in October and November 2014, for which the total aid applications amount to EUR 56 026 300.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up precisely to provide support and financial assistance to countries affected by natural disasters. Taking into account that the European Union Solidarity Fund expresses solidarity with the populations from regions affected by disasters, Member States should show mutual solidarity when necessary and the Commission must assist them in doing so in order to spend the funds from this Fund in the most equest and transparent way.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the proposal of the European Parliament and the Council to decide on the activation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. As Romania, Bulgaria and Italy applied to activate the Fund due to floods affected in 2014, the Commission proposed to launch a solidarity fund and assess the damage caused by the disaster. Therefore, the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 proposes the launch of the European Union Solidarity Fund, providing eur 66 505 850 in payment appropriations and commitment appropriations. The aim of this proposal is to show solidarity with the population affected by natural disasters. How important these types of aid are we had the opportunity to see last year in eastern Croatia, which was also affected by severe floods. In these moments, it is very important to react in an effective and flexible way in order to respond in time to the needs of the endangered population. In my view, by taking a decision to activate the Solidarity Fund, the European Parliament has once again confirmed its active role in humanitarian aid.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With my vote in favour, I wanted to strengthen the European Parliament's decision to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund with regard to the floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to enable the Union to respond quickly, effectively and flexibly to emergency situations, in order to show concrete solidarity with the populations of regions affected by natural disasters. I believe that the European Union must be able to deploy its full potential, especially when it is faced with the disastrous consequences of disasters that affect European citizens indiscriminately.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund for flood-affected states, because it is a use of funds in full compliance with the purpose of the Fund, i.e. expressions of solidarity and financial assistance to countries affected by natural disasters.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the floods in Romania (spring and summer 2014), Bulgaria (summer 2014) and Italy (autumn 2014), the European Commission has proposed mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund. I have spoken out in favour of the use of this fund. Of this total, 1.98 million will be used for Bulgaria, 56 million for Italy and 8.5 million for Romania.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution adopts the Council decision on the basis of the Commission's proposal to the European Parliament and the Council which, after an in-depth examination of the requests submitted by Member States Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, proposes mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for a total amount of EUR 66 505 850. Applications were considered eligible under the criteria considered relevant and, in line with the founding principles of the European Union, I voted in favour of the joint ly defined decision of the European Parliament and the Council, which aims to allocate the above-mentioned amount in authorisation and payment appropriations for the peoples affected by the 2014 natural disasters.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was created to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to major natural disasters and to express European solidarity to affected regions in Europe. This proposal aims to mobilise the European Solidarity Fund following floods in Romania (spring and summer 2014), Bulgaria (summer 2014) and Italy (autumn 2014). The EU must be in solidarity with its members suffering from natural disasters and I recognise the urgency of providing financial assistance through the EUSF by agreeing to a financial contribution of EUR 66 505 850.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. We approved the Commission's proposal to provide Bulgaria, Italy and Romania with 66.5 million euros in aid funded by the European Union Solidarity Fund. This financial support will enable them to better cope with the consequences of the catastrophic floods that occurred in 2014, which affected more than 130,000 people. In the context of the economic crisis, the mobilization of these funds is a strong gesture of European solidarity. As laudable as it is, we must not limit ourselves to this reaction. We need to go further in our response to these types of natural disasters. We need to review our flood prevention plans, as well as our actions to mitigate the effects of climate change. The answer lies in integrated disaster management systems, faster and more efficient information sharing, and enhanced management of cross-border crises. The European Union has real added value in coordinating these efforts, it must make it known.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilizing EUR 66.5 million in commitment and payment appropriations from the European Union Solidarity Fund to Romania (EUR 8.5 million), Bulgaria (EUR 2 million) and Italy (EUR 56 million). These aids will serve to repair some of the flood damage in Romania in the spring of 2014 affecting 30 of the 42 districts, causing damage to public and private infrastructure, households and agriculture worth EUR 167.9 million; flooding in Bulgaria in July and August 2014 where heavy rains caused destruction in public and private infrastructure, business, households and private goods, as well as in the agricultural sector of the northwest region for more than 79 million euros; and floods and landslides in five regions of northwestern Italy (Emilia-Romagna, Liguria, Lombardy, Piedmont and Tuscany) in October and November 2014, which caused severe destruction in public and private infrastructure, business, households and private goods, the agricultural sector and the environment, worth EUR 2.241 million.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the draft amending budget 4/2015 on the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. This intervention by the European Union Solidarity Fund, amounting to 66 million euros, concerns 4 cases of flooding in Romania twice, in Bulgaria and Italy.  In Romania, floods in 2014 caused considerable damage to public and private infrastructure, private housing and agriculture. Bulgaria suffered heavy and severe rains between late July and early August 2015. The rains have caused considerable damage to public and private infrastructure, businesses, homes and private property. In Italy, much of the north-west has suffered from recurrent periods of bad weather that have caused considerable damage to public and private infrastructure, businesses, homes and private property.  In order to help these countries affected by violent floods, the 2015 budget had to be amended by strengthening the Solidarity Fund by EUR 66,505,850, and it has been done.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal aims to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund following the floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy in 2014. Regulation No 1311/2013 sets out the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020, which is foreseen to mobilise the EUSF, within an annual ceiling of EUR 541.2 million, in addition to the corresponding headings of the financial framework. In the light of the requests from Romania, Bulgaria and Italy, the calculation of the Fund's aid, on the basis of the estimated total damage caused, totals EUR 66 505 850, and the Commission has proposed mobilising the Fund in the same amount. The Commission also proposes to apply a rate of 2.5 % to total direct losses in all four cases, as none of them reached their major disaster threshold. This mobilisation will entail a rectification of the 2015 budget which should be budgeted outside the ceilings foreseen for the MFF. This amount is in line with the ceiling of EUR 541.2 million applicable to the EUSF and there are no reasons for the adoption of this proposal, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Proposal of the Committee on Budgets on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund following the floods in Romania in spring-summer 2014, in Bulgaria in summer 2014 and in particular in Italy in the autumn of the same year, on the basis of point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013. As already stated, most of the funds allocated will be allocated to Italy (56 million out of 66.5).

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour as it is a question of allocating funds to help European citizens affected by natural disasters.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this mobilisation of funds because it is aimed at mitigating the dramatic effects of natural disasters in three European countries, in what must continue as solidarity support between Member States.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it mobilisations key aid on behalf of Romania, Bulgaria and Italy to deal with the effects of flooding in the spring and summer of 2014. The mobilization of more than EUR 66 million of aid is essential to alleviate the damage of these natural disasters in these countries as well as to initiate the necessary reconstruction processes. The report authorises the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, an absolutely necessary mobilisation in the face of such emergencies created by natural disasters. It is because of the absolute need for the need for the mobilisation of these funds that I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund to the amount of EUR 66 505 850 in connection with the floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy in 2014. The Italian authorities have estimated the total direct damage caused by the natural disaster at EUR 2 241.052 million.
