The five regions of north-western Italy (Emilia-Romagna, Liguria, Lombardy, Piedmont and Tuscany) affected in autumn 2014 by severe floods and landslides will be able to benefit from concrete help to repair the extensive damage suffered.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ While I understand that this is for aid, which could be used to help victims, the British public are already more than generous with donating funds to charitable causes when natural disasters occur. I do not believe foreign aid to be in the remit of the EU, so I voted against this proposal.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund for floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Romania, Bulgaria and Italy were affected by devastating floods in 2014. Solidarity is one of the cornerstones on which the EU is built. Applications by these countries for eu solidarity fund funding were considered eligible. For this reason, I voted in favour of mobilising the Solidarity Fund for the floods in question. In the case of this mobilisation, the criterion of a so-called 'regional disaster', which represents a rate of 2,5 % of the total direct damage caused by flooding, shall apply.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund serves to provide acute assistance to countries affected by natural disasters or other disasters. In 2014, there were widespread spring floods in Romania, in which up to 30 of the 42 Romanian regions were affected. The total amount of damages was quantified at EUR 167,9 million. Romania has also been hit by summer floods this year, causing €171.9 million in damage. The neighbouring country, Bulgaria, was also affected by widespread flooding during the summer floods of 2014, with significant damage to the regions. Autumn floods in 2014 affected five regions in northern Italy, where floods and landslides caused serious damage to public and private infrastructure, businesses, private property, the agricultural sector and the environment, and also claimed 11 lives. Following the request of the three EU states, we have agreed financial assistance from the EU Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy for a total amount of EUR 66.5 million.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond rapidly, effectively and flexibly to emergencies and to show solidarity with the population in disaster-stricken regions. In April and May 2014, many Romanian districts were affected by flooding. Direct damage to public and private infrastructure and in agriculture was estimated at EUR 167.9 million. In addition, the Romanian region of Oltenia in the same year was hit by landslides that damaged the business and agricultural sectors, as well as cultural heritage and private residences. The total direct damage was estimated at EUR 171,9 million. In Bulgaria, heavy rain in 2014 caused significant damage to public and private infrastructure, businesses and private residences. The Bulgarian authorities estimate that the direct damage totalled EUR 79,3 million. Floods and landslides also affected Italy in 2014, causing significant damage to public and private infrastructure, private residences and the agricultural sector, and claimed 11 deaths. The Italian authorities estimate that the direct damage totalled EUR 2 241 million. In an emergency situation, the EU must respond quickly and ensure that the Member States affected receive appropriate assistance. As I support swift action, I voted in favour of the vote.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution on mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund as a reconstruction aid following the floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy in 2014. Of the PACKAGE OF EUR 66.5 million proposed by the Commission and now approved by Parliament, more than EUR 56 million will arrive in Italy, which will be distributed between Piedmont, Liguria, Tuscany, Emilia Romagna and Lombardy. The appropriation allocated to Italy will serve to cover part of the costs of emergency interventions triggered by floods, to restore basic infrastructure and services, as well as to reimburse the costs of emergency and rescue operations and to meet in part those of reclamation in the disaster regions. It is therefore an important measure long awaited by citizens and businesses who, in October and November 2014, due to the devastating rains, suffered serious damage from floods, landslides and landslides in the five Affected Italian regions. A rapid transfer of resources to the regional authorities is now desirable in order to launch plans for the reconstruction and security of the territory.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The report proposes the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund due to the floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. This is a concern in the sense of mutual solidarity between the EU Member States. Accordingly, the German ECR delegation supports this demand.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Solidarity is manifested in difficult situations in the European Union caused by natural disasters. I therefore support the use of the fund for flood activities.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I agree with this Report, according to which the Commission proposes to mobilise funds from the European Solidarity Fund to help the affected areas in Romania (spring and summer 2014), Bulgaria (summer 2014) and Italy (autumn 2014), all based on point 11. Interinstitutional agreement for which a thorough review of all four applications has been carried out in accordance with Council Regulation No 1007/2013. 2012/2002.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I support the granting of solidarity aid in cases of major natural disasters or extraordinary regional disaster. The funding was part of the MFF agreement and does not go above the MFF ceiling. Furthermore, these margins exist for unforeseen disasters such as the floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the draft report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the activation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in accordance with point 11. Interinstitutional agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation on budgetary issues and on good financial management (floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy). Romania - floods in the spring: total direct damages were worth EUR 167.9 million; Romania - summer floods: total direct damage, worth EUR 171.9 million. The cost of basic emergency operations is estimated at EUR 94m from Romanian authorities. Bulgaria - summer floods: Bulgarian authorities estimate total direct damage at EUR 79.3 million. The cost of basic emergency operations is estimated at EUR 69.1 million. Italy - floods in autumn: total direct damage was estimated by italian authorities at €241 million. The Commission proposes to report these disasters at a rate of 2.5 % of total direct damages in all four cases. This is in line with past practice in case of regional disasters and disasters accepted under the provisions of the "neighbouring country".

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Written - I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund: floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. Floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy have caused direct damage to the authorities there of EUR 2 660.1 million. The European Commission proposes a total amount of aid of around €66 million. The floods directly damaged public and private infrastructure, the business and agricultural sectors, the cultural heritage, and in Italy they also claimed 11 deaths. Since all applications meet the conditions for obtaining funding from the EU Solidarity Fund on the basis of the provision on the neighbouring country and on the basis of the criterion on regional natural disasters, I supported my colleague Mureșan's report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU must be flexible when there are reasons to compensate countries affected by natural disasters.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The current report concerns the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for a total amount of EUR 66.5 million EUR in commitment and payment appropriations in response to four cases of flooding in Romania (two cases), Bulgaria and Italy in the course of 2014. In all four cases there has been considerable damage to public and private infrastructure, businesses, private homes and assets, the agricultural sector and the environment. The damage led the Commission to propose applying the rate of 2.5% of total direct damage in all four cases. Given the fact that the EUSF aims to provide a rapid, efficient and flexible response to emergency situations, I welcome the recommendation in the report to approve the Commission proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the Fund to these countries. Taking into account that almost one year has passed since these regions were hit by the floods, it is vital to transfer these funds without further delay. I voted in favour of this report and I hope its adoption will provide the necessary relief to the citizens living in these areas who were affected by the floods.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Solidarity Fund's mobilization text. However, I generally deplore the Council's tendency to honour its commitments to countries in need that qualify for EUSF intervention by soliciting funds from existing programmes rather than mobilising the additional resources provided by the special instruments.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund. Romania, Bulgaria and Italy which suffered from severe floods in spring and summer 2014 applied to mobilise the Fund so that they could receive a financial contribution to cover to some extent the cost of the emergency measures they took during the disaster. I believe that the EU should show solidarity with the citizens of Romania, Bulgaria and Italy and I therefore supported this resolution.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the allocation of around €66 million to Italy, Romania and Bulgaria for the floods that occurred in 2014. The mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund will make it possible to cover the costs for the operations of safety and reconstruction of essential infrastructures and services present in the territories that in October and November last year were affected by flood events, in Italy the regions of Piedmont, Liguria, Lombardy, Tuscany and Emilia Romagna. This is a considerable amount which will have to be made available to local authorities and citizens very quickly. This is practical aid from Europe, but it goes hand in hand with the many preventive instruments for the protection of territories, measures that we call on the Member States to implement in order to prevent a repeat of tragedies such as those that have occurred in recent years.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. When activating the Solidarity Fund, it is necessary to take into account the criteria determining access to the Fund, as well as delivery mechanisms. I fully support the Resolution on the Mobilisation of the Fund in the case of the three Member States, as I consider that the obligations to the countries in need, which have met the conditions for mobilising the funds as provided for in the specific instruments, must be met.  The natural disaster that hit the Republic of Croatia on a large scale was somewhat remediated by the Solidarity Fund, which, of course, greatly helped and facilitated the elimination of the catastrophic consequences of severe floods. I therefore fully sympathise with the afflicted population of the Member States and consider that the amounts envisaged should be paid to Member States, as member states' applications for the allocation of funds are eligible under the regional disaster criteria.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the draft amending budget. The European Union Solidarity Fund is intended to respond swiftly to the Union in the event of a serious natural disaster affecting one or more of its members. In doing so, the Union shows solidarity with the affected areas. The proposal concerns the use of funds resulting from the surplus budget for 2014. Part of this amount will be allocated to help with the aftermath of last year's floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this mobilisation of funds because it is aimed at mitigating the dramatic effects of natural disasters in three European countries, in what must continue as solidarity support between Member States.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 For all four applications, the Commissions of the European Parliament examined in detail the possible use of the aid and its form. In these cases, it is very important that reconstruction is accelerated and that future defences can be prepared. I supported the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this mobilisation of funds because it is aimed at mitigating the dramatic effects of natural disasters in three European countries, in what must continue as solidarity support between Member States.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of ensuring that the resources needed to deal with the effects of flooding in different areas of southern and eastern Europe are mobilized.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Commission proposal to grant EUR 66.5 million in aid to Romania, Bulgaria and Italy to compensate for the costs they incurred for the emergency measures taken during the 2014 floods. This aid comes from the European Solidarity Fund, and will serve to help the three countries repair damage to public and private infrastructure, private homes, businesses, agriculture, the environment and cultural heritage caused by the floods. In detail, EUR 56 million will go to Italy, around 8.5 million to Romania and almost 2 million to Bulgaria.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This Fund aims to provide the EU with the means to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies, as well as to show solidarity with the people of disaster-affected regions such as the floods cited. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it mobilisations key aid on behalf of Romania, Bulgaria and Italy to deal with the effects of flooding in the spring and summer of 2014. The mobilization of more than EUR 66 million of aid is essential to alleviate the damage of these natural disasters in these countries as well as to initiate the necessary reconstruction processes. The report authorises the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, an absolutely necessary mobilisation in the face of such emergencies created by natural disasters. It is because of the absolute need for the need for the mobilisation of these funds that I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft Amending Budget No 4/2015 proposes financial assistance to respond to the consequences of two floods in Romania, which occurred in spring and summer 2014, and bulgaria in July and August 2014 and in Italy in October and November 2014. This action implies a budgetary adjustment in the 2015 budget.  Its objective is to formally include this budgetary adjustment in the 2015 budget, as the surplus accumulated in 2014 and presented in draft amending budget No 3/2015 allows this adjustment without any problem.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This draft would have received my approval, as it is essential to compensate the affected regions. In the past, too, I have always supported proposals of this kind.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in agreement with my group on Parliament's resolution on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 4/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015 for the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for Romania, Bulgaria and Italy.  The EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up in 2002 to support eligible countries affected by major natural or other exceptional regional disasters. The ECR Group supports the principle and objectives of the EU Solidarity Fund.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of mobilising the European Solidarity Fund for floods in Romania, Bulgaria, and Italy. The European Solidarity Fund was created to respond to major natural disasters and to promote unity throughout the Union in times of crisis. In mobilising the EUSF for these three countries, the damage done to public and private infrastructure, private homes, businesses, agriculture, the environment and cultural heritage can be repaired and the clean-up and recovery for the disaster-stricken areas can be sped up. The EUSF is an important took for promoting solidarity amongst the European community, and its aid to disaster-stricken areas since its inception in 2007 until now amounts to nearly € 3.7 billion. Nonetheless, the devastation caused by these floods highlights the need for more investment in programs targeted at flood prevention and climate change mitigation measures in the future.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I welcome the adoption today in the Plenary meeting in Strasbourg of the report on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund to support Romania, Bulgaria and Italy following the 2014 floods.  I voted for this report, which allocates a total of EUR 66 505 850 to the three Member States. 8.5 million euros will be allocated to Romania. Part of this money will cover the costs of emergency operations and some are allocated to support the reconstruction of road or energy infrastructure affected by floods, but also to strengthen prevention.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The financial aid we have agreed on is €4,198,175 (floods in Romania, spring), €4,297,775 (floods in Romania, summer), €1,983 600 (Bulgaria) and €56,026 300 (Italy). An increase in budget article 13 06 01 (EU Solidarity Fund for Member States) is expected to be expected by EUR 66 505 850, to be budgeted outside the ceilings of the Multiannual Financial Framework. In addition, unused amounts of €403.9 million in 2014 can be used during 2015, while €50 million has already been mobilised and included in the 2015 budget. €895.1 million is still available for EUSF mobilisations in 2015. We voted for it.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I am very happy to support the objective of providing a single ticketing service across Europe. We are aiming to simplify travel across Europe when we operate in a single market. Therefore passengers should be able to purchase and to plan EU-wide travel with digital ticketing in the future. One way is to advance one ticket or travel card for all modes of transport across the EU. Currently, when we think about it, passengers face a very complicated procedure, purchasing bus or train tickets. However, multimodal integrated ticketing could at least simplify the system and make ticketing much more efficient. It opens up the opportunity, of course, for a much more competitive transport system. A single user-friendly European travel card could be topped up via digital payments, for example, and used to plan a variety of journeys. It would create the opportunity for transport to offer better deals for consumers and tourists.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, the establishment and implementation of multimodal integrated systems must be one of our top priorities in the transport sector, as in addition to further facilitating passenger movement, it also opens up a great scope for raising the quality of service, lowering prices and growing the whole sector. However, I cannot agree with somewhat unrealistic objectives, such as the one on the supply of all forms of transport in public local transport with intelligent real-time vehicle positioning information systems by 2020 and the tendency to make such a standard a prescribed requirement in tenders.  I believe that the potential imposition of such standards would mean huge costs for smaller carriers and that a large number of them would be put out of business in this way, which is unacceptable.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, yet again I find myself in this Chamber speaking against more daft motions, legislations and reports. This report calls for the whole of the EU to have the same integrated public transport ticketing system. The people of the United Kingdom do not want any more of their information to be stored by the Commission in an EU superstate database. The people of the United Kingdom do not want to have to change something that is not broken. Our ticketing system on public transport is fine as it is. If we want to change it, it is up to our own country, not the EU. The public sector back home in the UK is facing huge cuts and has been for a while. We cannot afford to rip up and change all of our systems just to suit a few in this place. It is entirely unfeasible for the EU jobsworths to believe that one of my elderly residents in a rural village of Shropshire should have to change the way she uses the bus just to get to the shops. If it is not broken, do not fix it. That is why I voted against.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent I voted in favour of Mr Koch's report because I believe that the introduction of an integrated ticketing system is an important step towards the creation of a common transport system throughout the European Union. This is particularly important for those countries that are weakly connected to other countries of the European Union. The use of innovative technologies will make it possible to make public transport more efficient, cleaner and enable the regions of the European Union to be developed. Consequently, colleagues, we need to speed up this integration process and the European Parliament must do everything to promote it, and this report is another step in this direction. Thank you!

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – (inaudible) ... all the time about diversity – that our Parliament is to defend diversity. But every time there is a vote, we are voting to unify everything. You are not for diversity but for unification. This time it is ‘Ein Reich, Ein Volk, Ein Ticket!’.

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D).
text: – Madam President, as a London MEP and a British MEP, let me also add my thoughts in relation to the terrible tragedy that happened 10 years ago, and also on how the communities in London pulled together, including the transport workers. I wanted in particular to say, in relation to ticketing, how much I welcome the report on ticketing and its recommendations. I was pleased to vote for it and, in particular, the fact that we underlined the importance of internet access at stations and interchanges and on the move, and how important that is for the citizens of Europe to be able to travel around. This is a very good example of how we work together to create a genuine single market for the benefit of everyone.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a commitment to a fundamental improvement in the quality and accessibility of public transport systems in the European Union. The creation of integrated systems to enable multimodality in public transport should be a priority to improve the interconnection of these transport services, especially for cross-border ones. The report also clearly bets on transparency in transport information as well as ensuring the rights of users of this type of transport. By betting on improving public transport in Europe, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. So far, it is sometimes difficult to get tickets for cross-border travel, especially if you want to use different means of transport, such as train and bus or ferry. In the digital age, we should be able to create a more integrated ticket.  Better ticketing systems require easily accessible and reliable timetable information, which is why this non-binding resolution calls on transport and travel planning service providers to step up existing cooperation, e.B.B. by providing multimodal, cross-border travel planning services. Member States should establish updated national timetable and fare information systems by 2020 at the latest, on the basis of open interfaces, linking the travel data of regional and local national timetables for public transport to be carried by private and public undertakings. However, if no significant progress is made by 2020 in the creation of integrated, interoperable, multimodal, cross-border ticketing systems, the Commission should establish minimum rules and a timetable. By 2024 at the latest, these will be cross-border and made accessible to transport companies, travel planning service providers and consumers. I welcome this resolution because easy and convenient ticket ingession through integrated ticketing systems makes public transport more attractive to more passengers.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The introduction of a multi-modal ticketing system in Europe would be a new step in the federalisation of the Union. The protection of personal data remains very unclear and no real mechanism is provided. The risk of establishing a monopoly situation is high, which would automatically lead to an increase in costs for users. Being committed to the defence of the sovereignty of States and to the Europe of Nations, I strongly oppose any attempt to federalize the Union. As the defence of users is also one of my priorities, I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Multimodal integrated ticketing will be of minimal benefit to the UK for geographical reasons.  However, we will share the cost of implementation.  It is clearly therefore not in the interests of my constituents, so I voted against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, because this decision is ultimately aimed at offering travellers a multimodal and cross-border solution, seamlessly, door-to-door, thus promoting access to quality public transport for all.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to make it possible to purchase a single ticket for all modes of transport. EU countries and the EC are encouraged to improve the exchange of timetable information between individual modes of transport (air, rail, water and road), allowing for the introduction of an integrated ticketing system and allowing a person to travel door-to-door with only one ticket. The long-term objective of integrated ticketing is to provide comprehensive information across the EU on offers for travel by public and private companies by air, rail, water and road, while at the same time enabling travellers to make smooth multi-modal and cross-border door-to-door journeys smooth. Travellers should be able to choose, book and pay online, on the basis of detailed information, regardless of how many different modes of transport they will use during that journey. However, such detailed information cannot yet be obtained at this time. Thus, pending the introduction of an integrated sales of tickets valid for all modes of transport used in a single journey, it is first necessary to ensure non-discriminatory and equal access to comprehensive information. Furthermore, the introduction of an integrated ticketing system involves high costs and technical barriers and should therefore not make it more expensive for certain modes of transport to make this mode of transport unattractive to users.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Clearly, this project to create an integrated multimodal ticketing system has many advantages, especially for those of our fellow citizens who travel regularly across our old continent. This proposal is even more enticing because it relies on Galileo, a European geolocation system, a competitor to the US GPS.  However, the undeniable advantages of this project are offset by major drawbacks: since mobility is facilitated, there is a risk that this will result in a decrease in controls. At a time when the Union is experiencing unprecedented immigration and a high risk of terrorist attacks, facilitating mobility and reducing controls does not seem to me to be a good solution; Ticket prices may rise sharply to pay for the system (except in the case of cost outsourcing); there is a right to fear a monopoly situation which would also lead to increased costs (the report leaves it to the Commission to fight monopolies...); the issue of personal data protection is too vague. That is why my colleagues and I finally opted for a vote against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. There are great challenges facing transport policy in Europe. Issues of sustainability, profitability, energy efficiency and environmental impacts are added to traffic congestion issues, such as traffic congestion and other traffic problems. The provision of information, planning and ticketing services for multi-modal travel throughout the EU can go a long way towards solving these difficulties, as these services facilitate the mobility and movement of EU citizens, help to promote the transition to public transport or contribute to better integration of modes of transport and more efficient use of existing infrastructure. I voted in favour of this resolution, which stresses the need for initiatives to promote these ticketing and planning services.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. The aspiration of all Europeans is to have a European meter where all modes of transport are interconnected. Creating a true unique transport space is a challenge and challenge that is full of opportunities for SMEs, innovation and quality job creation. It is the only guarantee of sustainable, efficient and cost-effective European transport. An essential element in this system to which we aspire is the single ticket that allows and promotes the mobility of all citizens in a multimodal way. To achieve this objective it will be necessary to have the local and regional administrations and in this sense the Basque Country has embarked on this path with a pilot project that will allow to move throughout the territory in a multimodal way with a single ticket.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This project to create an integrated multimodal ticketing system is an essential tool for achieving the single European transport area as well as the European single market promoted by the Union. The built-in ticket would allow you to make the trip with a single ticket and choose the optimal solution that is useful to the user.  The objectives set out in this report range from equipping all modes of transport for intelligent transmission systems by 2023 to establishing a single national information system to connect regional and local timetables, in order to promote greater use of public transport and promote the environment.   Although there are positive points in order to promote mobility and reduce constraints for users such as the use of the Galileo system, we cannot support this report because our differences are too great. Indeed, the facilitation of mobility may lead to risks due to the reduction of controls, but it is also to be expected an increase in tariffs to implement this system. I have therefore spoken out against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Koch report is acceptable and balanced. I believe that a European system aimed at removing the obstacles that currently exist in the public transport sector would encourage our citizens to become more mobile and make it easier to use public transport to travel throughout Europe, for these reasons I voted in favour of this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which aims to promote the creation of integrated tickets in different transnational modes of transport and to put an end to the added difficulties that users encounter when trying to book such a trip.  The report further reflects the Commission's complaint of a Charter of passenger rights of all modes of transport before the end of 2017, including a section on multimodal travel with clear and transparent protection of passenger rights in the multimodal context that takes into account the specificities of each mode of transport and an integrated multimodal ticketing. And in view of the demographic change facing Europe, it stresses the need to ensure accessibility to means of transport, in particular vulnerable people, asking that much more account be made of the needs of people with disabilities or reduced mobility, as well as the special needs of the elderly.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which proposes the creation of an integrated multimodal ticketing system in Europe. The aim of developing such a system is to provide comprehensive information throughout the European Union on offers of travel by public and private companies by air, rail, water and road, while at the same time enabling travellers to make smooth multi-modal and cross-border door-to-door journeys smooth. Travellers should be able to choose, book and pay online, on the basis of detailed information, regardless of how many different modes of transport they will use during that journey. However, such detailed information cannot yet be obtained at this time. Thus, pending the introduction of an integrated sales of tickets valid for all modes of transport used in a single journey, it is first necessary to ensure non-discriminatory and equal access to comprehensive information. Furthermore, the introduction of an integrated ticketing system involves high costs and technical barriers and should therefore not make it more expensive for certain modes of transport to make this mode of transport unattractive to users. Sustainability, economy, energy efficiency and environmental sustainability must therefore be ensured, and transport congestion issues such as congestion and other transport problems need to be addressed on the other.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 European transport policy faces a number of challenges. On the one hand, there is the issue of sustainability, economy, energy efficiency and environmental protection, and on the other hand, the question of what solutions can be found to the congested transport network, such as congestion and other transport problems, must also be addressed. A significant part of these issues is answered by multimodal travel information, route planning and ticketing services at EU level. There is still a long way to go for interoperable, compatible and continuous real-time information services at European level, but the development of the Internet and smartphones makes it possible and absolutely necessary to implement them. I welcome the commission's setting out, in the framework of a delegated act, the conditions for ensuring access to, exchange and further development of real-time information services at EU level. This is an appropriate step in the right direction, but further steps need to be taken to enable passengers in Europe to choose the most sustainable, fastest and cheapest door-to-door multimodal transport, to book and pay for tickets, and to find out about possible disruptions before and during travel and to make suggestions for alternative routes.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported this report, which actively promotes one of the European Union's most demanding projects at the moment, namely the introduction of a single ticket. European consumers could thus plan to travel within Europe through a single system of collection of information on transport, regardless of which means of transport they would travel by, and it would also be possible to combine journeys via a single ticket. It is an excellent project which will increase competition between providers and reduce transport prices, but it is extremely technically demanding, as information support must be provided.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this Report on the implementation of multimodal integrated travel and airfare issuance systems in Europe. The report calls on member states to share information on timetables and develop an intermodal service account, and service providers need to work even more closely together to provide a multimodal, cross-border travel planner.  As regards access to information before and during the trip, more attention should of course be paid to the needs of the elderly and people with disabilities.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to support this resolution with my vote because I believe that the introduction of integrated multimodal tickets valid for the whole of Europe would represent a huge innovation that would bring immense benefits both to passengers and to the economy.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 European transport policy faces numerous challenges. In addition to questions about sustainability, economic viability, energy efficiency and environmental sustainability, questions are raised about how to respond to traffic congestion, traffic jams and other traffic problems. Providing multimodal information, travel planning and ticketing services throughout the EU is an important part of the answer to all these questions. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the issuance of multimodal integrated tickets in Europe, because the provision, at EU level, of multimodal information, travel planning and ticketing services offers European businesses, in particular SMEs and start-ups, innovation opportunities and, therefore, a major contribution to the achievement of a globally competitive European single market and to the completion of the single European transport area.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. I more than agree with the report, which highlights the importance of information services, planning and ticketing of multimodal travel at Union level, in particular: integrated ticketing, measures to remove current obstacles, and the role of real-time information on local public transport.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Single Market provides for the freedom of movement of goods and people in all EU Member States. As such, transport policies in Europe are fundamental issues. There is a need to increase the viability, profitability and energy efficiency of our transport. This report proposes the establishment of an integrated multimodal ticketing system in Europe. This system will provide full EU-whole access to transport information across the EU. It will greatly facilitate access to transport for European travellers. It will also lay the foundations for a single European transport area. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the issue of integrated multimodal tickets in Europe. With this resolution, Parliament has highlighted the benefits that users would have if it were possible to buy a single ticket for a 'multimodal journey', using different modes of transport. The advantage of being able to use integrated ticketing systems would also attract more passengers to collective transport, increasing the use of public transport.  At present, it is too difficult to obtain tickets for cross-border travel, particularly when these include different modes of transport, such as trains and buses. In the modern online society it is therefore necessary to be able to issue more integrated tickets to facilitate the lives of travelers. Providers of transport services and route planning services should therefore further develop existing synergies, for example by providing multimodal and cross-border travel route planning services, while the Commission should work to put in place the necessary measures to support and facilitate such efforts.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this Report is to promote various modes of information provision on diverse transport methods using innovative forms of communication. The report is seeking to promote a shift towards the use of public transport, including options such as bike hire, park-and-ride and car sharing. The report included a number of important provisions such as fair, inclusive and equal access to free or low-cost online services for all travellers. Furthermore, it sought to ensure that clear and transparent protections of passengers’ rights were applicable for all transport modes. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of the Report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Multimodal integrated ticketing will be of minimal benefit to the UK for geographical reasons. However, we will share the cost of implementation. It is clearly therefore not in the interests of my constituents, so I voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I support the idea for a multimodal integrated ticketing system in the EU as it will benefit EU citizens across the board by simplifying our mode of transport and making ticketing more efficient and transparent. This I believe is a fair and better deal for EU citizens and tourists alike.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the efforts already made, Objective 22 of the 2011 White Paper, which aims to ensure smooth door-to-door multimodal travel using intelligent, multimodal and interoperable systems, for time search, information, online booking and ticket sales, has not yet been achieved. Mr Dieter-Lebrecht Koch's report therefore aims to implement an integrated multimodal system for transport in Europe by improving the information, planning and distribution services of multimodal tickets. By receiving comprehensive information, the traveler should be able to choose a customized travel solution that represents the most sustainable, fast or cost-effective alternative with a single ticket. In the light of the above, I voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I objected to this report, which is part of the logic of a single European transport area, thus the single market and the strengthening of integration. The objectives of a multimodal ticketing system are in the direction of a uniformity of transport services with an increase in the importance of cross-border services. While some of the possible advantages of such a system seem interesting - such as facilitating mobility in the European territory or allowing users to choose the optimal solution for their journey - many points are criticised in this project. In addition to the single market being placed in the globalist ideology at the expense of citizens, the facilitation of mobility risks leading to a reduction in controls, even though the Union is currently experiencing uncontrolled immigration which poses serious problems in terms of security and social. Moreover, the introduction of such a system may result in a cost on ticket prices which will weigh heavily on citizens. Finally, on the issue of the protection of personal data, the report remains very vague and this lack of transparency poses a risk to the privacy of citizens.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the provision of an integrated ticketing system for multimodal travel in Europe effectively facilitates the mobility and movement of EU citizens and visitors from third countries and consequently the exercise of their fundamental freedoms, while at the same time strengthening tourism and thus the economy. They shall also facilitate the provision of information which takes into account travellers with disabilities or limited mobility . With this in view of this, we support the resolution positively.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal on the issue of integrated multimodal tickets in Europe. The aim is to provide comprehensive information at Union level on travel offers from public and private companies operating in the air, rail, sea and road transport sectors, thus enabling travellers to benefit from a multimodal, cross-border and seamless travel solution. By receiving comprehensive information, the traveller should be able to choose, book and pay online for a personalized travel solution that represents the most sustainable, fast or cost-effective alternative and to get on the road with only one ticket, regardless of the number of modes of transport used during the journey.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that creating an integrated and multimodal ticket system in Europe is an important objective to be achieved in order to enable citizens to move more easily by accessing more accurate and effective travel information.  Thanks to the single market and the free movement of persons, EU citizens and visitors from third countries are increasingly tackling cross-border travel using different means of transport. Unfortunately, accessible information is often linked to commercial agreements between different private companies and is often limited at regional or local level.  The Union's institutions therefore have a duty to encourage private companies to coordinate more efficiently, so as to facilitate travellers' journeys and at the same time increase tourism and thus economic growth. Achieving this objective will also make it possible to combat traffic problems, such as congestion and pollution, by promoting the use of public transport. Therefore, I believe that the possibility of travelling using an integrated multimodal ticket is the first step towards improving passenger conditions which will have positive effects on the economy, tourism and the environment.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The mobility of European citizens is an essential requirement for the exercise of their fundamental freedoms by representing cross-border multimodal travel planning services and long-distance travel ticket ing is an important challenge for the transport sector favouring consumers, the economy in general, the environment and the tourism sector. I therefore support the Dieter-Lebrecht Koch Report by considering that it addresses, in a coordinated and moderate manner, the creation of integrated tickets, measures to remove existing barriers, underlining the crucial importance of social mobility, but always taking into account the possibility of choosing, on the basis of complete information, the user's journey taking into account, on the other hand, the high costs of introducing an integrated ticket which should not lead to a significant increase in ticket prices , discouraging the use of public transport. I stress the importance of this interoperability of multimodal travel plans with Information Technology systems, and stakeholders should develop joint solutions to this end.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the introduction of multimodal ticketing systems because this is the right way to enable travel and mobility in Europe to be efficient and sustainable from door to door. As a "border child", I have long been annoyed that travelling across the border by public transport is difficult to understand, is not transparent and very expensive. Thanks to this initiative, european citizens will also be able to draw on a full repertoire of travel options, regardless of which and how many different modes of transport they choose.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome Mr McDerman's report. Koch defined a number of essential points to improve the integration of services between the different modes of transport. Unfortunately, despite the fact that a few years have passed, Objective 22 of the 2011 White Paper has not yet been achieved, which called for smooth multimodal travel from door to door using intelligent systems aimed at easily searching for timetables, information and booking online. To date, given the lack of efficiency of some means of transport, citizens continue to prefer individual transport. To overcome this problem, citizens should be given the opportunity to obtain comprehensive, accurate and neutral information on both timetables and the availability of multimodal and cross-border transport links, within the framework of facilitated travel, while also offering high standards of comfort, booking and ticketing in electronic form. Another crucial point that needs to be improved is unindered equal access for all, people with disabilities or reduced mobility, the elderly and vulnerable people. All barriers in transport, but also economic and social barriers, will therefore have to be removed, defining prices and payment methods for every need.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The idea put forward in this report seems to be a good one. The fact that we are trying to promote a shift towards the use of public transport is positive as it reflects an increased awareness of our environment. This type of ticketing would mean that all Europeans would avail of a wider selection of mobility options in an easier manner. Real-time information would obviously have to cope with any disruptions in the service and the idea of being able to make a journey using a single ticket is certainly enticing. The first thing that must be done is obviously to create a national timetable for all transport modes as in this manner we will be able to establish cross-border networking. This is certainly a positive thing and with the right research and cooperation from all members, it can certainly be a success.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a commitment to a fundamental improvement in the quality and accessibility of public transport systems in the European Union. The creation of integrated systems to enable multimodality in public transport should be a priority to improve the interconnection of these transport services, especially for cross-border ones. The report also clearly bets on transparency in transport information as well as ensuring the rights of users of this type of transport. By betting on improving public transport in Europe, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It was agreed that service providers should build on existing synergies and cooperate more closely on providing multimodal, cross-border journey planners. Member states also called on the Commission to support and facilitate the efforts being made to develop intermodal ticketing. If no significant progress is made to develop intermodal ticketing by 2020, the report will call for legislative action. I voted in favour of this report because while this system might bring about some one time pressures on operators and authorities I am sure it will have a positive long term effect for EU citizens.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support efforts to achieve a fair and complete system of information and travel planning so that travellers can have access to that information on the websites of the services concerned. However, I believe that certain regions or countries are not adequately covered on existing portals in terms of options for different modes and possibilities of transport, which makes cross-border travel more difficult. The available information should enable EU citizens to choose the most sustainable, cheap and fast connection, without prejudice to the commercial interests of operators, and support the position of the rapporteur, who states that it is the Commission's task to identify the appropriate means to do so and to ensure that such access to information does not lead to a dominant position of a supplier, and , therefore, to the emergence of a monopoly which would significantly undermine the competitiveness of other market players.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report proposes the creation of an integrated multi-modal ticketing system within the European Union. Such a system aims to facilitate and encourage multi-modal travel for European citizens and will aim to address issues of sustainability, economic viability, energy efficiency and environmental awareness in transport. Aware of the need to offer, in the long term and despite the technical and material difficulties of such a project, to individuals throughout the Union the possibility of continuous travel through multimodal, cross-border and innovative solutions, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The Commission has made an ambitious proposal to eventually create an integrated ticket office for travelling throughout the Union and through several modes of transport. European citizens would have a single ticket and an electronic booking system. This implies that the offers of private and public operators in the 28 Member States are accessible to all on an online platform. Such a prospect, in addition to allowing the flow of traffic, would be a great step forward for the freedom of movement of people. With this text, we call on the Commission to make efforts in this direction, and set up an appointment in 2020 to assess the progress made.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report because it makes it easier to travel through Europe. Today, an overarching system for multimodal ticketing is lacking. With one unique ticket, drawn up via an interactive website with up-to-date travel information, travel will be smoother. The travel sector is being asked to take concrete measures before imposing European regulations.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report by the European Parliament stems from the need to be able to travel with a single ticket that allows the use of different means of transport for a so-called door-to-door journey. In 2011, in its White Paper on transport, the European Commission expressed the need to create a single travel document covering all modes of long-distance to short-distance transport. Despite the priorities that had been set, we are still a long way from achieving this project to date. That is why I voted in favour of this European Parliament proposal, which aims to promote a single transport document. To achieve this, the Commission will need to come forward with a proposal calling on providers to make all necessary information accessible on a fair and supportive basis and to create a platform at European level to facilitate cooperation between stakeholders.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The introduction of a single ticketing system for transport in Europe is a concrete and useful step forward for European citizens travelling through several EU member countries for both professional and personal reasons. The European Parliament wants European operators to develop a single integrated ticket for travellers using multiple modes of transport in different countries. This means sharing timetable information between different operators.  We will closely monitor the progress made towards the concrete implementation of this unique ticket. If the private sector's progress is not sufficient by 2020, then the Commission will have to present a legislative proposal.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the creation of an integrated multimodal ticketing system in Europe. This text has an appearance of common sense which aims to facilitate mobility within the European area. This would make it easier for travellers to make it easier for them to cross borders.   However, it seems that, in addition to the risk of a reduction in controls, the current environment does not lend itself to the facilitation of travel. Indeed, what about the migration flows and their already very low surveillance in the border crossing? Moreover, the terrorist threats intensified in recent weeks force us to be cautious, not to open up more and more. Public policy-makers aim to protect citizens by controlling their territory and ensuring the control of those who enter it. The Union is preventing us from doing so and would like to subject our states to more flows. This project is therefore neither serious nor responsible.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report seeks to identify ways of removing barriers to the purchasing of single multi-modal tickets for transport, both domestically and across borders. The report highlights many of the difficulties facing the provision of such services across the EU. Nonetheless, a number of concerns meant we were unable to vote in favour in TRAN. The report calls for the equipping of all forms of local transport with intelligent systems relaying real-time information by 2020. This would have severe cost implications, particularly for small and rural bus operators, and serve as a barrier to new entrants onto the UK bus market. Moreover, the report calls for a set of multi-modal EU passenger rights. We fear this would have the unintended consequence of small local and regional bus/rail operators being held liable for large sums of compensation in case of missed medium or long-haul connections.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained on the Report on achieving multimodal integrated ticketing in Europe for a number of reasons. In theory, the idea of a single ticketing system in Europe, as well as the creation of an online travel planning platform accessible to all for free, sounds excellent, but de facto unrealistic goals are set that would cost the livelihoods of dozens of small carriers. The report set out the idea that by 2020 every mode of public transport should be equipped with a smart system to monitor the movement of the vehicle in real time. However, you can imagine what the cost of such a computer system would be for our standards and what would happen to small carriers already in the industry, not to mention those who are yet to enter. We will find ourselves in a monopoly situation where the whole industry will be held by several large companies and small players will not be able to be competitive because of the overwhelming demands of the multimodal integrated system in question. These were the main reasons why I abstained.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report, as the text is unclear and moreover because it is precisely because of this ambiguity that it is likely to lead to a further impairment of national sovereignty and the ability of states to control their territory.

name: Édouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because it does not sufficiently take into account the protection of personal data, produces a monopoly situation and leads to an increase in costs.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are faced with a report full of apparent good intentions that cannot, however, hide their real intentions. The aim will not be so much to ensure better and more sustainable mobility for people, but rather to deepen the path of liberalisation and privatisation of the transport sector and the inevitable monopolistic concentration that always comes to them. This is evidenced by the references to the fourth railway package, the single European transport area or the single European sky. Including some logical and relevant considerations on multi-modality and ease of transport and travel planning in Europe, it is a pity that they appear to be the cover covering up the actual desiderates of the report, which seem to fall within the framework of the International Agreement on Trade and Services (TISA). The intention to promote good business for multinationals at the expense of public investment is visible. For the rest, not a word in relation to attacks on the public transport system, such as those currently underway in Portugal, driven by the EU, aimed at privatising public transport. This was after the attack under the IMF-EU aggression programme, which brutally increased the price of transport, reduced supply and degraded the quality of service.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe multimodal integrated ticketing is of benefit to ordinary citizens.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Transport policy is an important part of the lives of ordinary people and our task is to find answers to quality service provision, taking into account economy, energy efficiency and environmental protection. I therefore support the integrated sale of multimodal tickets in Europe, as it provides a range of services that facilitate the mobility and travel of citizens in the European Union. It will boost tourism and thus the economy. It promotes better integration of different modes of transport and more efficient use of existing infrastructure. Last but not least, it enables passengers with disabilities to provide information in a harmonised way, e.g. on boarding and getting-out aids, thereby increasing social mobility.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report, which highlights the importance of information services and aims to remove current obstacles.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the provision of integrated multimodal ticketing in Europe, firstly because the text is unclear and moreover because it is precisely because of this ambiguity that it is likely to lead to a further impairment of national sovereignty and the ability of states to control their territory.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained in this vote, although I broadly support the focus on removing barriers for cross border transport. I do not support the call for equipping all forms of local transport with real-time relaying equipment. This would be far too costly for rural transport providers.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ There is still a long way to go before a Europe-wide, interoperable, compatible and continuous real-time traffic information service is a reality but the evolution of the internet and smartphones make such a service both possible and very necessary. Therefore I welcome the Commission’s establishment, by way of a delegated act, of specifications for ensuring EU-wide accessibility and the exchange and further development of real-time traffic information services. This is a sound step in the right direction but further steps must be taken so as to enable people making a journey in Europe to identify the most sustainable, fastest or best-value multimodal door-to-door travel option, to book and pay for it and then to be informed, both before setting off and during their journey, about any disruption to it and, where applicable, to receive suggestions for alternative routes.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The transport sector is a central sector for the EU, from the point of view of the economy and employment but also from the point of view of integration between Member States. This report provides for a number of suggestions for the possible modernisation of this sector, with multimodal tickets valid for air, rail, sea and road transport, both with public operators and with private operators. The aim is therefore to make cross-border transport between all Member States easier, whatever means are used. In this way, consumers will be able to have economic and organisational benefits, and greater synergies between private and public operators and between local and national authorities may also have positive effects from the point of view of energy efficiency. In the light of these considerations, I voted in favour of the Koch report.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained today in the vote on the own-initiative report on the implementation of multimodal integrated ticketing systems in the EU. Basically, there is nothing against this idea – it is nice. And as the markets continue to digitalize, it is certainly interesting in the long term. At the moment, however, the demand – with only around 2 percent of cross-border passenger rail traffic – is certainly not urgent and of the highest priority. But the impetus should come from customers or railway companies – not prescribed by the European Parliament.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Koch report given it outlines a number of important recommendations for the EU to improve the passenger experience and make booking journeys easier. Passengers deserve a full range of options when it comes to deciding how they will get from A to B, but these choices need to be backed up by easy-to-use ticketing systems, with clear prices and timetables. It is particularly important to make sure that passengers with reduced mobility are able to make travel bookings without unnecessary inconvenience, for instance by reserving wheelchair spaces or station assistance.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this legislative initiative because it proposes to promote the development of information services, planning and issuance of banknotes for travel throughout the Union that respond to the challenges posed on energy efficiency and environmental sustainability, and economic profitability. The objective is to provide complete information on travel offers by public and private companies related to air traffic, by rail, boat or road and, in this way, to provide travellers with seamless, multimodal and cross-border door-to-door mobility. Based on comprehensive information, travellers should be able to find the most sustainable, fast or economical transportation alternative that best suits their individual requirements, book it and pay for it online, and start travel with a single ticket, no matter how many different modes of transport are used during the journey.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. As a member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism between 2004 and 2014, I voted enthusiastically for this resolution calling for the implementation of a single ticket for transport in the European Union: a very concrete and practical step that would make life easier for travellers in Europe. The ease, comfort of purchase and availability of travel information that such integrated multimodal ticketing systems would allow will attract European travellers to public transport.  In addition, such a system would put an end to websites and mobile applications that prevent the purchase of tickets for national and cross-border journeys, which I welcome, coming from a cross-border constituency par excellence. Facilitating cross-border trade through concrete and practical measures, providing high quality services and more fluid transport and, in short, making life easier for all Europeans travelling are the laudable objectives of our resolution.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in for this report along with my Labour Party colleagues in the European Parliament. People using public transport across Europe deserve a full range of options when it comes to getting from A to B, but this cannot happen without an easy-to-use ticketing system, with clear prices and timetables. This report highlights the positive steps that the EU can take to improve passenger experience and make booking journeys easier. This is of particular importance for those passengers with reduced mobility or other disabilities, so that people with such disabilities are able to make travel bookings and indeed travel, without unnecessary inconvenience.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the development of an integrated multimodal ticketing system in Europe.  Europe's transport policy faces many challenges. On the one hand, sustainability, economy, energy efficiency and environmental sustainability need to be ensured, and transport congestion issues such as congestion and other transport problems need to be addressed on the other. Multimodal travel across the EU information, planning and ticketing services are an important aspect in addressing these issues.  I welcome the fact that the Commission has set the specifications necessary for ensuring that real-time traffic information services are available throughout the EU, exchange and updating of this information by means of a delegated act. This is a good step in the right direction, but a few more steps are needed to enable travellers in Europe to choose the most sustainable, fastest and cheapest multimodal journey from door to door, to book and pay for it, and to get information on possible disruptions or alternative routes before and during the journey.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was very pleased to support the report on delivering multimodal integrated ticketing in Europe. Better integration of various modes of transport by means of multimodal integrated ticketing is an important step towards realising this aim. An important facet of this is that users should get one ticket per multimodal journey and that integrated ticketing systems should have comprehensive, easily accessible, reliable and real-time information for travellers. By making it easy to use multimodal ticketing systems more people will hopefully use public transport. I particularly support the Report´s call for the Commission to respond to the Parliament's resolution for a Charter of Passengers’ Rights. I ask the Commission to bring forward a proposal for such a Charter to address concerns regarding cross border passenger rights and to include a dedicated section on multimodal travel by 2017.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report, as mobility is a key part of modern life and travelling is not confined within national borders. An EU citizen should be able to obtain information, plan and obtain tickets within an integrated system. In today’s modernised world this proposal is practical, efficient and convenient.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report on delivering multimodal integrated ticketing in Europe because we need to put passengers first. Passengers deserve a full range of travel options which are underpinned by user-friendly ticketing systems with clear prices and timetables. This report identifies a number of measures which can be taken by the EU to improve the passenger experience in Europe. In particular, it highlights the need to ensure that the needs of disabled passengers and passengers with reduced mobility are incorporated into ticketing systems, for example through reservation of wheelchair spaces and station assistance. This is undoubtedly a step in the right direction for passengers’ rights.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this legislative initiative because it proposes to promote the development of information services, planning and issuance of banknotes for travel throughout the Union that respond to the challenges posed on energy efficiency and environmental sustainability, and economic profitability. The objective is to provide complete information on travel offers by public and private companies related to air traffic, by rail, boat or road and, in this way, to provide travellers with seamless, multimodal and cross-border door-to-door mobility. Based on comprehensive information, travellers should be able to find the most sustainable, fast or economical transportation alternative that best suits their individual requirements, book it and pay for it online, and start travel with a single ticket, no matter how many different modes of transport are used during the journey.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, the purpose of which is the creation of a system of information, planning and issuance of tickets for multimodal travel throughout the Union, services which make an essential contribution to the creation of a single European transport area and a European internal market.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls on Member States to share timetables and information and develop intermodal ticketing services. Moreover, service providers should cooperate more closely on providing multimodal journey planners. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz (EFDD)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against this project because local transport companies will suffer as they cannot afford new investments by creating a multimodal integrated ticketing system. On the other hand, large, thriving companies will develop even more dynamically, which may result in the ou dissuasing of smEs and the simultaneous hegemony of large corporations.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the implementation of multimodal integrated travel and airfare systems in the EU, as I believe that such a system has a great deal of positives: from fostering modernisation that contributes to the economic market, tourism and the mobility of citizens to environmental protection, sustainability and efficiency.  Furthermore, this system will contribute to the innovation space in SMEs and start-ups, which will consequently lead to the advancement and employment of the workforce and increase competitiveness on the European market. This system will increase the transparency of ticket purchases, encourage passengers to reduce the use of personal means of transport, and allow for better connectivity between even the outermost regions.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I decided to vote against the report on the multimodal ticketing system. It is a text that is part of a desire for uniformity, probably to follow two goals: the creation and deepening of a common market and the standardisation necessary for the signing of a transatlantic free trade treaty. This poses a great risk of monopoly contrary to the interests of European and French consumers. The report defends a federalist vision of Europe, in defiance of the sovereignty of the Member States, and opposes in every way the principles I defend. Uniformity, in any field, is neither desirable nor encouraged, as it is always against sovereign states and citizens.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote promotes an ever closer European Union, which is something I am working against. It is also a move towards more multinational personal data-sharing, which raises issues over data confidentiality and protection. Therefore I have voted against this motion.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Dieter-Lebrecht Koch's report on the creation of an integrated multimodal ticketing system in Europe. This report calls for the creation of a single European ticketing platform. This ticket will provide a single ticket for a trip with several different modes of transport (airplane, train, bus, etc.). This platform would allow for a greater readability of fares and a better consideration of the environment during journeys. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the creation of an integrated multimodal ticketing system in Europe. Such a system, which allows different means of transport to be combined on a single ticket, can only strengthen the European single market and contribute to the establishment of a single European transport area.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The proposal calls for the various ticket systems to be connected through interfaces so that the goal of "one journey – one ticket" can be achieved. External costs could be internalised, taxes and levies would be more clearly identified and credit card fees would be capped. The Commission is expected to take legislative action by 2020 if no progress is made at Member State level for an integrated, interoperable ticketing system. Member States themselves are invited to open up the current information systems in terms of interfaces and to equip all public transport transport with intelligent systems for transmitting real-time information. This great leap for Europe's consumers and travellers is an important achievement. I am therefore voting in favour of the report.

name: Rikke Karlsson (ECR)
text: Written. – This proposal contains parts that could help improve tourism conditions across Europe. However, I believe that the overall proposal is far too comprehensive. With the call for a common ticketing system, we are concerned that it will not be too costly for small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 7 July 2015, we voted in plenary on a report by the Committee on Transport and Tourism on the introduction of an integrated ticketing system for multimodal journeys in Europe. In my opinion, this is precisely where the EU should fully exercise its competences and powers and unify fragmented regulation across all Member States. A long-term objective across the EU should be a common system for multimodal travel, which will include both an information, planning and sales system for tickets, enabling customers to obtain comprehensive travel information in both air, rail, sea and road transport. All European public transport operators should publish specific data sets, including all the information necessary to ensure that EU citizens can choose the most sustainable, cheapest or fastest mode of transport. As my colleague Koch's report met my demands on this issue, such as, above all, fair, inclusive and equal access to free or low-cost online services for all passengers and strong protection of passengers' rights in all modes of transport, I have decided to support this document.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr Koch's report. This proposal underlines the importance for users of obtaining a single ticket for each multimodal journey and considers that fair and equal access to traffic and multimodal travel data, i.e. the provision of complete, easily accessible, neutral, reliable and real-time information for travellers, is an indispensable prerequisite for integrated ticketing systems. It also calls on the Commission to draw up a database of good practice on projects implemented at local, regional or national level, which provide a basis for the implementation of such projects across the EU.
