name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This project to create an integrated multimodal ticketing system is an essential tool for achieving the single European transport area as well as the European single market promoted by the Union. The possible advantages are: facilitating mobility in the European territory; choice for travellers of the optimal solution. There are also many points that are rather unfavourable to this type of system: as mobility is facilitated, there is a risk that this will result in a decrease in controls. While the Union is experiencing a wave of immigration and a high risk of terrorist attacks, facilitating mobility and reducing controls does not appear to be a good solution; risk of an increase in ticket prices to pay for the system 'in place' (unless cost outsourcing) risks a monopoly situation and therefore an increase in costs (the report leaves it to the Commission to combat monopolies); the issue of personal data protection is too vague. I voted against.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I supported the report on the implementation of a multimodal integrated ticketing system in Europe. This is a significant step towards a better and more convenient solution for consumers, first at national level and also at European level by 2024. A new Charter of Passenger Rights should also be presented by 2017 with a separate section on multimodal travel, taking into account the specificities of each mode of transport, as well as an integrated ticketing system. In terms of access to information before and during the journey, greater attention should be paid to the needs of the elderly and disabled.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it. The aim is to create an integrated multimodal ticketing system to facilitate the creation of a single European transport area as well as the European single market promoted by the European Union. Several objectives are planned (establishing a single system of information on timetables, equipping transport with intelligent transmission systems, developing public transport and promoting their use, involving local authorities, etc.). The integrated ticket would also enable the journey to be made with a single ticket and to defend, through Galileo GPS technology, the European technological advance. But facilitating mobility can interfere with control, which is absolutely unthinkable in the current context (terrorist risk, but also immigration-related problems). The issue of data protection must also be taken into account as well as the increase in costs.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The report aims to call for a boost for the creation of integrated tickets in different transnational modes of transport and to put an end to the added difficulties that users encounter when trying to book a multimodal and transnational trip. The motion for a Resolution calls as a first step for the development of integrated multimodal ticketing services for a range of measures in relation to the need to share information on timetables and fares, the first obstacle that service providers encounter.  In accordance with these considerations, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a commitment to a fundamental improvement in the quality and accessibility of public transport systems in the European Union. The creation of integrated systems to enable multimodality in public transport should be a priority to improve the interconnection of these transport services, especially for cross-border ones. The report also clearly bets on transparency in transport information as well as ensuring the rights of users of this type of transport. By betting on improving public transport in Europe, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The Commission has proposed to create multimodal banknotes with the ultimate aim of facilitating the transport of persons. The proposal has taken into account a number of requirements such as transparency in information, accessibility for disabled people or price flexibility, making the proposal viable and argued. I voted in favour for a number of reasons, including improving sustainability, accessibility or creating quality jobs, which will bring a benefit to society at large and to sectors in particular such as tourism, en making possible a quality and globally competitive European single market. The project aims to encourage European citizens to use private transport less and has therefore also presented as a requirement the improvement and implementation of an increase in alternatives.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The report on the implementation of integrated travel and air ticketing systems in the EU points out that smooth multimodal transport has not yet been ensured through smart timetable systems, online bookings and ticketing.  The aim of the Report is to encourage the creation of a single system platform that combines the entire process from planning to reaching the travel destination. Active involvement of the European Union in this project in the segment of financing through structural funds and the European Fund for Strategic Investments is needed.  I supported this Report because it encourages flexibility and facilitates travel.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the challenges facing the European transport sector is finding an easier way to plan journeys and combine different modes of transport. I support the ambitious objective of introducing the possibility of purchasing one ticket valid for all modes of transport within the European Union. Parliament's resolution calls on the Commission and the Member States to support efforts to achieve this goal through a clear framework, minimum rules and timetable. The ease and convenience of buying tickets is key to achieving a single European transport area, making it easier for consumers and ultimately attracting more passengers. In another week, when everyone's attention is focused on resolving the Greek issue, I welcome good European ideas like this. Transport is a major sector of the economy on which many jobs depend. I am convinced that the European Union will give us the right tools to deal with the challenges of the increasingly mobile society in which we live today. Many of us no longer remember that it was impossible to cross borders with only an ID card. Now that's a fact. I believe that modernising the ticketing system is a good initiative, an example of how the European institutions can and work in the service of citizens.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. Unifying documents from transportation systems is a wonderful idea. Sooner or later, in the EU we will all travel with the same tickets. I voted for it.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Congestion in transport is a Europe-wide problem. In 2012, 72.2% of passengers used passenger cars, 8.2% used buses and 6.5% used trains. This situation is particularly unfavourable for larger cities. Pan-European information services on mutlimodal travel, travel planning and ticketing will facilitate the mobility and travel of citizens in the EU, thus streamlining tourism and the economy, and promoting better integration of different modes of transport and more efficient use of existing infrastructure. They can help to move traffic to public transport and to make targeted use of transport alternatives such as bike rental, parking near public transport stops and car sharing. By providing real-time information consistently, we will also make it easier for residents with limited mobility to travel.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the provision of an integrated ticketing system for multimodal travel in Europe for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 6/7/2015 and because this report promotes the upgrading of European transport.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text setting up a multimodal European ticket office. This text gives the possibility of booking a ticket for a journey from one country to another from a single platform combining several modes of transport through a single information system.  This system has the disadvantage of unduly facilitating the free movement of people and thus reducing the controls, which are so important in these times of high immigration. There is also a risk of an increase in the price of tickets for the depreciation of the system.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The long-term aim is to facilitate the provision EU-wide of comprehensive information about travel by air, rail, sea and road with both publicly owned and private transport operators, and thus to offer travellers seamless, multimodal, cross-border, door-to-door mobility options. On the basis of comprehensive information, customers should be able to identify the most sustainable, fastest or best-value travel option for their specific needs, to book and pay online and to make their journey using a single ticket, irrespective of how many different modes of transport they use on the journey.  However, this comprehensive information is not currently available. Therefore, before work can begin on integrated ticketing, with tickets valid for all modes of transport on a given journey, provision must be made for equal access to comprehensive information on a non-discriminatory basis. A further consideration is the costly and technically complex nature of integrated ticketing systems and the resultant need to ensure that modes of transport for which such systems are introduced do not become so expensive that customers turn away from them. This is a worry notably in the case of particularly sustainable modes of transport.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the issue of integrated multimedia tickets in Europe. The aim of the report is to provide travellers with clear and transparent information on prices and reservation systems. Given that the majority of travellers still prefer individual transport, an integrated cross-border approach is an indispensable prerequisite in terms of the mobility and movement of citizens, as well as a system for planning comfortable and simple routes of the Union and visitors from third countries, while respecting the freedoms enshrined in the legal framework of the Union.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report refers to the possibility of issuing integrated multimodal tickets in Europe. The background to the document is Objective 22 of the 2011 White Paper, which stresses the need to ensure smooth multimodal travel through intelligent systems. I welcomed this report because I believe that the possibility of a comprehensive and systematic service in this area would create better conditions for European travellers.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. Multimodal mobility is key to successful public transport. That is why, from the European institutions, we must encourage the implementation of mechanisms to enhance their use by improving management. Integrated information, planning and ticketing services relating to multimodal travel across the EU are a great deal of measure and provide European companies, in particular SMEs and start-ups, with opportunities for innovation and therefore make an important contribution to a globally competitive European single market and to the realization of a single European transport area. My support, therefore, for the report on the creation of integrated multimodal ticketing systems in Europe, which improve information for travellers and facilitate efforts.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This proposal was supported by me, as the creation of multimodal integrated tickets offers a great deal of opportunities for travellers. In addition to the clear declaration of taxes and levies and the limitation of credit card fees, the First and Last Mile scheme is also a welcome innovation.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this Report as the further integration of the different modes of transport will make mobility more efficient and user-friendly. It will also facilitate and promote multimodal travel by providing online information, electronic booking and payment systems which integrate all means of transport.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. An integrated multimodal ticketing system is defined as combining different modes of transport on a single ticket with a one-stop shop, accessible to all. The stated objectives of increasing the mobility of people with reduced mobility or increasing the share of public transport used are commendable. Particular attention is paid to the protection of personal data by stating that the purchase of an e-ticket must be able to be done "preferably without the need to register in the system".  So far, that's good. But the ultimate goal is to participate "in the realisation of a single European transport area and a European single market." In the same spirit, the text argues that "the adoption of the fourth railway package" would allow for better integration of different modes of transport. This is unacceptable and I condemn it. In these conditions I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The introduction of a multi-modal ticketing system in Europe is yet another pawn of the Commission on the road to the federalisation of the European Union. Indeed, this process further uniformizes the transport sector, which is the federalist vanguard of the Union. Moreover, the issue of the protection of personal data remains too vague, and no real mechanism is provided. There is also a very high risk of establishing a monopoly situation, effectively increasing costs for users. Being very attached to the sovereignty of states and to the Europe of Nations and the defence of users, I voted 'against'.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the creation of this integrated multimodal travel ticketing system in Europe, we are making a significant contribution to the realisation of a single European transport area and a European internal market. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of developing ‘intermodal’ tickets and to boost efforts to provide single ticketing for trips across EU borders for all modes of transport. Therefore I fully supported and voted in favour of the report on delivering multimodal integrated ticketing in Europe. The report recommends that updated national timetable and fare information systems should be introduced by 2020, which should be linked on a cross-border basis and made accessible to operators, providers of journey planners and consumers. I also fully support the idea of having a charter of passenger rights covering all modes of transport by the end of 2017 and of improving access to travel information before and during journey with more attention to be paid to the needs of elderly people and those with disabilities.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In 2012, 72.2% of passengers in the European Union use cars and only 8.2% use buses and 6.5% use trains. However, multimodal travel information, route planning and ticketing services at EU level facilitate the transition to public transport and the prevention of congestion, thus contributing significantly to the sustainability of European transport, especially in cities. That is why I supported the report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The possibility of a single and integrated ticket between the different modes of transport in the 28 Member States is still far from a reality. For a tourist travel information, the possibility to plan, book and/or buy online are elements that will make the Union a more accessible and appealing destination. On the other hand, peer-to-peer mobility will bring direct benefits to union citizens. In addition, the integrated and single ticket responds to congestion and other traffic problems.  I believe that this system for multimodal travel in Europe should be implemented from the development of products and services in private individuals, which, alongside public authorities, should provide their application. However, in order for this to be possible, it is imperative that there is equal access, on a non-discriminatory basis, to travel data in different countries. On the other hand, local and regional authorities must be linked together through an interoperable platform. Looking at an example where ticketing is already a reality, the case of the UK, platforms and data are open to all operators, making it possible to create a single system.   For the above reasons, I am voting in favour of this document.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This integrated multimodal ticketing system defended by the European Union is essential to the realisation of the single European transport area and the European single market promoted by the Union. The profound aim is to allow rail passengers to use only one ticket and to choose the most optimal solution for intra-community travel. To this end, this report defends the equipment of all modes of transport of intelligent transmission systems by 2023 through the establishment of a single national information system to connect regional and local timetables, in order to promote greater use of public transport and promote the environment. Although it has some positive aspects that promote mobility or reduce constraints for users by, for example, integrating the Galileo system, this report poses risks to Member States as it will make controls more difficult due to increased mobility. Most importantly, all of these provisions are likely to increase the cost of tickets. For these reasons, I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Passengers in Europe deserve a full range of options when it comes to deciding how they will get from A to B but these choices need to be backed up by easy-to-use ticketing systems, with clear prices and timetables. This European Parliament report highlights the positive steps that the EU can take to improve the passenger experience and make booking journeys easier. It is particularly important to make sure that passengers with reduced mobility are able to make travel bookings without unnecessary inconvenience, for instance by reserving wheelchair spaces or station assistance.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the creation of an integrated multimodal ticketing system in Europe. The text calls on the Commission to formulate legislative proposals to facilitate travel across Europe, both in terms of information and programming and ticket booking. In particular, it proposes the creation of a single ticket for all the transport chosen. The aim is to develop tourism in Europe through innovations in the digital and service provider sectors and by adapting legislation.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this draft resolution, which has become necessary to intelligently address some of the issues relating to sustainability, profitability, energy efficiency and eco-compatibility and, at the same time, to respond to congestion situations and other traffic problems. We believe that an adequate response to all these problems can be provided by the information, planning and ticketing services of multimodal travel at Community level.  The element of multimodality facilitates mobility and travel while strengthening tourism and therefore the economy; promotes greater integration of modes of transport and more efficient use of existing infrastructure; allows information to be provided to travellers with disabilities or reduced mobility; it stimulates the use of real-time information to adapt to traffic disruptions and also strengthens Europe's industrial and research base. The multimodality element and the associated benefits will make it possible to make an important contribution to the creation of a single European transport area and a single European market.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The long-term objective of this proposal is to provide comprehensive information at Union level on travel offers from public and private companies operating in the air, rail, sea and road transport sectors, thus enabling travellers to benefit from a multimodal and cross-border travel solution. By receiving comprehensive information, the traveler should be able to choose, book and pay online for a personalized travel solution that represents the most sustainable, quick or cost-effective choice and to travel with only one ticket, regardless of the number of modes of transport used during the journey. Given that the mobility of citizens within the Union is a prerequisite for the exercise of fundamental freedoms and that citizens should therefore be able to obtain comprehensive, accurate and neutral information, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have vote this report that will bring multimodal integrated ticketing in Europe using intelligent systems for interoperable and multimodal scheduling, online reservation systems and smart ticketing.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because I think it makes sense to adapt the various ticket ingessay systems to the requirements of the 21st century through open interfaces and data exchange. By 2020, for example, the Commission is to take legislative measures to open up information systems in terms of interfaces and to equip all public transport transport with intelligent systems for transmitting real-time information, ultimately opening the way to a single ticket for several, including cross-border, means of transport.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to implement European-wide multimodal travel information, travel planning and ticketing services to facilitate the provision of comprehensive information on air, rail, sea and road transport. Facilitating the mobility and movement of EU citizens and visitors from third countries is a concrete way of implementing freedoms of movement. It also promotes the transition to public transport, which is necessary to reduce our consumption and carbon emissions in Europe. It is for these reasons that I supported this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft multimodal integrated ticketing system. Europe needs to achieve better integration of the different modes of transport, but each mode of transport must also become more efficient, sustainable and user-friendly. It is important for users to get one ticket for one multimodal trip, while receiving transparent pricing information. The purchase of a ticket with a simple and convenient new system will attract more passengers to use the public transport service, which in turn will increase passenger satisfaction.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 The major challenges in the field of European transport policy revolve around sustainability, economic profitability, energy efficiency, environmental sustainability, congestion, traffic jams and other traffic problems. Information, planning and ticketing services for multimodal travel throughout the Union make an essential contribution to the creation of a single European transport area and a European internal market: they not only facilitate the mobility and movement of citizens, but contribute to a more efficient use of the infrastructures and services available to the user. And I have voted not only for these reasons, but for another that is capital for us: they enable the transmission of personalized information to travellers with disabilities or reduced mobility. Making life easier for these groups and allowing them to enjoy efficient transport unhindered is to fix one of the biggest flaws in our transportation systems. Defects that are, in many cases, vitally important.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report on the provision of an integrated ticketing system for multimodal travel in Europe seeks to enhance competitiveness and "open up" new areas of profitability for monopolies by promoting, inter alia, the "combined use of various modes of transport with a single ticket", "real-time information transmission systems". As long as the transport sector remains in the hands of business groups, grassroots families are being groaned by rising travel costs, while the connection to remote areas is shrinking with multiple consequences for residents' lives. The electronic file of passengers is also generalized by processing their personal and traffic data.  The way out lies in another society and organisation of the economy, with socialisation of means of production, with central national scientific planning both in the transport sector and everywhere on the basis of meeting social needs rather than profit. With labour distribution and work for all, taking advantage of the socialised sector of industry, planning for interconnected and complementary transport operation (road, air, etc.) will benefit the people with the aim of quickly and cheaply moving people and products, saving energy, balanced intervention in the environment, planned development to eliminate regional imbalance , full control of the defence and security of the socialist state.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas most travellers continue to prefer individual transport and whereas the creation of travel route planning services at Union level will not in itself be sufficient to improve the integration of modes of transport, I am in favour of issuing integrated multimodal tickets in Europe

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report out of a desire to help simplify the lives of young people keen to travel within the EU. This report also supports entrepreneurs travelling for work and who often have difficulty entering the accounts and settling travel tickets. I believe that we have taken another step towards a more coherent and better integrated European Union.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported this report because I believe that a comprehensive cross-border approach to ticket sales and the provision of information on multimodal travel across the EU are key to the challenges of European transport. The mobility of European citizens across the EEZ is a prerequisite for the exercise of their fundamental rights and should therefore be able to access accurate and neutral information on timetables, available transport links and prices. This will benefit society, the environment, social cohesion and tourism, while providing opportunities for innovation, thus contributing to a greater competitiveness of the Single European Market.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union is working to improve the transport network but the long-term objective at EU level is to facilitate travel information and facilitate travel for all users of aviation, rail and other transport by introducing multimodal ticketing. A single travel ticket covering all modes of transport would facilitate passenger transport and make European transport efficient with social, economic and tourism benefits. The issuance of multimodal tickets across Europe should therefore be a priority, therefore it is necessary to encourage Member States to develop passenger networks and participate in better transport links between the European Union. Member States may also participate by fostering a variety of innovations on local public transport that would have wide coverage. While there is still a long way to go before a multimodal map is published, I support this report because it encourages better transport connectivity that will have social and economic benefits.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This integrated multimodal ticketing system defended by the European Union is a prerequisite for the realization of the single European transport area as well as the European single market promoted by the European Union. The aim is to allow rail passengers to use only one ticket and to choose the optimal solution for intra-community travel. To this end, the report defends the equipment of all modes of transport of intelligent transmission systems by 2023, through the establishment of a single national information system to connect regional and local timetables. The aim is to promote greater use of public transport and to promote the environment. Although it has some positive aspects (reducing constraints for users through the integration of the Galileo system, for example), this text poses risks to Member States as it will facilitate mobility and thus make it even more difficult to control entry and exit from the national territory. In addition, these provisions may increase the cost of tickets. For these reasons, I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I agree with Parliament's view that the challenges of European transport policy are numerous, such as economic sustainability, energy efficiency and environmental conscientiousness, with air traffic overcrowding, crowds, but the implementation of multimodal integrated information, travel and airfare systems represents a major part in the solution of these problems. The long-term objective is to ensure that air, rail, sea and land travel regulations are as easy as possible for all EU citizens to be able to identify as easily as possible the most cost-free, fast or high-quality travel option for a particular journey.  I support Parliament's position that in order to be in a position to provide travellers with detailed information within the deadlines, the same information must be available to all travel planning services across the EU, regardless of the specificity of the regions or the commercial contracts in force. While we have a long way to go before establishing an interoperable, compatible, real-time travel information transfer system at EU level, the evolution of the Internet shows how this service is as possible as necessary.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Unanimous support for the Proposal of the European Parliament Resolution on the implementation of multimodal integrated travel and air ticketing systems in the EU by the competent Transport and Tourism Committee speaks volumes about the quality thereof.  I support this resolution because I believe that the EU must insist on building a more competitive transport system, which was also a key objective of Initiative 22 of the 2011 White Book of the same name. In line with the continuous and accelerated technological progress, this Resolution for Union citizens represents significant progress in exercising their rights to smooth multimodal transport with intelligent and integrated ticketing services.  Integrated ticketing enables the combination of different modes of transport in one ticket, thereby responding propulsively to the main challenges in European transport. Such combined transport would have an impact on strengthening the fundamental European values of the Single European Transport Area, which include economic sustainability, increasing safety in all modes of transport, multimodality, efficiency, job creation and labour mobility. Such "smart" and sustainable mobility is equally beneficial for society, the economy, the environment, social cohesion and tourism.  The mobility of citizens across the EU is a precondition for the exercise of their fundamental personal and market freedoms and at the same time the necessary modernisation of sustainable and combined transport services would have an undeniably positive impact on the development of European tourism.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mobility is a fundamental part of modern life that is not limited to national borders alone. The planning of ticketing services requires an integrated European approach, in line with European transport policy and the roadmap for the delivery across the EU of information on multimodal mobility and ticketing service planning, already presented by the Commission. I believe that greater integration of the different modes of transport is necessary in order to make mobility more efficient. Online information, electronic booking and payment systems integrating all means of transport should facilitate and promote multimodal mobility. In the light of these considerations, I have decided to support this proposal by means of my vote in favour.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I was very happy to support the proposal to integrate the ticketing system for multimodal travel within Europe, as I consider it to be the next step in facilitating free movement in the EU. The integration of this type of ticket will also strengthen the unity of the internal market and the competitiveness of companies in the transport sector. At the same time, however, it is also important that personal data are protected in the implementation of this measure and that passenger data is not accumulated and leaked in a central integrated system.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "An integrated ticketing system will undoubtedly facilitate movement, which is much needed in today's globalised world, where travel is becoming more common. Ease, convenience, as well as the lower price of one common ticket will certainly attract more passengers and contribute to the development of public transport.  The EP's decision is a step in the right direction and a positive signal for all travellers, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In the face of the increasing diversification of transport modes and offers in Europe and within the European Union and in view of the increasing mobility of citizens, the European Parliament has adopted an initiative report on the creation of an integrated multimodal ticketing system in Europe. I voted in favour of this text and I believe that the Commission should propose reforms to simplify transport modes in Europe and to facilitate the transport of travellers. This includes creating a single ticket.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. By making the choice, reservation and payment of multimodal door-to-door transport more streamline, enabling and making cheaper the choice, reservation and payment of multimodal transport door-to-door, the European Commission defines, by means of a delegated act, specifications aimed at ensuring the exchange and development of real-time traffic information service for European passengers. The proposal is part of European transport policy and aims to strengthen the exercise of the fundamental freedoms of EU citizens, while stimulating tourism and, consequently, the economy. Economic gains are also added to the sustainability contributions of the European transport sector and the more efficient use of available infrastructure. The draft resolution which I voted in favour of calls on the competent authorities of the Member States to introduce up-to-date national information systems and intelligent systems to provide real-time information on the location of transport by 2020.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted positively for this report which encourages the creation of a single transport ticket, regardless of the different modes of transport used. The report calls on Member States to improve national timetable and tariff information systems and to implement "intelligent systems that provide real-time information" by 2020. I welcome the contribution of this report to the creation of a single European transport area. Multimodal travel information, planning and ticketing services at EU level are a substantial part of the response to the difficulties of European transport policy.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The free movement of people within the European area is a fundamental principle of the Union. However, today we are far from being able to travel safely within the Union. That is why I supported the adoption of the Koch report on the creation of an integrated multimodal ticketing system in Europe.  Objective 22 of the Commission's 2011 White Paper entitled 'Roadmap for a Single European Transport Area' is to enable multi-modal travel through intelligent timetable programming, online booking and ticketing systems.  Transport policy is one of the major challenges in Europe from both an environmental and traffic congestion point of view. In 2012, 72.2% of passengers used the car while only 8.2% travelled by bus and 6.5% by train.   While most passengers continue to favour individual transport, THE introduction of EU-wide information, planning and ticketing services would enable travellers to find the most appropriate solution for their needs, to book and pay for it online, and to travel with a single ticket, regardless of the modes of transport used.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. More in-depth European integration means efficiency and fluidity in transport. Although these are only recommendations to the Commission, I welcome the adoption of this report on the creation of an integrated multimodal ticketing system in Europe. Decongestion of the transport network and thus reducing carbon emissions will be among the main improvements. In addition, such measures will allow the user to select the route of his choice on the basis of neutral, reliable data obtained in real time and thus help him to optimize his journeys. The European Parliament is calling on the Commission not only to establish a coherent regulatory framework for innovation and entrepreneurship in this area, but also for the establishment of appropriate infrastructure.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which aims to promote the creation of integrated tickets in different transnational modes of transport and to put an end to the added difficulties that users encounter when trying to book such a trip.  The report further reflects the Commission's complaint of a Charter of passenger rights of all modes of transport before the end of 2017, including a section on multimodal travel with clear and transparent protection of passenger rights in the multimodal context that takes into account the specificities of each mode of transport and an integrated multimodal ticketing. And in view of the demographic change facing Europe, it stresses the need to ensure accessibility to means of transport, in particular vulnerable people, asking that much more account be made of the needs of people with disabilities or reduced mobility, as well as the special needs of the elderly.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Yesterday, I voted in plenary on the initiative report on the creation of an integrated multimodal ticketing system in Europe. The aim is to establish at European level a comprehensive system of information with consumers on the different modes of transport (air, road, rail, maritime) in order to propose "a multimodal and cross-border solution, without interruption, door-to-door". The report calls on Member States by 2020 to improve their national information systems on timetables and tariffs, as well as to implement 'smart real-time information transmission systems'. The voted text also sets 2024 as the final horizon for launching "a cross-border networking of national information systems on timetables and fares" with the aim of developing long-term multimodal and cross-border route calculators. In addition, Parliament has called on the European Commission to take the "necessary measures" in this regard if there is no substantial progress to be made by 2020, and to draw up a passenger rights charter covering all modes of transport.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report proposes the creation of an integrated multimodal travel ticket system in Europe, as objective 22 of the 2011 White Paper, which provided for the creation of multimodal, 'door-to-door' multimodal transport, with intelligent, interoperable and multimodal time-making, information, online booking and ticketing systems, has not yet been achieved. Like the rapporteur, I consider the multimodal ticketing system to be an extremely important and integrating element in the transport network, per se, providing attractive solutions for users, economically sustainable and economically viable, energy-efficient and environmentally friendly, avoiding congestion, traffic jams or other traffic problems. I therefore agree with the long-term objective proposed by the rapporteur: to provide, throughout the EU, complete information on the offers of public and private companies in the aviation, rail, maritime and road sectors and thus offer travellers a multimodal, cross-border and door-to-door solution, which does not currently exist, and also the proposal to connect local and regional authorities through a common platform , with the aim of moving together to a real-time traffic information service across the EU.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As a member of the TRAN Committee, I strongly supported and voted in favour of the report presented by Mr De Clercq. Mr Koch, who, being on his own initiative, aims to call on the European Commission to issue a legislative proposal in this area. The tourism sector must be seen as one of the driving forces of the European economy and facilitating travel within the old continent is one of the means of promoting our magnificent countries, as well as the potential advantage in terms of circulation with a keen eye also to respect for the environment. The report emphasises information systems, hoping that multimodal tickets can be sold in the future: a single ticket for multiple journeys also by different means of transport within the EU. Through better information sharing, European citizens will be able to organise their journey better and be able to move from one place to another without too much difficulty. The report identifies the creation of a single platform at European level as the instrument through which all local and regional authorities will be able to include details of the means of transport within their competence. The sharing of information can be a first real and concrete step towards improving the movements of all the people who will transit our continent.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, believing that I support the report, which highlights the importance of information services, planning and ticketing of multimodal travel at Union level.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this legislative initiative because it proposes to promote the development of information services, planning and issuance of banknotes for travel throughout the Union that respond to the challenges posed on energy efficiency and environmental sustainability, and economic profitability. The objective is to provide complete information on travel offers by public and private companies related to air traffic, by rail, boat or road and, in this way, to provide travellers with seamless, multimodal and cross-border door-to-door mobility. Based on comprehensive information, travellers should be able to find the most sustainable, fast or economical transportation alternative that best suits their individual requirements, book it and pay for it online, and start travel with a single ticket, no matter how many different modes of transport are used during the journey.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a commitment to a fundamental improvement in the quality and accessibility of public transport systems in the European Union. The creation of integrated systems to enable multimodality in public transport should be a priority to improve the interconnection of these transport services, especially for cross-border ones. The report also clearly bets on transparency in transport information as well as ensuring the rights of users of this type of transport. By betting on improving public transport in Europe, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The introduction of multimodal travel information, planning and ticketing services at European level could help to reduce problems related to transport sustainability, energy efficiency and traffic. At present, given the great fragmentation of the European market, travellers are not fully informed in real time about the travel alternatives (air, train, ship and road) offered by public and private operators. It is therefore important that, first and foremost, adequate European financial support is guaranteed to promote innovation in this sector and to address, thanks to new technological solutions, the many difficulties in the provision of these services throughout the EU. In order to gradually introduce interoperable electronic ticketing systems throughout the Union, I believe that we must start from the establishment of a platform for the exchange of information and good practices involving operators throughout the EU. On the other hand, it is necessary to proceed with caution with regard to the definition of specific time targets for the installation of intelligent systems for the transmission of information in real time in all local public transport. Having some doubts about the approach taken in the report on this and other points, I have therefore chosen to abstain from the final vote.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Passengers in Europe deserve a full range of options when it comes to deciding how they will get from A to B but these choices need to be backed up by easy-to-use ticketing systems, with clear prices and timetables. This European Parliament report highlights the positive steps that the EU can take to improve the passenger experience and make booking journeys easier. It is particularly important to make sure that passengers with reduced mobility are able to make travel bookings without unnecessary inconvenience, for instance by reserving wheelchair spaces or station assistance.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I share a report looking for ways to remove barriers for EU travellers. It correctly identifies the costs and technical problems associated with the creation of an integrated ticketing system. No restrictions should stand in the way of market development in this area. EU citizens should also be able to benefit from the Benefits of the Union when travelling. This proposal may encourage more frequent use of public transport. Higher revenues of carriers will also be the result of increased demand.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider public passenger transport for multimodal travel to be important because it provides transport for passengers from start to finish. On a daily basis, we encounter travel problems that could be improved by integrated sales of multimodal tickets in Europe. I can imagine integrated ticketing as a combination of different modes of transport on a single ticket, but unfortunately we are currently lacking extensive information to choose the kind of transport that will be the fastest, most cost-effective, not to mention that such a ticket could be booked and paid for online by the passenger online. I consider integrated sales of multimodal tickets to be a major challenge that will make travel more efficient, faster and cheaper. Public transport must be advantageous for passengers so that they do not favour individual transport. Integrated sales of tickets will also contribute to greater transparency and consumer protection.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the issue of integrated multimodal tickets in Europe, which highlights the benefits for users of being able to buy a single ticket for a 'multimodal journey', i.e. combining different modes of transport. The text suggests the introduction of an integrated ticket for travel across EU borders that allows various types of transport to be used, thus increasing the attractiveness of the use of public transport. In addition to significantly facilitating the lives of travellers, the integration of information, travel planning and ticketing services could be a response to the challenges posed by the European transport sector (such as sustainability, multimodality, improved safety in all modes of transport, efficiency, creation of quality jobs), benefiting the economy, society and the environment. With this resolution, we therefore call on the Commission to take the necessary measures to support and improve synergies between different providers of transport and route planning services, for example through multimodal and cross-border travel route planning services. The hope is that the advantage of being able to use integrated ticketing systems will attract more passengers to collective transport.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support making life easier for people. Linking traffic information and making it available to everyone through modern technologies is a step towards better mobility and ease of congested transport systems. I am pleased that the proposal also takes into account cycling, which is the urban transport of the future.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. 'Intermodal travel, say, easy to move across borders with different types of means of transport (train, tram, bus, ... ) is a concept we support. We are aware of the difficulties in this regard, including national ticket sales websites with information only available in a foreign local language. However, the fact that the difficulties have to be remedied by means of a single ticket or e-platform cannot be justified in terms of cost. The report contains such unrealistic proposals (disproportionate liability of small transport companies for missed connecting long-haul flights, advanced digital real-time systems in buses in rural areas...). However, we believe that regional and national transport companies should pool their timetables at national level and make it available as open data to companies working on integrated platforms. Google Maps, for example, shows the door-to-door route at a glance, including in cross-border public transport, as long as it gets access to itineraries. The N-VA delegation therefore abstained, in line with the position of its ECR Group. This sends a signal that the European Commission should focus on non-legislative action to support rather than stifling the relevant sectors.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the report on the implementation of multimodal integrated travel and airfare systems in the EU because it enables more efficient transport through EU member states. I believe that this will contribute to strengthening freedom of movement for residents of member states and to strengthening tourism. Given that 72.2% of citizens used the car as a means of transport in 2012, I believe that by implementing this system they would achieve more frequent use of public transport means, thereby reducing pollution and traffic congestion in cities. I also believe that implementing this system would improve the competitiveness of businesses and provide more space for SMEs.  This Regulation would also improve consumers' rights and information on transports in the European Union. This would greatly facilitate travel for travellers through the European Union as they would have one ticket throughout the journey regardless of the different types of transport they use.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Passengers in Europe deserve a full range of options when it comes to deciding how they will get from A to B but these choices need to be backed up by easy-to-use ticketing systems, with clear prices and timetables. This European Parliament report highlights the positive steps that the EU can take to improve the passenger experience and make booking journeys easier. It is particularly important to make sure that passengers with reduced mobility are able to make travel bookings without unnecessary inconvenience, for instance by reserving wheelchair spaces or station assistance.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. —Mobility is an integral part of the modern way of life and one of the fundamental values on which the European Union is founded. Freedom of movement for nationals of all 28 Member States is the basis for achieving all positive effects and economic objectives.  I support this report because we need to improve the infrastructure for all our citizens so that we can travel efficiently within the European Union. We need to work on integrated, multimodal transport that will improve service and facilitate movement. One of the primary objectives is to implement integrated transport tickets and obtain integrated transport information in a very simple and accessible way. The goals we want to achieve are multimodal stations, online platforms for booking and buying tickets for all modes of transport, connectivity between public and private transport providers, etc. Such a system would enable greater cooperation, mobility and the development of tourism and the economy as a whole. In addition, ease of use and efficiency of travel would lead to a reduction in the use of passenger cars, reduction of large traffic jams and harmful environmental impact. Noise would also be reduced and citizens would have a simple, affordable and quality service.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because, in order to protect consumers, it also significantly increases the regulatory burden in some cases, which will ultimately harm precisely those consumers who should have been protected.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the establishment of a connected multimodal ticketing system in Europe, because I am convinced that multimodal travel will make a significant contribution to the realisation of a single European transport area. Passengers should be given the fastest or cheapest travel option by a single ticket. They should be able to select, book and pay for this ticket online, regardless of how many different means of transport they use. However, these measures should not lead to an excessive increase in ticket prices.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I supported the report on the introduction of an integrated ticketing system for multimodal journeys in Europe, the main objective of which is to facilitate the mobility and travel of EU citizens and visitors from third countries, thus promoting not only tourism and the fundamental rights of passengers, but also other areas of transport which ultimately have an impact on the economy as a whole.  Another aims to help better integrate the different modes of transport and make more efficient use of existing infrastructure, which will contribute in particular to reducing air pollution and congestion, i.e. congestion. It thus targets the problems of large agglomerations in particular. Other objectives include promoting social mobility through the transmission (transmission) of traffic information facilitating transport for persons with disabilities or persons with reduced mobility (e.g. on boarding and disembarke. Last but not least, the report supports the development of technological information systems that are essential for interoperability, which is stepping up the development of integrated multimodal services in the field of travel information, planning and ticketing in the EU.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The text is unclear and is likely to lead to a further impairment of national sovereignty and the ability of states to control their territory.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The idea in the report, in my opinion, is correct, as it can lead not only to making the lives of citizens of the Member States of the European Union easier, but also to making public transport more efficient. However, I believe that such solutions should be pursued in the market process and not in the administration's own actions. The idea is that these, like any other solution in the economy, have their optimum efficiency.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for my colleague's text. There are great challenges facing transport policy in Europe. Issues of sustainability, profitability, energy efficiency and environmental impacts are added to traffic congestion issues, such as traffic congestion and other traffic problems. The provision of information, planning and ticketing services for multi-modal travel throughout the EU can go a long way in solving these problems.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was shadow rapporteur on this report and gave it my full support. It is more than time that we take mobility in Europe a step further by allowing travel across Europe with one single ticket covering train, plane, bus and bike trips. We already have such services for goods but are missing it for people. This report is paving the way towards achieving better interoperability of the different modes of transports across the EU. Efficient journey planning and accessible information are key elements in this respect: passengers should have access to comprehensive, accurate and neutral information regarding the different possible connections and respective timetables. This initiative by the European Parliament sets a framework to allow for changes and for the transport sector to jump into the digital age. Now, it is up to the businesses across Europe to make it happen. A large gap for investments and innovations just opened and I am calling on European companies to make good use of it.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 European transport policy must respond to very important issues relating to sustainability, profitability, energy efficiency, but also traffic congestion, which is why I believe it is essential to support all information, planning and ticketing services for multimodal travel at Union level. Integrated information services allow for greater mobility, reduce traffic congestion through more efficient use of public transport and alternative means of transport such as bicycle rental or car-sharing. Greater support for this type of technology must be ensured through existing research programmes and the completion of the digital single market also in order to consolidate the European industrial base. I fully agree with the emphasis of this report on the end user and the expected social benefits, the aim of the European institutions is to reduce the environmental impact and increase transport safety, including through the provision of information adapted to the needs of all travellers, including people with disabilities. A final welcome point in this report is the emphasis on fair and non-discriminatory access to the market, as well as a clear definition of end-user rights: consumer protection, data protection and privacy are essential issues for all European citizens.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I certainly commend the rapporteur's efforts to highlight to the Commission the need to create a non-existst framework to support the efforts already being made by operators across Europe.  I also agree with the irrefutable fact that restrictions should not be placed on the market aimed at hampering potential innovation through attempts to keep pace with constantly changing technologies. The long-term objective is to provide comprehensive information on air, rail, sea and road travel with public and private transport operators across the EU. Users should be allowed to choose the best and fastest travel option for their specific needs, to book and pay online, and to travel on a single card regardless of how many different means of transport they use during their journey.  As with any innovation, certain fears of failure exist, which does not mean that they should put a barrier to inevitable development and progress.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the report on the establishment of a connected multimodal ticketing system in Europe. Human mobility is an integral part of modern life and one of the EU's 4 freedoms. An integrated European approach is therefore needed, especially when it comes to the issue of multi-modal information on travel, planning and tickets. The European Commission has therefore produced a document providing for unification: a single system for obtaining information and tickets across the EU. Online information, electronic bookings and payment systems, which combine all means of transport, would facilitate and accelerate multi-modal travel, but the current fragmented landscape in the European market represents an obstacle to exploiting the full potential and benefits of the sector.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this legislative initiative because it proposes to promote the development of information services, planning and issuance of banknotes for travel throughout the Union that respond to the challenges posed on energy efficiency and environmental sustainability, and economic profitability. The objective is to provide complete information on travel offers by public and private companies related to air traffic, by rail, boat or road and, in this way, to provide travellers with seamless, multimodal and cross-border door-to-door mobility. Based on comprehensive information, travellers should be able to find the most sustainable, fast or economical transportation alternative that best suits their individual requirements, book it and pay for it online, and start travel with a single ticket, no matter how many different modes of transport are used during the journey.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Although much has been achieved , there is still much work to do regarding this issue. Either because of lack of coordination between states and operators, lack of information, language problems, etc., there is no option to purchase online or through mobile applications tickets for domestic and cross-border travel within the EU. We need a wide range of information that encompasses multiple providers so that users have fair, open and equitable access to all data for real-time traffic and multimodal travel. We need a proposal for suppliers to provide, under fair and equitable conditions, all relevant data necessary for the provision of more comprehensive services and thereby offer travellers a real possibility to choose the most sustainable, cheapest or quickest connection.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The objectives of this report are multiple: greater importance of cross-border services, establishing by 2020 a single national information system to connect regional and local timetables, equipping all modes of transport with intelligent transmission systems by 2023, integrating local and regional authorities to involve them in the provision of traffic information within the Union.  The possible advantages are that this type of system can only facilitate mobility in the European territory, this proposal is based on the Galileo GPS system which is a European geolocation system. There are also many points rather unfavourable to this type of system: mobility being facilitated, this will result in a decrease in controls, while the Union is experiencing a wave of immigration and is experiencing a high risk of terrorist attacks, risk of an increase in the price of tickets to pay for the implementation of the system (unless outsourcing costs); risks a monopoly situation and therefore an increase in costs (the report leaves it to the Commission to combat monopolies); the issue of personal data protection is too vague. So I'm voting against.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the report on the issuance of multimodal integrated tickets in Europe, through the upgraded input, will boost the mobility of European citizens. The introduction of an integrated system of travel planning and ticketing services is a response to the challenges for the European transport sector, ensuring the sustainability and improvement of the safety and security of means of transport. The creation of an integrated ticket, which can be used regardless of how many modes of transport are used during a journey, can make European destinations more accessible and can contribute significantly to the development of continental tourism. I believe that the provision, throughout the EU, of multimodal information, travel planning and ticketing services facilitates mobility at European Union level, a basic condition for the exercise of fundamental freedoms, and contributes to greater use of public transport when, in 2012, the car was the means of transport chosen by 72.2% of passengers. These services can lead to the creation of a single European transport area. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report regulates a very important area. European transport policy faces a number of challenges. On the one hand, there is the issue of sustainability, economy, energy efficiency and environmental protection, and on the other hand, the question of what solutions can be found to the congested transport network, such as congestion and other transport problems, must also be addressed. A significant part of these issues is answered by multimodal travel information, route planning and ticketing services at EU level. The proposal summarises the existing experience extensively and lists the problems that need to be solved. As Vice-Chairman of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, I supported the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this legislative initiative because it proposes to promote the development of information services, planning and issuance of banknotes for travel throughout the Union that respond to the challenges posed on energy efficiency and environmental sustainability, and economic profitability. The objective is to provide complete information on travel offers by public and private companies related to air traffic, by rail, boat or road and, in this way, to provide travellers with seamless, multimodal and cross-border door-to-door mobility. Based on comprehensive information, travellers should be able to find the most sustainable, fast or economical transportation alternative that best suits their individual requirements, book it and pay for it online, and start travel with a single ticket, no matter how many different modes of transport are used during the journey.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to improve the intermodality of cross-border transport as a measure promoting public transport.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it represents an important step towards the modernisation of the European transport sector, by helping to make travel across the EU more hassle-free. The report calls for an easier purchase of tickets for national and cross-border journeys, but also for more integrated ‘smart ticketing’. This means that journey planning and payment systems will be more transparent, user-friendly and therefore easier for consumers. The improvement of such systems will serve to make travel in Europe more accessible and increase tourism as a consequence.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The Koch report is trying to deal with the issue from a broad European multimodal perspective. The main line of the rapporteur of the report is to consider the issuance of multimodal banknotes as an important element for sustainability, economic viability, energy efficiency and sustainable use of transport. I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour of a report which introduces important elements of reflection on this subject.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a commitment to a fundamental improvement in the quality and accessibility of public transport systems in the European Union. The creation of integrated systems to enable multimodality in public transport should be a priority to improve the interconnection of these transport services, especially for cross-border ones. The report also clearly bets on transparency in transport information as well as ensuring the rights of users of this type of transport. By betting on improving public transport in Europe, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as passengers in Europe deserve a full range of options when it comes to deciding how they will get from A to B but these choices need to be backed up by easy-to-use ticketing systems, with clear prices and timetables. This European Parliament report highlights the positive steps that the EU can take to improve the passenger experience and make booking journeys easier. It is particularly important to make sure that passengers with reduced mobility are able to make travel bookings without unnecessary inconvenience, for instance by reserving wheelchair spaces or station assistance.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report calls for the creation of a dialogue platform, bringing together all transport sector representatives and competent authorities at local, regional, national and European level, with a view to developing viable mechanisms for the gradual gradual introduction at EU level of interoperable electronic ticketing systems, taking into account the entire travel cycle, from planning to ticket purchase , and to identify and resolve, in a proportionate manner, the problems of distributing revenue stemming from ticket sales and the allocation of costs in the event of a dispute between the Contracting Parties. However, it considers that these solutions should be developed in a market-oriented manner and calls on the Commission to promote strongly through EU co-financing synergies in this area between trans-European telecommunications and transport networks. In other words, it is part of a logic of privatization of the public transport service that we advocate and which has been gradually destroyed throughout the integration process.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have supported this proposal, as the creation of multimodal integrated tickets offers a great deal of opportunities for travellers. In addition to the clear declaration of taxes and levies and the limitation of credit card fees, the First and Last Mile scheme is also a welcome innovation.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote is on a report from the Transport committee on the implementation of ticketing that works across different modes of transport. It highlights the positive steps that the EU can take to improve the passenger experience and make booking journeys easier. It is particularly important to make sure that passengers with reduced mobility are able to make travel bookings without unnecessary inconvenience, for instance by reserving wheelchair spaces or station assistance. The report also supports the establishment of a Charter of Passenger Rights, with clear and transparent rules for passengers taking multimodal journeys (e.g. if a bus journey connecting to a train journey is delayed). Labour MEPs voted for this report because passengers in Europe deserve easy-to-use ticketing systems, and more rights in transit.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report we adopted today aims to implement an integrated multimodal system for transport in Europe by improving information services, planning and distribution of multimodal tickets. The long-term goal is to allow travelers to choose, book and pay online for a personalized travel solution that represents the most sustainable, fast or cost-effective alternative and to get on the road with a single ticket, regardless of the number of modes of transport used during the journey. The implementation of such information systems is certainly an important step forward for travelers who increasingly use the internet and smartphones. A key step towards achieving a citizen-oriented and sustainable transport system for safe, efficient and effective urban mobility.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report on "the provision of an integrated ticketing system for multimodal travel in Europe" seeks to enhance competitiveness and "open up" new areas of profitability for monopolies by promoting, inter alia, the "combined use of various means of transport with a single ticket", "real-time information transmission systems". As long as the transport sector remains in the hands of business groups, grassroots families are being groaned by rising travel costs, while the connection to remote areas is shrinking with multiple consequences for residents' lives. The electronic file of passengers is also generalized by processing their personal and traffic data.  The way out lies in another society and organisation of the economy, with socialisation of means of production, with central national scientific planning both in the transport sector and everywhere on the basis of meeting social needs and not profit. With labour distribution and work for all, taking advantage of the socialised sector of industry, planning for interconnected and complementary transport operation (road, air, etc.) will benefit the people with the aim of quickly and cheaply moving people and products, saving energy, balanced intervention in the environment, planned development to eliminate regional imbalance , full control of the defence and security of the socialist state.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly support the introduction of an integrated ticketing system for journeys in Europe involving several types of means of transport. I believe that such an initiative will contribute to the sustainability of European air, rail, shipping and road transport. Simplification of interstate services and better information will also be of great benefit to passengers.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I welcome the report on the introduction of an integrated ticketing system in Europe. This is an attempt to respond to the growing challenges in European transport policy. We have increasing problems with transport congestion, with increasing traffic jams and, on the other hand, with the need to protect the environment and maintain the viability of transport. In Europe, the structure of transport services is deteriorating. A growing number of travellers are using aircraft, which is understandable, but also passenger cars, which exacerbates traffic jams and destroys the environment. Only 8.2% of all travellers in Europe and 6.5% of all passengers travel on buses.  In this situation, an integrated ticket would increase the chances of using different modes of transport. Travellers would have to have up-to-date information to choose the fastest or cheapest travel option, book and pay for one ticket online, and then travel regardless of mode of transport. This is a good direction for exploration, which is why I support this report.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Freedom of movement in the European Union is a privilege to which we are all already accustomed. The lack of borders encourages citizens of Member States to travel across the continent for both professional and tourist purposes.  However, despite many modern technologies and digitalisation, the movement of different modes of transport between different countries is still very cumbersome. Different ticketing systems, different forms of payment and a lack of reliable information on travel times or timetables are the biggest obstacles faced by passengers in the EU.  The creation of a multimodal integrated ticketing system in the European Union will break these restrictions and facilitate door-to-door travel in Europe by booking only one ticket. This will reduce the time spent on administrative procedures for purchasing different tickets, speed up travel planning and organisation and encourage more travellers to use rail or water transport on cross-border journeys. I voted in favour of this report because, in my opinion, the EU's main task should be to facilitate citizens' lives and remove unnecessary barriers between Member States. The creation of a common ticketing system integrating different modes of transport will be a great facilitation, which will undoubtedly improve the travel comfort of the citizens of the Member States.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The non-binding resolution adopted today by a large majority in the European Parliament is a first step in the right direction to enable European citizens, in the near future, to be able to buy a single ticket for a 'multimodal journey', using different modes of transport. An integrated ticket to travel across EU borders that allows more modes of transport to be used could also increase the use of public transport, with clear benefits for the environment. I therefore hope that the technological advances of recent years will soon make it possible to carry out this project, which is primarily intended to make life easier for travellers.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. What we consider negative is that this project aims to deepen the path of liberalisation and privatisation of the transport sector and the inevitable monopolistic concentration that always comes to it. This is evidenced by the references to the fourth railway package, the single European transport area or the single European sky. Including some logical and relevant considerations about multi-modality and the ease of transport and travel planning in Europe, it is a pity that these appear to be the cover covering up the actual desiderates of the report, which seem to fall within the framework of the International Agreement on Trade and Services (TISA). For the rest, not a word in relation to attacks on the public transport system, such as those currently underway in Portugal, driven by the EU, aimed at privatising public transport. This was after the attack under the IMF-EU aggression programme, which brutally increased the price of transport, reduced supply and degraded the quality of service.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the extension on the Special Commission on Tax Resolutions as it addresses a crucial problem for the European Union, which is the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, as well as unfair tax competition within the internal market.
