This committee needs more time to complete its work, so that a full report can be obtained that incorporates an ambitious package of recommendations. Revelations of the LuxLeaks scandal have highlighted that certain Member States erode the rest's tax bases through confidential tax rulings agreed with individuals (known as 'tax rulings'). The European Commission has proposed in this regard an automatic and mandatory system for the exchange of information between Member States which the European Socialists strongly support, as well as the revival of the initiative to harmonise the corporate tax base.  Taxation should not be a closed burden where some States commit all kinds of abuses and bad practices, under the pretext of being part of sovereign competences. The Union is a community of law in which Member States must operate in accordance with the principle of loyalty and collaboration.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this extension because of the fundamental importance of this committee of the European Parliament in clarifying the agreements reached with European multinationals in the LuxLeaks case. This special commission was established in the face of the leak of that information, which directly targeted European multinationals and governments which signed anti-competitive agreements. Because there are no powers in the tax field, this is the only aspect that can be pursued at European level; however, the information extracted in the investigations should be critical to the prosecution of multinationals and those responsible who have signed these agreements. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this extension.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The Special Committee on Member States' tax rulings was set up in February 2015 to provide information on all Member States' tax rulings and to explore ways to end unfair tax practices and combat tax evasion in the European Union. The Committee therefore endeavours to ensure transparency in tax rulings. Parliament initially set up the committee for six months. However, in order not to leave questions unanswered on this important and complex issue, his mandate has been extended, which I very much welcome.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This matter was not subject to a vote; I did not raise an objection because I recognise that six months is insufficient to consider 20 years of taxation across 28 countries.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. As European news has not allowed the commission to conduct its good conduct, its mandate and duration should be extended in order to achieve its objectives.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a specific extension of the mandate of the Committee on Tax Rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. It was necessary to be able to extend the special committee on tax rulings by a few months in order to have sufficient time to finalise the work in progress. It is indeed important to use all available levers and information to move the lines and put an end to massive tax evasion that deprives the public of substantial revenues at a time when citizens are hard hit by austerity policies.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. On Thursday, February 12, the creation of a special commission on tax rulings and similar measures by their nature or effect with 45 members and installed for a period of 6 months was decided.  The purpose of this special committee is "to examine the practices relating to tax rulings from 1 January 1991, but also the way in which the European Commission deals with state aid in EU countries and their level of transparency with regard to tax rulings. It will also seek to determine the negative impact of aggressive tax planning on public finances and will present its recommendations for the future."   The vote calls for the extension of the commission until 30 November 2015. I decided to vote for it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of extending the mandate of the Special Committee on Early Tax Decisions set up in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal involving Luxembourg and Juncker.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. On the basis of Article 197 of the Regulation of the European Parliament and with the agreement of all political groups, I voted in favour of extending the mandate of the Special Commission on Tax Resolutions and Other Measures of Nature or Similar Effects (TAXE Commission).

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. It calls for the mandate of this special committee, which was set up following the LuxLeaks scandal involving Luxembourg and Juncker, to be extended.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agreed and voted in favour for the extension of the term of office of the Special Committee on tax rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the so-called LuxLeaks scandal involving Luxembourg and the current President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, for member states' tax ruling practices, the European Parliament decided to set up a special committee entitled TAXE on 12 February, initially for a period of six months. We have voted today to extend his term of office by a few months.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for an extension of the mandate of the Special Committee on Tax Rescripts and similar measures. The commission was set up in January to uncover problems related to abusive tax rescript practices within the EU, particularly in the wake of the revelations that led to the LuxLeaks scandal. Over the past six months, the Committee has conducted numerous hearings, including officials of the companies involved in the disputes, as well as investigations carried out in countries known to be in favour of such practices as Switzerland or Luxembourg. This work of transparency is necessary and it seems natural to give the committee an additional six months so that it can write its report and highlight the necessary conclusions.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Approved under Article 197 of the Rules of Procedure.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of extending the mandate of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and other similar measures by nature or effect. Pursuant to Rule 197 of the Rules of Procedure, known as the 'Setting up of special committees', Parliament shall, on a proposal from the Conference of Presidents, set up special committees whose term of office may not exceed 12 months, unless Parliament extends that period until it expires.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The extension for the special committee on the tax ruling was approved without a vote. It is felt that it should need more time, given the sensitive matter it is dealing with. According to Rule 197 of the Rules of Procedure, the term of office of these special committees, which are linked to specific powers fixed at the same time as they were set up, could not exceed twelve months unless Parliament extends this period to the deadline. I stress my view in favour of this extension.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this extension because of the fundamental importance of this committee of the European Parliament in clarifying the agreements reached with European multinationals in the LuxLeaks case. This special commission was established in the face of the leak of that information, which directly targeted European multinationals and governments which signed anti-competitive agreements. Because there are no powers in the tax field, this is the only aspect that can be pursued at European level; however, the information extracted in the investigations should be critical to the prosecution of multinationals and those responsible who have signed these agreements. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this extension.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the call for extending the mandate of the European Parliament’s TAXE Committee, a Special Committee on Tax rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect, for another six months.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The purpose of this vote is to extend the mandate of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and similar measures by their nature or effect, originally created for six months. I had supported the establishment of such a commission, the aim of which is to uncover the tax practices of the Member States of the European Union, to make concrete proposals to put an end to abuses in this area, in particular on the homogenisation of corporate taxation in Europe. Considering that this committee has already done important work and has tackled a central political issue, since the lack of tax harmonisation at European level can create a situation where the tax decisions of one Member State lead to tax shortfalls or a reduction in tax or tax in another Member State, I believe that the work of this committee should be extended , chaired by my colleague Alain Lamassoure, President of the French delegation to the European People's Party. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. While the European Commission has launched several investigations into tax rulings since the end of 2014, MEPs wanted to join this dynamic. A special parliamentary committee was set up on 12 February 2015. It is mandated to examine the compatibility of tax rulings and similar measures with EU state aid and tax law. Tax rulings are anticipatory tax rulings on a company, thereby guaranteeing it legal certainty in relation to the tax. This practice can fuel tax competition between states that are harmful to public accounts. The commission's work was originally planned for six months; this period has been extended to allow him to conduct further hearings and to make a full report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against extending the mandate of the Special Committee as its performance to date (a typical example of luxembourg's tax haven) is unacceptable.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am, of course, in favour of extending the mandate of the TAXE Committee, whose task has been and will be to shed light on the tax practices of all Member States and to examine ways of combating unfair tax practices and tax evasion in the European Union. The task of this special committee, set up in January 2015, seems crucial in the context of a monetary union which, in reality, has many differences within it and in which corruption and evasion practices seem to be normal.  As a side note, I would have liked to add that it would have been ironic to discuss the outcome of this special committee during the Luxembourg Presidency, a country which is the symbol of a major financial scandal over facts designed under the Jucker Presidency.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 At the time of the scandal that became known as "Luxleaks", involving the current President of the European Commission, we proposed a parliamentary committee of inquiry to investigate in detail the intricacies and implications of it, a proposal that was rejected by the majority groups of Parliament, namely the right and social democracy. In the face of what has been known – the conclusion of secret agreements with multinationals by the Government and tax authorities in Luxembourg in order to spare them due payment of taxes – and in the face of pressure from public opinion, the majority of Parliament eventually accepted the establishment of a temporary parliamentary committee on "advance tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect". A clear sign that they were aiming little more than shaking up public pressure because the six-month period proposed for the commission to operate (including August) was manifestly insufficient. To that extent, this extension was expected and necessary and we supported it. The practice of collusion between tax administrations and large multinationals is increasingly notorious in order to exempt them from paying taxes, a widespread practice that binds most EU governments and the parties that support them.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I confirm my support for extending the mandate to this special committee that was set up in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 In any case, my vote is negative because of the unacceptable performance of this committee in its work to date, with the luxembourg tax haven as a prime example.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the extension of the term of office of the Special Committee on Tax rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the extension on the Special Commission on Tax Resolutions as it addresses a crucial problem for the European Union, which is the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, as well as unfair tax competition within the internal market. This committee needs more time to complete its work, so that a full report can be obtained that incorporates an ambitious package of recommendations. Revelations of the LuxLeaks scandal have highlighted that certain Member States erode the rest's tax bases through confidential tax rulings agreed with individuals (known as 'tax rulings'). The European Commission has proposed in this regard an automatic and mandatory system for the exchange of information between Member States which the European Socialists strongly support, as well as the revival of the initiative to harmonise the corporate tax base.  Taxation should not be a closed burden where some States commit all kinds of abuses and bad practices, under the pretext of being part of sovereign competences. The Union is a community of law in which Member States must operate in accordance with the principle of loyalty and collaboration.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of extending the mandate of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect, because I believe that the work of this special committee and its impetus for greater tax justice in Europe are important. Citizens and small and medium-sized enterprises pay their taxes in good spirits. We must not allow ourselves to be demonstrated by international corporations.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this extension and await its findings with interest.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the extension of the mandate of the Committee on Special Tax Rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect, as I believe that the work started must be carried out qualitatively and completed.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that for the TAXE Committee to be effective it needs to have a realistic timeframe to complete its activities. This involves hearings with stakeholders, national parliaments and delegations to certain Member States. The rapporteurs should be given the time to come up with a fair and balanced final report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted to extend the mandate of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect so that the Committee could proceed smoothly and achieve the objectives for which it was established. Unfair tax practices need to be put to an end and the fight against tax evasion across the European Union should be strengthened. I therefore believe that the Committee can improve the transparency and effectiveness of tax rulings and am therefore inclined to extend its mandate, as provided for in Article 197 TEU. The rules of procedure.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of extending the special committee on tax rulings. This commission, chaired by Alain Lamassoure, aims to study the tax rulings of the various Member States and thus avoid excessive optimisation and tax evasion by multinationals as much as possible. The European Parliament has voted in favour of extending this committee, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The TAXE Committee is doing important work in investigating the Lux Leaks scandal and in the context of recommendations for a fair tax system. I am voting in favour of extending the mandate of this committee.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. On the basis of Article 197 of parliament's Rules of Procedure and with the agreement of all political groups, Parliament votes to extend the mandate of the TAXE Commission for a few months. Agreeing with these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this extension because of the fundamental importance of this committee of the European Parliament in clarifying the agreements reached with European multinationals in the LuxLeaks case. This special commission was established in the face of the leak of that information, which directly targeted European multinationals and governments which signed anti-competitive agreements. Because there are no powers in the tax field, this is the only aspect that can be pursued at European level; however, the information extracted in the investigations should be critical to the prosecution of multinationals and those responsible who have signed these agreements. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this extension.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ After the detected opaque and unfair tax treatments of individual Member States that were given to large international companies, thus distorting the tax bases of other Member States and the European Union single market, the European Parliament established a Special Committee on Tax Rulings and other measures of a similar nature or impact (TAXE) in Strasbourg on 12 February. Taxe aims to investigate tax rules, State aid schemes and similar measures in all Member States from 1991 to the present, to organise hearings in which representatives of the European Commission responsible for tax matters, representatives of member states' tax administrations, the private sector and representatives of other interested groups will participate in order to help find solutions to unfair tax practices and aggressive tax planning. Following the investigation, taxe should present concrete measures to help Member States improve cooperation between tax administrations in exchanging tax data, preventing aggressive tax planning, double non-taxation, but also taxation. Since the EP supported the establishment of the TAXE Committee in February and the length of its term of office of six months, I supported the extension of taxe's mandate until 30 November 2015, as decided at the Conference of Presidents at the end of June in order for taxe to fulfil its tasks assigned to it by the mandate.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of extending the mandate of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect, in order to continue the investigation and shed light on the practice followed in the application of EU State aid and tax law in relation to tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect taken by Member States.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the extension of the term of office of the Special Committee on ‘Tax rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect’ in order that it might complete its work.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Luxleaks case on the tax rulings in Luxembourg was revealed in November 2014. A special committee in charge of the case was set up by Parliament in February 2015. Its mandate is to examine the practices of tax rulings from 1 January 1991, as well as the european Commission's handling of state aid in EU countries and their level of transparency.  It also seeks to determine the negative impact of aggressive tax planning on public finances.  Under Rule 197, special committees are set up for a 12-month term, renewable by Parliament. As its work has not been completed, I vote for the continuation of the mandate of this committee.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the importance of the matter in question, I have presented my positive vote to the extension of the mandate granted to the special committee on tax rulings and other measures of the same nature or effect.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the idea of extending the term of office of the Special Committee on Tax rulings for another six months, so this way it has more time to make a comprehensive report and to continue with its investigations.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The SPECIAL committee TAXE conducted a significant number of hearings during its first six months of its existence and travelled to several countries as part of its mission on tax rulings in Europe.  The mass of information to be gathered and the time to organize these debates make it necessary to extend the mandate of the special commission in order to allow it to finalize its report by the end of 2015.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of extending the mandate of the special committee on tax rulings. Created in February 2015, the commission checks whether state aid is compatible with internal market rules and examines whether it is being unfairly allocated. It also examines the tax regimes applied to companies in Member States and sees whether fictitious transfers of profits within business groups could lead to tax cuts. It has an obligation to present its findings and recommendations in a final report.

name: n/a
text: in writing. – I have voted for the extension of the term of office of the Special Committee on Tax rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect, according to the report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. This is an extension procedure.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of extending the mandate of the Special Committee on Early Tax Decisions because careful monitoring is needed to ensure that Member States do not implement special tax regimes to favour large companies. I hope that this committee will have the opportunity to operate without external influences and that the Member States will cooperate without putting obstacles in the way.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ By a Decision of the European Parliament, on 12 February 2015, a Special Committee was established for tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature and effect under Article 197 TB. Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament. The article speaks of the right to establish special committees whose powers, composition and duration of the mandate are determined simultaneously with the adoption of the decision on their establishment. The Committee was set up on the proposal of the Conference of Presidents and by a Commission decision to explore the practice of tax rulings in accordance with EU State aid rules in all Member States. It consists of 45 members, has a mandate of six months from the date of its adoption of that decision, and aims primarily to shed light on the way Member States tax in order to avoid unfair taxation practices and to combat tax evasion in the European Union.  As I believe that this Committee can contribute to fair taxation practices within the Member States of the European Union through its actions and thus to improving and developing the economic picture of the Union itself, I supported the extension of its mandate. The existence of a Special Committee on Tax Rulings and other measures of a similar nature and impact is a logical way to achieve the EU's objectives and prevent activities that could jeopardise them.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Luxleaks scandal did not give rise to a strong enough reaction. Any measures that could prolong the mission of the special committee is therefore welcome, because this committee must be able to uncover the mechanisms that have enabled such a system of tax evasion to develop in this way for such a long period of time. At a time when the Union is imposing unbearable austerity on peoples, it is essential that it reform itself and do not encourage unfair practices among its own members. That is why I am voting in favour of extending the mandate of the special committee.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Since tax evasion continues to be significant losses for member states' financial budgets and consequently the European Union, I support the decision to extend the mandate of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and other measures. So far, this Committee has demonstrated through its work that it deserves an extension of its mandate and further tackles all the problems mentioned above.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. On the basis of Article 197 of the Regulation of the European Parliament and with the agreement of all political groups, I voted in favour of extending the mandate of the Special Commission on Tax Resolutions and Other Measures of Nature or Similar Effects (TAXE Commission).

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)

text: in writing. ‒ I am supportive of this committee and await its findings with interest.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the fiscal sphere, I support three fundamental approaches: fairness, fairness and transparency.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The aim is simply to codify existing legislation without the possibility of amending it. The existing legislation is empty and we do not agree with it as a whole.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of extending the term of office of the TAXE Committee. The committee, which I was also a substitute member, was entrusted with a very large-scale and important task, since it had to examine the member states' tax rules going back to 1991. In addition, the Committee has listened to a number of stakeholders in recent months, spoken out to ensure legal protection for whistleblowers and sent a fact-finding delegation to several countries where they met with finance ministers, tax experts and representatives of NGOs. The Board has undertaken to carry out a niche and indispensable work, but unfortunately the six-month mandate is not enough to prepare the recommendations and measures needed to stop tax fraud, tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning within the EU. More time is needed to address deep-seated problems, so it is of the utmost importance that the TAXE Special Committee continues its work.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. On the advice of our experts in the Socialist and Democratic Group, I followed the colleagues and voted positively on the extension of the mandate of the special committee on tax rulings and other similar measures by their nature or effect.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the extension of the mandate of the TAXE Committee. The work of the committee is essential to highlight bad practices of Member States and develop sustainable solutions to avoid this kind of behaviour happening again in the future.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the request to extend the mandate of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect, established on 12 February 2015.  In my view, this Committee is of utmost importance to citizens of individual Member States of the Union, as its members are tasked with investigating allegations that some States have benefited international corporations through special tax advantages.  Given the ongoing investigations launched by the Commission and the journalists' revelations concerning alleged illegal practices, I believe that the public has a great interest in this area and deserves a transparent tax system. In addition to this study of tax rulings taken in the Member States since 1991, I believe that the role of this Committee in examining the way the European Commission treats states and their existing state aid programmes is also important for the protection of citizens. Therefore, I voted to extend the mandate.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the extension of the mandate of the TAXE Special Committee. In accordance with the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, Parliament may at any time set up special committees, on a proposal from the Conference of Presidents, whose powers, composition and term of office shall be determined at the time of the adoption of the decision establishing them. Their term of office may not exceed 12 months unless it is extended by Parliament after the expiry of. The European Parliament therefore decides on the extension of the mandate to the Special Committee on Tax Decisions and Other Measures of a similar nature or with similar taxe effect, of which I am also a member. Given its important role, it is crucial that the committee continues to work.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in this vote because, despite our disagreement with the Juncker Plan and although we have already opposed EFSI itself on previous occasions, we believe that this correction does not alter the nature of the fund, either to improve it or to make it worse. Draft amending budget No 5/2015 - Response to migration pressures

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this extension as this important issue has to be tackled with full insight on the situation in all Member States regarding tax rulings and fiscal avoidance.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the extension of the mandate of the TAXE Commission, of which I am a member, while noting that the time limit granted to the special committee was insufficient, which makes it foreseeable that there may be more extensions in the future.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Against our initial proposal to set up a committee of inquiry to investigate tax-rulings, the European Parliament only approved the establishment of a special committee with a six-month term, which included the month of August. It was known from the outset that the time was insufficient. To this extent, this extension was expectation and necessary in view of the importance of the issue, which increasingly shows that the practice of collusion between tax administrations and large multinationals to exempt them from paying taxes is a widespread practice that binds the majority of EU governments and the parties that support them.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I, together with my group, voted in favour of extending the term of office of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and other measures of a similar nature. The Committee Coordinators of the Special Committee (TAXE) decided in May to extend the work of the Subcommittee on Taxation. The vote on the final report of the TAXE Committee will take place on 15 October, in accordance with the updated timetable. The European Parliament will vote on the report in the November plenary session.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 After the 'no' vote in plenary on EFSI (European Fund for Strategic Investments) in plenary on 24 June, we have today voted on amending budget No 1. This budget will make it possible to launch the EFSI, thanks to the first guarantee tranche with EUR 1360 million. Both in the BUDG Committee and in plenary we are opposed to the approach chosen.  The guarantee funds were found from the following European Funds: EUR 700 million from the Connecting European Facility (CEF) programme, EUR 500 million from the ITER programme and to a lesser extent from Horizon 2020. It is not acceptable that the decision to reinstate these funds is not certain, and it is only emphasised in the text that everything possible will be done to reintegrate them in the near future. We do not believe that reducing the funds allocated to European programmes, which have already been structured, is the best way to establish a new investment project. For these reasons, we voted against.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it entails the adoption of cuts in key research and infrastructure programmes to enable the development of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. This Fund is a guarantee for private investors in line with the European Bond Investment Bank Initiative Europe 2020. In order to promote this Juncker Plan, the Commission has decided to cut into significant public programmes such as the Connecting Europe Facility. My opposition to this plan which will support European speculators, rather than the real economy and the European industrial structure, has been frontal, and that is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF)
text: Written. \u2012 The EFSI Investment Fund is a large-scale project to re-build the economic engine in EU countries. The aim is to attract private investment through the Juncker Fund. In reality, it will turn out that this is a raunchy public fund, keynesian in nature, in which massive investments are financed with taxpayers' money. This fund is causing a bloodletting to the citizens. It is not just EUR 16 billion in guarantees that citizens have to cough up. The EFSI texts clearly state that public and semi-public partners are also encouraged to use the fund on a large scale for expensive and risky public investments. The cost to taxpayers will therefore be much higher than the initial 16 billion in guarantees. That seems to be just about everyone, willfully or not, overlooked. It is noble that some are trying to save what remains to be saved, by trying to keep money from, for example, Horizon 2020, money for research and development, out of EFSI. However, if the house is completely on fire, there is little point in wanting to save furniture. I am therefore totally opposed to this megalomaniacal Juncker Fund and everything and everyone who is most concerned with the logic behind it.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) was created as part of the European Commission's Investment Plan. This plan is intended to enable investments of EUR 315 billion in the future. The EFSI aims to address the investment backlog in Europe and contribute to the creation of growth and new jobs. The correction of the budget provides the EFSI with the necessary instruments to fulfil its purposes.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. It is a question of budgeting the resources needed for the implementation of the European Fund for Strategic Investment. I am opposed to the very mechanism of the EFSI, which I consider dangerous and counterproductive. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The Juncker plan is an imaginative attempt at financing projects, but it is fundamentally flawed.  Furthermore, it requires additional investment from the Member States and therefore an increase in taxpayers’ money would be required.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. In all coherence, I vote in favour of the budgetary transcript of the decisions voted in the previous plenary session.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which has a target of EUR 1.36 billion in commitment appropriations and EUR 10 million in commitment appropriations. Eur 100 million in payment appropriations for the financing of the Junker Guarantee Fund.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This is the first budgetary change to feed the EFSI, which must be implemented as soon as possible to promote growth and employment. I voted in favour of this draft amending budget.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft amending budget is the budgetary counterpart to the adoption of the EFSI. It thus amends the 2015 budget and budgets the resources needed for the implementation of the EFSI. The European Fund for Strategic Investment is the backbone of Juncker's Investment Plan for Europe. Based on a 16 billion euro guarantee financed from the EU budget and a contribution of 5 billion euros from the EIB, it hopes to mobilize about three times more resources through the issuance of bonds used to attract other public or private investors. It is clear that this Fund is just an additional artifice. Indeed, leverage is overestimated and is therefore likely to be a failure like the 2012 Growth and Employment Pact. In addition, it risks creating a windfall for companies that will use the Fund when they had previously planned to invest. It would make more sense to engage in a real small business act for SMEs as is practiced in the United States and to revive the industrialization of the Union in order to get out of this spiral of unemployment and austerity. Having already opposed the EFSI itself, I voted against this text, which is only its budgetary counterpart.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft budget 1/2015 on the European Fund for Strategic Investments is a direct consequence of the approval of EFSI at the last plenary session; With today's 'no' vote on this report, I would like to reiterate my opposition to EFSI.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to technically integrate the agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments into the EU budget for 2015, with a view to providing the EIE Guarantee Fund with the necessary EUR 1.36 billion. In this way, the EESI can be launched by responding to our priority of reorienting European economic policy towards growth and investment, which is urgent in the situation facing the Union.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because amending budget No 1/2015 aims to transpose the necessary amendments into the budget nomenclature, in accordance with the provisions of the legislative agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). The European Parliament welcomes the fact that the decision of all the institutions to ensure that the EFSI starts to function as soon as possible has led to a rapid agreement on this fund. Although the outcome of the negotiations is better than the Commission's original proposal, it regrets the negative impact on Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility. In addition, Parliament regrets the overall transfer of funds from the Connecting Europe Facility and Horizon 2020, as they are the main programmes for employment and growth in Europe. The European Parliament considers that investment in research and transport is essential to strengthen the role of the European Union budget and the objective of promoting growth, competitiveness and employment and to achieve the europe 2020 objectives.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of draft arrears No 1/2015 is to re-table the necessary changes to the budget nomenclature in accordance with the Legislative Agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (ESI) and to ensure the necessary redistribution of EUR 1360 million of commitment appropriations and EUR 10 million of payment appropriations. A total commitment appropriation of EUR 1 350 million will be realcted from the TPM (EUR 790 million), Horizon 2020 programme (EUR 70 million) and ITER (EUR 490 million) in order to replenish the Guarantee Fund in 2015. On the basis of the above, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 Draft amending budget No 1/2015 aims to transpose the necessary amendments to the budgetary nomenclature in accordance with the legislative agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). It is at the core of the programme, which is supposed to provide new employment through investment promotion, so swift approval of the amending budget is necessary. Unfortunately, despite our great efforts, we have failed to fully keep horizon 2020 intact, but the proceeds are much better than in the primary proposals. I nevertheless supported the report.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I am a supporter of the European Fund for Strategic Investments and I believe that it is a fundamental instrument for reviving growth in the European Union.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. This is the change in the budget following the approval of the EFSI (June II part-session) to ensure its initial financing for 2015. This is not "fresh" money but mainly taken from Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Mechanism (CEM). The vote against already given on the EFSI is confirmed.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Section III - Commission, which accompanies the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and amending Regulations (EU) No. 1291/2013 and 1316/2013. The report in question, by adopting amending budget No 1/2015 as amended by the Council in line with the legislative agreement on EFSI, gave its green light for EFSI to become operational as soon as possible. I am therefore pleased to note that the Community institutions have been able to reach agreement on EFSI as quickly as possible. I now hope that this instrument will be able to cope with the endemic lack of investment in the European Union, putting them back at the centre of Community policies in order to increase the competitiveness of the Member States.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The Juncker plan is an imaginative attempt at financing projects, but it is fundamentally flawed. Furthermore, it requires additional investment from the Member States and therefore an increase in taxpayers’ money would be required.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of amending budget 1/2015 as it introduces changes to the budget nomenclature for EFSI by creating new budget lines and provides for the necessary resources for this important guarantee fund for 2015. No changes are introduced to this amending budget and the extra funds will be financed through the Global Multiannual Financial Framework margin for commitments, which will be made available as of 2016.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the first amending budget that would allow the EFSI to start. Much of the resources are expected to be found from programmes such as CEF and ITER and, to a lesser extent, horizon 2020 and others. Among the destinations of the resources themselves is the financing of the European investment advisory centre, a body whose expensive establishment is not necessary, as we have previously expressed. I have therefore voted against.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this draft amending budget, which aims to budget for the resources needed to implement the European Fund for Strategic Investment. Such a fund is in fact only an admission of the Commission's inability to finance investments and also takes the form of quasi-blackmail to Member States: they are promised to extract their contribution to FIES from the calculation of their deficit. The result is that the Juncker plan will be favoured in the face of European structural funds and State/Region project contracts. In other words, we are taking the risk of diverting the funding of national public policies to the FIES, all for fear of being slapped on the fingers by Brussels in its consideration of national budgets. This new commission manoeuvre is mainly a testament to its inability to finance itself and, as a result, its willingness to re-strip Member States.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 On the Council's position on the draft amending budget, and bearing in mind that it aims to transpose the necessary changes to the budget nomenclature in accordance with the legislative agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments and to ensure the necessary reallocating of EUR 1,360 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 10 million in payment appropriations, I consider my positive support to be beneficial.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft amending budget for the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). the fund's draft regulation provides for the creation of an EU guarantee fund which can be used to pay the European Investment Bank (EIB) in the event of recourse to the EU guarantee. The amount of the Guarantee Fund will be progressively increased to reach the target of EUR 8 billion, or 50% of the total EU guarantee (EUR 16 billion). Instead, appropriations from the EU general budget will be phased in by 2020.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 1/2015 as it allows a structure to be created in the EU budget to cover the Guarantee Fund allocation in 2015. I believe that EFSI is an important step towards a concrete recovery of the economy in Europe. This vote will allow a redistribution of EUR 1360 million in commitment appropriations precisely for the Guarantee Fund in 2015 and will also allow eur 10 million to be transferred to payment appropriations that will go to finance the European Investment Advisory Centre and the European Investment Projects Portal. I therefore welcome the fact that the institutions have been determined to reach an agreement quickly, as it will make it possible to ensure the operation of EFSI as soon as possible. This fund aims to attract investments that benefit the real economy over the next three years and is the core of President Junker's investment plan. We must therefore ensure that the implementation process is not hampered and, if anything, do our part in such a way as to make it operational soon.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 1/2015 aims to insert the necessary changes in the budget nomenclature in accordance with the legislative agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI, better known as the "Juncker Plan") and to provide for the necessary reallocation of EUR 1 360 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 10 million in payment appropriations. I therefore welcome the adoption of this report which allows the EFSI to be launched as soon as possible, while regretting the negative impact on Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft amending budget aims to make changes to the 2015 budget nomenclature in order to ensure the operation of the European Investment Fund. At the same time, it guarantees the coverage of the financial envelope of the 2015 Guarantee Fund, providing for the necessary allocation of appropriations. Therefore, in welcoming this proposal, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ There is a constant need to support these investments as they add value to society both through jobs and skills, as well as by being conscious of our surroundings. It is obviously of importance to create a proper budget for the EFSI to be effective and this budget must be there to stimulate growth and to promote competitiveness and employment. This fund must be subject to transparency and accountability measures, so as to ensure that the fund is being used in the proper manner. This fund is a positive one and we must continue to strive to better serve the businesses concerned. This fund is important for states where there are SMEs as it will help these businesses to grow and to prosper.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it entails the adoption of cuts in key research and infrastructure programmes to enable the development of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. This Fund is a guarantee for private investors in line with the European Bond Investment Bank Initiative Europe 2020. In order to promote this Juncker Plan, the Commission has decided to cut into significant public programmes such as the Connecting Europe Facility. My opposition to this plan which will support European speculators, rather than the real economy and the European industrial structure, has been frontal, and that is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal is to technically integrate the EFSI agreement in the already adopted EU Budget 2015 in order to provide the necessary EUR 1 360 million for the EFSI Guarantee Fund in 2015. The content of DAB 1/2015 completely follows the EFSI agreement found between EP and Council, which has been already adopted in Plenary. As I have worked directly on the EFSI dossier at the ENVI committee I understand the importance of this allocation and this is why I supported it through my vote.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe is and must remain a leading player in the international market in promoting sustainable innovation and skills and creating new local jobs, which is why I welcome the Commission's proposal for the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), which can contribute, by supporting strategic investments, to boosting the competitiveness of the European Union and achieving the objective of smart economic growth sustainable and inclusive.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This amending budget report proposes to amend the budget for 2015 to take into account the agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). Budgetary translation of the draft voted last month by the European Parliament and the Council, this report grants 1.36 billion euros in commitment appropriations and 10 million euros in payment credits to the EFSI. This is not an increase in the European budget, since all funds are redeployed from other budget lines, including those of the European Mechanism for the Interconnection of Europe, Horizon 2020, the ITER programme, as well as budgetary margins. Considering that it is essential that the Juncker Plan be operational as soon as possible in order to finance strategic growth projects and to support the investment and development of European SMEs and medium-cap companies, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. At the plenary session on 24 June, we voted to create the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). We hope that it will raise EUR 315 billion for investment projects in the European Union over the period 2015-2017. The first step on this path has been validated: 1360 million euros of commitment credits and 10 million in payment will be released, in order to feed the EFSI guarantee fund for the 2015 financial year.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the political agreement on the EFSI regulation reached between the European Parliament and the Council, the Latvian Presidency has proposed amending draft amending budget (PBR) No 1/2015. The changes are intended to create coverage of the Guarantee Fund's allocation in 2015. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the proposal to amend the draft amending budget.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The EU budget must, in line with previous budgets, put forward investment and in particular the Juncker plan, without cutting certain programmes such as Erasmus or Horizon 2020. This is a necessary balance to be struck between investment and budgetary rigour. The implementation of the Investment Plan for Europe (EFSI) is one of the challenges of this mandate. We will be judged on its success.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this draft amending budget, which aims to transpose the necessary changes to the budget nomenclature, in accordance with the legislative agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments, and to provide for the reallocation of EUR 1.36 billion in commitment appropriations and EUR 10 million in payment credits.  While I am very pleased that an agreement on the EFSI has been quickly reached thanks to the willingness of all institutions to implement it as soon as possible, I deplore the negative impact on the Horizon 2020 programme and the interconnection in Europe in view of the importance of these programmes for jobs and growth in Europe. I am pleased, however, that an additional EUR 1 billion compared to the Commission's original proposal will be financed by the overall margin of the MFF for commitments, thereby reducing the amount to be redeployed from the Interconnection Programme in Europe and Horizon 2020.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The draft arrears no. 1/2015 aim to move the necessary changes to the budget nomenclature in accordance with the Legislative Agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (ESI) and to ensure the necessary redistribution of EUR 1 360 million of commitment appropriations and EUR 10 million of payment appropriations. A total commitment appropriation of EUR 1 350 million will be realcted from the TPM (EUR 790 million), Horizon 2020 programme (EUR 70 million) and ITER (EUR 490 million) in order to replenish the Guarantee Fund in 2015. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament’s resolution welcomes the agreement reached on EFSI but indicates that CEF and Horizon 2020 are essential programmes for jobs and growths in Europe and therefore sends a signal to the other institutions that Parliament will seek to remedy these redeployments in the upcoming annual budgetary procedures. The content of DAB 1 needs to follow the agreement found with Council on the legislative file which was adopted by Council on 19 June with a small change in nomenclature only, in line with the overall agreement. The legislative file was adopted by Parliament on 24 June. EFSI will be established during the summer of 2015 within the European Investment Bank by means of an agreement between the European Commission and the bank (‘EFSI agreement’).

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on draft amending budget No 1/2015 of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) because I support the idea of creating an additional mechanism to encourage investment in our country. The economic crisis has led to a sharp drop in investment across Europe, necessitate a common and coordinated effort at European level to achieve europe's lasting economic growth. In the situation with countries such as Greece, Italy, Spain and Portugal, it is important to focus on fiscal responsibility. However, this is not enough and other mechanisms should be sought to stimulate those Member States, including Bulgaria, which follow strict fiscal policy and have a low deficit. The Investment Plan for Europe is at the heart of a long-term development strategy. Bulgaria participates in it with 100 million euros, but our country has control over what projects these funds go to, and can prioritize those of national importance. While we will not see the effects of this new strategy immediately, in the long term the idea is to increase private investment in our economy, and hence more and better paid jobs and a higher standard of living.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as tackling poverty and unemployment is not achieved by setting up funds, which are more a means of manipulating public opinion than solving the problem.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of draft arrears No 1/2015 is to re-table the necessary changes to the budget nomenclature in accordance with the Legislative Agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (ESI) and to ensure the necessary redistribution of EUR 1360 million of commitment appropriations and EUR 10 million of payment appropriations. A total commitment appropriation of EUR 1 350 million will be realcted from the TPM (EUR 790 million), Horizon 2020 programme (EUR 70 million) and ITER (EUR 490 million) in order to replenish the Guarantee Fund in 2015. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. I am sceptical about the value of the new EFSI Fund, especially given that the money is taken to some extent from forward-looking programmes with clear European added value such as Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe Facility. But now that the fund is made, we get to make the most of it, for example how it can be used for infrastructure in Sweden.

name: Édouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation, because European policy in this area undermines any national strategic investment strategy.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft Amending Budget (POR) No 1/2015 aims to amend the 2015 EU Budget following the approval and agreement on the EFSI (Juncker plan), a plan aimed at the interests of high finance and large companies, and maintains a scandalous focus on public-private partnerships. This amendment translates into a total amount of EUR 1 350 million, which will be reallocated from the Connecting Europe Facility (EUR 790 million), Horizon 2020 (EUR 70 million) and ITER (EUR 490 million) in commitment appropriations. Although it is only credit commitments and not payment appropriations which would mean that these programmes would be less summable, the fact is that this is not a response to the problems that countries face, as it is not the public investment plan that is actually needed. Our vote is therefore inseparable from our appreciation of the European Strategic Investment Fund itself.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1/2015 EFSI, as the aim of this proposal is to transpose the necessary changes to the budget nomenclature in accordance with the EFSI Legislative Agreement, thus allowing the necessary reallocation of EUR 1360 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 10 million in payment appropriations.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the change in the budget following the approval of the EFSI. As already pointed out, this is money withdrawn mainly at Horizon 2020 and CEM.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against draft amending budget No 1/2012. 1/2015: European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), because I believe that tackling poverty and unemployment is not achieved by setting up funds, which are more a means of manipulating public opinion than solving the problem.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ One of the roles of the Union budget is to create added value by pooling resources and ensuring a high degree of synergy between the European Structural and Investment Funds and EFSI while enhancing the multiplying effect of Union contributions. I therefore support the mobilisation of additional sources of private and public finance to fund investment on goals of a European dimension, in particular by addressing cross-border challenges in areas such as energy, environment and transport infrastructure.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of draft arrears No 1/2015 is to re-table the necessary changes to the budget nomenclature in accordance with the Legislative Agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (ESI) and to ensure the necessary redistribution of EUR 1360 million of commitment appropriations and EUR 10 million of payment appropriations. A total commitment appropriation of EUR 1 350 million will be realcted from the TPM (EUR 790 million), Horizon 2020 programme (EUR 70 million) and ITER (EUR 490 million) in order to replenish the Guarantee Fund in 2015. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. It was important to support this draft amending budget No 1 of 2015 (PPR No 1/2015) as it is linked to the agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIEF) which was approved last week by this House.   Its purpose is to technically integrate the EIE AGREEMENT into the EU budget for 2015 to provide the EIES Guarantee Fund with the EUR 1.36 billion needed for 2015. The content of PPR No 1/2015 translates in its entirety the agreement on EIEF reached by Parliament and the Council.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted yes to this draft budget as necessary and supplementary to the EFSI approval vote at the last plenary session. We have high hopes for this instrument and we hope that it will really mark the step towards European policies specifically aimed at reviving European competitiveness and employment.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of Draft Amending Budget No 1/2015: European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) because I consider the Fund to be an important tool to address the crisis and accelerate Europe's investment in states and regions.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I welcome both the positive result of the vote and the pace at which the EFSI agreement was reached. It was clear that all institutions were determined to be able to implement it as soon as possible.  I agree with the rapporteur's position on the need to mobilise additional sources of private and public funding for investments to achieve objectives with a European dimension. Tackling cross-border challenges in areas such as energy, environment and transport infrastructure will be crucial. I also welcomed the fact that an additional amount of EUR 1 billion compared to the commission's original proposal will be financed from the total margin of the Multiannual Financial Framework for Commitments and will come from the margins available under the 2014 budget and the 2015 budget. This will reduce shifts from the Connecting Europe Facility and Horizon 2020.  It is worth noting that the transfer of a total amount of EUR 1 350 million to commitments of EUR 790 million from the Connecting Europe Facility, EUR 70 million from Horizon 2020 and EUR 490 million from the ITER project will nevertheless be felt for these programmes. These programmes are important for creating new jobs and generating economic growth in Europe. I hope that the promises of compensation under future budgetary procedures will be kept fairly and in time.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Gardiazabal Rubial report given that draft amending budget no 1 creates the budgetary structure that will make European Funds for Strategic Investments possible. If the UK Government is ready to grasp this opportunity, it will create many billions of pounds-worth of investment into the UK economy; investments in infrastructure, SMEs and green growth. I welcome the agreement that no fresh money will be used, which proves the Commission is serious about its commitment to do more with less. I am, however, disappointed that despite improvements which I have been pushing for, some of the funds are still taken from a heading that covers competitiveness for growth and jobs, including Horizon 2020, and I encourage the Commission to find more money from other headings to reinforce this area which is vital for our economy.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. The Juncker Plan is a necessary proposal to boost investment in strategic sectors such as digital, research or energy. In front of the Commission and the Council, which aspired to finance the plan with money already budgeted for such important programmes as the Connecting Europe Facility or Horizon 2020, Parliament defended the need to find additional funds and managed to reduce the cuts in these programmes by EUR 1 billion. We therefore vote today in favour of a correction of the budget which we would have preferred to be different but which we accept as the lowest common denominator between the three institutions and which allows the launch of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which should serve to stimulate EU competitiveness and contribute to the Union's strategy for smart growth , sustainable and inclusive.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in this vote because, despite our disagreement with the Juncker Plan and although we have already opposed EEF itself on previous occasions, we consider that this correction does not alter the nature of the Fund, either to improve it or to make it worse.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs, including myself voted in favour of this report. This report will make EFSI possible. If Cameron’s government in the UK is ready to take this opportunity it will create many billions-worth of investment in the UK economy, in infrastructure, SMEs and green growth. The agreement that no fresh money will be used is also encouraging and it demonstrates the Commission is ready to do more with less. However it is regrettable that this funding has come from Heading 1a. We hope that in the mid-term review more funding will be found to reinforce this productive area.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Council position on draft amending budget No 1/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Section III – Commission annexed to the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Fund for Strategic Investments and amending Regulations (EU) No 1291/2013 and (EU) No 1316/2013. In this report, the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy calls on the Committee on Budgets, as the committee responsible, to incorporate in its motion for a resolution proposals calling for support for strategic investments with high economic and societal added value, promoting sustainable innovation, qualifications and local jobs, increasing the EU's competitiveness and contributing to the Union strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. I believe that this is very important in order to ensure the economic growth and stability of the EU.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. During the last parliamentary terms, the Socialists have fought for the sign of European economic policy to turn 180 degrees, against austericide and in favour of investment as a way to energize the economy and return to growth without undermining the European social model. We are now pleased that this work bears fruit and the prospects begin to change with a Commission which finally considers the European Parliament's claims and is committed to including investment as one of the pillars in its economic strategy.  The report technically integrates the EASI agreement reached with the Council into the EU budget for 2015, providing the EIES Guarantee Fund with the EUR 1.36 billion needed for 2015. FEIE is the first of the major initiatives in this legislature in this new line. It aims, on the basis of public funding that endorses projects in line with Union standards, to drag private capital and revive the economy in the EU, leading to smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, as well as quality job creation and improved economic, social and territorial cohesion. That's why I voted for it.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support draft amending budget No 1/2015 regarding the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) which makes the necessary budgetary changes to provide for the necessary reallocation of funds for EFSI for 2015. It is positive that EFSI was quickly agreed and adopted by all involved, however the redeployment of funds to Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility is regrettable given the important impact of both programmes for growth and jobs in the EU. Nonetheless these figures were improved at trialogue from the original proposal from the Commission and I welcome the additional EUR 1 000 million which will be financed through the Global MFF margin.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which represents the budgetary aspect of the EFSI agreement for 2015. These budgetary changes are necessary for the budget nomenclature for EFSI (by creating the new budget lines) and they will provide for the necessary resources for provisioning the EFSI guarantee fund in 2015.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. Today, the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) was voted on. It is intended to promote economic growth, employment and recovery in Europe. The new initiative promises to allow for new investments of EUR 315 billion over a three-year period, most of which will be financed by the private sector. What is not so clearly stated, however, is the fact that the European Investment Bank is liable for defaults. In concrete terms, this means that the taxpayer should be liable for the default risks of private entrepreneurs. Irrespective of these considerations, EFSI will fail anyway. It is inconceivable that a new authority could make better decisions than thousands of company bosses. If this task were to be taken seriously, thousands of civil servants would have to be recruited. This is a step towards more bureaucratisation. That is why I rejected the EFSI.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in this vote because, despite our disagreement with the Juncker Plan and although we have already opposed EEF itself on previous occasions, we consider that this correction does not alter the nature of the Fund, either to improve it or to make it worse.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Council Position Report on draft budget amendment No 2012. 1/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Part III- Commission, annexed to the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the European Fund for Strategic Investments and amending Regulation (EU) No 1/2015. 1291/2013 and (EU) No. 1316/2013 (09876/2015 - C8-0172/2015 -2015/2011(BUD)) as I support the Commission's proposal to establish a European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) to support strategic investments with high economic and social added value, promote sustainable innovation, skills and local jobs, foster EU competitiveness and contribute to the Union's strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.  This supports the implementation of the necessary changes in the budgetary nomenclature in accordance with the legislative agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the implementation of the necessary redistribution of EUR 1 360 million of commitment appropriations and EUR 10 million in payment appropriations. I believe that the effects of the European Fund for Strategic Investments will greatly outweigh the negative effects of the redistribution of funds from the Connecting Europe-Horizon 2020 Facility.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the amending budget which reallocates EUR 1.36 bn in funds within the European Union budget to kick start the European Fund for Strategic Investments. At a time of reluctance across the EU to invest due to the difficult economic climate, the EFSI should encourage public-private partnerships to flourish and unlock funds of up to EUR 315 bn in the next three years. It should lead to the improvement of infrastructure, including broadband and energy networks, provide vital financing for SMEs and get the continent growing again.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Eider Gardiazabal Rubial's report on the draft amending budget of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. This amending budget creates new budget lines by amending the budget nomenclature, thus providing the resources needed to supply the EFSI guarantee fund, more commonly known as the Juncker Plan. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the European Union's draft amending budget No. 1/2015 for the 2015 financial year accompanying the proposed regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). This amending budget amends the budget nomenclature by creating new budget lines and provides the resources needed to supply the EFSI so that it can be launched as soon as possible.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. To transfer surpluses from 2014 to the EFSI is not, in my view, targeted. Instead, surpluses are to be reimbursed pro rata to net contributors unless the full budget is used up. I am voting against the motion.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 7 July 2015, we voted on draft amending budget No 1/2015 for the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). The proposal to create a European Fund for Strategic Investments was said to be the "most important" proposal put forward by European Commission President Juncker in the formation of the new European Parliament. I have said several times that his plan, which he presented in January this year, is anything but a real investment plan. This plan is a caricature of a genuine investment plan, because it does not bring any new money into the system, does not bring much-needed and urgent policy change, nor does it contribute to broadening the trend of increased public investment. In my opinion, in particular, a genuine public investment plan had to be created through the issuance of new money from the ECB and the EIB. However, we were not actually presented with such a thing. However, given that only the draft amending budget was voted on, the European Fund for Strategic Investments already exists and therefore needs to be sorted out, and the current agreement between the institutions is of far better quality than the original proposal, I have decided to abstain.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree. Efsi will enable the European Union to act in the face of cross-border challenges in the areas of energy, environment and transport infrastructure, helping to attract private investors through projects that are essential for the public sector. Once efsi is approved, all Member States must work in a targeted manner to create appropriate and clear conditions for the delivery of projects to SMS and to provide information on the opportunities offered by efsi to reach the widest possible range of potential investors. We need to think not only about the opportunities available for 'hard' investment, but more about the fact that efsi must be used primarily to strengthen the economic growth and competitiveness of each EU country.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I supported this report, which reaffirms the role played by the EU budget in creating added value, pooling resources and ensuring a high level of synergy between the European Structural and Investment Funds and EFSI while strengthening the multiplier effect of EU funds. The amount of the Fund will be gradually increased to reach the target of EUR 8 billion, or 50% of the EU total guarantee. The Juncker plan is an investment plan that will help to start again after the crisis, to invest in infrastructure and to boost employment, especially for our young people.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft amending budget is the budgetary counterpart to the adoption of the EFSI. It amends the 2015 budget and provides the resources needed to implement the EFSI. The European Fund for Strategic Investments is the backbone of juncker's investment plan for Europe.  Based on a 16 billion euro guarantee financed from the EU budget and a contribution of 5 billion euros from the EIB, it hopes to mobilize about three times more resources through the issuance of bonds used to attract other public or private investors and finance projects of about 4 times the initial risk-taking capacity (about 315 billion euros).  This fund is pure communication, since at worst it will be a failure (like the 2012 Pact for Growth and Jobs) and, at best, it will create windfall effects: that is, companies that have already planned to invest even without this plan, will do so with the GUARANTEE of the EFSI.  Having voted against the EFSI at the June mini-session in Brussels, it makes sense that we should oppose this text, which is only its budgetary counterpart. So I voted against it.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it entails the adoption of cuts in key research and infrastructure programmes to enable the development of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. This Fund is a guarantee for private investors in line with the European Bond Investment Bank Initiative Europe 2020. In order to promote this Juncker Plan, the Commission has decided to cut into significant public programmes such as the Connecting Europe Facility. My opposition to this plan which will support European speculators, rather than the real economy and the European industrial structure, has been frontal, and that is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. On 26 November 2014, the Commission proposed an Investment Plan for Europe with the aim of mobilizing at least EUR 315 billion over the next three years. To this end, the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE) established an agreement between the Commission and the European Investment Bank. These types of initiatives support the mobilization of both public and private capital while helping to remove cross-border barriers on energy, environment or transport infrastructure issues. That is why, and because such projects show the great correlation between European funds and EIEI, so I am voting in favour, because investments for research and transport are also key to strengthening and securing the objectives set within the Union's budgets, and thereby encouraging the growth expected with the Europe 2020 Strategy.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The new European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) aims to promote economic growth, employment and recovery in Europe.
