The new initiative promises to allow for new investments of EUR 315 billion over a three-year period, most of which will be financed by the private sector. What is not so clearly stated, however, is the fact that the European Investment Bank is liable for defaults. In concrete terms, this means that the taxpayer should be liable for the default risks of private entrepreneurs. That is why I am opposed to the report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The aim of this draft budget is to include in the budget nomenclature of the Item for the European Fund for Strategic Investments Guarantee, the Provision of Reservations of the Guarantee Fund of the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the European Investment Advisory Centre.  In addition, the draft amendment to the 2015 budget creates a budgetary structure for allocating funds to the fund. The european fund for strategic investments aims to steer funds towards the economy in several phases by 2020. The absorption of funds provided for in the European Fund for Strategic Investments at stages should be evaluated in order to be able to value the quality of implementation, which is underlined in this Report, so I supported it.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. The European Fund for Strategic Investments must be widely used to launch the European economy. If not, everyone will become Greece. I voted for it.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Fund for Strategic Investments aims to help kick-start investments in the EU that will lead to increased employment and economic growth. The plan is to mobilise and invest EUR 315 billion in the European economy over three years. Efsi will be able to support strategic and economically capable projects that could not have been supported by existing EU programmes and which would never have been implemented without EFSI.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1/2012. 1/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Section III - Commission, accompanying the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Fund for Strategic Investments and amending Regulations (EU) No 1493/1999 and (EC) No 1493/1999. 1291/2013 and (EU) No 1291/2013. 1316/2013, because I believe that the report is not sufficiently substantiated.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the Commission’s proposal for a European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI); reiterate the need to support strategic investments with high economic and societal value added, promote sustainable innovation, skills and local jobs, boost the competitiveness of the EU and contribute to the Union’s strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Votes in favour of draft adjusted budget No 1/2015 concerning the European Fund for Strategic Investments EFSI. This draft budget stems from the need to make appropriate changes to the budgetary classification and to redistribute EUR 1 360 million in commitment appropriations to the Guarantee Fund and EUR 10 million in payment appropriations for the financing of investment advice. This vote confirms the need to support strategic investments to promote innovation and the EU's competitiveness.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of the report signed by my colleague Gardiazabal Rubial, aware of the importance of these funds in the field of research and transport. No less important is the fact that the amount of the Guarantee Fund will be gradually increased to the target of EUR 8 billion and will create conditions of greater security.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained because I understood that, although I disagree with the Juncker Plan and on other occasions voted against EFSI, this amending amendment does not alter the nature of the fund, not for the better, not for the worse. Nevertheless, I believe that it is regrettable that these funds cannot be used for projects which I consider to be more relevant as research grants or investment support in public infrastructure, since these appropriations were already reserved by the 2014-2020 MFF.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Fund for Strategic Investments is of great importance in order to be able to carry out projects that contribute to sustainable growth and job creation in the EU. My support for the proposal to increase the budget for this Fund and I am confident that the commitment to implement it as soon as possible and effectively can be achieved, therefore favouring the achievement of the objectives that Europe has set for the coming years.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Since I have always opposed the establishment of the EFSI, I cannot support this draft either.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This Draft Amending Budget is linked to EFSI. The report’s purposes are to budgetise the resources needed to implement the European Fund for Strategic Investments in the 2015 budget.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This text reveals the nothingness of the famous recovery plan presented in 2014 by the new President of the Commission Jean-Claude Juncker. The key measure of the plan was the creation of a European Fund for Strategic Investments. That's a good intention. It is now a question of funding that fund.  Everyone was wondering how Juncker was going to do it. Here we discover how: by cutting 1.2 billion the investment programmes already existing in the EU budget (Horizon 2020, MIE, ITER). This new Juncker Fund is therefore pure media artifice. It is even likely that on arrival, even less investment will be financed than with the programmes decided before Juncker!  Thus Juncker's recovery plan is first and foremost a plan to stop certain activities. As a result, the report "deplores" the amputation of these programmes "in view of the importance of these programmes for jobs and growth in Europe". But, without any coherence, it still supports this redeployment.  I'm voting against this charade.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft amending budget No 1/2015 aims to make the necessary changes to the budget nomenclature in accordance with the legislative agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and to provide for the necessary reallocation of EUR 1 360 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 10 million in payment appropriations. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report for a draft amending budget No 1/2015: European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund contributes to packages of tailor-made services to help redundant workers find new jobs. Its annual ceiling is EUR 500 million. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business start-ups, job-search assistance, occupational guidance and various kinds of training. In most cases, national authorities have already started the measures and will have their costs reimbursed by the EU once their applications are approved.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the draft amending budget for the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). This vote was preceded by long and complicated negotiations with the Council, in which the representatives of the European Parliament managed to severely limit the cuts to the Connecting Europe Facility and Horizon 2020 to finance the EFSI. As a member of the ITRE Committee, I have also fought hard for this and I am pleased that, despite the fierce opposition of the Member States, we have managed to cut the money that goes to the EFSI from the Connecting Europe Facility and Horizon 2020 by EUR 500 million each. To this end, the proportion of funds from unused margins is now set at a higher rate than provided for in the Commission's proposal. In addition, the annual review clause of the budget gives us the opportunity to continue to fight for the protection of the Connecting Europe Facility and Horizon 2020 in the coming years. It is now up to the Commission and also the Member States to demonstrate their promises regarding the investment power of the EFSI.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Fund for Strategic Investments (ESII), and thus the investment offensive to be launched within the Union, is at the heart of the Juncker Commission's policy to improve the Union's economic competitiveness. The concept was supported by the Committee on Industry, Energy and Research, of which I am a member, and by the European Parliament itself. The proposal is about the transfer of the transfers needed to replenish the SII to the EU budget for 2015, which I was pleased to support as set out above.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 1/2015 aims to make the necessary changes to the budget nomenclature in accordance with the legislative agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and to provide for the necessary reallocation of EUR 1 360 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 10 million in payment appropriations. I advocate the role of the Union budget in creating added value by sharing resources and ensuring a high degree of synergies between the European Structural and Investment Funds and the EFSI, while improving the multiplier effect of the Union contribution and supporting the mobilisation of additional sources of public and private funding to finance investments to achieve European-scale objectives, in particular in the context of addressing cross-border challenges in areas such as energy, environmental and transport infrastructure. I would like to point out the speed achieved in the agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments and vote, and i therefore favour this budgetary amendment.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft amending budget is the budgetary counterpart to the adoption of the EFSI. It amends the 2015 budget and provides the resources needed to implement the EFSI. The European Fund for Strategic Investments is the backbone of juncker's investment plan for Europe.  Based on a 16 billion euro guarantee financed from the EU budget and a contribution of 5 billion euros from the EIB, it hopes to mobilize about three times more resources through the issuance of bonds used to attract other public or private investors and finance projects of about 4 times the initial risk-taking capacity (about 315 billion euros).  This fund is pure communication, since at worst it will be a failure (like the 2012 Pact for Growth and Jobs) and, at best, it will create windfall effects: that is, companies that have already planned to invest even without this plan, will do so with the GUARANTEE of the EFSI.  Having voted against the EFSI at the June mini-session in Brussels, it makes sense that we should oppose this text, which is only its budgetary counterpart.  So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ DAB 1 will make EFSI possible. If the UK government is ready to grasp this opportunity it will create many billions of pounds worth of investment into the UK economy; investments in infrastructure, SMEs and green growth. The agreement that no fresh money will be used is also encouraging and demonstrates that the Commission is ready to do more with less. It is with regret however that this money has come from Heading 1a and we hope that at the mid-term review more funding will be found from other headings to reinforce this productive area.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the budgetary aspect of the Juncker Plan (EFSI agreement) for 2015. This amending budget changes the budget nomenclature by creating new budget lines and provides the resources needed to supply the Juncker plan.  The plan is expected to mobilise EUR 315 billion for new investments in the real economy. The aim is for the Union to create leverage through a 16 billion euro guarantee to support public and private investment in the transport, telecommunications and energy infrastructure sectors (including interconnections of transport and energy networks), as well as digital infrastructure. This fund aims to revitalise the EU economy without further delay by facilitating access to finance and promoting the competitiveness of businesses.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We take note of the draft amending budget and welcome the fact that it has been possible to reach an agreement on EFSI quickly, thanks to the determination of all the institutions, in order to ensure their operation as soon as possible. We regret the negative impact on the two eu programmes that are so important in the field of cross-border research and transport (Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Mechanism).  We believe that the EU budget should create added value by pooling resources and ensuring a high level of synergy between the European Structural and Investment Funds. We are therefore in favour of mobilising additional sources of private and public funding to support investment in European-wide objectives, in particular to address cross-border challenges in areas such as energy, the environment and transport infrastructure.  We therefore welcome the decision to mobilise an additional amount of EUR 1 billion, compared with the Commission's initial proposal, through the margins available in the 2014/2015 budgets, thus reducing the realassignments of the two Programmes mentioned above. Investment in research and transport is essential in order to strengthen and stimulate growth, competitiveness and employment and to pursue the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 26 November 2014, the Commission proposed an "Investment Plan for Europe" aimed at mobilising at least EUR 315 billion of additional investment over the next three years. To this end, a new European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) has been set up in partnership between the Commission and the European Investment Bank (EIB). The EFSI provides for the creation of a Guarantee Fund which can be used to pay the EIB in the event of recourse to the EU guarantee. The amount of the Guarantee Fund will be gradually increased to reach the target of EUR 8 billion, i.e. 50% of the total EU guarantee (EUR 16 billion). Payment appropriations from the Union's general budget will be progressively introduced by 2020. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for the Council’s position concerning the draft budget.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Having closely followed this report I am happy to be able to vote for it now. EFSI is one of the main hopes for the revival of the EU economy and it was absolutely normal to readjust the budget lines we use in order to fully enable its creation and functioning. We can now hope for a fruitful implementation of its resources.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The creation of growth and sustainable jobs is the primary objective and guiding principle of this report. Despite the recovery from the economic and financial crisis, further investment is urgently needed. EFSI is an essential element in increasing investment levels and can stimulate the european economy. The basic idea is actually very good and sensible. Personally, however, I do not have a clear plan behind the idea. A transparent strategy is needed on how financial resources are to be used and what benefits can be derived from it. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft amending budget. I consider it important to support strategic investments with high economic and social added value, promote innovation and increase the EU's competitiveness, contributing to the EU's strategy for sustainable and inclusive growth. At the same time, I am concerned that, since programmes such as Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility are vital to the Europe 2020 targets and thus to ensure sustainable growth in the EU and can bring great added value, they should not be cut back.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted considering that the Commission intends to compensate for the reduction in ITER appropriations by increasing them in an equivalent way in the period 2018-2020 and that the allocation of the European Investment Advisory Centre, amounting to EUR 10 million in commitment appropriations and as many in payment appropriations, comes in full from realassignments from the ITER budget line (08 04 01 02).

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) report, because it is an important step towards long-term growth, job creation and tackling poverty. EFSI, which is at the heart of the European Investment Plan, will enhance growth, particularly in the areas of research and development, innovation and education. The Fund will be a key element in countries such as Bulgaria that are less developed and with less expertise. In particular, the European Investment Advisory Hub will help these countries develop their potential and allow them to achieve further economic growth. Furthermore, it will take a vital role in our ambition to stimulate the small and medium-sized enterprises within the EU as it will finance projects with a higher risk profile that will lead to more private investments. I welcome the report imposing stronger reporting requirements and increased accountability to the EP.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Purpose of draft budget modification No. 1 for the 2015 general budget is to make the necessary changes to the budgetary nomenclature in accordance with the legislative agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the implementation of the necessary redistribution of EUR 1360 million of commitment appropriations to the newly launched guarantee fund and €10 million in payment appropriations to finance the European Investment Advisory Centre and the European Investment Projects Portal.  November 26, 2014 The Commission has proposed an Investment Plan for Europe to activate at least €315 billion for additional investments over the next three years through the European Fund for Strategic Investments, as part of a partnership between the Commission and the European Investment Bank. I welcome these efforts by the Commission to encourage economic growth and employment through the activation of additional funds dedicated to investments in projects of importance, not only for individual Member States but also for the union as a whole.  Taking into account the Commission's draft budget change, the Council's position on the draft budget change and the proposal for a regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments adopted by the Commission on 13 January 2015, and that the European Parliament approves in its proposal for a resolution the Council's position on the draft budget amendment, I join the general consensus and support this Council Position Report.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft amending budget is the budgetary counterpart to the adoption of the EFSI. It amends the 2015 budget and provides the necessary resources for the implementation of the EFSI. The European Fund for Strategic Investments is the backbone of juncker's investment plan for Europe.  Based on a 16 billion euro guarantee financed from the EU budget and a contribution of 5 billion euros from the EIB, it hopes to mobilize about three times as much resources through the issuance of bonds used to attract other public or private investors and finance projects of about four times the initial risk-taking capacity (about 315 billion euros).  This Fund is pure communication, since, at worst, it will be a failure (like the 2012 Pact for Growth and Jobs) and that, at best, it will simply create a windfall: companies that have already planned to invest without the plan will do so with the EIFS guarantee.  Having voted against the EFSI at the June mini-session in Brussels, it makes sense for me to oppose this text, which is only its budgetary counterpart. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 Because the purpose of the draft budget modification no. 1/2015 making the necessary changes to the budget nomencalture in accordance with the legislative agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the implementation of the necessary redistribution of EUR 1 360 million of commitment appropriations and EUR 10 million in payment appropriations. The main role of the Union budget is to create added value by pooling resources and ensuring great synergies between the European Structural and Investment Funds and the EFSI, while increasing the impact of multiplying the Union contribution.  I agree with the position on supporting the mobilisation of additional sources of private and public funds to invest in objectives with a European dimension, in particular by addressing cross-border problems in areas such as energy, the environment and transport infrastructure. However, as the provision of the guarantee fund in 2015 is set to be set off in 2016, The total amount of €1 350 million is redistributed from the Connecting Europe Facility (€790 million), Horizon 2020 (€70 million) and ITER (€490 million) in commitment appropriations, as these programmes are essential for job creation and growth in Europe and I support efforts to compensate for these redistributions in the upcoming budgetary procedures.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. —First of all, the commitment of all institutions in an effort to reach an agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments in a timely manner should be welcomed in order to get it up and running as soon as possible. The fact that an additional €1 billion will be financed from the overall MFF gap for the commitments remaining from the 2014-2015 budget is extremely positive. Thus, a larger mass of funds remains available to connect Europe and Horizon 2020. Such EU programmes ensure stable and sustainable growth of Member States and increase the EU's competitiveness on the global market. As for all other programmes, transparency, accountability and control of financial instruments or any other mechanisms financed by the Union budget, in particular the EFSI, should be ensured.  The establishment of the European Fund for Strategic Investments is an example of good policy to stimulate investment, develop innovation and jobs, and therefore I support draft amendments to budget No 1000/2019. 1/2015.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union's current growth of less than half a percent suggests that this is not a good time to strangle the economy. On the contrary, we need to find a suitable way to revive it as quickly as possible. It is for this reason that I voted in favour of the draft amending budget drawn up by my colleague Eider Gardiazabal Rubial. On the basis of this report, it will be possible to allocate the €10 million in funds needed to establish the European Investment Advisory Hub. The Centre is one of the three main pillars of the Juncker Investment Plan for Europe, which is expected to create up to 1.3 million jobs and will focus on several key areas. This will include investments in energy, the environment, research and development and transport infrastructure. I am convinced that the plan will only work reliably if there is a place to which future investors or public authorities can turn if necessary. As the Centre will assist interested parties in identifying, preparing and developing projects, it will form a key link for promising projects to pass through a network of selection tests. I am glad that the Commission has promised in the future to call the budget for the ITER programme, from which the payment means for the centre will be transferred and which is currently urgently needed. It would be very inappropriate to take funds away from European programmes that do not have a sufficient financial cushion.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I wanted to support with my vote in favour this report on this draft budget which introduces changes to the budgetary nomenclature for EFSI (with the creation of new budget lines), and provides the necessary resources for the allocation of the EFSI Guarantee Fund in 2015. This money will be redistributed mainly between the Connecting Europe Mechanism (EUR 790 million) and the EU's Horizon 2020 programme (EUR 70 million), which I believe are important tools to fuel economic growth and improve the living standards of European citizens.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. One of the key elements of the new Juncker Commission's programme is the creation of a European Fund for Strategic Investments. I voted in favour of the draft amending budget No. 1/2015, which changes the nomenclature of the European budget by creating new budget lines to supply the Fund concerned.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the interest of the European Parliament in launching the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) as soon as possible, this report endorses the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1/2015 providing for the reallocation of EUR 1 360 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 10 million in payment appropriations. This redeployment aims at provisioning the fund to leverage strategic investments with high economic and social value. In this context, I voted in favour of the proposal, hoping that the EFSI will in fact be the necessary impetus and stimulus for innovation, and guarantee the last of a more competitive Europe in a context of sustainable growth.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft amending budget No 1/2015 aims to make the necessary changes to the budget nomenclature in accordance with the legislative agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), and to provide for the necessary allocation of EUR 1 360 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 10 million in payment appropriations. I welcome the fact that a rapid agreement on the EFSI has been possible, thanks to the determination of all institutions to ensure its launch as soon as possible. While the outcome of the negotiations is better than the Commission's initial proposal, I regret the negative impact on Horizon 2020.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. At the previous plenary, the European Parliament adopted, by a large majority, the creation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, the cornerstone of the Junker Fund, thus providing Europe with the means to encourage the timid resumption of growth. Today's vote, although less emblematic than the legislative proposal, is no less important. On the contrary, MEPs approved the budgetary structure to enable the supply of the EU guarantee fund. Initially, the Commission proposed a budget reduction of EUR 6 billion on the Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme and on the mechanism for interconnection in Europe in order to free up funds for the guarantee. Parliament has ensured that this amount is reduced to EUR 5 billion. The annual budget procedure will allow us to continue to defend these programmes from any budget cuts in the coming years. The plan is now operational. It is time to take action and ensure that the Junker plan demonstrates its added value for reviving growth and jobs in Europe.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to technically integrate the agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments into the EU budget for 2015, with a view to providing the EIE Guarantee Fund with the necessary EUR 1.36 billion. In this way, the EESI can be launched by responding to our priority of reorienting European economic policy towards growth and investment, which is urgent in the situation facing the Union.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the European Union's draft amending budget No. 1/2015 for the 2015 financial year in order to adopt the draft budget as presented by the Commission and thus see the European Fund for Strategic Investments implemented as soon as possible. I welcome the speed with which agreement has been reached between all institutions on this Fund.  Indeed, since the 2008 financial crisis, both public and private investment in the European Union have remained unusually low. We therefore need an investment recovery plan to put Europe back on the path to sustainable and inclusive growth.  Unfortunately, I must still deplore the redeployment from the Interconnection Mechanism in Europe (MIE) and Horizon 2020. These programs are of great importance for jobs and growth.  Finally, I support the idea that investments in research and transport will boost growth, competitiveness and jobs, and achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 1/2015, which aims to insert the necessary changes in the budget nomenclature, in accordance with the legislative agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), and to provide for the necessary allocation of EUR 1 360 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 10 million in payment appropriations. For the provision of the EU guarantee fund in 2015, a total amount of EUR 1 350 million is reallocated under the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) (EUR 790 million), horizon 2020 (EUR 70 million) and the ITER project (EUR 490 million) in commitment appropriations.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), also known as the Juncker Plan, is the focal point of the economic policy of the current European Commission. The green light for the implementation of this plan was already voted on at the last plenary session in Brussels. During the Strasbourg plenary session, the amendment to the 2015 EU budget was presented, following the entry into force of EFSI, for which I voted in favour. Let us remember that EFSI aims to stimulate private investors by using part of the European budget to guarantee riskier or less attractive investments. With regard to the 2015 budget, it was decided to redistribute EUR 1,360 million in commitment appropriations to the Guarantee Fund and EUR 10 million in payment appropriations for the financing of the European Investment Advisory Centre and the European Investment Projects Portal.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because EFSI has the structural limit of taking resources away from other European funds (e.g. 'Horizon 2020').

name: n/a
text: in writing. I abstained in this vote because, despite our disagreement with the Juncker Plan and although we have already opposed EIE itself on previous occasions, we consider that this correction does not alter the nature of the Fund, either to improve it or to make it worse.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it entails the adoption of cuts in key research and infrastructure programmes to enable the development of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. This Fund is a guarantee for private investors in line with the European Bond Investment Bank Initiative Europe 2020. In order to promote this Juncker Plan, the Commission has decided to cut into significant public programmes such as the Connecting Europe Facility. My opposition to this plan which will support European speculators, rather than the real economy and the European industrial structure, has been frontal, and that is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 1/2015, which aims to create the budgetary structure necessary to feed the Guarantee of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). A total of EUR 1 350 million will then be reallocated in commitment appropriations from the budget lines of the Connecting Europe Mechanism (EUR 790 million), Horizon 2020 (EUR 70 million) and ITER (EUR 490 million). Let us now hope that EFSI will begin to bear fruit.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ DAB 1 will make EFSI possible. If the UK government is ready to grasp this opportunity it will create many billions of pounds worth of investment into the UK economy; investments in infrastructure, SMEs and green growth. The agreement that no fresh money will be used is also encouraging and demonstrates that the Commission is ready to do more with less. It is with regret however that this money has come from Heading 1a and we hope that at the mid-term review more funding will be found from other headings to reinforce this productive area.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The objective of draft amending budget No 1/2015 was to identify the necessary changes to allow the reallocation of funds for the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). The Slovak Republic is also part of the EFSI Investment Plan, which aims to support the financing of viable investments in the EU, which is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Commission's proposal for an amending budget No 1/2015, which proposes, in line with the legislative proposal for a regulation of the EP and the Council on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), the financing of the guarantee fund and the possible use of the Union guarantee, as well as the allocation of appropriations for the purpose of providing advisory support. The resolution stresses the need to ensure transparency, accountability and control of financial instruments and all mechanisms related to the Union budget, in particular efsi. It is also necessary to carefully and regularly assess the functioning of such instruments and their contribution to the creation of new jobs and the implementation of the Union strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. The European Fund for Strategic Investments should contribute to economic growth in individual Member States and the promotion of employment in the near future.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Recently, we have recently given the green light in Parliament to start the Fund for Strategic Investments, and today, by voting on the draft amending budget, we have allocated fundamental resources to this fund and laid the groundwork for mobilising private capital. In the outcome of the recent negotiations, we have achieved great success in the amount of the funds redistributed. The cut in Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility, which are essential for achieving the Europe 2020 objectives, have been reduced by as much as €1 billion.  Unfortunately, the total amount of funds redistributed from these two programmes is still too high. We must not forget that the Horizon 2020 and CEF budget for 2015 has already basically hit the minimum for meeting the EU's commitments, as it has already been significantly reduced in the preparatory phase! Notwithstanding this, this proposal is a real step towards the much-needed growth of the European economy. However, we must be aware that this is just the beginning. In order to truly achieve the objectives of the Investment Plan, other measures are necessary, such as the preparation of a system of indicators to assess in advance the sustainability of investments and the quality of jobs, rather than merely the technical adequacy of individual projects.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft amending budget for the European Fund for Strategic Investments because I am convinced that it can be an important driving force for the development of the European production system. Indeed, the Juncker Plan starts from the observation of the sharp reduction in investment in the Union - quantifiable at around EUR 2000 billion - resulting from the crisis in the financial markets and in the banking sector after 2008 and the simultaneous crisis in public finances in many countries and. The revolution of the plan lies in the new model of growth that it contains, based on strategic priorities for future investments in the European economic and productive fabric, in particular in crucial sectors with greater social impact, such as education, renewable energy and digital energy, and which benefit the areas most affected by the crisis. Priority will be given to projects which meet the additionality criterion, i.e. those projects which could not have been financed without the plan, either because of a lack of resources or because they have too high a risk profile. Although EFSI is not the final solution to the serious problems facing our economy, in the age of the dogma of austerity and rigour, EFSI is an important attempt to revive growth and employment.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The new European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) aims to promote economic growth, employment and recovery in Europe. The new initiative promises to allow for new investments of EUR 315 billion over a three-year period, most of which will be financed by the private sector. What is not so clearly stated, however, is the fact that the European Investment Bank is liable for defaults. In concrete terms, this means that the taxpayer should be liable for the default risks of private entrepreneurs. Irrespective of these considerations, EFSI will fail anyway. It is inconceivable that a new authority could make better decisions than thousands of company bosses. If this task were to be taken seriously, thousands of civil servants would have to be recruited. This is a step towards a planned economy on the part of the EU. Knowing what planned economic policy has done, particularly in Eastern Europe, the EFSI must be rejected.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU needs to support investment in jobs. I welcome the establishment of a fund for long-term investments, because building infrastructure in transport, energy and digitalisation has a long-term return, but without quality infrastructure we cannot improve the environment for job creation. I share the proposal to strengthen the role and objective of the EU budget to stimulate growth, competitiveness and employment.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the Council's position report on draft budget amendment No. 1/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Part III, as it is in line with the legislative agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the implementation of the necessary redistribution of €1 360 million of commitment appropriations and €10 million in payment appropriations.  I welcome the decision to approve funding for the European Investment Advisory Centre and consider that additional investment in transport is essential to boost growth and competitiveness in the market.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ DAB 1 will make EFSI possible. If the UK government is ready to grasp this opportunity it will create many billions of pounds worth of investment into the UK economy; investments in infrastructure, SMEs and green growth. The agreement that no fresh money will be used is also encouraging and demonstrates that the Commission is ready to do more with less. It is with regret however that this money has come from Heading 1a and we hope that at the mid-term review more funding will be found from other headings to reinforce this productive area.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support this draft report because I think it is right that in 2015 the total amount of EUR 1 350 million is repurposed from the Connecting Europe Facility (EUR 790 million), Horizon 2020. (€70 million) and ITER (€490 million) in commitment appropriations, especially as all additional appropriations for the implementation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments in Liabilities and Payments have been fully repurposed and therefore the entire amount of commitment appropriations payment appropriations remains the same in the 2015 budget. I agree that an additional €1 billion, in relation to the Commission's original proposal, should be financed from the overall difference of the MFF for commitments abounding from the differences left over from the 2014-2015 budget, thus facilitating redistribution from the Connecting Europe-Horizon Facility 2020. However, as these are programmes of utmost importance for job creation and growth in Europe, it is essential to replace the repurposed funds in the upcoming budgetary decisions.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because I am convinced that EFSI will do more harm to the economy than it will help. The European Union does not need more redistribution and centrally managed investment, but on the contrary, it needs more economic freedom.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on draft amending budget No 1/2015 – European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). I support the Commission's proposal for a European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), which we have come to because of the strong determination of all institutions that investment in research and transport is urgently needed and that it is necessary to increase the EU's competitiveness and to contribute to the Union strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. I join the rapporteur's regrets, pointing out the negative impact on Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility, which are key to jobs and growth in Europe.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Reaffirms the willingness to adopt this plan with a view to the fastest possible start-up of the EFSI. Tackling poverty and unemployment is not achieved by setting up funds, which are more a means of manipulating public opinion than solving the problem.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important that the legislation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments is brought into line as soon as possible. I share the view that the budget plays an important role in the creation of value added by pooling resources and ensuring a high degree of synergy between the European Structural and Investment Funds and the SII, while enhancing the multiplier effect of EU contributions. However, I think it is important to point out that this instrument supports the mobilisation of additional private and public funds to finance investments for purposes of a European dimension, in particular investments aimed at addressing cross-border challenges, including in the areas of energy, environment and transport infrastructure. I note, however, that I do not fully agree with the transfers. The European Parliament has previously expressed in its reports and opinions that existing development funds (such as the TPM and Horizon 2020) should not be withered when designing the Fund. In this case and in the current year, a compromise solution has been reached in order to get the Investment Fund started as soon as possible; but the report also indicates a change in the transfer next year.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Draft Amending Budget No 1 of 2015 (DAB 1/2015) is a technical adaptation of the EU 2015 Budget, which is linked to the agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). The purpose of this DAB 1/2015 is to provide the necessary EUR 1 360 million to the EFSI Guarantee Fund in 2015. The ESFI agreement had already been adopted in plenary on 24 June by a large majority. The adoption of the report was the first step to putting into effect the EUR 315 billion investment plan. The approval of DAB 1/2015, which I voted in favour of, is the technical step to ensuring the full operation of the fund by September. That is particularly important, given the recent economic uncertainties which were increased by the result of the Greek referendum on 5 July. I voted in favour of this report because Europe needs, now more than ever, an investment plan to maintain and further enhance the EU’s competitiveness and economic growth.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the draft amending budget. however, I am deeply concerned about the significant reductions in commitments proposed in draft amending budget No. 1 to the 2015 general budget.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the amending budget which reallocates EUR 1.36 billion in funds within the European Union budget to start the European Fund for Strategic Investments. EFSI is an important step to improve the economic and investment situation on the continent. If properly implemented it will provide vital financing for SMEs and for the European economy in general.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The allocation of funds from the European Fund for Strategic Investments aimed at alleviating imbalances in Member States with low GDP rates can achieve good support practices and opportunities to address financing difficulties. The implementation of long-term productive strategic investments in the Union provides a boost to the economy and provides greater access to finance for companies whose number of employees does not exceed 3 000. I am particularly pleased that this focuses on small, medium and micro-enterprises in need of assistance in order to attract market financing, especially when it comes to riskier investments.  In this case, I believe that the very purpose of the draft budget amendment is well targeted in order to achieve the implementation and launch of the Fund as soon as possible, but I also believe that the regrouping of funds in the future must not be carried out at the expense of other programmes that also contribute to growth and employment.  As I have pointed out countless times, I support measures that ensure economic recovery with the extremely important need to increase regulatory predictability, and I mean transparency in information mediation. At the same time, I consider it necessary to reduce administrative burdens with better control of administrative supervisors. With the desire for the implementation of the Fund to achieve the best results, I voted positively.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal covers the budgetary aspect of the European Fund for Strategic Investments for 2015. It adds changes to the EFSI budget and provides the necessary resources for the creation of the EFSI Guarantee Fund. the funds are redeployed from Connecting Europe Facility (EUR 790 million), Horizon 2020 (EUR 70 million) and also from the ITER project (EUR 490 million). As the functioning of the Fund is important, I supported the proposal.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in this vote because, despite our disagreement with the Juncker Plan and although we have already opposed EEF itself on previous occasions, we consider that this correction does not alter the nature of the Fund, either to improve it or to make it worse.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The new European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) aims to promote economic growth and employment in Europe. The new initiative promises to allow for new investments of EUR 315 billion over three years, most of which will be financed by the private sector. This also entails significant risks for the taxpayer, who is liable for defaults through the European Investment Bank. The political selection of economic opportunities is not a success story, and without the recruitment of many new and correspondingly inexperienced civil servants, this task cannot be accomplished. Many areas of Europe continue to have fundamental structural problems and, first of all, need better conditions of competition and functioning banking systems. It is a particular pity that the EFSI is also damaging European basic research. For these reasons, the EFSI should be rejected.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report, as its approval is fundamental to ensure the success of EFSI and its fast implementation.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 A proposal for an amendment to the 2015 annual budget for the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) has been adopted, together with commission opinions and proposals for amendments, including those of the Transport Committee. I voted in favour of the amendment.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in this vote because, despite our disagreement with the Juncker Plan and although we have already opposed EEF itself on previous occasions, we consider that this correction does not alter the nature of the Fund, either to improve it or to make it worse.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted against this report, consistent with my vote in the last plenary session, rejecting the establishment of the European Fund for Strategic Investments with its current configuration. The Juncker Plan and its seed fund, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, is far from the investment plan needed for Europe. This simple readjustment of the budgetary resources already available, without new money or liquidity, cutting in environmental matters, is a missed opportunity.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The final agreement reduces the allocation of Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility to the EIE by one billion euros by one billion euros, obtaining these billion euros through the overall margin of the multi-year financial framework for budgetary commitments. This decision is positive and helps to bet on innovation and research, basic pillars for boosting European growth, so it is necessary to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it entails the adoption of cuts in key research and infrastructure programmes to enable the development of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. This Fund is a guarantee for private investors in line with the European Bond Investment Bank Initiative Europe 2020. In order to promote this Juncker Plan, the Commission has decided to cut into significant public programmes such as the Connecting Europe Facility. My opposition to this plan which will support European speculators, rather than the real economy and the European industrial structure, has been frontal, and that is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of DAB 1 as it will make EFSI possible. If the UK government is ready to grasp this opportunity it will create many billions of pounds worth of investment into the UK economy; investments in infrastructure, SMEs and green growth. The agreement that no fresh money will be used is also encouraging and demonstrates that the Commission is ready to do more with less. It is with regret however that this money has come from Heading 1a and the Labour MEPs hope that at the mid-term review more funding will be found from other headings to reinforce this productive area.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), known as the Juncker Plan, is expected to support an investment recovery programme of 315 billion euros.  This plan is actually a mirror to the larks: out of 315 billion announced, only 5 constitute fresh money, the rest being either guarantees (16 billion) or a very hypothetical "leverage" - that is, a euro of credit could generate ... 15 times the value of the investment!  Only very little support for new infrastructure financing programmes that can generate jobs will be really provided.   The text put to the vote is intended to validate technical adjustments to the 2015 EU budget to enable the implementation of the EFSI.  It takes resources allocated to European programmes with the right hand and places them with the left hand as collateral for the Juncker plan.  Not very convincing: I therefore abstained on this amending budget.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The so-called 'Juncker plan' is pointed out as a sign of a 'new cycle' – no longer that of 'austerity', but of 'growth' and 'investment'. It turns out that this plan is not an investment plan. It is a creative accounting exercise from which it is expected to gather the investment that has not emerged spontaneously from the normal functioning of the market. Moreover, this plan is an anthem to public-private partnerships and promiscuity between governments and large companies that live at the expense of public rents. It does not guarantee even a fair geographical distribution of funds. The decision is the responsibility of another body of experts which does not respond to any kind of democratic legitimacy.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Since I have always opposed the establishment of the EFSI, I would not have approved this draft either.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament resolution on draft amending budget No 1/2015: European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI).  I reject the Juncker Plan and its core, the EFSI. The EFSI contradicts economic reason and is therefore irreparably damaged. I did not agree with the EFSI and I will not give my consent to any budgetary steps that will ultimately launch it.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the ep motion for a resolution on the draft amending budget for the 2015 financial year, which accompanies the proposal for a regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). Draft amending budget No 1 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 May 1999 on 1/2015 aims to transpose the necessary changes to the budgetary nomenclature in accordance with the legislative agreement on the EFSI and to provide for the necessary reallocation of EUR 1 360 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 10 million into payment appropriations.  I welcome the fact that a swift agreement on the EFSI has been reached thanks to the institutions' determination to ensure the rapid launch of the Fund and the fact that an additional EUR 1 000 million from the Commission's original proposal will be financed by the overall MFF margin for commitments, resulting from the remaining margins available from the 2014 and 2015 budgets, thereby reduced the redistribution of the Connecting Europe and Horizon 2020 Facilities.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today we voted on amending budget number 1, which should allow the start of the EFSI and constitute the first guarantee tranche of 1360 million euros, through substantial transfers from programmes such as CEF (Connecting European Facility) and ITER, and to a lesser extent from Horizon 2020 and others. In addition, eur 10 million in payments for the launch and organisation of the European Investment Advisory Centre, a structure provided for by EFSI, which I personally consider to be quite superfluous. The text also states that efforts will be made in the annual budgetary procedures to reinstate the cuts made to these programmes (CEF and Horizon), but to date there is no guarantee that this option will really be feasible. I am opposed to the EFSI approach, not also because of the way in which the guarantee funds have been found, which affect programmes considered by the European Commission itself to be strategic. It is for all these reasons that I voted against.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the vote on this year's amendment to the EU budget to transfer funds from the CEF instrument, from Horizon 2020 and the ITER project to the newly created European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), I abstained because, in fact, this means that the funds used to finance this fund will reduce the grant share for transport projects. While this does not significantly affect cohesion countries, it also prevents transport policy from counting on this grant money. Overall, the Juncker Plan will not help to equalise living conditions and living standards in the EU, as most of its projects will be implemented in western European countries with a larger economy and population. The EFSI intends to use combined funding: private funding will be attracted, which will, of course, be interested in making a profit as quickly and to the highest possible extent. It is therefore logical that funding is likely to invest more in larger projects in large western European countries, where it will be able to make a profit. Admittedly, income gaps in the large western European countries and smaller countries, including Eastern Europe, will grow rather than level out in the future. In addition, cef was intended to finance transport infrastructure projects under the EU TEN-T policy, which priorited rail and inland waterway projects with cross-border connections and thus with greater EU total added value. On the other hand, projects will only be selected for EFSI funding on the criteria of economic return.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of transferring funds to support the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which aims to stimulate job creation in the coming years, although not without reservations. In fact, funds have been transferred from the Connecting Europe Facility and Horizon 2020, which also make a significant contribution to job creation, in the digital market and research. Our faction will therefore fight for these programmes to be compensated for the financial shortfalls mentioned above when the 2016 budget is created.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft Amending Budget (POR) No 1/2015 aims to amend the 2015 EU Budget, following the adoption and agreement on the EFSI 'u2012) Juncker plan, a plan aimed at the interests of high finance and large multinationals, and maintaining a scandalous focus on public-private partnerships. This amendment translates into a total amount of EUR 1 350 million, which will be reallocated from the Connecting Europe Facility (EUR 790 million), Horizon 2020 (EUR 70 million) and ITER (EUR 490 million) in commitment appropriations. Although they are only credit commitments and not payment appropriations, the fact is that this is not a response to the problems that countries face, which would go through a real public investment plan.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted against the draft amending budget because it provides for the first tranche of the EUR 1 360 million guarantee to launch the EFSI, to which we have already declared ourselves opposed. In addition, the maneuver recovers resources on other chapters that are very important to us through a transfer from programmes such as CEF (Connecting European Facility, minus 700 million in commitments) and ITER (minus 500 million in commitments), and to a lesser extent from Horizon 2020 and others. In addition, EUR 10 million is earmarked for the launch and organisation of the European Investment Advisory Centre, a structure provided for by the EFSI and considered by us to be superfluous. Finally, although the text nevertheless states that efforts will be made in the annual budgetary procedures to reinstate the cuts made to these programmes (CEF and Horizon), to date there is no guarantee that this will actually be done.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The European institutions have decided that the only way to solve the dramas we have seen in recent months in the Mediterranean is to advance the Model of Europe 'Fortress' which has led us here. I reject this amendment, which is intended to provide Frontex and Europol with greater resources for their border control work, which do not have the rescue between their missions and whether to prevent human beings from entering our borders. I therefore believe that if there really was a political will to solve the problem, it would be invested in non-police or militarized rescue missions and then in cooperation policies that help the economic emancipation of the southern countries. However, in line with High Representative Mogherini's plans, it has been decided to spend money on the militarisation of the Mediterranean, something I cannot agree with.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF)
text: Written. 'A mixed feeling creeps up on me when I read this report about the impact of mass migration flows on the EU budget. It is good to note that the rapporteur is faced with the seriousness of the situation and literally dares to write that migration can entail high costs. For years, it was politically unthinkable that this painful truth would be proclaimed at all. It is now important to act on this knowledge as well, and that is where the shoe is pinching. This report emphasises the importance of Frontex and Europol, and this is progress in itself, but only if Frontex is used to restrict rather than facilitate immigration. This document does not go far enough and does not touch the ground, namely that the whole Schengen Convention must be revised and that Member States should therefore once again be given the freedom to carry out targeted border controls. The eu's entire migration policy has turned into a nightmare. Member States must therefore be able to respond ad-brake to the influx of fortune-seekers on their way to our regions.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Almost every day we hear about the tragedies of refugees on the Mediterranean and hundreds of deaths off the coast of Lampeusa. It is time for the EU to provide the necessary resources to prevent such tragedies in the long term. The EU is a strong defender of human rights. It should therefore do everything in its power to protect the lives of refugees and to prevent further tragedies. I therefore welcome the correction of the budget, even if further efforts need to be made in the future.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft amending budget includes an increase in funding from the Frontex agency, which is responsible for monitoring the UNION's external borders.  The total increase is 89 million euros and a good part of this money would be taken from the Galileo budget, which, however, should not be overlooked.  The Frontex agency has proven its inefficiency and its inability to combat the flood of illegal immigrants on the shores of the Mediterranean. This reinforces the National Front's consistent position calling for the suspension of the Schengen agreements and the return of the competence of the EU's external borders to each Member State.  Rather than increasing Frontex's budget, I would like the Union to help the Member States bordering the Mediterranean in their fight against illegal immigration. For these reasons, I voted against this draft amending budget.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that migration should be an issue within the preserve of the nation state; consequently, I cannot agree to an increase in EU funding for this purpose.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. The means are still paltry to manage migration flows, but in terms of asylum, the Commission's proposal is a step in the right direction, the means we allocate, too.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for an additional EUR 69.9 million. support for migration policy. An additional EUR 69.9 million will be allocated to the three agencies managing migration flows into the EU and to the various EU migration funds. support from the Commission. In view of the challenges of managing the growing flow of migrants in the Mediterranean, the EP has consistently called for increased funding for this area. EUR 75,7 million | Eur 69,9 million for liabilities and EUR 69,9 million for liabilities. The payments will come from the Galileo budget of the European Satellite Navigation Programme and will reach the EU Agency for the Management of External Borders, the European Asylum Support Office and the European Police Office (EUROPOL).

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This is a first step in terms of budgetary challenges to the migration problem and the plight of migrants in the Mediterranean. This increase of 75.7 million euros will, in particular, expand the Triton and Poseidon operations, which must primarily aim to save lives at sea. I approved this proposal. Nevertheless, while these funds will increase the resources of Europol, the European Asylum Support Office and Frontex, it is clear that these additional resources will be insufficient to cope with the scale of migration trends, whether it is saving lives, effectively combating traffickers or amplifying development and protection programmes for North Africa.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. In the wake of the human tragedies in the Mediterranean linked to the influx of migrants, the EU is presenting a draft of the 2015 amending budget aimed at "strengthening EU resources for the management of migration flows and refugee flows".  This budget should first increase the funding of the Frontex agency (26.8 million euros), to triple the funding of the Triton and Poseidon operations for the rest of 2015. This will remain equally unnecessary since they are content only with surveillance missions, without preventing immigration into the Union. Secondly, this project is intended to better distribute the asylum burdens at a cost of 89 million euros, all to accommodate more migrants and by directly cutting Galileo's funds. These European policies are just a huge smokescreen and communication as it becomes vital to control our immigration. There is an urgent need to restore the sovereignty of nations, to leave them free from their migration policy, or to apply a policy of firmness as is done in Australia. So I voted against that point.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 5/2015, which reallocated existing resources, allocating them to the management of migration and refugee flows in the Mediterranean. The text as a whole is acceptable, even if it represents only an economic piece put by the EU to uncontrolled migration from Africa to Italy and certainly does not contain the solutions that I would like to see, such as a stop to the phenomenon of migration.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this report on draft amending budget No 5/2015, which aims to strengthen EU resources to manage the increasing increase in migration and refugee flows. The report values the intention of all institutions to increase budgetary appropriations related to migration and asylum in view of undisputed and urgent needs and recalls that Parliament had already requested a considerable increase in appropriations in these budget lines and additional staff for the agencies concerned. However, it regrets the limited increases proposed in draft amending budget No 5/2015, which do not correspond to real needs in the light of the crisis in the Mediterranean, which is likely to worsen, the growing risk of increased refugees from Ukraine and the need to meet the challenges posed by migration in general.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because draft amending budget No 5/2015 aims to strengthen the European Union's resources for managing migration and refugee flows following the recent disasters in the Mediterranean and the increase in the flow of migrants. It is important to note that if migratory flows are not managed efficiently and in a timely manner, they can lead to high costs in other policy areas. The European Parliament regrets, however, that the amount of the increases proposed in this draft amending budget is limited and does not meet current needs, given the ongoing and likely worsening crisis in the Mediterranean. It is also important to assess the growing risk of an increase in refugees from Ukraine, as well as the need to address migration problems in general. On the other hand, it must be emphasised that strict control of the purpose of these funds is necessary in order to avoid abuses. Parliament deplores the fragmentation of Member States in the Council as a result of the Commission's proposal on the 'European Agenda on Migration' and recalls that the nature of the migration phenomenon can lead to more effective regulation at EU level.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft budget 5/2015 aims to strengthen EU resources to deal with migration and refugee flows following recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and an increase in the size of migration flows. With the adoption of draft araks for a budget no. 5/2015, commitment appropriations will increase by EUR 75 722 000 and payment appropriations by EUR 69 652 000. The increase in payments will be transferred entirely from the Galileo programme, leaving the overall level of payment appropriations in the 2015 budget unchanged. On the basis of the above, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ With draft amending budget No 5/2015, which I supported, we are increasing european Union funds for managing migration and refugee flows by €75 million. Following the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and the rise of migratory flows, swift action is urgent. As a whole, 21 new posts are also foreseed at Frontex, EASO and EUROPOL. Although once again it is merely a reallocation, and the funds are far from being enough to significantly improve the migration situation in southern Europe, the state of emergency calls for immediate action, while at the same time looking in parallel for solutions at the level of the Common Understanding of the Member States.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I strongly believe that it is important for the Union to show real solidarity and help states at the forefront of the migration emergency and individuals who land on our shores in search of a better life.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. In response to the massive influx of migrants to European shores, the Council proposes, in this draft amending budget, to increase the UNION's resources by 75.7 million euros, of which 70 million comes from the redeployment of the Galileo programme's appropriations. These funds will strengthen the budget of Frontex and EASO and provide Europol with additional staff. In short, this project aims to alleviate the financial burden currently borne only by the countries of southern Europe. We are staunchly opposed to any transfer of sovereignty, especially when the powers are passed on to bodies such as Frontex whose results are poor in the fight against smuggling networks. The Schengen area has not met its objectives. That is why we believe that the re-establishment of border controls at each state will effectively stem these migratory flows.  Finally, we regret that this redeployment of credits is at the expense of Galileo. The European Union, rather than financially supporting cooperation projects, prefers to waste public money on policies whose inefficiency is no longer to be demonstrated.  That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to welcome draft amending budget no. 5/2015 as a first step in addressing the challenges of migration trends and the unprecedented situation in the Mediterranean area. Given the situation in this area, saving lives at sea should be the main objective of these operations. That is why the Commission must ensure that sufficient financial resources are made available for the Union to be able to fulfil its obligations with regard to search and rescue operations, and long-term solutions to the wider challenges of migration and trafficking in human beings are needed. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1 of the European Parliament and of the Council. 5/2015 of the European Union for the 2015 financial year in response to migration pressures, as the additional increase in funding for European operations Triton and Poseidon allocated to the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund is welcome to fulfil the EU's responsibilities.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. This is an increase, through the realisation of existing resources, in EU appropriations for managing migration and refugee flows following the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and the increase in the number of migratory flows. Overall: commitments +76 million; payments +70 million, subtracted from the Galileo programme. First of all, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund benefits. The increase for Frontex, intended in particular for Triton and Poseidon, amounts to 27 million in commitments and payments, partly from additional appropriations from PBR No 5/2015 and partly from a realisation within Chapter 18 02 (Internal Security), due to the closure of old files under the External Borders Fund.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The human disasters that took place earlier this year in the Mediterranean, resulting in the deaths of several hundred people, illustrate the need for urgent action to prevent such tragedies from happening again. The intensification of migration flows is a major challenge for Europe, which must react to find viable solutions. The draft amending budget aims to strengthen resources devoted to managing migration and refugee flows. It proposes to increase the efficiency and budget of the three agencies directly involved in responding to migration pressures: Frontex, Europol and the European Asylum Support Office. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report in order to increase funding to meet the real needs of managing migratory flows in the Mediterranean basin. The three agencies dealing with the management of migration flows to the EU and two EU funds for migration policies will receive an extra EUR 69.6 million for additional staff and other expenditure this year. The European Asylum Support Office and the European Police Office (Europol) should have more staff, while the two main sources of funding related to immigration, namely the Asylum and Foreign Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Affairs Fund (ISF), should receive additional commitment appropriations. I welcome the fact that the Border Control Agency (FRONTEX) can receive EUR 26.8 million, thus tripling the funds available for operations Triton and Poseidon.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that migration should be an issue within the preserve of the nation state; consequently, I cannot agree to an increase in EU funding for this purpose.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this draft amending budget as I believe that the Union’s resources need to be strengthened further in order to manage the migration and refugee flows following the recent developments in the Southern Mediterranean. I further agree that due to the ongoing and worsening situation in the Mediterranean an evaluation of the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) until 2020 needs to take place together with a proposal for an adequate increase in the context of the mid-term revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). The aim of this amending Budget is to strengthen the three agencies (European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders (Frontex), European Asylum Office (EASO) and European Police Office (Europol)) as well as the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF). 23 additional posts have also been proposed for the three agencies.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This budgetary correction was presented in May by the European Commission to respond to the growing migratory pressures, which affected Italy in particular, during these first months of the year. The appropriations envisaged amount to some 75 million in commitments and 70 million in payments; about 27 million will be used for Frontex.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I have chosen to reject this report which, under the pretext of facing migratory pressures, justifies an increase in legal immigration and a quota allocation among Member States. To do this, the draft amending budget intends to increase Frontex's appropriations - whose futility and incapacity have already been proven in the past - by 26.8 million euros: all this, to "monitor" the Union's external borders, without questioning the real culprit of this situation that is the Schengen Treaty. In total, the amending budget therefore brings an increase in funding to the tune of 89 million euros, much of which will be taken from Galileo's budget. We therefore prefer to undermine our research sector in favour of an incompetent structure, to the detriment of the European peoples who will once again have to carry the burden of mass immigration on their shoulders.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Amendment No 5 to the General Budget of the European Union voted on today in this House is only a first economic response by the Union to the growing migratory pressure at the external borders. The sum allocated of EUR 75.7 million – divided between the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF), the Internal Security Fund (ISF), the specialised agencies: Frontex, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) and Europol – aims to provide additional resources for the current year.  This appropriation should only be seen as the basis for future appropriations. Indeed, I consider the support and coordination work that the European specialised agencies are carrying out together with the authorities of the Member States most affected by migratory flows to be fundamental. I hope that this commitment will also be confirmed next year, and that is why I voted in favour of adjusting the budget for 2015.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Considering that the objective of the draft amending budget Number 5/2015 is to strengthen the Union's resources so that it can manage the flows of migrants and refugees following the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and to increase migration flows by EUR 69,652,000, we support this effort positively.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft amending budget aimed at strengthening the Union's resources for managing migration and flows following the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean Sea. The increase in commitment appropriations is EUR 75 million, while the increase in payment appropriations is EUR 69 million.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
