text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 5/2015 because the recent explosion of the migration phenomenon, the increase in tragedies in the southern Mediterranean and the obvious management difficulties shown so far make it essential to make a greater effort to coordinate and administer this difficult situation. I also believe that, as there is a clear demographic imbalance between the countries of the Union and neighbouring countries, these migratory flows are unlikely to decrease in the short term. Mismanagement of this emergency could therefore weaken other sectors of the economy already affected by the crisis. I therefore welcome the commitment made by the European institutions to increase the appropriations allocated to the management of this emergency.   Unfortunately, despite the fact that a step forward has been taken, there is still a risk that the amount of increases proposed in the draft amending budget will not be sufficient, given the possibility of further deterioration of the situation, due to the unstable geopolitical balance in the Middle East, North Africa and Ukraine. I therefore believe that the Commission must reassess the needs and that a proposal should be put forward which will increase the funding appropriately and adjust its distribution between the various programmes.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This amending budget project No 5/2015 aims to strengthen the Union's resources to cope with the humanitarian emergency and strong migratory pressure, following recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and the increasing size of migration flows, combining immediate needs, notably in FRONTEX, EASO and support for frontline countries such as Greece and Italy. I reiterate, however, the concerns expressed in both the LIBE Committee and the Committee on Budgets. On the one hand, this appropriation may not be sufficient for the emergency situation; on the other hand, the 2016 budget should certainly reflect the measures foreseen in the Migration Agenda. On the other hand, I would stress the urgency of obtaining information from the Commission on the appropriations allocated to the Poseidon and Triton operations. As the allocation is made through FRONTEX, the Commission should clarify the exact amount. Especially when it comes to saving lives, half words don't fit.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The money towards search and rescue missions in the Mediterranean and for an EU asylum policy, including extra staff to handle the increase in applications, is something which I believe should not be an EU competence, and this is something the British people have expressed. I believe the problem should be tackled at source, not when people traffickers have made money and people have started their journey to an EU country to seek asylum. The Australian approach is one I believe we should be adopting, and Britain must be able to control her own borders.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Migration flows to Europe have taken on dramatic proportions, requiring an efficient and coordinated response from the European institutions. In this context, the draft amending budget aims to increase the resources allocated to the management of migratory flows and refugees, through the appropriations for frontex, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (FAMI) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF). In the light of these considerations, I have decided to vote in favour of this report. Europe's credibility is very much at stake in its ability to respond to the great problem of migratory pressures which, for the time being, do not seem to have an end.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a good first step in response to the challenges countries like ours face with regard to migration. The lives of these individuals should not be treated any differently to our lives. We do need to find a longer term solution to this problem. The funding should also go to the Member States and it should be used to facilitate the processing of the applications made. It is also important to stress the fact that the employees of these agencies should at no point be redeployed, but their employment should be handled in a manner which will enable the agencies to meet their responsibilities. Having said all this we will need to have more efficient financial contributions which will be set in the medium to long-term period, in this manner we will be better able to deal with the whole issue and we will be able to reduce the loss of life at sea.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it represents an increase in the financial resources devoted to the European agency Frontex which is in practice militarising the Mediterranean. This amending budget represents an increase of EUR 75 million for this agency as well as for Europol, increasing the logic of criminalisation of migrants and military reaction rather than addressing the necessary fulfilment of the human rights of those persons. Frontex has been accused of not having mechanisms to control respect for human rights in its inner workings and for this reason it is an organization whose development we cannot support. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe faces an important and demanding task. The pressures on our coasts are running out and, day after day, rising tensions are increasing the number of people fleeing and seeking refuge. An eternity seems to have passed, and just over two months ago we were all outraged by yet another tragedy that had bloodied our seas. What's left of that commitment and that indignation. Little, maybe nothing. There is discussion by accountants about quotas, but nothing has changed in the strategic and political approach to the problem. Despite the Commission's efforts, the Member States, some of them, have covered up the debate, sterilising it and limiting its scope. Today we are voting for an increase in appropriations, we already know that it will be insufficient to cover needs and needs. Numbers in hand, we should take an example from a country, Lebanon, which, amid a thousand difficulties, finds the strength to host a number of refugees equal to a quarter of its population. Europe must regain its spirit of solidarity, otherwise those who still hope to break it up will win.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report suggests that the migration budget is increased together with more transparency. EASO and Europol should play a greater role in migration and asylum with an increase in staff and budget. While this financial aid will not be the ultimate solution to the migration situation we are witnessing in the Mediterranean it is a positive first step to allocate further financial assistance to these bodies hence I voted in favour of the report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The migration phenomenon facing the European Union, especially the crisis in the Mediterranean, is increasingly significant. As such, the urgency of this situation can be managed more effectively at Union level. I support the report's view on the need for the responsible agencies not to be subject to staff reductions or reagents, but, on the contrary, to be allocated to them properly in order to fulfil their growing responsibilities.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This amending budget report proposes to strengthen the EU's available resources for immigration and refugee flows, following the various events that have marked the Mediterranean in recent weeks. 75 million in commitment appropriations and 69 million in payment credits will therefore strengthen the resources of the three agencies responsible for these policies by redeploying funds from other programmes, such as the Galileo programme.  In a global context of destabilisation of the southern and eastern European neighbourhood and an increase in migration flows towards Europe, I consider it necessary to give European politicians the means to meet their objectives and challenges, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. According to the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, 137,000 refugees and migrants arrived in Europe in the first half of 2015, on the Mediterranean coast in the first half of 2015. The Commission's response to the intensity of migratory pressure has been up to the challenge. It did design a mechanism for the emergency relocation and resettlement of people in need of international protection; it proposed an action plan to combat smugglers; it also announced the strengthening of the resources of its agencies to support Italy and Greece in the identification and registration of arrivals. States have agreed on a number of these measures.  Now is the time to get to the next. With this vote, Parliament agreed to the release of 75 million euros of commitment appropriations, and 69 million payment appropriations to respond to the migration crisis. These are reallocated budget lines, not additional funds.  However, the amounts released remain insufficient given the likely intensification of the crisis in the Mediterranean this summer.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of draft amending budget (PBR) No 5 for the financial year 2015 because in this way there will be a strengthening of the resources that the European Union allocates to the management of the flows of migrants and refugees. In particular, there will be additional appropriations for the Frontex Agency, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (FAMI) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF).

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. In just a few years, the Mediterranean has become the deadliest passage in the world for migrants. Last year 3,000 died there, nearly 22,000 since 2000, and this beginning of the year seems even more dangerous, since 2,000 have already perished there. They are Syrians, Libyans, Eritreans, Sudanese, Somalis, Nigerians, etc., women, men, children, fleeing, risking their lives, their countries in the grip of war, civil war, political chaos, dictatorship, extreme poverty. And there is no hope that 2015 will be a year of return to stability and peace for them. On the contrary, Frontex estimates that 500,000 to 1 million migrants or asylum seekers will attempt to cross the Mediterranean this year. That is why we have granted an increase of EUR 69.6 million for three bodies managing migration flows to the EU and various funds for migration measures this year. In the face of these tragedies, in the face of their inexorable rise, the European Union and the Member States must, however, decide to act together, to develop a coherent strategy for the long term.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – Draft araking budget No 5/2015 aims to strengthen EU resources to deal with migration and refugee flows following recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and an increase in the size of migration flows. With the adoption of draft araks for a budget no. 5/2015, commitment appropriations will increase by EUR 75 722 000 and payment appropriations by EUR 69 652 000. The increase in payments will be transferred entirely from the Galileo programme, leaving the overall level of payment appropriations in the 2015 budget unchanged. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The increases on the five budget lines sum up to a total of EUR 75.8 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 69.6 million for payment appropriations for those budget lines, but they are fully financed through deployment from the Galileo programme (Heading 1a), leaving the overall level of payment appropriations in the 2015 budget unchanged. Council adopted DAB 5/2015 unanimously on 19th June.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I note that I agree with the report in principle. I have some remarks about the formulations. It is undeniable that much more money should be allocated to migration policy. I agree that southern countries are facing unprecedented pressure. I agree that this is a trend, not an isolated phenomenon. But I don't see a word about Bulgaria, and we are also under unprecedented pressure. It is also appropriate to think about Bulgaria. There should be additional funding. The situation is extraordinary. I would like to point out that there are no refugees from Ukraine in these sizes, moreover – Bulgaria is ready to accept its compatriots from Ukraine. I would like to stress that it is time to say honestly here how many more migrants from Asia and Africa we can accept. In my opinion, we have long since crossed the threshold of what is possible. Isn't it time to give a clear sign that he can't do that anymore?

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report, as it essentially calls for strengthening the reception and integration of migrants, thus aiming to improve the conditions of their way of life.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft budget 5/2015 aims to strengthen EU resources to deal with migration and refugee flows following recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and an increase in the size of migration flows. With the adoption of draft araks for a budget no. 5/2015, commitment appropriations will increase by EUR 75 722 000 and payment appropriations by EUR 69 652 000. The increase in payments will be transferred entirely from the Galileo programme, leaving the overall level of payment appropriations in the 2015 budget unchanged. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of this amending budget, the European Commission allocates resources to address the migration problem afflicting Europe and in particular the countries of first port in the Mediterranean. For this budget, we are talking about EUR 75 million in commitments and EUR 70 million in payments, of which EUR 27 million is going to Frontex (a transfer to the Galileo satellite navigation programme was needed to obtain this sum). Migration is becoming a phenomenon of absolute gravity in which the lives of many people clash with the financial interests of a few; I would remind you that in Italy alone 54,000 people have landed since the beginning of 2015 and numerous lie in the Mediterranean.  It seems clear, therefore, that we are faced with ineffective figures to try to resolve the emergency represented by migratory flows, but equally obvious is that, however derisory, I could only vote positively for this increase in resources.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because it is amputating the Galileo project and, overall, the European Union's migration policy is catastrophic

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Amending Budget No 5/2015 proposes an increase in authorisation appropriations for the management of migration and refugee flows, amounting to EUR 75 722 000, mainly reallocated from the Galileo Programme (EUR 69 652 000).  It is proposed to increase Frontex's budget by EUR 26.8 million, with 16 jobs for this Agency, 4 for the European Asylum Support Office (EAsA) and 3 more posts for the European Police Office (Europol).  We advocate a response to the disturbing reality of refugees and a serious approach to the causes of migration, which does not delude the responsibilities of the EU itself. These resources will cover some needs to achieve this response. Unfortunately, it is far from what is necessary to respond to the humanitarian crisis created. On the other hand, this proposal provides for 'border security' responses with which we do not agree. We deplore the weight of some of the priorities of this proposal – more money to feed the security agenda (Frontex and Europol), while recognising the importance of al-allocation of resources to the EADa, despite its insufficiency.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the management of immigration at European level that has been proving to be unsuccessful for years. However, I am voting in favour of this increase in the budget, despite the fact that it is a drop in the ocean of the measures that the EU should take.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against draft amending budget No 1/2012. 5 in the 2015 general budget - Tackling migration pressures by asking for additional funding to support the European Asylum Support Office (EASO).

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the fact that the financial burden related to the emergency has so far fallen mainly on the national budgets of the southern coastal states of the Union and that the increase in migration to Europe cannot be considered to be a temporary phenomenon, I welcomed the willingness of all institutions to increase the budget appropriations related to migration and asylum, given the obvious and urgent need.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft budget 5/2015 aims to strengthen EU resources to deal with migration and refugee flows following recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and an increase in the size of migration flows. With the adoption of draft araks for a budget no. 5/2015, commitment appropriations will increase by EUR 75 722 000 and payment appropriations by EUR 69 652 000. The increase in payments will be transferred entirely from the Galileo programme, leaving the overall level of payment appropriations in the 2015 budget unchanged. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. The draft amending budget No 5/2015 (PPR 5/2015) aims to strengthen EU resources to manage the increasing increase in migration and refugee flows. Commitment increases total EUR 75 million, while increases in payment appropriations amount to EUR 69.6 million.  The increase in payment appropriations will be financed through the redistribution of the Galileo programme, leaving the overall level of payment appropriations in the 2015 budget unvaried. The following aspects are reinforced: • Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (IIFF) • Internal Security Fund (ISF). • Agencies: Frontex, EASO and Europol PPR 5/2015 represents a first step in responding to the new challenges posed by the real needs arising from the current crisis in the Mediterranean and the increase in migration challenges. For all these reasons it was important to support him.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted yes to this measure because it involves an increase in the funds currently available to EU commitments to respond to migratory pressures. However, I cannot refrain from pointing out that the increase is definitely not up to the current emergency and that it alone is by no means sufficient to close the gaps in the EU strategy on this issue. We need more solidarity, we need all the Member States to put aside their selfishness and to start dealing with a problem that is first and for all European and not just Italian or Maltese. We need a radical change in the approach of the individual Member States and I will continue to do everything possible to ensure that this is done as soon as possible.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of draft amending budget No 5/2015: Responding to migratory pressures because I believe that the refugee issue needs a humane-friendly European response. For this we need action - not theses. This budget guarantees this in some areas through additional funding for the Frontex Agency, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF). It can be a start.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Gardiazabal report because I believe we urgently need to reinforce resources to manage migration and refugee flows, in particular through additional appropriations for the Frontex agency, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF). Too many have lost their lives in the Mediterranean, and we have a moral duty to take swift and coordinated action to put a stop to this suffering.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from this proposal for an amending budget on the ground that the current European border policy is currently guided by an absolutely sectarian concept and contrary to the humanitarian budgets that should guide the EU (Triton operations in Italy and Poseidon in Greece). But voting against would mean cutting down funds that are partly meant to save lives. My position has to do with a profound change in European migration, trade and development policies, without which everything that is being implemented and approved at European level lacks sustainability and coherence.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. In May 2015, the Commission published its 'European Migration Agenda', a strategic document that has been highly anticipated since the beginning of the new Commission's mandate and, above all, because of the tragic events in the Mediterranean Sea in recent months. With this agenda, the Commission is finally taking it! - the measurement and scale of the migration phenomenon in Europe, while we have been calling for European management and genuine European migration policy for years.  At the time, I welcomed the Commission's willingness to strengthen the Union's resources for the management of migration and refugee flows, to strengthen Frontex's capacity, as well as to triple the budget for European rescue operations and the Commission's immediate budget proposal translating these announcements into clear and concrete budget commitments.  I the example today of the rapid agreement reached between Parliament and the Council to increase the European budget for 2015 by EUR 75,722,000 (in commitment appropriations) for 2015 - proof that the European Union is capable of dealing with emergencies and taking action.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs, including myself, voted in favour of this report. This report covers a reinforcement of the Union’s resources to manage migration and refugee flows. It is again a good sign that the Commission is reallocating resources from existing budgets to meet unforeseen needs such as this. This will allow the EU to deal with the crisis occurring in the Southern Mediterranean, whilst not spending any more money.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of an amendment to the 2015 budget. It is indeed essential that additional funding be allocated as quickly as possible to deal with tragedies in the Mediterranean and the increase in migratory flows.  While the budget of EUR 75 million is not up to the current challenges, it was crucial that Parliament approved this decision quickly in response to the humanitarian emergency at the Union's doorstep.  On the other hand, this decision must be accompanied by a new reflection on European funding on migration. An ambitious EU policy, both to deal with the emergency and to understand the medium and long term, can only be born if it is adequately funded. This is not the first time that Parliament has sounded the alarm by calling for a substantial increase in the appropriations allocated to the Union's migration policies. This increase in funding must, of course, be accompanied by strict control over the destination of the funds and greater transparency in the procurement and subcontracting procedures, due to the abuses already seen in the use of these funds in the Member States.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Council position on draft amending budget No 5/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015 — response to migratory pressures. In this report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs calls on the Committee on Budgets, as the committee responsible, to incorporate in its motion for a resolution proposals calling for a response to the problems raised by migration trends and the unprecedented situation in the Mediterranean. For example, the Committee notes that frontex, in particular Triton and Poseidon, is proposing additional funds and insists that the main objective of these operations is to save lives at sea. I believe that, in order to avoid further deaths at sea, we must continue to respect the principle of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibility.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. The drama that millions of people live because of war, poverty, hunger or lack of freedoms today in regions neighbouring our continent means that an increasing number of people are at risk on a daily basis trying to reach Europe or seeking a future within the Union, trying to be partakers and join our way of life and social model. Europe cannot turn its back on these people and, in the present situation with increasingly pronounced migratory pressure, must be able to articulate a collective, solidarity, just and effective response. I voted in favour of this report because it represents a first step in this line, mainly in relation to the current crisis in the Mediterranean, but also knowing that much more needs to be done; such is the commitment of the European Socialists. This draft amending budget should be the first sign of strengthening EU resources to manage the increasing increase in migration and refugee flows. Increases in commitment appropriations total EUR 75 million and increases in payment appropriations amount to EUR 69.6 million.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to support this report on responding to migratory pressures, which aims to bolster EU resources to manage migration and refugee flows, particularly following the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean. Up to now the national budgets of our southern Member States have borne the brunt of responding to the migration crisis, so I am pleased to see an EU response. Increased migration will certainly continue to be a huge issue for Europe into the future, and if not managed properly now, we could see knock-on effects in other areas. Parliament previously called for increases in these budgetary areas in 2014, and although the institutions all agreed to this much-needed increase, it is regrettable that such proposed increases are small, given the scale of the task at hand. I would also encourage the Council to adopt a European approach to what is a European problem as soon as possible.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The proposed supplementary budget is linked to the enormously increased challenges in managing migratory flows and the associated increases in human and other resources. The ECR Group is in favour of the consistent implementation of existing national legislation in the field of asylum and also recognises the added value of coordinating the resulting tasks at European level. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament supported the Commission's proposal to increase the migration budget by the end of the year in order to respond to the unprecedented crisis currently facing Europe. Thus, the financial, technical and human resources of the European External Border Surveillance Agency Frontex, the European Asylum Support Office and the European Police Office Europol will be strengthened. Similarly, the Asylum, Immigration and Integration Fund (FAMI) to support member states' actions will be plentied. In total, these agencies will receive an additional 75 million euros.  I welcome this decision, which responds to an emergency and a need, given the migration phenomenon we are experiencing with more than 150,000 migrants who have crossed the Mediterranean since the beginning of the year.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from this proposal for an amending budget on the ground that the current European border policy is currently guided by an absolutely sectarian concept and contrary to the humanitarian budgets that should guide the EU (Triton operations in Italy and Poseidon in Greece). But voting against would mean cutting down funds that are partly meant to save lives. My position has to do with a profound change in European migration, trade and development policies, without which everything that is being implemented and approved at European level lacks sustainability and coherence.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the Council's position on draft budget amendments No 2012/2013. 5/2015 of the European Union for the 2015 financial year in response to migratory pressures, as this increases funds for managing migration and tackling refugees.  The tragedies that occur every day in the Mediterranean Sea are a clear sign that additional measures and additional efforts are needed to put an end to the continuing danger in our sea. It is necessary to ensure that the financial burden of this crisis is supported by the European Union as a whole, and that the southern coastal states of the Union are avoided. However, the funds in question do not meet the actual needs that are very complex and for which further deterioration is foreseen. I believe that urgent action is necessary that will contribute in an effective and as fast as possible to de-escalating this dramatic situation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote against the report on the draft EU amending budget 5/2015. This report focuses in particular on refloating the surveillance agency Frontex. If the latter were supposed to monitor our borders, we can only see its failure and that today it is mainly used to bring the boats of illegal immigrants back to Europe, in order to ensure that they do not sink at sea. However, this report wants a sharp increase in Frontex's appropriations to the tune of 89 million euros.  If, in the spirit, such an increase seems to go in the right direction, we know full well that, in fact, we cannot fight illegal immigration in this way. Frontex must either be abolished or deeply rethought, so that it effectively and ultimately fulfils its mission: to end all illegal immigration to the European Union.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote related to the complete failure of the migration policy implemented by the European Union, and I could not support the various mechanisms contained within this motion.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the budget adjustment responding to the migration influx across the Mediterranean and the tragedies directly related to this. The European Parliament has committed to putting finances in place to immediately address the problem and to prevent more deaths at sea. The reallocation of EU funds provides additional resources in 2015 for new and enlarged border patrols from Frontex, as well as its search and rescue operations Triton and Poseidon. Rightfully, this is the immediate focus of Europe in terms of the debate on migration. I am pleased that this budget adjustment does not enter into the debate regarding the resettlement of migrants, which is a separate question. I repeat my opposition to mandatory quotas imposed on EU member states.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Eider Gardiazabal Rubial's report on the draft budget amending migration pressures. This report strengthens the EU's asylum and migration capacity by increasing the financial resources of three Frontex agencies, Europol and EASO. The report proposes to create 23 additional positions across these three agencies in order to respond to the increase in activity. Credits from two other agencies - AMIF and EWB - have also been increased. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the European Union's draft amending budget No. 5/2015 for the 2015 financial year - Dealing with migratory pressures. This amending budget would strengthen the EU's asylum and migration resources by increasing the budget of the agencies concerned, while keeping the level of payments in 2015 unchanged, as it is a redeployment of appropriations from the Galileo programme, which has fallen behind.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. EU border security is complex and widespread. The problems are getting bigger and the capacity between Member States is very different, which has a detrimental effect on effective border management. I therefore believe that an increase in the budget of Frontex and Europol is right and proper.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote we gave the green light to the Commission's proposal to increase the allocation of funds relating to immigration. The result is certainly a step towards responsible management of the migration phenomenon. The additional EUR 69.6 million will be useful in the immediate future, both to increase the staff of the Frontex, Easo and Europol agencies, and to strengthen the funds for asylum, integration and immigration and home affairs. However, in the long term, more concrete aid is needed in order to manage migratory flows in the Mediterranean. We must ensure that Member States continue to provide additional means and funding to ensure rescue and rescue work at sea. Let us not forget, however, that in addition to economic aid, we need to take action on the real causes of migratory flows and, in particular, the situation in the countries from which these people are fleeing and the lack of legal access to Europe for refugees and people in need of international protection.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for draft amending budget No 5/2015 as it aims to strengthen the Union's resources for managing migration and refugee flows following the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and the increase in the number of migratory flows. However, these funds are not sufficient to cover the now emergency needs posed by the migration phenomenon, all the more so at the end of the summer season. We therefore call for further efforts not to leave Italy alone in the management of the phenomenon and to guarantee adequate and timely resources.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. Following the tragedies in the Mediterranean related to the influx of migrants, the EU is presenting a draft amending budget No. 5 for the 2015 financial year aimed at "strengthening EU resources for the management of migration flows and refugee flows". It is therefore: 1) to increase the funding of the Frontex agency (26.8 million), to triple the funding of the Triton and Poseidon operations for the rest of 2015, the effectiveness of which is more than hypothetical since we are confined to completely useless surveillance missions;  2) to better distribute "the burdens" on asylum in order to "accommodate an ever-increasing number of migrants".  In total, this is therefore an increase in funding of 89 million euros in commitments, mainly from the budget of the Galileo programme... Needless to say, this plan will prove to be completely useless and even harmful since it creates a gigantic call for air.  In the face of this, the only solution remains a national re-establishment of borders and a policy of firmness on the Australian model. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The draft amending budget aims to increase EU funding to better manage the ever-increasing migration and refugee flows.  The increase in payment appropriations was financed by the transfer of funds from the Galileo programme (savings due to delays in satellite production), leaving the overall level of payment appropriations in the 2015 budget unchanged. Additional funds will be provided to: • Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF), • Internal Security Fund (ISF); • Agencies: • Frontex, • EASO, • Europol. This is the first step in responding to new challenges posed by migration trends, such as the Crisis in the Mediterranean.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it represents an increase in the financial resources devoted to the European agency Frontex which is in practice militarising the Mediterranean. This amending budget represents an increase of EUR 75 million for this agency as well as for Europol, increasing the logic of criminalisation of migrants and military reaction rather than addressing the necessary fulfilment of the human rights of those persons. Frontex has been accused of not having mechanisms to control respect for human rights in its inner workings and for this reason it is an organization whose development we cannot support. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. In the 2015 budget presented by the European Parliament in October 2014, an increase in budget and staff for this issue had already been requested, and this year it has been re-addressed, not to warn of additional payments, but simply to reallocate existing resources.  The idea is to manage the growing trafficking of migrants and refugees in the EU. This increase in migration cannot be considered a temporary fact, as the demographic forecasts to which we are increasingly leaning have shown; this trend requires rapid and effective political attention that avoids further damage to other policy areas. Fortunately, all institutions have agreed to increase attention, and like all of them, I vote in favour of the project proposal, which anticipates these obligations which are obvious and imminent. I also agree with the request to the Commission to review in detail the needs of the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund by 2020.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The proposed supplementary budget is linked to the enormously increased challenges in managing migratory flows and the associated increases in human and other resources. I am in favour of the consistent implementation of existing national legislation in the field of asylum, and I also recognise the added value of coordinating the resulting tasks at European level. Accordingly, I support this supplementary budget.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Europe is increasingly facing a rise in people fleeing their countries due to wars, poverty and a volatile political situation coming to seek a better life within the borders of the European Union. More than 1,500 immigrants have perished in the Mediterranean since the beginning of this year, and estimates show that more than 20,000 people have died in the past 20 years.  If migration flows are not managed in a timely and efficient manner, taking into account all aspects of this problem, there will be an increase in costs in other areas.  The budgetary nomenclature of the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund needs to be amended, which is exactly what this Resolution is talking about. Adherence to the European Agenda on Migration is necessary, although it has resulted in divisions between Member States. In this case, closer cooperation between all Member States is needed and that is why I supported this proposal to amend the budget for the 2015 financial year.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Waves of migrants in the EU are going to increase. After the EU fostered several war conflicts, people are coming to Europe dodging wars and hunger. Of course, that requires more and more funding. I voted for it.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The situation in the Mediterranean region and the increase in migrants, especially from the African continent, require strengthening the protection of the southern territories of the European Union. Already in October 2014, when approving the budget, the European Parliament stressed the urgent need for border protection and the associated need for an increase in resources. I therefore support an increase in commitment appropriations of EUR 75 722 000 and a transfer of payment appropriations of EUR 69 652 000 to tackle migration. There is a need for an efficient use of these resources to protect the southern territories of the Union, to mobilise all components involved in tackling migration, to save the lives of migrants and to combat illegal smuggling.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1/2012. 5/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015 - Tackling migratory pressures, because I believe that the report is not sufficiently documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it. The project will withdraw EUR 89 million from the Galileo programme budget to benefit from refugee assistance programmes. Under the guise of better apportioning the burden of asylum, it is in fact a matter of raising awareness by accepting even more refugees that we will not be able to take in in decent conditions anyway.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the willingness of all institutions to increase the budget appropriations related to migration and asylum, given the obvious and urgent need.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Votes in favour of draft adjusted budget No 5/2015 on migratory pressures. The aim of this project is to increase the Union's resources, aimed at managing migrant and refugee flows, following recent developments and tragedies in the Mediterranean, through additional appropriations aimed at strengthening and fortifying the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders, the European Asylum Support Office and the Internal Security Fund. The increase in commitment appropriations and the increase in payment appropriations will make it possible to make greater efforts to respond to migratory pressures.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 5/2015 aims to strengthen Union resources for managing migration and refugee flows, following recent tragedies in the Mediterranean, and increasing the scale of migration flows. I felt it necessary to support this report, aware that the need to deal adequately and rationally with the migration emergency cannot be separated from a greater financial commitment on the part of the European Union.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. A much greater eu commitment to respond to the growing flow of refugees and immigrants and to avert social disaster from a humanitarian perspective is essential, which goes straight to the source of the issue in order to prevent war, poverty, political persecution and other causes that lead to these exodus. Not forgetting the EU's role in the origin of so many of these problems. This amending budget values a security approach by strengthening Frontex and Europol. So I voted against it.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The situation in the Mediterranean in recent months, in which unfortunately we have lost many lives of people trying to reach Europe on illegal boats, must make us even more aware of the need to manage migration flows effectively and in a timely manner. I therefore support the proposal to increase the EU's budget for these policies and the European agencies responsible for their management.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe that the burden on national budgets would be much greater if the management of refugee flows were not effective. The funds used here therefore avert enormous costs for the individual Member States and are therefore justified.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this draft amending budget which manages migration and refugee flows and increases commitments and payment appropriations. Reinforcement is proposed for three agencies (Frontex, EASO and Europol), the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF).

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report proposes to approve an increase in resources for managing migration flows. In reality, it is mainly a question of strengthening the security assets of the Frontex agency and Europol rather than preventing human tragedies in the Mediterranean or drying up the causes of immigration suffered by migrants forced to leave their countries.  The most indecent and grotesque, however, is the financing arrangements for this extension: an amputation of the Galileo programme, which is vital for the technological autonomy of the Union and also for information on migration in the Mediterranean.  I am voting against these short-sighted budgetary maneuvers.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft budget provides for an increase in order to better manage migration flows. This budget includes an increase in funding from the surveillance agency Frontex. It should be noted that this budget allocated to Frontex is aimed at strengthening border surveillance, when we know that it is too late to monitor, and that we must take concrete action against immigration. The total increase is 89 million euros and a large part of this money would be taken from the Galileo budget, which should not be cut. While we might think that this increase in appropriations would go in our direction to combat immigration in particular, we can see that, as always, the Union is not proposing a concrete solution. The MEMBER therefore voted AGAINST.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft amending budget No 5/2015 aims to strengthen the Union's resources for the management of migration flows and refugee flows, following recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and the increasing size of migration flows. The increase in commitment appropriations amounts to EUR 75 722 000. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I approved the increase of draft amending budget No 5/2015 by an extra EUR 69.6 million in order to respond to migratory pressures and to cope with migrants. Three agencies managing migration flows into the EU and various EU funds for migration measures should get a EUR 69.6 million budget boost for this year. MEPs have been calling for a long time now for bigger budgets in the wake of the April tragedies that cost the lives of around 1 200 migrants. Frontex will receive EUR 26.8 million, tripling the funding available for the Triton and Poseidon operations. The European Asylum Support Office and the European Police Office (Europol) will receive more staff, while the two main sources of migration-related funding – the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF) – will receive additional money.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission agenda on migration is going in the right direction, but the amending budget proposal is not enough. EASO should play a key role in establishing a common European policy on migration and asylum. Very soon it will be confronted with a big challenge, namely the provisional measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. If we want the system to work efficiently, we need to be consistent with the budget. Only a budget managed in a wise and timely manner will allow the EU to respect the human and fundamental rights of migrants and asylum seekers.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal is unfortunately incomplete. The envisaged increase in the commitment is clearly below actual needs, the proposal proposes only the reallocating of existing resources, not an increase in the total amount of payment appropriations for the 2015 budget, and the proposed increase in the number of agencies concerned is not sufficient. Nevertheless, it is capable of financing the most urgent tasks, so I voted in the hope that the Commission would shortly come up with a more comprehensive proposal to address the problem in a real way and not just to put out fires.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposal is to strengthen the UNION's resources for the management of migration and refugee flows.  Frontex's funding would be increased by 26.8 million euros for surveillance, and the aim would be to get the asylum burdens off the line better.  In the end, funding would increase by 89 million euros, to the detriment of the Galileo satellite positioning system.  We are against this text.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 5/2015 aims to strengthen the Union's resources for the management of migration flows and refugee flows, following recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and the increasing size of migration flows. I would point out that the financial burden so far related to the emergency situation has fallen mainly on the national budgets of the coastal states of the South of the Union.  In view of the medium-term macroeconomic forecasts and the opposite demographic trends within the Union and in neighbouring areas, especially in West and Central Africa, increased migration to Europe cannot be considered a temporary phenomenon and an adjusted budget is needed. To this end, I am voting in favour of this proposal to amend the budget.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Following the tragedies in the Mediterranean related to the influx of migrants, the EU is presenting a draft amending budget No. 5 for the 2015 financial year aimed at "strengthening EU resources for the management of migration flows and refugee flows".  The aim is to: - increase the funding of the Frontex agency (26.8 million), to triple the funding of the Triton and Poseidon operations for the rest of 2015, the effectiveness of which is more than hypothetical since we are confined to completely useless surveillance missions; - to better distribute "the burdens" on asylum in order to "accommodate an ever-increasing number of migrants". In total, this is therefore an increase in funding of 89 million euros in commitment appropriations, mainly from the budget of the Galileo programme...  Needless to say, this plan will prove to be completely useless and even harmful since it creates a gigantic call for air. In the face of this, the only solution remains a national re-establishment of borders and a policy of firmness on the Australian model.  So I decided to vote against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 5 for the year 2015 covers a reinforcement of the Union’s resources to manage migration and refugee flows, further to the recent developments in the Southern Mediterranean, in particular through additional appropriations for the Frontex agency, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF). I voted in favour of the report: the Commission should always look first to reallocate funds from within existing agreed budgets to meet emerging in-year pressures, which is highlighted in the approach of DAB 5.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the budgetary aspect of the EU's migration policy for 2015. The aim is to increase the financial resources of three European Union agencies - Frontex, the European Asylum Support Office, Europol - and to create 23 posts divided between these three agencies. Funding from the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund is also increased. The transaction remains financially neutral with the redeployment to these agencies of unused Galileo credits.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome draft amending budget No 5/2015 as it allows for an increase in budget appropriations for migration and asylum policies. We regret, however, the limited amount of the proposed increases, which in no way correspond to actual needs, given the current and probably future deterioration of the Mediterranean crisis, the growing risk of an increase in refugees from Ukraine and the need to address migration challenges in general. We take note of the additional amounts proposed for Frontex, for the Triton and Poseidon operations.  We call on the Commission to ensure that sufficient financial resources are made available to meet the Eu ropean Union's search and rescue obligations. We are convinced of the need for stricter controls on the allocation of these funds and, consequently, for greater transparency in the procurement and subcontracting procedures, taking into account the numerous investigations into the various abuses found in the Member States.  Unfortunately, we note the differences that have emerged between Member States in the Council in relation to the Commission's proposal contained in the European Agenda on Migration and we would like to stress that, given the nature of the migration phenomenon, the emergency can only be managed more effectively at European level.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 5/2015 aims to strengthen Union resources for managing migration and refugee flows following recent tragedies in the Mediterranean. The increase in the budget by EUR 75.7 million in commitments and EUR 69.6 million in payments will be financed largely from the funds previously earmarked for the European satellite navigation system Galileo, which will be reconstituted in 2016. I therefore voted in favour of this project as a first step in responding to the challenges posed by migratory trends and the unprecedented situation in the Mediterranean. Furthermore, I think it should be emphasised that in order to prevent further loss of life at sea, more and more predictable medium- and long-term financial resources will be needed.

name: n/a
text: in writing. – I have voted for draft amending budget No 5/2015 as a first budgetary step in response to the challenges posed by the migration trends, and the unprecedented situation in the Mediterranean.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I agree that we need to reassess and redistribute our funds for a better implementation of our policies on migration and asylum. The issue is not going to go away, but on the contrary, it seems it will only accelerate in the years to come. The EU needs to be able to prevent it when it is fuelled by conflict or crisis, to mitigate migration when it is illegal and dangerous, and to address migrants in an adequate, tolerant and legal way.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report and am in favour of using additional funds for migration policies amounting to EUR 69.6 million. While I am fundamentally critical of the response to the unprecedented recent refugee influx, I also see the need for more financial resources to be a decisive step towards better curbing illegal immigration.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft amending budget because it will strengthen the EU's capacity to help deal with the recent tragic events in the Mediterranean and the significant increase in migratory flows through migration and refugee flows. Migration flows must be managed efficiently and in a timely manner. Otherwise, they could lead to significant costs in other policy areas.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. The draft amending budget wished to increase the Union's economic resources to better and more broadly manage the flows of migrants and refugees as a result of the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and the growing size they are acquiring. It is also, as we are, quite critical of the limited budget increases, since they do not correspond to the real needs in the light of the crisis in the Mediterranean, which is likely to worsen, and the need to meet the challenges posed by migration. Immigration agencies play a key role in this; this amending budget also increases your level of staff. I voted in favour in view of these necessary changes, even though this is only the first step on the path we have to take.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe, in the light of the above, that in order to prevent further loss of life at sea and in order to apply the principles of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibility, more and more predictable medium and long-term financial resources will be needed. I voted in favour of this.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Draft budget amendment No. 5 for 2015 (response to migratory pressures) included an increase in Union funding to manage migration and refugee flows in response to recent developments in the southern Mediterranean, in particular additional appropriations for Frontex, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund. The total net increase in appropriations for this purpose is 75.8m euros.  Following the recent tragic event in the Mediterranean that killed around 700 people, the Council and Parliament agreed that the Union should act. I have also repeatedly warned Parliament and the Commission about the numerous sufferings of refugees and migrants and that they need urgent assistance. One of the reactions is envisaged to increase air and sea surveillance in order to increase search and rescue capabilities. It will also help frontier Member States to take in more migrants, which I certainly think is necessary, especially for members along the EU's external borders such as Croatia or Hungary. Taking into account the Commission's draft budget amendment, the Council's position on this draft and that Parliament confirms in its proposal for a resolution that, due to the urgency of the situation, it is ready to adopt this draft as presented by the Commission as soon as possible and that it approves the Council's position on the same, I support this report.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. After the tragedies in the Mediterranean due to the influx of migrants, the EU presents a draft amending budget No. 5 for the 2015 financial year aimed at "strengthening EU resources for the management of migration flows and refugee flows". The aim is to increase the funding of the Frontex agency (26.8 million), in order to triple the funding of the Triton and Poseidon operations for the rest of 2015, when their effectiveness is more than hypothetical since we are confined to completely useless surveillance missions, and to better distribute the "burdens" in terms of asylum in order to "welcome an ever greater number of migrants".  In total, there has been an increase in funding of 89 million euros in commitment appropriations, mainly from the budget of the Galileo programme... Needless to say, this plan will prove to be completely useless and rather harmful since it creates a gigantic call for air. In the face of this, the only solution remains a national re-establishment of borders and a policy of firmness on the Australian model. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒In light of macroeconomic forecasts and demographic trends in the Union and in neighbouring areas, in particular West and Central Africa, we cannot consider a noticeable increase in migration to Europe as a temporary phenomenon. As migratory flows have not been managed in an efficient and timely manner, it is clear that there are significant increases in costs in other areas.  I welcome the willingness of all institutions to increase budgetary resources related to migration and asylum, as this is an urgent need. I also regret the limited amount of increases proposed in the draft amendment to budget No 5/2015, which do not meet the real needs at a time of probably the greatest crisis in the Mediterranean, the growing risk of increasing refugees from Ukraine and the necessity to address the challenges of resettlement as a whole.  I agree that strict control is needed over the departing funds and thus more transparency when it comes to the procedures themselves, and that various investigations into several abuses detected in the Member States should also be taken into account.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for draft budget amendment No. 5/2015 - In response to migratory pressures aimed at increasing Union funding to manage refugee migration flows following recent tragedies in the Mediterranean Sea. The total level of payment appropriations in the 2015 budget remains the same, as the €69,652,000 increase is fully redistributed from Galileo.  I welcome the position clearly underlined in the report, which regrets the limited amount of increases proposed in the draft that do not meet the actual needs taking into account the current crisis in the Mediterranean, which tends to deteriorate, the growing risk of increasing the number of refugees from Ukraine and the need to deal with migration challenges in general.  At the same time, I agree that stricter control of the use of these funds is necessary and consequently greater transparency in contracting and subcontracting, given the various investigations into the multiple cases of abuse detected in the Member States.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The management of the massive migration phenomenon taking place, which is mainly concentrated in the Mediterranean Sea, subjecting local authorities and the populations involved to considerable efforts, needs the appropriate economic resources to allow the most appropriate responses from the EU. That is why I have decided to strongly support the European Parliament's decision to adopt draft amending budget (PBR) No 5/2015. The purpose of the amending draft is to make additional resources available to the Union for the management of migration and refugee flows. The main purpose of the reinforcements envisaged is to support the action taken by the three agencies directly concerned with these matters: the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders (Frontex), the European Asylum Office (EASO) and the European Police Office (Europol).

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the fact that resources are being increased to protect the EU's external border. This is the most effective way to reduce the flow of economic immigrants to Europe. Responsibility is primarily with border states, but Union countries must provide material and logistical assistance to those States. Border protection comes at a cost, but Australia's example proves that while the emphasis on consistent border protection is costly, it is effective in reducing the flow of economic refugees.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In the face of the urgency of the migration situation, the Commission has proposed to reallocate certain lines of the budget surplus in order to cope with migratory pressures. I voted in favour of this draft amending budget. The aim of this amendment is to strengthen the EU's asylum and migration capacity by increasing the financial resources of three agencies (Frontex, the European Asylum Office and Europol). Other funds related to migration and security issues have also been strengthened.

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the allocation of an additional 69.6 million euro. euro payments to cope with migratory pressures on Europe, because the crisis of recent years has proven that more strengthened measures at European level are needed to overcome this pressure. The allocations are not sufficient for the objectives set – increasing the capacity of the Triton and Poseidon naval operations, which save lives on the high seas, as well as supporting Member States through the Asylum and Migration Fund and Homeland Security, but they are only the first step towards rethinking European migration policy. Bulgaria will be entitled to receive some of the money provided to implement and comply with European legislation on refugee admission – to ensure sufficient capacity for their accommodation, rapid processing of asylum applications, as well as their integration into society. The sad truth is that the conflicts in Europe's neighbourhood will not be resolved anytime soon. Therefore, countries such as Bulgaria , the EU's external borders, must be prepared for new waves of refugees, which are already becoming a daily reality. This preparation will be possible through the allocations.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. The rapporteur regrets the limited amount of the increases proposed in draft amending budget No 5/2015 under this question, while approving the redeployment contained in the report, which aims at budgeting EUR 69 652 000, fully reallocated from the Galileo programme to address the management of the situation in the Mediterranean by strengthening the Union's resources for the management of migration flows and refugee flows. I voted in favour.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. This amending budget, which strengthens EU budgetary appropriations for migration and asylum, is a first step in helping the EU and Member States better cope with the reality of migration. This requires an urgent response, but also in the longer term. However, the amounts allocated will not meet the real needs and finance the measures of the European migration programme. It is essential that the EUROPEAN budget for 2016 addresses these shortcomings. The proposal to increase EASO's workforce by four positions is clearly insufficient given the growing role played by the agency. Priority is given as always to Frontex. Of course, strengthening search and rescue operations at sea is crucial to saving lives. But behind that, it's time to change the paradigm. Instead of locking ourselves into the costly and inefficient logic of border control and return policy, let us develop a real policy of welcoming and integrating migrants. Legal migration is not a problem, but an opportunity, which will bring real economic and social added value to the European Union, for the benefit of all.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 5/2015 aims to strengthen the Union's resources for the management of migration flows and refugee flows, following recent tragedies in the Mediterranean. I voted in favour of this report because the amending budget proposes to increase the staff and budget of the three agencies directly involved in responding to migratory pressures: Frontex, the European Asylum Support Office and Europol. I welcome the vote on this first measure to help the Union and the Member States deal with the most serious migration crisis that Europe has faced.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. By approving an additional EUR 69.6 million for the budgets of Frontex, Europol and the European Asylum Support Office, Parliament is providing a first response to the worst migration crisis europe has faced since the end of the Second World War. Of course, the budget for Operation Triton (border surveillance) will be tripled from 2.9 million euros to 9 million euros per month, but to stem this massive influx, Europe will have to propose more concrete actions. In particular, it is necessary to make Frontex a genuine border protection agency, to develop a humanitarian visa system that would not force migrants to rely on criminal networks, or to put in place a genuine Community asylum policy.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this report on draft amending budget No 5/2015, which aims to strengthen EU resources to manage the increasing increase in migration and refugee flows. The report values the intention of all institutions to increase budgetary appropriations related to migration and asylum in view of undisputed and urgent needs and recalls that Parliament had already requested a considerable increase in appropriations in these budget lines and additional staff for the agencies concerned. However, it regrets the limited increases proposed in draft amending budget No 5/2015, which do not correspond to real needs in the light of the crisis in the Mediterranean, which is likely to worsen, the growing risk of increased refugees from Ukraine and the need to meet the challenges posed by migration in general.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the draft amending budget No. 5 in the 2015 budget, which the European Parliament approved on 7 July in Strasbourg and which provides measures to deal with migratory pressures. Additional funding is planned for the Frontex agency, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund. An amount of EUR 89 million in commitment credits and EUR 76.6 million in payment credits is planned to finance the additional needs of migration measures. As some of these amounts can be financed from unused funds, the financial burden is actually EUR 75.8 million in commitments and there is no need to provide for fresh money.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 5/2015 aims to strengthen the Union's resources for the management of migration flows and refugee flows, following recent tragedies in the Mediterranean, specifically through additional appropriations for frontex agency, the Asylum Fund, Migration and Integration and the Internal Security Fund. In view of the reallocation margin, the total net increase in appropriations made amounts to EUR 75.8 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 69.7 million in payment appropriations for budget lines which will be fully financed through reallocation from the Galileo programme. After the Commission's analysis of the possibilities for reallocation of appropriations under the 2015 budget, a proposal for additional appropriations eur 75.8 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 69.7 million in payment appropriations was submitted in order to provide the additional funding authorised for the 2015 budget for migration measures, which i have agreed.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 An important victory for my country, Italy, is represented by draft amending budget number 5/2015. This proposal to amend the 2015 budget, for which I voted in favour, provides for a strengthening of European resources for the management of migratory flows, of which Italy has been one of the countries most affected. This reallocation of resources will support the Frontex Agency, the Asylum, Migration, Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour because it is a question of mobilising resources that cover at least part of the expenditure incurred by those Member States that are at the forefront of immigration.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from this proposal for an amending budget on the ground that the current European border policy is currently guided by an absolutely sectarian concept and contrary to the humanitarian budgets that should guide the EU (Triton operations in Italy and Poseidon in Greece). But voting against would mean cutting down funds that are partly meant to save lives. My position has to do with a profound change in European migration, trade and development policies, without which everything that is being implemented and approved at European level lacks sustainability and coherence.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The European institutions have decided that the only way to solve the dramas we have seen in recent months in the Mediterranean is to advance the Model of Europe 'Fortress' which has led us here. I reject this amendment, which is intended to provide Frontex and Europol with greater resources for their border control work, which do not have the rescue between their missions and whether to prevent human beings from entering our borders. I therefore believe that if there really was a political will to solve the problem, it would be invested in non-police or militarized rescue missions and then in cooperation policies that help the economic emancipation of the southern countries. However, in line with High Representative Mogherini's plans, it has been decided to spend money on the militarisation of the Mediterranean, something I cannot agree with.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Through draft amending budget No 5/2015, the three European agencies FRONTEX, EASO and Europol as well as the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund will receive extra appropriations for migration management as a result of the increase in the number of refugee flows to the European Union. I have chosen to vote in favour of this increase in resources, despite the fact that it does not correspond to actual needs and is not enough on its own to face the current migratory challenges and the worrying deterioration of the crisis in the Mediterranean.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the face of migratory pressure from neighbouring areas of the European Union, mainly West and Central Africa, and given that this phenomenon cannot be considered temporary and that, so far, it has been the national budgets of the Member States to respond to this situation, it makes perfect sense that the Union budget should be strengthened. In this way, the effort needed to respond to this situation will not be in the sole dependence of the Member States directly affected by the phenomenon, allowing a more integrated response from the Union to an issue which, despite having a greater impact on the coastal Member States to southern Europe, geographically closer to Africa, has effects throughout the territory of the Union which is, at the end of the day and the end , the fate of migrants. For all that, I consider this budgetary strengthening to be of the utmost importance. Not only because of the Union's increased responsiveness, but also because of the integrated approach it contains.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal calls for more staff to work in the following EU agencies: increase of 23 staff in total to support the migratory issue; 16 Additional posts for Frontex; 4 posts for the European Asylum Support Office (EASO); 3 posts for the European Police Office (Europol). It also calls for a budget increase of EUR 26.8 million. I think this is grossly too high. This is why I voted against this.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this budgetary procedure which responds to current migration pressures.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I appreciate the allocation of resources from the EU budget to strengthen the protection of the EU's southern border. The current situation shows that we need to act quickly and effectively. Dozens of people are still dying in the Mediterranean, and thousands are waiting with no prospect of a better future in detention camps in Italy and Greece. An increased budget for EU agencies will at least partially improve the refugee situation and also help southern Member States.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported draft amending budget No 5/2015 in response to migratory flows. The increase in migration to Europe has an upward trend and cannot be considered a temporary phenomenon. Therefore, the increase of EUR 75.7 million in commitment appropriations for Frontex, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) and the European Police Office (Europol) and the transfer of EUR 69.6 million from Galileo is the first step in managing the challenges associated with migration trends and the unprecedented situation in the Mediterranean. It is only to the detriment that last October, when the EP requested significantly higher appropriations, this did not happen. Even if these agencies recruit new staff, the increase in 16 additional posts for Frontex, four for EASO and three for Europol is insufficient. With increasing migration, it should be borne in mind that today the problems of migration concern not only southern states, but also Central European states, and when drawing up the EU budget for the next period, the funds need to be fairly determined for all Member States that deal with migration and asylum policy.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Following recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and the unprecedented increase in the dimension of migratory flows in the world, including towards the Southern and Eastern parts of Europe, the decision to increase the budget appropriations related to migration and asylum is a welcome one. However, the proposed increases in budget and Frontex and European Asylum Support Office staff are dismal compared to what is needed to respond to all migratory challenges in Europe and to avoid losing ever more lives. At present, the financial burden related to the management of migration is still shouldered by frontline sates, either in Southern or Eastern Europe. Given the size and nature of the migration phenomenon, this situation is untenable. Instead of applying emergency patches to our financing system that are insufficient, the EU should make a realistic assessment of needs and revise the financial perspectives related to the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund until 2020.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \ Following the increasing number of tragic events in the Mediterranean, it is essential that the European Union finally responds and strengthens the means of managing migration and refugee flows. To date, the financial burden associated with the state of emergency has mainly affected member states' budgets with coasts in the south of the Union. This draft amending budget supports the willingness of all institutions to increase the budget for migration and asylum. The inaction and almost inconspicuous assistance that the EU has so far provided to the most vulnerable countries could have unimaginable consequences in the humanitarian and social spheres today, if we do not face change in a timely and effective manner. Nevertheless, I am surprised that, compared to Frontex, the European Asylum Office receives a rather low share of funding, while its role is increasing sharply due to the increase in the number of asylum seekers. I support the intention that most of Frontex's resources should be used to strengthen search and rescue, but the relationship between ensuring security and promoting solidarity is not right!  In order to effectively improve the situation at sea and to implement the principle of solidarity between Member States, it is essential to take an integrated approach to resolving an otherwise complex situation and to support activities with much larger and strategically deployed resources.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft amending budget on the need to respond to migratory pressures with more resources for 2015.
