Thanks to this proposal, the three EU agencies responsible for managing migration flows (Frontex, EASO and Europol) and the two specialised European funds (including the Asylum and Integration Fund) will have additional resources, amounting to almost EUR 70 million, to strengthen their staff and resources. In the face of the dramatic events that led thousands of people to lose their lives trying to cross the Mediterranean, Parliament called for a significant increase in the 2015 budget for managing migration. Although the Commission's proposal for an increase was below what Parliament wanted to meet the real needs in terms of the resources and staff of the agencies involved, it is nevertheless an important measure in view of the rapid implementation of the European Agenda for Immigration published in May and being discussed in the EU institutions. Particular emphasis should be placed on increasing funding for Frontex to triple the current allocation for Operations Triton and Poseidon, aimed at preventing migrant deaths at sea in the western and eastern Mediterranean.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The report proposes a supplementary budget for the EU Solidarity Fund due to the floods in Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. The aid for solidarity itself is indisputable here. However, there are various options for how this aid should be paid for. The approval of a supplementary budget for this is critical in that the financial resources could also be saved in other budgetary areas. On the other hand, the EU Member States have the right to allocate additional funds to aid in solidarity to the three countries mentioned. In view of this situation, the ECR Group recommends abstaining on this point.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support an increase in the amount of financial resources intended to protect our borders, because without them we cannot effectively combat illegal migration.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the draft budget change aimed at increasing Union funding for the management of migration and refugee flows following all recent tragic events in the Mediterranean Sea. I also support the recruitment of additional staff at FRONTEX, Europol and EASO, all with the aim of better managing migration. While the goal and will to increase the funds of all institutions is laudable, I believe it does not meet real needs given the current crisis.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report covering a reinforcement of the EU’s resources to manage migration and refugee flows. The increased budget is essential, especially considering the developments in the Southern Mediterranean.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I agree with the draft report in fact, as the aim of draft budget amendment No 2013/2013 is to amend the draft budget. 5/2015 The increase in Union funding for the management of migration and refugee flows resulting from the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean Sea and that additional funding of €69 652 000 will be fully redistributed from galileo, meaning that the entire level of payment appropriations in the 2015 budget remains unchanged. Furthermore, it is also positive that 16 people will be recruited in three agencies, FRONTEX, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) and the European Police Office (Europol). While I commend the willingness of all institutions to increase the budget appropriations in the migration and asylum budget, as it is more than obvious how much urgent assistance is needed, I think the amount of the increase in funding is too limited in draft budget amendments No 10000/2007. 5/2015 This amount does not meet the real needs arising from the current crisis situation in the Mediterranean, which is likely to worsen over time the need to deal with migration-related challenges in general.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal. I agree that, in view of the current situation with migrants, the appropriate authorities should be given the increased resources to deal with this situation. I also welcome the fact that the proposal will be budgetaryly neutral.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on draft amending budget No 5/2015 – responding to migratory pressures. Amending budget No 5/2015 will increase Union funds for managing migration and refugee flows following recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and the increase in migration flows. The total payment amount in 2015 will not increase as the funds will be completely reallocated from the Galileo line. However, I wonder if, with the full scale of the migration flows, the amount of EUR 69 652 000 is right and if no additional funds are needed in the future.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported today's report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 5/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015 – responding to migratory pressures, as I believe that the current situation in the Mediterranean requires an adequate response, including in the area of funding for the UNION agencies involved in dealing with the situation. FRONTEX, EASO and Europol can contribute to the effective coordination of individual Member States and must be adequately equipped to this end, in particular on a staffed level. This is not just a question of security in a narrow sense, but of making effective use of the current instruments at the disposal of the Member States or the Union. Their effective use is a prerequisite for ensuring an area of security and justice, and this effective use must be seded before new measures are introduced. It can also be added that this is not an increase in resources, but only a transfer of resources within chapters.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Funds to tackle the migration problem should be used to prevent migration flows.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft decision by which the European Parliament approves, on the basis of a proposal from the Commission, the Council's decision to allocate funds to address migratory pressures at the Union's borders through an amendment to this year's budget, at the expense of the item providing galileo funding, with the need to compensate for it next year. In considering my vote, I took note of the fact that the direct reason for this decision was the recent Mediterranean refugee crisis, but I think it is important that in the future, in addition to the possibility of a wave of refugees from Ukraine mentioned in the proposal, due attention should also be paid to the need to manage the migratory pressure that is persistent along our Schengen borders in the South-East and the Balkans. I fully agree with the draft's finding that migration to EU Member States should be managed at EU level, using common and agreed methods and financial instruments, on the basis of political, economic and demographic trends in the issuing regions. This also justifies a comprehensive, structural and summary review of the relevant budget chapters, and I consider it particularly important to ensure strict monitoring of the use of Community funds for migration. Looking at these longer-term considerations, I also considered this decision to be an emergency, partial but a step in the right direction, and I therefore supported it.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Draft Amending Budget No 5 of 2015 (DAB 5/2015) aims at reinforcing the EU’s resources that are needed to manage the increasing migration and refugee flows. These reinforcements, up to a total of EUR 75.7 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 69.6 million in payment appropriations, concern the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF), Internal Security Fund (ISF), Frontex, EASO and Europol. With thousands of lives lost at sea on the way to reaching European soil, the present DAB should be seen as a first step in responding to the new challenges posed by the enhanced migration trends. However, more steps are required, particularly as the actual needs arising from the ongoing crisis in the Mediterranean and migratory challenges are much higher. I voted in favour of DAB 5/2015, for I acknowledge the urgency in increasing budget appropriations in order to deal with the growing flows of migration and refugees into Europe. I also consider DAB 5/2015 to be a way of showing our solidarity with the EU’s southern coastal Member States, which currently carry much of the financial burden.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I of course voted for it. However, I am appalled at the low amounts of the increases proposed in the draft amending budget No. 5/2015, which do not correspond to the real needs in view of the current crisis in the Mediterranean, which is likely to get even worse.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the budget adjustment responding to the migration influx across the Mediterranean and the tragedies directly related to this. This provides additional resources for new and enlarged border patrols from Frontex, as well as its search and rescue operations Triton and Poseidon.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft budget change addressing heightened migratory pressures, as this amendment seeks to increase funding to effectively manage the expanded volume of migration flows, as well as the increased influx of refugees following the recent tragedy in the southern Mediterranean.  The activation of additional funds has been proposed for three agencies (Frontex, EASO and Europol), the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund.  The increase for these five budgets relates to €75.8 million of funds fully allocated from the Galileo programme, with total payments from the 2015 budget remaining unchanged.  In my view, partner cooperation with third countries, aimed at addressing migration problems, can only result in the establishment of even more concrete measures aimed at preventing such dangerous journeys from being organised. Europe cannot receive and take into good care of all those seeking protection, and there are also problems with the integration of those it has already received. Therefore, when solving current problems, we should primarily focus on the root or sources of increased migratory pressures, thus achieving effective and timely action.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 5/2015 proposes to increase Union funds for the management of migration and refugee flows, in particular in the light of recent developments in the southern Mediterranean. The financial reinforcements of the three agencies, the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders (Frontex), the European Asylum Office (EASO) and the European Police Office (Europol), as well as the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF) are proposed. As migration is one of the EU's major challenges, it is important that we are effective in our efforts. That is why I supported this proposal.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from this proposal for an amending budget on the ground that the current European border policy is currently guided by an absolutely sectarian concept and contrary to the humanitarian budgets that should guide the EU (Triton operations in Italy and Poseidon in Greece). But voting against would mean cutting down funds that are partly meant to save lives. My position has to do with a profound change in European migration, trade and development policies, without which everything that is being implemented and approved at European level lacks sustainability and coherence.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The proposed supplementary budget is linked to the enormously increased challenges in managing migratory flows and the associated increases in human and other resources. The ECR Group is in favour of the consistent implementation of existing national legislation in the field of asylum and also recognises the added value of coordinating the resulting tasks at European level. Accordingly, the ECR Group supports this supplementary budget.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to address migratory pressures at the EU's external borders, the Committee on Budgets has tabled a proposal for amendments, including the redeployment of increased Community budget resources to support the functioning of FRONTEX. I voted in favour of the draft amendment.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from this proposal for an amending budget on the ground that the current European border policy is currently guided by an absolutely sectarian concept and contrary to the humanitarian budgets that should guide the EU (Triton operations in Italy and Poseidon in Greece). But voting against would mean cutting down funds that are partly meant to save lives. My position has to do with a profound change in European migration, trade and development policies, without which everything that is being implemented and approved at European level lacks sustainability and coherence.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Although I regret that not enough money is given to the Asylum Office and that Frontex is the only real beneficiary and the balance between security and solidarity is not right, I voted in favour just because to boost the budget for the Migration and Asylum area is vital at this moment.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Commission proposal to boost funding in response to the recent challenges linked to migration flows. Three agencies managing migration flows into the EU and two EU funds for migration measures will benefit from a EUR 69.6 million budget increase. More specifically, the EU border management agency Frontex will receive EUR 26.8 million, while the two main sources of migration-related funding, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF) will respectively receive an additional EUR 45.6 million and EUR 4 million in payment appropriations. At the same time, the European Asylum Support Office and the European Police Office (Europol) will receive more staff. My positive vote is a hope that the EU will be able to prevent other tragedies from happening in the waters of the Mediterranean through better prevention and better coordination between Member States.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. It is necessary to vote in favour of this report, since what is intended for this amending budget is to comply with the conclusions of the European Council on 23 April on immigration policy by allocating an amount of EUR 69.6 million in payment appropriations and EUR 75 million in commitment appropriations financed by the redeployment of the Galileo programme.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The European institutions have decided that the only way to solve the dramas we have seen in recent months in the Mediterranean is to advance the Model of Europe 'Fortress' which has led us here. I reject this amendment, which is intended to provide Frontex and Europol with greater resources for their border control work, which do not have the rescue between their missions and whether to prevent human beings from entering our borders. I therefore believe that if there really was a political will to solve the problem, it would be invested in non-police or militarized rescue missions and then in cooperation policies that help the economic emancipation of the southern countries. However, in line with High Representative Mogherini's plans, it has been decided to spend money on the militarisation of the Mediterranean, something I cannot agree with.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my EPLP colleagues, I voted in favour of this report because it covers a reinforcement of the Union’s resources to manage migration and refugee flows, further to the recent developments in the Southern Mediterranean, in particular through additional appropriations for the Frontex agency, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF). It takes into account the room for redeployment, including from the Galileo programme in payments, the total net increase of appropriations requested for these purposes amounts to EUR 75.8 million in commitment appropriations and zero in payment appropriations.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Once again we had to decide on migration policies. This time it was a question of integrating the budgetary consequences of the 'European migration agenda', which gave the surreal debates that we know in the Council, where Member States have procrastinated to distribute some 40,000 asylum seekers, or 0.005% of the European population. The title of the amending budget speaks volumes about "Dealing with migratory pressures". The message is clear, it is not a question of meeting the protection needs of Syrian and Eritrean refugees (to name but them) seeking protection in Europe, but only of strengthening Fortress Europe.  If I can support an increase in the budget allocated for the development of a real common European asylum system, I have doubts when we see that it is above all a question of identifying potential asylum seekers in order to better deport them if their application is rejected. We have little information on the actual use of these funds financed by a redeployment of funds to the detriment of the Galileo project. I refuse to take the risk of giving the Commission a blank cheque in this context, so I voted against it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The amount reallocated from the Galileo programme does not reduce this initiative, and it is in fact the transfer of money which in any case will not be used this year. Due to some delays in the implementation of its activities, this report calls, however, for the redeployment, which comes from Galileo, to be properly compensated in the 2016 budget. In addition, this draft amendment to the budget includes an increase in Frontex's budget by EUR 26.8 million, with 16 jobs for this Agency, 4 for the European Asylum Support Office (EAsA), and 3 more posts for the European Police Office (Europol).  These resources will cover some urgent aspects of the problems, and are far from what is needed to respond to the humanitarian crisis created and provoked in a co-responsible way by the EU, and this report calls for and includes border security responses with which we do not agree.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have voted in favour of this proposal, as I believe that the burden on national budgets would be much greater if the management of refugee flows were not effective. The funds used here therefore avert enormous costs for the individual Member States and are therefore justified.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the Report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1/2002. 5/2015 for the 2015 financial year – the reaction to migration pressures. I welcome the fact that the EP rapporteur pointed out in the resolution the limited volume of the proposed increases in draft amending budget No. 5/2015, which do not correspond to the real needs, given the crisis in the Mediterranean, which persists and is likely to worsen, the increasing risk of an increase in the number of refugees in Ukraine, as well as the need to address migration challenges in general.  The resolution also calls for strict control of the destination of these funds and, consequently, more transparency with regard to contracting and subcontracting procedures, taking into account the various investigations targeting several abuses discovered in the Member States.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have today approved amending budget Number 5, presented in May by the European Commission to respond to the migratory pressures to which the European Union, and Italy in particular, has been strongly subjected during these first months of the year. The appropriations envisaged amount to some 75 million in commitments and 70 million in payments, obtained through a transfer from the Galileo programme.  Specifically, some EUR 27 million will be earmarked for Frontex, which will also see its staff increased, as will the European Asylum Support Office and Europol. Unfortunately, it will certainly not be this additional EUR 70 million that will solve the problems related to migration issues, but, moreover, I can only support this amending budget, which could, however, improve the current difficult situation in Europe.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The migration crisis in the Mediterranean is very serious. In order to manage it effectively and to help those in need, it is essential to allocate sufficient funds for this purpose. I therefore supported the resolution. I welcome the fact that we have managed to secure the money by transferring funds from other budget headings, which has not led to a further wide increase in the budget deficit and the indebtedth of European taxpayers. The funds will be used to support the functioning of the three EU agencies (the EU Agencies for the Protection of the External Borders, the European Asylum Support Office and the European Police Office) dealing with migration management, and to strengthen two Union funds for migration (the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund) from which individual Member States can benefit. It will also be crucial for the future to set the EU budget for 2016 well. In its creation, we should not forget, among other things, that the risk of an increased number of refugees from Ukraine is constantly increasing.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The BUDG Commission's amending budget No 5/2015 proposes, in order to 'manage migration and refugee flows', an increase in commitment appropriations amounting to EUR 75 722 000, largely reallocated from the Galileo programme (EUR 69 652 000). This draft amendment to the budget includes an increase in Frontex's budget by EUR 26.8 million, with 16 jobs for this Agency, 4 for the European Asylum Support Office (EAsA) and 3 more posts for the European Police Office (Europol).  In this report, what is being advocated is an increase in security responses, border surveillance and the repression of migrants, with which we do not agree. We deplore the weight that some priorities chosen in this Decision have, as more money is placed in the insurance agencies (Frontex and Europol). The financing of Frontex's activities is made for the actions of Triton (Italy) and Poseidon (Greece), actions that we reject and represent failed solutions. We voted against it.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I was glad to support this report from my colleague Mr Jim Nicholson. It comes at a crucial time. The global dairy index is now at 634, which is just less than half of what it was in 2014. It is just 61 points below its lowest ever point, which occurred in 2009, and for an Irish dairy farmer with 75 cows that equates to a loss of approximately EUR 35 000 per year. As I speak, people in the town of Monaghan, Ireland, are now paying 29 cents per litre for milk, but that is going in the wrong direction. That is why I was pleased to see such strong support in this Parliament for stating that the existing safety net measures alone – such as public intervention and private storage aids – were not sufficient tools for addressing the persistent volatility or indeed for any crisis in the milk sector. I am calling on Commissioner Phil Hogan to implement more responsive and realistic safety net measures, and to ensure that the intervention price must better reflect real production costs and real market prices.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, what matters here is how much it costs to produce milk and how much it will be sold by farmers, not stock markets. We vote against this report because it puts market interests before people's needs. We have a duty as Members of the European Parliament: to tell the truth. And the truth is that, with these kinds of policies, we are killing the countryside and closing any chance of achieving full food sovereignty. I'm Asturian. It pains me that the Asturian countryside will end, as well as the countryside of so many other territories and peoples that struggle every day to survive, attached to the same. Because killing the countryside is killing who we are. And, ladies and gentlemen, we're not going to let them keep stealing our identity. Discordant voices may sound in this Parliament and we may not be a majority here, but the pulse of history is set by people. And people will never forget that you prefer to split the cake with the big speculators rather than protect people. We won't forget it. History is made by peoples and there is no doubt that we will have a memory.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the ending of the quota for milk production after 30 years presents a challenge for the dairy industry, but also a wonderful opportunity. It has been met with a positive reaction in Ireland, where farmers, as we speak, are looking at investing and upgrading their systems to improve and increase production. I welcomed the report and was happy to support it, particularly given the fact that it recognises the importance of the dairy sector for feeding our own people and particularly for exports. It also looks at the implementation of measures to address price volatility, which are a point of major concern to those farmers who are in the business of producing milk. I think that is somewhere where the Commissioner can – and should – make a clear statement, because there is uncertainty there, particularly for farmers who want to invest but whose relationship with their bank is not as good as it could be in many cases. Certainly, certainty in the area of intervention would help.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – The Russian embargo and the abolition of milk quotas have resulted in a fall in prices, which is why there are many problems in the dairy sector, as is also clearly stated in the Nicholson report, which I was also happy to support. I come from Slovenia, where dairy production is a key agricultural industry. In the country, about 60% of the agricultural area is covered by grassland, most of our area is an area with difficult production conditions, we belong to the Alpine area. And in such areas, where small farms are difficult conditions, farmers are particularly feeling the pressures once the price of milk is falling so much and when it is changing as it has been in recent years. I therefore support the European Commission's monitoring of the situation in this area in order to create a clear safety net in which dairy farmers can be saved from a difficult market situation, but there is certainly a solution in higher exports and high-quality milk products.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the measures proposed by the European Commission in the new reality facing the dairy sector are extremely insufficient and far from responding to the challenges faced by a large number of European dairy farmers.  Days ago, Russia issued a decree extending the import ban by another year. This news the Bulgarian dairy farmers accepted with concern and disappointment. Disappointment because the intervention mechanisms proposed by the European Commission last year proved inadequate to their needs. This is not due to a reluctance to participate in the schemes, but to the European Commission's failure to allow white and yellow cheeses into these mechanisms.  By supporting this report, I call on the Commission to activate adequate mechanisms in a short timeframe and to expand the list of products that may be supported. The free market in the sector leads to the free fall of not one or two dairy industries in the European Union. I strongly believe that the Union must intervene with adequate emergency measures.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent I voted in favour of this report because on 31 March 2015 the expiry of the milk quota system coincided with russia's import ban on European milk products in August 2014. Baltic farmers were the most affected by this, and as milk purchase prices fallen dramatically, Latvian producers lost their competitiveness. Dear colleagues, this is not about numbers and graphs, but about specific families who can lose everything they honestly earn. And to lose not only because of geopolitics, but also because for some officials their question did not seem important. This is a very important report, and I would like to regret that, so far, all the measures have been taken with a delay and an insufficient amount. I believe that it is the Commission's duty to fully assist dairy farmers in the Baltic States and other countries, including Latvia, who have suffered from the war on sanctions. Thank you!

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today, Parliament voted on an own-initiative report dealing with the general situation of dairy farmers in the EU and the impact of the abolition of milk quotas on the situation. The situation is serious, not least in Sweden, where on average a dairy farmer spends a day.  I voted in favour of the report because it is characterised by a crisis awareness which the situation undeniably requires. But also because the report is clear that it was right to abolish the flour quota system. Another important point of the report is the importance of cutting red tape and administrative burdens on milk producers. The Christian Democrats want to see a fundamentally changed European agricultural policy, in which liberalisation and natural competitiveness play a more prominent role. That is why I voted against many parts of the report. For example, calls for an increase in the intervention price of milk (price regulation), criticism of globalisation and calls for new subsidy mechanisms.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it encourages the expansion of the large dairy industry and large intensive farms, at the expense of the destruction of small and medium-sized holdings and a sustainable extensive mode of production. The report is also focused on an export-based economy and market expansion through the conquest of new markets, which I believe is not only unrealistic but can lead to serious problems for both EU milk farms, already mired in a very serious crisis due to the disappearance of milk quotas , as from third countries.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ My colleague Matt Carthy, as Shadow Rapporteur of this file, worked hard at trying to have the interests of small farmers reflected within the provisions. Unfortunately the final report had no tangible obligations contained within which would result in the Irish Dairy sector prospering in coming years; or see smaller family farms supported during turbulent times. The report could have been much more progressive in its proposals in terms of supports to farmers affected by extreme price volatility. Farmers deserve a fair price for their produce and an ongoing situation whereby milk is often a loss-making product is unsustainable. There are ways in which the Commission can and should be more proactive in offering support. For example, an intervention price can be a strong tool to balance a market but the intervention price has to reflect the cost of production. Much of the positive predications of what the post-quota era would mean for milk farmers have abated in recent times. It is clear that many in the dairy sector are finding the increasing price volatility difficult to manage and if action is not taken many small farmers will be forced out of the sector. Therefore, I voted against this report.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The milk quota scheme, which expired on 31 March 2015, poses major challenges for the European dairy sector. In particular, price fluctuations pose serious difficulties for dairy farmers. I welcome this resolution because it calls for regulatory instruments for crisis situations and for the market observatory to be strengthened.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The end of milk quotas, which took effect on 31 March, accompanied by a Russian embargo on this sector, has put producers in difficulty. It is the rural areas that are obviously the most affected, especially isolated areas such as mountainous regions. The European Union is trying to solve the problems it is causing with this proposal. This report attempts to reintroduce some market measures. So it is a modest initiative, but it is a step in the right direction, which is why I have supported it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This review fails to take into account the UK national interest or the huge percentage of our dairy trade which is in fresh milk.  Therefore, I voted against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. In a particularly difficult context for the European dairy sector, I voted in favour of this report. The "milk package" is a useful tool to maintain the income stability of dairy farmers and allows to anticipate certain cyclical accidents. I would like the Commission to face this text as one of its priorities and to step up controls on mass distribution and also to encourage a concentration of the sector and greater territorial differentiation.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Objective is to strengthen the monitoring of the milk market, to seek additional measures to overcome crises. The Milk Package, in force since October 2012, provides farmers with measures to respond to the challenges facing the dairy sector. With the help of producer organisations and interbranch organisations, stronger contractual relations and increased bargaining power have been created. Formal written contracts and stronger contractual relations have provided farmers with an appropriate tool and strengthened the obligation of dairy chain actors to take into account market signals, increase the impact of price changes on the final price and adapt supply to demand, as well as help avoid unfair commercial practices.  I agree that the Commission should take the necessary steps to ensure that the Milk Market Observatory fully exploits its potential. The Commission should also examine the possibility of predicting the pricing structure in the medium term in futures markets and strengthening the competitiveness of the sector.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Until 31 March, milk quotas limited milk production in each country in order to avoid too sharp a drop in the price paid to farmers: the abolition of these quotas poses a serious threat to French producers. Indeed, if European farmers can now produce the quantities they want, it is above all the countries where production costs are low that will benefit. The end of quotas will thus strengthen competition between the French sector (the second European producer of cow's milk behind Germany) and the major producers in Northern Europe, which are not subject to the same standards as our farmers.  International competition will therefore favour all forms of dumping and increased imports, resulting in a loss of market share for dairy products manufactured in France. This report intended to introduce some measures to remedy the most obvious deleterious effects of this total liberalisation of the milk market. However, the timidity of the proposed measures and their catch-all side led me to abstain.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The dairy sector was particularly affected by the end of milk quotas on 31 March and the impact of the Russian embargo. This report, which I have approved, calls on the Commission to implement a series of measures to counter these negative effects. In particular, it calls for the establishment of new financing opportunities for the sector through EIB aid, a review of intervention prices and the implementation of new regulatory measures to enable the stabilisation of supply and prices paid to producers.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. The report for assessing the 'Dairy Package' is of particular importance to the sector as it coincides with the end of milk quotas. The package includes a number of measures to better regulate the sector, promoting an improvement in the bargaining power of producers and strengthening their negotiating position.  The global dairy market is becoming increasingly volatile and reached the highest prices ever recorded in January 2014, after which there were considerable price falls over the rest of 2014. To ensure a fair and balanced free market, certain flaws and imperfections must be corrected, which is more manifested than ever in the case we are dealing with. It is true that the different degree of development and size of livestock holdings depending on the different countries gives a different reading of the situation, but in a large majority of countries imbalance problems persist and need to be addressed. Taking into account the specific problems of this sector, a number of measures and mechanisms are warranted to ensure the transparency and development of a true free market, and the report contributes to this.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal because it urges the Commission to deal with the crisis in the national dairy market for a variety of reasons, including the Russian embargo. I therefore believe that it is also necessary for the Council to reflect on the restoration of aid to producers leaving the activity as well as on the maintenance of previous decisions on milk quotas. That is why we need regulatory instruments to prevent and manage crises in the dairy sector.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Since 31 March 2015, the end of milk quotas has been effective and final in the EU. This has caused serious tensions and enormous concern for milk professionals. Already hard hit by the crisis, the deregulation of markets and the fussy standards of the Union, our farmers, especially small farms, risk losing further purchasing power (many often sell at a loss in this sector!). Moreover, the Russian embargo taken as a result of the EU's measures has exacerbated the sector's difficulties.  Although this text includes measures to protect farmers, such as the introduction of concrete aid in areas at risk and the strengthening of the power of producer organisations in contract negotiations, it does not in any way call into question the liberal agricultural policies that have been pursued by the Union for years.  Worse, paragraph 72 mentions "the possibility of using risk management instruments, such as futures markets, to take advantage of the volatility of the sector to increase its competitiveness." A sector totally liberalized in short and subject to the laws of the market! I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe has not been able to respond effectively to the end of the milk quota system, with disastrous consequences in Italy and Veneto for milk producers. This own-initiative report, while not clearly denouncing the delays and shortcomings of Community action, provides useful reminders to the Commission to put in place strategies capable of stabilizing the productive sector.  Although I have many reservations about the EU's ability to translate the good intentions listed in the text into concrete action, I can only support it with my vote and continue to fight alongside our producers and our territories.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution which points to the particularly serious time for dairy farms to go through, with high price volatility and recurrent crises hampering investment in farms, as well as the serious problems of the functioning of the single milk market. The motion for a Resolution also expresses disappointment at the measures implemented following the adoption of the 'Dairy Package', with a low level of application of compulsory contracts and the fact that in some Member States they contain unfair terms which neutralise the initial objective of stability of deliveries, as is happening in Spain and, in the first place, in Galicia. It is therefore necessary to strengthen the role of producer organisations in order to preserve bargaining power and influence in the supply chain and also to strengthen the Milk Market Observatory.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because, as of August 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a directive on the protection of the environment and the environment. The russian ban on imports of dairy products from the European Union has had a negative impact on the EU internal market. This situation has therefore shown the need to be prepared for the application of market measures related to crises, regardless of their nature. In addition, it is important to ensure a diverse export market for EU products, especially as global demand for milk is likely to grow, and it is also important to ensure a stable, solvent internal market. The European Parliament recalls that the milk package aims at a viable, sustainable and competitive dairy sector in the territory of the European Union, where there are expeditious measures to ensure fair remuneration for milk producers. Instability will continue to be a challenge for the dairy sector. Dairy farmers are particularly dependent on income fluctuations linked to high capital expenditure, unstable prices of dairy products and fluctuating consumption and energy prices. In addition, dairy farmers often take a weak position throughout the food supply chain and are particularly dependent on unfair trading practices. The increasing age of milk producers is also a cause for concern, and therefore encouraging and promoting generational renewal through existing and new instruments is essential for the future development of this sector and for stability.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree that the milk package policy based on producer organisations and the strengthening of producers' negotiating bargaining power are the paths on which we must go forward. Further efforts should be made to protect dairy farmers in disadvantaged areas and mountainous areas. The amounts withdrawn by the milk production levy should be kept within the agricultural budget and used for the competitiveness of the dairy sector. The powers of producer organisations need to be further strengthened and their influence on the establishment of collective supply contracts should be further increased. The performance of the Milk Market Observatory still needs to be improved. I voted in favour of the adoption of the report on the situation in the dairy sector in line with the direction of the European People's Party.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this report addressing the implications for dairies following the abolition of milk quotas and the Russian embargo. The report has been improved by many amendments by Socialist and Democrat MPs and contains proposals and measures aimed at protecting dairy farmers in the difficult situation they found themselves in, from how to deal with risks in the dairy sector, the effects of UTPs and the like.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report as there was no tangible obligations contained within which would result in the Irish Dairy sector prospering in coming years; or see smaller family farms supported during turbulent times. The report should have been much more adventurous in its proposals in terms of supports to farmers affected by extreme price volatility. Farmers deserve a fair price for their produce and an ongoing situation whereby milk is often a loss-making product is unsustainable. There are ways in which the Commission can and should be more proactive in offering support. For example, an intervention price can be a strong tool to balance a market but the intervention price has to reflect the cost of production. Much of the positive predications of what the post-quota era would mean for milk farmers have abated in recent times. It is clear that many in the dairy sector are finding the increasing price volatility difficult to manage and if action is not taken many small farmers will be forced out of the sector. They need more than platitudes from the European Commission.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the dairy sector is not only a sector that allows the livelihood and development of a not inconsiderable part of the European population, but also, and above all, an excellence of our continent and that, therefore, it must be supported and safeguarded.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution on the implementation of the milk package once again suggests that the European Union must correct the adverse effects of its agricultural policy, to the detriment of dairy professionals. The end of milk quotas, previously introduced by the EU, has been in effect since March 2015. This has caused great concern about lower prices and the disappearance of small-scale farms in rural areas, in a context of counter-Russian sanctions that have exacerbated the sector's difficulties.  The text proposed by the Commission proposes to take concrete aid measures in order to preserve the territorial balance and to enable the sector to cope with the liberalisation imposed by the Union. This motion for a resolution attempts to solve the difficulties of a strategic sector for the French economy. It also demonstrates the dirigiste character of the European Union, by not allowing Member States to follow their own policies. For these reasons, I abstained on the vote of this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The 'milk package', which has been in force since October 2012, is the only Community initiative aimed at producers to provide them with the necessary tools to meet the challenges facing the dairy sector, especially after the end of the quota system. Implemented later through the new CAP in 2013, for the first time it establishes producer organisations and interprofessional organizations in the dairy sector. Although it contains some important instruments (structuring the supply chain, production planning, inter-profession, new contracts, etc.), its uneven application within the EU and within many Member States, as well as the difficulty of relations between producers, processors and, above all, large-scale distribution, have prevented its correct implementation.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because the Eu ropean Union must do more to help milk producers adapt to the new market reality. European milk producers are operating in a crisis scenario caused by the end of the milk quota system, the fall in domestic consumption, the Russian embargo and the extreme volatility of prices, which should be countered by an appropriate legal framework that allows production to be organised through supply management in the dairy sector. I think it is essential to encourage research and innovation in order to enable all producers and processors to adapt their production techniques and meet economic, environmental and social expectations. Another challenge is generational renewal. In this regard, I welcome the financing possibilities granted to dairy producers by the new EIB fund, which grants lower interest rates to facilitate investment and modernisation on the farm, while offering funding opportunities to young producers to grow their business. Finally, I would like to point out that world demand for milk and cheese is growing and that extraordinary markets are opening up. It is therefore essential to encourage exports in order to protect the sector.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ As Shadow Rapporteur of this file, I worked hard at trying to have the interests of small farmers reflected within the provisions. However, I had no option but to vote against the report as there was no tangible obligations contained within which would result in the Irish dairy sector prospering in coming years. And of course, while I commend Jim Nicolson for his work on the report, I would have preferred if the report was more adventurous in its proposals in terms of supports to farmers affected by extreme price volatility. Farmers deserve a fair price for their produce and an ongoing situation whereby milk is often a loss-making product is unsustainable. Much of the positive predications of what the post-quota era would mean for milk farmers have abated in recent times. It is clear that many in the dairy sector are finding the increasing price volatility difficult to manage and if action is not taken many small farmers will be forced out of the sector. I have called on the Commission to introduce strengthened supports for dairy farmers who are dealing with increased price volatility in their sector and in the coming months.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This review fails to take into account the UK national interest or the huge percentage of our dairy trade which is in fresh milk. Therefore, I voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I agree with the points raised in this report on the repercussions of the end of the quota for milk production after 30 years in place. The report questions the capacity of the EU regulatory framework to deal with episodes of extreme market volatility or with a crisis situation. Dairy farmers are particularly vulnerable to income variations due to high capital costs, volatile dairy commodity prices and fluctuating input and energy costs. In many disadvantaged areas dairying remains the sole farm income and employment and its continuation is essential to avoid land abandonment. It is important to work towards a viable, sustainable and competitive diary sector across the EU.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is rather vague, leaving aside some of the problems that operators in the sector and farmers are experiencing both on the supply chain and in production practices. There is no mention of the issue of milk powder, of any 'ad hoc' labels on cheese produced with such milk, there is talk of PDO and PGI without, however, properly highlighting how these brands are suffering competition in foreign markets, especially with TTIP and CETA. The text should be improved, but since the M5S delegation cannot be amended, it has decided to abstain.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I wanted to support this report, which seeks to stem the disastrous effects of the end of milk quotas, which expired on 31 March 2015 in line with the decision taken in the context of the 2003 CAP mid-term review. The text thus recalls the important role of dairy farming in terms of land use planning, rural employment and economic, environmental and social development in many European agricultural regions. Taking into account the negative consequences of the Russian embargo on our agricultural production, the report gives real recognition of the crisis in the dairy sector and calls on the Commission to intervene by introducing additional targeted market measures, in particular to combat the effects of the downward pressure imposed on prices resulting from the lack of adequate measures to prevent the crisis , a decline in global demand, global price volatility. Although he remains timid about what needs to be taken to protect our farmers, I have therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The Russian ban on European dairy products since August 2014 has had a negative impact on dairy products in the EU internal market. It is therefore necessary to adopt a package of measures for the milk sector which will enable Member States to adopt support measures to assist producers. I note that dairy producers will find themselves in an even weaker position if there is no support programme . For these reasons I support positively .

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the prospects for the EU dairy sector and on the review of the implementation of the milk package. Overall, the medium and long-term prospects for the dairy sector are positive both on the domestic and world markets. Demand is strong, especially in emerging economies. As far as the implementation of the milk package is concerned, the results are disappointing and the implementation of the measures envisaged has not been uniform in the Member States. Therefore, stakeholders in the dairy sector are invited to make use of the measures provided for in the milk package and also to make recommendations on the new instruments that should be evaluated by the Commission and industry. Finally, the role of the Milk Market Observatory, established in April 2014, whose main task is to disseminate and analyse market data, enabling stakeholders to make the best financial and investment decisions, is underlined.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the prospects for the dairy sector as milk and in particular products with a protected designation of origin, protected geographical indication and traditional guaranteed specialities produced throughout the EU are an essential component of the European agri-food industry. They are also an important driving force for agricultural and rural development throughout Europe, especially in disadvantaged, mountainous and island areas and in ultra-peripheral areas where livestock farming is often the only viable agricultural activity. With the abolition of the milk quota system, however, price volatility will initially be a stumbling block for producers in the sector who are particularly sensitive to changes in income due to high capital costs. Unfortunately, the level of implementation of the measures provided for in the milk package has so far been disappointing, but I hope that more will be done in the future. For this reason, too, the Milk Market Observatory has been set up for the dissemination and analysis of market data, which is set to play a strategic role in the future in the creation of a profitable, sustainable and competitive dairy sector within the Territory of the Union.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because, with the end of the quota system, we need new measures to stabilise the situation of milk producers. The report makes constructive proposals for a competitive and sustainable dairy industry.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is unfair to the British dairy farmers who produce for a market which, unlike many other EU countries, demands fresh milk. It also risks creating another wasteful surplus such as was seen in the worst days of the CAP.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The milk package in place since October 2012 has provided producers with multiple tools to meet the challenges posed to the dairy sector, has also strengthened contractual relations and strengthened negotiating power. It is also true that the implementation of the measures introduced by this package has not been uniform in all Member States, thus undermining the soundness of the sector. The initial objective was the creation of a profitable, sustainable and competitive sector, equipped with response tools that allow fair compensation for dairy farmers, in particular for small farms which are particularly vulnerable to changes in income and risks due to high capital costs, perishability of production, price volatility as well as energy costs and inputs. Unfortunately, the abolition of milk quotas on 31 March began to create a solution of instability for the benefit of large farms. In my opinion, it is necessary to confirm previous decisions on milk quotas and to provide for new financing opportunities, also with the help of the EIB, so as to encourage investment and the modernisation of farms and to enable young producers to grow their activities.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 (M) supports the abolition of the European milk quota system. In the long term, it is positive to let supply and demand guide this market. Now, however, in the transition phase, it creates some negative consequences with a lack of profitability and closures.  (M) cares for a living countryside and that it should be possible to live throughout Sweden. We therefore voted in favour of this report, which aims to mitigate these negative effects. On the other hand, we believe that trade restrictions and various forms of financial support are not long-term sustainable solutions.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it encourages the expansion of the large dairy industry and large intensive farms, at the expense of the destruction of small and medium-sized holdings and a sustainable extensive mode of production. The report is also focused on an export-based economy and market expansion through the conquest of new markets, which I believe is not only unrealistic but can lead to serious problems for both EU milk farms, already mired in a very serious crisis due to the disappearance of milk quotas , as from third countries.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report focuses on the various measures implemented in the dairy package that effect farmers, namely the opening of the possibility to introduce compulsory contracts to help producers and processors plan their production volumes and the enhanced recognition of producer organisations and the crucial role that cooperatives play. It evaluated the impact of the Russian embargo in this sector and other current challenges. The report focuses greatly on disadvantaged regions, of which Malta qualifies as and makes an emphasis on the need for safety net provisions to be made for such regions. The need to have extra assistance to disadvantaged areas from the Rural Development Programmes fund – a notion which Malta is very much in favour is also mentioned. Hence I supported this report.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is undoubtedly a starting point for reopening the debate on the milk package. We all agree that we must guarantee income support for our farmers, who have suffered significant losses in recent months as a result of the Russian embargo, losses which will unfortunately not cease if we continue to negotiate with economic giants that produce without respect for quality and safety. What concerns us, however, is that this report too has not given due weight to a problem which risks undermining the quality of our products, namely the presence on the markets of dry dairy products and milk-free cheeses. We therefore call for the debate on the 2012 package to be reopened, taking into account the new scenarios that we are all experiencing. That is why I abstained on this report, which does not reflect any of our requests and which is ambiguous and inconclusive.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 To counter the possible consequences of the elimination of milk quotas, I consider the following actions welcome: - compensatory income payments – the most affected category are farmers in primary production. The level of this compensation should take into account actual income losses and come from extra-CAP funds; - introducing temporary measures to discourage retailers from taking advantage of the market situation and maintaining high market prices; - the introduction of support to restrict the supply of milk where the market situation so requires.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The aim of this initiative report is to take stock of the implementation of the milk package and to propose a new European dairy policy following the end of the quota system. Given the seriousness of the situation in a dairy sector that is seeing its prices fall, I am convinced that the market law alone will not prevent a new crisis comparable to that of 2008. New regulatory tools must be put in place to avoid overproduction in the long term at the expense of the whole of Europe.  As such, some solutions exist, such as strengthening contracting between producers and distributors, developing dynamic crisis management tools and essential use of the Milk Market Observatory, set up during the last CAP reform.  Considering that it is essential to help dairy farms and to ensure that farmers are able to respond to market demands, I voted in favour of this report, which must not be forgotten and must be heard by the Commission.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The common agricultural policy has long been marked by the milk quota system. The latter expired on 31 March 2015 and a new way of regulating milk production has been introduced.  I voted for this text, which takes stock of the implementation of this new model of regulation. For the past two months, farmers and processors have been required to file mandatory milk volumes. These are accompanied by contracts between states and producer organizations to plan production while balancing the various links in the milk supply chain.  Finally, the change in the regime of the dairy sector must be accompanied by increased vigilance to market disruptions. The data provided by the European Milk Market Observatory will be valuable in this regard.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2003, with the mid-term review of the CAP, EU Member States agreed to end the milk quota system from 31 March 2015. The milk package adopted last parliamentary term has proved inadequate to provide dairy farmers with the necessary tools to meet the new challenges posed in this sector. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this proposal, which calls on the European Commission to put in place measures to better manage the crisis that milk producers are experiencing.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. European milk producers face significant structural challenges with the end of milk and cyclical quotas with the consequences of the Russian embargo. They need assistance from the EU to deal with it. Firstly, the Union must have the tools to respond to crisis situations, as the food market is particularly volatile. It must also be able to protect producers from certain unfair trade practices from third countries.  Secondly, the Union must help the dairy sector regain competitiveness. This sector needs all our support because it has been very destabilized by the abolition of milk quotas. Export markets need to be diversified and new opportunities identified.  Finally, the recognition of producer and farmer organizations needs to be improved.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. As milk quotas ended on 31 March 2015, this report provides a timely and useful assessment of the implementation of the 'milk package', which is why I voted in favour.  Dairy farming plays an important role in many European agricultural regions, in terms of land use, rural employment, economic and social development. Although the dairy sector has long-term potential for growth and job creation, the market outlook is now uncertain, with very high price volatility, in the context of the prolonged Russian embargo.  It is therefore important: to facilitate the exchange of information and the consultation of producers in order to enable them to take into account market developments and anticipate crises; Promote inter-professional management tools to adapt market intervention tools, with intervention prices to be adapted to production costs in Member States; to set up a market observatory which is also a real-time steering tool. Finally, we must combat unfair business practices, which severely limit the profitability and ability of companies to invest and thus adapt to markets.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report on the situation in the dairy sector in line with the direction of the European People's Party. My fellow Northern Ireland MEP James Nicholson has put a producer-focused report on the table. I agree with him that the milk package's policy based on producer organisations and the strengthening of producers' bargaining power in negotiating are the paths on which we must move forward. Specific efforts should also be made to protect dairy farmers in disadvantaged areas and mountainous areas. The amounts withdrawn by the milk production levy should be kept within the agricultural budget and used for the competitiveness of the dairy sector. The powers of producer organisations need to be further strengthened and their influence on the establishment of collective supply contracts should be further increased. The performance of the Milk Market Observatory still needs to be improved. The European Commission should be called on to adjust intervention prices to the real market price and production costs. Furthermore, in the event of a major crisis, the application of export refunds should be activated on a temporary basis. These proposals shed light on the fundamental shortcomings of EU crisis management and concern the market functioning of all product pathways.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for the report on the future of the European dairy sector: a review of the implementation of the 'milk package'. It is trying to take some action on the crisis left by the disappearance of milk quotas. Many farmers denounce this suppression in favour of large industrial groups capable of mass production, weighing down the final price of milk. Small structures suffer the direct consequences of this removal by selling their milk at a loss. It should also be noted that this does not encourage short circuits, carried by local farmers and herders and not by the powerful in the sector.  The Union is therefore trying to remedy a situation which it has itself provoked.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report considers the success thus far of the measures put forward under the 2012 Milk Package and identifies where action is needed to ensure a viable, sustainable and competitive dairy sector in the post-quota market. The report calls on the Commission to address the current crisis facing the sector as a result of the Russian embargo, a dip in global demand, global price volatility and the imbalance of power in the dairy supply chain. In particular, the report calls on the Commission to strengthen the role of the Milk Market Observatory in providing the sector with market data, including market indicators, price and consumption trends. The report also recommends that the Commission work with the sector to explore the feasibility of a futures market for dairy.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report because, although the report is in the right direction, the solutions it proposes are likely to cause further market distortions and do not fully protect producers' rights.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The context of this report is that of changes and prospects in the dairy sector, especially after the mid-term reform of the CAP, the common agricultural policy, in 2003, which provided for the definitive end of the milk quota system from March 2015. For Italian producers, this was a double-edged measure, on the one hand those who were forced to limit their production are no longer, on the other hand the elimination of quotas will lead to an inevitable increase in the offered (especially from the most equipped Member States), resulting in a drastic fall in prices. In addition to the issue of quotas, the text touches on other important points for the dairy sector, but leaves out others that are essential to us, such as, for example, the issue of milk powder and dairy products obtained from it, not even mentioned, and all the PDO and PGI talk which, although mentioned, never refers to the suffering that these products are facing as a result of a very competitive and sometimes unfair foreign market. Therefore, although the text itself does not present any particular problems, I felt that I had to abstain in view of the absence of passages that could have made it a bolder text.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report because, beyond certain common-sense measures, it advocates securitisation of agricultural production, particularly in futures markets, to which I am totally opposed.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In recent months, as we have been observing and warning, there has been a fall in demand from foreign markets. Global price volatility and the effects of the Russian embargo have put increased pressure on the milk sector and downward pressure on prices. It is therefore clear that the EU crisis measures for the dairy sector are extremely insufficient and do not fit the reality and needs of all member states. Existing security measures, such as public intervention and private storage assistance, are neither adequate nor sufficient. The EU regulatory framework does not allow us to deal with episodes of extreme market volatility or a crisis situation after the end of the quota system. This 'milk package' argues that market conditions are favourable and that there are great export opportunities to be explored, recommending that the European Fund for Strategic Investments should be used to drive this expansion. Finally, they want to hide that only the regulation of production, in particular through a quota system adjusted to the needs and potential of each country, can safeguard production in countries such as Portugal and prevent truly liquidating situations, which are already announced. Obviously, we voted against it.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I believe realistic supports, reflecting the cost of production must be put in place.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On the basis of an assessment of the common agricultural policy in 2003, Member States agreed to end the quota regime for milk and milk products on 31 December 2015. The end of quotas presents new challenges and opportunities for the dairy sector. Overall, the sector has positive prospects in both the internal and global markets, mainly due to high demand from emerging economies. Nevertheless, in recent months, the decline in demand in external markets, the volatility of world prices and the Russian embargo have increased pressure on the sector and put enormous downward pressure on prices. Unfortunately, the EU's current contingency measures and instruments are not designed to match the reality of modern dairy. It is therefore our duty to adopt, but above all to ensure that measures are implemented that promote a competitive and sustainable dairy sector.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is not perfect but I support it because the 'milk package', which has been in force since October 2012, is the only Community initiative to provide producers with the means to meet the difficulties and challenges of the moment, especially after the end of the quota system.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the prospects of the EU dairy sector - a review of the implementation of the dairy package because, although the report is in the right direction, the solutions it proposes will cause further market distortions and do not fully protect producers' rights.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the dairy sector. The ECR is committed to better regulation and scrutiny of legislation. This review identifies areas that need action and reacts to changes in the sector. Reviewing and reforming previous legislation is key to reduce the regulatory burden to our own constituents and the dairy sector.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Volatility will be a continuing challenge facing the dairy sector. Dairy farmers are particularly vulnerable to income variations due to high capital costs, volatile dairy commodity prices and fluctuating input and energy costs. Furthermore, dairy farmers often occupy a weak position in the overall food supply chain and are particularly exposed to unfair trading practices. The ageing demographic of dairy producers is also a matter of concern and encouraging and supporting generational renewal via new and existing tools is essential for future growth and sustainability for the sector. The strengthening of contractual relations, foreseen in the Milk Package, represents a concrete method of ensuring a more equitable distribution along the supply chain.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report on the situation in the dairy sector in line with the direction of the European People's Party.
