name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The dairy sector is in a very difficult phase. The problems arising from a complex adjustment to a new regulated framework, price volatility, energy costs and inputs, to name but a few, have been compounded by the very serious repercussions of the unholy sanctions imposed on Russia. In today's report we have analysed the situation and taken stock of the implementation of the milk package. The Commission must act as soon as possible with concrete proposals to remedy these problems and prevent the crisis from escalating, just as the Member States must be reminded of the implementation of all those measures that have not yet been implemented in the milk package that could bring further support to the dairy sector.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the future prospects of the EU dairy sector - review of the implementation of the dairy package, because I agree with the EP's request to the Commission to present a specific plan to address the different problems in the dairy sector. The review is necessary as a result of the end of the milk quota regime and the Russian embargo on EU imports.  The resulting price volatility in the unprecedented markets, which is at the root of the fall in producers' margins, amply shows the inadequacies of the current milk package. These are important issues, which the EU urgently needs to address if we want an innovative, competitive and sustainable dairy sector, and I therefore agree with the reference to the issue of producers' bargaining power over processors and the issue of strengthening producer organisations, in order to eliminate unfair competition and increase producers' incomes. Finally, I consider it essential to refer to the disadvantaged, peripheral, island and mountain areas and to the role that the dairy sector plays in those territories in terms of social and territorial cohesion, the livelihood of families, rural development and employment and the preservation of traditional agricultural practices. It is a just vision, which looks to the territories with a view to the recovery of innovating traditions.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the prospects for the EU dairy sector - review of the implementation of the milk package - in particular for Articles 9, 24, 26 (separate votes) and Article 70 (separate votes). It is important to me that our farmers receive a fair price for their milk and that their family farms have a future. I rejected Article 69: Subsidised dried milk destroys domestic markets in Africa.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the Nicholson report given it openly undermines the free market arrangements in the dairy sector by making the case for a return to supply management of the sector. The definitive phasing out of milk quotas in April this year marked a success of years of hard work to bring competitiveness and efficiency to one of the key sectors of the EU’s rural economy. The end of milk quotas marked a beginning of a new era of productivity and fairness for farmers. I am disappointed that, instead of trying to focus on viable solutions, the Tories and the Liberals chose instead to make an irresponsible case to get back to market management and intervention. It was even more surprising to see some Eurosceptic Tories voting for the European Commission to effectively commit more funds to market-distorting intervention. Farmers are at the heart of our rural communities and everyone, from Commissioners to consumers, must act to ensure they get a fairer deal.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The history of milk quotas, which over the years has so animated the European debate, ended after 30 years. There is no point in asking whether it was good or bad, there is no point in reopening the controversy. Today we need proposals, we need to transform the end of milk quotas from unbridled liberalisation to opportunity. It is estimated that without the bridle of quotas milk production will increase, so we must put our producers in a position to grow, to be able to produce in larger quantities, eliminating all the other obstacles that chain them and limit them much more than when they did not make quotas. We must act on all those barriers that stand in the way of production and competition, on the Russian embargo first of all, but also on the fiscal constraints and red tape that only increase production costs. And then focus on the quality and enhancement of the famous know-how and made in, real protections and guarantees of extraordinary agri-food production, heritage of the whole of Europe.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because the overall approach to this report does not meet the real needs of dairy farmers or society. There are important parts in its wording that include a strong neoliberal approach, in proposing, for example, that financial risk mechanisms be used to take advantage of price volatility in the sector, rather than establishing other instruments aimed at reducing such volatility. In addition, the rapporteur's interest in opening up to foreign markets is clear when our perspective is to prioritize and protect traditional production, as well as to strengthen local markets in order to move towards food sovereignty.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the crisis in the dairy sector requires decisive action by the Commission. The milk package currently being implemented does not improve the situation of milk producers and its mechanisms are ineffective and too bureaucratic. In many EU countries, including my own country, Poland, the proposals for producer organisations have not worked. These solutions do not respond to the problems of the dairy sector, i.e. the fall in global demand, price volatility and imbalances in the supply chain, which are further exacerbated by the effects of the Russian embargo.  I also supported this report because of the provision drawing the Commission's attention to the problem of high penalties for exceeding milk quotas in the last two years of quotas. This amendment was promoted by me and my colleagues from the Polish ECR delegation. The penalties that have affected Polish farmers in particular are not justified on economic grounds, as the limits have not been exceeded across the EU.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it demonstrates our solidarity with dairy farmers affected by the global slump in milk prices. While we support measures aimed at reducing market inequalities in food supply chains, Labour MEPs are calling for government action to strengthen the powers of the Groceries Code Adjudicator to defend farmers’ interests against supermarkets driving down farm-gate prices, and for greater consumer action.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because the 'milk package', which came into force in 2012, is an important tool to deal with the challenges faced by the dairy sector, particularly in terms of market management now that the quota system has disappeared. The abolition of quotas could lead to a further concentration of milk production to the benefit of the largest dairy farms and to the detriment of the smaller producers, which we must therefore protect.  I regret, however, that the implementation of the 'milk package' has been rather disappointing so far. It needs to be improved, and I support, in particular, the development of additional tools to better anticipate and make dealings with crisis situations and market volatility, a major challenge for producers.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the future of the EU dairy sector. Review of the implementation of the milk package'.  As the Milk Package, which has been in place since October 2012, which provides farmers with the means to respond to the challenges facing the dairy sector has been disappointing and has not helped to achieve its objectives, the EU needs to take new measures. This report sets out the position on which the Commission should take the necessary steps to ensure that the Milk Market Observatory fully exploits its potential. The information provided by the Milk Market Observatory should include news of market and price trends and should be more accessible and user-friendly than its current presentation. The activities of the Milk Market Observatory should be supported by Member States by providing adequate information in a timely manner and the Commission is recommended to examine additional ways of obtaining such information in due time. Strengthening the contractual relationship provided for in the Milk Package is a concrete approach to ensure a more balanced distribution throughout the supply chain. The report asks the Commission and other actors in the EU dairy sector to explore the potential for long-term integrated supply chain transactions, forward transactions, fixed margin transactions, AB transactions and the possibility of capturing the price of milk for a certain period of time. This should help to strengthen the dairy industry in the future, which is so important in Lithuania as it is.

The report highlights the importance of adequate market measures for the sector, which I support.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The UK dairy farmers are hit hard by this legislation since they, unlike their European colleagues, cater for a market which predominantly is involved in a market with a high demand for fresh milk rather than powdered or UHT.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. The crisis that dairy farmers have been going through since the end of the milk quota system proves that the European Union was insufficiently prepared for a situation of extreme gravity that we could have predicted. The existence of dairy farms is not only essential for our economies, it is also essential for the identity of our countryside.  The current episode of extreme price volatility combined with unfair trade practices in certain sectors of the supply chain exposes farmers to an unstable situation, plunging them into a state of vulnerability and discouragement that is strictly intolerable. Europe's role is to support the modernisation and investment efforts of the agricultural world in order to be able to cope with global competition. It is certainly not to be destroyed by the force of the market law alone. There is an urgent need to propose a new European dairy policy that will introduce mechanisms to regulate the dairy sector more calmly.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report notes that the dairy sector has to date not fully engaged with such schemes as the protected geographical indicator status. Many areas of the EU produce wonderful traditional dairy products and I include amongst those the Cambus O’May cheese from my own constituency. PGI status adds value to these excellent products and I was happy to support this report.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 There is a high risk for dairy farmers in a small country such as Bulgaria after the abolition of milk quotas. It is a well-known fact that only in our yogurt there is the bacterium lactobacilus bulgaricus, which makes it tasty, healthy and in demand around the world. I therefore hope that the EU will be able to use all the opportunities for expansion of the economy so as not to deprive ourselves of such valuable products in the absence of milk quotas.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because the overall approach to this report does not meet the real needs of dairy farmers or society. There are important parts in its wording that include a strong neoliberal approach, in proposing, for example, that financial risk mechanisms be used to take advantage of price volatility in the sector, rather than establishing other instruments aimed at reducing such volatility. In addition, the rapporteur's interest in opening up to foreign markets is clear when our perspective is to prioritize and protect traditional production, as well as to strengthen local markets in order to move towards food sovereignty.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the 'Dairy Package'. The report stresses that the reformed CAP offers a wide range of tools to help a competitive and sustainable dairy sector.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE)
text: Writing. The phasing out of the EU-wide quota system for milk production offers European dairy farmers a great opportunity to benefit from the sharp increase in global demand for dairy products in recent years. However, the European dairy sector is currently in a serious crisis situation due to the effects of the Russian trade embargo and falling producer prices. The European Parliament today called for an appropriate response to these challenges and for improving the international competitiveness of the EU dairy sector. I call on the Commission to develop uniform rules for the production, processing and marketing of dairy products throughout Europe and to provide appropriate crisis instruments. In addition, the current situation means that intervention must be opened up. Now is the latest time to ease the burden on the market through intervention purchases. Overall, much greater attention must be paid within Europe to strengthen the position of producers in relation to the often overpowering retail chains and to better protect them from unfair business practices. The price war of the discounters must not be fought on the backs of the dairy farmers, who have long since reached the lower end of the flagpole in the face of ever-increasing price pressures.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the future of the EU dairy sector - a review of the implementation of the 'milk package' as this proposal raises the level of competitiveness and sustainability of this sector suffering the effects of the crisis. The solution to the problems arising from the crisis is not the same in each Member State, but different ways of solving them, such as the processing of milk into a higher level of product, could be applied.  The importance of the dairy sector also stems from the fact that it is an extremely important part of the agri-food industry, in terms of job creation and long-term growth, especially in rural, outermost and island towns and regions. It is therefore necessary to ensure market stability through additional promotion and quality programmes to ensure the growth and improvement of the sector.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The end of milk quotas, which took effect on 31 March, accompanied by a Russian embargo in this sector, has put producers in difficulty. It is the rural areas that are obviously the most affected, especially isolated areas such as mountainous regions. The European Union is trying to solve the problems it is causing with this proposal. This report attempts to reintroduce some market measures. I have, therefore, decided to vote for this report.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague John Nicholson's report on the review of the implementation of the 'milk package'. In the run-up to the end of milk quotas on 31 March 2015, the EU had put in place a measure to allow a better balance between milk producers and their buyers so that producers are not harmed by traders.  This report reminds us of the importance of milk producers for Europe's food independence and their vulnerability. The text also highlights the inadequacy of the security measures currently planned to deal with the new challenges that the end of milk quotas will create. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the future of the European dairy sector. In the face of difficulties affecting national dairy markets, particularly due to the Russian embargo, it is essential to give priority to this issue and to strengthen targeted market measures in order to make the dairy sector viable, competitive and sustainable on eu territory.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The expiry of the milk quota system is hitting the European dairy sector, which has long been struggling to implement the Russian embargo. The average price of milk received by producers has fallen by more than 16% over the last year, and the same is also true for dairy products, among which the price of, for example, skimmed-milk powder has fallen by around 35%. In addition, supply continues to grow and dairies are bursting at the seams without finding a sufficiently large market for their products. If we add to this the penalties that Member States will have to pay for exceeding quotas (in some countries it will be hundreds of millions of euros), the crisis in the sector is becoming extremely serious. Unfortunately, the measures taken by the European Commission to improve the situation on the EU milk market are still insufficient. It is crucial to put in place mechanisms to reduce the severe effects of the Russian embargo and to end the quota system. An increase in intervention prices appears necessary in order for farmers to be able to obtain at least compensation equal to the cost of production. On the other hand, the distribution of penalties for exceeding amounts in instalments will mitigate the financial consequences. I also call for the funds from the above-called fees to go back to the dairy sector, because it is in a really difficult situation.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The report provides a coherent picture of the European dairy sector. I am particularly pleased that he highlights the opportunities offered by the abolition of the milk quota. I am therefore voting in favour of the report.

name: Rikke Karlsson (ECR)
text: Written. – Before this vote is over, milk prices will have fallen further and this will continue. Eu legislation in this area has never worked as intended and probably will not. It is still farmers who will pay the highest price, which is extremely worrying, but Nicholson's proposal may shed more light on the challenges we face.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft report on the outlook for the EU dairy sector — review of the implementation of the milk and milk products package primarily deals with the implementation of the milk and milk products package (the so-called milk package), which is valid from 3 June 2012 until 30 June 2020. The report notes that milk producers are particularly vulnerable due to market fluctuations and price fluctuations. The current situation is negatively affected by the Russian embargo. According to the report, the milk package has a low level of implementation. The report recommends greater use of the potential of long-term contracts. It also proposes that more use be made of promotional measures and that protected designations of origin and protected geographical indications be better treated. The report also stresses that the current measures of the TT safety net such as public intervention and private storage are not sufficient and the European Commission is encouraged to put in place additional safeguards. I therefore voted in favour of the draft report without hesitation, because it is in the interest of the Czech citizens for the European Commission to take further measures to stabilise the milk market.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report on the situation in the dairy sector in line with the direction of the European People's Party. My fellow Northern Ireland MEP James Nicholson has put a producer-focused report on the table. I agree with him that the milk package's policy based on producer organisations and the strengthening of producers' bargaining power in negotiating are the paths on which we must move forward. Specific efforts should also be made to protect dairy farmers in disadvantaged areas and mountainous areas. The amounts withdrawn by the milk production levy should be kept within the agricultural budget and used for the competitiveness of the dairy sector. The powers of producer organisations need to be further strengthened and their influence on the establishment of collective supply contracts should be further increased. The performance of the Milk Market Observatory still needs to be improved. It is Hungary that both of my fellow Members Norbert Erdős's proposals to increase the effectiveness of crisis management have been included in the report. The European Commission should be called on to adjust intervention prices to the real market price and production costs. Furthermore, in the event of a major crisis, the application of export refunds should be activated on a temporary basis. These proposals shed light on the fundamental shortcomings of EU crisis management and concern the market functioning of all product pathways.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr Nicholson's proposal. The 'milk package' entered into force on 3 October 2012 and is applicable until 30 June 2020 and, as set out in the 2003 MID-TERM REVIEW of the CAP, milk quotas will expire on 31 March 2015. Russia's ban on European dairy products in August 2014 had a negative impact on the EU internal market and therefore highlighted the need to be ready to apply crisis-related market measures, regardless of their nature, and the importance of ensuring diversification of export markets for UNION products. Finally, I would like to stress the role of dairy production in terms of land management, rural employment and the economic, environmental and social development of many European agricultural regions.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Last year saw the prices of milk and certain components used to produce milk fluctuate violently. As it stands, the prices paid to producers are well below production costs. To top it all off, the end of production quotas exacerbates these trends by no longer guaranteeing fair incomes and by severely undermining the viability of small farms.  In the end, we are witnessing a strengthening of large producers at the expense of small producers, increasingly concentrating production, against consumer choice, environmental rules, and rural activity This resolution rightly raises the alarm bells for dairy farmers, but without asking to change the current production rules. It simply calls to play with the current instruments when these have no impact on fund trends!  On the contrary, I support the establishment of price monitoring and call for a mechanism of remunerative prices on production volumes to compensate peasant labour. That is why I objected to the adoption of this report, which does not provide any funding for the ongoing drama in our campaigns.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. Certainly, it has the merit of trying to help milk producers who are in a worrying economic situation. In particular, it aims to strengthen the power of producer organisations so that they can better negotiate milk sales contracts. However, this text will not work miracles. The end of milk quotas has plunged milk producers into lasting difficulties, delivering their production without precautions to the law of the market. Much more seriously, this text endorses the new system by yielding to the ultraliberalism of the environment, in particular to paragraph 72.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained. The end of milk quotas is bad news for the sector. This project contains good proposals, such as support for farms in disadvantaged areas, producer organisations and the announced desire to avoid the consequences of too much deregulation. There is therefore a desire to push the Commission to act, which it has not done so far.  That being said, there are other concerns. Suggesting relying on futures markets for risk management and taking advantage of price volatility to make the sector more competitive appears to be a threat to the sector. This is the consequence of the liberal model that pushes the concentration of farms to make them more productive and competitive. However, this is at the expense of other more fragile farms with negative impacts on rural areas.  So there is a form of contradiction in this catch-all relationship. Together with my colleagues, I do not want to take the risk of sacrificing our farms on the altar of productivity.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The EP's motion for Resolution identifies as major sector challenges the high price volatility and recurrent crises that hinder investment in farms, as well as the problems of the functioning of the single milk market. The 'Dairy Package' highlights the disappointment at the low level of application of compulsory contracts and the fact that in some Member States they contain unfair terms which neutralise the initial objective of stability in deliveries, as is happening in Spain. It calls for the strengthening of the Milk Market Observatory, which calls for a more important role in the recommendation of measures based on market analysis and crisis prevention. In accordance with these considerations, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it encourages the expansion of the large dairy industry and large intensive farms, at the expense of the destruction of small and medium-sized holdings and a sustainable extensive mode of production. The report is also focused on an export-based economy and market expansion through the conquest of new markets, which I believe is not only unrealistic but can lead to serious problems for both EU milk farms, already mired in a very serious crisis due to the disappearance of milk quotas , as from third countries.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. The Milk Package aims to strengthen the position of dairy producers in the dairy supply chain and prepare the sector for a sustainable and market-oriented future. As there have been significant changes in various segments of the European Union, the effects in the EU dairy sector need to be analysed.  The report states that the dairy sector has a long-term perspective, but also that demand for milk and dairy products is volatile. In addition, the possibility of obtaining funding from the European Investment Bank to assist Member States to implement the necessary reforms should be opened up. It is important to strengthen national initiatives in implementing reforms.  Statistical indicators for the Republic of Croatia show that in 2014 the number of milk suppliers fell by 11 percent, and the number of dairy cows in the last 5 years has fallen by as much as 25 percent. On the other hand, the quality of Croatian milk is at an enviable level. It is clear that reform is needed in the dairy sector, which this Report highlights, and that is why I supported the same.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. What quotas can we talk about when dairy companies close in Eastern Europe one after the other? I voted in favour because that will be an additional mechanism to help farmers in my country, Latvia.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the prospects of the EU dairy sector – a review of the implementation of the dairy package, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 6/7/2015 and because it does not take into account the damage suffered by dairy production in Greece, with the troika having dismantled the primary sector by crushing my fellow farmers in poverty and poverty.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report. This text attempts to overcome the uncertainties associated with the end of milk quotas, effective since 31 March 2015. The end of quotas had caused great concern among professionals who feared that market laws would lead to lower prices and a loss of operations. This text proposes to the Commission to re-introduce quotas in certain areas at risk, under the guise of protecting the territorial balance. This report is an attempt by the Union to back down, now that it is aware of its mistake. We blame him for his decision to end the quotas that are causing the problem, but we welcome this attempt to remedy the crisis suffered by the sector.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report stresses that dairy producers, especially small-scale dairy producers, are particularly vulnerable to imbalances in the supply chain, in particular owing to fluctuating demand, rising production costs and decreasing farm-gate prices, but also to the economic priorities in each Member State.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the dairy package. The dairy sector contributes decisively to the promotion of the image of the European agri-food industry in the world, therefore it represents a fundamental pillar of the economy. The milk mini-package was one of the first major agricultural legislative acts adopted by the European Parliament and the Council under the ordinary legislative procedure, which has applied to agriculture since the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon. This report emphasises the need for all parties involved in the milk supply chain to adopt and make use of the instruments provided for in the milk package (whereas the implementation of the measures provided for in the milk package has proved inadequate) in order to stabilise the milk market and consequently the incomes of milk producers in times of crisis.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the milk package is to promote conditions for a profitable, sustainable and competitive dairy sector within the Community. I have decided to support this report with a favourable vote, aware that the consolidation and improvement of contractual relations would help to ensure a fairer distribution of revenues along the production chain, giving the same added value.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The dairy sector is going through a time of great uncertainty and our producers have a logical concern about a crisis situation that seems to have no end. My support for the report which sets out concrete measures to support farmers. I hope that both from the Commission and from the Member States these proposals will be addressed to improve the capacity of producer organisations and to create an effective alert system to act immediately in the event of a price drop.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report as it is partly capable of sustainably improving the current situation of dairy farmers in the EU. Unfortunately, despite some positive aspects, such as the development of safety instruments to counteract the fall in the price of milk, the core problem, the abolition of the milk quota, remains untouched.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. The Russian embargo on EU dairy imports has severely affected farmers in Europe, including Lithuania. Dairy farmers, especially small family farms, are poorly protected against fluctuations in income levels, and their livelihoods from dairy farming are a constant challenge, as production costs are often equal to or above buying-in prices. In addition, the abolition of milk quotas, which has entered into force, also raises a number of questions and challenges that require new measures and Commission proposals.  In view of these and a number of other problems that concern milk producers and processors, the European Parliament calls on the Commission in its report to provide for new ways of financing Member States, including through the support of the European Investment Bank (EIB), and to implement the reform of the dairy industry.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Prospects for the EU dairy sector – review of the implementation of the dairy package, outlines the opportunities and threats to the sector in the medium to long term in the context of the new era for milk producers post quota abolition. The report highlights the important of adequate market measures for the sector, which I support.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. On 31 March 2015, milk quotas expired, in line with the decision taken as part of the 2003 CAP mid-term review. In an increasingly deregulated global market and price volatility, selling prices are often lower than production costs. The text rightly regrets the disappearance of quotas and proposes a "milk package" which should enable, by contracting between the actors of production and those in processing/distribution, to plan production volumes and strengthen the sectors. Back to square one? However, the text does not for a moment envisage redirecting European agricultural production to the level of its consumption or introducing protectionism on these products. It merely "asks the Commission to define an adequate legal framework to enable the organisation of production through supply management in the dairy sector". I am voting against this text, which does not take the measure of the ecological and commercial issues raised.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The end of milk quotas, which took effect on 31 March, accompanied by a Russian embargo in this sector, has put producers in difficulty. It is the rural areas that are obviously the most affected, especially isolated areas such as mountainous regions. The European Union is trying to solve the problems it is causing with this proposal. This report attempts to reintroduce some market measures. As this solution was a lesser evil, the Member voted in favour.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is urgent that the European Commission take additional market action to address the milk crisis. Following the pressure to reduce prices, resulting from the lack of adequate crisis prevention instruments, a drop in global demand, price volatility and russia's embargo on European dairy products, it is extremely important to defend a sector with a major socio-economic contribution to agricultural and rural development.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the review of the implementation of the dairy package, which aims at helping EU dairy producers to boost their bargaining power. We need to secure various export opportunities for EU produce shut out of the Russian market and improve the current volatility confronting dairy farmers. The report covers all these aspects plus the impact of the Russian embargo, broader challenges and opportunities in the sector, and the particular problems faced by disadvantaged, mountainous and outermost regions.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The CAP is a particular slice of EU policy that requires specific knowledge and preparedness. I have unreserved confidence in the competence of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development in this way, and I voted on this basis.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The so-called 'milk package' entered into force on 3 October 2012 and is valid until 30 June 2020. It was decided in the 2003 mid-term review of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) that milk quotas expired on 31 March 2015. Nevertheless, given the specific nature of milk production in mountainous areas, disadvantaged areas and the outermost regions of the European Union, the measures set out in the resolution of 11 December 2013 advocate the maintenance of such production after the expiry of the milk quota system. I am voting in favour of this report because it argues that the removal of quotas would have a largely detrimental effect on the outermost regions, especially in the Autonomous Region of the Azores, where milk production is the main economic activity, representing about 46% of the regional economy. For the above, and the fact that the rapporteur emphasises the importance of creating in the outermost regions a transitional mechanism between the end of quotas and the liberalisation of markets to protect producers and the sector in these regions, this report has my vote in favour.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Nicholson report on the implementation of the "milk package" comes as part of the end of the effective milk quotas since 31 March 2015. This decision may have raised the concerns and even the indignation of the players in the milk sector. Indeed, our operators have already been heavily affected by the crisis and market deregulation, and now risk a substantial loss of their income to the benefit of the largest producers. As a result, many are forced to sell at a loss. The embargo against Russia also substantially affected the exports of French operators. This text does not call into question these deregulation policies carried out by the Union for years and confirms the dismantling of the Community preference, even if it tries pusily to protect farmers a little more, in particular with the introduction of aid in danger zones and the strengthening of the powers of producer organisations in negotiations. I therefore abstained in the vote on this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it demonstrates our solidarity with dairy farmers affected by the slump in milk prices. The report also includes useful policy suggestions aiming at reducing market imbalances in the food supply chains which has traditionally been a strong Labour line. The report is also right in arguing in favour of enhancement of farmers’ participation in producers’ organisations, expansion in export opportunities for EU dairy produce and moving up the value chain in terms of innovation and improvement of quality of our dairy products.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the implementation of the 'milk package' and the outlook for the dairy sector. In particular, in order to defend the interests of our milk producers, I supported the adoption of paragraph 9, which condemns the Council's immobility on the implementation of aid to producers who voluntarily reduce their production in times of crisis. On the other hand, I voted in favour of the paragraphs of the text aimed at better structuring the dairy sector and introducing income stabilization instruments.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Nicholson report on the future of the European dairy sector and the review of the implementation of the 'milk package'. The latter, in force since October 2012, has provided operators with tools to deal with the challenges faced by the dairy sector. It has strengthened contractual relationships and increased bargaining power through producer and inter-professional organizations. However, I would like to point out that supply management measures, which contribute to the stability of the dairy market, must be supported, as well as all measures to punish over-producing farmers in times of crisis.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We declare our support for this important draft resolution, as producers in the sector are particularly vulnerable to changes in income due to high capital costs, volatile dairy prices and fluctuating energy costs and inputs. In addition, we want to emphasise that dairy farmers often occupy a weak position in the global food supply chain and are particularly exposed to unfair trade practices.  The ageing of milk producers is also a cause for concern to us. Therefore, it is essential for the future growth and sustainability of the sector to encourage and support generational renewal, using both new and existing instruments. There is also no doubt that the negative effect on producers in this sector has been affected by the embargo imposed by Russia. Finally, it was important, in deciding to support the resolution, to note that in many disadvantaged areas and ultra-peripheral regions, dairy production remains the only source of income and employment for farms.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As the level of implementation of the measures provided for in the milk package has proved unsatisfactory, the report urges the parties involved in the milk supply chain to make use of the measures provided for in the milk package, and also makes recommendations on the new instruments that should be evaluated by the Commission and industry. Finally, the report emphasises the strategic role to be played by the Milk Market Observatory, set up in April 2014, in the years to come. In the light of the above, I have decided to support the report favourably.

name: n/a
text: in writing. – I have voted for this report on the prospects for the EU dairy sector – review of the implementation of the dairy package, to tackle the current crisis in the dairy sector.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ D’oibrigh mo chomhghleacaí, Matt Carthy, a bhí mar scáthrapóirtéir ar an gcomhad seo, go dian ionas go mbeadh leasanna feirmeoirí beaga tugtha san áireamh i bhforálacha na tuarascála. Ar deireadh, áfach, ní raibh aon rogha fágtha againn ach vótáil i gcoinne na tuarascála toisc nach raibh faic ann a chinnteodh go rachadh an earnáil déiríochta i bhfeabhas sna blianta atá romhainn; nó go mbeidh cosaint ag feirmeacha teaghlaigh beaga i rith tréimhsí neamhsheasmhacha. Tá sé de cheart ag feirmeoirí praghas cóir a fháil ar a gcuid torthaí agus níl sé inbhuanaithe a thuilleadh go mbeadh bainne, an-chuid den am, mar earra talmhaíochta neamhbhrabúsach. Tá bealaí ann ina bhféadfadh an Coimisiún a bheith níos tacúla; mar shampla, is uirlis láidir é praghas idirghabhála chun an margadh a chomhardú, ach caithfidh an praghas idirghabhála sin an costas táirgeachta a aithint. Tá sé soiléir anois go bhfuil an-chuid feirmeoirí déirí ag streachailt le luaineacht na bpraghsanna agus mura gcuirtear san áireamh sna tuarascálacha gníomhaíocht chun feirmeoirí beaga a chosaint, ní bheidh Sinn Féin sásta tacú leo. Leanfaimid ar aghaidh ag cur brú ar an gCoimisiún gníomhú ar bhealach suntasach ionas gur féidir leis an earnáil déiríochta a acmhainneacht iomlán a bhaint amach.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ While I voted in favour of this report, as I believe it is an important document in the reform of our agricultural sector, I could not support paragraph 22 in the same way my Group chose to. Milk quotas are a highly sensitive issue and we need to take more into account the needs of producers also in Eastern and Central Europe when it comes to the end of the milk quotas.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because it contains many positive aspects. Among other things, it calls for the resumption of the debate on aid to producers who voluntarily reduce production and wants to keep the door open for measures such as milk quotas, which I opposed some time ago.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The report provides an overview of the state of the EU dairy sector and points to a range of concerns, including how to respond more efficiently and quickly in crisis situations, how to create sustainable jobs and stimulate economic growth in all rural areas of the EU.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. The report for assessing the 'Dairy Package' is of particular importance to the sector as it coincides with the end of milk quotas. The package includes a number of measures to better regulate the sector, promoting an improvement in the bargaining power of producers and strengthening their negotiating position.  The global dairy market is becoming increasingly volatile and reached the highest prices ever recorded in January 2014, after which there were considerable price falls over the rest of 2014. To ensure a fair and balanced free market, certain flaws and imperfections must be corrected, which is more manifested than ever in the case we are dealing with. It is true that the different degree of development and size of livestock holdings depending on the different countries gives a different reading of the situation, but in a large majority of countries imbalance problems persist and need to be addressed. Taking into account the specific problems of this sector, a number of measures and mechanisms are warranted to ensure the transparency and development of a true free market, and the report contributes to this.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering, in the light of the above, that for a large number of dairy farms located in less-favoured, island, remote and mountainous areas or in the outermost regions, the costs of producing, harvesting and placing on the market of milk and milk products outside their production area are much higher than in other areas and that these farms cannot make equal use of the growth opportunities offered by the abolition of quotas due to natural constraints of these regions; For these reasons, these producers could be threatened by a greater concentration of production in areas with a better economic position within the Union, so I am in favour of this review.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European dairy sector is the most sensitive sector of agriculture and has in particular encountered major challenges and difficulties following this year's end of the quota regime.  The crisis is affecting the dairy sector in a negative way. One problem for the dairy industry is that production costs exceed the prices of agricultural products alone, negatively affecting producers whose numbers are decreasing. Existing measures to help the dairy sector are not a good enough tool as they do not address problems such as instability and the crisis in the milk sector, so it is necessary to draw attention to possible fixed milk prices that should target production costs.  Supply chain imbalances have a negative impact on SMEs who are often vulnerable as a result of rising costs and falling prices, which is why there is a need to introduce a contingency programme to prevent the power of large food corporations over dairy producers.  The dairy sector needs help to cope with the crisis that has occurred, in particular in rural areas dependent on this activity.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the implementation of the "milk package" is part of the end of milk quotas, effective since 31 March 2015. This decision has raised concerns, even indignation, among those involved in the milk sector. Our operators are already heavily affected by the crisis and market deregulation and now face a substantial loss of income to the largest producers. Many are now forced to sell at a loss. The embargo against Russia has also significantly affected the exports of French operators.  This text does not call into question the deregulation policies carried out by the Union for years and confirms the dismantling of the Community preference, even if it tries pusily to protect farmers a little more, such as the establishment of aid in danger zones and the strengthening of the powers of producer organisations in negotiations. I therefore abstained in the vote on this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Republic of Croatia is significantly behind the Members of the European Union in terms of development of agricultural production and milk production and in 2014 produced 522.7 million kilograms of fresh raw milk. The circumstances that have disadvantaged the Croatian dairy farm are manifold and largely relate to the consequences in production caused during and after the Homeland War, unfavorable results of the process of reconstruction and privatization, underdevelopment of the agrarian structure, small production capacities and a large number of small economies. Croatia from its own production meets about 80% of the annual need for milk and dairy products. The share of imports of finished dairy products is increasing enormously and this trend is expected to be continued, which will certainly contribute to the abolition of milk quotas earlier this year.  I therefore support this report, in particular its part which points out that dairy producers, in particular small producers, are particularly vulnerable to imbalances in the supply chain, in particular due to changes in demand, rising production costs and falling prices of agricultural products sold directly from farms, but also due to economic priorities in individual Member States. It is necessary to find a mechanism that effectively protects farmers from exploitation of industry and distributors, which is why I join calls on the Commission to present its proposal on combating UTPs as soon as possible and to consider the possibility of a sectoral approach to competition law and UTPs.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Milk is produced in every EU country and its production is constantly growing. As the world's leading exporter of various dairy products, the EU plays a major role in the global dairy market. Within the Union, dairy production is an essential agricultural sector of significant economic, social and territorial importance. For more than 30 years, milk supply in the EU has been managed by a quota system that expired at the end of March 2015. While long-term market prospects are broadly positive, the challenges facing the EU in the coming years are numerous. Current tensions regarding the price of milk and the 2009 milk crisis show that market liberalisation and dependence on foreign markets are a factor in volatility and volatile prices.  The report expressed concerns stemming from the disruption of the milk quota system and any further market volatility. A series of tools should be created that will be further developed and improved to help milk producers, including livestock farmers in Croatia. I support this proposal because I think it will be very helpful in these difficult times.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 31 March 2015, after 30 years, the EU ended the milk quota regime, which poses a major challenge for the entire dairy sector, which is characterised by its price volatility, high demand for milk on the market, but also the complicated position of primary producers. The European Parliament has recommended a number of measures to better manage the end of quotas, as well as for the future growth of the competitiveness of the dairy sector, the finding of new export markets, as well as better technologies for sustainable production. In this respect, I would like to emphasise the role of the 2012 milk package, which strengthens contractual relations and the bargaining power of producers. Its implementation has shown a number of practical positive effects, but only in states that have sufficiently supported implementation. Many Member States still have large reserves in this. It is important for the Commission to take more accommodating and realistic measures with regard to the intervention price (not updated since 2008!), which must take greater account of production costs. Furthermore, the potential of the Milk Market Monitoring Centre established in April 2014 needs to be increased. The Centre shall process market status data and shall be able to send timely warnings to the Commission services enabling it to act more quickly in the early stages of a possible crisis in the sector. I believe that the importance of accurate and timely information will increase strongly in the period following the abolition of quotas.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The end of milk production quotas is a challenge for the dairy sector as a whole. Milk producers are particularly vulnerable to changes in income due to high commodity prices and fluctuating costs of inputs and energy resources needed for production. In addition, milk producers often occupy a weak position in the global food supply chain and are particularly exposed to unfair trade practices. I believe it is necessary to create the conditions that will ensure the balanced development of milk production throughout the EU, while safeguarding the needs of producers. For this reason and in order to be able to continue the work of monitoring the prospects of the dairy sector, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour of the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In 2003, Member States reassessed the CAP and decided to end the quota system from 31 March 2015. After a 30-year quota period, this decision will have several impacts on the dairy sector. The report adopted by Parliament lists the various challenges and prospects for the dairy sector within the Union and outlines the assessment of the implementation of the 'milk package'.  I voted in favour of this report. However, I regret that some points have not been integrated, notably regarding the inclusion of supply management measures. These measures should be supported as they contribute to the stability of the dairy market.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report made a first effort to assess the effects of the 'milk package' on the dairy sector adopted under the codecision process in 2012 with the aim of strengthening the position of milk and dairy producers in the supply chain and preparing the sector for a sustainable and more market-oriented future. The end of quotas for milk production, after 30 years of implementation, presents challenges with regard to market volatility or a crisis situation, and that 'the milk package' considers in order to prepare the sector for a sustainable future. In terms of the operation of the 'milk package', the report indicates that it has improved relations throughout the supply chain, noting that it is too early to see significant effects. Still, the rapporteur insists that greater transparency and the continued and thorough analysis of milk production data will lead to the strengthening of contractual relations, enhancing the sustainability of a structurally volatile sector. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this vote, the European Parliament has clearly called on the European Commission to come up with a new plan to deal with the negative consequences for milk producers following the elimination of quotas in this sector. I welcome the outcome of this vote, because it demonstrates the need to act quickly and with concrete measures to support milk producers throughout the European Union, in particular small producers who, because of the general crisis, the elimination of quotas and the restriction of trade with Russia, are on the verge of survival between the costs of production and the profit obtained.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Nicholson report, which is the European Parliament's response to the Commission's response to the changing situation in the dairy market and the implementation of the 'milk package'. This is in the context of the end of the milk quota system since 31 March 2015. Of course, the new European approach is made up of uncertainty and no one can predict whether its flagship measure, which is the opportunity for farmers to collectively negotiate supply contracts with dairies, will be sufficient to guarantee a viable future for producers.  In Belgium, for example, this agreement is not compulsory and consists of a code of good practice signed by 98% of processors and the three main agricultural organisations. Among the sensible proposals is the ease of farmers joining producer organizations (OPs) that can collectively negotiate contract terms, including the price of raw milk. Increased bargaining power for dairy farmers is part of a rather favourable environment, with the increase in the average price of milk in the European Union to more than 40 ct/kg, and the increase in consumer demand for dairy products.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 My colleague Ricardo Serrão Santos, Azorean MEP for S&D, was the shadow rapporteur for this report of the Parliamentary Committee on Agriculture. It shows that a significant proportion of dairy farms in the EU are located in disadvantaged, outermost, island or mountainous regions, where the costs of production, collection and marketing on the milk and milk products market are usually much higher than in other areas better located within the EU. The removal of quotas is expected to have a very negative impact in these outermost regions, such as the Autonomous Region of the Azores, where milk production is the main economic activity, representing about 46 % of the regional economy. It is therefore necessary for the European Commission to take additional market action to address the crisis facing this sector by carrying out ambitious policies to support these regions, increasing the bargaining power and influence of producers, by striving to open new markets in third countries and to remove barriers to trade, always balancing exports with a stable internal market.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution which points to the particularly serious time for dairy farms to go through, with high price volatility and recurrent crises hampering investment in farms, as well as the serious problems of the functioning of the single milk market. The motion for a Resolution also expresses disappointment at the measures implemented following the adoption of the 'Dairy Package', with a low level of application of compulsory contracts and the fact that in some Member States they contain unfair terms which neutralise the initial objective of stability of deliveries, as is happening in Spain and, in the first place, in Galicia. It is therefore necessary to strengthen the role of producer organisations in order to preserve bargaining power and influence in the supply chain and also to strengthen the Milk Market Observatory.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The EU must ensure a better balance in the supply chain, introduce better tools against market disruptions and help farmers find new markets for their products: this is what the European Parliament called for yesterday in adopting a report on the milk and dairy sector.  Parliament therefore calls on the Commission to intervene, by introducing additional targeted market measures, in the face of the current crisis in national dairy markets, as a result of the downward pressure on prices resulting from the lack of adequate measures to prevent the crisis, a decline in global demand, global price volatility and the Russian embargo.  Parliament regrets that the Council rejected its request to set up, in the event of a serious crisis, assistance to producers voluntarily reducing their production. Parliament also calls on the Commission to implement more effective and realistic safety nets and to ensure that intervention prices (which are far too low...) more reflect real production costs and real market prices, and are better adapted to market changes.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are several challenges facing the dairy sector after the end of milk quotas on 31 March this year. Price volatility, the impact of the Russian embargo and the need to pay special attention to the outermost regions, in particular the Azores, where milk production is the main economic activity, representing approximately 46% of the total value of the regional economy. To that extent, I agree with the rapporteur's recommendations, in particular as regards the existence of regulatory instruments, the adjustment of intervention prices, making them higher, the definition of indicators on production costs, the development of instruments to protect against milk price decreases, the analysis of new income stabilisation instruments and the need to create a limitation on unfair commercial practices. I therefore agree with the adoption of this report, which also proposes the allocation of additional resources to the POSEI programme, creating a transitional mechanism between the end of quotas and market liberalisation. I also highlight the importance of bilateral trade negotiations, the opening up to new markets in third countries and the removal of barriers to trade and export.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. With the end of milk quotas, the European Union needs to think about a new European dairy policy to avoid any crisis, as the dairy sector has seen, particularly in 2008. The end of milk quotas represents a real economic challenge for the dairy sector and it is essential to help farmers and ensure that they will be well able to meet market demands. The Commission must the thereby consider solutions such as strengthening contracting between producers and distributors or developing crisis management tools. The Milk Market Observatory must also play a leading role in crisis prevention and, in the long term, it is imperative to think about mechanisms to avoid overproduction.  It is in this sense that I have supported this report which allows Parliament to express its concerns and make proposals on European dairy policy.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report presented by Mr De Clercq. Nicholson on the prospects for the EU dairy sector. The end of the milk quota policy thirty years after its entry into force has opened up new and important challenges for the dairy sector. An assessment of the implementation of the milk package paints a fairly disappointing picture, which is why I agree with urging stakeholders in the dairy sector to take advantage of the measures provided for in this package.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, appreciating some useful calls to the Commission to implement a series of strategies (review of the Centre's tasks, updating and improvement of the safety net) which I consider useful for the productive sector.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because the overall approach to this report does not meet the real needs of dairy farmers or society. There are important parts in its wording that include a strong neoliberal approach, in proposing, for example, that financial risk mechanisms be used to take advantage of price volatility in the sector, rather than establishing other instruments aimed at reducing such volatility. In addition, the rapporteur's interest in opening up to foreign markets is clear when our perspective is to prioritize and protect traditional production, as well as to strengthen local markets in order to move towards food sovereignty.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the Nicholson Report. We need market instruments that guarantee the stability of dairy prices, and I believe that eliminating quotas from this sector was a decision taken prematurely.  In recent months, falling demand from foreign markets, global price volatility and especially the Russian embargo have increased the pressure on the milk sector. Although the European Commission has taken measures to limit the effect of this embargo, the sector has suffered significant losses, with farmers' income severely affected. The elimination of quotas requires the creation of functional market intervention instruments, and I hope that in the coming period the Commission will come up with some concrete proposals to avoid crises in this sector, and so quite sensitively.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I believe that I should start by recognising that the situation in the sector has to do with the decisions that have been taken on the abandonment of production control instruments.  However, it states that the abandonment of quotas must not be called into question in order to give stability to the sector. Nor do you recognize that they were wrong when they said we had great opportunities in the world market (they talked about China, Russia...) even if the reality is clearly different. It continues to insist on this path and proposes totally speculative measures such as 'futures markets', which will bring more price volatility and make the sector much more vulnerable.  It also insists on contracts but without considering a clear policy of setting remunerative prices. For a fair and sustainable European dairy sector, this document should propose a clear public dairy policy to provide stability and prevent crises. However, it delves into the decisions that brought us this crisis and merely speaks of crisis management. In short, it deepens the liberalization and abandonment of milk producers in the hands of the interests of companies and the agri-export business.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to exist, dairy farmers and in particular small farms face many challenges on a daily basis, such as high capital costs, perishable production, high price volatility, fluctuating energy costs and inputs. We have left behind the era of milk quotas which ended on 1 April. It is now important for the Eu ropean Union to accompany dairy farmers in this new scenario, giving them greater flexibility to respond to growing demand in the world market while ensuring that the sector remains competitive and profitable. I have chosen to vote in favour of this own-initiative report because I believe that it correctly highlights not only the challenges, but also the opportunities for European producers. Thanks to the new instruments that will be made available by the European Fund for Strategic Investments, we must help the sector to reach its maximum potential and thereby promote job creation and economic growth in rural areas of the EU.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. I welcome the content of this report, which identified the needs of the milk sector, in particular in the Azores, and calls on the European Commission to act swiftly to promote the stabilisation of the internal market. The combined effect of the end of quotas, the Russian embargo and the prolonged and continuous price break limits future options for dairy farmers and incentives for generational renewal and investment in farms. This issue acquires greater importance in areas with natural constraints and economic disadvantages, such as the Azores, where dairy activity as an economic activity is hardly replaceable. This specificity and relevance of territorial cohesion, which is one of the objectives of the CAP, has been recognised, and the EP calls on the European Commission to take consequent measures. Among others are the strengthening of POSEI, measures to support the impact of the end of quotas in the Azores, supply management, transparency of the value chain, ensuring that large distribution practices do not prejudice the payment of a fair price to the producer, strengthening the milk observatory, mechanisms that protect against sudden losses of income in the milk sector and new crisis management instruments.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it demonstrates solidarity with dairy farmers affected by the slump in milk prices.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Small milk producers, including Slovak ones, are currently facing pressures from several sides. In Slovakia, this is mainly due to the abolition of quotas and the embargo by Russia. For this reason, I voted in favour of adopting a resolution on the prospects for the EU milk sector. The resolution points out that the surplus of dairy products from some Member States creates a major imbalance on the domestic markets, which results in a sharp fall in prices and the fact that local small producers are losing competitiveness. The resolution therefore calls on the Commission to take urgent measures that will create new funding opportunities for Member States using the European Investment Bank, the Guarantee Fund and the Revolving Fund.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because I believe that, in the context of the expiry of milk quotas on 31 March 2015 and in view of the current situation in the area of milk and milk products production, it is essential to reconsider the implementation of the milk package, which should apply by 30 June 2020. In this context, I consider it extremely important for the Commission to prepare new possibilities for supporting the dairy industry, which is becoming increasingly unstable worldwide. I regret to say that the milk sector is also in crisis in Slovakia, where I come from, and I believe that this crisis will not be the same as in 2008-2009, when there was a significant drop in purchase prices in Slovakia and dozens of businesses ended up with dairy primary production. Although only a very short period of time has passed since the abolition of quotas, as in Europe and Slovakia, the only regulatory instrument on the market has become the price that caused market imbalances. I expect the Commission, in cooperation with the Member States and those involved in the dairy industry, to develop effective and adequate instruments to ensure against sudden and significant falls in milk prices.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the report on the future of the EU dairy sector. I believe that the "milk package" is important given the volatile global milk market. The aim of this package is to achieve a sustainable and competitive milk market and to help small and family businesses that are highly vulnerable to market volatility. Also, this package gives dairy producers more bargaining power.  I am also of the opinion that the Commission can do more to implement the 'milk package' in peripheral regions of the European Union in order to ensure further production on these premises, as dairy production is the only form of cash income in a number of regions.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report on prospects for the EU dairy sector. While it does demonstrate how farmers are affected by the slump in milk prices and includes useful policy suggestions aiming at reducing market imbalances in the food supply chains, the final report voted on in plenary included an amendment that would pose the risk of the reintroduction of milk quotas.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the report on the procedures and ways of hearing commissioners-designate, lessons learned from the 2014 procedure. The completion of the milk production quota after thirty years poses challenges for the dairy sector. Dairy producers are particularly vulnerable to variations in income, due to high capital costs, volatile prices of dairy goods and variable input and energy costs.  Furthermore, milk producers often take a weak position in the overall food supply chain and are particularly exposed to unfair trading practices. In many vulnerable areas, e.g. mountains, the outermost island milking areas remain the only generator of farm income and employment, it is therefore necessary to keep it to prevent it from leaving the country.  Existing safety nets of measures such as public interventions and private storage support are not suitable to address the crisis in the milk sector. The members of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, together with the rapporteur, tabled 482 amendments and 35 compromise amendments were negotiated between political groups. The amendments to the compromise cover key issues such as a sustainable and competitive sector across the EU and fair milk allowance.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the prospects for the EU milk sector – review of the implementation of the milk package. The expiry of milk quotas at the end of March 2015 and the Russian embargo on dairy products since August 2014, which has had a negative impact on the EU internal market, have led to a significant fall in prices, resulting in very high uncertainty. All this has brought farmers making a living producing milk into great difficulties. I therefore support the call in the report for the Commission to discuss the crisis currently facing the dairy sector and to take measures to prevent future crises.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported today's report on the outlook for the EU dairy sector – a review of the implementation of the milk and milk products package, as it can contribute to improving the difficult situation of milk producers, who may be affected by large fluctuations in milk prices or high energy costs, for example. It is also important to address this issue at European level and thus effectively contribute to the interests of Czech farmers. The adoption of the report was recommended by the Ministry of Agriculture of the Czech Republic.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Union, by subsidizing the withdrawal of agricultural products, chooses to continue the policy that destroyed Greek production while, at the same time, with its foreign policy, causes enormous damage that it is not willing to repair.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report on the situation in the dairy sector in line with the direction of the European People's Party. My fellow Northern Ireland MEP James Nicholson has put a producer-focused report on the table. I agree with him that the milk package's policy based on producer organisations and the strengthening of producers' bargaining power in negotiating are the paths on which we must move forward. It is Hungary that both of my fellow Members Norbert Erdős's proposals to increase the effectiveness of crisis management have been included in the report. The European Commission should be called on to adjust intervention prices to the real market price and production costs. Furthermore, in the event of a major crisis, the application of export refunds should be activated on a temporary basis. These proposals shed light on the fundamental shortcomings of EU crisis management and concern the market functioning of all product pathways.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal on dairy products, as more than 30 years of regulation in the sector have expired and the report contains useful elements for the development of the new regulation. The report also deals with the abolition of the quota system, which has been the subject of concern in several Member States. I believe that, in order to reduce the possible negative impact, a binding contract between producers and processors, an increase in the role of the Milk Market Observatory, the fight against unfair commercial practices, improvements in information and promotion programmes and a system of new instruments to protect producers' profit margins can help. I am sure that the increase in demand globally will give all Member States the opportunity to make use of it. However, this requires active participation by governments not in propaganda, but in EU negotiations, and concrete steps in my country and in Hungary! I therefore urge the preparation of the actors in the Hungarian sector, social coordination and the involvement of civil-professional organisations to develop a real and crystal clear strategy. I think it is important to note that rural development resources, which have already been belatedly, need to be launched immediately for the sake of the sector and market acquisition should also be encouraged.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dairy products are an important chapter of the European Union's common agricultural policy. They are an essential element in the healthy nutrition of European citizens, as demonstrated by studies carried out by specialists in the field, and must therefore be actively supported by the Union's profile programmes. In this respect, it is worth remembering the Milk Package, adopted in October 2012 and applicable until 2020. This support is intended to contribute to the positive development of the Less Developed Mountain Rural Regions of the Union and to maintaining an equally high level in the main producing regions, which are vulnerable to global milk price oscillations.  At the same time, the embargo imposed by the Russian Federation against European dairy products has led to a crisis in this area. Measures should therefore be taken to support producers in the field, including through the Income Stabilisation Instrument, in view of the particular potential of these products at international level.  This report is an important step towards improving the situation of dairy farmers within the EU and, for this reason, must be supported by the European Parliament as a major institutional forum for European citizens.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament today took stock of the 'milk package', although milk quotas have not been in place since 31 March. Socialist and radical MEPs have always opposed the end of milk quotas. For us, it was the system of public supply regulation allowing both an effective control of the production essential to the maintenance of prices and incomes, and the maintenance of many family farms in all territories. Unfortunately, during the 2003 and 2008 CAP reforms, the right decided to liberalise the milk sector and put an end to milk quotas: since 31 March, nothing has prevented the geographical concentration of production in the territory. Medium-sized and isolated family farms are the most at risk.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Following the Russian ban on EU milk and the end of the milk quota, the European milk market needs to adapt. For this reason I supported the European Parliament resolution on the review of the implementation of the dairy package. The EU farmers entered the international market which brings the opportunity to become more competitive. I voted to ensure the resolution is in line with the agenda on better regulation: I opposed provisions on coming back to imposing quotas or fixed prices. On the contrary, I welcomed the implementation of incentives to create producer organisations: I think they are the appropriate tool to address imbalances in the supply chain. I also encourage the use of EU quality labels which can bring a real added value to European products in a highly competitive international market.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. Dairy quotas expired at the end of March 2015, ending public supply regulation, which limited the geographical concentration of production and price fluctuations in the market. The Nicholson report takes stock of the "milk package" put in place in 2009 to meet this deadline.  The report deplores the fact that the implementation of the 'milk package' has not been a priority for the Commission. The protection of the dairy sector from price volatility remains insufficient and does not guarantee farmers' incomes.
