Parliament has proposed an improvement of the Milk Market Observatory and the development of effective crisis management tools; it is a matter of anticipating market accidents in order to limit their influence on producers. Supply-regulating tools should be put in place. The report draws attention to the most vulnerable areas that will be particularly affected by the end of milk quotas. It calls for measures to support rural development.  This report raises the multiple challenges facing the dairy sector and calls on the Commission to react decisively. So I voted for him.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I commend the great efforts made by the rapporteur to analyse the impacts and successes of the measures presented through the "milk package" from. 2012 and the concrete proposals it has created to ensure a vital, sustainable and competitive dairy sector on the market following the abolition of milk quotas. The rapporteur has well detected the vulnerability of European milk producers, and their exposure to market arbitrariness, increasing input prices and building perceptions of milk as a leader in losses between retailers. As a result of the embargo given by Russia on dairy products, I particularly support the rapporteur's proposal to strengthen the role of the European Milk Market Observatory, whose role would be to supply the dairy sector with relevant information, market indicators and consumption trends.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The withdrawal of quotas on milk production certainly poses one of the challenges for the dairy sector. The EU's ability to tackle an extremely volatile market or crisis situation is questionable, so the proposal underlines the importance of building a viable, sustainable and competitive dairy sector across the EU (eliminating concentration in some regions) and proposes to create appropriate crisis instruments to respond to the high level of price volatility and other problems facing the sector. It is also essential to put an end to unfair trade practices in order to protect farmers who are already in a weak position, which is why I supported this proposal.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because the overall approach to this report does not meet the real needs of dairy farmers or society. There are important parts in its wording that include a strong neoliberal approach, in proposing, for example, that financial risk mechanisms be used to take advantage of price volatility in the sector, rather than establishing other instruments aimed at reducing such volatility. In addition, the rapporteur's interest in opening up to foreign markets is clear when our perspective is to prioritize and protect traditional production, as well as to strengthen local markets in order to move towards food sovereignty.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I think that the Commission made a mistake last year in abolishing quotas for milk products, and this is why I have voted against paragraph 22. I am also of the opinion that, when prices are too low due to a crisis, more intervention should be possible to sustain producers.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained. The end of milk quotas is bad news for the sector. This project contains good proposals, such as support for farms in disadvantaged areas, producer organisations and the announced desire to avoid the consequences of too much deregulation. There is therefore a desire to push the Commission to act, which it has not done so far.  That being said, there are other concerns. Suggesting relying on futures markets for risk management and taking advantage of price volatility to make the sector more competitive appears to be a threat to the sector. It is the model of free trade that pushes the concentration of farms to make them more productive and competitive. However, this is at the expense of other more fragile farms. So there is a form of contradiction in this catch-all relationship.  The Delegation of the National Front also does not want to take the risk of sacrificing our farms on the altar of productivity.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because the overall approach to this report does not meet the real needs of dairy farmers or society. There are important parts in its wording that include a strong neoliberal approach, in proposing, for example, that financial risk mechanisms be used to take advantage of price volatility in the sector, rather than establishing other instruments aimed at reducing such volatility. In addition, the rapporteur's interest in opening up to foreign markets is clear when our perspective is to prioritize and protect traditional production, as well as to strengthen local markets in order to move towards food sovereignty.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted against this report as it seeks to increase milk exports (which makes it necessary to import more feed), rather than seeking a balance between local production and consumption.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. " The dairy sector is very important for Lithuania. Workers in this area are under particular pressure as the price of dairy products is falling. It is particularly important for Lithuania to export dairy products.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this non-binding resolution, which aims to tackle new challenges that have recently arisen such as the end of milk quotas, the Russian embargo on EU foodstuffs and price volatility. The EU must do more to help its dairy sector and use the existing tools more effectively, in order to take full advantage of the many long-term opportunities. Export markets must be diversified in order to help EU producers deal with new contingencies like the ban on EU imports imposed by Russia. Overall, the EU must better balance the food supply chain, further improve milk market monitoring, introduce better tools for dealing with market disturbances and provide further incentives for dairy farmers.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. After analysing the Commission's report on the situation of the dairy market, Parliament decided to carry out its own-initiative report on the subject. This report recalls the importance of milk farming to the economy and rural management and endorses the validity of the 'Dairy Package' as an instrument for rebalancing the supply chain. As the report rightly points out, it is necessary for the Commission to use the available instruments to avoid the high price volatility that producers have suffered in recent years. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it encourages the expansion of the large dairy industry and large intensive farms, at the expense of the destruction of small and medium-sized holdings and a sustainable extensive mode of production. The report is also focused on an export-based economy and market expansion through the conquest of new markets, which I believe is not only unrealistic but can lead to serious problems for both EU milk farms, already mired in a very serious crisis due to the disappearance of milk quotas , as from third countries.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The milk quota system ended on 31 March. This report from the European Parliament takes stock of possible developments in this area. In line with previous reports, we are told that, since global demand "remains dynamic", production "could increase" and prices are "slightly higher", the sector is doing well. It's not true. The end of quotas puts many producers in a difficult situation, leaving them at the mercy of the dairy industries. Production will be concentrated in the hands of the largest producers and the smaller producers will not recover. To give these industries the power to impose their conditions is to destroy thousands of jobs and upset entire territories.  We have been warning for months about the abolition of quotas and nothing has been done to protect our producers. We must give ourselves the means to ensure fair remuneration and to ensure food sovereignty. That is not how we will do it. I vote against this blissful report winding the purported benefits of free and undistorted competition on this common good that is milk.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. As recognised, the "Milk Package" failed in its attempt to bring improvements in the position of milk producers on the market. Even with contracts integrated into organizations, milk producers are unable to negotiate an acceptable price for their product with industry.  On the other hand, and without any alternative mechanism for regulating supply, this package proved incapable of being able to respond to the increasing price instability and unpredictable character. We believe that supply management and pricing cannot be done so only in a mercantile logic. We therefore propose, from the European Milk Observatory in conjunction with the national authorities, the introduction of sustainability criteria that take into account the production costs and economic and financial viability of the holdings.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have voted in favour of this report, as it is partly capable of sustainably improving the current situation of dairy farmers in the EU. Unfortunately, despite some positive aspects, such as the development of safety instruments to counteract the fall in the price of milk, the core problem, the abolition of the milk quota, remains untouched.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of Parliament's resolution on the prospects for the EU dairy sector – review of the implementation of the milk package – for reasons of group discipline. This own-initiative report considers the impact and success of the 2012 milk package to date and identifies the areas where action is needed to ensure a viable, sustainable and competitive dairy sector in the post-quota market. The report calls on the Commission to address the EU-homegrown crisis in the industry, which has been created as a result of the Russian embargo, a jump in global demand and global price volatility. The report also highlights the specific challenges facing milk producers in disadvantaged, remote and mountainous regions and identifies measures that could help producers in these areas.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The current situation in the EU dairy sector is complex and, of course, solutions need to be found, but the right tools must be used to achieve the objectives set. I reject the intervention in this sector, especially in the form of milk quotas, which have been used at a different time than now. Milk quotas would now only act as a brake on the dairy sector's competitiveness and tie the hands of farmers who could otherwise increase production at a profit.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, it is essential to share knowledge, research, innovation and measures to improve the quality and labelling of products in this area. This will only increase the competitiveness of European products on the international market. It is important to seize the opportunity for the growth and development of this sector through european fund funding in order to facilitate success in this sector.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution assesses the impact to date of the measures included in the milk package, including with regard to the cancelled dairy quotas for small producers and the embargo imposed by Russia on imports of our dairy products. I voted in favour of the report because it contains a number of useful recommendations, the implementation of which can contribute to strengthening the dairy industry: to a fairer setting of prices for raw milk, to greater export of products to new foreign markets and to job creation.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 'Milk Package' failed in its attempt to bring improvements in the position of milk producers on the market. Even with contracts integrated into organizations, milk producers are unable to negotiate an acceptable price for their product with industry.  On the other hand, and without any alternative mechanism for regulating supply, this package is unable to respond to the increasing price instability of the market. Alternative supply regulation mechanisms are essential to address this problem and this report does not take over.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I have chosen to abstain on the report on the milk package because, in the face of some correct analyses, there are unfortunately no concrete answers to solve the problems that have been highlighted. Indeed, the end of the milk quota system from April of this year liberalises a market that has so far been strictly regulated, while exposing it to the risks of an open market that is no longer quota-free. Producers in the sector are particularly vulnerable to changes in income due to high capital costs, volatile dairy prices and fluctuating energy costs and inputs. In addition, dairy farmers often occupy a weak position in the global food supply chain and are particularly exposed to unfair commercial practices. However, the report merely suggests strengthening the competences of the Milk Observatory and strengthening contractual relations in order to ensure a fairer distribution of profit along the supply chain, without proposing a valid mechanism for monitoring prices and resolving possible market crises in order to protect producers.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, honourable colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. I believe that this report is very important because public-private partnerships can benefit least developed countries, because PPPs are an effective way of using European funds and achieving other sustainable development goals. For example, poverty reduction. But we have to be careful, because sometimes we try to help, not taking into account the real needs of these countries, but only out of our vision. Sometimes we Europeans are prepared to impose a specific project, because we believe that this is exactly what the people of this country need, and the country's elite may not object, because they are interested in getting the money, but the projects that really need will never be implemented. These aspects must certainly be taken into account when supporting public-private partnership projects, which I also carried out today in my vote. Thank you!

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, it is a pleasure to get to speak on the second day of the plenary. It has been a long battle to get to be heard, but thank you for that. Fighting against PFI contracts and the problems that they cause is one of the main things that occupy me back in England, and to see anything that promotes this contagion of PFIs is something that I will always vote against. A perfect example is that in the Dudley Group of Hospitals in my constituency – one of the poorest areas in the UK – the private service provider has put up car park charges massively for people who cannot afford to pay to go and see their relatives and for hard-pressed hospital staff who are being taxed to go to work. This money goes into the pockets of private monopolies. These PFI schemes are the worst of all worlds: they are private monopolies, they are unethical and they are plain wrong, and we should oppose them at every point.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it is a boost to the investment model promoted by international capital to ensure its investments at the expense of the public sector.  Public-private consortia aim to attract private investors by protecting their resources from any risks that may involve the loss of funds. The report is committed to this speculative investment model as a form of economic and trade intervention in third countries. This investment model is directly contrary to a real development project in third countries that improves the quality of life of the working classes; on the contrary, it is only intended to guarantee the great capitalists. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report on public-private partnerships (PPPs) and the impact of EU trade and investment policy. Unfortunately, this parliament has adopted a very skewed and deceptive text which does not recognise the serious risks and problems PPPs have for the delivery of public services to citizens. I am particularly disappointed that they include water supply as a target area for an increased participation of private companies. Water supply is a natural monopoly. Private companies prioritise profit for shareholders whilst public operators are more appropriate to provide safe, clean and accessible water to citizens. In my colleague-Lynn Boylan’s report-on the Right2Water she has underlined the need for the human right to water to be enshrined in EU legislation so that no operator can put profit before provision of water services to citizens. Private involvement in the water sector has a record of failure across the world and should not be promoted by the EU.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. This report calls on the Commission to work towards ensuring that European companies have fair access to public procurement markets in third countries. The report emphasises in particular the involvement of European SMEs, which I welcome, as they are still the largest and most important employers in Europe.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report promotes public-private partnerships, which are presented as beneficial to the European economy. These public-private partnerships are proving so financially disastrous for public authorities that there are more examples where initial funding projects are abandoned, in order to limit the explosion of costs.  The issue of developing these partnerships in third countries is therefore worrying, especially for emerging countries that could quickly fall victim to the same plunderings that have been suffered by French public authorities. Moreover, the access of foreign companies to domestic markets under these partnerships is questionable. Companies from "protectionist" countries will be able to win easily accessible public contracts, without necessarily reciprocity. Once again, the Union tolerates this kind of distortion of competition without making anyone react. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe that public-private partnerships represent the way forward, given the mess that they have caused in the UK.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because I believe that SMEs are the engine of job creation and wealth creation in developing countries, and that they generate about 90% of jobs.  It is therefore essential to become more involved with SMEs and start-ups, both local and private, as they are essential for resource mobilization and job creation at national, or European, in public-private partnerships in order to mobilise long-term financing, stimulate innovation in technologies and business models, and define mechanisms for private sector accountability.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to encourage EU companies, especially SMEs, to participate in PPPs. Although public-private partnerships (PPPs) are a long-term tool for government policy at international, national and regional level, it does not have an internationally recognised definition and a comprehensive regulatory framework. I support the calls on the Commission to promote the definition of PPPs, which could be recognised at international level as a long-term link between public entities and private investors, in order to provide quality and accessible public services and infrastructure. European companies would benefit greatly from job creation, productivity, competitiveness and technology and innovation through increased participation in large international projects, in particular PPPs, as well as to benefit from economic growth across the EU and in host countries.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This report serves us as an ultraliberal catechism, believing that there can be no economic dynamism until there are more "interactions" between the public and private sectors, through joint ventures and other joint projects: the text insists on PPPs (public-private partnerships). In fact, it turns out that PPPs are primarily used for deregulation, for the liberalization of public sectors, such as health. That is why I voted against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The report first recalls the importance of public-private partnerships (PPPs) in economic development and job creation in the European Union. However, it highlights the difficulties that European companies often face when it comes to participating in a PPP in a non-EU country. Therefore, it urges the Commission to work, in the negotiations of trade and investment agreements with other countries, to remove the administrative, procedural and technical obstacles that prevent EU companies, and SMEs in particular, from participating in PPPs in third countries.  I have approved this text, which is part of a desire to develop EU businesses and therefore employment in a context of trade reciprocity with third countries.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy in third countries attempts to make us believe that public-private interactions, joint ventures or joint projects are inherently good for the economy.  While it is good in areas such as research to engage in more public-private partnerships, this should not encourage or encourage P3s whose negative effects we know are often higher (and even more so than if there were frequent public borrowing).  This report encourages the use of it, particularly in emerging countries, in order to cope with the lack of financial resources.  However, there is never any mention of other measures in European policies, such as tariffs. So I have decided your against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text we are voting on is acceptable and I believe that it defends the interests of our companies in third countries, which is why I supported it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which highlights the need for a strong and clear regulatory framework, which prevents any kind of conflict of interest in EU companies' access to public-private partnerships (PEs) abroad. As the report shows, it is necessary to design the risk transfer model very carefully, to ensure that the private partner will not make a profit without taking responsibility. In addition, an PPP should not be the first step towards privatisation of a service. It is essential to ensure that administrations retain the right to decide on the model of management of services of general interest, at any time, in accordance with the interest of citizens.  Finally, the EU must commit itself to supporting the financial and technical capacity of the administrations responsible for PPP in the partner countries that require it, to ensure good design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of projects, applying the principles of good governance, transparency, participation of civil society actors, and combating corruption and fraud.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which stresses the need to promote decent jobs, competitiveness and productivity in the European Union and in third countries through innovative policies and new measures to promote the activities of economic operators in order to re-promote sustainable growth. Public-private partnerships (PPPs) could lead to the growth of EU businesses, while at the same time benefiting our third partner countries, as such PPPs could provide infrastructure, deliver goods of common interest and provide services. The European Parliament's rapporteur considers that some of the positive experience gained in PPPs has been gained as a result of better implementation of projects, good quality indicator or value-to-price ratio, access to long-term financing to cover infrastructure construction costs, promotion of innovation and research, private sector involvement in the design and execution of projects, as well as funding, a more flexible and skilled governance environment, the benefits of providing resources for well-established enterprises and SMEs and strengthening the competitiveness of EU enterprises and their access to public procurement procedures in third countries.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report because it very clearly encourages the European Commission to take greater action in the area of ensuring equal treatment when competing for operations outside the borders of the European Union. The EU is very open and looks very hard at the fact that its calls are as open to all as possible, whereas, on the other hand, European companies are often in a less favourable position than 'domestic' providers, and through international agreements these things need to be improved and the procedural and technical barriers that stand for European companies in the way of obtaining contracts from public-private partnerships.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this Report on the External Impact of EU Policy on Trade and Investment outside the EU. The report calls for market access to EU companies abroad, where significant barriers in the purchasing market continue to be noticed. The report highlights the need to facilitate access to SMEs in tenders and makes recommendations in this direction, such as the establishment of a Consortium.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report on public-private partnerships (PPPs)and the impact of EU trade and investment policy. Unfortunately, this parliament has adopted a very skewed and deceptive text which does not recognise the serious risks and problems PPPs have for the delivery of public services to citizens. I am particularly disappointed that they include water supply as a target area for an increased participation of private companies. Water supply is a natural monopoly. Private companies prioritise profit for shareholders whilst public operators are more appropriate to provide safe, clean and accessible water to citizens. In my report on the Right2Water I have underlined the need for the human right to water to be enshrined in EU legislation so that no operator can put profit before provision of water services to citizens. Private involvement in the water sector has a record of failure across the world and should not be promoted by the EU.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that public-private partnerships are an innovative solution to help European businesses grow, and that is why I believe that the trade agreements concluded by the Union with third countries must contain precise provisions in this regard, which do not discriminate against our companies.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Creating decent jobs, competitiveness and productivity within the EU and in third countries through innovative policies and new tools to encourage the work of economic actors to boost economic growth, including through investments outside the single market, are being felt for at this time. In this context, public-private partnerships (PPPs) could be, among other options, a potential source of growth for EU businesses and, at the same time, could be useful for partner third countries, as these PPPs could provide infrastructure, goods and services of general interest. I voted in favour of the report on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy on public-private initiatives in non-EU countries, because increased participation of EU businesses in large international PPPs could create substantial benefits in terms of decent job creation, productivity, competitiveness , as well as the development of technological capabilities and innovation in the EU.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of a report which has already seen a very broad consensus among the groups in the Committee on International Trade and the vote in favour of the Lega Nord. This issue is very technical and relates to public-private partnerships conducted outside the European Union. The rapporteur (from the ECR Group) has managed to strike a certain balance between positions which look to the interests of our large companies in the rest of the world, with the demands of those on the extreme left who, on the other hand, proposed amendments which emphasised, on the contrary, the need to protect the populations of third countries. The vote in favour is therefore due to the presence in the text both of positive assessments of the activity of these partnerships and of social references concerning the commitment of the companies involved to respect the environment and workers' rights.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, because increased participation of European companies in large-scale international projects, in particular IN PPPs, would create substantial advantages in terms of job creation, productivity, competitiveness, technology and innovation, which would bring benefits and economic growth in the EU and in the host countries. We need to stimulate decent job creation, competitiveness and productivity within the EU and in third countries through innovative policies and new tools to encourage the work of economic actors to boost economic growth, including through investments outside the Single Market. PPPs could, among other options, be a potential source of growth for EU businesses and, at the same time, could be useful for partner third countries, as these PPPs could provide infrastructure, goods and services of general interest.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The European economy is still suffering from a major slowdown due to the crisis. It is necessary to stimulate job creation and restore real competitiveness and productivity within the Union in order to revive sustainable growth. Investment outside the single market could be a major source of growth for EU businesses.  This report aims to strengthen the instruments of our companies, especially SMEs, enabling them to compete in foreign markets. Increased participation by European companies in large-scale international projects, particularly in public-private partnerships, could bring substantial benefits in terms of productivity and competitiveness. I recall the importance of reciprocity and fair competition in our trade relations with third countries.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy on public-private initiatives in third countries. The report is concerned with public-private partnerships (PPPs), an important instrument for economic growth and job creation both within the European single market and outside, for which there is currently no internationally recognised definition and no global regulatory framework. The report therefore calls on the Commission to promote an internationally recognised definition of public-private partnership, as a long-term relationship between public promoter and private investors for the provision of quality and accessible public services and infrastructure. The reference to European SMEs operating abroad, to which the Commission must guarantee the possibility of competing on the same terms as foreign domestic companies, through clear regulation and easy access to information on tendering criteria, is also very important, and it must remove all discriminatory and unjustified trade barriers with regard to public procurement, services or investments.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe that public-private partnerships represent the way forward, given the mess that they have caused in the UK.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I am convinced that increased participation by EU companies in large-scale international public-private partnerships (PPPs) outside the single market could lead to substantial benefits in terms of the creation of decent jobs, productivity, competitiveness, technological capabilities and innovation development in the EU. It is a potential source of growth for EU companies and, at the same time, useful for our partner third countries, as these PPPs could provide infrastructures, goods and services of general interest. I agree that the Commission should also be encouraged to guarantee that EU trade agreements contain instruments for our companies, especially SMEs, to compete abroad on equal terms with foreign national companies and believe that PPP-related challenges can be overcome through principles of good governance, such as transparency and clarity of rules, the area of development aid. PPPs are an effective way to spend European funds while supporting EU priorities and coherence with other policies.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Jan Zahradil's report highlights the need to stimulate decent job creation, competitiveness, technology exchange and productivity within the Eu ropean Union and in third countries through innovative policies that foster interaction between the public and private sectors: the so-called public-private partnership. Today, however, European companies, particularly SMEs, are difficult to enter third-country markets. The text voted on today therefore calls for greater coordination between the public and private sectors through appropriate technical assistance that strengthens the legal and institutional framework in which public-private partnerships have developed, evaluating and monitoring the implementation of these projects in strategic sectors such as energy, water, digital, road and telecommunications infrastructures. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which is based more on beliefs than facts about development, in this case, especially for third countries. Indeed, it is affirmed that only interactions between the public and private sector in joint projects or joint ventures would inflate economic dynamism, the model in this area being in particular public-private partnerships. For the latter, the costs they entail for public investment are too often overlooked, even if they may be an alternative for infrastructure financing. Where the problem lies is that from this perspective our public procurement is open to companies from countries practising protectionism. A total asymmetry that this report calls for to be resolved, but without giving a real negotiating lead. While we can welcome the desire to ensure that our companies have access to third-party public procurement, it is inconceivable to try to introduce WTO-type dispute settlement mechanisms once again, to the detriment of national courts.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Noting that public-private partnerships are the combination of the two worlds – the provision of services and infrastructures of general interest through enhanced private sector participation and not through privatisation processes. We also stress that private investment and financing appear to be the driving force behind sustainable development which in developing countries is estimated for the coming years at around 5%. With this in view of this, we support the report positively.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy on public-private initiatives in countries outside the EU. The importance of public-private partnerships (PPPs) is linked to the fact that they are an instrument of economic growth, innovation, competitiveness and job creation both in the single market and externally and play a strategic role in the modernisation of infrastructure, in particular energy, water, road and digital infrastructure. The positive effects of partnerships are due to better project implementation, good cost-benefit, the possibility of long-term cost financing, the stimulation of innovation and research, and a more flexible and specialised management environment. Greater participation of European companies in large-scale international projects, in particular public-private partnerships, would bring substantial benefits in terms of job creation, productivity, competitiveness, technology and innovation, resulting in benefits and economic growth in the EU and host countries. This proposal therefore calls on the EU institutions, and in particular the European Commission, to take the necessary steps to promote the participation of EU companies, and in particular SMEs, in public-private partnership projects.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission's own-initiative report because I believe it clearly and comprehensively highlight the positive and negative aspects of public-private partnerships (PPPs). PPP means a long-term employment relationship, between the public authority and a private partner, to finalise a project that responds to a public interest. This type of cooperation brings benefits to both sides as it allows for greater efficiency and timing, better value for money, new job opportunities for EU citizens and new resources for private companies. Benefits that are increased by the ability to share risks. Considering, therefore, that the interaction between the public and private sectors is an innovative solution that benefits the economy as a whole and that these benefits will be distributed to citizens, consumers and private companies, I believe that it is constructive to support sustainable growth also through investments of this kind in third countries, as they could represent a first step towards new global economic growth.  Since there is, however, still confusion about its own internationally recognised definition of PPPs, I believe it is the Commission's duty to commit itself to better defining this type of practice.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the aftermath of europe's economic crisis, Public-Private Partnerships can be a stimulus to job creation, competitiveness and productivity in third countries.  Despite the negative value attributed to them, for example in Portugal, due to their poor implementation, in essence PPPs must create high added value for citizens and consumers, guarantee quality services and goods, providing competitive and economic advantages to public administrations. I support the Zahradil Report because I believe that both SMEs and large enterprises can provide knowledge, experience, good practices and specific private sector networks involving public authorities from third countries, helping to implement policies for sustainable development. The obstacles that European companies continue to face in third country markets must be tackled.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome Mr Zahradil's report, which focuses on the benefits of public-private partnerships: better project implementation, good price/quality ratio, various funding possibilities and a predisposition to encourage and invest in innovation and research. In addition, PPPs are an instrument of economic growth, innovation, competitiveness and job creation both in the single market and externally and play a strategic role in modernising infrastructure such as energy, digital, water and road. They also bring high added value to citizens and consumers by ensuring high-quality goods/services.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report calls on the Commission to guarantee that European small businesses are treated in an equal manner as foreign companies when trading in non-EU countries. PPPs are important as they are the solution to the growing lack of public investment. It is important to also understand that SMEs are the driving force of job and wealth creation in developing countries, and therefore there must be interaction between the public and private investors. The Commission must also work to help to open up the market access for European companies in the context of the PPP arrangements outside of the Union. It is also important that the different bodies within the Union help SMEs on how to be able to enter PPPs in countries outside the union. These partnerships will help the SMEs to grow and develop better. Therefore it is important to ensure their equal treatment when trading in non-EU states.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it is a boost to the investment model promoted by international capital to ensure its investments at the expense of the public sector.  Public-private consortia aim to attract private investors by protecting their resources from any risks that may involve the loss of funds. The report is committed to this speculative investment model as a form of economic and trade intervention in third countries. This investment model is directly contrary to a real development project in third countries that improves the quality of life of the working classes; on the contrary, it is only intended to guarantee the great capitalists. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report stresses the opportunities provided to EU companies by public-private partnerships in third countries and the effects on job creation, competitiveness and productivity. It calls for EU trade policy to work towards ensuring market access for EU companies abroad where they still face substantial barriers in procurement markets. The report emphasises the need to facilitate SME's access to these tenders and makes a number of recommendations in this regard, including the formation of consortia. I believe both in the importance of public –private partnerships and in opening as many avenues as possible to our entrepreneurs so I supported this report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation of developing countries is rather precarious, especially in the context of the financial crisis, and the public sector cannot provide adequate investment in areas such as infrastructure, water supply and energy. I therefore support the rapporteur's view that most of these investments could benefit from the involvement of the private sector, because public-private partnerships have the potential to facilitate the adoption of innovative solutions that mobilise long-term private financing and internal resources in order to achieve different development objectives, as they are increasingly promoted as a means of eliminating the infrastructure funding gap in developed countries , but also in developing countries.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that public-private partnerships are a good tool for promoting job creation and growth, increasing competitiveness and productivity on the one hand and ensuring the reliability of public infrastructure on the other. However, the validity and effectiveness of these instruments depend on the degree of transparency and the soundness of the legal framework that accompanies them.  In international trade relations, the development of public-private partnerships also provides a guarantee of better access to third-country markets for European companies, and smEs in particular: this is particularly important in certain sectors such as public procurement, where the high degree of closure that still exists in the international market must be overcome, which significantly penalises our companies and rebalances it on the basis of the principle of reciprocity. For this reason, I voted strongly in favour of the report on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy on public-private initiatives in countries outside the EU.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to examine the challenges posed by public-private partnerships for European SMEs within the framework of the EU's Common Trade Policy. The approach defended is to strengthen the competitiveness of European companies when participating in public procurement in third countries. Considering that there are a number of potential economic benefits and inherent risks that can be shared between the public and private sectors, I believe that European companies should be able to participate in large-scale international projects in the form of public-private partnerships and that the European institutions must take steps to promote this participation. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The internal market operates in accordance with the principle of free competition, not only for the benefit of European operators, but also for companies established in third countries. This policy of openness applies even to public order. On the other hand, some of the EU's trading partners continue to favour domestic operators, mainly when it comes to entering into public-private partnership contracts. We have called by the vote of this text for free trade agreements with third countries, negotiated by the Commission on behalf of the European Union, to include clauses for opening public procurement procedures to European companies.

name: n/a
text: in writing. – The EU is increasingly engaging with the private sector to promote growth and development in African countries. I support the need for better regulation on Public-Private Partnerships, clear impact assessments and evaluation mechanisms. Transparency and accountability are two very important concepts in this regard, and they need to be fully adhered to.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The text codifies some European trade rules. The European Commission will now be able to initiate, conduct and close international dispute resolution procedures once it hears a complaint from European companies. This new procedure will improve the coherence and effectiveness of European trade policy, the EU's exclusive competence. Member States will, of course, be informed.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report focuses on PPP-related challenges such as risks, transparency, accountability, corruption, management and cost-effectiveness while arguing that the increased participation of European companies in large scale PPP projects would lead to substantial benefits in terms of job creation, competitiveness leading to economic benefits across the EU and in developing countries delivering tangible development results.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Countries’ societies and economic structures, and the dynamism thereof, benefit from environments which allow interaction between the public and private sectors; public-private partnerships (PPPs) are a long-term tool used in government policies at international, national, regional and local level, there is no internationally recognised definition and comprehensive regulatory framework for them; we need to stimulate decent job creation, competitiveness and productivity inside the EU and in third countries; both SMEs and larger companies alike can provide unique private-sector know-how, experience and good practices, as well as networks involving public authorities in non-EU countries, effectively helping to deliver on sustainable development policies.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report, as PPP has been primarily used as a destabilising factor for public services and consequently channelling official development aid (mainly in developing countries) to private companies.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because I oppose public-private partnerships in principle.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report addresses EU investment in so-called Public-Private Partnerships (PPPs) in third countries. PPPs are one of the most visible and finished demonstrations of a certain vision of the State, captured and at the service of particular interests. We know well its disastrous result in Portugal and what they mean from the summing up of public resources and its transfer to large economic and financial groups. The report considers that some positive PPP experiences result "from better project implementation, good quality or value ratio in relation to cost, possibility of long-term financing of infrastructure construction costs, stimulating innovation and research", etc., etc., little novelty, the usual argument. This report attributes to PPPs a whole set of virtues that reality bereaves. PPPs have contributed to the dismantling of public services and their democratic character. They have been a determining factor for the worsening of regional asymmetries. This report aims to 'export' PPPs and force them through trade policies with third countries. Obviously, we voted against it.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Higher participation of European enterprises in major international projects, in particular public-private partnerships, could result in significant benefits, especially in the areas of job creation, productivity or competitiveness. These could ensure that economic growth is promoted throughout the EU, but also in host countries. I therefore support the participation of EU businesses, especially SMEs, in public-private partnership projects.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report emphasises public-private partnerships conducted outside the European Union. This issue is supported by us and I believe that the references in the social text concerning the commitment of the companies involved in respecting the environment and workers' rights are important.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 My vote is against the report, as PPP has been primarily used as a destabilising factor for public services and consequently for the channelling of official development aid (mainly in developing countries) to private companies.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In the building, management, maintenance or operation of infrastructures in the transport area (roads, rail, subways), public buildings and equipment (prisons, schools, hospitals), the environment (water and waste treatment or management), utilities, telecommunication or energy networks or development of new technologies or products, there are a number of potential benefits and risks inherent that can be shared between the private and the public sectors. Increased participation of European companies in large-scale international projects, most notably in PPPs, would lead to substantial benefits in terms of job creation, productivity, competitiveness and technology and innovation, leading to benefits and economic growth across the EU and in host countries. Therefore, I would like to focus attention on the possibilities offered by PPPs in non-EU companies, and urge the EU institutions to take the necessary steps to promote the participation of EU companies, especially SMEs, in PPP projects.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. As coordinator of my group for the ACP delegation and rapporteur on the role of family businesses in emerging countries and on development policy, I voted today in favour of the report on the external impact of the EU's trade and investment policy on public-private initiatives in third countries. I believe that we must take our mission as a 'Europe of values' seriously, especially when it comes to our global economic strength. Here we have the potential to change the world.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Zahradil report given it sets out a number of important recommendations on the use of Private-Public Partnerships, including many that were championed by my group. These crucially include the need for the legal framework for PPPs to be reinforced towards the establishment of a clear, predictable and legitimate institutional framework supported by competent and well-resourced authorities, the securing of adequate human resources to enable the administration to properly design PPPs and oversee their implementation; and the need to undertake efforts to raise the capacity of public administration in developing countries. Furthermore, it was key for my Group to underscore that transfer of risks should be well defined to ensure the balance between the risk for the private sector and the guarantees that need to be offered by the public sector, and to include reference to the implementation of the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights as well as principles of good governance, transparency, the consultation of stakeholders and civil society organisations, and the fight against corruption and fraud. Finally, it is vital to ensure that future PPPs within the post-2015 development agenda, pursue poverty reduction and other sustainable development goals, and are aligned with partner countries’ national development plans.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which in particular promotes public-private partnerships, which are presented as beneficial to the European economy. In fact, I myself saw the inanity of these public-private partnerships when I was regional councillor for Nord-Pas-de-Calais with, for example, the Grand Stade de Lille, whose construction was attributed to Eiffage. This project has heavily indebted the metropolis of Lille and will probably never be depreciated. Public-private partnerships are proving so financially disastrous for public authorities that the initial seine-Nord Canal funding project has been abandoned in order to limit the cost of the project! The issue of developing these partnerships in third countries is therefore worrying, especially for emerging countries that could quickly fall victim to the same plunderings as our own public authorities... In addition, the access of foreign companies to our own markets, as part of these partnerships, is also questionable. Companies from "protectionist" countries will be able to win our own public contracts, which are easily accessible, without necessarily reciprocity: no one will be surprised, of course, that such distortions of competition are tolerated by the Europeanists, who are not at a near contradiction.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it because I reject the public-private partnerships (PPP) strategy as a mechanism designed and used primarily as an instrument for market access, deregulation and liberalization of public services and government procurement in third countries, especially developing countries, and a means of diverting development funds to private enterprises. In addition, we consider that there is a link between PPP and the risk of debt unsustainability; APPPs are often a way to transfer the risk of private companies to taxpayers.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, alongside my European Socialist and Democrat colleagues, voted in favour of this report. This report highlights the potentially positive contribution public-private partnerships can make to infrastructure development, whilst reinforcing the need within these for strong regulatory frameworks, and methods for fighting corruption. And crucially the report acknowledges that PPPs are not, and should not ever be, a route to privatisation.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy on public and private initiatives in non-EU countries. I believe that some of the positive experience gained in PPPs has been gained from better project implementation, good quality indicator or value-to-price ratio, access to long-term financing to cover infrastructure construction costs, promotion of innovation and research, private sector involvement in the design and execution of projects. It is also due to funding, a more flexible and skilled governance environment, the benefits of providing resources for well-established enterprises and SMEs and strengthening the competitiveness of EU businesses and their access to public procurement procedures in third countries. I believe that the construction, management, maintenance or operation of infrastructure in the field of transport, in public sector buildings and installations, in the environment, in the provision of utilities, telecommunications or energy networks, or the development of new technologies or products can bring many benefits and risks that the private and public sectors could share. I argue that European companies would benefit greatly from job creation, productivity, competitiveness and technology and innovation by taking greater part in large international projects, as well as benefiting from economic growth across the EU. I would therefore like to focus on the opportunities offered by PPPs in non-EU companies, and the EP urges the EU institutions to take the necessary steps to encourage EU companies, especially SMEs, to participate in PPPs.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report but would also like to record my concerns regarding the use of Public Private Partnerships. In this context I am pleased to see the statement that EU trade policy should neither encourage nor discourage the sovereign decision on whether or not to use PPPs - but that once a decision has been made by a sovereign state that the EU has an obligation to ensure that SMEs and companies of all sizes have the best possible access to procurement markets in the partner countries. This policy must be in line with the principles of openness, participation and accountability. I also believe we need to ensure strong legislation in order to prevent land grabbing and that where possible we strengthen Corporate Social Responsibility and ensure the promotion of human rights and gender equality in all our actions.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ When my party came into power in Scotland we moved away from previous governments’ obsession with lining the pockets of the private sector. The Scottish Futures Trust now exists to make investments in Scotland’s infrastructure in a manner efficient to the tax payer. Unfortunately this report seems most concerned with maximising profit for shareholders and I accordingly voted against.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it because I reject the public-private partnerships (PPP) strategy as a mechanism designed and used primarily as an instrument for market access, deregulation and liberalization of public services and government procurement in third countries, especially developing countries, and a means of diverting development funds to private enterprises. In addition, we consider that there is a link between PPP and the risk of debt unsustainability; APPPs are often a way to transfer the risk of private companies to taxpayers.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which emphasizes the importance of public-private partnerships and urges the EU institutions to take the necessary measures to promote the participation of EU businesses, in particular SMEs, in PPP projects, which would bring considerable benefits in terms of job creation, productivity, competitiveness and technology and innovation that would translate into benefits and economic growth across the EU and host countries.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy on PPP initiatives in non-EU countries (2014/2233(INI)), as public-private partnerships both in the single market and abroad are an important driver of economic growth, innovation, competitiveness and job creation and play a strategic role in infrastructure modernisation; whereas countries' economic structures benefit from environments allowing interaction between public and private actors.  Furthermore, as public-private partnerships are achieved in various forms, legislation prescribes high procedural standards. The positive impact of public-private partnerships on improving project implementation, fostering innovation and research, a more professional management environment, achieving high added value for citizens and consumers has been demonstrated. Attention should be paid to ensuring the quality of services and/or goods and benefiting from the public sector, while avoiding additional burdens or losses in the public sector.  Greater participation of EU companies in large-scale international public-private partnerships can lead to significant benefits in terms of job creation, productivity, competitiveness, technological opportunities and innovation development in the EU. There are numerous achievements in the EU through the use of public-private partnerships in infrastructure development and leading fields of technology, research, e-learning and other high value added sectors.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Jan Zahradil's report on the external impact of eu trade and investment policy in third countries. The report encourages the EU to promote public-private partnerships involving European companies in countries outside the EU. The text recalls that these partnerships can have extremely positive benefits for European SMEs and businesses, but they must be reciprocal, as European markets are already very open, unlike many third countries. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy on public-private initiatives in third countries. By following the principles of good governance, the establishment of public-private partnerships in third countries would, on the one hand, create decent jobs and fight poverty in developing countries and, on the other hand, open up new employment and growth opportunities for European companies that still face obstacles to their development abroad.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Public-private partnerships, abbreviated as PPPs, are broadly understood cooperation between public and private sector actors with a view to exploiting common public service opportunities. The services are provided by a public partner, while the private partner is a private partner to do business and make a profit. PPP is therefore not a form of privatisation but a substitute for it. The combination of public services and private capital often results in reduced costs and increased efficiency, as well as the quality of the services provided.  Public-private partnerships are very important as they contribute to economic growth, innovation, competitiveness and job creation. They also affect the development and modernisation of infrastructure. This is a huge opportunity for small and medium-sized enterprises to take advantage of the opportunities offered to them by the public sector. I believe that such an innovative solution, which is PPPs, is beneficial for both sectors, for the Member States and for the EU as a whole, as it combines the most important advantages of both sectors, without the need for a privatisation process.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The report points to the opportunities, particularly in the context of the expansion of the Austrian export industry, but fails to mention that developing countries with weak institutions and unstable legal systems can be advantaged by multinationals. I am therefore abstaining from voting.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 7 July 2015, I voted against my colleague Zahradil's report on the external effects of EU trade and investment policy outside the EU. In a recent set of directives (No 2014/23, 2014/24, 2014/25), the Commission expressed its orientation towards supporting the private and public sectors in a deregulated environment without any barrier to competitiveness. In my opinion, this orientation is in fact a veiled attack on public services and public procurement in developing countries. This is, of course, in stark contrast to the development and protection of social and environmental rights. Our faction has tabled an alternative motion for a resolution rejecting public-private partnerships as a tool used for market access, deregulation and liberalisation of the public sector, public procurement in developing countries and redirection of development funds to private companies. I believe that the private sector can only contribute to job creation and the well-being of local people if there is a clearly defined regulatory framework based on respect for and development of social rights, environmental protection and cultural diversity, as well as strong and efficient public services. Since I am deeply concerned about the private sector's misuse of public funds from cooperation programmes and our alternative proposal has not passed, I had to vote against the resolution.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Undoubtedly sustainable development is closely linked to private investment and financing. In fact, the contribution of investment to developing countries can help to support local economies and combat unemployment. But it is still "unclear" how services of general interest could be privately managed when companies aim to maximise profit in the short term rather than fair investments.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which stresses the need to stimulate the creation of decent jobs, competitiveness and productivity within the EU and in third countries. All this, through innovative policies and new tools aimed at promoting the dynamism of economic actors to relaunch sustainable growth, including through investments outside the single market. The report also believes that public-private partnerships (PPPs) could be a potential source of growth for EU businesses and, at the same time, be useful for our partner third countries, as they could provide infrastructure, goods and services of general interest.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy on public-private initiatives in third countries. The National Front is opposed to public-private partnerships, which are a tool for deregulation and liberalization, and which open up the health sector to the private sector. Mr Zahradil's report is entirely in line with the P3 logic. That is why I supported Amendment No 1, which rewrites this report in a fundamental way, but which unfortunately has not been accepted.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it is in favour of public-private partnerships (PPPs), to which I am opposed. P3s are very expensive for public investment.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it. While the costs of public-private partnerships are very high, they are described in this text as the solution to develop infrastructure in emerging countries. The report calls for well-defined policies to address the differences in openness between our public procurement and those of other countries. Unfortunately, there is no indication of what is actually possible in terms of negotiation. The creation of information and assistance platforms to support our companies so that they can have access to third-party public procurement is recommended, as well as the establishment of dispute resolution mechanisms with these third countries. Having said that, we refuse to support this text, because we believe that public-private partnerships are not a good solution and because the Commission is always trying to gain more and more power.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. There are numerous references to the need for a strong and clear regulatory framework to prevent any type of conflict of interest in the report, as well as the need to design the risk transfer model very carefully, to ensure that the private partner will not make a profit without taking responsibility. Reference is also made to the importance of ensuring that administrations retain the right to decide on the management model of services of general interest, at any time, in accordance with the interest of citizens. Finally, reference is made to the need to create 'decent work' and the need to incorporate the gender perspective into EU policies. Agreeing with these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it is a boost to the investment model promoted by international capital to ensure its investments at the expense of the public sector.  Public-private consortia aim to attract private investors by protecting their resources from any risks that may involve the loss of funds. The report is committed to this speculative investment model as a form of economic and trade intervention in third countries. This investment model is directly contrary to a real development project in third countries that improves the quality of life of the working classes; on the contrary, it is only intended to guarantee the great capitalists. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. Public-private partnerships (IPPs) allow interaction between the two sectors, which also means that they are part of the structure that enables economic growth, innovation and competitiveness. Since the 2007 crisis, which affected all countries, funding for projects of all kinds needs high capital, which would be much more supported if synergies between these two sectors are favourable. I voted in favour of the measures taken and the European Parliament's motion for a resolution, because in addition to the reasons mentioned above, the European Union has also taken into account the creation of rules to support fair competition within the single market, en making it possible to place a level playing field in international investor negotiations.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I see no reason why the EU should train other countries in the field of public-private partnerships. PPP projects are contentious and should not be promoted by the EU at the expense of a market-based solution. We see no reason for the EU to create documentation centres for large companies with all the taxpayers' money.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Private investment and financing have been key drivers of sustainable growth, projected to be around 5 per cent in developing countries in the coming years. Experience shows how properly structured public-private partnerships can bring many benefits including innovation, greater efficiency, resource exploitation and quality assurance and monitoring.  I supported the Report, which strongly supports the effective and comprehensive dissemination and application of the UN principles on business and human rights both inside and outside the EU, and stresses the need to take all policy and legislative measures to ensure the smooth application of the UN principles, including in the field of access to justice.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 It will be very difficult to make an effort and get the economy up and running without attracting private capital. Outside the EU these mechanisms must work, showing an example of fruitful collaboration to many other countries. I voted for it. And I also voted against the proposal for an Alternative Resolution, proposed by the Communists.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy on public-private initiatives in third countries, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 6/7/2015.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I obviously voted against this report. We cannot endorse public-private partnerships (PPPs), which are catastrophic in terms of costs for public investment, giving a white-seing to private multinationals, without allowing small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to have some clout. We therefore disagree with the Commission's view of these partnerships as good. We also condemn the asymmetry that allows companies in protectionist markets to access our open public procurement.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Votes in favour of the report on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy on public-private initiatives in countries outside the EU. Partnerships are important instruments used in government policies at international level as a means of economic growth and innovation.  The report therefore stresses the need to stimulate the creation of decent jobs, competitiveness and productivity within the EU and in third countries through new direct instruments to boost sustainable growth.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 At present, there is no global regulatory framework other than public-private cooperation initiatives.  That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of this report, which clearly defines the external repercussions of the EU's trade and investment policy on public-private initiatives in third countries.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. Public-private partnerships have proven highly effective in many sectors, so an extension of such initiatives could be very beneficial for Europe in order to achieve greater economic growth and more employment. That is why I support this report, in which from the European Parliament we are advocating for measures that promote greater participation of businesses, also SMEs, in these partnerships, and the establishment of instruments to enable EU businesses to participate in public-private partnerships outside the EU.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. The Zahradil report is tasked with considering the creation of a new legal framework for public-private partnerships (PPPs). It also seeks to promote an international definition of P3s, listing its benefits, limitations and prospects for improvement.  We must welcome the lucidity shown by the report in calling on the Commission to question the very high degree of openness it has imposed on European public procurement, even though many of our partners do not act with the same naivety (the discussions around the transatlantic treaty with the United States show this on a daily basis). The rapporteur also sets out interesting safeguards, including specifying that PPPs should not be a first step towards privatising the public services of the countries concerned.  On the other hand, the report goes too far in stating that public-private partnerships must be a privileged instrument to encourage the development of the countries of the South. It also tends to see P3s both as an effective substitute for lower public spending and as a good way to boost growth in Europe.  In the face of this flawed reasoning and the rapporteur's liberal tropism, I abstained on this report.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Unfortunately, I was unable to give my assent or reject this report. There are certain dangers of developing countries being over-exploited by multinational and experienced companies; at the same time, new expansion opportunities are also emerging for European companies.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report begins by stating as an established fact that "societies benefit from an environment conducive to interaction between the public and private sectors". The text aims to promote public-private partnerships, particularly in developing countries. The report thereby calls for the opening of markets in these countries to European companies that will be able to meet their important infrastructure needs. I am voting against this incondic text which plans to plunder developing countries.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are positive PPP experiences that result from the following elements: better project execution, good quality or value ratio in relation to cost, possibility of long-term financing of infrastructure construction costs, stimulation of innovation and research, participation of the private sector, both in the construction and operation of projects and also with regard to financing , more flexible and qualified management environment, resource benefits for renowned companies and SMEs and enhancing the competitiveness of EU companies for participation in public procurement in third countries. Increasing the participation of European companies in large-scale international projects, including PPPs, could bring substantial benefits in terms of job creation, productivity, competitiveness, technology and innovation, resulting in socio-economic benefits and economic growth across the EU and host countries. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report, which stresses the opportunities provided to EU companies by public-private partnerships in third countries and the effects on job creation, competitiveness and productivity. It calls for EU trade policy to work towards ensuring market access for EU companies abroad where they still face substantial barriers in procurement markets. The report emphasises the need to facilitate SMEs’ access to these tenders and makes a number of recommendations in this regard, including the formation of consortia.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal considers it important to make better use of the potential of PPP in non-EU countries, based on a number of positive experiences with PPP, and urges the EU institutions to help EU businesses, in particular SMEs, participate in PPP projects in third countries. I agree with both the statement and the proposal, so I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Public-Private Partnerships (PPPs) are important as vectors for economic growth, innovation, competitiveness and job creation, both in the European single market and internationally, taking a strategic role in modernising energy, water, road and digital infrastructure. I am in favour of this report, which calls on the European Commission to foster innovative solutions that mobilise private funding and long-term national resources for development objectives, as large-scale investments are needed in developing countries.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
