text: In writing. This report attempts to make us believe that public-private interactions, joint ventures or joint projects are inherently good for the economy. However, while this desire to break the walls between the public and private sectors is sometimes necessary and beneficial, especially in research, this observation should not be aimed at giving a blank-seing to public-private partnerships whose harmfulness is known: costs are pushed back on future generations and projects are often more expensive than pure public investment.  However, this report encourages its development in emerging countries to cope with the lack of budgetary resources! One of the resources that remains taboo for Europeanists could be tariffs, which have been largely abolished under the WTO's blows. Finally, the report believes that the opening asymmetry between the union's public procurement and those of other countries must be "resolved" without disclosing any means of achieving this.  I therefore voted against this text, which extols the merits of public-private partnerships.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which includes a number of key points including references to strong regulatory frameworks, SMEs, the principles of good governance and fighting corruption. The report also supports participation of stakeholders and civil society, gender mainstreaming, capacity-building in public administration of partner countries and references to the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights and CSR. Crucially, the report also acknowledges that PPPs are not, and should not be, a route to privatisation, and governments retain the right to take over full management of such services.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on eu trade and investment policy in third countries. This text indicates that a country's societies and economic structures benefit from an environment conducive to interaction between the public and private sectors as well as cooperation between public and private entities, among others, in the context of joint projects and joint ventures.  Public-private partnerships are an engine for economic growth, innovation, competitiveness and job creation, both inside and outside the single market. They also play a strategic role in modernizing infrastructure, including energy, road, digital and water infrastructure. The report also points out that EU companies are well positioned to win and manage these markets.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this draft resolution, which has become necessary as a result of the fact that the construction, management and maintenance of infrastructure in the transport, buildings and public structures, the environment, telecommunications or energy networks or in the field of the development of new technologies, entail certain potential advantages and risks that the private and public sectors can share. Indeed, we firmly believe that greater participation by European companies in large-scale international projects, in particular public-private partnerships, would bring substantial benefits in terms of job creation, productivity, competitiveness and innovation, with consequent economic benefits in the EU and host countries.  The opportunities offered by public-private partnerships, both for non-EU and European SMEs, can best be exploited through more timely compliance with the planned budgetary time and limits, good value for money, possibility of long-term financing of construction costs, stimuli for innovation and research, commitment of the private sector also in project management , a more flexible and specialised management environment, resource benefits for businesses, strengthening the competitiveness of EU companies to participate in public procurement in third countries.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is an inta Commission own-initiative report on public-private partnerships (PPPs), i.e. long-term contracts between the public authority and a private partner, under which the private sector finances a public service using its means and dividing the joint risks. The partnership is therefore a business relationship between two actors, one public and one private, in order to implement and finalise a project that responds to a public interest. Considering that PPPs are an instrument of economic growth, innovation, competitiveness and job creation, both in the single market and outside, and play a strategic role in modernising infrastructure, particularly for energy, water, road and digital infrastructure, I have chosen to vote in favour of this report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this report on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy on public-private initiatives in countries outside the EU, that proposes potential tools that can enable EU companies to engage in Public-Private Partnerships outside the EU.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ Chaith mé vóta i gcoinne na tuarascála seo ar chomhpháirtíocht phríobháideach/poiblí agus an tionchar atá ag polasaithe trádála agus infheistíochta AE.  Ar an drochuair níl sé aitheanta ag an bParlaimint na baoil agus na fadhbanna a bhaineann le chomhpháirtíocht phríobháideach/poiblí agus le soláthar seirbhísí poiblí do saoránaigh. Tá díomá orm go háirithe go bhfuil soláthar uisce roghnaithe mar spriocréimse i gcomhair tuilleadh rannpháirtíochta de chuideachtaí príobháideacha. Is monaplacht nádúrtha é soláthar uisce. Tugann cuideachtaí príobháideacha tosaíocht do bhrabúis dá scairshealbhóirí, cé go bhfuil oibritheoirí poiblí níos dílse a mhéid a bhaineann le huisce sábháilte agus glan a chur ar fáil do shaoránaigh.  I dtuarascáil mo chomhghleacaí, Lynn Boylan, maidir le Right2Water (Ceart chun Uisce), tá béim curtha aici ar an tslí gur chóir ár gceart daonna d’uisce a bheith cumhdaithe i reachtaíocht AE ionas nach mbeidh oibritheoir ar bith ábalta brabús a chur roimh sholáthar uisce do shaoránaigh. Tá cúlra de theipeanna le sonrú ar fud an domhain a mhéid a bhaineann le cuideachtaí príobháideacha a bheith bainteach leis an earnáil uisce agus mar sin níor chóir do AE é a chur chun cinn.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. Member States have not always had the best experience with public-private partnerships in recent years. Nevertheless, there are many European companies that are among the world leaders in this area. The aim of this report is to encourage them to expand worldwide. However, I do not think that sufficient attention is being given to protecting developing countries from over-pre-eposition by these companies. That is why I abstained.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted against this rapporteur who shamelessly promotes public-private partnerships in developing countries. We know that these new ways of public procurement are a financial abyss for communities to benefit businesses, which use them to pay handsomely on the backs of taxpayers.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is important that EU companies and SMEs participate more in international projects, as this would benefit in the areas of job creation, productivity, competitiveness, technology and innovation. However, this would stimulate economic growth in the EU and in third countries.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy on public-private initiatives in countries outside the EU. Indeed, I believe it is necessary to stimulate the creation of decent jobs, competitiveness and productivity within the EU and in third countries through innovative policies and new instruments aimed at promoting the dynamism of economic actors in order to relaunch sustainable growth, including through investments outside the single market. I am convinced that public-private partnerships (PPPs) can be a potential source of growth for EU businesses and, at the same time, be useful for our partner third countries, as they play a strategic role in modernising infrastructure, in particular energy, water, road and digital infrastructure, given that EU companies are well prepared to compete and operate such agreements. Finally, I argue that PPPs should bring high added value to citizens and consumers, ensure quality services and/or goods and provide real competitive and economic benefits for public administrations, both at state and local level, while avoiding creating additional burdens or losses for the public sector.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. Having regard to the fact that many emerging and developing countries are facing an imbalance between the dynamism of private companies and the unreliability of public infrastructure, I am in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Public-private partnerships in both the single market and globally are an important driver of economic growth, innovation, competitiveness and job creation and play a strategic role in the modernisation of infrastructure, in particular in terms of energy, water, road and digital infrastructure.  Public-private partnerships, if properly implemented, can reduce costs, improve the efficiency, performance and quality of public services and ensure the timely delivery of public infrastructure, with the appropriate participation of public and private stakeholders. Such projects usually have a long lifecycle and should be meaningful, consistently targeted towards objectives regardless of whether they are labour, exchange of goods or services to be provided. SMEs, as well as large companies, can provide private sector knowledge and skills, experience and good practices, as well as networks involving public authorities of non-EU countries, effectively helping to create sustainable development policies. They can best realise their potential if they create networks and operate on the global market by entering markets outside Europe, including through public-private partnerships. As the economic structures and societies of countries and their dynamism benefit from environments enabling interaction between the public and private sectors, I supported this report.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The report recommends that companies in Member States develop public-private partnerships in third countries. On the other hand, it does not envisage any serious avenue to enable these same companies to have access to external markets protected by protectionist measures when the Union's public procurement must be open, even without reciprocity.  Once again, this is pure ideology, a dogma imposing practices that have proven their inefficiency, or even their capacity for nuisance (the example of the Georges Pompidou Hospital in Paris should alone be enough to disgust anyone who is sensible to the concept of public-private partnership). Much worse, this ideology still applies at the expense of the economy of the countries of the Union, because the other States of the world retain the protections that are in their interest and do not hesitate to take all necessary measures to safeguard the sectors they consider strategic.  Once again, in the name of an absurd liberal dogma, it is the businesses of the Union, and therefore the citizens, who are the turkeys of farce. I am, of course, voting against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ There has always been a need to create decent jobs, stronger competitiveness and productivity within the EU and in third countries through innovative policies and new tools to stimulate the activities of economic actors. Public-private partnerships are exactly this innovation that could be a potential source of growth for EU businesses and beneficial for our partner third countries, as it could provide infrastructure and goods and services of general interest.  Public-private partnerships should deliver high added value for citizens and consumers, guarantee the quality of service and/or goods, and provide a concrete market and economic advantage for public administrations, both at national and local level.  I support the rapporteur's position that in the construction, management, maintenance or operation of transport infrastructures, public buildings and equipment, the environment, the utility, telecommunications and energy networks or the development of new technologies and products, there are a number of potential benefits and inherent risks that can be shared between the private and public sectors.  I welcome this initiative and agree that the opportunities offered by PPP outside the EU are great. I welcome the call for the EU institutions to take the necessary steps to start working as soon as possible to promote the participation of EU companies, in particular SMEs, in these projects.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the Resolution on the External Impact of European Union Policy on Trade and Investment on Public Private Partnership (PPP) initiatives in non-EU countries.  PPPs require a significant level of flexibility between the public and private sectors to achieve joint initiatives and strategic ventures. It is this resolution that unequivocally underlines the need to ensure fair competition and access for all parties involved in PPP. Private sector capital investments under PPP serve as a means to generate economic growth, innovation, competitiveness and job creation not only within the Single European Market, but also abroad, with particular role to be set aside in developing countries. As PPPs are of utmost importance in delivering major infrastructure projects, they play a strategic role in modernising the energy, water, road and digital economic sectors.  Significant investments in these areas are needed in developing countries and european SMEs should be ensured to remove administrative, procedural and technical barriers so that they can enter into public-private partnerships more easily. Greater participation of EU companies in international PPPs could lead to significant benefits in terms of job creation, productivity, competitiveness, technological opportunities and innovation development, both for the EU and for third countries.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Public-private partnerships (PPPs) are long-term agreements between the government and a private partner in which the private partner offers and finances public services with their own capital sharing their related risks. PPPs therefore refer to commercial relations between a private sector company and a government body with the aim of completing a project that will serve public users. The PPP can be used to finance various initiatives such as major infrastructure, for example, such as roads, ports and prisons, which would otherwise find it difficult to find the resources necessary for their implementation. With regard to the impact on third countries, I am convinced that the increased participation of European companies in major international projects, through PPPs, would lead to significant benefits both in terms of job creation and in terms of economic growth throughout the EU and in the host countries. The resolution urges the EU institutions to take the necessary measures to promote the participation of European companies, in particular SMEs in PPP projects. For all these reasons, I thought it appropriate to support this proposal.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In the face of increased trade between the European Union and third countries, and the growth of European investment in third countries, it is important to protect the interests of our businesses and to ensure the competitiveness of the European economy.  In this context, the European Parliament has adopted a report on the external impact of eu trade and investment policy in third countries. I voted in favour of this report. The text also highlights the importance of public-private partnerships in EU-third country exchanges.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Free trade agreements concluded by the European Union (EU) have an external impact on public-private initiatives in third countries. These agreements are useful for third-country governments in order to ensure that their citizens provide infrastructure, goods and services of general interest, while ensuring the best possible access for European, large, medium, small and micro-enterprise sands to public contract markets in third countries. Considering the economic, social and technological benefits across the EU and in the host countries, which are involved in public-private partnerships (PPPs) between the parties, I voted in favour of the report assessed here in favour of the EU institutions to promote and promote the participation of European companies in PPP projects.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I welcome the adoption of this report on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy on public-private initiatives in third countries, as it contains a number of key points, including references to sound regulatory frameworks, SMEs, principles of good governance and the fight against corruption. Increasing the participation of European companies in large-scale international projects, including PPPs, could bring substantial benefits in terms of productivity, competitiveness, technology and innovation, resulting in socio-economic benefits and economic growth across the EU and host countries. For these reasons and because it is crucial to revitalise job creation, I voted in favour of this document.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted this afternoon in favour of the Zahradil report, which highlights the importance of public-private partnerships (PPPs) in developing countries. The plenary followed the recommendations of the Committee on International Trade which advocated the development of PPPs, based on European expertise in this area: the EU dominates this market in the field of infrastructure, which accounts for more than 45% of the nominal value of PPPs. The report highlights the positive experiences of P3s that have resulted in better project delivery, an opportunity to finance long-term costs, but also a more flexible and qualified management environment. There are other benefits to the PPP. At the heart of this partnership approach are the demands of transparency and accountability, translated into English by the concept of "accountability". Two demands in today's economic world marked by reduced public investment and a renewed approach to public management.  This is another reason in the support provided by MEPs to the development of public-private partnerships in developing countries, where they are often the only way to launch major infrastructure projects.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Public-Private Partnerships (PPPs) can mean an important strengthening of the competitiveness of EU SMEs with third countries. I share the rapporteur's view when he considers that increasing the participation of European companies in international projects of this nature can bring substantial benefits in terms of job creation and increased productivity, competitiveness, technology and innovation. It is particularly important that such participation translates into socio-economic benefits in the EU and host countries. Given these potentials, the greater importance of the EU institutions taking the necessary measures to promote the participation of EU companies, including SMEs, in PPP projects in third countries.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which highlights the need for a strong and clear regulatory framework, which prevents any kind of conflict of interest in EU companies' access to public-private partnerships (PEs) abroad. As the report shows, it is necessary to design the risk transfer model very carefully, to ensure that the private partner will not make a profit without taking responsibility. In addition, an PPP should not be the first step towards privatisation of a service. It is essential to ensure that administrations retain the right to decide on the model of management of services of general interest, at any time, in accordance with the interest of citizens.  Finally, the EU must commit itself to supporting the financial and technical capacity of the administrations responsible for PPP in the partner countries that require it, to ensure good design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of projects, applying the principles of good governance, transparency, participation of civil society actors, and combating corruption and fraud.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report, of which I was shadow rapporteur, warns of the main challenges posed by PPPs in the framework of the common commercial policy, with the aim of strengthening the competitiveness of European companies when participating in public contracts in third countries.  In this context, the increased participation of European companies in large-scale international projects, in particular in the context of PPPs, will make a significant contribution in terms of job creation, increased productivity and competitiveness and increased technology and innovation, with a clear impact on economic growth not only from the EU but also from third countries. I therefore endorse and naturally vote in favour of the proposals on the need to encourage the participation of European companies, especially SMEs, in PPP projects, given the scale of investment and the opportunities offered by existing free trade agreements in relation to such partnerships. I would also stress the proposals for the inclusion of investment/access provisions for public tenders, the need to establish positive reciprocity in opening up to external markets, free from any barriers or protectionism, and the guarantee to investors that their long-term investment will benefit from sound and effective legal protection and certainty.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. Public-private partnerships (PPPs) are long-term contracts between the government and a private partner, where the private partner provides and funds a public service using assets and sharing associated risks. This allows the public sector to benefit and benefit from the private sector's experience in its construction. These PPPs represent a number of potential benefits and inherent risks. Increased participation of European companies in international projects under these PPPs could have a positive impact on job creation, productivity, competitiveness, technology and innovation.  Nevertheless, this development must take place in accordance with positive reciprocity in public procurement and access to PPPs. Investors must have sufficient guarantees of legal security and good governance for their long-term investments, and SMEs must be able to become more competitive in international markets.  I have therefore supported this report, which calls for measures to promote the participation of European companies, particularly SMEs, in PPPs.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the own-initiative report presented by the INTA Committee on public-private partnerships in third countries, those long-term contracts between the public authority and a private partner, under which the private sector finances a public service using its means and dividing the joint risks. This report, as the report pointed out, can have a very positive impact on employment (think, for example, of private participation in a major public project). This is therefore an important means of increasing employment and which, for this reason, I have decided to support with my vote.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I share the positive assessments in the text about the work of these partnerships, as well as the focus on the commitment of the companies involved on respect for the environment and workers' rights.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it because I reject the public-private partnerships (PPP) strategy as a mechanism designed and used primarily as an instrument for market access, deregulation and liberalization of public services and government procurement in third countries, especially developing countries, and a means of diverting development funds to private enterprises. In addition, we consider that there is a link between PPP and the risk of debt unsustainability; APPPs are often a way to transfer the risk of private companies to taxpayers.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it is a boost to the investment model promoted by international capital to ensure its investments at the expense of the public sector.  Public-private consortia aim to attract private investors by protecting their resources from any risks that may involve the loss of funds. The report is committed to this speculative investment model as a form of economic and trade intervention in third countries. This investment model is directly contrary to a real development project in third countries that improves the quality of life of the working classes; on the contrary, it is only intended to guarantee the great capitalists. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote calls on the Commission to take the necessary measures to support the participation of European companies, in particular SMEs, in public-private partnership (PPP) projects in third countries. I voted in favour of this initiative because I believe that greater participation by our companies at international level could produce attractive opportunities in terms of job creation, competitiveness and innovation for both the EU and the host countries. PPPs could make it possible to develop and finance more efficiently a range of strategic investments such as roads, bridges and hospitals through shared risk and benefit management. In any case, I believe it is essential that sufficient guarantees be given to private investors with regard to legal certainty and equal treatment between all the parties concerned.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation on the use of public-private partnerships.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. I agree with the EKR line that well-set PPP projects can be the engine of economics and infrastructure development. Already, their share of the total construction of new infrastructure in developed countries is around 20 percent.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution concerning the EU's trade and investment policy outside the EU, as I consider it to be very important, especially for public-private partnerships. They are an important means of achieving economic growth, innovation, competitiveness and job creation, and within the single market and abroad they have a strategic role to play in modernising infrastructure, in particular energy, water, road and digital. EU companies have sufficient capabilities to participate in competition and the implementation of EU trade and investment policy outside the EU, even if they are characterised by a long life cycle, sometimes of 10 to 30 years. Therefore, the Commission should ensure that Union trade agreements contain the necessary conditions to enable European companies to compete with domestic companies abroad on equal terms.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 International trade is a successful tool for generating growth and jobs. I therefore support the proposal for the Commission to take steps to promote the involvement of small and medium-sized enterprises by removing obstacles to their participation in public-private partnerships in trade and investment agreements with third countries. I share the view that greater participation of EU SMEs in large international public-private partnerships could lead to job creation, higher productivity, greater competitiveness and the development of innovation in the EU.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy on PPP initiatives in non-EU countries, as I believe member states and their societies benefit from public-private partnerships. I believe that these partnerships are important as they stimulate economic growth, job creation, innovation, etc. I am of the opinion that this encourages the development of SMEs, which, due to the provision of cheaper projects, achieve competitiveness on the market. I also believe that public-private partnerships can improve the quality and performance of service provision and reduce costs.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy on public-private initiatives in countries outside the EU as it includes references to strong regulatory frameworks, SMEs, the principles of good governance and the fight against corruption. Furthermore, I welcome the report’s support of participation of stakeholders and civil society, gender mainstreaming, capacity-building in public administration of partner countries, and references to the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights and CSR.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Public-private partnership represents cooperation between public and private partners that in many cases leads to the establishment of joint investments. Public and private sectors bring together resources and expertise to meet a public need through adequate allocation of resources, risks and benefits. This is a very good way for the private sector to employ its resources and skills in delivering goods and services traditionally provided by public services. Successful public-private partnerships are characterised by the division of investment costs, risks, responsibilities and profits between partners. The consequences of concluding public-private partnership agreements are stimulating economic growth and faster development of many significant projects. At a time when economic growth needs to be boosted, we must also support public-private initiatives outside the European Union. There are many benefits that can come from large international projects in the form of public-private partnerships. The development of such projects will boost job creation, increase productivity and further develop technology and innovation. We need to promote new investment opportunities and encourage the participation of European companies, in particular SMEs, in public-private projects outside the European Union, and that is why I support this report.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal because I agree that the Commission should work to extend the possibility of using PPP projects. PPPs can in many cases be a much more effective way of implementing public projects. However, it should be stressed that the increased efficiency of PPP projects is not automatic, as well as that the expansion of the possibilities for using PPP projects must not come at the expense of increasing the overall regulatory burden.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy on public-private initiatives in non-EU countries. The public-private partnership, which is under-utilated by Member States, is, as the report rightly notes, a driver of economic growth, innovation, competitiveness and job creation, both in the single market and more broadly. This mechanism is also appropriate for reducing poverty in third countries. In doing so, I would like to point out that we often under-listen to countries that know best which projects are best for them.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 PPP has been primarily used as a destabilising factor for public services and consequently channelling, mainly in developing countries, official development aid to private companies.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The current report stresses the opportunities provided to EU companies by Private-Public Partnerships (PPPs) in third countries. The report calls on working towards an EU trade policy to ensuring market access for EU companies abroad, particularly in countries that continue to pose substantial barriers in procurement markets. It emphasises the need to facilitate SMEs’ access to these tenders and makes a number of recommendations in this regard. Few, among others include: reinforcing the legal framework for PPPs for establishing a clear, predictable and legitimate institutional framework; ensuring adequate human resources to enable the administration to properly design PPPs and oversee their implementation; implementing the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights (UNGPs); and asking that future PPPs within the post-2015 development agenda will follow the goals for poverty reduction and other sustainable development goals. I voted in favour of the report for the potential opportunities it provides European companies and SMEs in large scale international projects. Facilitating the participation of EU companies will not only lead to the creation of jobs, but will also contribute to the development of a sustainable business environment in host countries.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I spoke out in favour of the text. Let us recall the importance of public-private partnerships (PPPs) as an engine of economic growth, innovation, competitiveness and job creation both within and outside the single market; it highlights the strategic role played by PPPs in modernising infrastructure, including energy, road, digital and water infrastructure. I would also like the Commission to ensure that EU-backed bodies, such as the European Agency for Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (EASME) and the Enterprise Europe Network (EEN), can also obtain and share with SMEs information on how to integrate PPPs in third countries, and promote the participation of small and medium-sized enterprises in PPPs in third countries.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. —Public-private partnerships are long-term agreements between private stakeholders and public authorities seeking to achieve mutually advantageous public goals (in segments such as infrastructure, energy, telecommunications and the environment) by sharing resources and expertise. I certainly share the rapporteur's concerns about transparency, accountability, corruption and resource management efficiency, but also his primary focus on the positive aspects of these partnerships, which are common practice in developed countries, especially in eu-US countries. The rapporteur argues that increased participation of European companies in large-scale public-private partnerships would enable significant benefits to be realised in terms of creating new jobs and increasing competitiveness, which I certainly welcome.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. Interest in public-private partnerships has grown in recent years, and the need for fiscal constraints on OECD countries (including EU countries) is likely to increase the need for them. The INTA therefore examined in more detail the challenges of public-private partnerships under the EU's common trade policy with a view to strengthening the competitiveness of EU businesses and participation in public procurement in third countries.  There are a large number of potential benefits and risks for both sectors, both public and private. The increased participation of European companies in large-scale international projects, particularly in public-private partnerships, would bring significant benefits in terms of job creation, productivity, competitiveness, technology development and innovation, which can lead to economic growth in the EU and in the host countries, which is why I supported this report.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it because I reject the public-private partnerships (PPP) strategy as a mechanism designed and used primarily as an instrument for market access, deregulation and liberalization of public services and government procurement in third countries, especially developing countries, and a means of diverting development funds to private enterprises. In addition, we consider that there is a link between PPP and the risk of debt unsustainability; APPPs are often a way to transfer the risk of private companies to taxpayers.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report explains that public-private sector interactions, joint ventures and joint projects, are good for economic dynamism (including public-private partnerships - PPPs). Public-private partnerships are catastrophic in terms of costs for public investment and are described as a means of developing infrastructure in emerging countries, given the lack of budgetary resources. The tools that the Commission, the Council and Parliament must implement according to this report: - to reduce the asymmetry of openness between our public procurement and those of other countries through requests for openness! However, no real negotiating avenue is envisaged; - create information and support platforms by the Commission so that our companies have access to third-party public procurement; - work towards establishing dispute settlement mechanisms with third countries to ensure that our investments are well protected. This may mean the "shunting" of national courts. We obviously disagree with this report both in terms of the use of PPPs and the Commission's willingness to nibble on power. I'm voting against it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it because I reject the public-private partnerships (PPP) strategy as a mechanism designed and used primarily as an instrument for market access, deregulation and liberalization of public services and government procurement in third countries, especially developing countries, and a means of diverting development funds to private enterprises. In addition, we consider that there is a link between PPP and the risk of debt unsustainability; APPPs are often a way to transfer the risk of private companies to taxpayers.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted against this report, which aims to put a lot of pressure on third-country markets, especially in the process of developing, to facilitate the arrival of European industry. I also strongly disagree that private public partnerships (IPPs) are a useful economic tool for development; on the contrary, they are opaque instruments in which the private party maximizes profits at the expense of the public party.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. As the report rightly points out, increased participation by European companies in large-scale international projects and through public-private partnerships can bring substantial benefits in terms of job creation, productivity, competitiveness, technology or innovation, thus assuming benefits and economic growth across the European Union. That is why I consider it appropriate to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it is a boost to the investment model promoted by international capital to ensure its investments at the expense of the public sector.  Public-private consortia aim to attract private investors by protecting their resources from any risks that may involve the loss of funds. The report is committed to this speculative investment model as a form of economic and trade intervention in third countries. This investment model is directly contrary to a real development project in third countries that improves the quality of life of the working classes; on the contrary, it is only intended to guarantee the great capitalists. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report discusses public-private partnerships (PPPs) and their promotion in relations with third countries.  The initial statement, which "considers regrettable that the Union has maintained its public procurement very widely open to international competition", can only be shared.  However, the conclusion drawn from this is shameful with cynicism: if free trade has wreaked havoc in Europe, there is no reason why the Union's trading partners should not also bear the brunt! This report therefore looks at the huge infrastructure needs in developing countries and therefore calls for opening markets for European companies. The "economic partnership" (EPA) agreements for African countries but also free trade agreements of all kinds with Tunisia, Mexico, Vietnam, etc. are covered here. Together with my GUE-NGL group, I oppose deregulation and liberalization of public sectors, the misappropriation of development funds for private enterprises and the damage already caused by PPPs in developing countries, particularly in the agriculture and health sector. So I voted against this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Public-private partnerships today represent for many countries simultaneously a symptom of this model of capitalist integration and a cause of the current crisis.  This model of European integration, with the single currency and all budgetary constraints, leaves states without room to be able to make the public investments necessary for development. They are now dependent on large enterprises not only on large transport infrastructure, but also on key areas such as health, energy or education. I could cite many examples of political figures passing from government to the boards of large economic groups with which the state maintains absolutely ruinous PPPs for citizens. In Portugal, ppp spending grows exponentially, unlike all social expenditures. In other words, austerity is only for some and not for large economic groups, which increasingly benefit from public rents. What is needed is to protect Europe against the openness proposed by the TTIP. It is a question of combating and not extending the validity of an instrument that has become a cancer for our democracy.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I would not have approved or rejected this report. There are certain dangers of developing countries being over-exploited by multinational and experienced companies; at the same time, new expansion opportunities are also emerging for European companies.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the own-initiative report on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy on public-private initiatives (PPPs) in non-EU countries. I welcome the fact that the rapporteur has seen the potential of PPP initiatives outside the EU, which can generate new opportunities for EU businesses in terms of growth and jobs.  This report shows that increased participation of EU businesses in large international PPPs could create substantial benefits in terms of creating decent jobs, productivity, competitiveness, and developing technological capabilities and innovation in the EU. Moreover, the Commission's 2010 study 'Internationalisation of European SMEs' highlights the positive link between internationalisation and innovation in products, services and processes.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report gives public-private partnerships (PPPs) a whole range of 'good' qualities and considers them a 'success'. The reality and the various experiences in the various Member States contradict these claims. PPPs, yes, have contributed to the dismantling of public services and their provision to the populations. They have been a determining factor in the worsening of regional asymmetries and have compromised the democratic nature of public services. This report aims to 'export' the model of setting up PPPs in the establishment of trade policies with third countries and, for that reason, we voted against it.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – (incomprehensible word) I supported my colleague Mela's report, because producer organisations in the greenery sector are the right answer to joint production planning, overall cost reductions and, of course, marketing in increasingly harsh agricultural trade conditions. The fruit and vegetables sector covers only 3% of Europe's agricultural area and the value of this product is as high as 18%. So we are talking about an intensive agricultural sector, which also has 550 000 jobs. The report also clearly states that countries where there are no producer organisations should be encouraged. I come from Slovenia, where unfortunately we do not have any producer organisation.  I did my best to organise a conference in the European Parliament, a tour of Belgian good practices and also a consultation in Slovenia, and I hope that this report, as well as the situation in this area, will encourage the Slovenian agriculture minister to develop a strategy in Slovenia as well and to set up the first producer organisations.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I strongly support paragraph 18 of the Fruit and Vegetables Report, in particular the call on the European Commission to restore financial support for the investments of the newly created fruit and vegetable producer organisations. These organisations are a strong mechanism in the hands of producers in negotiating with other actors in the supply chain, but they are still unpopular, especially in newly joined Member States, such as my country Bulgaria.  The developments of the last year related to the Russian embargo have clearly shown that the sector is sensitive and the measures envisaged by the European Commission have proved extremely insufficient. I therefore call on the Commission to commit adequate resources and direct aid to producers, rather than leaving the millions of farmers without perspective and livelihoods.  I also call on the Commission for information campaigns aimed at presenting the attractiveness of the sector to young people as an opportunity for livelihoods. The current worrying trends of ageing and depopulation of rural, mountainous and remote regions are an acute problem and the Commission must put in practical efforts and make concrete proposals to address this trend.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today, Parliament voted on a report commenting on the Commission's report on the implementation of the 2007 reform for the fruit and vegetables sector.  The Commission's report, as well as Parliament's report, see EU subsidies to professional organisations as the key to competitiveness. I do not agree with this. The report also contains directly protectionist elements which risk hampering access to the European market for fruit and vegetables from the poor part of the world.  I therefore voted against.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although some improvement was made in relation to the original document, I have decided to abstain in my final vote. This is because the report does not reflect the need for public policies to support the bargaining capacity of medium and small farms, the fall in fruit and vegetable consumption in countries with austerity policies that lead to the adoption by families of an unhealthy diet, the promotion of traditional diets based on seasonal vegetables and fruits , the limited use of funds by producer organisations, the closure of farms leading to the desertification of large areas of land, the inclusion of social and economic value criteria for small and medium-sized enterprises farms to preserve the rural environment, as well as the exclusion of agricultural products from TTE negotiations and the defence of the marketing and consumption of local networks that promote social cohesion and Regional.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This own initiative report aims to encourage the Commission to present a legislative proposal aimed at the revision of the aid scheme for the fruit and vegetable sector. However, there were some problematic aspects to this report specifically Recital AE, paragraphs 63 and 71 which welcomed the school milk and school fruit schemes, and the accompanying propaganda measures, as being beneficial for the fruit and vegetable sector. My colleague Matt Carthy was shadow rapporteur on the school milk and fruit scheme and he specifically highlighted that EU Funds should not be spent on advertising EU involvement in the scheme as opposed to the promotion of healthy eating. However, there were a number of positive aspects to the report including §51 which called on third countries to adhere to the EU’s environmental, social, health, food safety and animal welfare standards if they export to the EU. It was for this reason that I tabled an abstention.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. The fruit and vegetable sector will need to be reformed in the coming months. The Melo report to which I have made several contributions makes a number of recommendations for this. The most important are to: - adapt and clarify the rules governing the creation of producer organisations so that the sector is collectively better organised;  - increase support for producer organisations; - put in place tools for crisis prevention and management; - combat unfair trade practices in the food chain and especially in the retail sector; - strengthening sustainability and environmental protection; - stimulate innovation and research; - promote short circuits and fruit and vegetable consumption programs in schools; - apply reciprocity in trade with the outside world; - to control more effectively the importation of plant pests. I will support this important report on the economic and employment initiative, particularly in the Mediterranean regions, which are the largest fruit and vegetable production areas in Europe.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF)
text: Written. The Melo report gives a good picture of the situation in the fruit and vegetable sector and touches on a number of pain points. Overall EU support is steadily increasing, and the level of organisation in the sector – with the creation and expansion of producer organisations – is also increasing. This does not prevent production acreage from steadily declining, the bulk of the subsidy pot from entering a limited proportion of POs, and the lack of use of resources relating to crisis prevention and management, training and research and experimental production. The Russian boycott is not the fault of the sector, but it is a major victim of it. However, the Commission is sitting back.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Today, fruit and vegetable production is under enormous pressure. The high concentration of retail and discount chains allows them to play an increasingly important role in setting market prices. Producers are also facing increasing competition from third-country products. The only way to solve our structural problems is to strengthen the role of our producer organisations.  I welcome the report that has been adopted, as it proposes, among other things, in this regard, to form together larger associations of producer organisations in order to strengthen the bargaining power of farmers in the food supply chain. It also points out that well-functioning producer organisations can be seen as an aspect of increasing the attractiveness of agriculture to young people, which could help reverse the unsustainable demographic trend in this sector.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The economic crisis has been particularly difficult to negotiate for the fruit and vegetable sector, which is mainly composed of small and medium-sized farms and businesses. It represents a significant weight in European agriculture, generating a turnover of 120 billion euros per year. Consumption of fruits and vegetables has fallen sharply, especially among the youngest, increasing the risk of obesity. The EU's bellicose foreign policy towards Russia has provoked an embargo on the part of Russia, exacerbating the crisis facing producers.   I therefore consider it essential to help this sector and this report is a step in the right direction, although it does not refer to unfair competition from third countries. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution as a whole, but there were some good points contained in it.  It recognises the need for more young people to eat more fruit and vegetables, although in my view this is a matter for national governments.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it calls on the Commission to redouble its efforts to protect farmers from unfair business practices by large retailers. It makes little sense to invest resources in strengthening and creating OPs (a slow and difficult process) if the bargaining power in the food chain continues to be primarily the domain of retailers. Moreover, as many Member States adopt national measures to deal with these problems, some coordination is needed at EU level to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to strengthen the bargaining power and resilience of farmers producing fruit and vegetables and dairy farmers. Farmers should be encouraged to join producer associations and the Commission should assist them in finding new markets, especially in view of the negative impact of the Russian embargo. The European Union should rebalance the fruit and vegetable supply chain, with a turnover of more than EUR 120 billion. with around 550 000 jobs. Employees.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have endorsed this report which draws attention to the difficulties faced by fruit and vegetable producers who are struggling to earn a decent income due in particular to the unfair trade practices and pressures of large distribution groups and therefore calls on the Commission to step up efforts to combat these practices by establishing clear European rules. It also aims to make producer organizations more attractive by simplifying the rules, promoting research and innovation, and providing more funds to encourage more farmers to participate.  Finally, as the Russian embargo on EU exports has seriously affected many European producers, the report calls for the Community support measures to be kept in place for as long as necessary until the normal market situation is fully restored.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 European farmers and ranchers work to obtain high quality products but sometimes suffer from the achievement of circumstances affecting the sector, such as the Russian veto, which change the prices of the products and their stocks in a way that makes them especially vulnerable. That's why they need to have the right tools that allow them to react and grow the industry. That is why we must help them find new opportunities with internationalization processes to ensure they earn fair income and create a profitable sector. That's why I voted for it.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The text on the fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform seeks to support this sector economically through the development of producer organisations but also to participate in health education, especially among children who are less and less aware of nature. All of these objectives are laudable and, therefore, it appears that this text is moving in the right direction. However, there are gaps: there is no mention of wage differences within and outside the European Union, nor of the use of illegal labour by some operators, nor of plant health standards and their implementation. I am in favour of this text in spite of these shortcomings, because of my support for the national fruit and vegetable sector, which needs special attention because of the number of jobs it represents.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the Melo report, which analyses the development of the fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform. The fruit and vegetable sector is of fundamental importance to the EU and our territories: it accounts for 18% of the total value of European agricultural production totalling over EUR 50 billion. For these reasons, I believe that the Commission should remove the existing bureaucratic obstacles which prevent the effective aggregation of producer organisations in the Member States and which would lead to a maximisation of the operational management of this sector.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 the Commission published a report last year on the implementation of the fruit and vegetable reform, agreed in 2007, containing some valid analyses such as the persistent diversity between Member States, the degree of organisation of the sector and the limited bargaining power of producers in the value chain. In view of Commissioner Hogan's commitment to simplify the fruit and vegetable regime during his term of office, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution as Parliament's first position on the next reform. The reform must confirm the validity of the organizational basic structure of this sector around producer organisations, their market orientation and the improvement of the quality and environmental aspects of production, carried out through operational programmes.  In addition, European legislation on the recognition of producer organisations, the audit of operational programmes and the measures taken in each Member State should be simplified; improve crisis management tools that have become ineffid in large cases such as the Russian veto; encourage the creation of producer organizations, and combat unfair practices in the value chain, among other issues.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with the development of the fruit and vegetables sector and the 2007 reform. The common agricultural policy (CAP) has reduced the regulation of agricultural markets over the last 20 years, allowing production to be channelled to market forces. This general approach was particularly applicable to the fruit and vegetables regime, which led to the abolition of measures such as the fixing of an export refund or the fixing of minimum prices to be paid to farmers by processors for certain products. The European Union has linked this liberalisation process to a policy of strengthening producer organisations (POs) in order to enable farmers to take action to protect their interests, for example by collectively selling their production or increasing the value of these production by processing on farms. Thus, the CAP GO provides the financial support they use to implement their operational programmes. POs use such programmes to achieve a variety of objectives consistent with their specific situation, such as investing in marketing campaigns or in training activities. In March 2014, the Commission published a report on the implementation of the new rules of procedure in the fruit and vegetables sector established following the 2007 reform. This report provides a coherent overview of the situation in the fruit and vegetables sector, identifies areas where progress has been made and highlights some of the ongoing problems.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is of the utmost importance for Hungarian farmers and producer organisations that the European Commission restore EU aid for investments in newly formed fruit and vegetable producer organisations. Without it, it is extremely difficult for the established organisers to obtain the state recognition necessary for its operation. It is therefore one of the most effective tools for improving producer organisations and increasing the level of organisation. It is also a major step forward that the report calls on the Commission to deal more effectively with crisis situations. On the one hand, it is necessary to improve the mechanism for withdrawal from the market and, on the other hand, to adjust intervention prices to real market prices and production costs. By my vote, I supported the adoption of the report on the situation in the fruit and vegetables sector, in line with the direction of the European People's Party.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Due to the disabling of exports to Russia, many countries face a major problem of fruit and vegetable placement and need commission support. I advocate that these grants continue until the situation is resolved. I also support the focus on the role of producer agencies, in particular in the fight against UTPs.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This own initiative report aims to encourage the Commission to present a legislative proposal aimed at the revision of the aid scheme for the fruit and vegetable sector. However, there were some problematic aspects to this report specifically Recital AE, paragraphs 63 and 71 which welcomed the school milk and school fruit schemes, and the accompanying propaganda measures, as being beneficial for the fruit and vegetable sector. EU Funds should not be spent on advertising EU involvement in the scheme as opposed to the promotion of healthy eating. However, there were a number of positive aspects to the report including §51 which called on third countries to adhere to EU’s environmental, social , health, food safety and animal welfare standards if they export to the EU. It was for this reason that I abstained.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that public-private partnerships are an innovative solution to help European businesses grow, and that is why I believe that the trade agreements concluded by the Union with third countries must contain precise provisions in this regard, which do not discriminate against our companies.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The proposed resolution on the fruit and vegetable sector aims to help a sector in a very difficult economic situation. Producers' organizations will receive compensatory aid to help them cope with the negative consequences of the restrictions imposed.  The fruit and vegetable sector is strategic not only for Europe's food self-sufficiency, but also for its economy. It supports 500,000 Europeans in all Member States and contributes 18% to the total value of agricultural production. Since this text is in favour of French fruit and vegetable producers, I voted in favour.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) has reduced the regulation of agricultural markets over the past 20 years, allowing market forces to guide production. This general approach was specifically applied to the fruit and vegetable sector scheme ('the F&L regime'), where instruments such as export refunds or the setting of minimum prices which processing operators were required to pay to farmers for certain products were waived. The increase in the organisational rate across the Union should continue to be a priority for the F&L regime. It is important to find ways to increase the attractiveness of producer organisations. I voted in favour of the report on the fruit and vegetables sector from the 2007 reform to the present, because it presents a balanced picture of the situation in the F&L sector, and also underlines the fact that the EU has a trade deficit in the fruit and vegetable sector, particularly in terms of fruit, but in recent years has started to open up its market.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of the measure. In the EU, the fruit and vegetable sector accounts for 18% of the total value of agricultural production, uses only 3% of the cultivated area and is worth over EUR 50 billion. Also in this sector the theme of the aggregation of supply and organization of the supply chain is very important for an adequate presence on the market. The "producer organisations" (OPs) and their associations (AOP) can represent, in this sense, a useful instrument provided for by Community rules, encouraged by the recent reform of the CAP which, however, is used, in the fruit and vegetable sector, only in those geographical areas where there is a more advanced figure of farmer, aimed more at the market of destination of its products (Northern Italy is an example). The organisation rate between producers therefore remains low on average and, in some Member States, considerably below the EU average.  The report lists a number of references, some of them useful, to the Commission in order to increase the aggregation between producers and remove the main obstacles (many of them bureaucratic) to the operational management of POs.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Over the past 20 years, the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) has reduced the regulation of agricultural markets, allowing market forces to guide production. This general approach was specifically applied to the fruit and vegetable sector scheme, where instruments such as export refunds or the setting of minimum prices which processing operators were obliged to pay to farmers for certain products were waived. The Union has linked this liberalisation process with a policy of strengthening producer organisations (POs) in order to enable farmers to act to protect their interests, for example by collectively selling their products or increasing their added value by processing them on the farm. The 2007 reform of the fruit and vegetable regime confirmed and extended the policy of strengthening the role of producer organisations and associations of producer organisations (PDo).

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Recent political and health crises illustrate the need to strengthen competitiveness, resilience and innovation in the fruit and vegetable sector. The latter suffers from serious problems of competitiveness and organization. This report is Parliament's response to the Commission's report on this issue. It does not advocate a change in the current architecture of the fruit and vegetable sector, but identifies the successes and progress that can be made. It stresses the need to increase the rate of organization of the sector and to make it more attractive or to combat unfair business practices.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The importance of the European Union's fruit and vegetable sector is undeniable, both in terms of added value and employment. We must also not forget the health benefits of fruit and vegetables for citizens. However, this sector is characterized by frequent market crises, since even small production surpluses can cause drastic falls in prices. In addition, serious crises such as the one caused by the E. coli bacterium or the current one, generated by the Russian embargo, have demonstrated the vulnerability of the sector. That is why, as the report we have voted on has shown, the Commission should consider the establishment of new crisis management instruments, which have so far been used too little and with insufficient results. Also in connection with the Russian embargo, Community support measures should be extended until the normal market situation is fully restored: producers must not be charged for crises caused by causes outside the agricultural sector. Finally, the Commission should step up its efforts to combat unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain, which reduce incomes and threaten the efficiency of the sector, in order to guarantee a decent income for fruit and vegetable producers, a sine qua non for securing the future of the profession and attracting young labour.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This own initiative report aims to encourage the Commission to present a legislative proposal aimed at the revision of the aid scheme for the fruit and vegetable sector. However, there were some problematic aspects to this report specifically Recital AE, paragraphs 63 and 71 which welcomed the school milk and school fruit schemes, and the accompanying propaganda measures, as being beneficial for the fruit and vegetable sector. I was shadow rapporteur on the school milk and fruit scheme and I specifically highlighted that EU Funds should not be spent on advertising EU involvement in the scheme as opposed to the promotion of healthy eating. However, there were a number of positive aspects to the report including §51 which called on third countries to adhere to EU’s environmental, social , health, food safety and animal welfare standards if they export to the EU. It was for this reason that I tabled an abstention.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution as a whole, but there were some good points contained in it. It recognises the need for more young people to eat more fruit and vegetables, although in my view this is a matter for national governments.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report in response to the Commission’s Report on the implementation of the provisions concerning producer organisations, operational funds and operational programmes in the fruit and vegetables sector since the 2007 reform. I believe that the basic organisational structure for the fruit and vegetable sector remains valid, and no major changes are needed, but that there are areas where improvements can be made, for example, in the simplification of the rules and controls governing the functioning of Producer Organisations (POs) in order to increase its membership and become more effective. I also believe that well-functioning POs are viewed as having a role to play in attracting more young people into farming and reverse the unsustainable demographic trend being experienced by the sector. As the rate of organisation of producers into POs remains low on average in all the Member States, this is another matter that needs to be tackled.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Over the past 20 years, the CAP has reduced the regulation of agricultural markets, especially in the fruit and vegetable sector, allowing market forces to direct production to the detriment of distributors, processors and operators in the short supply chain. The 2007 reform strengthens the role of producer organisations (POs) and producer organisations' associations, and sets funding limits at 4.1% of the value of production marketed by POs. Mr Nuno Melo's report highlights the importance of ensuring legal certainty by simplifying the arrangements applicable to fruit and vegetables and the practices for setting up and recognising the various POs at national level. It also calls for the focus to be on human capital and the choice of qualified managers who can compete in competitive international markets, such as those in third countries with which the EU has trade agreements, and where unfair practices, which POs are already forced to face at national level, are accentuated. It calls for greater transparency and democratic control over the handing out of Community funds, so as to increase mutual trust between POs and combat unfair practices, which are common in the large-scale distribution of the fruit and vegetable sector. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I wanted to support this report, which provides an overview of the fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform. In particular, the text recognises that, compared to private commercial companies, producer organizations are subject to a series of restrictions, including the use of invested funds, income structure or the need to sell. The rapporteur also stresses the need to support the fruit and vegetable sector throughout the EU, given its importance in terms of added value and jobs and its interest in health through healthy and balanced diets. Therefore, the report rightly calls on the Commission to redouble its efforts to deal with unfair trade practices in the food supply chain, which have a negative impact on producers' revenues, reduce their incomes and place them in a precarious situation, which threatens the viability and stability of the sector. French farmers themselves are particularly threatened by certain practices carried out by retailers, which is why I support the AGRI Commission's desire to better protect our farmers.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report rightly asks the Commission to consider contributing to mutual funds eligible as crisis prevention and management measures in order to provide farmers with greater protection at times of market crisis leading to a significant drop in income. , for example, the ban imposed by Russia on EU exports, which has seriously affected many European fruit and vegetable producers. That's how we vote in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on fruit and vegetables after the 2007 reform. The sector in question has been liberalised, thanks to the reduction of market regulation, the abandonment of instruments such as export refunds or the fixing of minimum prices for certain products, which processing companies were obliged to pay to farmers. In addition to this liberalisation process, the EU has confirmed and strengthened the role of producer organisations (POs) and producer organisations' associations (AOPs) with the aim of enabling farmers to act in defence of their interests, for example by collectively selling their products or by bringing added value through farm processing. The increase in the rate of organisation in almost all Member States in recent years indicates that the Union's policy in favour of the creation and development of POs has been successful. Therefore, the report calls for the creation of POs and AOPs in the EU Member States to be encouraged and encouraged.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the fruit and vegetable sector as the reform implemented in 2007 strengthened the role of producer organisations and producer organisations' associations with tangible results. The rate of organisation has increased, with a percentage of fruit and vegetables marketed within the EU between producer organisations and producer organisations' associations increasing to 43%.  The Commission's public consultation pointed out that most of the people interviewed were in favour of continuing the scheme inaugurated in 2007, albeit with the introduction of some corrective measures. The regions where producers have reported the highest rates of productivity and competitiveness are those where the rate of organization of production is highest, but the latter is still not very widespread among producers. That is why we must continue to encourage the creation of organisations and associations and the merging of them, simplifying the arrangements applicable to the fruit and vegetable sector and allocating funds to encourage the improvement of the management capacity of organisations. In addition, the population employed in agriculture is ageing and it is of the utmost importance to give impetus and charm to a fundamental activity such as agriculture.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Melo's report because I agree with the need to strengthen incentives to encourage the creation of POs and AOps and their mergers. The purpose of producer organisations, as well as associations, is to enable farmers to act in defence of their interests, for example by selling their own products or by bringing added value through farm processing. It is also important to improve the human capital of POs by investing in it to make the agri-food sector competitive and international, as well as to protect farmers from unfair commercial practices in large-scale distribution.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although some improvement was made in relation to the original document, I have decided to abstain in my final vote. This is because the report does not reflect the need for public policies to support the bargaining capacity of medium and small farms, the fall in fruit and vegetable consumption in countries with austerity policies that lead to the adoption by families of an unhealthy diet, the promotion of traditional diets based on seasonal vegetables and fruits , the limited use of funds by producer organisations, the closure of farms leading to the desertification of large areas of land, the inclusion of social and economic value criteria for small and medium-sized enterprises farms to preserve the rural environment, as well as the exclusion of agricultural products from TTE negotiations and the defence of the marketing and consumption of local networks that promote social cohesion and Regional.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Overall the fruit and vegetables sector has increased since 2004 but on the other hand general fruit and vegetable production declined in Europe. It is also clear that the Russian ban will have significant negative effects on this sector. Therefore the report calls on the Commission to intensify efforts at improving the sector by addressing unfair trade, simplifying the Common Agricultural Policy, encouraging producer organisations and increasing negotiations with 3rd world countries among others. Keeping in mind the fragility of Malta’s agricultural sector and the importance of this niche for those who are dependent on it I supported fully this report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that both the European Commission and the Member States must develop existing actions or establish new actions, including training and exchange of best practices, that can improve the management of producer organisations and their competitive position in the food supply chain, and I stress the need to revise the legislation in force in order to ensure better targeting of producer organisations in all Member States.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to provide an overview of the fruit and vegetable sector in Europe since the 2007 reform. In particular, the European Parliament calls for strengthening producer organisations and inter-professionals, and for improved tools to support their actions in Europe and internationally.  As such, during the reform of the CAP, I had incorporated many tools to strengthen this weight, particularly in trade negotiations. Nevertheless, it is clear that these tools remain little used in many countries. France has a leadership role to play here, in order to promote its vision of the organisation of producers and inter-professionalism in Europe.  The report also discusses crisis management and the cost of intervention. It is worth recalling the requirement of Member States, including the French Government, to be solely responsible for setting intervention prices.  Given the balanced nature of this report, I voted in favour of it.
