name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Union is pursuing a policy of supporting the fruit and vegetable sector by promoting producer organisations, to which financial aid is paid. This method of market regulation should improve the competitiveness of European producers while stabilizing their incomes. The role of these organizations is also to attract more young people to the agricultural trades, to reverse the negative demographic trend that this sector suffers from. Finally, the aim is also to encourage the consumption of fresh fruits and vegetables. Indeed, as the report points out, this amounts to 387 grams per day per capita in the EU, when the World Health Organization recommends 400 grams.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the 2007 reform in the fruit and vegetable sector, the Commission wanted to strengthen the role of producer organisations (POs) by providing it with a wide range of market crisis prevention and management tools and by creating incentives to encourage their merger with OP associations (AOP) for greater transnational cooperation in the sector. Nevertheless, in order to make POs a further attractive tool, it is still necessary to reduce the excessive complexity and lack of legal certainty that characterise the current regime applicable to fruit and vegetables. I voted in favour of this report in order to call on the European Commission to combat unfair commercial practices in the supply chain that affect producers' performance, reduce their incomes and threaten the efficiency and sustainability of the sector, and to strengthen incentives to encourage the creation of POs and AOps and mergers between them.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. This report aims to encourage farmers to join producer organizations (OPs) in order to increase their bargaining power, strengthen their position in the food supply chain and thus increase their incomes in a struggling agricultural sector.  It is essential to increase their competitiveness and to tackle certain unfair trade practices in third countries. The EU must help its farmers find new markets for their products and facilitate exports in the context of the Russian embargo and the ongoing trade negotiations conducted by the European Commission.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the situation of the fruit and vegetable sector after the reform of the common market organisation in 2007, as it helps to strengthen a specific policy adapted to the fruit and vegetable sector.  Producer organizations are the main component. Tools to serve producers to organize collectively in the markets, they have an essential role in defending producers' incomes. In order to strengthen the effectiveness of producers' collective action, it is also necessary to strengthen the OPs associations and to provide for the possibility of associating producers who are not members of a producer organisation, including a good valuation of products, managing or anticipating crises, and carrying out environmental actions.  Finally, it is necessary to strengthen inter-professionals for their role in improving dialogue within the sector as well as in generic information and food education.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the adoption of the report on the situation in the fruit and vegetables sector, in line with the direction of the European People's Party. The European Parliament supported my fellow Member Norbert Erdős's proposal for the European Commission to restore EU funding for investments in newly formed fruit and vegetable production organisations. This is extremely important for Hungarian farmers and producer organisations. Without it, it is extremely difficult for the established organisers to obtain the state recognition necessary for its operation. It is therefore one of the most effective tools for improving producer organisations and increasing the level of organisation. I am pleased that this explanation is reflected in the report. It is also a major step forward that the report calls on the Commission to deal more effectively with crisis situations. On the one hand, it is necessary to improve the mechanism for withdrawal from the market and, on the other hand, to adjust intervention prices to real market prices and production costs. This is in line with my fellow Member Norbert Erdős's opinion on market crisis management, which he has already voiced on numerous occasions in various forums of the European Parliament.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for the report on the fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform.  Fruit and vegetable production has declined since 2007. This is a concern for several reasons. First of all, the fruit and vegetable sector employs many French people, worried about the possible consequences of a drop in production. In addition, this leads to a decrease in consumption, even though fruits and vegetables are basic foods for the health of everyone, especially children. Finally, this leads to an increase in imports which once again reveals the unfair competition faced by French producer organisations.   We therefore need to revive the French fruit and vegetable economy, both economically and culturally, in order to produce competitive, viable food for producers and accessible to consumers.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Congratulations on the report, you can see that a lot of work has been done. I am pleased that some of the key problems of the sector have been clearly and categorically identified. I note that, rightly, large retail chains create a lot of problems for manufacturers. They harm competition and the growth of the sector. And another - we need to think about more incentives to increase production. And especially in Southeastern Europe, whose producers suffered the most from the Russian embargo, the practice of large chains and the difference in subsidies. For example, cherries producers in Bulgaria are currently experiencing serious difficulties. I therefore call on us to show solidarity and to consider mechanisms to support SMEs of vegetable growers and fruit producers.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report because the Union chooses to continue the policy that has destroyed Greek production by subsidising the withdrawal of agricultural products, while at the same time its foreign policy is causing enormous damage that it is unwilling to repair.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report on the situation in the fruit and vegetables sector, in line with the direction of the European People's Party. The European Parliament has supported my proposal for the European Commission to restore EU funding for investments in newly formed fruit and vegetable production organisations. This is extremely important for us Hungarian farmers and producer organisations. Without it, it is extremely difficult for the established organisers to obtain the state recognition necessary for its operation. It is therefore one of the most effective tools for improving producer organisations and increasing the level of organisation. I am pleased that this explanation is reflected in the report. It is also a major step forward that the report calls on the Commission to deal more effectively with crisis situations. On the one hand, it is necessary to improve the mechanism for withdrawal from the market and, on the other hand, to adjust intervention prices to real market prices and production costs. This is in line with my opinion on crisis management, which I have already said many times in the European Parliament.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, because I believe that the relationship between producers and purchasing and retail centres should be supervised.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Successive CAP reforms over the past 20 years have reduced to almost nothing the regulation of agricultural markets. 'Liberalisation' and 'market orientation' prevailed. This was also the approach taken in the fruit and vegetable sector, where instruments such as minimum prices were abandoned. This process was accompanied by a policy of strengthening producer organisations (POs), with very unequal results in the different Member States, with the aim of empowering farmers to act in defence of their interests, for example by selling their production collectively or increasing added value through agricultural processing. The amendments we have tabled reflect the reality of the sector and the need for public policies to support producers and domestic production. Among other proposals, we highlight the inclusion of economic and social criteria to increase support for small and medium-sized agricultural production, preserving the rural environment; or the defence of local marketing and consumer networks that promote social and regional cohesion. We have also proposed the exclusion of agricultural products from the TTIP negotiations. We regret the rejection of these amendments by the majority. Despite this, and falling clearly short of what is needed, the report reflects some fair concerns, pointing out real problems and needs of the sector.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 A report by the European Commission and a study by the University of Wageningen presented to the European Parliament in January 2015 shows that the current fruit and vegetable scheme is too complex and lacks legal certainty. It is precisely the absence of legal certainty that is a significant obstacle to increasing the rate of producer organisation, since farmers who set up such an organisation may theoretically be invited to withdraw funding from the European Union if recognition of such an organisation is withdrawn or called into question. I therefore agree that the European Commission should step up its efforts to protect farmers from unfair trading practices in large chain stores and that the European Parliament should address this issue to a greater extent in the report prepared by IMCO in the coming weeks.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report for the fruit and vegetable sector, which represents 18% of the total value of agricultural production and uses only 3% of the cultivated area with a value of over 50 billion euros.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the fruit and vegetable sector from the 2007 reform to the present day, because the Union chooses to continue the policy that destroyed Greek production by subsidising the withdrawal of agricultural products, while at the same time its foreign policy is causing enormous damage that it is unwilling to repair.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Strengthening the position of Producers’ Organisations (POs) in the supply chain by creating incentives for mergers, associations and transnational cooperation is a very important action that we must support. Producers’ Organisations have become essential for EU agricultural policy and should be encouraged to develop at all levels, especially in the Member States where the number of organisations is still low. I believe that POs could be effective tools to combat unfair trading practices in the food chain ensuring better remuneration for the growers. The fruit and vegetable sector has been severely hit by the Russian ban on EU exports, and this will continue next year as Russia will extend the ban to 2016. I believe that the EU should continue all the support measures for this sector until the normal market situation is fully re-established.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report on the situation in the fruit and vegetables sector, in line with the direction of the European People's Party. The European Parliament supported the European Commission's re-setting of EU aid for investments in newly formed fruit and vegetable producer organisations. This is extremely important for Hungarian farmers and producer organisations. Without it, it is extremely difficult for the established organisers to obtain the state recognition necessary for its operation. It is therefore one of the most effective tools for improving producer organisations and increasing the level of organisation. It is also a major step forward that the report calls on the Commission to deal more effectively with crisis situations. On the one hand, it is necessary to improve the mechanism for withdrawal from the market and, on the other hand, to adjust intervention prices to real market prices and production costs.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report on the situation in the fruit and vegetables sector, in line with the direction of the European People's Party. The European Parliament supported my fellow Member Norbert Erdős's proposal for the European Commission to restore EU funding for investments in newly formed fruit and vegetable production organisations. This is extremely important for Hungarian farmers and producer organisations. Without it, it is extremely difficult for the established organisers to obtain the state recognition necessary for its operation. It is therefore one of the most effective tools for improving producer organisations and increasing the level of organisation. I am pleased that this explanation is reflected in the report. It is also a major step forward that the report calls on the Commission to deal more effectively with crisis situations. On the one hand, it is necessary to improve the mechanism for withdrawal from the market and, on the other hand, to adjust intervention prices to real market prices and production costs. This is in line with my fellow Member Norbert Erdős's opinion on market crisis management, which he has already voiced on numerous occasions in various forums of the European Parliament.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the state of the fruit and vegetable sector after the 2007 reform. The fruit and vegetable sector supplies European citizens with fresh and quality products, but in recent years it has been in a severe recession, as shown by the 6% decrease in the area under cultivation dedicated to it. Despite the importance of the sector for the health of its citizens and for the direct and indirect employment it guarantees, the EU continues to import, because production is insufficient, due to high costs and the Russian embargo has made the situation worse. Most producers are SMEs, unable to cope with the bargaining power of large-scale distribution and suffering from derisory profit margins. I therefore agree with the call to encourage producer organisations and associations of POs, including across borders. The rate of organization is still too low, with large differences between member states. They must be encouraged, as they increase the competitiveness and innovation of the sector, promote youth initiative and strengthen the negotiating power of producers. The call for policies to shorten the supply chain and promote direct sales to territories is also good, as is the call to create stable crisis management tools such as the Russian embargo.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform because I believe that it strikes a balance between the need for and the benefits of free markets on the one hand and the need to promote our medium-sized, partly rural producers in the fruit and vegetable sector.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report given I strongly support the measures it proposes to ensure efficient functioning of the fruit and vegetable sector, which is crucial for generating employment in agriculture as well as the food-processing sector across the EU, not in the least in the UK.  While the EU fruit and vegetable scheme is already highly valued by UK farmers, it is important we send a strong signal to the Commission in favour of implementing further simplification where possible. While I believe farmers should be compensated for losses they may suffer because of external factors, like the agrifood embargo that is currently hurting many that are active in the sector, I could however not give my support to the paragraph of the report that calls for crisis prevention and management measures to be financed outside of the CAP budgetary envelopes, given the CAP already provides adequate financial measures to deal with such emergencies.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting because, although the report includes some improvements to its initial version, the amendments proposed by the GUE/NGL Group, which qualitatively improved the report, were rejected in the AGRI Committee. These amendments included some aimed at implementing public policies to increase producer negotiating capacity, prevent falling consumption of fresh fruits and vegetables in the countries most affected by the crisis, promote a traditional diet based on seasonal vegetables and fruits, prevent the depopulation of large rural areas after the dismantling of a livestock farm, introduce socio-economic criteria or exclude agricultural products from TCA negotiations.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I have voted in favour of the report on the fruit and vegetables sector since the reform in 2007 because I believe that the Commission should take action to improve the functioning and attractiveness of producer organisations. Undoubtedly, the level of these organisations in the European Union varies, and in the new Member States, including my own country, Poland, they are less numerous and weaker than in the countries of the old Union. I believe that these organisations should focus instead on introducing solutions to increase competitiveness and adapt to the needs of consumers.  In the light of the crisis caused by the Russian embargo, which has resulted in the greatest loss of fruit and vegetable producers, it is necessary to simplify EU rules on aid to the sector and to improve the programme-related instruments for crisis prevention and management. The measures taken so far by the Commission have not covered the real losses of producers and it is therefore necessary to introduce new instruments. I supported this report because it calls on the Commission to re-analyse the funding rules in the area of crisis prevention and market management.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, alongside my fellow Labour MEPs, voted in favour of this report. The EU fruit and vegetable scheme is highly valued by UK farmers. However, as Labour MEPs we voted against paragraph 60: we believe that the CAP already provides sufficient financial measures to deal with crisis prevention and management.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text, which aims to present the evolution of the fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform, which has made it possible to provide producer organisations with a wider range of instruments to prevent and manage market crises. The report stresses, however, that the persistence of a lack or low degree of organisation in the fruit and vegetable sector in some Member States remains a major problem. It is therefore necessary to improve the management of producer organisations and to take the necessary measures to ensure a higher degree of organisation and representativeness of producer organisations across all Member States.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the fruit and vegetables sector following the 2007 reform. I believe that the priority of the fruit and vegetables sector regime should continue to be to increase the level of organisation throughout the Union. It is therefore necessary to strengthen incentives for the development and pooling of POOs and POOs. It is important to find ways to make your GO attractive. I believe that the first step towards making POs more attractive should be to reduce complexity and uncertainty. With this report, Parliament asks the Commission to step up its efforts to protect farmers from unfair trading practices by large retailers. It is unlikely that it would make sense to invest funds in the strengthening and development of POs – a slow and difficult process – if the bargaining power in the food supply chain remains concentrated mainly in the hands of retailers. Furthermore, given that many Member States have national measures to address such problems, certain coordination at Union level is necessary to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report on the situation in the fruit and vegetables sector as a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, in line with the direction of the European People's Party. The European Parliament supported my fellow Member Norbert Erdős's proposal for the European Commission to restore EU funding for investments in newly formed fruit and vegetable producer organisations. This is extremely important for Hungarian farmers and producer organisations. Without it, it is extremely difficult for the established organisers to obtain the state recognition necessary for its operation. It is therefore one of the most effective tools for improving producer organisations and increasing the level of organisation. It is also a major step forward that the report calls on the Commission to deal more effectively with crisis situations. On the one hand, it is necessary to improve the mechanism for withdrawal from the market and, on the other hand, to adjust intervention prices to real market prices and production costs.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the evolution of the fruit and vegetable sector since 2007. This reform helped strengthen the role of Producer Organisations and ‘the rate of organisations’ increased from 31% in 2004 to 43% in 2010. Total EU financial assistance has increased from €380 million per annum to €671 million in 2010. However there was a decline of 6% in the fruit and vegetable production in the EU with a long term decline in fruit and vegetable consumption. In order to reverse this decline I fully support the proposal that Producer Organisations be strengthened and that the Commission needs to intensify its efforts to protect farmers from unfair trading practices by large retailers. We must ensure that negotiating power is not strongly concentrated in the hands of the retailers.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report on the situation in the fruit and vegetables sector, in line with the direction of the European People's Party. The European Parliament supported my fellow Member Norbert Erdős's proposal for the European Commission to restore EU funding for investments in newly formed fruit and vegetable production organisations. This is extremely important for Hungarian farmers and producer organisations. Without it, it is extremely difficult for the established organisers to obtain the state recognition necessary for its operation. It is therefore one of the most effective tools for improving producer organisations and increasing the level of organisation. I am pleased that this explanation is reflected in the report. It is also a major step forward that the report calls on the Commission to deal more effectively with crisis situations. On the one hand, it is necessary to improve the mechanism for withdrawal from the market and, on the other hand, to adjust intervention prices to real market prices and production costs. This is in line with my fellow Member Norbert Erdős's opinion on market crisis management, which he has already voiced on numerous occasions in various forums of the European Parliament.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report highlights many issues of importance to the fruit and vegetable sector. Today’s vote is timely given that 2015 is Scotland’s Year of Food and Drink, and I would encourage colleagues to take the opportunity to explore Scotland’s wonderful fruit and vegetables.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting because, although the report includes some improvements to its initial version, the amendments proposed by the GUE/NGL Group, which qualitatively improved the report, were rejected in the AGRI Committee. These amendments included some aimed at implementing public policies to increase producer negotiating capacity, prevent falling consumption of fresh fruits and vegetables in the countries most affected by the crisis, promote a traditional diet based on seasonal vegetables and fruits, prevent the depopulation of large rural areas after the dismantling of a livestock farm, introduce socio-economic criteria or exclude agricultural products from TCA negotiations.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which considers that, under the fruit and vegetable sector regime, promoting the degree of organisation should remain an EU-wide priority and proposes strengthening incentives for the establishment of producer organisations and producer organisation associations and promoting mergers between them.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the fruit and vegetables sector since the 2007 reform. (2014/2147 (INI)), as the 2007 reform aimed to strengthen producer organisations in the fruit and vegetable production sector and, inter alia, to make available a wider range of instruments to enable market risk prevention and management, then to improve and target supply, improve quality and competitiveness, adapt supply to market needs and provide technical support for environmentally friendly production.  The report provides a balanced picture of the development of the fruit and vegetables regime since the 2007 reform, which confirms the validity of the core organisational structure for the sector and identifies areas where progress has been made. On the other hand, it is necessary to call on the Commission to make greater efforts to address UTPs in the food supply chain that adversely affect producer income, lower revenues and threaten the viability and sustainability of the sector. It also stresses the importance of maintaining European quality standards for fresh fruit and vegetable products in order to always guarantee high quality and for the benefit of the final consumer; deplores the fact that in certain Member States the degree of organisation in producer organisations is extremely low and recommends that Member States prioritise perseverance in promoting producer associations.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote for this report on the implementation of the provisions on producer organisations, operational funds and operational programmes in the fruit and vegetable sector, which has been in force since the 2007 reform.  Indeed, the economic crisis has been particularly difficult to negotiate for this agricultural sector, especially since it is almost exclusively composed of small and medium-sized enterprises. Nevertheless, it is far from negligible, generating a turnover of 120 billion euros per year. However, due to the decline in the area under cultivation and therefore production, consumption has fallen sharply, especially among the youngest, increasing the risk of obesity even more. Finally, the EU's foreign policy has resulted in the Russian embargo, not facilitating the activity of producers.  It is essential to help this sector, and this text is a step in the right direction, although it does not refer to unfair competition from third countries.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Nuno Melo's report on the fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform. The 2007 reform of the sector allows for greater protection for fruit and vegetable producers by allowing them to partner in producer organisations. These organizations allow producers to better structure themselves and increase their production and thus better defend themselves during negotiations.  The report calls on the Commission to redouble its efforts to combat the unfair practices of large retailers and calls for better coordination between Member States for a better functioning of the internal market. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I have voted in favour of the resolution on the fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform. Given the importance of the fruit and vegetable sector in the European Union in terms of employment, value added and health, it is essential to strengthen the role of producer organisations and inter-professionals, as well as to ensure the specificity of the fruit and vegetable sector.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the fruit and vegetables sector, we have seen the empowerment of producer organisations in recent years, which enable farmers to obtain better prices for their products, as well as to make effective use of EU support and effectively protect their own interests. This is particularly important today, especially today, when the turmoil in the sector is often due to reasons beyond the control of farmers, such as the 2011 E. coli epidemic or the current Russian embargo. Moreover, we are increasingly hearing about the use of UTPs by large retailers. It is therefore necessary to strengthen initiatives supporting the creation of producer organisations, to finance projects to improve the professional qualifications of their employees and to put in place mechanisms that guarantee fair competition in the sector. I would also like to draw attention to another important point, namely the use of crisis prevention instruments. As the rapporteur confirms, these tools have so far been used to a very small extent. Meanwhile, the fruit and vegetables sector often faces sudden problems requiring immediate intervention. Exceptional support mechanisms must therefore be available in order to ensure the stabilisation of the sector and to allow for rapid compensation for losses incurred by farmers.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Although the report contains some critical aspects such as price support, overall it describes a good picture of the strengths, weaknesses and future of the European fruit and vegetable economy. That is why I am voting in favour of the report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The current fruit and vegetables regime is too complex and unfortunately does not provide legal certainty. I therefore believe that the first step towards making producer organisations more attractive should be to simplify the scheme and remove legal uncertainty, which is why I voted in favour of the draft report. The fruit and vegetable sector accounts for 0.98% of the total arable land area of the Czech Republic and is experiencing a steady slight decline, which needs to be changed. The association of the producer sphere in the Czech Republic, which can be dated to 1998, when the first sales cooperative with the territorial scope of the whole republic was founded, showed the possibility of improving its position on the market. During the period of the Czech Republic's accession to the EU, the organisation of the sector was about 20%, in 2007 it was already 28.5%. Currently, organizing is almost 40%. The areas of fertile orchards and market vegetables included in producer organisations and producer groups in the Czech Republic currently total 9 638 ha (a 27.2% increase compared to 2007) and represent a total of 25.2 thousand hectares. This is therefore an important issue and I hope that this draft report is a step forward.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report on the situation in the fruit and vegetables sector, in line with the direction of the European People's Party. The European Parliament supported my fellow Member Norbert Erdős's proposal for the European Commission to restore EU funding for investments in newly formed fruit and vegetable production organisations. This is extremely important for Hungarian farmers and producer organisations. Without it, it is extremely difficult for the established organisers to obtain the state recognition necessary for its operation. It is therefore one of the most effective tools for improving producer organisations and increasing the level of organisation. I am pleased that this explanation is reflected in the report. It is also a major step forward that the report calls on the Commission to deal more effectively with crisis situations. On the one hand, it is necessary to improve the mechanism for withdrawal from the market and, on the other hand, to adjust intervention prices to real market prices and production costs. This is in line with my fellow Member Norbert Erdős's opinion on market crisis management, which he has already voiced on numerous occasions in various forums of the European Parliament.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of Mr Melo's proposal on fruit and vegetables after the 2007 reform. I believe that it is of fundamental importance to support the fruit and vegetable sector throughout the Union, given the importance it has both in terms of added value and employment and in terms of health, being the main component of the Mediterranean diet. The proposal urges the Commission to strengthen the existing aid scheme for the distribution of fruit, vegetables and milk in schools, given the importance of promoting healthy and balanced eating from an early age, while bringing young consumers closer to local producers.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is a step in the right direction, although we may regret that it does not make sufficient reference to unfair competition from third countries in terms of employment (use of illegal labour, but no longer any reference to wage differences within the Union), nor to differences in regulations related to plant health standards. Amendments have been proposed by our group to address these shortcomings. I vote in favour, because there is a desire to help this sector in crisis and because the local sectors, therefore national, are supported and privileged (point AE).

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it aims to help the fruit and vegetable sector, on the one hand, by supporting good food practices among young children in schools and, on the other hand, by strengthening producer organisations.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for it. The text aims to help this sector for an economic purpose through the support and development of producer organisations, but also for educational and health reasons, by supporting good food practices among young children in schools. The 2007 fruit and vegetable sector reform aimed to improve competitiveness by strengthening fruit and vegetable producer organisations. The sector is experiencing a decline in production which results in an increase in imports, in a difficult context due to the consequences of the Russian embargo, but also unfair competition from third countries (tariff barriers...). This text is a step in the right direction, although we may regret that it does not make sufficient reference to unfair competition from third countries in terms of employment, nor to differences in regulations related to plant health standards.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The motion for a Resolution is a first position of the EP in the face of the next reform of the sector. The starting point is to confirm the validity of the basic organizational structure of this sector around producer organisations, their market orientation and the improvement of the quality and environmental aspects of production, carried out through operational programmes. However, it identifies improvements to the current instruments of this regime that should correct the next reform. In accordance with these considerations, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although some improvement was made in relation to the original document, I have decided to abstain in my final vote. This is because the report does not reflect the need for public policies to support the bargaining capacity of medium and small farms, the fall in fruit and vegetable consumption in countries with austerity policies that lead to the adoption by families of an unhealthy diet, the promotion of traditional diets based on seasonal vegetables and fruits , the limited use of funds by producer organisations, the closure of farms leading to the desertification of large areas of land, the inclusion of social and economic value criteria for small and medium-sized enterprises farms to preserve the rural environment, as well as the exclusion of agricultural products from TTE negotiations and the defence of the marketing and consumption of local networks that promote social cohesion and Regional.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. Since the 2007 reform, the fruit and vegetable sector has undergone positive change, both economically and in the image, especially because of the added value it enjoys and that society is increasingly taking into account, which is to lead a healthy life on a varied diet, respecting the environment and opening up new markets. Large distribution chains continue to put pressure on producer orgtanizations, a detrimental factor for such jobs. I vote in favour of the decisions taken, as producer organisations are considered to be a great tool at the service of the producers themselves so that they can organize themselves on the market in a natural way and be able to defend their interests freely. The European Union should support producer organisations as they also manage the particularities of each State; supporting them would also prevent the abandonment of land and help the employment of young labour, guaranteeing the future of the profession. Such measures maintain quality standards in the sector and also improve competitiveness and efficiency.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The agricultural sector must be developed in accordance with national strategies and protected from different political influences. For example, Russian sanctions and the ban on fruit imports have left significant consequences for the European Union, including the Republic of Croatia, which has suffered direct damage.  I support The Resolution of Nuno Mela, which proposes detailed measures to support the whole agricultural sector, taking into account education on agricultural products in order to encourage healthier eating habits and consumption of fruits and vegetables, and to create a youth employment plan in the agricultural sector, strengthen import control regimes and better negotiate with third countries.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. The agricultural sector needs reforms and new forms of support in the EU. I voted for it.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the report on the fruit and vegetables sector after the 2007 reform to date for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 6/7/2015.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text, which promotes, among other things, the local French sectors of the fruit and vegetable sector. This report follows the 2007 reform of the fruit and vegetable sector, which aimed to make the sector more competitive. Indeed, this text aims to revitalise this sector through educational, health and economic actions, including support to producer organisations, with the ultimate aim of boosting the consumption of fruits and vegetables. This positive vote should not make us forget that this text makes little mention of unfair competition from exporting countries.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the fruit and vegetable report after the 2007 reform. Fruit and vegetables are a key compartment for the European Union, not only in terms of turnover but also in terms of employment. The report stresses the need to strengthen incentives to encourage the creation of POs - producer organisations and AOP - associations of producer organisations, in order to make them more competitive and to promote the agricultural market sector.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report signed by Mr Melo, as I believe that the Union's policy in favour of the creation and development of POs has achieved considerable results in recent years. In particular, I welcomed the reference in the document to the need to strengthen incentives to encourage the ever-increasing development of the fruit and vegetable sector.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The increase in the creation of producer organisations has been one of the greatest successes of Community agricultural policy in recent years. In particular, in the fruit and vegetable sector, promoting the degree of organisation must remain an EU-wide priority and we must create incentives to create new entities and foster mergers between existing ones.  My support for the report on the fruit and vegetable sector following the 2007 reform therefore stresses the importance of paying particular attention to improving the management of producer organisations.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The strengthening of agriculture is to be welcomed and I therefore supported the proposal. The proposed changes will improve sales figures for vegetable and fruit growers and compensate for Russia's failure as a trading partner.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform recognises that this reform has strengthened the market presence of producer organisations and highlights areas where improvements are needed.

name: Anthea McIntyre (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The Report’s welcome emphasis on measures intended to increase the market orientation of fruit and vegetable growers is important. There is also a strong focus on research and innovation in POs to boost product value. Conservative MEPs have always called for POs to be given the flexibility to adapt their Operational Programmes to suit their level of maturity, and to target their funds on a broader range of measures aimed at increasing the sector’s competitiveness. To be attractive, we need a scheme that is more effective and more adaptive to market conditions. The Report’s concentration on these measures is highly relevant to the sustainable growth of the fruit and vegetable sector. They represent more achievable aims for the PO Scheme and would give fruit and vegetable growers a better chance of adapting to market volatility.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In a process of regulatory reduction, the Common Agricultural Policy has introduced the "fruit and vegetable" regime, which abandons certain measures protecting farmers (minimum price fixing). This process has been linked to a policy to strengthen producer organizations (OPs), to enable farmers to defend their interests, by selling their products collectively or by adding value through on-farm processing.  This disengagement of the public forces leaves all the power in the market to guide production, resulting in a 6% decrease in the share of the area cultivated in fruits and vegetables and a 39% decrease in the number of farms between 2003 and 2010.  The report details the shortcomings of this system, but does not propose a different model based on ecological planning. I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The economic crisis has been particularly difficult for this agricultural sector, especially since it is largely made up of small and medium-sized enterprises. Nevertheless, it is far from negligible, generating a turnover of 120 billion euros per year. However, due to the decline in the area under cultivation and therefore production, consumption has fallen sharply, especially among the youngest, increasing the risk of obesity even more. Finally, the EU's foreign policy has resulted in the Russian embargo, not facilitating the activity of producers.  It is essential to help this sector, and this text is a step in the right direction, although it does not refer to unfair competition from third countries.  I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The report on the application of provisions on producer organisations, operational funds and operational programmes in the fruit and vegetables sector since the 2007 reform has been adopted with 598 votes in favour, 53 against and 41 abstentions. The own-initiative report calls for the simplification of the fruit and vegetables scheme, improved management of producer organisations, increased the overall level of support for these organisations and better use of crisis prevention and management tools to help farmers protect themselves against large falls in incomes. I believe that increasing the organisational rate should remain a priority for the fruit and vegetables scheme. It is also important to provide producer organisations with funds to hire capable managers, continue to support all sectors suffering the consequences of the Russian embargo, step up efforts to protect farmers from the unfair commercial practices of large retailers and to grow agriculture generationally.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree that the EU must do more to help farmers to earn a fair return from the food supply chain, introduce better tools for dealing with market disturbances and help farmers to find new outlets for produce shut out of the Russian market. Therefore, with a few reservations, I voted in favour of the draft report on the fruit and vegetables sector since the 2007 reform. The Russian ban on EU exports has seriously affected many European fruit and vegetable producers and has even worsened market crisis situations such as that experienced by the stone fruits sector, and the report asks that in such circumstances Community support measures be kept in place for as long as necessary until the normal market situation is fully re-established.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The CAP is a particular slice of EU policy that requires specific knowledge and preparedness. I have unreserved confidence in the competence of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development in this way, and I voted on this basis.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report on the fruit and vegetables (PHF) scheme identifies a decline in PHF consumption in the Union, aggravated by the economic crisis. At the same time, the Union has a trade deficit in PHF, in particular in fruit. In order to respond to the liberalisation of the Common Agricultural Policy, the Union has implemented measures for the establishment and strengthening of Producer Organisations (POs) and Associations of Producer Organisations (AOP).  The number of POs and AOP is quite skyrocketing among Member States, so this document calls for more incentives from the Commission. Reducing complexity and legal uncertainty are other elements that will make POs and POs more appealing, as well as the creation of more funds and operational programmes for investment in human capital, for the management, promotion, marketing and internationalisation of POs. This effort should be coordinated at Union level and not lead to national protectionist measures.  For the reasons described above, I am in favour of the adoption of this own-initiative report.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to provide support to the fruit and vegetable sector for an economic purpose, by developing producer organisations, but also by supporting a certain food education, through good food practices, especially in schools. Indeed, the 2007 sector reform aimed to improve competitiveness by strengthening fruit and vegetable producer organisations to deal with possible crises in the sector. This sector employs more than 550,000 people, mostly smallholders. Although this text contains many omissions regarding the decline in production, in particular on the responsibility of unfair competition from third countries (detached and/or illegal workers...)  or on sanctions against Russia (whose cost remains enormous for fruit and vegetable producers), this text remains to be welcomed as it supports local and national sectors. So I voted for it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report to give support for good organisation and efficient functioning of this important sector of the rural economy, generating employment not only in agriculture but particularly in the food-processing sector. The EU fruit and vegetable scheme is highly valued among UK farmers and deemed largely efficient. It is, however, important to send a strong signal to the Commission in favour of further simplification of the scheme. At the same time, I support the development of POs as a way of increasing the bargaining power of fruit and vegetable farmers and managing market risks. The report’s provisions advocating shorter supply chains and the development of local markets for direct sales should also be strongly supported. I voted against paragraph 60 of the report, calling for the crisis prevention and management measures to be financed outside of the CAP budgetary envelopes. Whereas Labour recognises the fairness of compensating farmers for losses they may suffer because of factors that remain out of their control (such as the Russian agrifood embargo), the CAP already provides adequate financial measures to deal with such emergencies.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the fruit and vegetable sector. This text recalls that the 2007 reform helped to ensure the specificity of this agricultural sector and to strengthen the role of producer organisations and inter-professionals. I am in favour of these measures, because they support this sector, which provides jobs and added value throughout the European Union. It is also important to encourage the consumption of fruits and vegetables, as they contribute to healthy and balanced diets. In the European Union, 22 million children are overweight, while adolescents consume on average only 30-50% of the recommended daily serving of fruit and vegetables.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Melo report on the fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform. Over the past 20 years, the Common Agricultural Policy has reduced the scope of its regulation with regard to agricultural markets, which has allowed market forces to direct their production. This report aims to ensure the specificity of the fruit and vegetable sector as well as to strengthen the role of producer organisations and inter-professionals. Fruits and vegetables are mostly perishable products, which puts farmers in a particularly vulnerable trading position when market conditions are unfavourable. Efforts must be redoubled to protect farmers from unfair trade practices, which implies some coordination at EU level in order to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of this draft resolution, given that the increase in the rate of organisation in almost all Member States in recent years indicates that the Union's policy in favour of the creation and development of producer organisations (POs) has achieved results and requires that this path be continued without hesitation. Therefore, we believe it is necessary to strengthen incentives to encourage the creation of POs and ASSOCIATIONS of POs and mergers between them. It is also important to find ways to improve the attractiveness of membership of a producer organisation. Disincentives to the creation of POs have been found to be the excessive complexity and lack of legal certainty that characterise the current arrangements applicable to fruit and vegetables.  The lack of legal certainty is a significant obstacle to the increase in the rate of organisation, since farmers who form a PO, if recognition of the op is subsequently cancelled or challenged, could in theory be asked to return EU funding out of their own pocket. It is therefore essential, as a first step, to proceed without delay to reduce the complexity and uncertainty in order to increase the attractiveness of these organisations.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2007 reform of the fruit and vegetable scheme strengthened and expanded the role of producer organisations (POs) and producer organisations' associations (AOP). The report considers that the increase in the rate of organisation in almost all Member States in recent years shows that the Union's policy in favour of the creation and development of POs has been satisfactory. Finally, the report considers that increasing the rate of organisation throughout the Union should remain a priority for the 'fruit and vegetables' scheme. I have therefore decided to vote in favour of this report because I believe it is essential to strengthen the incentives to encourage the creation of POs and AOP and mergers between them.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this report on the fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform to strengthen policies, the role of producer organisations and associations of producer organisations.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ An sprioc atá leis an tuarascáil féintionscnaimh seo ná spreagadh a thabhairt don Choimisiún togra reachtach a chur chun tosaigh ag díriú ar athbhreithniú ar an scéim chúnaimh don earnáil torthaí agus glasraí.  Bhí cúpla rud fadhbach sa tuarascáil áfach, go háirithe Aithris AE., Mír 63 agus Mír 71, a chuir fáilte roimh an scéim bhainne agus torthaí do scoileanna agus an bholscaireacht a tháinig leis a dúirt go mbeidh sé buntáisteach don earnáil torthaí agus glasraí. Bhí mo comhghleacaí mar scáthrapóirtéir ar an tuarascáil seo agus chuir seisean béim ar an tslí nár chóir cistí AE a chaitheamh ar fhógraíocht bunaithe ar an mbaint atá ag AE leis an scéim ach ina áit sin gur cheart fógraíocht a dhéanamh ar chur chun cinn bia shláintiúil. É sin ráite, bhí neart rudaí dearfacha ann; Mír 51 go háirithe, a d’iarr ar thíortha eile cloí le caighdeán AE maidir leis an timpeallacht, le gnéithe sóisialta, le sláinte, le sábháilteacht bia agus le leas ainmhithe má tá siad ag iarraidh easpórtáil a dhéanamh chuig AE.  Mar gheall ar na cúiseanna thuasluaite, staon mé ón vótáil.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this own-initiative report because it looks objectively at both the Commission's report on the state of the fruit and vegetables sector and the reality on the European market. It is very important that the Commission's report has brought to the fore improvements to the fruit and vegetable market, but at the same time it is very important that this own-initiative report underlines the shortcomings of reforms so far, such as unfair competition and pressure on small producers. At the same time, it is important that at European level there has been an attempt, and this report is also calling for, to increase the promotion of the association between producers so that they, under this legal status, are better organised, stronger and better protected.  However, the reality in countries such as Romania shows that there is still much work to be done in this area, that corruption in the field and unfair competition must be combated. Without this, many EU markets, including Romania, will not have a competitive market in which producers get the profits they deserve. This is underlined by the European Parliament's report and, for this reason, we supported it today by vote.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This report calls for price support, especially for new builders. It also calls for the distribution of free fruit (linked to many conditions) to public institutions. Another point is the development of new exporting countries. Overall, the report contains good approaches to support fruit and vegetable farmers, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The report points to a number of shortcomings in the fruit and vegetables sector that need to be addressed, including low levels of organisation in several Member States and the need to improve the means of crisis prevention and management.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the light of what has been learned, and considering that the crisis caused by the Russian embargo has had and will also have a significant negative impact on the fruit and vegetable sector in the future and that producers have suffered the greatest losses; that the importance of strong POs, organised in such a way as to be able to deal together with unexpected and adverse situations, with the support of appropriate instruments adapted to the seriousness of each crisis, should be underlined, I express my support for this motion for a resolution.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With this resolution, we welcome the Commission's report outlining the development of the regulation of the fruit and vegetables sector following the 2007 reform. I voted in favour of the resolution because it encourages producers to join producer organisations and associations with a view to increasing their bargaining power, strengthening their position in the food supply chain and thus increasing their revenues. It is also important to achieve an increase in competitiveness, which could be achieved by eliminating red tape, improving aid to organisations and introducing better mechanisms for managing crisis periods. I support efforts to eliminate unfair trading practices in the food supply chain, to help them to appear in new markets and, last but not least, to promote activities that contribute to the consumption of more fruit and vegetables.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The fruit and vegetables sector has found itself facing major challenges due to the decrease in production volumes, recently pressed by the Russian embargo, and needs to be encouraged. Manufacturers of this sector face various obstacles, so I see this resolution as a significant incentive to strengthen their competitiveness and strike a balance in the food supply chain.  Encouraging farmers to join producer organisations is a significant new possibility, especially for Croatian farmers, opening markets to small producers who have weaker bargaining power and are more exposed to risks associated with large markets. Unfortunately, we in Croatia lack a national programme under which our producer organisations could use eu money, so I call on the Ministry of Agriculture to develop it. I believe that producer organisations are useful for the protection of small farmers and enable them to be safe and demand-enhancing. Various operational programmes and clear objectives aim to strengthen the commercial value of products and stabilise producer prices.  I also emphasise the importance of implementing the Fruit and Vegetable Delivery Programme to educational institutions through which small, local producers can supply fresh fruit and vegetables to schools. Well-functioning producer organisations can play an important role in attracting an increasing number of younger populations through agricultural activities, which contributes positively to the demographic picture of this sector, but also to rural space in general.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to provide support to the fruit and vegetable sector for an economic purpose, by developing producer organisations, but also by supporting a certain food education, through good food practices, especially in schools. The sector reform in 2007 had already set itself the objective of improving competitiveness by strengthening fruit and vegetable producer organisations to deal with possible crises in the sector. The sector employs more than 550,000 people, most of them smallholders.  Even if the text conveniently forgets important factors of the decline in production, in particular the responsibility of unfair competition from third countries (detached and/or illegal workers...) or sanctions against Russia (whose cost is very high for fruit and vegetable producers), it remains to be welcomed, since it supports local and national sectors. So I still voted for it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Common Agricultural Policy going back the last 20 years has focused its efforts on deregulating agricultural markets, allowing market forces to target production. This general approach has been specifically applied to the fruit and vegetables sector, where instruments such as reimbursement for exports or setting minimum prices that processors are forced to pay farmers for certain products are abandoned.   2007 Fruit and Vegetable Reform  has just reaffirmed the union's position on strengthening the role of producers and producer associations. By 2010, trends at EU level regarding the organisational level of the fruit and vegetables sector were positive, as was the overall proportion of fruit and vegetable producers registered producers or members of the association. However, the rise in trends has been stagnant ever since. The current disproportion in the levels of organisation within the fruit and vegetables sector between member states, I agree, should be attributed to differences in start-up positions when starting the 2007 reform, rather than the failure of the Member States themsies themses to implement reforms.   I am of the opinion that working to grow mergers and organisation within the fruit and vegetables sector remains an EU imperative, especially since by jointly stepping forward on the market, fragmented growers such as those in Croatia have a better chance of making quality progress on the EU market, despite the decline in production in the last year.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The contribution of producer organisations (POS) in the fruit and vegetables sector has been highlighted in various parts of EU legislation. The Reform of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) in 2007 adopted a new set of tools aimed at strengthening their role in the fruit and vegetables sector. For the first time, POS was able to receive EU support in the form of contributions to finance its operational programmes. EU financial assistance to the POS is limited to 50% of the total operating fund, but in specific cases it can be increased to 60%. Member States had to put in place national strategies for sustainable operational programmes, in which the role of purchase orders was further underlined. The EP is obliged to adopt a report aimed at encouraging the Commission to present a legal proposal aimed at revising the fruit and vegetables assistance programme.  I welcome various regime measures for the fruit and vegetables sector, but also addressing shortcomings and inconsistencies, such as tackling unfair trading practices, the lack of clarification of purchase order rules and the need to reduce complex procedures. Consequently, I support the proposal.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 2007 reform of the fruit and vegetables scheme confirmed and extended the policy of strengthening the role of producer organisations and associations of producer organisations. This is particularly important in the fruit and vegetables sector, where the Union has essentially left a free hand to the market. EU financial support to producer organisations is capped at 4.1% of the value of marketed production. The share of the total value of fruit and vegetable production marketed by producer organisations increased to 43 % in 2010, but there are still large differences between Member States in the level of producer organisation and fruit and vegetable producers still show a very weak position in the distribution chain in a number of countries. Nevertheless, like the rapporteur, I believe that the increase in the level of organisation of producers so far shows that the EU's policy of promoting the creation and development of producer organisations has been a success. Further improvements in this area should continue to be one of the EU's priorities for the fruit and vegetables regime. For this reason, I support the strengthening of incentives to create and merge producer organisations and associations of producer organisations. It is important to find a way to make membership of these organisations more attractive; the first step towards this should be to simplify the scheme and improve the management of producer organisations.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this own-initiative report, which is the counterpart to the European Commission's report on the implementation of the provisions on producer organisations, operating funds and operational programmes in the fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform. I very much hope that the European Union's policy in this area will focus on strengthening the role of producer organisations (POs), in order to stimulate competitiveness, increase productivity and encourage practices that are more respectful of the European environment and agricultural heritage.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In 2007, the reform of the fruit and vegetable regime helped to gradually liberalise the sector, which until now has been heavily protected under the CAP. The European Parliament adopted the report providing an overview of the developments and developments in the fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform. I voted in favour of this text and I am satisfied with the guidelines of the report aimed in particular at ensuring the specificity of this sector and strengthening the role of producer organisations and inter-professionals. The latter is strategic, as these organizations provide farmers with the means to act to defend their interests.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission presented in March 2014 a report on the implementation of the new standards of the Fruit and Vegetables (PHF) scheme, with a view to identifying progress made, while at the same time highlighting existing problems. The FPH rules establish a fundamental vector for the creation and development of producer organisations (POs) in order to be able to ensure production programming and promote the concentration of supply and the placing on the market of products.  In the current context, the rapporteur recalls that the ongoing PHF regime is too complex and lacks the legal certainty necessary to strengthen integration into po. In this sense, and according to the rapporteur's opinion, the resolution of the problem involves reducing the complexity of the existing regime. The rapporteur considers that, although operational programmes constitute a modest leverage of the negotiating power of POs in the distribution chain, the latter remains highly concentrated in the hands of retailers. The obvious solution recommended is to strengthen cap support for the sector, which translates into an improvement in the 'human capital' of POs and, consequently, a better supply of fruit and vegetables.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. This report analyses the situation in the fruit and vegetables sector since the 2007 reform and makes progress with a number of recommendations to improve the current scheme and protect farmers. I support the simplification of the PHF scheme, the improvement of the management of producer organisations, the increase in the overall level of support for these organisations and better use of crisis prevention and management tools in order to help farmers protect themselves against large falls in incomes. I welcome the adoption of this report, which also underlines the need to step up efforts to protect farmers against the unfair commercial practices of large retailers.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Everyone knows the importance of "eat 5 fruits and vegetables a day" health advice. Unfortunately, this action is not followed in the light of statistics, since adolescents consume on average only 30-50% of the recommended daily serving of fruits and vegetables, while 22 million children are overweight in the European Union.  This lack of fruit and vegetable consumption can be the cause of many chronic diseases. It also directly represents a problem for the fruit and vegetable sectors, with a loss of production in recent years, exacerbated by the economic crisis marked by an increase in the consumption of processed foods and the Russian embargo on many products: apples and pears, as is the case in Belgium. Hence the importance of the clear message of support for the European fruit and vegetable sector delivered this lunchtime. The European Union must redouble its efforts to ensure the viability and sustainability of the sector. The goal of a fair income for farmers cannot be achieved without effective action against unfair trade practices in the food supply chain and policies geared towards greater protection and better opportunities for producers.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Portugal being a country rich in diversity and quality of fruits and vegetables, I welcome the proposal to simplify the regime of this sector, through the improvement of the management of producer organizations, the increase in the level of support to these organizations and a more effective use of crisis prevention and management instruments in order to safeguard producers from sharp declines in their incomes.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 the Commission published a report last year on the implementation of the fruit and vegetable reform, agreed in 2007, containing some valid analyses such as the persistent diversity between Member States, the degree of organisation of the sector and the limited bargaining power of producers in the value chain. In view of Commissioner Hogan's commitment to simplify the fruit and vegetable regime during his term of office, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution as Parliament's first position on the next reform. The reform must confirm the validity of the organizational basic structure of this sector around producer organisations, their market orientation and the improvement of the quality and environmental aspects of production, carried out through operational programmes.  In addition, European legislation on the recognition of producer organisations, the audit of operational programmes and the measures taken in each Member State should be simplified; improve crisis management tools that have become ineffid in large cases such as the Russian veto; encourage the creation of producer organizations, and combat unfair practices in the value chain, among other issues.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I have voted in favour of the report on the fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform for several reasons, Firstly, in order to ask the Commission to set clear European standards to combat unfair practices and pressure from mass-market producers and their incomes, and secondly to call for an increase in aid to producer organisations and the restoration of EU investment aid newly created organizations.  Through my vote in favour of this report, I also call on the Commission to set up a mechanism for withdrawing products in the event of a crisis in order to prevent fruit and vegetable producers from serious losses. Finally, with this report, I urge the Commission to strengthen schemes to help distribute fruit, vegetables and milk in schools. This is how young people will be encouraged to eat a healthy and balanced diet.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report is the result of the European Parliament's assessment of the Commission's report on the implementation of the fruit and vegetables policy since the 2007 reform. EU policy for this sector has strengthened the role of producer organisations (POs) in order to boost competitiveness, increase productivity, support research and innovation, improve promotion and marketing, prevent and manage market crises, improve producers' position in the agri-food chain and encourage environmentally friendly practices. I agree with the rapporteur on the need to simplify the fruit and vegetables regime, to improve the management of producer organisations, to increase the overall level of support for these organisations, to make better use of crisis prevention and management tools, to help farmers protect themselves against large and abrupt declines in their incomes , and the need for the Commission to step up its efforts to combat unfair commercial practices by large retailers. For all that is exposed, I have given my vote in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which stresses the need for a specific policy adapted to the fruit and vegetable sector, with particular emphasis on the essential role of producer organisations and inter-professionals.  The tools of the Common Agricultural Policy represent an opportunity to strengthen the weight of producer organisations and inter-professionals, particularly in trade negotiations. These tools are underutilized and we need to reaffirm the role and place of producer organisations and inter-professionals in Europe.  The report also stresses the need to increase the competitiveness of producer organisations and to combat unfair competition.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report presented by Mr De Clercq on behalf of the Committee on The Melo and discussed in the AGRI Committee is the study of the fruit and vegetable sector after the 2007 reform. The data collected showed that the reform adopted confirmed and expanded the policy of strengthening the role of producer organisations (POs) and producer organisations' associations (AOP), the EU's policy in favour of the creation and development of POs has therefore achieved positive results that need further incentives, which is why I have decided to vote in favour of the report.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the report contains a number of references to the Commission aimed at increasing the aggregation of producers and removing the main obstacles (many of them buocratic) to the management of producer organisations.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting because, although the report includes some improvements to its initial version, the amendments proposed by the GUE/NGL Group, which qualitatively improved the report, were rejected in the AGRI Committee. These amendments included some aimed at implementing public policies to increase producer negotiating capacity, prevent falling consumption of fresh fruits and vegetables in the countries most affected by the crisis, promote a traditional diet based on seasonal vegetables and fruits, prevent the depopulation of large rural areas after the dismantling of a livestock farm, introduce socio-economic criteria or exclude agricultural products from TCA negotiations.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the Melo report on the fruit and vegetables sector, because it is a balanced report, which illustrates its situation very well. Unfortunately, both the amount of fruit and vegetables produced in the Union and the area under cultivation have decreased in recent years. The Russian embargo had a significant impact on the fruit and vegetable market and severely affected consumer incomes. These losses must be properly rewarded by the Commission. I want to stress the importance of supporting short supply chains in this sector, because it ensures the freshness and quality of fruit and, at the same time, helps local producers. I believe that small producers need more support for the marketing of fruit and vegetables and, in particular, for access to supermarkets, and I hope that, in the future, the Commission will pay more attention to this type of producer. I am pleased that the level of organisation in the sector is at an upward pace and I hope that it will be kept that way in the years to come.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although some improvement was made in relation to the original document, I have decided to abstain in my final vote. This is because the report does not reflect the need for public policies to support the bargaining capacity of medium and small farms, the fall in fruit and vegetable consumption in countries with austerity policies that lead to the adoption by families of an unhealthy diet, the promotion of traditional diets based on seasonal vegetables and fruits , the limited use of funds by producer organisations, the closure of farms leading to the desertification of large areas of land, the inclusion of social and economic value criteria for small and medium-sized enterprises farms to preserve the rural environment, as well as the exclusion of agricultural products from TTE negotiations and the defence of the marketing and consumption of local networks that promote social cohesion and Regional.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Parliament's own-initiative proposal calling for the implementing provisions concerning operational programmes, funds and producer organisations in the fruit and vegetable sector after the 2007 reform. The report proposes to strengthen the role of producer organisations in the fruit and vegetable sector in order to increase productivity, support research and innovation, prevent and manage market crises. In order to achieve these objectives, I believe it is necessary to simplify the rules governing the functioning of these organisations, which play a leading role in the food supply chain in our territories.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is essential to organize production in the fruit and vegetable sector, to improve the negotiating position of producers in the face of distribution and to integrate the process of adding value to products. This is particularly relevant in a context where the market is becoming less regulated and more exposed to crises caused by prices or diseases and pests.
