European incentives should be consistent with the aim of promoting producer organisations (POs) and PO associations, thereby strengthening the role of producers, who often find themselves in less favourable situations because of the need to rapidly drain their products, which are highly perishable. I support this report which is a good one for these issues.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 We adopted a report entitled 'Fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform', which analysed the reform of the FRUIT AND VEGETABLE market in the EU in 2007, which introduced significant market-based measures and provided for a support system for producer groups and producer organisations to strengthen the position of fruit and vegetable producers. The Melo report points to significant shortcomings in this area and suggests solutions for the future, perhaps the most important of which is to ensure that producers have a greater share of the processing of their products, i.e. that they make greater use of the added value that arises in the field-to-table chain.  Vegetables and fruits are an important component of any diet, but their consumption is still too low in Europe.  The production of fruit and vegetables is largely carried out on smaller farms and requires a lot of work, which gives many people the opportunity to work. Fruit and vegetables are a particularly significant item in both EU and Polish exports. In the context of this sector, the situation with regard to the Russian embargo, which has recently been extended for another year, is particularly important. Therefore, together with other Members of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, we have in recent days sent a letter to Agriculture Commissioner Phil Hogan calling for an extension of support mechanisms for producers affected by the embargo.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which looks into implementation of the provisions concerning producer organisations, operational funds and operational programmes in the fruit and vegetable sector since its 2007 reform.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. Over the past 20 years, the common agricultural policy (CAP) has reduced its regulation of agricultural markets, allowing market forces to be geared to production. The Union has linked this liberalisation process to a policy to strengthen producer organisations in order to empower farmers to act to defend their interests. An example is the collective sale of their products or the addition of value to products through their processing directly on the farm. This report gives a completely comprehensive picture of the state of the sector in the EU. It also sees problems that are still unresolved, such as the low bargaining power of POs in the supply chain. In this case, farmers need to be better protected against unfair commercial practices by large retailers.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Fruits and vegetables are important elements of a healthy, balanced diet, whether as part of the main meal or another form. There is no need to convince anyone of this. Lay people know that, even the experts. Nevertheless, we must say that consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables in the EU in 2012 was 387 g per day per inhabitant, a decrease of 8.7% compared to 2007-2011. We remain to believe that this decline will not continue in the next period. I supported the report, but it is disgraceing that the total EU agricultural area under fruit and vegetables in 2007-2011 has been reduced by 6% and farmers have either switched to other crops or, in many cases, abandoned farming. I come from a region of Slovakia where the cultivation of fruits and vegetables was a tradition. After replacing generations, today's farmers have abandoned this activity. Personally, I see a problem in the fruit and vegetables sector, not in production, but in the sales themselves and in the lack of competitiveness of our supermarkets. I also believe that support for the CAP in this sector of 1.5% of the total value of EU production is insufficient.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I have supported the proposal for a fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform, as it strengthens the role of fruit and vegetable producers in a market that is important given its role in the economic development of the European Union. In my view, this resolution improves the quality and supply of fruit and vegetables on the European Union market.  I am of the opinion that it is important to develop the fruit and vegetable sector in view of their healthy contribution to health and nutrition. Also, as they are mostly small and medium-sized entrepreneurship in the fruit and vegetables sector, I think this proposal will improve innovation and competitiveness in the market. This proposal will preserve many jobs and improve the development of member economies from Central and Southern Europe.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on the report on the fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform. While, I do not support the crisis prevention and management measures being financed outside of the CAP budgetary envelopes, I am strongly in favour of the good organisation and efficient functioning of this important sector of the rural economy which generates employment not only in agriculture but particularly in the food processing sector.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the report on the implementation of fruit and vegetable legislation in the period since the 2007 reform This initiative report looks at the Commission's report on the application of the provisions of producer organisations, operational funds and operational programmes in the fruit and vegetables sector since the 2007 reform. European Union policy for this sector focuses on strengthening the role of producer organisations in order to boost competitiveness, increase productivity, support research and innovation, improve promotion and marketing.  The report highlights the importance of purchase orders coming together in the form of a larger association of producer organisations, in order to increase the bargaining power of peasants in the food supply chain. Finally, the well-functioning of producer organisations is seen as important for attracting young people to agriculture, which will contribute to the demographic trend of the sector.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the proposal. While I welcome the efforts to simplify the rules, I reject efforts to increase the appropriations allocated.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the fruit and vegetables sector since the 2007 reform. The fruit and vegetables sector plays a very important role in many areas of the European Union. From fruit and vegetable producers, where they are mostly small and medium-sized entrepreneurs, to a healthy and balanced way of eating. The fruit and vegetables sector is also very important in Slovenia and has still a lot of room for progress, both in the field of technology and in the field of marketing. I therefore support the organisations and associations of producer organisations with which it seeks to increase the competitiveness of this sector, and I would like producer organisations to also introduce Slovenia.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the fruit and vegetables sector since the 2007 reform, as this report highlights possible further steps towards empowering fruit and vegetable producers through the creation of producer organisations and producer groups. The report notes that the current regime is too complex and does not provide a sufficient degree of legal certainty. This issue also applies to the Czech Republic, where the total area for growing fruit and vegetables, which falls under producers associated in producer organisations and producer groups, accounts for 39 % of the total area used for growing fruit and vegetables. The Ministry of Agriculture of the Czech Republic also voted in favour of the report.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report on the situation in the fruit and vegetables sector, in line with the direction of the European People's Party. The European Parliament supported my fellow Member Norbert Erdős's proposal for the European Commission to restore EU funding for investments in newly formed fruit and vegetable production organisations. This is extremely important for Hungarian farmers and producer organisations. Without it, it is extremely difficult for the established organisers to obtain the state recognition necessary for its operation. It is therefore one of the most effective tools for improving producer organisations and increasing the level of organisation. I am pleased that this explanation is reflected in the report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it Hungary important findings and recommendations on the FRUIT and Vegetables sector in the EU. As is known, the aim of the 2007 reform was to strengthen producer organisations in the sector, both by providing a wider range of instruments to prevent and manage market risks and by improving and con concentration of supply, enhancing quality and competitiveness, adapting supply to the market and technical support for environmentally friendly production. I agree that the European Commission's report provides a balanced picture of the progress made since the sector's reform in 2007, giving a realistic picture of the problems that are existing. The report rightly calls on the Commission to step up its efforts to tackle unfair trade practices in the food supply chain and to take further steps to protect producers. I agree that producer organisations should continue to be supported; that European quality standards should be maintained and that European quality and standard elements should be enforced in negotiations with third countries. The report is therefore an important step towards unifying and helping the EU fruit and vegetables sector, but I believe that the system will be fully uniform and solidarity when Member States cannot over-tax our food.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Fruits and vegetables are basic foods for the health of European citizens. At European Union level, however, there is modest support for this sector, the development of which has been left to the free market.  Since 2007, however, there has been an increase in support for the fruit and vegetable sector through European agricultural programmes. The economic crisis has halted this positive development, neutralising the beneficial effects of policies implemented in recent years. There has even been poor fruit production in relation to vegetables in the Member States, although there are significant differences on a case-by-case basis. Added to this was the embargo imposed by Russia on exports of fruit and vegetables within the EU, which deepened the existing crisis.  This resolution proposes a number of remedies to these problems, including support for producer sassociations, investments in human resources in the field, environmental actions, measures to support producers in crisis or against abusive practices of supermarket chains.  For these reasons, this document must be supported, because it supports a sector so important to our citizens.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for Mr Melo's report. I believe that the Commission is redoubling its efforts to protect farmers from unfair business practices by large retailers. It makes little sense to invest resources in strengthening and creating OPs (a slow and difficult process) if the bargaining power in the food chain continues to be primarily the domain of retailers. Moreover, as many Member States adopt national measures to deal with these problems, some coordination is needed at EU level to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market. In any case, this issue will be addressed more fully by the EP in a report to be prepared by our committee, the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee (IMCO) in the coming weeks.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform. The report by the European Commission that evaluates the development of the fruit and vegetable regime offers a comprehensive perspective while pointing out suggestions for improvement. One of the positive trends facilitated by the new rules has been the increased concentration of producer organisations, which have played centre stage in the fruit and vegetable policy since the 1990s. The majority of the producers are small and medium-sized businesses and collective action and coordination enhances their competitiveness, as well as environmental sustainability. I welcome the report’s call to improve the management of producer organizations, which need qualified managers to succeed in this competitive sector.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Nuno Melo's initiative report on the fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform. It is a question of finding ways to ensure stable incomes for farmers. Unfair trade practices, the perishability of their products and the repetition of crises are all factors that increase farmers' vulnerability and make their incomes more volatile.  However, it has been established since 2007 that collective action by producers allows for greater protection. The report therefore proposes to increase European aid to producer organisations, simplifying administrative rules, providing greater support to small producers and increasing their financial aid. It encourages the Commission to try to overcome the obstacles faced by producers in exporting, in particular by acting on non-tariff barriers. It also reminds us of the importance of the agricultural fruit and vegetable sector in promoting healthier food for European citizens.  The European Parliament, through this initiative report, draws the Commission's attention to the subject and shows that it is aware of the issues in this key sector of agriculture.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The sanctions imposed on Russia and the resulting export blockade have direct consequences for the European fruit and vegetable sector and unfortunately we are forced to see severe market disturbances and falling producer prices. That is why it is essential that this report has been approved by the European Parliament, because it is necessary to collectively address unexpected and adverse situations and to provide producers with all the means to strengthen their contractual position vis-à-vis the main retailers, including through production planning, support for innovation and crisis prevention measures.  Producer organisations have become indispensable to European fruit and vegetable policy and should be supported at all levels, particularly in Member States where the number of organisations is still low. These organisations could also be effective tools for combating unfair commercial practices in the food chain, ensuring better remuneration for even small producers, who are most affected by market instability.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 The report on the fruit and vegetables sector since the reform in 2007 focuses on producer organisations that aim to ensure attractiveness through simplification of rules and reduction of administrative burden, which will ultimately result in an increase in competitiveness of individual producers, strengthening innovation in these sectors as well as market-oriented fruit and vegetable sectors.  In my view, in crisis situations, such as the prohibition of imports of certain agricultural products into the Russian Federation, it is undoubtedly necessary to approach the activation of intervention measures protecting producer organisations. However, I note that we must not forget about non-members of producer organizations that need help equally, namely small and medium-sized farms that make up the majority of fruit and vegetable producers at Union level, and the consequences of which the Republic of Croatia has felt in its agricultural sector.  Also dangerous are the indirect consequences that can occur in anomalies in the export of products, which can manifest in the increase of surpluses in the domestic market, which can also cause a big drop in producer prices. I therefore support efforts to improve the functioning of producer organisations, facilitate producers' accession to them and simplify complex rules so that they can work.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I have supported the report on the fruit and vegetables sector since the 2007 reform. The report presents the European Parliament's reading on the European Commission's report on the implementation of provisions relating to producer organisations, operational funds and operational programmes in the fruit and vegetables sector since the 2007 reform. EU policy for this sector focuses on empowering producer organisations in order to increase competitiveness, productivity, support research and innovation, improve promotions and marketing, prevent and manage market crises, improve the position of producers in the food supply chain and promote environmentally friendly practices.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting because, although the report includes some improvements to its initial version, the amendments proposed by the GUE/NGL Group, which qualitatively improved the report, were rejected in the AGRI Committee. These amendments included some aimed at implementing public policies to increase producer negotiating capacity, prevent falling consumption of fresh fruits and vegetables in the countries most affected by the crisis, promote a traditional diet based on seasonal vegetables and fruits, prevent the depopulation of large rural areas after the dismantling of a livestock farm, introduce socio-economic criteria or exclude agricultural products from TCA negotiations.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The 2007 reform of the fruit and vegetable sector aimed to improve competitiveness by strengthening fruit and vegetable producer (OP) organisations to cope with the various crises. The aim was to make the sector more competitive in terms of its importance in terms of employment (550,000 jobs) and because it is a sector composed of small and medium-sized operators, which should be supported, especially since the sector has a turnover of 120 billion euros.  However, there is a decrease in the area under cultivation and therefore in production, resulting in a decrease in consumption, as children do not consume enough fruits and vegetables.  The aim of the text is therefore to help this sector for an economic purpose through the support and development of producer organisations, but also for educational and health reasons by supporting good food practices among young children in schools. This text is a step in the right direction, although we may regret that it does not make sufficient reference to unfair competition from third countries in terms of employment or to differences in regulations related to plant health standards.  So I voted for it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting because, although the report includes some improvements to its initial version, the amendments proposed by the GUE/NGL Group, which qualitatively improved the report, were rejected in the AGRI Committee. These amendments included some aimed at implementing public policies to increase producer negotiating capacity, prevent falling consumption of fresh fruits and vegetables in the countries most affected by the crisis, promote a traditional diet based on seasonal vegetables and fruits, prevent the depopulation of large rural areas after the dismantling of a livestock farm, introduce socio-economic criteria or exclude agricultural products from TCA negotiations.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted against this report which contains important elements of criticism of how fruits and vegetables are imported into the EU without meeting minimum social and environmental criteria.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for an EP resolution on the fruit and vegetables sector following the 2007 reform, as I believe that association in the sector is the right step that will provide producers with better bargaining positions with retail chains and make them more competitive on the internal and external market, ensuring a high quality of production.  The extension of the Russian embargo has contributed to the vulnerability of the sector. It is therefore essential to strengthen the attractiveness of producer organisations by reducing administrative burdens and creating additional incentives to accompany farmers. Information campaigns are needed on the benefits of association, especially in countries where the degree of association is very low or almost lacking, as is the case with some of the new Member States, including Bulgaria.  Association in the sector will increase their strength in negotiations with retail chains, which is a prerequisite for addressing unfair trading practices. Producer organisations can give young farmers a strong start, especially in the early years of their business when building their market positions. Last but not least, the association of producers will stimulate short supply chains for the benefit of the final consumer, who will be able to consume seasonal fruits and vegetables locally.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this non-binding resolution which calls on the EU to introduce better tools for dealing with market disturbances and help farmers to find new outlets for produce, as a consequence of the prolonged Russian ban on imports from the EU. The EU must encourage growers to join producer organisations so as to increase their bargaining power, strengthen their position in the food supply chain and thus improve their incomes. It is also essential to increase their competitiveness and tackle unfair trading practices. Furthermore, the EU must help its farmers find new outlets for their products and facilitate exports in times of unforeseen crises.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 We are talking about one of the engines of the agricultural economy in Spain. The report contains support for the strengthening of producer organisations as well as the simplification of current operational programmes and the strengthening of instruments in the event of serious crises, and I therefore consider it appropriate to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although some improvement was made in relation to the original document, I have decided to abstain in my final vote. This is because the report does not reflect the need for public policies to support the bargaining capacity of medium and small farms, the fall in fruit and vegetable consumption in countries with austerity policies that lead to the adoption by families of an unhealthy diet, the promotion of traditional diets based on seasonal vegetables and fruits , the limited use of funds by producer organisations, the closure of farms leading to the desertification of large areas of land, the inclusion of social and economic value criteria for small and medium-sized enterprises farms to preserve the rural environment, as well as the exclusion of agricultural products from TTE negotiations and the defence of the marketing and consumption of local networks that promote social cohesion and Regional.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation is once again paradoxical. We have a decline in the agricultural areas used for the production of fruits and vegetables. We have a consumption that continues to decline and is below the recommendations of the World Health Organization. We have a model in essence where the large multinationals in the food sector today determine the diet of our young people. Producer organisations are key. Its degree of organization has been growing, but the picture is very diverse from country to country. In this sense, we continue to advocate greater flexibility for its recognition, depending on the specific reality of each region. On the other hand, more support is needed, as well as the extension of eligible expenditure in order to create sustainability conditions.  However, it is good to say that we cannot feed into the illusion that it will be possible, with greater PPAs, to be able to deal with the serious problems of the sector and, for example, the mastery of large distribution. In this sense, we continue to maintain great reservations in the face of this trend of complete liberalisation of the CAP which continues to focus on market solutions that will not bring anything good to our farmers.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The strengthening of agriculture is to be welcomed and I would therefore have supported the proposal. The proposed changes will improve sales figures for vegetable and fruit growers and compensate for Russia's failure as a trading partner.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider this report on the fruit and vegetables sector since the 2007 reform to be very positive, which is why I supported it. I very much welcome the fact that our producers are making full use of financial support, especially for investing in advertising campaigns or training. I very much like the fact that this reform has approved and extended the policy of strengthening the role of associations of producer organisations.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We report that the decrease in fruit and vegetable consumption in countries with austerity policies have led to the adoption of unhealthy and scarce diets in essential nutrients by families. We advocate the promotion of traditional diets based on vegetables and fruits of the time, denounce the limited use of funds by producer organizations, the closure of farms that lead to the desertification of large areas of land, advocating the inclusion of criteria of economic and social value for small and medium-sized agricultural productions, preserving the rural environment and the defense of local marketing and consumer networks that promote social and regional cohesion. We propose the exclusion of agricultural products from the TTIP negotiations. The report reflects some of our concerns and we follow the analysis it has made of the sector, its needs and the problems it has been experiencing since 2007.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the condition of the fruit and vegetable sector because I believe that it contains interesting ideas for strengthening an important sector of our agri-food production. The recent reduction in the regulation of agricultural markets has led to distortions in the market to the detriment of producers and, in particular, operators in the short supply chain.  The report highlights the importance of strengthening producer organisations, through which critical mass can be made to ensure legal certainty and simplification of the applicable regimes. It is important to focus on human capital on greater transparency and democratic control over the handing out of Community funds so as to increase mutual trust between POs and to combat unfair practices of opportunism, which are common in the large-scale distribution of the fruit and vegetable sector. Particular attention should also be paid to the Russian embargo, which has aggravated the situation of farmers who are increasingly in a particularly vulnerable negotiating position vis-à-vis wholesalers or retailers. I agree with the request to the Commission to consider making contributions to funds for crisis prevention and management, in order to help farmers protect themselves from substantial drop in income.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on the preparation of the Commission's 2016 work programme (2015/2729(RSP)). I would like to point out from the outset that we do not allow a catch-the-eye procedure or blue cards on this item on the agenda, because the agreement between the groups is that there is only one speaker speaking per group.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, exactly 10 years ago in London, 52 people died and hundreds were wounded in a terrible terrorist attack. I remember vividly those days. I remember the outpouring of solidarity in London, in the United Kingdom, and across the world, especially in the European Union. I want to mention this at the start of my contribution today, because I do believe that we, as Europeans – whatever our position may be on European integration, on European cooperation – at that moment had a sense of destiny, of common destiny. Whatever else we may do right or wrong, we have a common duty to fight for the security and safety of our citizens. We have a common duty to make sure that these barbarians, these distorted thinkers, these nihilists, are not in a position to wreak havoc in European society. This is one of the main challengers all our nations face. This goes beyond politics. This is about human dignity. This is about our common values. If I look back at the last couple of years, we have seen that Europe is facing a number of huge challenges: terrorism, as I just mentioned; the migration crisis; the need to create jobs and to create growth; the need to face the changes in the world’s economy and the place of Europe therein; and Greece. This is the backdrop against which we are working on our Commission Work Programme for this year and for next year. Let me say something briefly about this year’s state of play and the Commission Work Programme 2015. Over half of the Work Programme items are fully or mostly fulfilled. Thanks to you, to this Parliament, the European Fund for Strategic Investments has been operational since 1 July. We have set out strategic agendas, including for investment, energy union, the digital single market, migration, internal security and a fairer corporate tax system. These agendas and action plans signal a considerable legislative workload for this House in the months and years to come. Some of these proposals are already before you, and more are coming – starting with the revision of the energy labelling and emissions trading legislation next week. In total, over 40 proposals for legislation will flow from the strategies we have already presented. That comes on top of the 140 proposals which are pending on the table of the co-legislators. So please let us bust this myth that this Commission is not forthcoming enough. Where legislation is the right response to address the big things, we will be big on legislation. We are working on ambitious strategies on trade and investment, on the single market for goods and services, on an ambitious package for the circular economy. We will present an action plan for developing a real capital markets union in autumn, and we will accompany it with the first legislative proposals in the most pressing areas. And before the end of the year, we want to put to you a comprehensive – and clearly much-needed –’EMU package’. The importance of the social dimension – in EMU, obviously, but also more widely – is something President Juncker and I are both very attached to. To speed up the Youth Employment Initiative, we proposed making EUR 1 billion available this year. We are also actively working on a labour mobility package, to be adopted later this year. The College will have a further orientation debate dedicated to social policy immediately after the summer. Before looking ahead towards 2016, I would like to stress that it takes – in this case, oddly enough – three to tango. Delivering results where it matters is a shared responsibility of all three institutions. That is why we are now negotiating a revised interinstitutional agreement (IIA) on Better Law Making, and I am very much looking forward to my first meeting – on a political level as well – with Nicolas Schmit, who is representing the Presidency, and with Guy Verhofstadt, who is representing your Parliament. Our proposal pays particular attention to reinforcing and consolidating the annual and multiannual planning and programming. While respecting the specific arrangements for close cooperation between Parliament and Commission that are set out in the Framework Agreement – we respect and will continue to respect that Framework Agreement – and while respecting each of the three institutions’ roles under the Treaties, it is by working better upstream that we believe we can really make sure our combined efforts deliver effective and ambitious results to address the challenges Europe faces. Let me turn briefly to the preparations for next year. A first orientation debate will be held in College a week from now. In September, we will have an opportunity to take stock of the progress made and of the challenges ahead during President Juncker’s state of the union address. We intend to adopt the 2016 Work Programme on 27 October. In the run-up, the Commission will engage actively in dialogue with Parliament, in full accordance with the Framework Agreement. We will also listen to the input of Member States in the General Affairs Council. To launch and guide our discussion, a ‘letter of intent’ will be sent in parallel with the state of the union address here in this House. So that is for September. You can expect another targeted and balanced work programme, focused on 2016 – and 2016 only – grounded in the 10 priorities set out by President Juncker and agreed with your Parliament. Our strategic agendas – those we have already presented and those still to come later this year – will obviously be the main frame, and we will keep a clear focus on delivering what we have announced there. So please remember that those are the pivotal points in our Commission Work Programme. You know this already. This is the basis upon which we will develop our concrete proposals. And then, of course, next year will also be the year of the MFF mid-term review, which is also going to be a big challenge for both our institutions. There will be a strong emphasis on REFIT, because keeping the acquis up to date and pertinent to today’s challenges requires a permanent effort. And if pending proposals need to be repealed or withdrawn to allow the co-legislators to use their energy on files that have a chance of being adopted, we will flag them. We need to be, I believe, pragmatic and result oriented. If others need to be prioritising and speeding up, we will flag them too. I hope that we can work closely together with Parliament on this. I strongly believe in this, and I think we need to deliver better results for our citizens. In conclusion, Mr President, aligning our political priorities and planning can help make all the difference to whether Europeans look at Europe as part of the problem or rather as part of the solution to the huge challenges they face. I look forward to the resolution that this House will adopt later this week, which will be very useful in guiding the Commission’s ongoing reflections. Let us work together, let us work hard. There are so many challenges we face and so many results our citizens expect of us: let us do it together.

name: József Szájer
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, we often say here in the House that Europe is in a difficult phase, a difficult situation in its history. This week I think we can rightly say this, but that underlines the fact that we have to work on the effectiveness of how our Union works. The exercise of discussing the Commission’s work programme is something like that. Let us go back a little bit. I am glad that the Vice-President started with a little stocktaking because, here in the middle of the year, we can already see what has been happening. On behalf of the EPP I can confirm that the Commission has made a quick start and a good start. The investment package and many other initiatives have been strong, and on behalf of Parliament we would like to help this process of going forward in these areas. This energetic start should go on. I also would like to comment on the point that many have misinterpreted Parliament’s decision in January about the lack of support or a resolution on the Commission’s work programme. Normally in election years this is not required, because planning is much longer and much more preparation is needed, so it is not a failure to meet our obligations. But this year is a full year, which means that we can already have full preparation, which we are doing. Obviously, I am not saying that the preparation process is perfect. For example, in the negotiations which we are now having here in Parliament, we have had to discuss all the things which had been done in this last half year – all the compromises which we are going to foresee in the next year and the second part of this year – which are a little bit too dense, which means that we cannot make the same kind of compromises. However, in exercise of Parliament’s very important power, which is the right of initiative, we have this instrument which we have to use in order to get some kind of ideas on the Commission table, and we expect the Commission to follow those. The first thing is the method. I am glad that the Vice-President has mentioned that we want effective legislation, fighting red tape (including a significant reduction of the cost of the bureaucratic burden), and the transposition, implementation and enforcement of EU legislation. Very often we do not need new legislation; we just need to implement that which already exists in the right way. It obviously should not be a question of vanity whether someone has a report or a piece of legislation. We have to look more thoroughly in this Parliament at whether we can do more with a view to implementation. The Commission has to do the same. So this is why we are fully supporting the better law-making exercise and law-making programme. Another very important matter is the alignment of the legislation to the delegated and implementing act provisions of the Lisbon Treaty. This is a big delay; the Lisbon Treaty has been in force for quite a long time. We have seen resistance on the part of the Council. The Commission should also help Parliament to have full rights in this, otherwise we are falling into a constant inter-institutional fight in this area. We should solve this problem; it is already impossible that we have not gone further ahead on this.  Unfortunately, the Commission has withdrawn this piece of legislation. We hope that in the framework of the better law-making package we can do more. In our view, jobs remain the top priority; mobility and flexibility of the labour market have to be improved, as well as youth employment. The digital agenda has to play a crucial role in our society, especially in creating and re-shoring jobs, improving skills of EU citizens and work and school for the younger generation, giving better access to digital services. The next development of the EMU should be based, in our view, on the existing two-pack and six-pack legislation. We are against any revision of these two main instruments for the moment; we want them to be fully implemented and applied. On taxation policy, which is an integral part of the structural reform of the Member States, we would like to see a development, a shift of the tax burden from labour to other forms of taxation. Concerning the EU budget, the fight against tax fraud and evasion, supporting the better performance of the EU budget, is something very important. So just to sum up, we would now like Parliament to say that we want to have a say in this exercise, and this is what our resolution, hopefully, will be there to do. I hope that many colleagues in this House can support the joint resolutions which we have prepared.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, we are in a double exercise. On the one hand, to check, in some way, what has happened, on the part of the Commission, since the presentation of its investiture programme, and, secondly, to try to provide an opportunity for the European Parliament to contribute to the political direction that the Commission itself has to put in place. Of course, this is an element of the interinstitutional agreement, but I think it goes beyond an agreement. It goes further. Because of its high political dimension, Parliament must be part of the political leadership of the Union. When it comes to reviewing what has happened in this first part of the Commission's action, the assessment I make is frankly positive. The mixing of the investment programme, the EIE, with the flexibility of the growth programme has enabled the Union's economic policy to be turned around and directed towards the elements that we have to solve in the context of the economic crisis: growth and job creation.  But, in turn, the Commission has also come up with a rather substantive proposal on fiscal policy and with action, in addition to a very courageous proposal, on immigration. And it has also come with ambitious positions in energy policy and also in other areas in the economic field. I would also like to point out that transparency has been established, has been installed in the Commission's behaviour and I think this is a positive point. For 2016, my group has sufficiently identified priorities in the social field, in the field of immigration, in the field of fiscal policy and in the field of democracy. In the social field, we want all The Union's policies to be crossed cross-cutting through social approaches. I know that the Vice-President often says that it is not enough to say that we are in favour of a social policy. I believe that we can work together to concrete in what respects. For example, in the fight against poverty and exclusion, in compliance with collective bargaining, in , as the Vice-President has just pointed out, legislation on the mobility of workers and rights, respect for workers' rights in the context of this mobility. In the area where you pointed out that you are going to present a package on economic and monetary union, we also want the social dimension to be a basic point of enhanced economic and monetary union, not only in the Presidents' document, but also in the Commission's action as a whole. In fiscal policy, the proposal can be simplified in two respects. We want it to be taxed in those countries where income is generated and we want there to be a common rate, a common consolidated corporate tax base. And in the field of immigration, the truth is that what I want is for the Commission to maintain the firm pulse it has maintained so far, asking Member States to comply jointly and severally with the burdens that are being generated by humanitarian crises. , also with solidarity, the issue of asylum. As far as democracy is concerned, and I conclude, I would like , my group wants - to put forward a proposal with objective indicators and a mandatory mechanism to respond to the failures and violations of the fundamental rights of the Union, enshrined in its Treaties. So there is a broad level of coincidence and we look forward to working continuously with the Commission next year.

name: Vicky Ford
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, last year, from this very place, I warned of unprecedented challenges to our economies, our resources and our security, and today in much of Europe the situation is no better. Indeed, in many countries it is worse. Europe does need to change, and the perpetual path to political Union is not the solution, and my group does not support this. In my country six years ago we faced a deep economic crisis, but we now have more jobs than ever before and it is the fastest growing economy in the West. This is due to a long—term economic plan. In Europe, the economy needs to come first, and it is competitiveness that drives jobs and growth. This resolution has some helpful suggestions. The EU should not churn out new laws without thinking about the impact on growth, small businesses and innovation. The Commission has cut back new legislation, is focusing on making sure existing laws work and has promised to remove burdens for businesses and set a target for cutting red tape. This report supports all of that. I have also said that every EU initiative should face the simple test: will it make it easier or harder for businesses to thrive? This report supports that. A generation ago, politicians created the single market to make it easier to trade. This report says we must make it fit for purpose in a digital age, underpinning the digital revolution – not undermining it. This report supports that. We must increase external trade too. Let us sign the deal with Canada, and keep negotiating the one with the US. Yes, we need investment, built on private funds because the crisis in public debt is even more acute today than it has been in the past. We need to sort out Greece and to stop pretending that all sovereign credits are equal. Structural reforms are key. Majorities in this house at the moment are very narrow. Grand plans are easily stalled. We do need less law, but it needs to be very well targeted to get support. My group wants to put the economy first, and to support the EU in putting competiveness first. We will work with others who share that vision.

name: Sophia in ‘t Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, as the Commissioner may probably note with a smile on his face, Parliament’s resolution opens by saying that we want to focus on the big themes – and then we need about 29 pages to explain what the big themes are. I very much welcome the aim of the Commission, supported by the majority in this House, to cut red tape. I think that is always a good idea anywhere, but it should not become a goal in itself. Quite frankly, cutting red tape – important as it may be – is not the answer to all the big challenges of today. It is not the answer to the refugee crisis. It is not the answer to the crisis in the eurozone. It is not the answer to the dismantling of the Schengen area. It is not the answer to Mr Putin. So we need to cut red tape, but we need more than that. I think what we need to keep in mind is that what we are doing here today is creating the European Union that future generations will be living in. It is not just about us and our little differences, or indeed the things that bind us, it is about future generations. I will make a first remark about better law-making. As far as I am concerned, that is much more about the process than it is about the outcome, because the outcome is a matter of political choice. In the process I think there is a lot that needs to be improved, and the Commission can do a lot there too, for example by introducing a true culture of transparency and access to documents because, despite all the nice words, I find that the three institutions – and that includes the European Parliament – still have a very conservative reflex when it comes to opening up and being transparent. A second point – it is a minor one and is not in the resolution, but I think I am speaking on behalf of all of us – would be getting true and serious responses to our written parliamentary questions, rather than the non-answers that we usually get. It also means responding to legislative proposals by the European Parliament. I think that the Commissioner himself has said that he intends to do this, because there is something odd in the fact that a citizens’ initiative requiring a million signatures obliges the Commission to respond, but this Parliament, elected by no less than 170 million voters who went to the ballot boxes last year, can be ignored. Finally, I think the Commission can – and should – do a lot better on review and evaluation. On the big themes, we are talking about improving the eurozone – and that is not just Greece, that is eurozone governance – and we need to go much further than the five Presidents’ proposals. The Commission should stand shoulder to shoulder with the  European Parliament in avoiding the dismantling of the Schengen area and free movement. Finally, this House has called for a mechanism for the enforcement of Article 2 fundamental rights and the rule of law. This House will elaborate proposals, and we hope that the Commission will do the same.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, at the difficult time that several countries of the European Union and the peoples are going through, dramatic moments which not only compromise the daily lives of people, workers, but also the possibility of future development of the countries themselves, it is urgent and essential to break with European Union policies which, in the opinion of our group, are subject to the interests of great economic and financial capital. That is why in the resolution that we are going to table and in the amendments we are going to table, we refuse to maintain debt as a pretext for imposing austerity measures and we propose their renegotiation, including their reduction and restructuring, so that debt in the various countries reaches sustainable levels, does not smother the development possibilities of countries and that they are simply payable. That is why we have proposed the repeal of the Stability Pact and the Budgetary Treaty, as well as the legislation on economic governance, giving countries the possibility of having a fiscal policy according to the different needs of each. That is why we propose that the Stability and Growth Pact be replaced by another pact, a pact for development and employment, which benefits all countries and we call for an intergovernmental conference to be held with the aim of repealing the budgetary treaty. That is why we demand a major change in the statutes and mandate of the European Central Bank in order to ensure equal political and democratic control of the European Central Bank. That is why we believe it is necessary to give the Member States the power to decide on matters as fundamental to the development of countries, such as monetary policy. That is why we advocate the repeal of banking union legislation and the need to ensure public and democratic control over the banking system. It is clear that when policies do not serve the interests of peoples and workers they must be changed. Only resists this basic logic who understands that politics does not exist to serve people but other interests. In the proposals we are presenting, we give all members of this Parliament the opportunity to clarify and which side they are on.

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his introduction. I think all of us in this room can agree on one point, namely that Europe should indeed be big on big things and small on small things. But the debate, of course, is about what we call big and what we call small. That is a political debate and a political decision. Let us not hide between impact assessments, scrutiny boards or whatever. This should be an open political debate on what we call big and what we call small and where we will put Europe at the forefront. There is a lot of criticism about how Europe works at the moment, but is that because there are many rules coming out of Brussels or is it because of the situation in Greece? Is it because of the rising unemployment in Europe? Is it because of the rising inequalities in Europe? I think it is the latter. That is the big thing for me. Europe should become a Europe that is addressing inequalities and moving towards a social Europe and a sustainable Europe. That is the core, the big thing and the big challenge for Europe. I think we should always be united there. Mr Timmermans said that we should get rid of the myth that this Commission is not being progressive and not being ambitious on legislation. Well, I still have to say that we need to see some proof of that. One of the biggest moments when we are going to read that out is, of course, when you come forward with the so-called more ambitious proposal on the circular economy package. We will certainly watch closely to see whether that is indeed more ambitious. Mr Timmermans, you said in our group, ‘let me prove you wrong’, because you know we are sceptical. Well, I am happy to be proved wrong, but we have to see it. The same goes for issues like migration, and also the Commission’s first reallocation plans. These are good and we support them, but we all know that this is just the start of a big debate. The Commission should also come forward here, for example by creating legal routes for labour migration, which is a very important part. The same on taxation. The taxation package until now has not been very ambitious. We should have far more on transparency and country-by-country reporting. It is the same when we are discussing EMU, which needs to be more democratic and more social. We will challenge all these issues and have to look at them. In the end this needs to be done together, so let us indeed look forward to collaborating on the interinstitutional agreement – but let us do it on an equal footing. Let us not hide behind bureaucratic impact assessments, and let us make it a political debate where all three institutions are at the same level.

name: David Borrelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, clearly after what has happened in recent weeks, and particularly last Sunday in Greece, it is no longer possible to look at any action programme of the European institutions as before: something important happened on Sunday, something from which everyone – each according to their own institutional responsibilities – must learn. The signal from Athens is not just a technical signal, limited to the subject of this question: it is above all a political signal, and no one more than this Parliament, as the direct representative of the citizens, can and must grasp its political significance in the noblest sense it contains. I therefore call on you to encourage the Juncker Commission to set up a work programme that knows: to consider the important events of last week, to show a Commission that is truly capable of holding the power of political initiative, with real benefit for all the peoples of the Union, especially the most vulnerable, for example, by reorienting the Juncker Plan according to criteria that take account of the geographical areas most in difficulty. Because – over and above the merits or responsibilities of governments – we in the European Parliament must have the people at the centre of our thoughts. The Commission has control over the leverage of political initiative: use it with awareness of the present and with attention to the future and above all with concrete solidarity. The individual measures must– in our view – focus in particular on the following elements: high unemployment and low growth, high levels of public debt and excessive bureaucracy, a credit system that is insensitive to the demands of families and businesses, a meapic and ineffective approach to immigration policies and the fight against climate change. Then there are some cross-cutting evils, such as corruption, tax evasion and the infiltration of organised crime, which make more incisive and coherent action urgently needed at Community level. In essence, what we as European institutions cannot afford is to lose the confidence of our citizens even more. The Commission, with its work programme, can do a great deal in the direction of restoreing credibility with our voters; Let us therefore demand that he do his job well and that, above all, he does so with the necessary conscience.

name: Lorenzo Fontana
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, many things were going through my head during this debate and I have to say that the impression I have is that, unfortunately, we will find ourselves, perhaps in a year's time, being more or less in the same situation, if not worse.  The problem is to understand what the Commission wants to do not only about its own future but also about the future of Europe, at least, about the future of this European Union. , but a complete renovation needs to be carried out.  We will have to take decisive action to revise certain treaties which, of course, instead of bringing prosperity as we said a few decades ago, are leading to disaster for certain peoples. It is true that Sunday's signal in Greece was above all a political signal and I invite you, I implore you to change your policies more than what you are doing, because the Juncker plan, which was proclaimed last year, does not seem sufficient at the moment. Above all, however, you must also make us understand what your real priorities are, those that may not be said: that is, we care about our small and medium-sized enterprises, our traditions, our identities; we think that Europe is strong precisely because it is different. On the other hand, there often seems to be political action that looks more like multinationals, big banks and wants to homolote everything and everyone, in order to make us numbers. We do not accept that and sooner or later the people will rebel.  Think, for example, of the fact that the Made in Directive is practically blocked, while we are moving forward on TTIP, which, on the other hand, we know will probably be useful for some large multinationals but certainly not for our small and medium-sized enterprises, at least as it seems at the moment. Look also at the rest of the world: I do not understand why nothing is being done, for example, for our persecuted Christian brothers and sisters. We are talking here about all phobias – Islamophobia, homophobia – but we are not talking about Christianphobia. What about Isis? About the Islamic State? We need strong action by Europe to defend ourselves against the greatest danger that will be there in the coming years.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – The new European Commission programme clearly states that it supports the legal form of migration and will take 'tough steps' against illegal migration. I ask the Commissioner to make a clear distinction between the two here in public. Explain to European citizens what is meant by legal and illegal migration. All we know is that it's obviously legal migration when someone flees war, seeks asylum. I ask why such a man is vandalising and throwing away his passport, his personal documents, on the Serbian side of the Hungarian-Serbian border in Schengen, why he does not come forward with his passport and say, please, I come from Syria, I am from a war zone, I am in danger of life, here I am to be declared a refugee. Another question: how can people who come from Muslim countries leave behind their female family members, wives, children, mothers in a life-threatening war situation? I'd like an explanation for that, and you're obviously aware of that.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me just react to a number of comments that have been made. First of all, I have to say that there is broad support for working closely together on a Commission Work Programme that is targeted and, of course, that chooses political priorities after a debate. Political priorities are something you debate, and you look for majorities to get them, clearly. At the same time I also see the willingness in this institution, just as much as I know it exists in the Council and in the Commission, to reach an interinstitutional agreement – hopefully before the end of this year – on better law-making. Of course, better law-making is not the answer to all our problems: better law-making will not solve the crisis in Greece; better law—making is not the way to tackle Putin. I accept all these points. But better law-making is a way of trying to answer the plea of an endless number of SMEs across Europe which are telling me whenever I go to a Member State: ‘please help us cut red tape; please help us create more clarity; please help us understand that it is possible to create clear legislation, not legislation where Member States then have endless possibilities of gold plating so that we are completely lost.’ These are things that are important. They are important to SMEs; therefore, they are important to employment and to growth. Yes, of course this is not earth—shattering – this is not going to change the nature of Europe. But it is going to make a difference for hundreds of thousands of people who are trying, day by day, to work very hard to create a living for themselves, their families and the people who work for them. Therefore, this is an important thing for me. The way we create legislation is important to hundreds of millions of Europeans. Even if they do not know it is important to them, it still is, because the outcome is something they have to deal with. And let me be very clear on impact assessment. Let me be very clear on more scrutiny. This does not lead to taking away the power of politicians. We do not change that. It leads to better-informed politicians. I do not know what would be the problem with better-informed politicians. Better scrutiny and better impact assessment means that the politicians, when they decide, are better informed about what they can decide. I would say to Mr Eickhout: do not turn things around. Do not use the argument that ‘the politicians should be in charge’ to dismiss impact assessment and to dismiss scrutiny. That would be changing the argument you are using against me completely around. Both are wrong. The Commission does not want to use impact assessment and scrutiny to disempower politicians. On the contrary, we want to help politicians to be better informed. We see across our Member States that sometimes scrutiny or analysis leads to a conclusion, and the experts then say this means that this measure is going to be more costly for this or that reason. Then parliaments still decide, but we think that this cost is justified for bigger political goals, and therefore we do it anyway. But at least people know what you decide, and I think there is nothing wrong with that. As regards more transparency: I am all for it. But one of the reasons why we – the two institutions – need more transparency is also to show our customers, i.e. the recipients of our legislation, where we are responsible – Parliament and Commission – and where the Member State is responsible. There is still a tremendous amount of gold-plating going on. And again here, Member States have the full right to do that. If they want to create stricter legislation, it is entirely up to them – they have the full right to do it. But then do not blame Europe for it. Be honest about it, be transparent about it. I think the proposals we will discuss in our interinstitutional agreement will help us become more transparent. This also applies – and I say this clearly to Mr Szájer as well – to delegated acts and implementing acts. There, I hope we can reach an agreement which will create more transparency. As far as the Commission is concerned, we will put all draft delegated acts on the internet for a period of four weeks, so that everybody in the outside world can see what we are proposing. For the implementing act it is slightly more difficult, because sometimes – like when you change the price of a product – you cannot give that over for public debate for a long period of time. Everyone will understand that. But we will try to put the maximum amount of primary and secondary legislation up for public scrutiny, so that everybody knows what we are doing. Hopefully, then, we will avoid another ‘olive oil can’ disaster or something like that. It might help by putting it in the public sphere. Of course, we will need to act on a number of things that are very important, and migration is one of them. I am sure tomorrow, when the debates are held on the results of the European Council, President Juncker will want to come back to this. But the Commission sticks to its proposals. We believe, also after debate with your Parliament, that we are on the right track with these proposals. If you ask me what the difference between legal and illegal migration is, clearly somebody who is abusing the asylum system because they want a better life in Europe is an example of illegal migration. Asylum policy should be for people who flee because they fear for their lives. I think we have less support in Europe for asylum policy, because many of our citizens know that the system is being abused and because we are not able, if we discover people abusing the system, to make sure they return to the countries they came from. If we want a credible migration and asylum policy, we have to make sure that the rules are actually applied, so that people who deserve asylum get asylum – unfortunately too often the system fails them – and that people who do not deserve asylum are sent back to where they come from, and also that we have agreements with third countries to do that. But we also need – and this is simple demographics – possibilities for the European Union to have traditional, legal forms of migration. There needs to be a possibility for people to apply for a visa, at an embassy in the country where they live, to come and live and work in Europe. They should not be at the mercy of smugglers, nor should they run the risk of drowning in the Mediterranean, but rather they should have a fair chance – if Europe needs people like them – to apply and then come to Europe. In that sense, I believe legal migration is also part of the solution. Let me conclude by saying that for me, the important thing here is that our two institutions work closely together, because I do not think anybody disputes our goal that we should perform better in delivering results for our citizens. Sometimes these are huge – big earth-shattering results – but very often they are small results. But a number of small results will create more growth, more jobs, better social protection and a better future for hundreds of thousands of young Europeans who are still unemployed today. I think that that is a goal worth fighting for.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: At the end of the debate, seven motions for resolutions were tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 9 July. Written declarations (Article 162 CRP)

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. – In terms of persistent economic, social and security problems facing the Union, it is very important that Commission’s Work Programme for 2016, first and foremost, concentrates on improving its law making processes and institutional effectiveness. This way it would not only help to reduce regulatory costs but at the same time enable better coordination and synchronisation of political activities among the EU Member States. This, as a result, would help to speed up the implementation of such strategic agendas as the Energy Union, the Digital Single Market, Growth and Jobs and others. In addition to this, the EU should act as a stronger global actor. We need to be ready to take the lead and address new challenges such as Russia’s aggression in Ukraine in the East and the irregular migration flows on the EU’s southern borders. The Commission should ensure an operative response and ability to make corresponding legislative and budgetary proposals. Finally, the Union needs to improve its policy coherence and systematically project its internal policy to external action, including streaming of human rights to all policy areas.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. –We have heard about important issues, but when I listen to suggestions for solutions on specific topics here, I often think of the Gandhi quote "Be the change you want to see in the world". Europe is suffering from an identity crisis, and at the same time we are cutting the wood with our hesitation in our immigration policy, or even with the idea of curtailing our freedoms, such as the Schengen system. It is time to treat our Europeanism as a key issue, as there are already 6 referendums threatening this joint project. This includes, inter alia, traditional European diversity, interactions and coexistence of indigenous peoples living here. It is time to take concrete steps to protect indigenous minorities by creating a two-pillar minority protection system.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D)
text: Written. – The European Commission has announced its intention to turn the 2016 work programme into a political document focusing on the main lines, on the real priorities for 2016. That approach is good, at least if it contains the right priorities and they are ambitious enough at the same time. And that may be where the shoe is rubbing. The Commission keeps reiterating that the EU must be big in big things and small in small things. For me, this means that the EU must address the biggest problems, the problems facing EU citizens, as a priority. This does not mean that social legislation will be abolished under the guise of reducing administrative burdens. Problems that wake citizens up include social dumping, (youth) unemployment and tax evasion by multinationals. I therefore call on the Commission to pay sufficient attention to the vigorous ly tackling these problems in the 2016 work programme. For example, the Posting of These Directive needs to be urgently reformed to tackle secondment fraud and social dumping. I hope that the Commission will work on this in 2016 and that it will not be limited to studies and evaluations. The problems with the Posting of Posting directive are well known. It is now time for action and solutions.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. – When drawing up the Commission's 2016 programme, we must bear in mind the following priorities: reducing administrative burdens for citizens and businesses (reducing the number of legislative proposals and focusing on the main priorities), new incentives for jobs, growth and investment, a resilient energy union and a reasonable and balanced free trade agreement with the US. A key challenge remains the area of justice and fundamental rights. We must take measures to promote the employability of European workers and to address the problems of long-term unemployed people, especially young people. Our priority is a resilient energy union that leads to greater energy and economic independence, and also ensures the political independence and stability of the EU. Climate change policy must be forward-looking, and the reform of the Emissions Trading System (ETS) is also important. A reasonable and balanced free trade agreement with the US is of strategic importance. It is the most important project which, if successfully completed, will revitalise the Transatlantic Partnership as a whole, in addition to its trade aspects. I support the efforts of a mutually beneficial agreement that fully respects European social, environmental and consumer protection standards. And crucially, justice and fundamental rights. The Commission must act more systematically in the area of cooperation in civil and criminal matters and in the further development of the European legal area and in the protection of human rights in the Union.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Sergio Gaetano Cofferati, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2007/36/EC as regards the encouragement of long-term shareholder engagement and Directive 2013/34/EU as regards certain elements of the government report (COM(2014)0213 - C7-0147/2014 - 2014/0121(COD)) (A8-0158/2015)

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking my fellow Members who have contributed to this report. They are due thanks and not ritual, because, as they first know, the path has been very long and difficult. The vote was postponed for the first time in committee. Then, after the committee voted, it was sent back to the Chamber following a decision by the Conference of Presidents. The vote scheduled for June in this House has therefore been postponed to July and tomorrow we will finally be able to vote. We have gained time, but I believe that it was a wise choice which made it possible to deepen the substance of complex and controversial issues on which there were, quite legitimately, non-convergent opinions. So thanks to the shadow rapporteurs of the JURI Committee, thanks to Olle Ludvigsson, who was the rapporteur for the ECON Committee, and to his colleagues who worked as shadow rapporteurs. However, before I quickly get to the content of the directive, I wanted to say one thing to the Commission. I regard this directive as part of a larger mosaic, the one that should correctly and effectively define the governance profile of the European company of the future. The intuition even lies in Jacques Delors' 1993 White Paper: we are working in the direction he pointed out to us. However, it is a very good job. Today we deal with shareholders, then we will have to move on to stakeholders to give that social dimension to the company that the then President took as a reference, indeed built with his proposal. For this reason, I expect the Commission to take further initiatives of this kind in this direction.  In the meantime, as I said, we have come to define what the long-term orientation will be on the part of companies and shareholders and, above all, to increase transparency on key elements of the management of the company, of its corporate governance. We have agreed – and this is very important – that companies can identify their shareholders; I am talking, of course, about publicly traded companies. Just as measures are planned to improve the ability of shareholders to vote: it is an element not only of democracy but of effectiveness in the management of any company. The transmission of information along the intermediary chain will also make the work of shareholders more effective and also aware. Then there are the measures that, if applied correctly, can increase the transparency of the relationship between institutional investors, asset managers, and companies, so that the commitment policy defines for companies their return, in the short term but above all in the long term, thus emerging from the risk of being used simply for financial purposes. There are also measures that will increase the transparency of proxy advisor activity, an important function in any system. Now, we have confirmed the transparency requirements that were laid down by the Commission. And this, I think, is an effective and conscious choice. The same will apply to transactions for related parties, which must be subject to controls that will be differentiated according to the legislative system of each Member State of the Union. The changes proposed by Parliament will therefore make it possible to take account of these national differences, without them becoming an element of questioning the unity of European policies. Then there is the issue of directors' remuneration, which has been widely discussed. There was strong convergence between us on this issue, but there were different views on how to give it an adequate consistency. We have found the solution to the case and the shareholders will vote but their vote may be binding or advisory, depending on the decisions taken by each country.  And last but not least, country-by-country reporting. The fight against tax evasion can and must be done through the use of new tools: the annual reporting for publicly traded companies is one of them. The Kaili report had already suggested this: we have used this path, that of the shareholders' directive, as a first legislative appointment to introduce a hypothesis of immediate revision of the accounting directive. Once again, I would like to thank all those who have contributed to this report and, of course, I will listen with interest to your comments.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, let me thank you for your strong interest in this proposal, and allow me to recall briefly what our intention was when we tabled this proposal. Remember, the financial crisis hit the world economy and some of our societies very hard. Structural weaknesses in corporate governance have become more evident, and a broad consensus emerged that short-termism has played an important role in causing and deepening the crisis. This directive is one of the contributions to addressing these shortcomings at EU level. It will also contribute to putting the EU back on the path of long-term sustainable growth. Over the last few years capital markets have become more driven by the prospect of quick trading gains rather than by conscious and engaged investment. Even investors such as pension funds, whose very mission is to secure a long-term return on investment, have followed the markets and put short-term pressure on companies. We need to encourage more long-term financing and long-term shareholder engagement. This also means more competitive companies on the global stage. We believe that by enhancing corporate governance, we would give investors the necessary tools to engage and protect their rights. This should make European companies more attractive for investors. I would like to thank Mr Cofferati and all the shadow rapporteurs for their efforts in defining Parliament’s position. I welcome the compromise found, and the Commission is ready to engage in negotiations with the co-legislators. Let me now express some views on several of your amendments. First, concerning transparency obligations on companies about tax matters and tax rulings – the so-called country-by-country reporting. As the honourable Members know, the Commission is committed to fighting tax evasion and aggressive tax planning and will analyse whether additional disclosure of certain corporate tax information should be introduced. On 17 June, the Commission launched a public consultation on possible options, which will feed into the impact assessment work that will be concluded at the latest in the first quarter of 2016. Second, concerning measures to incentivise long-term shareholdings through increased voting rights or dividends: while the Commission agrees with the overall objective, the question is: how best to achieve this? We should avoid discouraging investors, especially cross-border and foreign investors, from investing in European companies, and we should not lose sight of the interests of minority shareholders. Finally, concerning related party transactions, the Commission notes that the amendments tone down the original Commission proposal.
