I believe that we need a harmonised threshold for the application of rules on related party transactions in the single market. Currently, 40% of shareholders are cross-border based, and the lack of a uniform definition of related party transactions leads to fragmentation and increased costs both for investors and for companies.

name: n/a
text: rapporteur on the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I welcome the measures we are now discussing.  It is quite right to encourage institutional investors and other shareholders to step in more actively and in the long term and influence the development of the companies in which they have invested. Not least, it is important to facilitate active cross-border ownership. The package of measures should increase engagement – and thus better functioning companies. It is particularly important that there is now broad support in Parliament to increase transparency around cross-border businesses. Extending country-by-country reporting requirements to all sectors is a natural and effective reform. It is about giving shareholders more transparency and, more generally, pushing back corruption, tax evasion and aggressive tax planning. This is an issue that Parliament should push hard in the forthcoming trialogues.

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It took a lot of time and a lot of effort to get to today's debate, but I think it was worth it, because the final seems to be extremely promising and interesting. This debate is extremely important not only because of the content of the document we are currently working on. We must ask ourselves a few key questions, which are really extremely important in the context of the regulations that we have before us, namely company law, any other legislation that will regulate the functioning of companies and companies operating in the European Union, regardless of their size. Key question: when will people, when the citizens of the European Union be happy, be happy? When they have a job – good work, well paid. Question 2: how will we treat entrepreneurs in the European Union, or just those who want to cheat and not pay taxes all the time, as those who will stiing workers and give them the least possible wages, or whether we will look at it from a slightly different point and deal with it in real terms, rather than looking for a hole in the creation of legal forms in the European Union that will not interfere , and they will allow economic development to create the mythical economic growth that we are fighting for, boasting about the free market in which we operate in the European Union. The free market is another key word in this context, because, I ask you, who creates jobs? Member State governments, European Commission, European Parliament? No, jobs in the European Union and everywhere are created by companies, entrepreneurs, these active people. I would remind you that more than 90% of companies operating in the European Union are small and medium-sized enterprises. What do we suspect of them? That they are oppressors? Let us start thinking logically and, with regard to this free market, we will also address other issues related to it, namely the remuneration of executives, which are, after all, part of the free market. I believe that shareholders should have the right, not the obligation, to decide what remuneration system they choose, a system that is appropriately adapted to the company's operating profile and to the objectives that the company puts before it. I am therefore very pleased and thank you very much to our rapporteur, my colleagues on my committee, that, after a hard and long debate, we have come to the conclusion that this is the right direction. And we have a document on the table today with which we can move on to the next stage: negotiations with the Council, negotiations, which, of course, will not be easy, because we still have some differences. But I firmly believe that with the right outline of the goal we want to achieve, that with a pro approach, not against it, we will achieve the success that everyone is counting on so much.

name: Evelyn Regner
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the My thanks are especially due to Sergio Gaetano Cofferati. He has done a truly wonderful job on this report in a situation that has sometimes been anything but easy. It has really improved the content of the draft directive, together with the shadow rapporteurs and all those who have then taken a very constructive part. We in the Committee on Legal Affairs and The Internal Market have certainly made a number of contribution to improving transparency, corporate governance and compliance with tax rules. We have achieved – and here I would also like to highlight the role of social democracy – that important information on the remuneration of the board of directors, tax strategies and risky business of society must now be submitted to the public. Let me send a message, above all to you, Commissioner, but also to some Members of the PPE and ALDE: it is time to wake up. We need more employee participation. Under the original rules, the Annual General Meeting had to approve the remuneration of the Board of Management at least every three years. This is an attempt to unilaterally strengthen the competences of the Annual General Meeting and thus often in the short term the interests of shareholders, but it massively neglects the interests of employees and other stakeholders. In the end, they are particularly interested in the sustainable success of a company. Our changes – the S&D Group – have strengthened the interests of employees in their role as a key success factor in the company.  However, the text that has been adopted now also contains something that is of particular concern to me, particularly in the light of our work in the TAXE Committee: namely, the measures that are capable of actually combating tax evasion. Here, of course, as you have already mentioned, Commissioner, and many others will probably address me, I am addressing country by country reporting, which is so important in order to shed more light on the dark, and this is also right here in this report, and I stress that it is absolutely right. The mandatory country-specific disclosure of essential information is an absolutely important concern for our group and should be highlighted at every point. It is about the good reputation of the company, which is at stake when the pressure to behave correctly increases accordingly, and therefore we should always take this opportunity openly as far as possible. Today, we can set the right course in the fight against tax havens and for greater tax justice, and we should be aware of this.

name: Morten Messerschmidt
text: for the ECR Group. Mr President! I believe that we all agree that there should be a level playing field for the companies at issue here, but the proposal that has been put forward goes far beyond what is reasonable. This goes far beyond what we in the European Parliament should get involved in. By setting the scope for regulating issues of deals between related parties and the remuneration of directors, we are interfering to an unprecedented extent in how private companies should be run, how their individual management rights should be arranged. In my view, the proposal is based on the idea that the management of Europe's listed companies is generally driven by the desire for short-term gains rather than long-term goals and good solid results. Nothing could be more wrong if you come from Denmark, where we know Novo Nordisk, where we know AP Møller Maersk, which has just proved itself worthy of wearing the confidence that has shown that they can handle these issues themselves. That is why we in the ECR Group will today refrain from supporting the report. We will abstain because a good framework is needed, but this proposal goes too far.

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –  Mr President, allow me first of all to thank Mr Cofferati and all the other colleagues for the hard work and good cooperation in improving this important legislative proposal. I am very happy that we have been able to find a compromise, in the centre of this European Parliament, that can gather broad support among pro-European and progressive forces. This has, of course, meant that all of us have had to make concessions and do so in a spirit of compromise on a number of points, but I believe that the end result is acceptable to all of us. For the Liberal group it has been a paramount concern that this directive should improve the ability for shareholders to exercise their rights in cross-border situations and not to add unnecessary red tape and bureaucracy, because let’s face it, European entrepreneurs and companies will not flourish because of the additional rules to comply with, but rather if we create a good business environment where they can focus on their core tasks. We do not believe that we can generate long-term engagement in companies by investors through legislative proposals requiring various sorts of policy papers or creative tax incentives. Shareholders need access to appropriate information, but then it remains their responsibility to engage with the companies that they own. If this interest is not there, it cannot artificially be engineered by politicians or bureaucrats. I think that the focus put to a large extent by the proposals of the Commission on requiring a detailed remuneration policy and remuneration report for the director’s remuneration is, to say the least, difficult to understand, not to say rather populist. Although I would personally have been happy to remove even more, I am happy that the compromise proposals have respected the key points that were problematic. Today I feel a lot more comfortable, and I ask my group to support the compromises and the report, and I look forward to the trilogues and the continued work on this file, fighting for a directive that is fit for purpose and focuses on shareholders’ rights rather than shareholders’ obligations.

name: Jiří Maštálka
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, today we are discussing a proposal to revise two directives in the field of commercial law. In particular, one of the objectives of the proposed legislation should be to motivate shareholders to participate in companies in which they have invested in the long term. The financial crisis, as the Commissioner also pointed out, has shown that in many cases shareholders have encouraged trustees to take excessive short-term risk, focusing only on short-term returns. Furthermore, I believe that the rapporteur's efforts to increase transparency in companies should be supported by publishing the minutes of the general meetings on the companies' websites. For the first time, the regulation of remuneration policy at European level is mentioned. What I consider to be key to our faction is the anchoring of the principle of country by country reporting. We all agree that tax evasion is a major problem that needs to be addressed. I therefore welcome the progressive content of this report.

name: Pascal Durand
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, with this proposal to amend the Shareholders' Rights Directive, the Commission has become aware of the need to integrate the issue of long-term investment and this is an excellent thing, because the European economy suffers from the permanent diktat of urgency and, above all, short-term financial profitability. Taking into account - as you do and as you have proposed - all stakeholders, small shareholders, of course, but also employees, who constitute the wealth of a company, is extremely positive. However, it was insufficient and more needed to be done on the issue of opacity, which encloses large groups and their activities.  It is obvious to environmentalists to push the issue of transparency to the question of what is euphemistically called tax optimization and to ensure that we can move forward on this issue. The LuxLeaks scandal has shown us all that the warnings that have been issued for many years, especially by environmentalists, are likely to force us to provide answers. What for? Because this famous tax optimization is a direct attack on fair competition, because large groups can choose tax optimization, where SMEs, SMALL and craftsmen, for example, or the liberal professions cannot do so. It was therefore necessary to act and I pay tribute to Mr Cofferati, for the quality of his work and his listening, as well as to all the groups that have tried to find a synthesis to ensure that this Parliament has the general interest against national private interests and tax competition that some States - the richest for that matter - and the interests of large private groups.  Yes, Commissioner, as I said in the last session to Mr Moscovici and Mrs Thyssen, do you rely on this Parliament to change the rules of operation, so that there is more transparency and less opacity in Europe and that we can finally abolish the privileges of some against the general European interest!

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking Mr Cofferati for his hard work and good work. Tomorrow, Parliament will have the opportunity to adopt a report which could represent a turning point in the governance of companies, at least in terms of ethics and management. We consider it extremely important to introduce strict rules on management transparency, effective control of managers' remuneration and their link to the real performance of the company they direct. In this respect, and, in our opinion, the introduction of the principle that the commitment of ethically responsible managers on the basis of the programmes and results achieved in the field of corporate social responsibility can be rewarded is particularly important. Another firm point, which is essential for us, is the adoption of rules to combat tax avoidance and evasion, such as the obligation for companies to state publicly in which countries they pay taxes. The new rules on the governance of companies will certainly benefit the citizens, serious and ethically responsible companies and, ultimately, the European economic system, to the detriment of the financial speculators who have damaged the economy, causing a crisis from which, unfortunately, Europe is still struggling to emerge.

name: Steeve Briois
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the financial crisis has shown that banking institutions favour short-term returns, resulting in an underperformance of our productive apparatus.  Shareholders, wishing to increase the profitability of their investments, have taken reckless positions that threaten the sustainability of our companies. In order to combat these financial excesses, the report plans, among other things, to extend the participation of shareholders and stakeholders in corporate governance.  The directive also calls for greater transparency between companies and investors. Once is not customary, we believe that these measures are going in the right direction. We regret, however, that they do not go any further, because we must be naïve to think that this project will allow better regulation of the international financial system.  Only a large-scale joint project to tax financial transactions will limit stock market speculation and encourage shareholders to invest in long-term assets.

name: Axel Voss (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. I believe that we already have a modern, strong company law in Europe, so that the Commission's proposal could not actually promise too much here in this area. In my opinion, too little attention has been paid to national shareholder engagements in national systems, or the issue of the protection of minority shareholders has not yet been resolved. However, I believe that the report we had in committee at the beginning of May has made the situation much worse, which we do not really want to have today under the heading of better regulation. We cannot generate strong companies and economic enterprises and growth by selectively strengthening shareholder rights and ignoring existing corporate law systems or by entrusting companies with even more tasks. Today, there is absolutely no objection to having dualistic stock corporation systems, whereby the tasks of the Executive Board and supervisory board should not be diminished by the function of the Annual General Meeting, especially with regard to the design of the remuneration policy. The identification of shareholders must also be in the hands of the respective companies. Only the excellent work of the shadow rapporteurs has ultimately led us to have significantly improved compromises here. They also better meet the demand. The long-term involvement of shareholders would be strengthened, including in corporate activities, and existing national rules would not be circumvented. In my view, country-by-country reporting is a problem. This proposal for a directive is the wrong place for me, and we run the risk that we will now get different country-by-country reports in different regulations.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Mr President, like other colleagues, I welcome the provisions for country-by-country reporting in the directive with the objective of tax justice for our world, but as Parliament’s rapporteur on corporate social responsibility, I welcome the recognition in this directive that business responsibility is an issue of corporate governance too. The move towards long-termism is an essential response to the financial crisis but is essential for sustainability too. The Commission produced a communication saying it was in favour of long-term investment, and I strongly support the directive incentivising long—termism, as it chimes with the global move being led by the United Nations Environment Programme Finance Initiative, the UN Principles for Responsible Investment and the UN Global Compact. I support the right of shareholders to vote on remuneration policy and to be informed by their stakeholders too. If Alcoa, ING National Grid and Shell can reward their executives based not just on profitability but also on sustainability, so can other companies. Transparency throughout the investment chain, including for fund and asset managers and financial analysts, is important. I regret the fact that the UK Government calls the provisions in this directive overly prescriptive. The aspects for institutional investors to engage with companies on social, environmental and human rights issues are important and are an important part of ensuring that the new EU law on non-financial reporting is actually used.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I support improving shareholder engagement and increasing transparency. But I feel that this report has moved too far away from those aims, instead placing unnecessary burdens on business. Articles 3f, 3g and 3h risk revealing business-sensitive information with no obvious benefit to the public, and I ask: why should an asset manager be responsible for reducing his or her investees’ social and environmental risks? I am pleased that recent negotiations have reverted back to the Commission’s initial ‘comply or explain’ approach, and I disagree with the obligation for Member States to introduce additional measures to support long-term shareholding. Surely shareholders should have rights which relate to their amount of capital investment rather than how long they have owned the shares.  Finally, the inclusion of a far-reaching country-by-country reporting requirement for large and listed companies in every EU country is unacceptable. This has nothing to do with shareholder rights, and it is inappropriate for those on the left of this House to attempt to include this issue in multiple files. Instead we should promote the work that the G20 and the OECD have already done at an international level.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the rapporteur's commitment is certainly to be welcomed, but we are still a long way from moving closer here in Europe to achieving true economic democracy, especially in company meetings, including the representation of small shareholders, at least in the share of one third of the board of directors. And from this point of view, why not consider setting up primary elections in order to allow real direct representation of the legitimate interests of small shareholders, who often represent the workforce, savers, to whom we should pay more attention and greater powers? Freedom of expression must also be ensured in assemblies, penalising companies and managers who prevent or unlawfully limit them. Commitments for stakeholders to ensure greater transparency of notes to financial statements and therefore on information, external actors, the list of subsidiaries, etc., taking into account the differences that still exist between the various Member States, are certainly important.  All this, if carried out and further pursued, will help, or would help, to give confidence to citizens and consumers, to investors, including institutional investors, by helping to eliminate or at least limit the heavy veil of opacity that surrounds the activities of large companies, especially multinationals.

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I welcome this important report. I welcome this important objective of promoting the long-term involvement of shareholders. I also welcome the clearly positive developments that have already been mentioned since the last plenary session and the improvements in the legal text. It is also important to me – also as an Austrian Member of Parliament – that the traditionally successful structure of the Supervisory Board and the Executive Board has been preserved and that there are no shifts in competence. Now this seems to have been corrected by an exception in Amendment No 27. It was curious to see, however, that there were also efforts in the Socialist Group here in the House to deprive the Supervisory Board – that is the level of employee representatives that is legally mandatory in our country – of the right to decide on manager's salaries. I would like to point out that this right is better located in the Supervisory Board than in the shareholders' general meeting, in which large funds also have a significance, which do not necessarily welcome this objective. The exception is therefore very positive. The traditional structure must also be taken into account when identifying shareholders. When it comes to country-by-country reporting, we do not want to refuse in principle, but doubts must be justified that there will be no nationalist, national bureaucratic burdens and regulations. Here we expect this to be closely observed in the trialogue.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Sergio Gaetano Cofferati has significantly improved the Commission's proposal. The report now before us strengthens transparency in corporate governance. Unfortunately, however, this text does not go far enough, especially when it comes to co-determination. My question to the majority of colleagues from the Christian Democrats and the Liberals is this: why are you so reluctant to take on employees? After all, it is precisely the employees who have a great interest in a company having a good, long-term future! It is also worrying that the Annual General Meeting in listed companies is to vote on remuneration policy every three years. This could unilaterally shift the balance of power between shareholders, the supervisory board and the board of directors in favour of shareholders, and short-term shareholders can thus jeopardize the company's well-being in the long run. (The speaker refused to answer a question about the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Yes, we are definitely talking today about tax secrecy for companies. The left of all colours, I would say, would like to abolish the tax secrecy. Companies should make public for everyone what taxes they pay in which country – that's the glass company. But companies are not accountable and accountable to the public, but to the owners and the tax office. Companies also have a right to data protection and tax secrecy.  Ms. Regner said: "Bringing light into the dark. I believe that the right to data protection and tax secrecy is a matter of the first. In Finland, tax secrecy does not exist in its form. Once a year, it is published how much money each Finn has earned and how much tax he pays. The day is called the national day of envy in Finland.  Today, the left of all colours demand the glass enterprise. Tomorrow they will also demand the glass citizen. I reject both.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: Mr President, this text aims to replace financial capitalism with responsible capitalism. Its objective is to encourage investors to keep their shares longer and to distract them from the temptation to make short-term profits. In order to achieve this, the text seeks, among other things, to identify shareholders. The identification of shareholders is a good thing: it will lead to the creation in each company of a list of shareholders in the interests of transparency. However, it will be necessary to ensure that there are not excessive costs associated with consulting this list. On the other hand, the text seeks to reward shareholders who keep their shares for more than two years, by allowing states to give them a dual voting right. This right is a good idea, if the beneficiaries are the state or the employees of the company. It will prevent the takeover by foreign companies. The double vote, thus conceived, will be the instrument of a kind of economic patriotism.

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to the Members who contributed to the compromise for the fact that it was possible for us to agree on a common line in the end. I would like to thank our shadow rapporteur, Tadeusz Zwiefka, but also the rapporteur, Sergio Gaetano Cofferati, for this. Because I am convinced that the goal, sustainable business development and greater transparency, in any case unites us across all political groups. The only question is how far we can get with this directive at these points. And I know that there is a catchphrase for the rapporteur in particular and for many parts of this House. It's about country-by-country reporting. I am not a specialist in accounting. All I know is that we had a tax law professor in the TAXE Committee of Inquiry last week who pointed out that country-by-country reporting – okay, he came from the UK, but I think he spoke representatively for everyone – would not end up with intra-business transfers. And the problem with the large groups, with the big companies in the world, is not that they do not, so to speak, create transparency per country, but that we do not know how the financial flows for patents and other things within companies are going. That is why I think that there is still a considerable need for discussion here in order to meet the objective of greater transparency. But the first step has been taken with this proposal. Secondly, as Mr Becker has already pointed out, it is, of course, also a question of finding adequate solutions that work in all the Member States. And there are different models of company law in the individual Member States. I believe that the amendments in the compromises have taken us a big step forward. I would therefore like to ask the rapporteur that we now work together to find other ways of achieving a genuine common goal in the end. From my point of view, there is still a bit of a way to go, but I believe we can achieve it. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr President, as Mr Schwab mentioned long-term investment and boosting long-term investment, I would like to ask him if he thinks fostering long-term shareholding is a sure way to boost long-term investment. There are probably other ways as well.

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, thank you very much for your question. I do believe that it can be said that we need to incentivise a number of investors. However, in particular, as far as bonus schemes are concerned, a longer-term preservation of company shares must be taken into account. I am sure that we will also discuss the further steps that can be envisaged in the context of the trialogue. That is why I do not want to rule this out at this point.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I believe this report is an important step forward in not just tackling shareholders’ rights but also tackling tax evasion. It is one of the first co-legislative files where we as a Parliament have a say on tax issues, and I think companies have to be transparent about the taxes they pay. If they follow the rules, what exactly is the problem? I agree with another set of experts who actually say country-by-country reporting is a way of achieving this. It is a top priority for my group in terms of how we tackle tax evasion. What is crucial for major shareholders is to continue questioning the tax policies of their management. I think it is also crucial that the colleagues on the right of this House who talk about tackling tax evasion turn their words into action. We all want greater transparency on tax matters, especially given that ordinary citizens have to declare their earnings and pay taxes and accept deep cuts in all their services, while the multinationals still get away with paying very little. I know that the Committee on Legal Affairs has made a clear, democratic decision and I hope that this House will seize the opportunity and support the vote tomorrow.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I too congratulate the people involved in this report, calling it a good start.  Strengthening europe's economic and business environment must be a permanent concern of the European Commission, with the major objective of stabilising existing jobs on the one hand and, on the other hand, creating new ones, as well as increasing competitiveness at European Union level. Today we are talking more and more about what the European Single Market means, which, of course, also requires legislation that ensures a harmonised and transparent approach throughout the European Union. It is important to have adequate standards to ensure functional corporate governance of companies with a view to long-term sustainability, which is in their interest as well as that of the Member States. At the same time, however, it is necessary to strike a balance between facilitating the exercise of shareholders' rights, the right to confidentiality and the right to the protection of personal data. There is also a need for an increase in transparency in the remuneration of directors. However - and I say 'however' by pointing this out, I appreciate that the existence of a legislative framework at European Union level must not impinge on the rights of shareholders of a company, be it cross-border, to establish its own remuneration policy within the framework of the business plan. It should be noted, however, that effective and sustainable shareholder engagement is the foundation of the effective corporate governance model, and stakeholders, and in particular employees, need to be stimulated and encouraged to engage in decision-making as a guarantee of effective management.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on his efforts in carrying out this very well structured report and which, in my opinion, embraces the views expressed in the Committee on Legal Affairs.  The report adds transparency to companies listed in Europe in relation to important corporate governance elements. For example, it allows us to have a clear vision of the involvement of employees, institutional investors and shareholders in companies. It also increases transparency on the remuneration of directors and on the operating system of tax regimes in Europe. The document also includes individual country-by-country reporting on the tax system imposed on multinationals, so that citizens and authorities can see if and how large companies pay taxes. This measure is a necessary tool to support the effective fight against tax evasion and financial engineering, and the European Parliament, we here, cannot miss the opportunity to provide a real solution that avoids situations such as Luxleaks or other scandals affecting the image and credibility of the business environment in the European Union and the European Union.

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE).
text: Madam President! I am a strong advocate of the active involvement of shareholders in companies and the transparency of companies' remuneration policies and major transactions. Of course, as a shareholder, you have to be involved and have a say. The original Commission proposal for this directive is both inappropriate and would harm European companies with an inflexible model that would not accommodate the existing national solutions for public limited liability companies and shareholder involvement. We must give shareholders influence, but we must also ensure that we do not hamper European companies in growth. We should not make rules that are so burdensome and rigid that the competitiveness of companies is deteriorating. I believe that we have reached a reasonable compromise in Parliament and I believe that we can also have a sensible solution in the negotiations with the Council.  Finally, let me stress that I am in favour of combating tax evasion and tax evasion, and companies must of course cooperate with the authorities in this effort. Having said that, I think we should stay focused on this directive. It is about the rights of shareholders, not tax policy. Let us tackle the tax policy initiatives where they belong, namely in tax legislation, and involvement in this directive, concentrate on creating the best possible framework for shareholders. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
text: Blue card question. Madam President! I would like to hear mr. I would like to ask Mr Bendtsen whether it is important that we ensure that there is equal and fair competition between companies and whether country-by-country reporting in relation to companies is not therefore essential for transparency and to ensure that no one cheats in tax at the expense of others' companies? I would also like to hear mr President- Mr Bendtsen, if not Mr Bendtsen. Does Mr Bendtsen support the fact that country-by-country reporting should be included in this directive?

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE)
text: Blue-card response. – What I mentioned in my speech was that I think transparency is good and that I am in favour of country-by-country reporting. I think, however, that there are a great many places in different directives. That is why I really believe that this should be about shareholder rights. Then we should take tax policy together at another time, rather than mentioning it in a number of initiatives.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: – What transparency can do, LuxLeaks has shown. The once secret agreements of the Luxembourg tax authorities have unleashed a storm of outrage and brought the approach to tax avoidance closer. The principle is that companies pay taxes where they make profits. But if there is no information about it, then that principle is empty and empty. Transparency and country-by-country reporting are therefore crucial for ensuring that this principle is adhered to. If the principle is that rewards should be fair – and I would add that the top of the business community is setting an example – then that principle is empty if there is no information about it. It is therefore important that the ratio between the top and the average employees is reported. I think transparency can be further elaborated. However, I would very much like to thank the rapporteurs and the shadow rapporteurs for the steps that have been taken. Transparency is a powerful weapon and the European Parliament is showing it.

name: Georgi Pirinski (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I believe that there is one overriding issue or characteristic to this report which should be clearly recognised, and this is that in fact it provides very strong impetus for responsible corporate governance. All the provisions having to do with shareholders’ and stakeholders’ rights, the necessity for clear reporting, both of remuneration and costs and profits, the country-by-country provision – all these are very well aimed at achieving a new quality of corporate governance which very much favours redirecting the behaviour, and the incentives for behaviour, of companies away from short-termism, from profiting unaccountably, into really serving the long-term interests of their stakeholders and society.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there is only one word to welcome this report: congratulations! Congratulations to Sergio Cofferati for his outstanding work on this directive on shareholder rights! It has made it a real text of progress to encourage long-term investment and transparency in corporate governance.  As part of the major advances, the implementation of country-by-country reporting will allow the detection, finally, of tax optimization manoeuvres. Multinationals will now have to openly declare the taxes paid in each country where they operate - including tax havens - so that citizens and the authorities can know where they actually pay their taxes, despite the temptation among our colleagues on the right of this Chamber to abolish these transparency measures.  If we want to take the measure of the Luxleaks scandal, if we claim to support SMEs, the first job creators who pay taxes, if we want to prevent large companies from embezzling billions through tax optimisation, we must support these transparency measures. I hope that we can count on a large majority in this House tomorrow to support these provisions that we, the European socialists and democrats, have made. I hope that this House will show that it has understood the expectations of our fellow citizens and that it sends a clear message to the citizens, to the Member States, but also to the Commission.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: Madam President! Commissioner! It costs money to run a welfare society, to ensure that the hospital is open and that the doctor and the doctor are ready when the accident hits. It costs everything money, the money we pay through our taxes. But for too long, it has been far too easy to sneak around when the tax bill was to be paid. Tax evasion, tax speculation, tax evasion, unfortunately, remain a popular sport in some international companies. Other companies, through irresponsible high-risk investments, have plunged entire countries and regions into economic crisis. Both phenomena are devastating for our well-being, our growth and our values. With this directive, we are now putting a lot of work into the fight against tax evasion and in the fight against irresponsible investment. We need to introduce country-by-country reporting across all sectors so that we can track cash flows and ensure that companies pay tax in the countries where they make their money and do not send the entire profits into tax havens.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Madam President, bravo Sergio, bravo to the JURI Committee and angry at this Parliament if it approves the Cofferati report which has dramatically strengthened the efforts of the tax, police, judicial and journalist and citizens administrations to detect and combat the aggressive tax planning and tax evasion and corruption they feed. There is an urgent need to halt the fiscal jungle in the European Union which the Luxleaks and Swissleaks scandal exposed and which seriously undermines the European project and also other countries, especially developing countries.  This is too important a subject to leave only in the hands of tax administrations, often devoid of resources and investment due to disastrous austerity policies, in the face of multinationals that have been fighting European legislation that rightly requires the publication of their accounts of country by country. It is pressing to extend this standard of transparency to all multinational companies in all sectors.

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D).
text: – Madam President, there are many elements of this report to be welcomed, but I also wish to focus on the area of country-by-country reporting. As colleagues have said, this would require large multinationals to report about their staff levels, turnover and tax paid in every EU country in which they are based. This reporting has got to be public: firstly, because shareholders and other investors need that information to make efficient allocation decisions, as many have already told me; secondly, because it is our right as consumers and as citizens to know basic information about the operations of firms within our own countries; and thirdly, because the vast majority of businesses already provide this information because they are only based in one country. Finally, we need this information so that academics, journalists and NGOs, as well as tax authorities, can help identify instances of abuse. Let us grasp this opportunity and make things better for shareholders, for other investors and, above all, for taxpayers.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE).
text: – I support the amendments and amendments to the directive to promote long-term shareholder participation, which requires large companies operating in the European Union to publish data where they declare their profits and where they pay taxes. Small and medium-sized enterprises are at a disadvantage compared to multinational companies that value their profits in tax havens. As companies publish more data, it will also mean a rise in competition, as data on where monopoly profits are generated will be known and companies will know which markets are better and safer to invest in. Multinationals wishing to do business on the European market take advantage of tax systems in their business and minimise their tax burdens. Such transparency, together with the planned amendments to the Directive on the mandatory exchange of tax decisions, is a good way to promote the conditions of competition and investment activities.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in another speech yesterday, I appealed to the principles of transparency, coherence and the protection of savings, so that they remain the backbone of any economic reform. This report contributes to respect for the principles of public faith and bears another important piece: the complex relationship between shareholders and corporate governance. It is necessary to restore a climate of confidence in economic and monetary operators, financial markets and banking institutions, and the main route is that of clarity, of the easy availability of activity-related information up to the level of corporate participation. In fact, we are all aware of the risks that shareholders have borne in the short term in their investments, but less well known is the inadequacy of the level of disclosure in the investee companies by institutional investors and asset managers. This inadequacy and lack of clarity contribute to reducing the long- to medium-term investment time horizon and, consequently, instead of being leveraged, it becomes limited to achieving the company's financial and non-financial results. The issue of disclosure is a key theme of a fragile European framework such as the current one.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the rapporteur recognises well the need for greater transparency in the operations of listed companies, but I must admit that I am not sure that this objective can be reached by the methods proposed in this report – not least by amassing regulations and reporting obligations to various stakeholders. Further so, while I consider, in principle, that contacting shareholders with each other on matters concerning the company is desirable for better management of the company, I consider that the assignment of information on the identity of all identified shareholders to an individual shareholder should not be possible without the express consent of all others. I must point out that in the long term we will not encourage shareholding by increasing the already excessive administrative burden, but only by creating a stable business environment, ensuring a high level of predictability of business opportunities, tax cuts and market deregulation.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, there is no doubt that this discussion, but unfortunately also too long a crisis that is still ongoing, has shown that we need new regulation when we talk about shareholder companies. That is why, I support this report especially after compromise amendments have been reached, when a consensus has been reached, because I am convinced that we need the identification of shareholders of all those companies that are on the stock exchange, I am convinced that we need transparency because it will guarantee a far better situation in the part concerning tax evasion and all that we have unfortunately experienced and heard in recent years.  Also, I think country-by-country reporting is a useful thing because there are different experiences, and in this way we are starting to achieve one kind of communion within the European Union.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, this Directive aims to ensure the best involvement of shareholders in the company's decisions.  I identify a certain myopia on the part of the administrations of companies, which are very focused on short-term profitability, even calling into question the long-term sustainability of the company itself.  However, this directive is paradoxical because it ignores or pretends to ignore the rights of shareholders who want short-term profits, as is also fully identified in the theme of the conflict between the principal and the agent. In this sense, in addition to not guaranteeing the involvement of shareholders, since they are completely pulverised through investment funds, this directive puts the question the other way around.  The solution to align business decisions as long-term sustainable management and, at the same time, ensure fiscal transparency involves the involvement of workers and local actors in the strategic decisions of companies, as we suggest.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – Some 50 years ago, such provisions and such proposals were likely to face disapproval, including from company leaders. Today, of course, is different. After the severe economic crisis that we went through after the Luxleaks affair, after many tax havens that have happened in the past, all of this has, of course, convinced the public that it has the right to demand more transparency, more transparency in the business of companies, and, in fact, larger companies and large multinationals are also being ordered to have more transparency in their business, including profit reporting, taxation. , about everything that needs to know in order to be able to have confidence in the companies. In this way, if, of course, what the Commission proposes, then in the future we can be put forward that players who do not play by the rules will not, and can slowly regain our confidence in the political and therefore ... (The President interrupted the speaker.)

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done This report provides for a greater say by shareholders in corporate remuneration policy, with the aim of increasing transparency and achieving better corporate governance. Additional voting rights, higher dividends and tax breaks for long-term shareholders are also foreseen. Undoubtedly, the model for this report was France, namely the Florange Act of March last year – in particular the second part of last year's Florange Act, which provides for precisely these points, namely the strengthening of shareholder participation in remuneration, tax relief, double dividends and double voting rights.  There is much criticism of this law from France, but there is also criticism from Bloomberg, in the sense that it is said that double voting prefers dominant shareholders – in France, that is the state – and disadvantages minority shareholders. Similarly, institutional investors would be preferred in diversified economies. This is certainly to be taken seriously as a criticism.  But there is also something positive that I would like to emphasize... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: –A Uachtaráin, is féidir a rá is dócha go bhfuil an tuarascáil seo ar an mbóthar ceart, ach nach bhfuil an sprioc bainte amach go fóill. Is maith an rud é mar shampla go ndéanfar gach iarracht go mbeadh baint níos mó agus teagmháil níos mó ag daoine a dhéanann infheistíocht i gcomhlachtaí leis an gcomhlacht sin. Go rómhinic, déanann daoine infheistíocht i gcomhlachtaí agus ansin déanann siad dearmad air. Tugann sé sin an iomarca cumhachta don bhord, agus is fiú féachaint air sin.  Is fiú freisin brú a chur ar chomhlachtaí go n-íocfadh siad a gcuid féaráilte de cháin agus tá moltaí déanta faoi sin, ach ag an am céanna is fiú éisteacht leis an méid a dúirt an tUasal Schwab; nach ndéanfaidh tuarascáil tír de réir tíre a dóthain chun an sprioc sin a bhaint amach. Dá bhrí sin is fiú don Choimisiún éisteacht le guth na Parlaiminte agus beart a dhéanamh dá réir.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the Cofferati report emphasises two points: first of all, the social dimension of the enterprise, because this is an important element, especially at a time like today, when we are facing a huge economic crisis and we have thousands of unemployed.  The second is the emphasis on transparency, transparency on the action of the company itself, transparency on shareholder relations with the company, transparency on who the shareholders are in the company, transparency in shareholder relations with the company's managers. Really in this phase of globalisation there are central questions: Why is an investment in a business made? Where do the funds come from? Is the investment made to support the company itself or for money laundering or for tax evasion and avoidance purposes? Also, where do large multinational companies pay their taxes? What will be the role of the employees themselves in the company, who must have an important role? The report answers all this.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I would like to respond briefly to the discussion on country—by—country reporting. I would like to be very clear about that. I fully agree with all of you who expressed here the need for more tax transparency. It is also the priority of the Commission, including the fight against tax evasion and tax avoidance. So the Commission says yes, but we must address this problem through another piece of legislation. This is the Shareholder Rights Directive, and we are planning and working intensively on new legislation which will be fully focused on tax transparency. As I said before, we are now working on the analysis. We need a thorough analysis in order to be sure, for instance, that we will not increase the administrative burden, that we will reduce or cut red tape, and that we will do this in the most efficient way, expecting the best possible results. All that we need is some more time. As I said before, we plan to have the impact assessment ready next spring. So this is the position of the Commission. I wanted to thank you for your discussion. Many of you said that this is a directive which can enhance competitiveness and economic growth. So I would like to thank you for all your opinions and I count on your continued support in the voting.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank my fellow Members who have spoken, not only for the things they have said, but for the way in which they have said them. The work we have done, laborious and very long, has created this positive climate, in which the sharing of objectives is combined with the search for the best technical solution in a climate, however, of great collaboration, something that was not obvious and that has instead been achieved. This must be welcomed by the goodwill, willingness and intelligence of all the shadow rapporteurs and then, as we have seen, also of colleagues in this House. I would like to say that our objective remains what was contained in the Commission's proposal, which we have strengthened and relaunched: on the one hand, to have an incentive for investors who look to the company as a place to produce wealth and not to activate speculation. For this reason, the investor's stay in the company is to be considered a positive choice and as such must be encouraged; on the other hand, we need transparency, as we have all said: transparency in order to combat fraud, transparency to combat illegality, transparency also, more simply, to combat tax evasion and avoidance. Paying taxes is a duty, even if it is a sacrifice for everyone: for individual citizens just as it is for businesses. But what is then paid has a reuse in terms of the stabilization of communities through the development of social protection policies, which are thus paid for. That is why it is an act of civilisation, which must be modulated, but modulation is easier when everyone loyally participates in the objective and the contribution that comes with it. I would like to remind you, with regard to country-by-country reporting , and I say this above all to the Commission and the Commissioner, that the Kaili report that we adopted in this Parliament last March called for country-by-country reporting to be activated through an immediate review of the accounting directive. The Rights Directive amends the accounting directive, which is why this is the right place to introduce this novelty, on which we will all work together, starting with the Commission. But it's right to start here.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 8 July 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The implementation of this report will make it possible to take a major step towards the transparent operation of listed companies. This will be done without adding procedures or obligations that would increase the burden on the companies concerned and without increasing their costs. This report is also consistent with our desire to reduce tax evasion and tax avoidance. The European Parliament approved by a very large majority the principle requiring multinationals to file a country-by-country tax return that would fall into the public domain.  The European Union must play a leading role in driving as many countries as possible in its wake. All available levers and information must be used to end massive tax evasion that deprives governments of substantial revenues at a time when citizens are being hit hard by austerity policies.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Ivo Belet, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning the establishment and operation of a market stability reserve for the Union greenhouse gas emission trading scheme and amending Directive 2003/87/EC (COM(2014)0020 – C7—0016/2014 – 2014/0011(COD)) (A8—0029/2015).

name: Ivo Belet
text: Rapporteur. Thank you very much, Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues. I think all eyes are on the Greek crisis this afternoon. Unfortunately, the urgency of this case is to put all the other files into the background. But global warming cannot wait, unfortunately. We must move forward in the fight against greenhouse gas emissions. With the introduction of this automatic correction mechanism (the market stability reserve or MSR), we are – I am convinced – taking a very important step in the reform of our emissions trading system, which was almost capsized under the pressure of the economic crisis. I believe that this will save us the most important pillar of our European climate policy. The MSR must ensure that there are new incentives to invest in energy efficiency and therefore in lower emissions. We are taking a first important step to achieve our ambition to reduce CO2 emissions by 40% by 2030. This will fundamentally strengthen our credibility and our negotiating position at the crucial UN climate conference in Paris at the end of this year. The reform we are now adopting proves that we can indeed reconcile an ambitious climate policy with economic growth and jobs. We are well aware that the transition to low-carbon production requires very important investments. Many European companies today have to compete against competitors from outside the European Union who do not have to buy CO2 emission rights, and so there is indeed a risk of carbon leakage. The energy-intensive industrial sectors, which are making great efforts to reduce CO2 emissions and are subject to international competition, must, of course, continue to be guaranteed that they will not be penalised if they want to increase their production – which of course we all want when economic growth picks up. I would also like to add something in English: ... What is more – and this is often forgotten – in this context, important derogations and important new initiatives have been agreed and are part of this decision – initiatives that are specifically in favour of those Member States with a GDP lower than the EU average. Let me refer to three decisions in particular. Firstly, the derogation for free allowances for the power sector will be continued for those Member States. Secondly, the new modernisation fund of approximately two billion euros will be created for additional investment in those Member States. And thirdly, a solidarity mechanism will be created of which the revenues are to be invested and distributed among the less-than-90% average income countries, and this is all too often not mentioned in this debate and in this context. If all goes well, Commissioner Cañete will come up with a new proposal for ETS reform next week. Of course, this new proposal must also further refine the guarantees against carbon leakage for the next few years. We are counting on the Commissioner and we are confident that he will come up with an ambitious yet balanced proposal. Finally, I would like to express my thanks, first and foremost to Commissioner Cañete and the services of Director-General Delbeke for the excellent cooperation and excellent proposals. I would like to thank the Latvian Presidency, which is unfortunately absent. I would particularly like to thank Ambassador Stalmeistars for the very effective and very pleasant leadership in this dossier. I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, Mr Groote, Duncan, Gerbrandy, Kyllönen, Eickhout, Evi and their team for their excellent cooperation. I would also like to thank ENVI President La Via and ITRE rapporteur Tajani for the excellent cooperation, because without their cooperation it would never have been successful.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is a satisfaction for me to appear once again before you in the context of this debate on the reserve of market stability. Once this Parliament ratifies the agreement reached with the Council, this reserve will form an integral part of the Union's Emissions Trading Scheme, and this scheme is the cornerstone of the European Union's climate policy. However, in recent years, excess emission allowances on the market have prevented this regime from giving the signals necessary to make sufficient low-carbon investments. The stability reserve is designed precisely to address this problem and make the provision of rights more flexible. This is expected to increase market confidence in the Emissions Trading Scheme and, in the coming years, prices will give the right signals in order to achieve our long-term emission reduction targets. In this way, the stability reserve will ensure that we do not miss important opportunities for efficient emission reduction. I would like to thank all Members for their work. In particular, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Belet, and his negotiating team, as well as Mr Tajani and the shadow rapporteurs of the political groups, for their efforts. The commitment reached is a solid solution around the great elements of this reserve of market stability. Let me highlight the most important ones. The Commission's original proposal set 2021 as the date for the reservation to be operational. During the debate many Members requested an advance of this date, which has led to the commitment made to make the reservation operational in 2019. The commitment also provides for the transfer of withdrawn market duties and duties not attributed to the market stability reserve. And so, the nine hundred million rights that were withdrawn from the market between 2014 and 2016 will not return to the market in 2020 as originally planned. Untributable rights are also transferred to this reserve, which will reduce the risk of regime volatility. The importance of innovation — for me one of the essential elements of this agreement — is also reflected in the compromise text reached. It has been agreed that, as part of the revision of the Emissions Trading Scheme, consideration should be given to whether fifty million untributable duties should be used to accelerate investments in low CO2 technologies. The agreed text also recognises the importance of industrial competitiveness and the risk of carbon leakage for European industry. I can assure you that these two elements will be important issues to be addressed in the framework of the proposal for a revision of the Emissions Trading Scheme. All the elements I have mentioned will allow a solid architecture of the market stability reserve, as well as ensure the strengthening of the Emissions Trading Scheme in the future. We have reached an important milestone with this compromise text, which allows us to focus now on the revision of the Emissions Trading Scheme for the period 2020–2030. Last year I committed myself to Parliament to translate the elements of the 2030 climate and energy package related to this Emissions Trading Scheme into a concrete proposal as soon as agreement on the market stability reserve was reached. I am going to fulfil this commitment and I intend to present, in July, a proposal on the basis of the consensus reached by the Heads of State and Government during the European Council last October 2014. This proposal will be an important part of the work we are called to do to achieve an energy union with a future climate change policy, which is a priority for this Commission.

name: Antonio Tajani
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Ivo Belet, for his excellent work in reaching agreement and concluding this dossier. Agradezco también el comisario por su trabajo y su cooperación. With the final agreement, we have struck an excellent balance between environmental policy and industrial policy. We have introduced important measures, which will make it possible to balance the additional costs to businesses arising from European climate legislation. I would remind you in particular of the provisions on carbon leakage and the Innovation Fund, to which 50 million co2 quotas will be allocated. In order to consolidate this necessary combination of the fight against climate change and industrial policy, a good compromise will have to be found in the reform of the ETS, in particular on two aspects. Therefore, looking to the future, we will have to take care to reach agreement on the allocation number to be allocated to the energy-intensive industries and compensation for indirect costs due to the increase in the price of CO2. I hope that the number of relocations for the energy-intensive industries will not be revised downwards: we must protect our industries and, above all, those sectors at risk of relocation.  As far as compensation for indirect costs is concerned, we need a harmonised solution at European level. The current system does not work and creates competitive distortions between Member States with negative effects for European industry. I hope that the Commission will take these suggestions into account with a view to reforming the ETS. Of course, it is important to achieve the 40% greenhouse gas reduction target by 2030, but we must also remember that there is another goal: manufacturing must generate at least 20% of European GDP by 2020. Without industry, there's no work.

name: Peter Liese
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I would like to thank Ivo Belet very much, but also the chairman of the committee, Giovanni La Via, the rapporteur of the Committee on Industry, Research, Antonio Tajani, and all the others who have taken part. The GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats will, of course, vote in favour of the text tomorrow. It has been a good proposal from Commissioner Hedegaard on the table, and we have also made it even better with the help of her successor, Miguel Arias Caete. The proposal that we now have on the table is more ambitious than what the Commission originally proposed. I say this to all those who criticise the proposal because they say that it is not enough. Not only are we starting two years earlier, but more importantly, contrary to the original proposal, the allowances that were temporarily taken out in backloading are actually permanently in reserve and that the allowances that we have not distributed until 2020 will also be placed in reserve. This is certainly an ambitious approach in terms of climate protection, so that emissions trading really works again. On the other hand – and I fully support this – we have made clarifications that help to avoid carbon leakage. We do not want the energy-intensive industry to leave, but we want it to be up-to-date with state-of-the-art innovation. This is what the benchmarks serve, and that is also the purpose of the fund, which Parliament has pushed through in the negotiations against sometimes massive opposition. We, as a Parliament, have ensured that we help industry along this difficult path. I would ask the industry, this outstretched arm, to accept this outstretched hand now and to reject unambitious climate protection proposals. I believe that this is the path that we should continue along and which the Commission should continue to take next week in its proposal, which I am sure will come next week: ambitious climate protection, but with opportunities for industry to continue to produce in Europe: if we manage to achieve this, we will also be a good example for the rest of the world.

name: Matthias Groote
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank Ivo for the work he has fore- First of all, thank you very much for the good cooperation! I have to say that Parliament has acted really responsibly on this important issue. After all, the emissions trading system will finally be able to breathe, it has to be said, through the market stability reserve that we are launching here tomorrow – our group will also be voting in favour of it. You can react to cyclical fluctuations. Previously, the emissions trading scheme was static allyed and constructed; this was a design error that we had installed there. In this respect, the emissions trading system with the market stability reserve has now arrived in reality. I think it is very good that we are taking a total of 1.5 billion allowances into reserve – out of the market – which will cause us these difficulties, that we will then really achieve a reasonable realistic price for a tonne of CO2, that investments are made – investments in climate-friendly technologies – but also that clear framework conditions are given, legal framework conditions for those who want to invest now. In this respect, it was very long overdue that we had come to this. I believe that this will create a stable legal framework, but also send out a signal to the rest of the world, including the COP21 conference: the fact that a sensible industrial policy, as Mr Tajani has just described, can be combined with climate protection and environmental protection is not mutually exclusive. In this respect, I am really glad that we – and I repeat at this point – have acted so responsibly and launched the whole thing. For our group, the start date is a drop in the ocean. But it is a compromise, as has already been mentioned. In this respect, I believe that we do not need to be ashamed tomorrow of getting this legislation off the road in this way, but, quite honestly, we can be proud that we have taken European climate protection policy, but also industrial policy, a step further.  Then, Commissioner Arias Caete, we are waiting for your proposal. I hope he will come before the summer. Perhaps you will be able to comment on this again in a while. I asked Mr. Efsovic at the committee meeting at the time. He said: yes, before the summer break. I asked him: In what year? In 2015, he said, and that's what it should be. 2015, before the summer break.

name: Ian Duncan
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the emissions trading scheme has been for some time now the EU’s flagship policy, but there has been no wind in the sails. I take my hat off to Mr Belet, who has begun the journey of trying to reform what has been a dysfunctional but important policy. The challenges that we faced in trying to bring about compromise were not easy. The start date alone created a great deal of tension, not only in this Parliament but also in many of our own individual groups. I think the 2019 start is the right start. I am also aware of the challenge again of those unallocated allowances measured in the billions represented. I am pleased, again, that they have been sequestered away because without that happening, quite frankly, this process would not work. I am also aware that the phase 4 of the emissions trading scheme that we must shortly embark upon will again ask very serious questions about the functionality which we must achieve if the emissions trading scheme is to deliver and if in the bygoing we are going to begin to link that scheme with comparable schemes in the rest of the globe. But I am fully aware that if we get this wrong, and if we do put a burden upon many of our larger emitters, then we will have serious challenges. That is why I am pleased again to see that there are conditions affecting carbon leakage. We must get that right too. We do not wish to find ourselves securing significant reductions in our emissions simply by the exclusion and the loss of industry, which is important in so many parts of our Union. All that being said, I think where we are now is in the right place. I believe we are going to make significant progress if we can put on the table the beginning of a functioning emissions trading scheme when it comes to the COP meeting in Paris. I look forward to the vote tomorrow. I think we should endorse this as an important step forward – but it is just that: the first step forward. We have much further to go yet if we are indeed to embrace the challenges represented by Paris.

name: José Inácio Faria
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mr Belet, President La Via and my colleague Gerbrandy for their excellent work in this document.  The greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme is the most important instrument for combating emissions that promote climate change. It is therefore essential to restore full performance to this instrument which, due to the economic slowdown and excess liquidity of allowances that has occurred on the market, no longer provided the appropriate final price for limiting emissions.  Economic incentives need to be in favour of the transition to a clean economy, not against. I therefore believe that this reform is essential to correct the present imbalance. The outcome of the negotiations on this legislative proposal will allow for a more stable and predictable market environment, more environmentally friendly and more investment-friendly in green technologies. I hope that the European Commission, Commissioner, will now work to propose, even before 2020, an innovation fund to promote research and development in low-carbon technologies. The future is built today by betting on tomorrow's technologies. I am pleased that the reserve for stabilising the licence market will be operational earlier than originally proposed by the Commission for 2021, i.e. as early as 2019. Ladies and gentlemen, the Planet thanks you.  It will also be positive to place, directly in the market stabilisation reserve, 900 million carbon allowances that have been deferred to prevent them from once again inducing the fall in their market price.  The fact that we can adopt this legislative proposal tomorrow is also a signal to our external partners that the European Union continues to treat the fight against climate change seriously. Commissioner, we must not forget the urgent need to reach a legally binding global climate agreement later this year in Paris. We must not forget, Commissioner, that it is up to us Europeans to lead this process. Commissioner, I end by thanking you for demonstrating your full willingness to work to achieve this. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8)).

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – Madam President, I would like to ask Mr Faria a question, who said that the carbon market is the main instrument for combating climate change. I would like you to give me examples of places and times when the carbon market has ever worked to promote, lead to reductions in greenhouse gas emissions. I said here that he stopped giving the signal price: tell me then in what period, namely the European Union emissions trading scheme, when he provided that signal price to lead to the reduction of carbon emissions. Secondly, whether it is available, in the face of the failure of this mechanism, to consider other types of instruments.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – Madam President, once again, the position of the extreme left is pronounced on this instrument. I believe that this instrument is indeed an instrument of full access to climate reduction and I do not see what other response it could give here, unless, in fact, we continue to fight for this greenhouse gas emission to be made through this important instrument. I think that's what we're doing here and treating.

name: Merja Kyllönen
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, my warmest thanks go to the rapporteur and colleagues. I'm here today with some mixed feelings. We are living in a situation where unambitious targets, an economic downturn and, in the first place, too lax the allocation of allowances have led to a huge surplus of allowances. The market economy did not work optimally for coal. Now, with regard to the emissions trading scheme, we have reached this correction. It may not be the fulfillment of the dream that I myself had to rectify the situation, but it is a step forward.  That is why I can see that I can be prepared to vote in favour of the motion, because I am a realist and perhaps even an optimist in the sense that I would rather fix the old one than make time to look for completely new ways. I know that there are many members of my group who do not see this as a solution and who do not believe that we can get a valid instrument from the emissions trading scheme by correcting it. I hope that this, these issues, will not end the debate, but we will find solutions so that we can keep the climate targets ... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank Ivo Belet for the great work he has been doing. We all know how difficult it is to get a compromise on ETS. Somehow this is always a fun debate in the plenary and all over the place and then, in the end, we usually do not get to a compromise. But this time you did manage to get to a compromise, and you should be applauded for that. Thank you also for the great cooperation. We as Greens can also support this compromise, so we will vote in favour because we do think it is an improvement on what we have. However, the work is only beginning, because we know now that we have a stability mechanism, but the biggest issues are still the huge surplus of allowances hanging above the market and what we are going to do in the long term on ETS. These are the issues that we expect the Commissioner to address in his proposal – and hopefully next week, because in the Commission you have the same issues around ETS. It always takes a bit longer than expected, but let us see what we get next week. Just one question to Commissioner Cañete: we are reading news that you are already more or less changing one of the proposals that was such a success, which was that unallocated allowances would go directly into the reserve, but now we see that in your new proposal you are wanting to use 250 million of those allowances for a new entrance reserve, therefore already lowering the ambition for the 2030 target. I hope I have read that completely wrongly and that you will correct me, because otherwise we have to say that next week you will start tinkering with the issue as we felt it, which was an early start and surplus allowances into the reserves. I hope we can keep it that way.

name: Eleonora Evi
