text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is the second attempt to try to fix an instrument that does not work: the ETS system, a system that assumes that serious and effective climate policies can be implemented through the market. In fact, looking at the reality, we understand that the current system has in no way encouraged companies to invest in new technologies. In addition, ETS brings with it a number of disastrous side effects. Firstly, financial speculation, financial brokers have been enriched by the quota market to the detriment of the environment. In addition, fraud: a system that promotes tax evasion, which has already caused some EUR 5 billion in damage to European taxpayers, a market so uncertain that the European Court of Auditors has drawn up a report on the exposure of the credit market to illegal activities due to the intangible nature of securities.  Finally, the issue of human rights. In developing countries, projects are being carried out that are immorally and unlawfully described as sustainable in total disregard for the human rights of the peoples living there. Thus, such a rotten system that even the Pope has called for the role of the financial world to be diminished and for greater emphasis to be placed on the human dimension of the problem.

name: Mireille D'Ornano
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, Madam Vice-President, the European Union wanted to show its commitment to comply with the Kyoto Protocol proposals and recommendations by setting up a market for greenhouse gas emission allowances.  This mechanism was to allow a gradual increase in the price of CO2 and thus initiate a transformation of our economy. Alas, the forecasts were contradicted by reality, once again, as prices collapsed. The creation of a market stability reserve is only a palliative for a system that reproduces market failures.  The real debate should have been about the same system of quota trading and emissions regulation. The countries of the Union have already made a considerable effort in this area, while developing countries are polluting more and more, soon catching up with the level of the countries of the North.  The Kyoto system is failing. Our industries and our competitiveness suffer the consequences. Colleagues, let's get out of the diy of technocrats! (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: blue-card question. – Do you not see that what we are trying to do with the Market Stability Reserve (MSR) is to get the system working? We know that it has not been effective and that it has not been working, but then we have to strive to make it work. If we compare, for example, the industry in your home country with the steel industry in Sweden, I dare to say that the Swedish ones are cleaner, more efficient and more competitive. In addition to the ETS, and the upcoming MSR, we have extra, quite high CO2 taxes. Would you not see that you would benefit from doing the right thing?

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer. Yes, Mr Federley, but how can we defend a system where the most polluting are China and the United States, which are excluded from binding targets? It's a burden on our industries. So we are at a disadvantage. That is why we need to be economically efficient and environmentally realistic.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – The EU CO2 trading scheme was introduced to ensure the EU's emission reduction commitment in a cost-effective manner. The 2020 target is automatically guaranteed by the total quota. Any interference with the functioning of the market, such as the stabilisation reserve, is necessary due to overachieving. This is because of ambition, while the EU is responsible for only 9% of global emissions. After 2020, the free quota would only be left for the most efficient facilities. In other words, an electric power plant or steelworks which has made all possible improvements, but not the most up-to-modern, in addition to the technology in particular, will become uncompetitive and may close by paying an increasing quota. Tens of thousands of jobs will be lost, and the import stream could come from Ukraine, steel from India, where they don't care about carbon emissions. Is that what we want?

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner – I would also like to say, Minister, because they too have given a great hand in reaching this agreement – I believe that it is appropriate in this House to thank Mr Belet and all the coordinators of all the political groups, not forgetting the Presidency of the Council on duty, because it has played an important role, in order to reach an agreement that is the best possible agreement in this context. I have heard someone, in the course of the debate, criticising the ETS: we already knew that the ETS was not perfect and that it should of course be reviewed. But this is a review of the system: the market stability reserve serves to bring the value of CO2 back to levels that are acceptable and that can really provide a stimulus for the industrial system towards sustainability and emission reduction. It is clear that we are talking today about the market stability reserve – which I hope will be approved tomorrow by all the political groups in this House – but one thing is certain: we are talking about this system on the eve of its review.  Commissioner, you have made a commitment, we are sure you will honour it, but we are sure that we must give a strong signal before COP21 in Paris from a Europe that still wants to be a leader in the fight against climate change and that wants to give an indication, also with the instrument that we will vote on tomorrow, of a strong will to have sustainability in the future of our industrial system.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the EU emissions trading scheme is the cornerstone of the European Union’s policy to combat climate change and covers around 45% of the EU’s greenhouse gas emissions. However, the current EU ETS is flawed, as it fails to address problems of oversupply of allowances in the market, which enable the industry to emit greenhouse gases. It is crucial that we take action to repair the ETS and turn it into a mechanism that both controls emissions and promotes investment in clean technologies such as renewables. We need to give stability and predictability to the EU ETS in order both to achieve our climate objectives and to give more stability to industry. I believe the market stability reserve is the right instrument to achieve stability in the market. It has been the position of the S&D to support its introduction as soon as possible by transferring carbon allowances to the market stability reserves in times of over-supply and releasing them in times of under-supply. The EU ETS will be more flexible and more stable and therefore better placed to achieve our climate goals. We must have a balanced system that will benefit our industries and enable a transition to a sustainable and green economy in Europe, which will provide a model for other countries worldwide. We as Europeans owe this to our citizens, our industries and future generations. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I do not agree with this argument that we must, at all costs, dogmatically pursue high emission and renewable energy charges, because there are also countries that are based on the coal economy. But if you already think so, I would like to ask what compensation are to be given to those economies that are traditionally based on coal? What kind of act of solidarity can we expect from such a policy?

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I represent the north-west of England and, as my colleagues will be aware, the mining industry was incredibly important to my region, as are all the technologies and the industries that we are determined to protect through this modernisation of the ETS MSR. We have taken action through the Modernisation Fund, and we will have stability with other Member States to make sure that this is an initiative which both protects the climate and promotes renewables, and protects our industries.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I strongly oppose the agreement on the establishment of a market stability reserve. Firstly, the reserve was adopted on the basis of a bad legal basis and its adoption could have a significant impact on the energy mix in countries such as my homeland Poland. The procedure should be conducted on the basis of unanimity rather than a majority in the Council.  Secondly, emissions per capita in Poland are only slightly above the EU average. It is worth recalling that old Member States such as Germany, Belgium, Luxembourg have much higher emissions per capita, and the introduction of the reserve will mainly hit consumers and industry in Poland due to our specific energy structure. From this point of view, it is a measure with a cost completely disproportionate to the benefits.  Thirdly, I am against attempts to control the price of emissions, such an artificial attempt to control the price. Today, this emissions are cheap because of the economic crisis and raising the price of emissions will not affect a faster exit from the crisis. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the "blue card" (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. –Listening to the previous speech, I was reminded whether there is actually a rational explanation for someone starting to object to making matters affecting our lives part of the market. The whole of Europe wants to adapt to this situation, which promises terrible perilous perspectives. It is not really possible to look for individual paths. So I'm asking Congresswoman... (the President withdraws the floor)

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – In accordance with the principles of the Treaties, each Member State has the right to decide on its energy mix. This is also linked to the principle of solidarity. Please take into account the energy specificity of Polish industry – for us, the principles that you propose are absolutely unacceptable. They will deepen the gap between a rich, developed Europe and a country such as Poland, which aspires to make its citizens live better.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to express thanks from Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy, who, owing to unexpected reasons, could not be here today, and also from myself for the good work that the rapporteur, Ivo Belet, has done here. He was able to gather different political forces in a good and strong compromise; even though we, as ALDE, would have preferred to go even further, we know that you were working hard to get the different sides together. We saw in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) – where all political confidence between the parties fell apart – how hard it can be. So you actually made a great political achievement here. Secondly, I would like to refer to some of the colleagues to say that it is impossible, that we are driving industry out of Europe. We can see that we still have strong industries in Europe, and these are mainly the ones which have already enacted the reforms that you need in order to lower emissions. We can see that the United States is performing better when it comes to the steel industry today, and we can see that China is performing better when it comes to the cement industry. Next week, when Commissioner Cañete and his colleagues present a review on the ETS, we will have a new chance to take the further steps we need in order to have a modern and progressive industry that is competitive in Europe.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, let me also thank my colleague for the prepared report, because I think it is quite crucial. The aim of this proposal is to make structural changes to the ETS so that the surplus of billions of allowances accumulating in the system since 2009 is finally settled. Unfortunately, this is not the first attempt to kick-start the already collapsed allowance trading system several times, and I must say that I am becoming increasingly sceptical about this instrument after previous experience. The allowances market can only serve to reduce greenhouse gas production in the short term as a temporary complement to legally binding air protection commitments. Notwithstanding the fact that we still lack legislation on segment issues in the economy most at risk of carbon leakage in the long term, the so-called carbon leakage. The principle of reducing greenhouse gas emissions is based on a political agreement and we need a political agreement at the highest level. But without an agreement between China, India, the US, and South America on legally binding and, above all, enforceable commitments, this will not work. Our efforts must not only focus on the long-term maintenance and management of the emission allowance market, but above all must focus on globally binding agreements between all the major players at the forthcoming Conference in Paris.

name: Peter Eriksson (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I have to say that I have also often despaired about this emissions trading scheme that we have had in Europe. It is, of course, the tool at European level that we have had, while the Member States have had the majority of the tools that have actually existed, but when it has not worked for a long time, you have to think about what the problem is. That is why I am very pleased, even as shadow rapporteur in the Committee on Industry, that an agreement was reached which now represents a clear step forward. The commission's proposal was, in fact, spectacularly weak, so that I find it extremely important and gratifying that a proper step forward has now been agreed and that Parliament has contributed to it, but we must not forget that this will not be enough to make the system work. Further steps are needed, and I hope that Mr Cañete and the Commission will come up with it in a short time, so that we can say that europe is taking its responsibilities in this area.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, the rapporteur supports the Commission’s proposal to introduce a market stability reserve on the basis that this reform will govern fluctuations in the market, providing long-term predictability and stability to European industries. This is untrue. Mechanisms like the ETS, the back-loading system and now the MSR are one of the main causes of the impoverishment of our industries. The idea that the ETS and its traded CO2 emissions will send a signal to the market, thus promoting energy conservation and new low-carbon technologies, has proved to be a failure. Recognising the ongoing failure of the ETS, the Commission now proposes to introduce a market stability reserve. However, what many do not realise is that a market mechanism, requiring constant regulatory intervention to maintain the price levels originally foreseen, is in itself a contradiction, as markets are supposed to set their own prices autonomously. We should not support plant closures, carbon leakage, and industry and job losses. We need to reinvigorate the declining EU economy with a new competitive approach.

name: Olaf Stuger (ENF).
text: – The EU is a bad luck magnet. It attracts failure, whether it is the Greek issue or the migrant problem, and in this case ETS. It never worked, it doesn't work now, and it's never going to work. The smiling third parties are the airlines from China and the Middle East. They're laughing at me. They don't even have to compete. That's what their best friend, the EU, does. Because it makes plane tickets so expensive that the passengers automatically switch to these airlines. The Turks, shaking with laughter, are building all the money they get from the EU, the largest airport in the world, just to wipe Amsterdam-Schiphol off the map. The most harmful CO2 comes from the mouths of the people in the Brussels committees. If a CO2 tax is to be in place, it must be done on the dangerous ly the part of these bureaucrats. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Stuger mentioned that the over-allocation of allowances has led to a significant destabilisation of the system. Mr Stuger, do you think that the creation of the market stability reserves is going to stabilise the market in the end?

name: Olaf Stuger (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer. – All I am saying here is that everything that is made up here has only one effect and that is destabilisation. This can be seen in cooperation within the EU. You can tell by the migrants. You can see that on the Greek issue. Everything the EU deals with here is destabilising and is a failure. That's only going to get worse. This House must be aware of this.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Ivo Belet, and all those who helped him, for reaching this agreement on 5 May on the creation of the ETS Market Stability Reserve, which should encourage companies to invest in low-carbon technologies, while allowing them to remain competitive on the international stage.  This reserve, as proposed today, takes into account the concerns of sectors that are exposed to CO2 leakage. It's very important. In fact, Commissioner, we will be very vigilant. We will continue these efforts in the revision of the ETS Directive to be published next week.  Some companies have already made enormous efforts: they have halved their CO2 emissions over the last thirty years and now they know that they will not be able to go any further because they do not have the right technologies and they have made all the necessary efforts. To force them to have more ambition would be to put them in great difficulty - I am thinking particularly of the steel sector.  Within the EPP group, we also wanted an innovation fund to be provided for the auctioning of emission allowances. I welcome the Commission's commitment to create such a EUR 50 million fund. It is certainly too weak, but it is a start and it will at least have the merit to exist. It is a concrete way to support the technologies of the future.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Grazzi President u ppermettili billi nibda billi nirringrazzja lir-rapporteur u anki lix-shadow rapporteurs li ħadmu fuq dan li qegħdin nitkellmu llum għaliex bħala omm ta' tifel żgħir nixtieq li ibni jgħix f'ambjent nadif u li 'l quddiem ikollu impjieg ta' kwalità fl-Ewropa. Huwa dan il-bilan大 li rridu nilħqu u dan għandu jkun l-għan ewlieni tal-ETS. Għaxar snin beauty l-Unjoni Ewropea waqqfet din is-sistema bħala l-għodda ewlenija tagħha kontra t-tibdil fil-klima imma l-implimentazzjoni tas-sistema kif inhiħalissa ftit li xejn qed talli effett. Fuq naħa l-ETS waslet għat-tnaqqis fil-Green House Gas Emissions, għalkemm parti minn dan it-tnaqqis jista' jkun dovut għall-kriżi ekonomika, u min-naħa l-oħra l-ETS baqgħet i offrietx prezz tajjeb biex tinħentiva d-dħul ta' teknoloġiji innovavitti u sorsi aktar aktar nodfa. L-Emissions Trading Scheme kif inhi bħalissa mhijiex taħdem kif suppost. Hemm ammont żejjed ta' allowances li rridu nindirizzaw u nirranġaw u biex din is-sistema tkun effettiva fi żmien raġonevoli rridu nimplimentaw il-Market Stability Reserve malajr kemm jista' jkun u ikeertament mhux aktar tard mill-2019. Il-Market Stability Reserve għandha tipprovdi stabilità u tipprevjeni volatilità fil-prezzijiet. Għandha tibgħat sinjal qawwi u tgħin flower-industrija tippjana fit-tul filwaqt li tippromwovi investiment f'teknoloġija aktar innovattiva u aktar nadifa. Is-su大大ess jew il-falliment tal-ETS se jinfluwenza b'mod dirett l-emissjonijiet fl-Ewropa u t-tibdil fil-klima. Irridu sistema b'saħħitha biex innaqqsu l-emissjonijiet bl-aktar mod effettiv u bl-anqas spejjeż filwaqt li ngħinu lill-industriji Ewropej jibqgħu fil-tag kontinentħna u jibqgħu kompetivit.

name: Julie Girling (ECR).
text: – Madam President, of course ETS as a policy instrument is not perfect, but it is the key policy instrument that we have here in the EU, and it is interesting that those today who have criticised it have done just that. That is all they have done, they have criticised it. They have come up with no concrete idea of how else we would reduce greenhouse gases, and on that basis one can only conclude that they have no concern about decreasing greenhouse gases. In fact, in many cases I am well aware that they deny that there is any problem at all with greenhouse gases, and it is unfortunate that this sort of argument is still going on here, because it certainly is way out of the mainstream of thinking on the science of these issues. I would like to just mention one issue, and that is carbon leakage. We need to take into account the competitiveness of industry. This is not incompatible with our climate change objectives, and it is very annoying to hear yet again today a polarisation of these arguments. We talk about converting to low-carbon technologies – only yesterday, Mr. Timmermans sat here and told us that the future of European industry is in smart green technology – but in order to advance that we need to have investment, we need to be profitable and we need to be able to have the funds to go forward and make that change.

name: Cornelia Ernst (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The glass is half full or half empty – you can agree on it. I think, however, that it is extremely important to say: yes, it is half full. And it is good that something should happen and that something has to happen. We are glad that the launch is even taking place earlier than the Commission has proposed, namely by two years. It is good that we are creating a flexible mechanism. This really has to be seen as progress. Likewise, the backloading certificates come into the market stability reserve. That's really okay and it's been a long fight. But the problem is: what happens to the huge surplus in the reserve? Why aren't deletions made directly? That was, of course, something we would have liked more. This is also, in a way, inconsistent. So we need to talk about it in the near future. It is important that there is an increase in the price, so that an effect can actually be achieved and that emissions trading does not produce what we really want in terms of climate targets, so that the glass is not only half full at the end.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, we in Europe are facing a crisis of competitiveness, and that crisis is brought on by very high energy prices. We are seeing plants closing, jobs being lost. We are seeing investment moving offshore out of Europe entirely, and yet we in this House today are discussing a policy explicitly designed to make energy more expensive. We should be debating here today how we make energy less expensive. It seems, colleagues, that we have an economic death wish. As my colleague Dr Reid has already said, any market mechanism (so—called) which starts out with a preconceived price level and which requires constant regulatory intervention in order to achieve that price is not, in fact, a market mechanism at all. What it is is an extremely cumbersome and bureaucratic and expensive carbon tax. So why do we not cut to the chase and have a sensible carbon tax or, better still, no carbon tax at all?

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is now clear to everyone that the emissions trading system is not working. But rather than question it, the technocrats, so dear to Mr Schulz, prefer to create a reserve of stability of the ETS market in order to compensate for this proven dysfunction. This deviation from the principle of market self-regulation, to which Europeans are usually very attached, thus appears to be a terrible admission of failure. But for our industries, this solution is akin to the creation of a new indirect tax and it will be all the more damaging to them if their non-European competitors are not subject to it. This system, in fact, only benefits speculators, who unscrupulously use the ecological pretext of reducing CO2 emissions to make pollution a market value like any other. So it's no surprise that high-flying scammers take advantage of this flawed system that you have put in place. This is what seems to have done a group of rogue affairists, with a gigantic fraud estimated at more than 5 billion euros. It was the voices of the National Front and its allies in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy that had helped defeat the Tajani report. You can now count on the votes of the Europe of Nations and Freedoms group to vote against the Belet report.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: "We have been talking about emission reductions for a long period of time. Have we achieved any success as a Union? Of course, we have emission reductions. Has the ECJ worked properly as a market system? We have achieved some of the objectives of this system, but we also know that the prices of CO2 emission permits have fallen. Why did they fall? Not least because there is an economic crisis and fewer emission allowances are needed.  From the outset, I was opposed to the proposal to speed up the introduction of IAS. Why? Because he's breaking some legal certainty. We knew that IAS would be introduced from 2021. This is an agreement that was made in the framework of last year's Autumn European Council on climate, where, among other things, the principle that a stabilisation reserve is to be launched in 2021. I would like to point out that it is also inappropriate to include in IAS the allowances that were to be restored to the market in 2019 and 2020. This, too, breaks some legal certainty. The Council and Parliament thus amend the law that they adopted barely two years ago. This is not an example of good regulation, which should be predictable for businesses, for Member States. The question is, will there be no carbon leakage – that is what we are all worried about – will production from Europe, from the European Union, not be transferred abroad? We do not really know what we will achieve at the Paris Summit, although we would probably like to get a global agreement, so for these reasons we cannot change the systems that we are introducing in the European Union so easily.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the debate on how to move forward in the emission allowance trading system is very long and complicated in Parliament. I am one of the skeptics that further administrative adjustment will solve and stabilise the allowance system in the long term. The problem lies already in the artificial market system itself. I believe that, despite the pre-defined rules for intervening in the allowances market, the system is unsustainable in the long term. Moreover, I also have reservations about the administrative interventions themselves, which may be economically very dangerous for many business entities in the future. I agree with the rapporteur that the Commission needs to have a fundamental debate on the redistribution of free allowances, but I also recommend addressing the very essence of the emission allowance trading scheme. The debate and final vote in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy on this report shows the need for much deeper changes to the whole emissions control system.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work. As a trade union, the European Union is in global competition, including with the United States. And the main condition of the United States energy policy is to ensure that prices are as cheap as possible, while for us in Europe our energy objective is to ensure the lowest possible CO2 emissions. Unfortunately, reducing CO2 emissions has often meant more expensive energy prices, which makes it difficult for our industry to compete, including with the United States, because they simply have cheaper prices. So I do not doubt, colleagues, that it is important, and science proves that mankind as such must reduce CO2 emissions in order to reduce global warming. But we, as politicians, must also think responsibly about the competitiveness of our European industry, so that in the bid to reduce CO2 we do not accidentally raise energy prices so high that our industry becomes uncompetitable. Therefore, we must have some reservations directly for our industry, so that we do not stop exporting products and start exporting an industry that is not our goal. Thanks for the attention!

name: Massimo Paolucci (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the long economic crisis has weakened and undermined the ETS system. The price of co2 allowances has become too low and this low price has not encouraged processes of innovation and eco-sustainable conversion. That is why the stabilisation reserve is good, fair price, certainty for businesses; This is the right way, a path that does not put the environment at odds, the fight against climate change with the productive future of our nation and of Europe. The stabilisation reserve, however, is a necessary but not sufficient measure; we need the reform of the ETS now. We have taken note of the commitments you have made, Commissioner. We need the reform that is required before Paris.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for their work on this dossier. It is a sensitive issue, and getting an agreement that is fair to all Member States is very difficult. Obviously, the differences between our economies, between key industries for each state and between infrastructures are very large. In my country, heavy industry plays a very important role, which means that our country is more exposed to the impact of a higher carbon price and it is very costly to protect industry through state aid, as other countries do. I believe that we need to assess the option of providing compensation or financial support at European level for industries affected by the indirect costs of the EU certificate trading scheme. I call on the Commission to consider this proposal as part of the forthcoming review of the ETS mechanism. Apart from these difficulties, the mechanism is an important pillar of EU climate change policy and we are on track of the 2020 targets.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this is a very important proposal, and certainly my colleague Ivo Belet has done tremendous work. I saw him in action, and he has come up with a very sensible solution, which I think will be very helpful to Commissioner Cañete when he makes his report on 15 July. Certainly, we have two targets: one is to reduce emissions in the European Union by 40% by 2030, and the other is to grow industry by 20% of GDP. They are not mutually incompatible – in fact they can both be achieved by sensible proposals. Certainly, with developing technology, and particularly with the proposals here on ETS and the very sensible 2019 starting date, we can make a lot of progress. I am the rapporteur for the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) on Climate Change in Paris, and hopefully this will lead to a successful summit.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as the European Parliament's rapporteur on COP 21, I would like to thank you, Commissioner Arias Caete, for the creation of this ethese market stability reserve, which we will endorse tomorrow in the plenary vote. It will effectively reduce the surplus of quotas and gradually restore confidence in this European instrument.  But by the COP 21 of December 2015, in Paris, and quickly, a real reform of the CO2 trading system is needed to create an independent market authority of the ETS and set the targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, both at EU and national level.  This tool will enable us, Commissioner, to strengthen the European Union's international credibility in the fight against climate change.  This is a great prospect for THE COP 21 next December.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the legislative proposal to reform the European Emissions Trading System proposes the establishment of a reserve for the stability of the system market and as a solution to the imbalances between the supply and demand of emission allowances. These imbalances led to a surplus of around two billion emission allowances in the 2013-2020 trading period and thus reduced incentives for low-carbon investments. The aim is therefore to correct the shortcomings of the system in order to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The creation of a market stability reserve for the existing system will be ineffective if serious and sustainable investments for alternative energy sources are not planned and financed.  Without the above investments, tackling climate change and the European Union's transition to a sustainable low-carbon economy will remain an empty letter.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, I want to welcome this Commission proposal because I see it as a step forward, a step in the right direction to try to stabilise the market. The principled contradiction, which is emissions reduction and growth of the economy, is only a contradiction in principle. In fact, it can be resolved precisely by investing heavily in innovation and research that has already yielded results to some extent.   However, what I would like to specifically warn the Commission about, what will we do with those investments that are there, in front of us and that want to be done by further carbonising our industry, especially coal-based energy production – do we have an answer to such demands? And secondly, I think it would be good to think about a special policy towards Poland because Poland is in the most unenviable situation of all EU countries when it comes to the coal industry that is very much present in Poland.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, there are questions which carbon market advocates simply cannot answer.  What structural changes have been achieved to date with resources to market instruments such as emissions trading? None, zero. What alternatives do you have to a market approach? Neither did we see today here, zero.  The carbon market has already proven that it is ineffective and that it is perverse, has provided fabulous profits to large polluters, has proved to be permeable to numerous failures and frauds, some of which have hurt the public bank by billions of euros. Given the evidence of failure, the solution is not that anything changes so that everything remains the same, as the heralds of market solutions argue. The solution is to change approach, to a regulatory and regulatory approach, effective, from the point of view of environmental objectives to be achieved and socially fair.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all of you for this debate, which showed that we have reached a balanced compromise. Now it is time to look forward. Allow me to recall the broader context. An important milestone for the European Union ETS has been achieved. We can now turn this page and concentrate on our efforts to complete the architecture of the European Union ETS for the period after 2020. Last year I committed here to translate the ETS-related elements of the 2030 Climate and Energy Policy Framework into legislation swiftly after the Market Stability Reserve (MSR) had been agreed. I will keep my promise. It is our firm intention for the Commission to present a legislative proposal on the revision of the European Union ETS next week, on 15 July. This proposal will constitute an important part of the work on the achievement of our resilient Energy Union with a forward-looking climate change policy, which is a key political priority for the Juncker Commission. It will focus on the aspects on which the European leaders gave us their guidance in October 2014. Firstly, free allocation to industry will be continued to ensure that sectors at genuine risk of carbon leakage will be adequately protected. Secondly, the proposal will establish a modernisation fund for modernisation of the energy systems in lower—income Member States. The option of free allocation of allowances to modernise electricity generation in the same Member States will also be continued, but transparency will be considerably enhanced. Finally, support for the development of low-carbon innovation will be continued through an innovation plan which, compared to the current NER300 facility, will see its scope extended to industrial innovation projects. Given the variety of uses addressed in the future proposal, I expect a challenging, yet constructive, legislative debate. I sincerely hope that we will be able to continue the positive cooperation that we have been able to establish through the work on the Market Stability Reserve. I am confident that we will be able to reach a good deal for the climate, for the competitiveness of European industry and for European citizens.

name: Ivo Belet
text: Rapporteur. I think we can say that the decision we are going to vote on tomorrow is indeed not perfect. You can't do that. The perfect and the ideal is often the opposite of the good or 'the enemy of good', as they say. With regard to the date, the innovation fund and so on, we could perhaps have gone even further, made even better decisions, but it is a compromise. I think we can say that this decision deserves the approval of this House, because it is indeed an important step forward in the fight against global warming. I also remember what Mr Girling said. Those who are critical, here in this House, there is nothing wrong with that. But then you expect alternatives to be put on the table. I haven't heard any alternatives. It seems to me, therefore, a little too easy to give meaningless criticism. So I would say: give this proposal for a decision tomorrow the benefit of the doubt. I repeat that colleagues from Poland and other Member States are all too easily forgetting to mention that there are very important exceptions and also new initiatives and measures in place to assist the so-called low-income countries. I am thinking of Member States where, for example, the coal industry and coal generation still have an important place. The Commissioner has just referred to an exception for the energy sector, to the modernisation fund and to the Solidarity Fund. These are very important funds with billions of euros in them that can help those countries. The next step is indeed next week. The Commissioner has announced it: 15 July, the fundamental ETS reform. The work is obviously not finished. I suggest that we already agree that we are not too defensive in dealing with this, that we are doing so in a future-oriented manner, but also, as the Commissioner rightly pointed out, selectively, that we should indeed build in guarantees for the energy-intensive industry that is subject to carbon leakage, that we should help the industry that cannot, for example, pass on electricity costs. Finally, Mr President, climate protection on the one hand and going for jobs and a further expansion of industry here in Europe on the other, on the other hand, there is absolutely no need to be enemies of each other, quite the contrary.

name: n/a
text: – The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 8 July 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – We have been witnessing the introduction of the EU ETS as an important element of the climate and energy package for a long time. The administrative interference and stabilisation of this system by creating a so-called CO2 reserve in the single market makes it pseudo-market- Mr Tajani rightly stated that the instability in this system adversely affects the competitiveness of industry. But what kind of competitiveness is it about? The question must be asked: how does the EU ETS affect the fair competitiveness of Member States? I have doubts. We are therefore faced with a desperate attempt to get out of the previous unfavourable regulatory decisions of the pseudo-market system through further regulation. Let us therefore have the courage to say that this is a system that has not passed the test and that it should be rejected because it does not take into account, for example, agriculture, forestry, etc., and therefore to make money by, for example, absorbing CO2, which could, after all, have a positive impact on the formation of the amount of this gas at auction. The climate and energy package must be modernised by abandoning the existing EU ETS or rejecting it in its entirety. The focus must be on so-called benchmarking and efficiency criteria. Only scientific and technical progress, rather than imposing emission limits, and increasing the efficiency of primary energy conversion, transmission and final efficiency will reduce CO2 emissions per unit of energy produced and other material production.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The Market Stability Reserve is a first step in the reform of the European Emissions Trading System. The plan is to reduce the oversupply of emission allowances in order to achieve price stability. At present, the surplus of allowances that could be added to the market stability reserve is two million units. With a certificate price of 7.50 euros, this corresponds to a value of 15 billion euros. Similarly, the 900 million allowances should be moved from backloading to the market stability reserve and not returned to the market. The present compromise provides for the introduction of the market stability reserve to start as early as 2019 and not 2021, as stated in the Commission proposal. There are also different approaches to the upper and lower limits of allowances, from when certificates are withdrawn from the market or returned to the market. What is completely lacking in this report, however, is a new regulation on carbon leakage measures, in other words a new regulation for the granting of allowances, which are of the utmost importance, particularly for the energy-intensive industry.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. – The reform of greenhouse gas emission allowances is one of the most important issues in terms of climate change policy today. I believe that the solution proposed by the European Commission to create a market stability reserve will help to solve the current problems of the emissions trading system by reducing the excess allowances generated by the economic crisis on the market, regulating their price, and encouraging industry to invest in modern, environmentally friendly technological solutions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Looking at the issues and concerns raised by the Member States, the Council, the European Parliament, industry, environmental organisations, we can say that the agreement reached should strike a balance between europe's high environmental standards and industrial interests.  While this proposal addresses the problem of surplus allowances to be auctioned, it does not address the issues relating to the allocation of free allowances or the provisions governing carbon leakage. An effective reform of emissions trading should ensure that industry sensitive to energy resources does not transfer their production capacity to third countries outside the European Union where there are no such high environmental standards. It is therefore essential that the Commission submit its proposals for measures to reduce the risk of carbon leakage as soon as possible. I hope that these measures will help to strike a balance between the European Union's ambitious environmental objectives and industrial action without reducing competitiveness.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. – I think that we can be satisfied with the introduction of a mechanism to help restore the European Emissions Trading System (ETS). However, too much optimism is out of place. Now a first step is being taken. However, structural problems will not solve all this, and this will have to be done with the ETS review proposed by the Commission next week. The proposed stability mechanism, the so-called market stability reserve, will regulate the lack of trade in supply and demand of allowances by slowly placing the large surplus of unused allowances in a reserve. However, this cannot be a permanent solution. The allowances that come into reserve remain hanging over the market like a thunder cloud. If we want to stimulate green technology and end our fossil addiction, we need a high CO2 price. We can't get there just by introducing a reserve. The European Commission will come forward next week with a proposal for the ETS rules after 2020. This review will hopefully address the structural problems, such as the removal of unused emission rights and a halt to the plentiful giving away of free rights. So the real fight is about to begin.

name: Preşedinte.
text: – The next item is the debate on José Manuel Fernandes' report, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the 2016 Budget - Mandate for trilogue (2015/2074(BUD)) (A8-0217/2015).

name: José Manuel Fernandes
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, Mr Vice-President, Commissioner Georgieva, ladies and gentlemen, it should be recalled that the European Union budget is a small budget: it has about 1% of gross national income and corresponds to just over EUR 140 billion in payments, in a European Union which has been increasing its powers and which has also expanded in terms of the Member States.  The European Union budget, which, if we want to compare it with that of the United States, is 1 % of gross national income, while that of the United States is about 20 % of GDP. But it is a budget that has a high added value, I would even say enormous added value, given the fact that 94 % of the budget is for investment and only 6 % of this budget corresponds to administrative expenditure and operating expenditure. And it is a budget that represents in many Member States more than 50 % of public investment. A budget also for which we set priorities for 2016. What we called the three "E": employment, business, and in particular small and medium-sized enterprises, and entrepreneurship. This has consequences in terms of programmes, from the youth employment initiative. We know that there has been an advance of EUR 6 billion for 2014 and 2015, but we in 2016 want this programme to continue and therefore we want authorisation costs for this programme.  It is clear that programmes such as the Cosmos, programmes such as Horizon 2020, or the Connecting Europe Mechanism, which also contribute, which are in rubric 1a, should pay special attention, but we do not forget internal solidarity.  In internal solidarity, we have the cohesion policy which also helps employment, also helps entrepreneurship, innovation and research. In this cohesion policy, in addition to this objective and all the objectives inherent to it, the objective of corresponding to the internal solidarity of helping the poorest regions, the Most Difficult Member States and also of helping the social rise of people can never be forgotten. Internal solidarity is also a goal for us.  As far as external solidarity is not, we must not forget what is happening in the European Union, what is happening in Ukraine, Syria, but also what is happening to refugees, what is happening in the Mediterranean and, in this sense, rubric 3 and rubric 4 are also very important for us in these areas.  And that's also why we say that the cuts that are made to agencies cannot be blind cuts. We also have, when we look at a staff cut, to check the consequences of that cut, the costs that this has. We have financial oversight agencies where, if we reduce staff, this will come at a cost. We have migration agencies, for example, where if we reduce staff, this has a higher cost than the one that comes from the reduction itself.  Then we also demand that commitments be respected, that we respect the plan we have defined in terms of payments, that the Multiannual Financial Framework be respected, that the flexibility that we want and ask for is respected.  And, in essence, we hope that the Council will have an attitude of respect for the commitments, of consistency with the declarations and proclamations that it has made, that it too will put the sufficient funds for the longings, for the objectives to which we all propose.  I end up thanking all the shadow rapporteur colleagues, all the political groups that have contributed to this report and for this mandate where Parliament wants to have great strength and great unity.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Fernandes for putting forward a very thoughtful mandate for the 2016 draft budget for Parliament’s participation in forthcoming negotiations. As you said, many have contributed to coming up with a thorough description of which priorities, why these priorities and how best we can make use of the funding we have at our disposal. We support the priorities that Parliament has outlined. Yes, we need to focus on a revival of our economy. You call it the three E’s – employment, enterprises and entrepreneurship. We need this if we want to see Europe growing again, and growing to a point that allows us to strive for both higher competitiveness and a better quality of life for our people. You have been very supportive of the key initiatives of the Commission, including the investment plan. We have just adopted an amending letter, and I am very grateful that it is based on the agreement we have achieved and that we can put it forward. We also agree with you that, in addition to focusing on growth, we have to retain solidarity at home and with those who count on us in dire circumstances outside the European Union, especially people who are escaping wars and especially when this also turns into an eternal problem for the European Union. This is why, as we have put forward the payment appropriations, we have been very precise in where we need to have an increase in budgets, especially in terms of payments, so we can underpin these priorities. We have EUR 143.5 billion, or a 1.6% increase in total payments, to trim down the shortage of payments from previous years, and we have concentrated on areas where the needs are most profound. For example, in Heading 4 we have proposed a 28.5% increase, and for Erasmus, we have proposed a 30% increase. In the philosophy that we have put forward, what dominates is that we are asking for what is needed – no more, no less – and we count on Parliament to support us in this prudent approach to the budget. I want to stress that, with the encouragement of Parliament, we have been improving our forecast capabilities. This allows us, together, to make the best possible allocation of our scarce resources and to manage payments in the future, so that the drama we had in 2014 will not be repeated. I want to take this opportunity to thank you for this whole vote today on our amending budgets and the payment plan. Obviously we count in the future on that firm execution of commitments we make to our citizens. If we say we drew on that schedule, we drew on the schedule we have agreed and with the objectives that we have agreed. I am looking at the forthcoming first trilogue on 14 July as a place where we will together promote exactly this responsibility to our citizens, putting our money where our mouth is.

name: Arne Lietz
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. Mr President, I would like to thank the As draftsman of the opinion in the Committee on Development, I put two key points in the foreground. Firstly, there is an urgent need to increase spending on humanitarian aid in 2016. As a global player, the European Union must cope with a particularly large number of emergencies. However, this also includes humanitarian crises such as those in Iraq, Syria, South Sudan, but also Ukraine. With regard to the budget, the increase in humanitarian aid must not only be the case with commitments, but above all with payments. This is the only way to ensure that the funds are immediately available to people in need. Secondly, I would like to point out once again that not all EU Member States have fulfilled their commitment to spend 0.7% of their gross national income on development cooperation. This goal should have been achieved as early as 2015. The EU must mobilise enough resources in its budget for development work to support this effect.

name: Deirdre Clune
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Mr President, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL) wanted to have a particular emphasis in the budget on job creation measures, jobs and growth strategy, which we all support, and the three E’s: enterprise, employment and entrepreneurship. How are we going to do that? Supporting SMEs is where we would like to see a focus, because SMEs are the backbone of all our economies, being 90% of businesses across Europe. Particularly, the area of microfinance is something that can really be established to support SMEs because governments, commissions, councils do not actually create jobs, but they certainly can contribute to creating the environment within which jobs can flourish. Of course, within the employment area, youth unemployment is a very serious issue. We are continuing with this debate here, and we want to see a strong focus on this in the budget opinion of this Parliament, and also, indeed, on the need to re-skill, particularly in fields where job seekers can benefit, like the IT sector and retrofitting of buildings. There is huge potential there, and the EMPL Committee wants to see a strong focus in these areas in the opinion.

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we thank you for what you have done, but I believe that there is still much more to be done. I would, of course, like to thank Mr Fernandes for his work. Unfortunately, budgetary experience in recent years has taught us that the scarcity of payment appropriations often prevents the implementation at cruising speed of certain programmes that have difficulties and delays, as was the case, for example, with the LIFE programme. On behalf of the ENVI Committee, I call for the resources allocated to all the lines devoted to the environment, public health and food safety, although contained in numerical terms, to be in line with multiannual programming and at least to be maintained at the levels of previous years. We also have a number of programmes dedicated to heading 3, which are related to consumer protection and civil protection, for which we are calling for them to be given the necessary attention, given the great usefulness in terms of their impact on citizens' lives. A final comment only for the agencies: the ENVI Committee monitors a number of agencies that frequently acquire external resources to carry out their work. The programme of containment of agency staff often runs counter to the objectives and the objectives.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – As ITRE rapporteur for the 2016 budget, I continue to oppose the savings in, among other things, the successful Horizon 2020 research programme to finance the Juncker Plan. I believe that the programme is a clear example of where Europe can add value. Flanders is one of the European leaders when it comes to research and innovation, not least thanks to European support. I'm proud of that. I will therefore continue to call for this support to be safeguarded. I cannot repeat enough that we have to do it again year after year. Finally, I would like to stress that this procedure must not be misused to increase the European budget. Like the Member States, the European Union must also make a move.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – As rapporteur for the budget of the IMCO Commission, I believe that the single market, including consumer policy, must remain a key and priority area, especially for economic growth. However, it is very important that this area also has adequate budget lines. I believe that the Commission's figures in the May proposal provide an appropriate framework for this, and I thank you for that. I would like to stress the need for a balanced, adequate financial framework for the functioning of the customs union and for the functioning of standardisation bodies. In a rapidly changing environment like the one we live in, it is very important to put the right emphasis on standards. However, I would like to highlight a sore point on which I would like to draw the Commissioner's attention. This is the Single Market Forum. As the Commissioner knows, this is the last year of preparatory work, when this forum still exists in this form. We want this to remain in this content. I would like to hear some encouraging words in this area.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the European Commission, the money given through the Structural Funds is a significant, drastic boost to economic activity through synergies in all the countries of the European Union, but in fact the only source of funding for countries in crisis for both the economy and social cohesion. For this to happen in practice, it is urgent to implement without divergence the timetable presented by the European Commission for solving the problem of outstanding payments from the previous programming period.  It's obvious we're in danger of getting in the face of an avalanche. Think about what is happening in my country, Greece, where the financial system has been frozen and payments from the European Union are not reaching the recipients. When revising the multiannual financial framework in 2016 we must also take into account the new data created by the crisis in the countries affected. We must ensure that EFSI returns in full, together with the profits, the funds it uses from HORIZON and SES.  We have to rush. To ensure that new taxpayers' money reaches the real economy and not repeat the same mistakes.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Fernandes, who has been able to set up a genuine consultation with the various committees in preparation for this trilogue. The Committee on Budgets will work on this issue on 14 July. I would like to reiterate a number of priorities in this negotiation. First of all, I believe that we need at least a stable budget, particularly that of agriculture. It is good to set up the European Fund for Strategic Investments, but it is also a pity to draw on the budget lines. I think we need to protect those budget lines, and of course those relating to agriculture.  I also think it is imperative to keep the crisis reserve, because agriculture is going to face, unfortunately, repeated crises, whether it is the Russian crisis that we are experiencing today, the milk crisis that is looming, or that caused by various predators of agriculture. We must be very vigilant on these issues and absolutely maintain this reserve of crisis.  We also need to be able to use ceiling margins and feed a number of programs: I am thinking in particular of the milk distribution programme in schools.  Agriculture is indeed an essential element, as it is the most integrated policy in the European Union. This should not prevent us from being extremely attentive to other policies. I am thinking in particular of heading 1b on the Structural Funds, as has already been mentioned, and on the Youth Guarantee, which is very important for the future of the Union. We have to be able to guarantee that funding. You also know that the issue of migration has been debated for a long time. We need to fund these immigrations or rather find a solution to this problem.  Finally, we must pay close attention to the imbalance between payment appropriations and commitment appropriations, and we will be very vigilant about this in the Committee on Budgets.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – The culture of which we are so proud in Europe should have the support not only of nation States, of the Member States, but also of interest in the European Parliament. Without high-quality education, without interest in participating in culture, we will be weaker, we will be less creative, and therefore also less effective in raising funds. For every member of the Committee on Culture, the most important is the young audience, the one who starts the education, the one who continues it, and the one who is the first recipient of culture.  What is welcome is the increase in support for programmes, mainly scholarship programmes, for programmes such as Erasmus+, but also for Creative Europe and Europe for Citizens. It is worrying that the importance of pilot schemes, those that have already been tested, and the importance of pilot development programmes is not underestimated.  On behalf of the Committee on Culture, I would like to draw attention to the importance of programmes such as Euranet plus or projects aimed at collecting and processing extremely valuable information on artistic events, such as various festivals.

name: Barbara Matera
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mr Fernandes for the work he is doing and for the conviction and dedication with which he is working on this project. As draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, I would like to stress that gender equality must be promoted in all Eu ropean Union policies. I would ask Mr Fernandes to insist during the trialogue on the importance of allocating funding to support programmes for women's entrepreneurship, such as the COSME programme, the European Social Fund and the youth employment initiative. Furthermore, in the light of the many feminicides and acts of violence suffered by women on a daily basis, I stress the importance of increasing expenditure to support awareness-raising and awareness campaigns against gender stereotypes and, above all, the need and importance of continuing to maintain the Daphne programme.

name: Reimer Böge
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I strongly support the priorities set out by our rapporteur, José Manuel Fernandes, and I am now concentrating on the discussions in the Committee on External Trade on the 2016 budget. We already believe that the budget should take into account the increasing importance of trade policy and the changed geopolitical landscape, and that a good budget is also needed. We believe that the increasing trade activities of the Commission services must also be taken into account here and that, above all, we have one thing to do more in the future: to pay more attention to the proper management of trade agreements, in particular for interim and ex-post evaluations and their impact, more intensively than before, while also taking greater account of the assessment of the Court of Auditors' special report. It is clear that the very emotionally overblown debate on globalisation also makes it necessary to make EU funds available for an effective communication strategy. In addition, the 2016 budget should take into account the successes of the 9th WTO Ministerial Conference and, above all, provide sufficient funds for trade-related aid for trade for the least developed countries to provide technical assistance and capacity-building. I would also point out that the discussion we are having on financial support for European initiatives for SME internationalisation is of paramount importance.

name: Jens Geier
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Vice-President Georgieva, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. We have had many disputes with the Council in the past, and I have little hope, but a little hope, that we can reach a new era. If we look at the payment crisis that I hope is behind us, the Council has gone through all phases of psychotherapy, from denial to catharsis to the beginning of healing. So I am looking forward to a situation where, a few weeks ago, the institutions agreed in a paper on how the payment crisis will be managed. Now I very much hope, ladies and gentlemen, that the Luxembourg Presidency can remember very carefully what the Latvian has agreed. Against this background, I wonder: if the Council now looks at the draft budget and changes it, does it do so arbitrarily, as we have seen in recent years, or is the Council's policy a recognisable political priority? This is all the more important because, to my not insinuable surprise, the Commission has presented a draft budget in which payments and commitments are as far apart as ten billion. This is certainly not a cardboard stick. And this is happening in a situation where the EU is facing considerable difficulties; we talk about it every part of the week. I am thinking of the crises in the Middle East, I am thinking of the failed state of Libya, and I am thinking of the Ukraine crisis, to name but a few. If the budget is a policy in figures, then the European Union's foreign policy instruments must be effective. This is not only due to money, but also to money. The same applies to the migration policy instruments that we are developing. We are facing an additional challenge because we need to include the EFSI in this budget. We have agreed on funding, which means that one billion more will be taken out of the margins. However, this still means five billion from the current budget. As you can see, ladies and gentlemen, the challenges are great. I hope that we will no longer be talking about deletions, but about the political design of the budget. That would be a new era.

name: Bernd Kölmel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Thank you very much, Mr President. Thank you also, Vice-President Georgieva, for the excellent cooperation in drawing up this proposal. On the one hand, we, the ECR Group, are very pleased that this budget is taking steps in the right direction. At the same time, however, we are also a little sad that, in the end, the status quo is still being continued, especially – and I must also contradict the rather medical analysis of the previous speaker, Mr Geier, whom I very much appreciate – I do not see that we are actually tackling the problem of unpaid bills when, at the same time, we are providing for commitments of EUR 153 billion and payment of EUR 143 billion. Then there is simply EUR 10 billion missing, and they will not disintegrate. I would be very pleased if we in Parliament had the courage to take a really great approach to reform, which does not always add together what is desirable, and in the end unpaid bills come out.

name: Nedzhmi Ali
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, José Manuel Fernandes, on his comprehensive report because it represents a good basis for the trilogue. The general assessment of the presented budget for 2016 reveals that it abides by the previously-set priorities – employment, enterprise and entrepreneurship. While commitments are going down by 5.2%, real payments are calculated to increase by 1.6%. Thus we expect to melt down the huge pile of backlogs and to reach a sustainable level by the end of 2016. In this regard, we appreciate the cooperation between the Committee on Budgets and Commissioner Georgieva in drafting the budget and in implementing the Commission’s pledges at the beginning of this mandate. The budget supports the political priorities: the Energy Union; the Digital Single Market; the European Programme for Education, Training, Sport and Youth; increasing competitiveness; support for farmers; and, of course payments to EFSI. The EU budget also responds to new developments in Europe’s neighbourhood and beyond. While an increased budget will be available to tackle today’s immigration challenges, we should be very careful, because the increasing pressure of migration flows means that the level of the ceiling set in the MFF could be outdated. At the same time, we should be aware that the above—mentioned increase in payment appropriations, taking into account inflation, reveals that there is almost no increase in real terms. This means that the overall weight of the EU budget remains more or less the same. Furthermore, we must ask ourselves: is it appropriate to reduce, by 4%, the financial resources for economic, social and territorial cohesion when there is a growing division between regions and states within the Union? Generally, we support the main goals of the budget to boost innovation, create jobs, deal more effectively with migration and strengthen  the global role of the European Union. I believe that we will get the best positive result from the trilogue process as a whole.

name: Liadh Ní Riada
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, ba mhaith liom mo bhuíochas a ghabháil leis an Uasal Fernandes i gcomhair an obair go léir a chuir sé isteach sa tuarascáil. Is maith an rud é go bhfuil roinnt pointí comónta eadrainn, cé go bhfuilid go beag, ach ar a laghad tá siad comónta.  Cé go bhfuil feabhas éigin tar éis teacht ar an mandáid i gcomhair 2016, ní féidir a rá go bhfuil go leor athruithe déanta. Tá tuilleadh déine ann, polaitíocht dhiúltach, agus clár nualiobrálachais atá á neartú ag an mbuiséad.  Caithfidh gur comhartha í an ghéarchéim atá faoi lán tseoil sa Ghréig go bhfuil gá ann an treoir dhamáisteach seo a athrú. Ba chóir dúinn díriú ar riachtanais na ndaoine, fostaíocht ar ardchaighdeán a chur ar fáil, agus gealltanas a thabhairt maidir le fás inbhuanaithe cliste. Is é an rud atá uainn chomh maith ná níos mó tacaíochta do bheartas comhtháthaithe, agus tá sé thar a bheith tábhachtach go dtugaimid tacaíocht do na tíortha sin atá ag streachailt de bharr srianta sóisialta agus eacnamaíochta. Táimid fós cráite, ar ndóigh, mar gheall ar an gcreat airgeadais ilbhliantúil 2007-2013. Ní bheidh clár 2014-2020 an Aontais Eorpaigh tosaithe roimh lár 2016 agus ba chóir athbhreithniú a dhéanamh ar an gcreat airgeadais ilbhliantúil. Tá sé de dhualgas orainn an rud ceart a dhéanamh ar mhaithe lenár saoránaigh, agus fíorinfheistíocht a dhéanamh i ndaoine.

name: Ernest Maragall
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Mrs Georgieva, Mr Fernandes, the best thing to say about this budget is that it will not cause great damage to anyone. It's right, it's balanced, it's solvent. We'll negotiate until the last minute, like every year, and I'm sure we'll reach an honorable agreement. Let me say, in any event, that an increase of 2.4% and 1.6% in commitment appropriations and payment appropriations speaks to us of overall prudence, but it does not mean appreciable real growth. We are dazzled by a sharp reduction in the volume of outstanding payments, but it is not at all clear what will happen in the following years, when all 2014–2020 programmes are fully performing. We can cite, in a positive sense, the LIFE programme, a first, provisional and expectant attempt to green the budget. Welcome back. But we must also cite, in the negative sense, very negative, the support that continues to be given to a project like ITER: up to more than five hundred million for a project that offers, of course, more doubts than certainties and more concerns than hopes. Let's wait for the 2013 discharge reports and then we'll finish judging. But this budget is also a symptom of another much larger issue of order. Like the Titanic orchestra, we continue to perform our song, our budget, in this case, while everything around us cries out for answers of another order, much more ambitious, urgent and meaningful. The debate on TTE or on Greece, which we have in this House today, perfectly illustrates this inconsistency. The unequal dialogue Europe—the United States—the United States has a budget of more than 20% of its GDP, and Europe, about 1%—speaks clearly to us about this. This budget is safe and sensible, but it is also irrelevant. It is not part of the remedies that Europe really needs for economic growth and to respond to the inequalities we have raised.

name: Jonathan Arnott
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, when your ship is on course for an iceberg, you turn it around. The answer is not ‘steady as she goes’. Our rapporteur speaks of the cost of EU membership as a percentage of GDP. This is a conjuring trick – GDP is of course roughly three times our total tax take. Nor does he take into account the huge cost of compliance with European Union legislation. This will be more of the same budget for more of the same European Union.  If the Greek óchi teaches us one thing, it is that this is no time for more of the same. One of the problems here is the EU principle of ever closer union, because who here will dare to admit that anything, anything at all, could be done more efficiently by a sovereign nation than by the Brussels bureaucracy?

name: Sophie Montel
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the draft 2016 budget perfectly reflects the attitude of the European Union: "Do what I say, not what I do".  It is therefore planned to increase administrative expenditure by 2.2% and parliament's by 2.4%. The Commission is not left behind, as spending on staff salaries and the pensions of its public servants is expected to increase by 2% and 5.4% respectively. Brussels should start by applying austerity to itself before administering it to others.  Meanwhile, the internal demand of the Member States continues to be foolishly squeezed, and it is not with the Juncker plan, expected as the messiah by the delights of the European crèche, that things will get better. But the European Union does not stop in such a bad way. Thus, macro-financial assistance to Ukraine, a non-EU country, is planned, while at the same time there is a lack of say to grant aid to Greece. The solidarity of the Europeanists has a good back.  Last time, funding for democracy and human rights would increase by 2%, while the Social Democrat Martin Schulz wanted to end the Syriza era and replace it with a technocratic and undemocratic government.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Fernandes, for taking into account the opinion expressed by the Committee on Foreign Affairs on the budget proposal made by the European Commission. I would then like to express my satisfaction with the significant increase in both payment appropriations and commitment appropriations for the European Union's foreign policy in the Commission's draft budget.  If the Union is to exert its influence on the international stage, it must give itself the means of its ambitions. It is therefore essential that the additional budgetary resources provided in the Budget proposed by the Commission be preserved in the final budget. These increases are particularly important for payment credits because, if not, a whole range of EU programmes, such as the instrument contributing to stability and peace, will find it difficult to resume their activities partially suspended for financial reasons. In terms of foreign policy, our Parliament will continue to be engaged in the neighbourhood both in the South and in the East, and it seems to me essential that a European neighbourhood instrument be equipped with sufficient means for us to be able to support the countries around us. I also believe it is important that this year's budget reflects our commitment to respect for human rights and democracy in our neighbourhood, but also beyond. I therefore hope that the final budget will reflect those two concerns that are at the heart of our foreign policy.

name: Richard Ashworth (ECR).
text: – Mr President, this report talks about accountability, value for money and big on big, small on small. That is enormously encouraging, and for that, my grateful thanks to Commissioner Georgieva, who brings real common sense and discipline to the whole budget procedure. But I have a concern. This Parliament takes a keen interest in the formulation of the budget, but we take very little interest in the outcome and performance of the budget. That is not acceptable. Colleagues, we are spending taxpayers’ money, and yet we have no way of assessing value for money, no procedure for gauging effectiveness, and no scrutiny. In consequence, too often our decisions are based on political traditions, and far too seldom are they based on sound, proven evidence.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like - he will not be surprised - to give my full support to the excellent report by our colleague José Manuel Fernandes.  I particularly appreciate the very clear priority he gives to what he calls the three "E's", that is, in reality growth and employment. Ladies and gentlemen, as you well know, Europe needs growth as well as bread, and it is in this context that I fully support the expressed desire to ensure the guarantee linked to the European Fund for Strategic Investments while preserving as much as possible, as we have managed to do, the means planned for Horizon 2020 and for the mechanism for interconnection in Europe. I also support the commitment to work to strengthen the resources allocated to migration policy and, in particular, in the immediate future, to the equitable distribution of asylum seekers between Member States. I would also like to say that it is a scandal that some Member States which greedly pocket the funds of the Structural Funds selfishly refuse any true solidarity in the care of a few dozen asylum seekers. I also support our rapporteur's request to provide the necessary resources to finance the European security agenda, which the Commission has recently proposed.
