The terrorist threat is real and it will remain so! To combat it, European instruments, in particular Europol, must be given the necessary means.  More generally, and I am speaking to the Commission, we must put an end to the stupid system which mechanically cuts the resources of the agencies without ever taking into account either priorities or emergencies.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Mr Fernandes, our group has tabled numerous amendments, and many of them have been introduced and, in our view, improve the document. However, we reaffirm our general criticism of this draft budget. We believe that it is clearly too rigid and insufficient, and that it does not live up to the challenges of the economic crisis we are suffering, aggravated by policies of austerity and cuts. Without truly ambitious public investment policies, stimulating and geared towards quality employment generation and changing the non-fossil energy production model, Europe will continue to deepen its cohesion problems and de-inject the needs of tackging the real social dramas of a fundamental part of our population. The Greek people have just said loud and clear 'enough' to politics and to the Europe of austerity. You have a duty to listen to your peoples.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I speak on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, which does not have strong vested interests in the budget area, but I would like to leave with you two messages. One is of particular importance for us in the AFCO committee. This is the Europe for Citizens programme, for which the Commission has increased the funding, and I hope that this increased funding will remain untouched through the negotiations. We believe that in these difficult times, when we have a lack of trust, when we have to reach out to citizens, when we have to build confidence and when we have to improve understanding, this programme can have great added value. And the second issue – the European Citizens’ Initiative – is also a major tool of participatory democracy. We propose  to make this initiative and this programme more visible in the budget, so we propose to establish a sub-line which will be budget-neutral but will help us to make the initiative more visible.

name: Clare Moody (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Fernandes for his work on this mandate, and I also welcome Commissioner Georgieva’s focus on the revival of the economy, but it cannot just be about supporting the shape of the economy today, it has to be about shaping the economy of the future as well. That is why the Horizon 2020 budget is so important, and the 2016 budget trilogue should be used as a means to reinforce this area. The research and innovation that is supported through Horizon 2020 is the means by which we can secure good-quality jobs into the future – a future that involves huge technological change. It is through this area that we can make sure that those generations that come after us, as well as those that are in work today, have got the jobs that are so necessary for them.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Speaking in this debate, I would like to point out that commitment appropriations of EUR 153.5 billion and payment appropriations eur 10 billion lower in nominal terms compared to 2015 are only increasing by 2.4%, 1.6%, which means that in real terms this increase is in principle gone. In this situation, it will be difficult for the Commission to meet the outstanding payments, although in a tripartite agreement all three institutions announced a reduction in payments from 24 billion in 2014 to 20 billion at the end of 2015 and two billion at the end of 2016. Such a large reduction in outstanding payments, although obvious and desirable by project beneficiaries, in the absence of a clear increase in payment appropriations in 2016, means in practice their rollover – as these outstanding payments relate to the previous perspective, those from the current perspective will have a significant delay in funding.

name: Jan Olbrycht (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for 2016 will be an extremely important year from a budgetary point of view. Firstly, this will be the year in which we will check whether an interinstitutional agreement on payment issues will work. It is next year that the backdue period is to be reduced to EUR 2 billion. We will see if a new operating system is in place in 2016, not just a reduction in the backlog. Secondly, this is the year in which we will see the first results of the use of a guarantee scheme called the Juncker Fund. Thirdly, this is the year in which the first results of the 2014-2020 programming period are to be expected.  We hope that the first results and the first payments are already emerging, which, in connection with the first element I mentioned, is important, as the question arises as to whether the new payments will not create the same backlog system as before. In addition, 2016 will be the period for a decision on the revision or review of the budget. The quality of spending in the 2016 budget will largely depend on the way in which discussions will take place on the revision of the multiannual perspective. From this point of view, this year will be extremely important for us.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the European Parliament presents itself to this trilogue with a clear and firm vision of how we think about the European budget. For us, it is very important that the European Union's budgetary strategy is focused on development and investment that ensures a better life for European citizens. In this context, our message is a simple one: we must have a budget that comes out of the logic of austerity and focuses on investing in people, in European projects and programmes dedicated to job creation, in those aimed at vocational training, in those that support the development of SMEs, in those that support the development of European democracy and our active role in promoting our values.  We therefore expect more clarity, efficiency and transparency from the European Commission in spending European public money, and we expect, especially from the European Council, which we see that even today is lacking, to be able to support the commitments for a European budget that live up to the expectations of the citizens it must represent.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, you will negotiate the 2016 budget with Mr Fernandez - you know him very well, you negotiated EFSI with him and, in the end, a very good regulation came out. Budget 2016 - I think it's a budget to say "benchmark" because it will be the first payments from structural funds. You have to make the payments to cover the debts to cohesion policy - there are a lot, over 25 billion - and at the same time I believe that there must also be the recovery of money for Horizon 2020 and for the SEF. So you have a complicated negotiation. You've seen the warrant, it's a solid mandate. Fernandez knew how to build it very well, and the expectations at the end of these negotiations are very high.  I hope that these negotiations will not, as usual, be until the last evening, when the Council says 'that's it' and everyone has to accept it, because otherwise we don't have a budget. I believe that if we do not strike a balance in the budget by meeting the three conditions – to pay the debts, to take into account the payments for cohesion policy 2014-2020 and, at the same time, to ensure the recovery of the funds taken by the EFSI from the two important programmes – we must experience one thing: not to have a budget for 2016.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, forgive me, but this is truly a special day. Commissioner, you may think that I have a bad mind, but this delay in the implementation of shared management programmes is timely to relieve the burden of our unpaid bills.  For the 2016 budget, the Commission finally has, it seems, the necessary leeway to propose a drastic reduction of these bills to EUR 2 billion. However, two issues remain unresolved. Firstly, what about the attitude of the Member States? Will the Council finally agree to settle its debts, because unfortunately, as we see year after year, the sense of responsibility, respect for the word given and even solidarity do not always characterize the attitude of the Heads of State and Government. Secondly, there is still a gap of almost EUR 10 billion between payments and commitments. This lag does not bode well for the end of the programming period because, as we know, the plan to resolve the payments crisis is not a trick, but an accounting loophole, while the structural problem of the Union budget remains the same. The accumulation of unpaid bills at the end of the programming period is also a way for Member States to save money on the back of the European budget. The model of the multi-year financial framework is outdated and the budget funding model is opaque. All this is hurting the Union!  Today we are debating this subject, but we are fully aware of the limitations of this exercise. Indeed, this budget is increasing, but there is only 2 billion euros of margin left, as if the Union did not need investment. This budget focuses on priority issues and I should welcome it, but we are far from the real needs of the Union. For example, our proposal does not provide for a penny to help the 5 million unemployed young people in Europe.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first of all, let me thank the Commissioner, because the Commissioner really does form a large part of a good atmosphere in which the European Parliament works very well. Thank you for coming between us and discussing with us. I would also like to thank my colleague Fernandes, because this is indeed the first rapporteur to come with us to discuss the budget for the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, of which I am shadow rapporteur.  I would like to say a few important things about the budget or what has been put forward. Ensuring the security of our citizens is one of the most important tasks of the European Union and the Member States. I therefore believe that the European Union budget must not be undersized in the long term as it is at present. Although the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs is currently fighting to increase spending on key agencies such as FRONTEX, EASO, Europol, Eurojust at least in the 2016 budget. It is clear that there is a lack of funding and will still be missing in the future. It is not possible for only a percentage of the budget to go to security from European money. We should therefore systematically focus on how to ensure the security of the European Union. The reality is that this is not possible without sufficient resources. I therefore consider it important that we really strive for this in this negotiating mandate.

name: Wim van de Camp (PPE).
text: My confidence in Rapporteur Fernandes is high, as is the one in Mrs Georgieva, by the way. If you can bring the EFSI dossier to a successful conclusion, then the 2016 budget is simple. I cannot always follow the Council's stance. On the one hand, the Council wants Europe to do more and more. On the other hand, he is very reticent when it comes to paying. But we too can improve our credibility. If new things need to happen, we must also be prepared to delete old things. We can be a little more strict about that. It is also striking that annual expenditure is always lower than budgeted expenditure. I therefore repeat my plea last year: do not refund the surplus to the Member States, but, for example, use it to make arrears. Finally, the use of margins. There are still many margins in the European budget. We need to make the budgetary framework more flexible. As spokesman for transport for the EPP Group, I would of course like to rejoin the Commissioner on the relationship between EFSI and CEF. We'd like some CEF money back. Thank you very much.

name: Alain Cadec
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mr Fernandes for his work. I am pleased to see that the appropriations requested in the draft budget are in line with the forecasts we have set out in the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund regulation. Control and data collection, fleet modernization, adaptation to the landing requirement are extremely important points.  The FEAMP concentrates the vast majority of the available funds in our field of activity. As you know, it is very important for the Committee on Fisheries that the appropriations allow for the proper implementation of this common policy.  In the fisheries and maritime affairs budget, I note unfortunately the near-stagnation of appropriations available for international agreements and compulsory contributions to fishing organisations. I can only deplore it.  The Common Fisheries Policy must achieve the objectives set by the reform, including sustainable maximum yield, in 2015. I am also thinking of fisheries control and data collection, which are crucial for proper enforcement and compliance with the rules of the common fisheries policy.  I also look forward to the Council reading the budget, because I do not want any cuts to the Commission's proposal made by Mrs Georgieva.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Madam Vice-President, people outside this building are rarely interested in the sections of the budget, interest rates, rates or numbers in it. What they are very interested in, however, are the results achieved. And I believe this is one of the first budgets based precisely on results. Today we face four main challenges: the situation in Greece, Ukraine, North Africa and the fragile economy. All four are properly reflected in this budget, for which I thank you, as well as for the work of Mr Fernandez. But there is something I personally want to thank as a young person, actually the youngest in this Parliament, and that is that Erasmus+ has 30% more than last year and Horizon 2020 has 10 billion more than last year.  I want us to move in that direction and reflect the principle that we have to be small for the little things and big things. I wish for more budgets like this. Congratulations one more time.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D).
text: – When the debate on the 2016 Union budget takes place here, we must ask the question of its fundamental scope: does the EUR 153 billion in appropriations and the direction in which they are being dispensed respond properly to European problems? In my opinion, they only partially respond to them.  I welcome the fact that higher investment is foreseen next year, and I also welcome the fact that, for the first time, much more resources are foreseen for security and stability in Europe. But there is, unfortunately, a very serious weakness when it comes to this budget. This is an investment to support small and medium-sized businesses. Let us remember that it is these companies that are, above all, creating new jobs, and this is unfortunately still the fundamental social problem that we have today. So I think you would also have to look for more money for these companies.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, we are discussing the European Union's 2016 budget, which provides for commitment appropriations of EUR 153.5 billion, which is crumbs, compared to the EUR 1.6 trillion allocated by the Member States to rescue the banks. They are crumbs, when compared to the EUR 1.1 trillion that Mr Draghi has available for quantitative easing and for the purchase of public and private debt. However, even in the context of budgetary austerity in the 2016 budget, these funds must be made available mainly for job creation, for supporting the unemployed, for hitting poverty, for strengthening the action of small and medium-sized enterprises, for the social, economic and territorial cohesion of the Union, for sustainable agriculture, for regional development, especially in island regions. , to strengthen solidarity actions in the countries of the European South and especially in Greece which has been impoverished by austerity and memoranda.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, if we are to succeed in this Mandate of the Commission and we want success for our mandate in Parliament, it is arguable that only investment in the growth of the economy and the growth of our European Union will be the result of the success of the Commission and the convening of Parliament. So, I am definitely convinced that cohesion policy can play a very important role in this element, especially for some Member States, because it is certain – the data shows – that cohesion policy enables significant investment in many regions within the EU.  The second, of course, is the announced Juncker Fund. This must not be a failure, it must be the full success of this mandate of the Commission and this parliament. What I still want to warn about are macro-regional strategies. I am Parliament's rapporteur for the Adriatic-Ionian Strategy, which includes the countries of the Western Balkans. I ask that we find a common denominator so that various projects can also be financed for macro-regional strategies.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – It has been music to my ears to hear that the EU budget for 2016 will provide serious support, help to the poorer countries of the Union, stronger solidarity between rich and poor Member States, greater so-called cohesion, but as usual we have heard only generality about this, so I will ask the Commissioner and the reportter what measures they will take, what budget lines they will be. For example, what can a Hungarian citizen expect in terms of the fact that the EU budget will make efforts to stop the economic exodus from Hungary and other poorer countries, to raise living standards, as promised when Hungary and other countries were lured into the Union, to improve income conditions. I look forward to a concrete response from the Commissioner and the reporter.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President,   many thanks to all who have contributed to this debate. I will try to be concise and address questions that have been directed to the Commission. First, there were a number of comments referring to the difference between commitments and payments in the 2016 budget and some expressing concerns that, a with EUR 10 billion difference – with commitments being about EUR 10 billion higher than payments – we might not deal with the gap that existed particularly seriously last year. We are confident that this will not be the case, for two reasons. One is that, because of the very specific measures we are taking as part of the payment plan that Parliament requested, we can bring down the amount of unpaid bills from EUR 24.7 - 20 billion this year to EUR 2 billion next year. EUR 2 billion is normal, and we would be in normal territory. The other reason is that in 2016 we are out of the pressure of the previous MFF, which last year and this year demanded from us significant payments, but we are not yet under the pressure of payments coming from the new MFF. So 2016 is a year where it is normal to have commitments being higher and payments being lower, with a difference of EUR 10 billion as we have calculated them. I can assure you that we will be monitoring very carefully throughout the implementation of the budget whether or not we are properly managing the payment side in particular. Secondly, there was concern on the question of the underlying economic data for the calculation of the amounts to be paid for cohesion. What exactly would be the envelope for cohesion for different countries, given that they are shifting up and down in terms of their relative GDP size? There will be a recalculation in 2016 which would then impact on the envelopes of cohesion. Thirdly, a number of speakers brought up very forcefully the point that we want this budget to be different. We want it to be focused more on priorities and we want it to be focused on performance; Mr Novakov talked about a budget focused on results. We want it to be a budget in which we carefully manage the administrative side and, yes, we are working in that direction. We are, of course, like the Queen Mary – we take time to shift, but shift we will. You will see over time a results-focused, performance orientation of the budget, also looking into multiple benefits from the euros we invest. That takes me to a very important point: investing in innovation in SMEs. Of course we have to do that. This is where growth in employment is going to come from. This is where we are going to see an increased standard of living, especially for countries where unemployment has been persistently high. That is where the thinking of the budget connects not only with what we spend directly for SMEs, for example COSME, but also how we are gearing the investment plan for Europe – how we are gearing up the Juncker Plan to be more effective. There was a very specific question on Hungary. What would happen to people in Hungary as a result of your budget? Obviously we need to come back to you with specifics, and I am already running out of time. But what you will see that is somewhat different from previous budgets is this: we are looking at a composition for the Hungarian budget which would have a strong cohesion component, from the structural funds; it would have a very strong agricultural component, because the country has a sizeable farming sector; but we would also see the impact, hopefully, of the Juncker Plan, of taking money to invest in waking up the sleeping liquidity in our financial sector. I would be happy to sit with you and walk you through what would be in it for me if I were a Hungarian. Mr Fernandes, I very much look forward to negotiating with you again, be it day or night – day still being a bit more preferred.

name: José Manuel Fernandes
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for all her work and constructive attitude, and to thank all the colleagues involved in the construction of the European Union budget in this mandate for the trilogue.  I would like to say that, on Parliament's part, we will be up to our responsibilities. I am sure the Commission does, too. We are coherent, ambitious but rigorous, and I expect the Council to do the same.  I expect consistency from the Council and it does not always exist. It should be seen that we all know that, in to approve the Multiannual Financial Framework, unanimity is needed and then there are Member States that successively vote against budgets which are in accordance with that same Multiannual Financial Framework and sometimes are even below that Multiannual Financial Framework. This is not consistency. Unfortunately, we have Member States in the European Union that vote consecutively against all the budgets of the European Union, without public opinion often knowing it.  For our part, we will demand that commitments be made. We want flexibility and it was at the expense or because of the flexibility that we have taken the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, which is lower than in 2007-2013. And flexibility means using the flexibility instruments, using the margins of previous years that have not been used, and we will well need them because we maintain the goal we have set in relation to Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility. We will continue to minimize as much as possible the impact that the Strategic Investment Fund has on these two programmes. I think we all agree with one objective: growth, jobs, internal solidarity, external solidarity, security, and i therefore expect a massive vote in this report for the mandate.

name: Preşedinte.
text: – The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 8 July 2014. In accordance with Article 190(1), I have been informed by the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament that tomorrow, in the opening of the debate "The role of the European Union in the Middle East peace process" will request the postponement of the debate for a plenary session at which the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative will be able to attend. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I look with concern at the Commission's two major budgetary initiatives for 2016. The first, the Juncker Plan (FEIE), which will be financed by budgetary margins that should be used for resource-free initiatives (such as the Youth Guarantee) and with cuts in research and infrastructure programmes. Under no circumstances can the problems of access to finance for European companies - and particularly SMEs, which suffer in addition to cuts in COSME - be considered to be solved by socializing their potential losses through the EIE. On the contrary, public investment funds are being redirected to private speculation, to the detriment of taxpayers and the robustness of the economy as a whole. Nor do I share the increase and priorities in the security and neighbourhood items, supporting policies that politically and economically destabilize the countries around us, as with credits to Ukraine. It is cynical to "see" the "crisis" in Syria or Libya, without taking responsibility. Responsibilities which concern, first and foremosm, the duty to take in the refugees that Europe receives from conflict zones. The effective right to asylum must be guaranteed and not turned the Mediterranean into a grave for thousands of migrants.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – We are preparing a budget for next year. We must already think ahead today so that the situation of 2014 does not happen again in three years' time. At the end of last year, the EU owed almost EUR 25 billion for unpaid invoices. We do not know what these unpaid EU invoices have caused to towns, municipalities, hospitals, small and medium-sized enterprises ... What if unpaid invoices forced suppliers to lay off or they passed on the problem and there were negative chain reactions of non-payment and distortion. I know personally the people at the head of the municipalities who did not draw on the Euro funds precisely because they saw problems with colleagues. This could also have resulted in a lower absorption of EU funds in my country. We need to know the consequences of this non-payment so that we can prevent them in the future. That is why I tabled an amendment adopted by a faction of European Socialists and Democrats. Under the heading of the whole group, we will vote on this proposal.

name: PUHEMIES. –
text: The next item is the debate – the oral question to the Council by Claude Moraes, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the European Agenda on European Security (O-000064/2015 – B8-0566/2015 ) and – the oral question to the Commission by Claude Moraes, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the European Agenda on Security (O-000065/2015 – B8-0567/2015).

name: Claude Moraes
text: author. – Madam President, today we update our Internal Security Strategy for 2015 to 2020, proposed by the Commission. In doing so we could not have envisaged in just how important a context we would discuss the need for increased cooperation of the highest quality to ensure the security of our citizens and to ensure we get the balance right between tackling terrorism, on the one hand, and ensuring that those same terrorists do not disrupt the freedoms we enjoy. It is always the case that Member States provide the first response in terms of internal security, but it is now absolutely clear that cooperation across borders of the European Union and cooperation in the priority areas of counter-terrorism, cyber security and related organised crime have taken on a renewed importance. Let us not forget the terrorist attacks of recent days on EU citizens in Tunisia, in Paris some months ago, in Copenhagen and in Brussels – and, of course, today marks the anniversary of 7/7 in my own city of London, which was the biggest single terrorist attack on UK citizens. So what is Parliament contributing in terms of the Commission’s priorities for a modernised security agenda at this critical and sensitive moment? First we underline that in preventing radicalisation we must search for the best possible models of European practice on so-called ‘foreign fighters’. In monitoring the internet for content which may lead to terrorist attacks, we must stick to the rule of law so as not to end up in the grey zones of censorship. In fighting violent extremism and terrorism we should use our existing tools effectively before creating new tools, and in doing so we should not undermine the very fundamental values that terrorists wish to violate. We want to be practical in this House, and our practical priorities for this Parliament, in terms of existing and new measures, are firstly to update the SIS II system to make compulsory alerts of persons convicted or suspected of terrorism and to help Member States implement travel bans at national level. Secondly, the importance of cross-border access to information and in particular the European police record index system. Third, Parliament is calling for a legal framework for all semi-permanent or permanent joint investigation teams and, of course, the PNR Directive by the end of 2015. We suggest possible solutions to the most sensitive and difficult security challenges – for example, online terrorism threats and online radicalisation. We never say that this is going to be easy, but we welcome new structures within Europol called the European Counter—terrorism Centre and the effective work that it is already doing. We never say that this is easy or without risk or without problems. We also welcome cooperation with IT companies and civil society and law enforcement authorities through an EU forum to develop tools to counter terrorist propaganda online and in social media. The resolution that we present is full of ideas from Members of this Parliament who have great experience spanning many years of dealing with terrorism and dealing with many reports in this House – both legislative and non—legislative. That is why the import of what I am saying today is: please treat the European Parliament as your partner in dealing with the EU Security Strategy. I know that in dealing with this resolution we have had many shades of opinion and political differences, but the most important thing that I want to say as Chair of this Committee is that the expertise, both in terms of security and in terms of fundamental rights and understanding of data issues, is very rich in this Parliament. So please, Commissioner, treat that with seriousness. Please, President—in—Office, see the expertise in Parliament. I say that to both parts of our European Union. I would also say that, from PNR to tackling radicalisation, these are very sensitive ongoing issues, but the European Parliament will play its part. We fully understand that the Union’s internal security has become more complex, asymmetric and difficult to predict, but equally we understand that there has been more value placed on cross-border cooperation, data sharing and cyber security. For these very good reasons you will find full commitment and partnership in the EU security agenda. I look forward to hearing the contributions of my colleagues who contributed to the resolution before the House today, and I ask the Commissioner to respond in as detailed a way as we have contributed to that resolution.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express my joy first, since I am in a way a revenant. I was there ten years ago, during the last presidency of Luxembourg, and I am very pleased to come back and work with you. The motto of the Luxembourg Presidency is to "create a Union for citizens" and I believe that our citizens have every right to the best possible security. That is why security must be one of our top priorities. As you have said, Mr MEP, the events which have shocked us, shaken us in recent months, require us precisely to strengthen and, as you have pointed out, to further adapt our means of cooperation to these new challenges of terror. It is for this reason that the Luxembourg Presidency will concentrate all its efforts on the implementation and follow-up of the renewed internal security strategy for the European Union for the years 2015-2020. If I may, I will outline the broad principles of this strategy and what is planned for its implementation. The renewed internal security strategy was adopted by the Council on 16 June. I think it is important to point out that this strategy is also based on the elements and principles contained in the Commission's communication on the European security agenda of 28 April 2015. It is also important to stress that the renewed strategy must be seen as a common and shared programme of the European institutions, and both the Council and the Commission have taken into account the principles set out in your resolution of 17 December 2014. Let me now quote a few essential elements.  Firstly, this strategy identifies three main priorities in the area of internal security of the European Union for the next few years. The first is the fight against terrorism, as you have just pointed out, as we have made the tragic experience in recent months, radicalisation leading to terrorism and recruitment, and terrorist financing and the prevention of these phenomena. For this priority, special attention will be paid to the issue of foreign terrorist fighters, to the strengthening of external border controls, in a systematic and coordinated manner, using relevant databases and on the basis of risk assessments and risk indicators, and integrating internal and external aspects of the fight against terrorism. The second priority is to prevent and combat serious organized crime. The third is to prevent and combat cybercrime and strengthen cybersecurity. The second element I would like to stress is respect for fundamental rights, the need to respect and defend the rights, freedoms and principles set out in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union in the context of all the actions taken to create and maintain an area of freedom, security and justice, which is a fundamental principle. A third important element is the need for a comprehensive, multidisciplinary, integrated and information-based approach. Access to information and the availability and exchange of information in the prevention and fight against large transnational organized crime and terrorism will remain crucial points for the coming years. We need to pay particular attention to the interoperability of current systems. The coordination of investigations and prosecutions in Member States should be encouraged and improved, including for financial investigations aimed at the confiscation of criminal assets, as well as the effective use of joint investigation teams and procedures for mutual legal assistance and mutual recognition. Finally, justice and home affairs agencies such as Europol, Eurojust, Frontex and Cepol play an important role in the internal security of the European Union. These agencies, which are at the service of the Member States, should continue to be built and supported. As such, our Presidency will continue to negotiate with the European Parliament on the new Europol regulation with the aim of achieving a legislative basis for this agency to deploy its full potential in the service of the Member States. With regard to the other elements to be taken into account, we must first strengthen our operational cooperation and improve our border management capabilities, particularly by using the most modern technologies. Second, we need to strengthen the prevention of criminal acts by paying particular attention to the organized financial crime, forfeiture of criminal assets and the prevention of terrorist attacks, including by preventing radicalization. Secondly, we must adopt a fast and flexible, intelligence-led approach that allows the European Union to respond comprehensively and in a coordinated manner to emerging and ever-changing threats. Finally, we need to consolidate existing legislative tools and ensure their best implementation. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, these are some of the essential principles of the renewed strategy. Now let's talk about implementing this strategy, which we are working to prepare a clear and dynamic program of work. Discussions will begin within the Council, including the Standing Committee on Operational Cooperation on Internal Security, which is responsible for ensuring adequate implementation and regular monitoring of the strategy. This will be done in close cooperation with the Commission and, if necessary, involving other key players, such as European agencies, such as the European External Action Service. The Presidency intends to discuss for the first time in detail our approach to the implementation of this strategy on 22 and 23 July, when the COSI and the Coordination Committee in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters will meet informally in Luxembourg. In addition to the methodology for implementation, we intend to tackle the work immediately and mobilize all our working groups within the Council to do so. Of course, we will take parliament's new resolution into account, just as we have done in the past. MEPs were invited to the conference organised by the Italian Presidency in September 2014. The chairman of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs was a key speaker at the event. The Presidency, the Commission and the Member States used the conclusions reached at the conference to draw up the Council's conclusions on the renewed strategy. We also used the Commission's final report on the implementation of the Internal Security Strategy, which echoed the European Parliament's resolution on this subject. I therefore remain confident in our ability to develop a common approach to the implementation of the strategy. The President of the COSI will inform the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs about this work. In conclusion, ladies and gentlemen, we look forward to your new resolution. I am confident that many of your recommendations are already reflected in the renewed strategy and that we will be able to take them into account when implementing the strategy. I am thinking, for example, of the best use of existing instruments before creating new ones, the need to adopt a comprehensive and balanced approach taking into account the principle of proportionality, and then the need for more effective and operational cooperation between Member States, the attention to be paid to the judicial dimension and the role of the European Parliament and national parliaments to ensure democratic control over the implementation of the strategy. I thank you for your attention and intend to listen carefully to your debate.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for the opportunity offered by your oral question to debate further with you on the European Agenda on Security. I also want to express my thanks to Claude Moraes for his support. Thank you also for the draft resolution, which is to be voted on two days from now, and which I will of course take into consideration. I hope that the resolution will have the wide support of this House. As I – and many among you as well – have said several times, we need to show our citizens that we all work together on the basis of a shared agenda. Today’s debate happens, as was mentioned before by Claude, on the 10th anniversary of the 7 July terrorist attacks in London. Sadly, it also happens only a few days after another series of unacceptable terrorist attacks. Even if these are addressed specifically tomorrow, as you know, it shows that our security has to remain high on our agenda. One year ago, in June 2014, the European Council asked the Union to renew and update the previous Internal Security Agenda 2010-2014. All the institutions have provided their contribution to this process in a coordinated fashion. Following the last Commission’s report on the implementation of the Internal Security Strategy (ISS), both the Council and Parliament paved the way in December 2014 for the Commission to develop its European Agenda on Security adopted on 28 April 2015.  Last month, the Council adopted, on the basis of the Commission’s agenda, conclusions on the development of the renewed European Union Internal Security Strategy 2015-2020. The renewed Internal Security Strategy is the result of this process, and it constitutes a major achievement for the European Union. It was endorsed at the highest level by the European Council at its June summit, both in terms of content and in terms of cooperation among the institutions. In terms of content, the new strategy sets out the shared vision of the three institutions for the next five years on what needs to be done at Union level to make Europe more secure for the sake of its citizens, societies and economies. It identifies the main priorities for the Union’s actions, namely tackling terrorism and radicalisation, disrupting organised crime and fighting against cybercrime. From the institutional point of view, the Commission, Parliament and the Council have acted together, with each one offering their strategic contribution to the security strategy in line with the spirit of the Lisbon Treaty. As the Commission put it in its European Agenda on Security: successful implementation on renewed Internal Security Strategy depends on the political commitment of all actors concerned to do more, and of course to do better. This includes not only EU institutions, but also Member States and EU agencies. In addition to active engagement, coordinated and coherent action is a prerequisite. I therefore welcome the European Parliament’s call to the Commission and the Council to work together towards effective implementation and to engage in an interinstitutional dialogue. The Commission is fully committed to maintaining a constant dialogue with the European Parliament on internal security matters. The Commission undertakes to update the European Parliament and the Council twice a year on the implementation of the agenda. This will be the opportunity to take stock, together, of both the achievements and the challenges faced, and to exchange views on the state of EU internal security. In addition, transparency contributes to increasing citizens’ confidence in security policies. The Commission will therefore set up an EU security consultative forum to further enhance transparency and participation. This forum will bring together Member States, the European Parliament, EU agencies and representatives of civil society, academia and the private sector. The format of the forum will be finalised in due course, and the European Parliament will be kept informed. In the same context, the Commission will also develop performance indicators for key EU institutions. Now, when speaking about implementation of the agenda, an important aspect is resources, including those of the EU agencies. The European Agenda on Security has set, as one of its key principles, the need to ensure better application and full implementation of existing instruments. Pursuant to this principle, implementing the agenda will centre on consolidating the existing instruments and reprioritising available resources. The principle also applies to the agencies: for instance, the European Counter-Terrorism Centre within Europol is also included. It is meant to bring together anti-terrorism law enforcement capabilities, thereby pooling resources and maximising the use of the existing legal structures, services and tools already available. Of course, ensuring sufficient resources to EU agencies is crucial for them to be able to perform their work and to fully contribute to the goals of the agenda. As envisaged by the European Agenda on Security, the Commission will launch a reflection on how to maximise the contribution of all JHA agencies through closer inter-agency cooperation. The Commission invites the Member States to assign appropriate resources at the national level and to reinforce their efforts in seconding their national experts to agencies. In a situation of limited budgets, all efforts must be made to prioritise and reallocate. Increasing the agencies’ budget is the only other way to increase resources. As you know, the Commission is following the interinstitutional agreement of December 2013 that foresees that all EU institutions and bodies – as well as all agencies – reduce their total staffing levels by 5% over five years. This does not prejudge the budgetary rights of the European Parliament and the Council, but any increase in the agencies’ resources would require the firm commitment and agreement of both branches of the budgetary authority.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner Avramopoulos, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, the security agenda is one of the most important issues we have at the moment. For hardly anyone could have imagined a few years ago that terrorists would move to holiday resorts and arbitrarily seek out European citizens – in this case mainly British citizens – to shoot them on the open beach. Nor would anyone have thought that in France a man who had been a simple, decent worker would ever be bebeheaded. We have now arrived in a security situation which, on the one hand, makes us anxious and, on the other, calls on us to react calmly but consistently. After all, security is a fundamental right, and if this fundamental right is no longer guaranteed, then there will no longer be any freedom for citizens. For this reason, it is essential that the Member States cooperate closely and speed up their cooperation. Requests for mutual assistance, requests for mutual legal assistance must no longer last so long, and the exchange of data must flow. Colleagues, who sometimes have reservations about data exchange, must also be consistent and say that we need close data exchange, because the criminals are networked, while our authorities sometimes still suffer from some restrictions. Security agencies need our trust and support so that they can work consistently. The agencies need adequate financial resources – whether it is Eurojust, EASO, Frontex or Europol – to work accordingly. We also need an effective agreement on PNR data, with which we can work accordingly. Now that it is now known that this instrument is a very important instrument in the fight against terrorism or serious crimes, we must also make use of it. Despite the fact that we have our focus on terrorism, we should not forget other types of crime, particularly in the area of organised crime, because the human, financial and economic damage is appalling.

name: Birgit Sippel
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Fear is a bad guide. The same applies to the debate on the European Agenda on Security: respect for fundamental rights distinguishes us from totalitarian systems. That is why we must respond with the confident voice of the European constitutional state. Where changes in security policy become necessary, we must act without falling into frantic actionism.  The following points are particularly important to me. Firstly, the european court of justice ruling on the abolition of data retention must be taken into account in the implementation of security policy: no indiscriminate mass surveillance of citizens. Secondly, we need a comprehensive review of all security policy measures in order to identify concrete improvements. The Commission has so far failed to make such an evaluation. We need better exchange of information between Member States so that existing information can be used effectively.  Fourthly, the work of intelligence services is also important for us, for our democracy, but they too must be within the limits of the rule of law. In order to make a clear assessment of their activities, we need a universal definition of what is meant by national security. Fifthly, escape is not a crime and protection from persecution of international law. When refugees increasingly cooperate with organised crime or come from these circles themselves, we must react. But in return, we also need legal and safe ways, so that refugees do not have to rely on the services of criminal smugglers.  Sixthly, radicalisation in Europe towards crime and terrorism also requires a greater emphasis on prevention. Poverty or permanent discrimination gives many people the impression that they are not part of our society. Stigmatisation and exclusion are everyday experience for too many people. That is why integration, prevention and de-radicalisation are imperative. Finally, we face enormous challenges. But the greatest thing will always be to keep in mind that in the long term we can only shape security by the democratic means of the rule of law.

name: Timothy Kirkhope
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, today we remember all those who tragically lost their lives in the senseless and merciless acts of terror in London ten years ago. We also remember the families and friends who live with their grief every day, and our thoughts are obviously with them today. Also, recent events in Paris have tragically reminded us that our security and our freedom are never guaranteed, and that maintaining our security is one of the greatest challenges we face. The right to security is a fundamental right, and we have a responsibility, as legislators, to ensure that we protect people and that we detain and punish those who seek to do us harm. Whilst the Commission’s strategy has been welcomed by me and my group, unfortunately, I fear that Parliament’s response and recommendations would insufficiently equip the EU and its Member States to fight the worst kinds of criminality. Ensuring data protection, fundamental rights and self-reflection are, of course, an important part of creating effective policies in the area of security and law enforcement and a vital ingredient in order for measures to be proportionate, necessary and democratic. However, focusing on these elements alone is not sufficient to deliver a strategy intended to keep the EU and its citizens safe for the next four years. Law-making is about balance. I see little balance in the resolution from Parliament. The EU needs policies, measures, resources, expertise and actions which show that criminality and terror have no place in the EU. We need to be talking in serious and clear terms about how we protect children from abuse and exploitation; how we stop radicalisation; how we can better exchange law enforcement information; how we can stop drugs and arms smuggling; how we can help protect victims and how we can ensure that law enforcement agencies have the funding and resources they require to be effective. This was not intended to be a resolution on fundamental rights; it was supposed to be a resolution on delivering clear and firm security. Therefore, I cannot support something which, sadly, misses the point.

name: Gérard Deprez
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, Minister, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, congratulations first of all to Claude Moraes for this very fine work. I hope, despite what Mr Kirkhope has just said, that he will have a very large majority. In the current circumstances, it is important that the European Parliament expresses a strong and courageous position in favour of the safety of European citizens. I say to my dear colleague, Mrs Sippel, that it is not fear that guides us, but responsibility. I would like to say that the creation of the European Counter-Terrorism Centre within Europol, which I hope will indeed be operational from 1 January 2016. I stress the need to provide Europol with the financial means necessary to carry out these additional tasks. I call for the compulsory registration of terrorism suspects in the Schengen information system, as well as the harmonisation of reporting criteria. I also call for all Member States to organise their border guards' access to the Europol information system, which contains the names of thousands of terrorism suspects. I ask that any new European security tool necessarily include binding mechanisms for information sharing and cooperation between Member States, all of which, of course, respect the fundamental rights of citizens and the principles of necessity, proportionality and legality. Finally, let me reflect on the future. You have spoken, Commissioner, of the Commission's intention to organise a forum where all stakeholders will discuss the necessary strategy. This forum will provide information and that is a good thing. But who will implement it? My conviction is that in the area of internal security, we would have to have someone with the same responsibilities as the Head of External Security of the Union. Today, who really acts on behalf of the European Union and the Member States with Twitter, Google and Facebook when it comes to discussing the removal of terrorist content? Who is really responsible for the management of the Schengen information system? Who determines the strategic directions coordinating the action of Member States, the Commission, the various agencies and the various services in the field of security? Commissioner, my conviction is that in order to deal with the threats we face, decisions will have to be taken that will modernise our system. (The speaker agrees to answer a question "blue card" (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE)
text: blue card question. – Mr Deprez, you are a respected man in this House and in this group. I respect him very much. You said you expect Mr Kirkhope to have the majority to get his PNR ahead. Our group will support you. Could you use your influence to get the ALDE Group to support Mr Kirkhope?

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: "blue card" answer. I answer very clearly that I will tell my friends. Are you satisfied with that answer?

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, since 2001, the Member States of the European Union have been sinking into security logics at the expense of the protection of fundamental rights. Security is essential. Indeed, our citizens are entitled to it, as well as all those who live on our territory.  The fight against terrorism is an absolute necessity, but this concept remains to be defined, and not only in its so-called jihadist form, which effectively stigmatizes the Muslim community as a whole. The European security programme is imbued with this prism. To combat radicalism, the rise of hatred, we must attack evil at the root and, in particular, fight against rising inequalities and change foreign policy. We need to assess the existing instruments and highlight their shortcomings The European Parliament's resolution has made many advances, and I want to thank our President, Claude Moraes in particular. But it does not go far enough in terms of the balance between prevention and repression, between security and law, particularly in terms of data protection, proportionality, necessity and cybercrime. The risks to freedom of expression exist in view of the excesses of the Member States. The same goes for the European NRL. We can create all the European gas plants we want, they will continue to be illusory, risk becoming more and more liberticidal, but will serve no purpose without real cooperation of the services concerned between the Member States, but also within them. I am not sure that our citizens are winners, including in terms of security. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, I have listened to our colleague, Mrs Vergiat, talk about fundamental rights and inequalities, which are very important aspects. The three major threats to our lives are terrorism, organized crime and cybercrime. But do you not believe that, in situations where our citizens are shot on the beach by terrorists, we must strengthen with all possible means the European security and defence bodies?

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" answer. "I did not expect such a question from the Socialist Group, and I am sorry because I am used to working with certain members of this group, but not in this frame of mind, and not for them to make me false trials in terms of security and human rights.  I have been defending the Tunisian people for years and I am a human rights activist. Your question is an insult, sir. Keep! I will not even answer that.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Sure, of course. We must tackle terrorism, cybercrime and organised crime in a European and coordinated way. But you can see in this debate today that we may agree on the objective, but not on the means at all. Solutions in the sphere of mass surveillance have so far not proven to help. This Parliament has been asking for evidence for a very long time that PNR and TFTP are effective. So far, none of that has come into the house. In fact, it leads to unsung security services who think it's okay to spy on the neighbors for a third country. I understand, in the light of major disasters like the one we've seen in Tunisia, Paris or the London Underground, that you want to take big measures. Major disasters call for major measures, here and now. But they also ask for the cool heart that says, "Does it work? And prove it." Because if we do not, we run the risk of taking measures that do not work, but which limit our freedom. The Greens stand for old-fashioned detective work, not just the search for wires and the profiling of people, but the search for the real dangers. And we don't do that with mass surveillance. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Sargentini, I would like to thank Mrs Sargentini for her work on this report. I have a question. We had a lot of pundits on passenger name records, we had experts with us who have now explained the TFTP to us. I visited Europol and i was informed about the TFTP. Why are you simply repeating the untruth that these instruments are not useful when the experts have shown us on a daily basis that they are useful and are now being used in a very targeted manner?

name: Judith Sargentini (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" answer. I would like to say two things. First of all, if you have obtained the evidence, I wonder why the rest of us are still waiting for it. I think experts have shown evidence that they are different from simply showing them to MEPs who have to make a very difficult ethical assessment. I haven't seen them yet. Secondly, we put money and time into initiatives that we do not stop in the real search. Can I just mention you? Toulouse: we knew the man. The Jewish Museum in Brussels: we knew the man. Detroit: we knew the boys. Every time it turns out to be people we know, but we didn't do anything.

name: Gerard Batten
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, this motion for a resolution calls for the implementation of the European Agenda on Security, and various spurious reasons are given for the growth in international crime and terrorism. As usual, the EU solution to any problem is to call for an increase in its powers and to usurp the powers of the democratic governments of nation states. The fundamental problem in relation to the increasing crime in some Member States is the EU’s own open borders policy. The fundamental problem in relation to the increase in terrorism is the growth of Islamic fundamentalism. Neither of these problems is addressed in this motion. The start of a solution is to return border controls to nation states, which would discourage and hamper the movement of criminals, illegal migrants and terrorists. When such barriers are in place, we can then adopt genuine security cooperation measures between independent nation states.

name: Vicky Maeijer
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. You would think that a piece entitled 'Security Agenda' would make the European Union a little safer. But nothing could be further from the truth. It is again a lot of bleating and little wool. The Commission and the resolution also call on paper for a strong response to terrorism, but it is easy to forget to mention the source of terror, namely Islam. This naivety and lack of any realism are the greatest threat to security in the European Union. How many more victims are there to fall? How many more beheadings, bombings, shootings in the name of the so-called "religion of peace"? As long as you walk away from reality, the European Union will not be safer on it. As long as you continue to import hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants and terrorists, it won't get any safer. And as long as we are stuck here with a foreign policy chief who thinks that Islam belongs to Europe, it really will not be safer. You can still present 100 security agendas and resolutions in this way, but until you acknowledge that Islam is at the forefront of virtually all terrorist attacks, the security of our citizens is at risk. The time for looking away is really over. Stop the Islamization of our continent. Stop mass immigration, close the borders and protect the people of our countries.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, once the ancient Greek poet Aristophanes wrote: "People with wisdom often learn a lot from their enemies". Wisdom is a good guard. From enemies, not friends, we learned to build high walls and build big ships. This lesson saves our children, our homes, our goods.  In Europe we are talking about security; The extremists of the Islamic State whose creation is it? Drugs, cross-border crime, migrant smuggling rings, human traffickers, which centres of power do they finance? The brutal intervention in Syria and Libya has been translated into a restoration of legitimacy. The foreigners who live among us have been translated into European citizens, who are thickening the ranks of terrorist organisations. The millions of illegal immigrants have been baptized as irregular immigrants. You've made Europe unhinged. As long as we vote on reports and amendments, the enemy kills Christians, destroys ancient monuments, recruits new fighters and plans to destroy Europe. You forgot that the best way to deal with the enemy is on the battlefield and not wait until it invades our homes. But the first enemy we have to face is within us. He's often the only one.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: – Madam President, forgive me for going straight to the point, but thank you first, Claude Moraes. For me, the main threat to European security, while there are others, is terror, the Daesh. The Daesh uses cruel, selective or indiscriminate terror, and uses it as an essential instrument for the conquest and occupation of the territory. Eurojust declared yesterday that there are already 10,000 European terrorists. Many use clandestine immigration networks to go back and go. The expansive lethal phenomenon is also spreading in the south: Al Nusra, Al Shabab or Boko Haram are daily examples. Thus, we have serious threats to the east, to the south and at home, within Europe. It takes a coordinated and urgent response, because no, terror doesn't stop, and neither does its expansion. I am talking about what we can and should give here in Parliament what we can do for our agenda: a PNR already, tomorrow, next week there will be votes; tFTS, a European system for monitoring the financing of terror; a strengthened and funded policy against cybercrime; more budget for Europol, its CAT and Eurojust; more average: $153 billion is going to be by 2016 and a ridiculous budget for security—new risk, budget; and a new legislative package on cross-cutting smart borders, which also looks at security aspects. Then the rest.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Europe is more than a single market. Above all, Europe should be a common area of justice, security and freedom. That is what the citizens expect. They expect the rule of law, security and freedom.  This security strategy is very positive and I wish it a success. It is very important for all of us that we combat terrorism, through de-radicalisation work, which we perhaps talk about too little, by combating the financing of terrorism, where we should be bolder, by revising the rules on the trade in firearms, which we should be paying more attention to, and by security at our borders. We should be particularly careful and prudent here, because it is also a question of safeguarding the freedom of citizens.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: – In September 2015, Europol coordinated Operation Archimedes. This operation fought crime in 34 countries and led to more than a thousand arrests across Europe. This shows that cooperation between EU Member States to combat organised crime is actually delivering results. The Security Agenda recognises that EU agencies play a crucial role in facilitating such cross-border cooperation. It is essential that these institutions have the expertise and financial resources to operate efficiently. This afternoon we voted on the Rubial report on the draft amending budget No 100 000.  5/2015, where the Commission was asked to analyse the financial impact of the migration agenda. The same exercise on the efficient spending of taxpayers' money must also be done for the security agenda. Threats, trends and priorities are constantly changing. That is why it is important for the Commission to take this into account when setting priorities for budgeting. The Commission has previously indicated that the use of the European Internal Security Fund would be aligned with the priorities of the agenda. Can the Commission therefore indicate whether or not it intends to evaluate the needs of this fund until 2020 in the context of the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework?

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: – Madam President. Commissioner, you know that. We need the security agenda to include items that we didn't take into account before. Threats are growing, hybrid, mutant. The challenges: deradicization, network action, care for victims, social leadership in prevention. Threats to our freedoms take on unusual faces and we must face them without obsession, democratically, seeking, yes, maximum unity and effectiveness. In general, we write more than the account in this Parliament, Commissioner, but this report needs the words we have written and some questions: How are they going to implement the agenda? How are we going to supervise the MPs? Will they endow it enough? Because there are good ideas, which can become words, ashes, smoke, and we need to avoid, as much as possible, ash, smoke, blood, rage and fear. And I know what I'm talking about.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, the agenda we are debating today recalls the real need to give european people a sense of security. But the "security or freedom" dilemma is artificial and misleading. We can have more security and together more freedom and justice. This presupposes full respect for international and European human rights law as well as democratic principles. Moreover, security policies should not be treated in isolation but as part of a complex approach to economic and social issues. We need more solidarity both within societies and between the Member States of the Union and not punitive logics such as those currently being traded against the Greek people, who have been suffering for years, and who tomorrow can be applied to anyone else. But European unification cannot be based on fear. Europe needs a more general change of course before it is too late.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the cross-border nature of the threats to the internal security of the European Union imposes measures and means of law enforcement of the same character: an effective fight against terrorism, organised crime and cybercrime can and must be achieved through closer police and judicial cooperation, the exchange of information between Member States and with third countries. Criminal groups, especially mafia-type groups, are the first to take advantage of loopholes in cross-border law enforcement activities.  Trafficking in migrants and trafficking in human beings, arms trade, drug trafficking and environmental and financial crimes have or have a huge human, social and economic impact, affecting fundamental rights, health and the environment. Organised crime, with its ability to infiltrate the legal economy and pollute institutions, heavily influences political and economic decision-making processes. The European institutions and agencies, the Member States and the competent actors of civil society must play a key role in raising the level of internal security, identifying and implementing common means of combating, with respect for fundamental rights, aimed at tracing the financial operations of criminal networks, and freezing and confiscating illegal assets and resources.

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would especially like to thank Claude Moraes for his work on this subject. The European Agenda on Security is a comprehensive action plan. What we need now is a clear schedule on how to implement all of those solutions as soon as possible. In the implementation we should respect the division of competences – what should be done by the Union and what should remain as national competences – while being more open to cooperation. The digital revolution brought us tremendous possibilities and advantages, but it is also abused by criminals. The estimated value of cybercrime activity in 2014 was USD 400 billion, and such activity relates to financial fraud, child pornography, new psychoactive substances, hacking all kinds of data and identities, and various forms of cyber terrorism. Organised crime not only uses technological digital developments; the criminals are rapidly developing their skills and their tools. Therefore, we need to provide our law enforcement agencies with modern technology and tools. Developing such solutions is not cheap, and it is time consuming. It is clear that we need to converge on the response and promote pan-European, intercontinental cooperation in that matter and build on public-private cooperation. Research and innovation can be the successful source for new forms of security; this is the new concept of data-driven security. For this, we should build up the capacity of EU agencies and give them adequate resources and a proper regulatory framework and stimulate cooperation.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the context of European intervention in the field of security, which has been made more penetrating as a result of the Treaty of Lisbon, the security agenda is certainly a good framework: it sets out a series of principles, strategic priorities, guidelines consistent with current needs and with the changed institutional framework. However, this framework must be filled with concrete and effective measures at legislative and operational level.  That is why we need – and I am pleased that the Presidency of the Council has already mentioned this – a road map which, with constant attention to the topicality of the threats, will determine steps to be taken and the timing and also of the valid criteria for verifying the progress of the implementation of the measures, including through the establishment of a political cycle of the Union on security. Even now, the Commissioner has stressed that safety must remain a priority. However, institutional mechanisms must be introduced to ensure that the five key principles of the agenda are actually effectively fully designed. The adoption this year of the data protection package, especially the directive on criminal authorities, would be very useful, and it would also be useful to present the feasibility study on confiscation as soon as possible this year in the absence of conviction. It is a fundamental measure to combat not only organised crime, but also, more generally, money laundering, corruption and the financing of terrorism.  Finally, I believe that there is an urgent need for a serious assessment of the current instruments and their shortcomings, as a prerequisite for better use of the legislation of the existing instruments, adapting, if necessary, the human and financial resources of the European agencies, but also for the creation of new rules and instruments and structures, where necessary, as in the case of the European Public Prosecutor' s Office, as rightly stated in the security agenda itself.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Madam President, honourable Members, perhaps symbolically today, ten years after the London bombings, we are having this conversation in the European Parliament building. And while security should be and is a priority of sovereign national states, the European Commission still has its obligations under the European Agenda on Security. Undoubtedly, the biggest threat to European peoples today is Islamist terror. The lack of reliable security at the southern borders threatens the security of European Union citizens. To the south of us grows a huge threat, which gave already its poisonous fruits in Madrid, London, Paris, Lyon, Copenhagen and in many other European cities. Islamist terror growing in the south of us, supported by the government of the Republic of Turkey, threatens not only security, threatens the identity, self-consciousness, culture and security of all European peoples.  The European agenda must be aimed at strengthening the southern borders of the European Union. It is necessary to build and complete a protective facility along the Bulgarian-Turkish border. The trafficking of migrants, including Islamic State fighters, through the Black Sea, which is inevitably created, needs to be deterred. It is necessary to strengthen intelligence sharing and cooperation within the European Union in order to prevent terrorists from moving within the borders of this European Union.  Do I need to remind myself that the perpetrators of the terrorist acts in both Paris and London and Madrid were citizens of their countries, i.e. European citizens? It is time for the European Commission not only to declare security as its priority, not only to hold continuous meetings, but also to put into practice the measures listed.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Mr President-in-Office, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, after Claude Moraes, many have recalled that it has been ten years since the London attacks and six months since the attack on Charlie Hebdo. Outside the European Union, I would like to recall the recent attacks in Egypt, Nigeria and Libya. I would like to congratulate the Commissioner on the adoption of the European Agenda on Security 2015-2020, which does not ignore this link between internal security and the Union's external security.  However, I would like to highlight two points which seem crucial to me. The first is that we must continue to stimulate mutual trust between member states. More than multiplying single measures or great media, we need to use the full potential of the measures and instruments that are already in operation, making adjustments whenever necessary. The Schengen information system and the new Schengen evaluation mechanism are good examples. Of course, we need more Europe, and the Union agencies, starting with EUROPOL and FRONTEX, need to have a legal mandate, human and financial means in order to be able to effectively fulfil their growing role, as Mr Boni has just recalled. I leave two questions here. Is the European Commission prepared to take on its new role in monitoring the Schengen acquis? And how do you intend to cooperate with Parliament? Is the Council really willing to give a more relevant role to European agencies in the field of internal security?  Mr President, over the last fifteen years the Union has developed and implemented a strategy to combat terrorism. We must be able to act and adapt according to the times, but we cannot give in to outdated nationalisms or security populism.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the threats against the internal security of the European Union are growing every day. Many have become unconventional, asymmetrical, fast and difficult to predict. Each Member State must defend its internal and external security, but the Union must also have its own security strategy to apply with the Member States. And trust here - trust between Member States and confidence of the Union in each Member State - is very important.  There is still no real European governance of the common area of freedom, security and justice that is the European Union. How there is no common defence policy and no European army to intervene for the maintenance of peace when it is in danger in a Member State or in a neighbouring State.  The European Agenda on Security, which we are discussing today, and I congratulate the Commission on its adoption, has three priorities. The first priority is the fight against terrorism and the stopping of European citizens from joining terrorist groups. Another priority is the fight against cybercrime and a third priority is the fight against cross-border organised crime.  Organised crime funds terrorism, brings weapons to terrorist groups and infiltrates the economy. The European Anti-Fraud Prosecutor and the Joint Investigation Groups must work as soon as possible within the Union. Confiscation of the money used, which comes from organised crime, is vital. Black money that travels freely creates death and brings terrorism. We save lives by fighting organized crime and confiscing money.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: – Thank you to the Commission for the European Security Agenda. Security is the most important issue at the moment and I would like to thank the Commission for its clear focus on three very specific issues. I had hoped that we would be able to put the same focus on Parliament, but I am sorry to say that we have not succeeded. In Article 2 of this resolution, we are already sending the Commissioner out into the wider world to combat possible perceptions of unfairness in eu foreign policy, as Don Quixote once tried to combat the windmills.
