I would have hoped that we as a Parliament could have put a much greater focus on the safety of 500 million people. Three priorities. A great deal has been said about terrorism. I would like to talk about organised crime, particularly in the border regions. Our borders may have disappeared on paper, but criminal gangs still know how to find them in practice. Trafficking in human beings, drug trafficking, prostitution, motorcycle gangs are increasingly literally pushing the borders. I would therefore like to call for better cooperation, better exchange of information between Member States in the area of policing and judicial work, and much more work on cross-border confiscation and asset freezing. A third point: joint research teams are a great tool. They should be used much more often anyway. But a specific question to the Commissioner and to the Council: can we not also set up permanent and semi-permanent joint investigation teams to provide a much more structural response to structural crime in the border region?

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I have listened very carefully to this debate and I would like to bring a specific element and observation from the Czech Republic, from my country, into the relatively general debate. We in the Czech Republic, as lawyers, are debating whether Czech law allows the phenomenon of foreign fighters to be sanctioned. It is not clear, there are different legal opinions on this, whether or not participation in the armed forces, such as the Islamic State, is or is not criminal. I would therefore strongly recommend (and it is my advice to the European Commission and the Commissioner) that we really update the Framework Decision on terrorism within the framework of the programme and clearly define that the phenomenon of foreign fighters is criminal, it should be criminal in all the legal systems of all the Member States of the European Union, and we have clearly described what the phenomenon of a foreign fighter means so that we can have uniform arrangements so that we can fight this together effectively. when Europeans leave to fight in the colors of the Islamic State.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, let me start by thanking Claude Moraes for the good job that he is doing. The EU security agenda is a welcome framework in which to address the rise in organised crime, terrorism and cyber crime. Cross-border cooperation and exchanges of information must be strengthened, whilst upholding the right to freedom of movement and privacy for EU citizens. However, crime and terrorist activities are not confined within the borders of the EU. EU internal security and global security are mutually dependent and interlinked. Radicalisation must not only be tackled at local and EU level, through community integration work and education and by having dialogue and anti—discrimination policies; it must also be tackled outside our borders, as the challenge we are facing also has origins outside the EU. Common security and defence policies play an important role in realising the EU’s security goals. The EU has never before faced such a convergence of security crises on its doorstep. Security and defence now matter more than ever. We need to stop talking about security: it is high time we started delivering security.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, as is well known, criminal activities know no borders and have a global character. Terrorism, organised crime, prostitution, arms smuggling, online piracy are some of the areas included in the new European Agenda 2015-2020 on security. But the question is how best to protect European security; how can we make security more efficient for the five hundred million inhabitants of the European Union. I believe that mutual trust between the Member States of the European Union, more efficient cross-border cooperation with Frontex and closer cooperation with other international organisations such as the OSCE could make European security more effective and crucial in terms of the objectives and results it seeks. The new European Security Agenda must serve society and the citizen itself, and that means ensuring a framework that respects the fundamental freedoms of European citizens, their personal data and their privacy.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, this is another example of where we need more Europe. More Europe, better coordination, better connectivity and understanding among Member States that the EU must coordinate this difficult security work.  It has never been more difficult, worse, more dangerous and if there is no clear joint cooperation between member states' police services or member states' security services at all, coordinated through EU bodies, it will not be good.  Of course criminals know no borders, of course everything we are aware of today, which is fighters and terrorists coming to our territories, all of what we see as cybercrime – all this knows no borders. That's why we need more Europe.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I would like to ask that the European Union stop playing bag cats and speaking in double language. Here and now, if and if the European Commissioner listens to me, I would ask you, Commissioner and the rapporter, as well as the Representative of the Council, to give a clear answer to the public as to whether Hungary has the right to its own border, which is also the Schengen border with the European Union, to protect it from criminals, terrorists and illegal border offenders beyond the border by building a fence? Do you have the right to restore your Border Patrol? Here, you are constantly talking – calming the European public, citizens – about protecting the citizens of the European Union from cross-border crime, especially terrorism, while thousands of border offenders enter Hungary across the green border. They're obviously not all terrorists, but they could very easily be terrorists. What's your answer, Commissioner?

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, the challenges we have faced over the past year have made it clear to us that threats to the Internal Security of the European Union have become more complex and unconventional. It is increasingly difficult to predict and tackling them requires a common integrated approach by all Member States, with a clear division of tasks at European and national level.  The main causes of high crime are: increasing inequality, poverty, racial and xenophobic hatred, and they cannot be solved by security measures. They need to be addressed in a broader context, which includes social and employment policy as well as education. But also taking measures to reintegrate the most affected parts of our societies.  Completing, I welcome the European Agenda on Security 2015-2020 proposed by the Commission, as well as the priorities set out therein. But I also want to emphasise the fact that we must also be ready to face new challenges in the near future.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, first of all I would like to express my thanks to all of you for this debate on the future of EU internal security. Referring to some of your remarks and your questions on counter-terrorism, I would like to inform you that during our debate that will take place tomorrow, as you know, I plan to update you in detail on the work that is ongoing. Today, as you know, was the third time that the Commission and the European Parliament have exchanged views on the content of the European Agenda on Security. Last December, this Parliament gave useful advice and guidance to the Commission in its preparation of the agenda. Let me tell you that I took note of almost everything that was said, and I want to express my gratitude for your contributions. In April this year, the Commission responded to the European Parliament’s resolution by presenting the European Agenda on Security. As you have seen, the Commission’s agenda took up much of your earlier guidance. In the short period of one semester, the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council have developed in a successful way a shared vision of what needs to be done in concrete terms at Union level to make Europe more secure for the sake of our citizens. We have found common ground on the main threats, principles and priorities, and thereby defined a renewed Internal Security Strategy. In the spirit of the Lisbon Treaty it is now time to work closely together towards the implementation of this renewed strategy. One institution alone cannot meet the ambitious goals that we have set for ourselves. Our three institutions are mutually interdependent to deliver. We are all each other’s key partner. Therefore, permanent and flexible cooperation is needed to ensure consistency, complementarity and continuity of action over the next five years. I am looking forward to this cooperation.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, I would like to thank mr MEP once again for asking these questions which have enabled us to have this important debate on a subject of deepest concern to our citizens.  In fact, I do not have much to add to what the Commissioner has just said. Of course, the right to security is a fundamental right and we all know - and you have repeatedly said this - that our countries and our citizens are facing all kinds of new phenomena of crime or terrorism; the two very often going together. These phenomena ignore borders. They operate on a truly global scale and use and master, sometimes to perfection, new technologies. Hence the real threat that comes from cybercrime. It is also true that terrorism poses a real challenge to us. A challenge to our open societies, a challenge to our states and democratic systems for which security and freedom, freedom and security are intimately linked. That is the strength of our democracies. That is why this strategy is so important and we need to work together to implement it effectively. It will help strengthen our Union so that it protects its citizens and fully respects rights and freedoms.  The Luxembourg Presidency is determined to favour a comprehensive approach that involves all stakeholders. It will pay close attention to the views and concerns of Parliament as expressed in today's debate and in its resolution.

name: President. –
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 9 July 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Agenda on Security, adopted at the end of April, is an important step in ensuring European security over the next few years. It takes into account ever-evolving threats and offers flexible measures and solutions for a more secure Europe. At the same time, the success of the programme depends in particular on how Member States implement the proposed measures and how cooperation with the European institutions and relevant agencies proceeds. It is therefore essential that existing information exchange tools such as the Schengen Information System and the Criminal Records Exchange System are made the most of the relevant services. It is important to strengthen the coordinating role of agencies such as Europol, especially in the fight against terrorism and organised crime. Last but not least, legislative initiatives taken such as the EPPO must be adopted as soon as possible. In order to ensure the implementation of the security agenda, I call on the European Commission to draw up an action plan describing what concrete steps will be taken when to implement the proposed measures. The European Action Plan must be complemented by plans from each Member State, and synergy between action must be sought at European and national level. Only in this way will the strategy become a reality.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the joint debate on – the report by Laura Agea, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the proposal for a Council decision on guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States (COM(2015)0098 – C8—0075/2015 – 2015/0051(NLE)) (A8-0205/2015), and – the report by Jean Lambert, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the Green Employment Initiative: Tapping into the job creation potential of the green economy (2014/2238(INI)) (A8—0204/2015).

name: Laura Agea
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the guidelines for Member States' employment policies can be a powerful tool for countering the effects of a crisis that has incinerated millions of jobs and literally destroyed the lives of tens of thousands of people. And the stronger and more shared the document we manage to adopt, the harder it will be for the Council to ignore it. We cannot allow the mistakes of the past to be repeated. The indications of these guides have not been met and the situation has even worsened over the last five years. However, historically, European efforts have concentrated on the constant improvement of the living and working conditions of its peoples: the promotion of employment, the right to work and working conditions, training, further training, social security and trade union law.  Despite this, the Eu ropean Union has put the turbo on the economy and finance, while it has left in the background the urgency of the policies essential to ensure recovery and a dignified life for European citizens. Structural reforms and budgetary policies have produced an unsustainable situation, with stagnation and deflation in many Member States, especially in the euro area, with dramatic realities, as we can unfortunately see in various States, particularly in Italy, Portugal and Greece. The Europe 2020 strategy itself calls on us to lay down the conditions for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, which aims to increase the employment rate, by creating the quality and quantity of lasting jobs, by reducing the drop-out rate and by increasing the level of tertiary education. Support measures are needed for those who do not have a job but also accompanying measures for reintegration into work, through the retraining of skills and actions that stimulate lifelong learning. I also believe that we need to define certain indications of the absolute poverty afflicting millions of Europeans. We cannot continue to talk about the risk of poverty. Misery is out there and it grips the lives of many people, condemning them to an existence of hardship and deprivation. I believe that action must be taken to reduce poverty, with the aim of removing at least 20 million people from the uncertainty and anguish caused by their living conditions. A minimum income must be introduced in all Member States to combat poverty and social exclusion, as Mr Juncker and Commissioner Thyssen have already said. To date, as many as 26 out of 28 countries have adopted forms of income support, leaving the Union unfinished, since in Italy and Greece this right is still denied. Ladies and gentlemen, we can propose effective and shared policies to combat unemployment, with actions aimed at favouring not only small and medium-sized enterprises, but also micro-enterprises, innovative start-ups and businesses that aim for the green economy. We can speak out in order to reduce the segmentation of the labour market through a restructuring of collective bargaining and the involvement of the social partners, combating undeclared work and precarious employment. We can reduce discrimination in access to the labour market. We can facilitate the mobility of workers where this is an opportunity. We can contribute to the development of sustainable, safe, adequate pension systems for women and men, with schemes that guarantee decent income support. We can reintroduce the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy into the guidelines, significantly increasing the employment of citizens. We can put the founding principles of economic, social and cultural union back at the centre by creating jobs, cohesion and inclusion. We can now! I therefore hope that there will be a clear expression from this Parliament, because 500 million European citizens are waiting for an effective response: let us give this answer together.

name: Jean Lambert
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I wanted to start by thanking all the shadows for their very serious input to my report and also the opinions from the two committees. We also held a round table in Brussels and a hearing in the committee. I really welcome all the additional input that came from those that participated. While the issue around green jobs was originally to have been published with the circular economy paper with the previous Commission, I really welcome the opportunity to debate it this evening, in particular with a very good report on employment guidelines, which I think makes this discussion more strategic, rather than a small niche area. We know that the European Union needs jobs. We have just heard that being very eloquently put. We can identify a number of new sectors where we can find them. And we have seen resilience, for example in the environmental services sector, during the crisis. We also know we need to respond to global trends, the inefficient re-use of resources, the unsustainable pressure on our environment and, indeed, climate change. We know that we have growing social exclusion and inequalities challenging our societies. So we really need to maximise the employment potential of new sectors. We need to change working practices and methods to increase resource efficiency, minimise environmental impact and take care of those whose existing employment may be adversely affected by change. We also want to ensure that those new jobs are quality jobs that actually pay a decent wage, as the International Labour Organisation has in its definition of a green job. So what does it take to help maximise this potential? We were clearly told in the hearing and elsewhere that we need a coherent comprehensive policy framework which will provide a predictable environment for training and investment. That was recognised at the meeting of EU environment and employment ministers not so long ago. So we need policies that are mutually reinforcing, not running off in different directions. Whether that is within the Semester or within the EU 2020 Strategy and the review of the strategy, we need the ‘Just Transition’ roadmaps which will move from the local level onwards to actually help people plan for the changes that we need. We need this to be reinforced by an efficient implementation of relevant EU legislation with clear and ambitious targets where those are appropriate. We also need this effort to be supported strategically by European Union funds, including as well the 2016 review of the Multiannual Financial Framework, using that as an opportunity to promote the green transition of the economy. We were also told in the background to this report that there are three very effective drivers of change: environmental tax reform (which proved very controversial in the committee), energy and resource efficiency and the development of the supply chain. We are also aware how essential workforce engagement is in initiating, owning and helping to create the necessary changes. There is clear evidence of the value of this engagement. So we should be taking full advantage of the existing experience and opportunities within social partnership and sectoral and social dialogue. There are many companies that want to make changes but are not confident or cannot find people with the right skills. So we need to raise general awareness, to promote stem skills and to make sure that women can also participate in the new economy. We need to look at generic sectoral and specific skills, as well as at supporting SMEs in the changes that they are trying to make.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, my thanks to the rapporteurs for their report and for their introduction. As we all know, the crisis has brought us further away from our employment and social inclusion targets under the Europe 2020 strategy, with some little signs of improvement coming only recently. It is good news that the economy is recovering, but it is also true that many European citizens do not yet feel it. The Commission proposed its new employment guidelines as part of the integrated guidelines on 2 March. Our goal was to take a comprehensive approach to employment, social and macro-economic objectives. Indeed, the integrated guidelines also frame the scope and direction of the Union’s policy coordination of Member States’ policies and provide a basis for country-specific recommendations. The Commission has opted for more concise, targeted and operational employment guidelines with a view to sharpening the focus on key priorities and improve ownership and implementation by Member States. The guidelines are fully in line with the new approach to economic policy—making built on investment, structural reform and fiscal responsibility. The employment guidelines need to be applied on a national, regional and even local level and, of course, in close coordination with the social partners. Indeed, the employment guidelines provide guidance firstly on boosting demand for labour. This refers directly to the investment plan, with the goal to increase investment by EUR 315 billion and the need to reduce bottlenecks to investment and growth and shift taxation away from labour. Secondly: enhancing the labour supply, skills and competences. Making the most of our human capital is fundamental. We have already acted by injecting one billion euros for the pre-financing of the youth employment initiative. After the summer, the Commission will propose to the Council a recommendation to fight long-term unemployment, and we are working on a comprehensive skills strategy. Investment in human capital is the main approach needed in order to support productivity gains and ensure that future growth is both job-rich and inclusive. Thirdly: enhancing labour market functioning. Member States need to step up progress in labour market reforms, eliminate the segmentation of the labour market, improve active labour market policies and protect workers rather than jobs. Fourthly: fostering social inclusion, combating poverty and promoting equal opportunities. The guidelines clearly put the accent on modernising social protection systems so that they can effectively provide adequate protection throughout all stages of an individual’s life. This affects all pillars of social protection – not only pensions but also access to healthcare, education, childcare and other enabling services. I am delighted that, in general, the European Parliament is supporting the Commission’s approach. I especially note that, in the opinion of Parliament, qualitative and social considerations must find their place throughout the employment guidelines. I feel it is right to say that this has been the concern of the Commission in drafting its proposal. Our aim is to achieve sustainable growth so as to allow upward social convergence and to bring concrete results to the European citizens. This means that job creation will continue to be our number one priority, because it is also what people – men and women – care most about: having a good and decent job. Let me say a word on green jobs. A year ago, the Commission adopted the communication on the Green Employment Initiative, tapping into the job creation potential of the green economy, calling for an integrated approach and supporting employment in the green economy. Generating green growth is good for society at large. The environmental goods and services sector has been one of Europe’s success stories in the last decade and a half. The number of Europeans employed in this sector increased from around 3 million to 4.3 million people between 2002 and 2012. This positive growth in jobs continued even throughout the recession. I would like to focus on two actions proposed in the communication where the Commission may bring added value. Firstly, further investment in green skills. The transition to a circular economy needs to be underpinned by changes to qualifications and national education and training curricula to meet emerging occupational needs. Such a process needs to be based on commonly-defined competence standards in order to facilitate cross-border certification and to ease professional mobility in the sector. Secondly, involvement of the social partners, in particular, in the most concerned sectors, for example: electricity, extractive industries, gas, transport and construction. Involvement of the social partners can also help in overcoming barriers to the circular economy. In this context your report is very welcome. It addresses a number of pertinent issues, like a call for creating the conditions for a fair transition to quality and sustainable jobs, addressing the skills gaps and mismatches, full implementation of environmental legislation and enhancing participation of workers in the transition. My efforts, as well as those of my fellow Commissioners, in respect of the circular economy package or the Energy Union have the potential to enrich the implementation of the Green Employment Initiative. Dear Members of Parliament, both your reports, on Green jobs and on Employment Guidelines, are certainly an additional impetus for us to continue working together on these topics.

name: Eleonora Evi
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the dichotomy between economy and ecology has been strengthened over time by the succession of logics and policies for maximising profits, production and consumption. We are finally realising that, as a result of the alarming signals coming from our planet, the two dimensions, economic and ecological, are living together and not only synergistically creating prosperity and employment. And we are talking about really important numbers: millions of jobs that can be created by exploiting the potential of the green economy, for example, in energy efficiency and resources, in the life cycle of products, from design to repair to reuse, in the protection and maintenance of the environment and the safety of our territory.  As draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, I would like to mention some of the most important measures, which have, moreover, been taken up by Mrs Lambert, namely the elimination of all subsidies, direct and indirect, harmful to the environment, including those for fossil fuels, the shift of taxation from work to environmental pollution and the use of resources in the spirit of the 'polluter pays' principle. Finally, the introduction of a system of tax relief for SMEs, the real backbone of Europe, through appropriate tax relief instruments for those companies that produce products and services with high environmental added value.

name: Monika Vana
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights, I would like to say that we very much welcome the report on green employment, not only because of the enormous job potential, but also because of the resistance to the crisis of green employment. Green jobs are investments for the future. However, in order for women to benefit from green jobs, as has already been mentioned today, we must overcome the blind spot of the lack of a gender perspective and the so-called glass ceiling in the green economy and significantly increase the proportion of women in the green jobs sector through investment in education – green skills, as the Commissioner has already mentioned – and active labour market policy.  Member States and the regional and local level are also called upon to exploit the potential, for example, of public services and public procurement for green jobs, and to promote women's business activities in the green economy. The Committee on Women's Rights also encourages the use of the UN and the definition of the International Labour Organisation for Green Jobs. Green jobs are not only environmentally friendly, but also vital.

name: Georges Bach
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The guidelines for member employment policies of the Member States are an integral part of the European Semester. Unfortunately, the European Semester was already concluded at the European Council at the end of June with the adoption of the recommendations. Since we are not voting on our position until tomorrow, I regret this poor timing, because we cannot therefore incorporate our considerations into the recommendations. Nevertheless, I hope that Parliament's position in the Council will be taken into account. For us as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, the text contains a number of very important points. For example, it is important to us that the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy are confirmed in a new way. These employment guidelines, which have been revised this year for the first time since 2010 and are dealing with the crisis, this high level of unemployment, this youth unemployment, long-term unemployment and rising poverty are among the most important points on which we attach great importance and which we must address. As the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, we also support the Commission's new priorities for more growth and job creation without debt, investment, structural reforms and responsible fiscal policy. Commissioner Marianne Thyssen has now made a list and set her priorities. That is absolutely to be welcomed. We also believe that a minimum income should be considered. We stress that, in accordance with the Treaties, it should be done at national level and also in accordance with national rules and practices. Other important points are the reduction of the early school leaving rate, the promotion of businesses – including entrepreneurship among young people – and, of course, the focus on small and medium-sized enterprises, mobility within Europe and, as I said, the fight against unemployment. Qualifications, and in particular the transition from school to work, should also be improved. Finally, I would like to express the hope that the Council will take up our recommendations. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Laura Agea, for the good cooperation.

name: Jutta Steinruck
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Above all, we have a key employment policy guideline, namely the creation of sustainable and high-quality jobs in Europe. The fight against unemployment must be a top priority, especially the fight against youth unemployment.  In general, I would like to thank the rapporteur. Your report makes really important corrections to the Commission's draft. On the one hand, the mobility of workers is an opportunity – but it must not become an obligation.  For mobility, we also need accompanying measures, such as improving the transfer of pension rights, recognising qualifications, and much must also be made easier for workers.  The second important point is a clear rejection of automatic pensions. The link between the retirement age and life expectancy must be deleted in the Commission's draft. It is not the appropriate instrument, because only a high level of employment and really good jobs ensure the sustainability of public finances and also of the pension system.  What is clear is that guidelines that have been said are not enough. There must be mandatory rules.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Although we are against centralisation and over-harmonisation within the European Union, we will vote as the Polish delegation in the ECR in favour of mrs Agei's report. Not only because this report rightly points out on several occasions the need to remove obstacles for small and medium-sized enterprises, but also because, in times of crisis, it is particularly important to recall the social dimension of the economy and to point out the need for an active employment policy.  Of course, this policy should be primarily the responsibility of the Member States, but they should be exchanged best practices and the Commission should encourage them to make effective efforts to combat unemployment and social exclusion. However, we are sceptical about artificially supporting green jobs at the expense of other jobs.

name: Renate Weber
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I want to thank the rapporteur for the good cooperation we had and for her constructive efforts, regardless of our differing political views. It is a shame that, in spite of the importance of these employment guidelines, Parliament is involved only in a consultation procedure. I consider this very unfortunate in a time when ‘more Europe’ is needed, which should imply, above all, the European citizens’ representatives. At the core of these guidelines there are two aspects: employment and education. We are struggling with higher rates of unemployment, particularly youth unemployment, and the shortage or mismatch of skills. This ultimately points to education again. Therefore, Member States are being asked and encouraged to tailor policies aiming to boost employment and to curb unemployment, especially among the young population. To achieve these goals they should adapt the education framework so as to be able to foresee future changes in the labour market and thus to prevent skill mismatches. We need realistic and pragmatic approaches to take into consideration each Member State’s specificity. Education adapted to the needs of the market, apprenticeships, traineeships, sustainable jobs and quality employment are what we should aim for. On the other hand, I am a strong defender of having minimum wages, according to the economic and social capacities of each Member State, although I prefer solutions that create opportunities for employment, rather than measures – such as the minimum wage – which may risk prolonging unemployment and perpetuate a static society. Inter-EU job mobility should be considered one of the answers here. Therefore, fake ‘scarecrows’, such as abuses of national social security systems, recently used by politicians, should be disregarded, as they undermine the European idea and the principles it was built on.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, it is contradictory on the one hand to promote deregulation of industrial relations and neoliberal policies of austerity and memoranda and, on the other hand, to discuss social aspects of the European Semester or employment guidelines in the same context. The Commission's employment guidelines, which are part of the European Semester, are far from giving a minimum social face to the European Semester process, let alone actually promoting decent employment.  We thank My Colleague Laura Agea for her work and for the positive references to the report. Our positions, as the Left, have been clear from the outset: for us we do not mean employment without social security, without decent wages, without securing jobs and without guaranteeing the right to collective bargaining. Employment which does not guarantee a decent living for workers is not understood. The wage dumping observed in Germany and the salaries of three hundred and four hundred euros, promoted in Greece and the other countries of the South, are nothing but a clear attack on the dignity of workers' lives. They result in the poverty of the peoples of the European Union and their impoverishment.  In order to improve the working and living conditions of workers, we have tabled amendments in plenary which ensure at least one safety net for the minimum guaranteed income and we call on colleagues to vote in favour. As GUE we will continue to fight with trade unions and the mass grassroots movement for the right to work and for decent and quality jobs.

name: Tatjana Ždanoka
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the new employment guidelines proposed by the Commission are, to our regret, weaker than the previous ones. Therefore the rapporteur and her shadow rapporteurs had a very responsible task to work out more ambitious proposals for Parliament’s position. The text approved by a large majority of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs goes much further than the Commission, and I want to congratulate Laura Agea for this. The Commission does not provide any actions at the level of the European Parliament – it is all up to the Member States – and this matter was not mentioned in Commissioner Thyssen’s statement. Parliament’s report calls for EU action towards an EU social protection floor. It calls for decent minimum wages across the EU and offers a number of other concrete proposals. So we hope very much that the Council will take Parliament’s input on board. Nevertheless, the request for codecision in the guidelines included in this report is extremely relevant and reasonable.

name: Jane Collins
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, according to the figures quoted in this report, the renewable energy economy will create 20 million new jobs in Europe. But let us look at some of the numbers behind that headline statistic. Research by a Spanish academic found that for every one green job created, another 2.2 jobs were lost in the real economy. In the manufacturing sector alone it is estimated that about four jobs are lost for every one green job. That means, according to the Commission’s own projections, that, with the EU’s green agenda (which ignores any opposing science), 44 million jobs will be lost. Unemployment across the whole of the EU is 10.5%. Towns in my region in Britain, including Grimsby, Bradford, Barnsley and Hull, have youth unemployment of over 25%. But the only jobs I can see being created by this report, and by the green representatives, are in the trade unions which Ms Lambert calls for, where the people in question will, no doubt, get significant salaries and enjoy very generous expense accounts.

name: Joëlle Mélin
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, you are issuing employment guidelines that are supposedly compatible with broad political and economic guidelines, which are themselves considered to be of common interest and therefore obligatoryly coordinated within the Council of Europe. Therefore, you are asking the Member States to give up their right to subsidiarity, even though Europe has no employment competence. The question is who is doing what in Europe in this area. It is indecent to talk about employment policy for the 21st century when today almost 24 million unemployed people in the European Union are demanding accountability. Your very ambiguous attitude forces one in four young Europeans to live in the anguish of unemployment and impoverishment. Whole swathes of our economies, entire regions are suffering.  The unemployed and entrepreneurs ask you to do so, so give back their sovereignty to the peoples of the Member States!

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Madam President, today's debate is about employment and the big problem of unemployment. I keep hearing suggestions, reading the amendments and for a moment I thought we could actually solve this problem.  But then I thought about the destruction and despair caused by the Union's policies. For five years my country has implemented the reforms that reports call for to be imposed on all countries; the reforms that tripled unemployment, which would theoretically disappear; the reforms that doubled our public debt; the reforms that brought down GDP by 25% and, while boosting the competitiveness of businesses, led thousands to a lock.  Even worse were the effects of the programmes on weak social groups. You impoverished these people and led them to soup kitchens, begging, ATM queues and others unfortunately to suicide. Today you are blackmailing the Greek people. Tomorrow who? At some point you're definitely going to try to blackmail yourself. Let the Council and the Commission understand that.  You and your policies are bankrupt, not Greece. You live away from the problems and needs of ordinary people. But you will wake up abruptly when the people themselves turn their backs on you and send you once and for all to the basket of political waste.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Madam President, to those who would question the job potential of green jobs, I would point them to the submissions the committee received from various sectors of our economy, pointing to the potential for jobs in this area, particularly those in the construction area in terms of refurbishing old buildings and public buildings right across Europe. There is enormous job potential there in terms of upskilling people in plumbing, and for electricians, using the digital economy and technology to upgrade our public buildings. That is just one area.  I do not understand the opposition and the questioning of the potential for green jobs in our economy. The inefficient use of resources needs to be tackled – climate change, the impact of our actions on the environment: the more knowledge we have, the more potential we have to protect these areas. Innovation, how to tackle pollution, how to tackle pollution of our waterways, waste disposal, energy efficiency, various areas in which jobs in the green economy can be created. I would like to thank Jean Lambert for her support and for her work with the various groupings in producing this report. One area that I think is very important – and the Commissioner touches upon this – is the area of skills and the need to develop skills for the green economy, which is particularly relevant to young people. We have had this discussion before on the need to match skills to the needs of industry, to the needs of the marketplace, and I think it is something where the Commission has very strong role to play with the Member States in ensuring that education and training establishments develop the necessary skills for such jobs.

name: Jan Keller (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I consider the green jobs document to be of good quality and balanced, and I believe that this is mainly due to the rapporteur, Jean Lambert.  In my opinion, it will be essential for the success of this initiative that green jobs be not only full-fledged in other respects, not only on pay, but also in other respects. This is not guaranteed automatically, because such jobs are largely created in low-wage and highly feminized sectors. It would be very unfortunate if our economy were to be guided along the path of greening by low-paid women dependent on below-average paid employment contraction, while men continue to do much better, but unfortunately often very problematic activities.  In view of this morning's debate on the Treaty between the European Union and the United States of America, I would like to express my firm belief that green jobs and the products of their work will not end up on the list of non-tariff barriers to trade as a barrier to the development of big business.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, my colleague Laura Agea, on her report. Let me point out that employment policy in the European Union has completely failed. Mercel austerity has filled Europe with armies of the unemployed, with millions of poor people. In Greece in particular, the memorandums have failed completely. We have over a million and a half unemployed. The unemployment rate stands at 25.4%, the unemployment rate for women at 29.1%, the youth unemployment rate stands at 50.1%, the highest in Europe.   And yet even now the troika insists on its callous anti-social policy. Although we have a huge humanitarian crisis, the troika insists on calling for a reduction in wages and pensions, an increase in VAT, the maintenance of hard taxes, such as ENFIA, requires the dismantling of the insurance system. But the Greek people reject the ultimatums and threats of the troika, which is why in the referendum the day before said a thunderous no to the troika and to the memoranda.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I want to thank Laura and Jean for their excellent work on the two reports. For now, I will concentrate on the green economy. In this context I fully support the view that sustainable patterns of consumption and production have a very significant potential to generate new jobs and help transform existing jobs into green jobs. That is in fact what I would call future-proofing employment opportunities. In order to achieve that future-proofing we need to anticipate future skills needs. In that context, we should listen to CEDEFOP who propose that adapting curricula and including environmental awareness with an understanding of sustainable development and business efficiency is better than proposing new training programmes. That is down-to-earth and informed advice and we need to take it on board.  I fully support the phasing-out of environmentally harmful subsidies and indeed I support the rapporteur when she calls for the phasing-out of all subsidies by 2020. I also support the call to the Commission requesting independent studies on the costs and benefits of a shift in the tax burden, for example from labour to environmental taxation. While taxation is a Member State competence, the results of these studies can and should inform thinking in the Member States.  We now have the opportunity in the framework of the European Fund for Strategic Investment to promote investment that will act as a catalyst for a green transition. In the area of social policy, this fund can alleviate energy poverty by promoting energy-efficient homes and in the context of job creation we, in ALDE, fully support the creation of decent jobs, as defined by the ILO, which will lead to quality employment.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I want to commend the rapporteur on her very good work on the Green Employment Initiative report, which will help us realise the job creation potential of the green economy while ensuring that the transition does not leave working people behind.  I am disappointed that some groups appear to be attempting to water down important elements of the report, such as the commitment to creating quality, secure jobs. A just transition means ensuring targeted skills training is provided for workers and students, including workers dislocated from declining polluting industries in emerging green technologies. The new jobs created in the green economy should be decent, secure and well paid. This Parliament should send a clear signal tonight that we want to see workers and their unions deeply involved in this process. Workers’ input should extend from the workplace level right up to the state level. This will help minimise dislocation and maximise the success of the economic transformation that we need. Public procurement can also play an important role in the transition by including proactive environmental and social criteria. Any shift in taxation from labour to the environment should target the major polluters and aim at changing polluting behaviour. It must not be regressive taxation of consumers, which only hits the poorest hardest. This Parliament should also call on the Commission to ensure that the Just Transition agenda remains a strong part of its negotiating position at the COP 21 Paris climate summit.

name: Linnéa Engström (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I welcome this report by Mr Lamberts, and the fact that the important perspective of equality is being highlighted so clearly and consistently throughout the report. To meet the challenges of a green economy, we need to train more technicians, scientists, scientists and engineers. Europe's transition to a low-carbon and resource-efficient economy offers great opportunities for both society and the labour market. Many new jobs will be created in renewable energy production, waste and water management, air quality, biodiversity restoration and green infrastructure development. In order to meet Europe's high demand for skilled labour in a green economy, we need to train more young women as technicians, scientists and engineers. To achieve this, we need to invest in gender equality and to come to terms with discrimination and sexism in the labour market. A green economy must include clear gender equality initiatives.

name: Daniela Aiuto (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the european Union's responses to rampant unemployment to date have not been satisfactory. We welcomed this own-initiative report to promote green employment, as we believe that it can be an effective instrument for the recovery of the economy in Europe. It is proposed, in fact, to outline a solution to two of the main obstacles: the serious employment crisis and the problem of environmental sustainability. We must, however, remember to protect women's access to green employment. We women are, in fact, under-represented precisely in the technological and scientific disciplines that are strategic for environmental issues and for entrepreneurship in general and we often have lower salaries, with equal skills and responsibilities. As mothers, it is precisely we women who are more sensitive to ecological policies and our involvement can certainly lead to added value.  I therefore call on the Commission to work with the Member States to implement a truly active policy in the field of green employment for women and to ensure that the principle of equal opportunities is fully respected.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to make two comparisons. In 2008, the unemployment rate in Germany and Greece was almost the same. It was 7% in Germany and 8% in Greece. 26.6% in 2015. In Spain in 2007 8%, now 23.2%. That was not just the crisis, Commissioner, these were the austerity programmes, and that was the many reforms. This, of course, was also the uncontrolled immigration that has reached Europe in the meantime.  The Greek people have said a stop to this austerity programme. I think that all employment programmes are pointless as long as five-figure numbers of foreigners come to Europe every month who enter illegally and are not deported. We need a consistent return policy, and then we can also regulate the labour market.

name: Thomas Mann (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Jean Lambert has developed valuable ideas for exploiting the potential of the green economy. We are taking up the European Commission's green employment initiative as well as the Green SME Action Plan, and we are seeking hundreds of thousands of new jobs. In the committee responsible for the Work and Labour, we were right to adopt the report by a large majority. My group, the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, has contributed to almost all the compromises. But there are motions with a strong ideological coloration. We therefore have problems with side-cutting on budgetary discipline, which is the basis for new growth and investment. There is also an exaggeration, for example when Member States are urged to introduce a new social, climate-friendly growth indicator. It is important to remove the shift in the tax burden from labour to the environment. In my motions, I have called for detailed and independent studies to be carried out first of all on the costs and benefits of such redistribution. We are also critical of paragraph 60, which calls on the European Commission to include environmental and climate-related considerations in the European Semester. We are against it because it distracts from necessary reforms and balanced budgets as the core objective of the semester. I hope that this point will be voted out tomorrow, so that we can then say 'yes' to a report, dear Jean.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur of this report on her excellent work in the Committee on Employment in these weeks. Commissioner, this is a general policy debate and you have therefore made a general speech with which there are not many problems to agree with. But the problem is not what we share, the problem is not the speech you make, but what you don't say. Because in the general discourse you have done there is one thing that is missing in one way, I think worryingly, which is the problem of inequality in the European Union today. We have a common problem in our area, in our region, but we have a common problem that also focuses on specific problems state by state. We have a problem of labour poverty which is also due to the wage devaluation that the Commission has promoted state by state in recent times and which it now continues to recommend in moderation; a problem of labour poverty that you are unable to recommend to be solved by increasing wages or setting sufficient minimum wages in all countries. We have a problem of precariousness, of temporality, which you continue to allow by not incentivising new labour reforms that correct excessive flexibility that has eaten all the security that was in our labour markets. We have a problem of social exclusion, mainly because we have taken unemployment benefits and decent pensions, and that you are unable to recover by country or via recommendations, as I say, work priorities. You are therefore missing the opportunity to recover, as I say, a European area of dignity at work, decent jobs and security through the social model, which is ultimately what sets us apart from other monetary areas. Take advantage of the opportunity allowed by this debate and the country-specific recommendations you discuss in the Council in the coming weeks.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, unemployment is not being fought with wishful meals and generalities. The report we are looking at is cynical and indifferent. For countries with high unemployment urgent measures are needed, which will also act as a stabilisation of the economy, and not just for Greece, whose referendum was distorted by officials, who tried to convince us that the citizens voted against Europe.  No, the Greeks were not and are not against Europe. But reading the employment report I felt sad, because recession policy has made Greece a black hole in Europe in employment. We therefore urgently need to extend our emergency tools such as the youth guarantee initiative with the corrections we have recently made to increase the advance to 30%, and in particular to Those Member States with an unemployment rate above the European average. Extend this to the unemployed who are at the peak of their productive lives, i.e. between thirty and forty-five years of age.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). Madam President, employment policy, pretending to be socially sensitive, escalates the anti-labour attack. Steady work with collective agreements, a satisfactory salary and rights is sacrificed to the competitiveness of enterprises. Shifting taxes from monopolies to the backs of the people to achieve bloody budget surpluses. Reduction of employer contributions and pensions, work to death with active ageing, reduction of pensions at the poverty line, as well as the adoption of the minimum guaranteed income as a means of downward wage pressure. Abolition of unemployment benefit by converting it into a grant from a new company doomed to close and many more similar mentions in the report. This is the European Union's path for all countries and for Greece, where now and with a government first left it is heading for a third worst memorandum. It has turned out that the European Union and the dictatorship of capital do not change; they are only overthrowd by popular struggle.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! The updated employment policy guidelines represent an important step in improving the labour market situation and in achieving sustainable sustainable growth and the relevant Objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. At present, insufficient job creation and a poor matching of the level and type of qualifications of potential workers with those of employers pose a major challenge for the European Union. With 24 million unemployment in the European Union, there are at least 2 million vacancies that lack adequately qualified people and 30% of employers complain of skills mismatch.  Increasing the mobility of European Union citizens and structural reform of vocational education, which should be more closely linked to the labour market, to the use of new technologies and innovations, are important for improving the situation. The dual education model introduced from the post-primary level to higher education is one of the most promising solutions. It is also important to be able to complement competences on a short course on a day-to-day and to recognise competences acquired outside formal education. Language skills, openness to cultural diversity and the ability to move in the digital world are important for mobility and job preparation, but also for job creation. The latter are necessary not only for obtaining information, communicating at work at a distance, but in virtually every profession and at every level of professional advancement. Digitalisation significantly enhances job creation and capacity, so digital skills should be developed on an equal footing with language as a base for any education regardless of pupils' level and profile.

name: Marita Ulvskog (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Thank you, Commissioner, for being here. The crisis and the fact that economic freedoms are put before social rights have created severe rifts in Europe's social model. Can we change this? With strong training initiatives, with investment, and of course also investment in green jobs and in transition? Of course we can do it! At the same time, we know that workers and Member States are currently pitted against each other in unfair competition where companies are competing not to be the best at what they do, but to be the cheapest. They do not compete with excellence, but by means of low wages and poor working conditions. I would therefore like to take the liberty of changing perspectives somewhat. I think it is incredibly important that the Labour Mobility Package that the Commission and Commissioner Thyssen are currently working on should be allowed to become a Fair Mobility Package, so broad and yet so pointed that it actually makes a difference, otherwise we run the risk of ending up at a level of conflict in society that we now see even in this House every day.

name: Verónica Lope Fontagné (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, with economic growth beginning to consolidate in the European Union, our objective must focus on creating sustainable employment and reducing poverty and social exclusion. Employment policies therefore need to be consistent with economic policies, moving towards the Europe 2020 Strategy. The European Union must gain in productivity and competitiveness by adapting supply and demand in the labour market to be able to respond to a changing environment and, in particular, to an increasingly digital and environmentally responsible economy, while linking strategic investments to structural reforms and budgetary control. Thanks to these policies, which are much criticized from certain sectors, unemployment has fallen in the last year by one and a half million people and expected growth is around 2%. That's what Spain, my country, has done with one of the highest unemployment rates, but it's been creating jobs for months. As we are seeing these days, if we want the European Union to grow and to create jobs harmoniously, all Member States have to fulfil their responsibilities. The other key point is education. Education needs to be the cornerstone of this process, from school to lifelong learning for older workers, as well as greater recognition of qualifications at European level, both middle and higher education, which will facilitate labour mobility.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate Laura Agea on a great report which has had a very wide degree of consensus here. We all agree that successful businesses are ones which value their workers, which pay them properly, which look after them and their health and safety and which treat them with respect. There is a very wide degree of consensus across nations and across political groups in this House but not, unfortunately, in the United Kingdom, where the government does not believe those things at all.  We have recently had a reduction in unemployment in the United Kingdom to levels not seen since the previous Labour government, but it is poor-quality employment, employment in which five million people are in low-paid jobs. Two million people are on zero-hour contracts. That is the difference, the fundamental philosophical difference, and it is one in which, I am afraid, they are wrong and in this House people are right.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D).
text: Madam President, I also wanted to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Agea, on this excellent work, because it helps to moderate a frequent tendency of the Commission, which is to consider that employment can only be created in flexibility, precariousness and competition.  The challenge is not just to create jobs, but also to create meaningful jobs, which pay and decently protect workers, so that they can take on their own lives. From this point of view, the proposed report allows, among other things, to insist on new indicators (on poverty, on the minimum wage - so important today in the European Union ) and to combat the segmentation of the labour market, against precarious work, against underemployment, against unreported work and against the zero-hours contracts mentioned here. It is also very important that the European Parliament can play its full role on the issue of employment. That is not the case today. It is very important that the European Parliament can propose amendments and give guidelines, even if national states must of course retain their prerogatives. I conclude by saying that the need for investment in the vocational training system is very important, but they must never obscure the fact that jobs today must be protections and not just submissions.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – One of the amendments draws attention to the risk of excluding 'those who have interrupted their careers due to family responsibilities, such as family carers'. It is alibiism, since even in countries where paternity leave is compulsory, it is mothers who devote the most time to childcare and household care. In my opinion, the logic of similar proposals is per capita. They do not try to motivate employers to give work to mothers and create a suitable working environment for them. On the contrary, they want women to pay other women to look after their children. In my opinion, the unblocking of the Directive on the representation of women on the boards of companies required by this proposal is elitist and does not address the situation of most mothers in any way.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, the problem of high unemployment is particularly evident in countries where reforms have not been implemented and which are spending significantly more than they can afford. However, while the diagnosis is clear and long overdue, there are those who advocate the absence of reforms and the rejection of fiscal discipline, so we have Amendment 11 to the Commission's text of the Proposal for a Decision on member states' employment policy guidelines that rejects the call for structural reforms and fiscal responsibility and replaces it with all the force of social rights and protection. It must be clear to us that these rights cost money and that someone has to fund them. In Croatia, those who finance the system are getting smaller every day because they are either moving their business abroad or closing their companies, so I would like to know what magic measures you would recommend to us, whose implementation would ensure a high level of entitlement for everyone without it including structural reforms and fiscal responsibility on the one hand or further headless borrowing on the other.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, who is very much involved in employment issues. I think that the European Union should send strong signals and positively encourage Member States to act in order to create favourable conditions for entrepreneurship, to use European funds for active employment policy and also for improving the quality of education.  In its resolution, the European Parliament sets out a number of initiatives that can help to create new jobs and to take a greater initiative in business. The condition of employment and employment in working life is quality education and completion of secondary education. I think that this is the main communication that should also be directed from the European Parliament from the Level of the European Union to the Member States.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, resolving the issue of crisis and unemployment in Europe is a fundamental issue ahead of which this Commission term and parliament are standing. The idea of resolving unemployment in Europe through green employment is definitely, simply put, a win-win situation. Because we can reduce the problem of the unemployed, and on the other hand we will do good things for the environment. That is why I strongly support this idea and ambition, but we must be aware that often green jobs are difficult to reach and expensive. I also support the need for a so-called conservative common approach, such as retraining, labour mobility, youth employment so that they get their first jobs in a flexible way. I think we need to make a combination of both.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to distinguish between when green policy brings jobs, on the basis of good proposals, such as the reconstruction of old buildings, public buildings, brownfields, etc., and I think that is also an example of this report, which I clearly appreciate, from those where green policy only brings jobs through the growth of bureaucracy, administration and hard-to-understand procedures. , which rather lead to a negative. I therefore also want to appreciate the sustainability in this report, which is emphasised and is based on the principle of the Europe 2020 objectives that it adheres to. For me, this report is a good example of the compatibility of those green solutions that can also contribute to the development of the economy at no major cost.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner Thyssen, I would like to thank commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to join very briefly in my colleague, Mrs Zaborska, only that, unfortunately, as always, she does not go far enough. There is one area of work when we talk about equality in the labour market that is completely forgotten: education. Salaries are paid in nurseries, in kindergartens, in children's homes. But parents fall out. Sustainability cannot exist if parents, especially mothers, are held as slaves to society.  We need an education salary – a parental wage. Parents, especially mothers, are our most important workforce in Europe. I would ask that these should also be taken into account and that they are not simply accepted in their performance.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, respected Commissioner, it seems that it is often necessary to recall that the Europe 2020 strategy is what we should adhere to at least for this period of the next five years and having already undergone a review. It is this strategy that rests on something that makes the European Union competitive on a global scale, which is sustainable development.  We don't need to say what sustainable development is, but we do know that small, micro and medium-sized enterprises are the cornerstone of the European economy. For it to succeed, they need to have the right skilled workforce, they need to get to a certain capital. Thus, the success of green employment and thus the green economy is possible if we meet three basic requirements: the first is to invest in education for sustainable development that we do not currently have in any Member State, knowing that the average is currently 2% of GDP investment, and that we need to have much more. Enable fiscal measures that will direct and facilitate private investment in green technologies. Simplify the procedures for using public money from EU funds, but also through green public procurement to encourage Member States to invest in green technology, green employment and the green economy.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like once again to thank both rapporteurs, Ms Agea and Ms Lambert, for their reports. I can assure you that the deliberations in Parliament have inspired the Commission during the entire adoption process of its employment guidelines proposal. In general, the Commission could accept most of your amendments. The goal of the guidelines is to be operational for policy—making by Member States, and that is why the Commission focused on what Member States can do and on short operational texts. As you know, there is currently a general approach of the Council on the table. In general, many of your amendments are in line with those proposed by the Council. The Council’s general approach includes an explicit recognition that action in line with the employment guidelines is an important contribution for the European Union to the Europe 2020 objectives. It also incorporates further explicit references to quality and social goals. The Commission feels that its employment guidelines proposal is well balanced and that the Parliament’s report generally supports this view. I would also like to thank you very much for your discussion on the Green Employment Initiative report, as well as for the enriching contributions of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM) and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI). I want to thank Members of Parliament for their support on shifting taxation away from labour onto environmentally harmful activities. As you know, taxation is a national competence. Nonetheless, the Commission has been recommending this shift for years in the framework of the European Semester. I heard many of you talking about skills mismatches, skills upgrading, and transition from school to work and so on. I share your preoccupation, and I am working with colleagues to address these issues. In particular, last month we made efforts to give a new boost to the European Alliance for Apprenticeships by convincing enterprises to make pledges to create more possibilities and more places for apprentices so that they have the chance to have some work-based learning experience. The Commission will be carefully considering Ms Lambert’s report, not only in the implementation of the Green Employment Initiative, but also when promoting green skills and social dialogue aspects in both the Energy Union and in the forthcoming circular economy package. This highlights a strong link between investment in human capital, and the capacity to innovate and roll out innovative, resource—efficient processes and technologies.

name: Laura Agea
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I will use these two minutes simply to thank my fellow Members who, first of all, have given me the opportunity to show that it does not matter where you sit in this Parliament if you want to represent the citizens and their demands. I thank them because they believed, in giving me an opportunity, to test the skills and competences that a small delegation of citizens has made available to this Parliament. So the first thanks go to Georges Bach, Maria João Rodrigues, Zdzisław Krasnodębski, Neoklis Sylikiotis and Tatjana Ždanoka, because they believed that I could be an asset and because they gave me the opportunity to collaborate. I would like these names, mine as well as your names, which will appear in this report, which I believe is the result of the work shared with all of you, to be the names of those 500 million citizens that we represent. I would like the name of the citizens of Europe to be written in this report, because I believe that this document manages to represent their demands, their sufferings, their needs and their needs. So the more support is shared, the less we will stop and look at who presents something, but the ideas that are presented, because it is ideas that change; And I believe that this Parliament has enormous potential if it only goes beyond the seats allocated here in the Chamber. I congratulate Jean Lambert on his excellent work. We have supported it and will continue to do so. I would also like to thank Commissioner Thyssen because, although we do not always agree on so many positions, I know that she understands the voice of whom I and my colleagues represent.

name: Jean Lambert
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would also very much like to thank colleagues for their warm words this evening, and the report, I think, really does reflect the work across most of the political groups. I want to see how we can make the green jobs report link with the employment guidelines so that we really do move this forward. One thing I do regret is that I did not get the name of the anonymous Spanish economist so that I can check on the figures we were being given about the job swap, because I really hope that we are not just seeing some jobs go, green jobs come in, and somebody making the assumption that green ones are forcing the others out. We live in a world of change, and the way in which we get through that transition and try to do that in the best interests of all of us and our planet is very important.  The potential is clear – we have heard that from so many people in this room tonight. Whether it is the social impact and the environmental impact of energy efficient buildings, or whether it is working on renewable energies. These are jobs, a lot of which are ‘sur place’ and not offshore, which can make a real difference to people’s lives.  As regards the small business sector, we have figures showing that 93% of small businesses have tried to take some small step towards resource efficiency. It saves them money. They believe it is the right thing to do, and they want to do more of it, but they need support. They need support in terms of the skills, and they need support in terms of actually finding support that might be out there in financial terms. I would like to make an advert here: the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs has, I think, put forward a very useful pilot project along these lines that I hope Members will support. The skills development is crucial, but it is not enough; it is about that broad coherent policy framework. So I really hope the Commission is going to take this on board, as we have heard, in the energy union and the circular economy package. We cannot leave this sort of change to chance. It needs to be managed if we are really to see the full potential – socially, economically and environmentally. (Applause)

name: n/a
text: – The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 8 July 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – Employment policy guidelines must cover not only economic but also social aspects. The europe 2020 targets for reducing employment, poverty and social exclusion and education are still not met, and Member States must implement these guidelines as effectively as possible in order to tackle high unemployment and prevent long-term unemployment in Europe and reduce inequalities and discrimination. Firstly, it is essential that Member States make every effort to tackle poverty, especially child poverty. This can be done by providing affordable and quality childcare and education services, effective training, ensuring a decent income for families, providing housing support and high-quality healthcare available to all. Secondly, in order to reduce poverty and improve quality employment, social inclusion, education, Member States should make effective and productive use of the support of the European Social Fund and other EU funds. The European Fund for Strategic Investments should also be mobilised to ensure that quality jobs are created and that workers have the skills necessary for the European Union to move towards a sustainable growth and social model. It is also essential to ensure a decent income for all, so that poverty and illegal employment in Europe do not spread.

name: Martina Dlabajová (ALDE)
text: in writing. – It is important to set guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States and for the European Parliament to send a clear message that Member States’ labour market reforms are fundamental to contribute to a competitive and growing Europe. Technological changes, the digitalisation of the economy and globalisation are leading to new labour market patterns and needs as regards future skills. Labour market reforms need to take into consideration such changes and anticipate the needs of the future to ensure the maximum employability of people, especially young people. Such reforms should be complemented with educational reforms – it is important to introduce entrepreneurial education in schools and to teach a variety of skills, especially soft skills, as they become more important for a large number of occupations. I support this report and would like to congratulate the rapporteur for her work. I also welcome the fact that the Commission has proposed guidelines on such an important issue and I urge the Council to deal with this proposal as a matter of urgency.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. – According to Eurostat data for May 2015 23 348 million European citizens are unemployed. Unemployment in the EU is close to 11%, millions live with minimal financial resources. At the same time, in a number of industries there is a shortage of labour and skilled personnel. I believe that against the background of this labour market picture, the European Commission needs to develop a strategic vision and an estimated analysis of the needs of the European economy and labour market.
