We need to know what they will look like in the long term in order to be able to focus our efforts on retraining staff and training professionals precisely for those sectors in which they are really needed, and to meet labour market demand and supply in order to improve the overall economic growth and living standards of European citizens.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – For several years now, the Council has been preparing recommendations to Member States on employment policies in the framework of the European Semester. Despite this, the labour market situation in many EU countries is still very difficult, and there is no significant progress in meeting the Europe 2020 objectives, and the social impact of the crisis remains one of the main challenges facing European governments.  In this situation, it seems appropriate to recommend that the European Parliament, the institution closest to citizens, should also be involved in the process of creating the guidelines. The European Parliament points to the need to supplement the guidelines, taking into account, inter alia, the need to provide affordable and high-quality childcare for parents.  Another thing that MEPs are paying attention to is the need to promote entrepreneurship and to promote its spirit, especially among young people. In this context, closer cooperation between business and education institutions is also crucial.  The document also often includes a proposal to introduce minimum wages as an instrument to combat poverty and social exclusion. In this context, I would like to express my support for such action. At the same time, I would also like to stress that, in the current situation, however, there can be no question of introducing a common European minimum wage because of the differences in the economic and social development of the Member States and the legal basis enshrined in the Treaties.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – Global trends such as inefficient use of resources, unsustainable pressure on the environment and climate change will soon achieve irreversible effects. This report deals with solutions on how to exploit the employment potential to address these challenges and to develop policies and skills for the transition to a green economy. The transition to a sustainable economy can create new quality jobs or turn existing jobs into green jobs. Continued economic growth is only possible if environmental constraints are respected. The new European Fund for Strategic Investments is another opportunity for targeted quality investments. The Commission and the Member States should therefore also promote high-quality investments within this fund that generate social and economic benefits. Investments should focus on areas with a positive impact on the labour market in order to create sustainable jobs. Public procurement policy must also play its part by applying sustainability provisions for responsible shopping. Member States should fully implement the new provisions of the recast EU public procurement legislation and to consider whether the introduction of environmental and social criteria in public procurement policies could encourage job creation in a greener economy.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the report, as I believe that it is fundamentally good. The green economy is present in all sectors of the integrated chain nowadays, and rightly so. I believe that the EU here, globally, is one that is followed by other countries. However, I would like to draw attention to the fact that the right balance needs to be struck, and I am thinking of the balance between green employment and the burdens that would arise on the side of the economy. We need to pay real attention to that. We must not forget the fact that the economic picture of the Member States is indeed very different. I would also like to point out that it is of the utmost importance that Member States promote innovation in this area and create a favourable economic environment for SMEs that show potential, especially when it comes to a positive impact on employment.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. Environmental policy is important, there is agreement on this. In this policy area too, however, it is necessary to offer realistic solutions and not dreams. Unfortunately, this has only been partially achieved. As shadow rapporteur for the 'green labour market initiative', I have tried to focus on innovation so that we can achieve environmental protection and growth at the same time. I have tried to focus on decentralisation and subsidiarity when it comes to environmental protection, as long as there is no cross-border pollution. I have tried to leave decisions on training and health at work at national level and not to Europeanise them. And I have warned against too much optimism, because many projects are required without considering side-effects or consequences. In particular, the issue of building insulation and the difficulties in fire protection. Unfortunately, I have only partially penetrated with my warnings and I have to say that there is too much wishful thinking in this report. Many green concerns have been linked to social objectives and are to be managed by The European level. For example, the Commission should ensure that 'social change is always well managed' or that 'jobs with unrestricted social protection' are created. Unfortunately, a competitive green economy cannot be achieved by centralising and overloading the paper with social demands.

name: Elly Schlein
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today, the unreserved fight against tax avoidance and evasion is at the heart of the European debate and is becoming a priority. But at a time when huge capital flows easily move from one part of the world to another with one click, it is clear that these are global challenges and to overcome them we need global law enforcement tools and solutions, to re-establish a very simple principle: taxes must be paid where profits are generated. In this European Year of Development we will take decisions that outline which world we will leave to future generations: the new objectives for sustainable development, the climate conference and, in a few days' time in Addis Ababa, the third international conference on financing for development. These ambitious objectives will only be achieved if we ensure adequate funding with official development aid but also with more effective mobilisation of national resources. And this is where taxation and the fight against tax evasion and avoidance become fundamental. Estimates should be taken with caution, but illicit financial flows out of developing countries are estimated to reach a trillion dollars each year. An impressive fact: almost ten times the total amount of development aid; resources taken from services to citizens. There are many obstacles facing developing countries in the fight against evasion and avoidance. Not to mention that they themselves tend to grant incentives and exemptions in ruthless tax competition that is harmful to them. With this report, we are calling on the Commission to have a genuine action plan to support developing countries in creating stronger and fairer tax systems. We therefore call for increased support for developing countries by providing financial and technical assistance, which is still insufficient. We call for the UN Tax Committee to be transformed into a genuine intergovernmental body with additional resources to finally ensure that developing countries participate on an equal footing in the reform of the global tax system. We call for support for international initiatives to reform the global tax system, such as the BEPS process promoted by the OECD; But more account must be taken of the needs of developing countries. Two instruments are particularly important: we call for the adoption of the country by country reporting standard for multinational companies in all sectors, including the extractive sector, and for complete information to be accessible to all countries and made public. It is time for the Commission to come forward with a proposal to this effect. I would be surprised if someone voted against what we already unanimously approved in committee tomorrow. In addition, when the automatic exchange of information is applied, a transitional period should be provided for countries that have not yet fully developed the necessary capacities to collect and share all the information required. We also call for transparency on the effective ownership of companies, trusts and other similar institutions. There is the long-established problem of tax treaties between developed and developing countries, which do not guarantee the fair distribution of taxation rights between country residences and country sources. In this, the model developed under the auspices of the UN guarantees a more balanced approach. Finally, we call for impact assessments of European tax policies on developing countries, in order to strengthen the coherence for development policy, and we call for a definition of tax havens at international level by 2015 with a black list and sanctions. I was surprised that someone asked for a separate vote, I thought we all agreed here on the seriousness with which this issue needs to be addressed.  Last but not least, we pay particular attention to gender issues: evasion and avoidance affect the most vulnerable part of society where women are often and unfortunately over-represented. I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their cooperative spirit and also the secretariat and my office for their support. I hope that tomorrow the report will pass with the largest majority to make the voice of this Parliament heard loudly before Addis Ababa and to show that we are at the forefront of the fight against global evasion and avoidance, in order to have a truly ambitious development agenda capable of hitting the root of the tragedy of poverty and inequality.

name: Nicolas
text: Schmit, Current Chairman of the Council. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it has been almost two years now that we have embarked on a complex process of negotiations aimed at nothing less than to establish a new global partnership to meet the inseparable challenge of eradicating poverty and sustainable development.  This partnership will guide the international community for years to come. The European Union and its Member States cannot miss this historic event. This partnership must be based on the principles of universality and shared and mutual responsibilities. We will have to take into account the capabilities of each and involve multiple actors. This new global partnership should also promote human rights, equality, non-discrimination, democratic institutions, good governance and the rule of law. It should enable everyone to participate actively and ensure environmental sustainability and respect for the limits of our planet.  Women's rights, gender equality, the emancipation of women and girls, which are already a goal in themselves, are essential means of implementation and should be encouraged at all levels. I am thinking in particular of girls' education, which is an extremely important factor for development.  After Monterrey and Doha, which laid the foundation for this partnership, we must continue to develop an overall vision for change in the world order. The Addis Ababa conference, which opens next Monday, should not be limited to assessing progress in implementing the Monterrey Consensus and the Doha Declaration. It must be forward-looking, address all means of implementation in an integrated manner, and focus on the mobilization and effective use of all financial and other resources. The European Union and its Member States must continue to affirm this essential principle acquired since Monterrey. National public funds are the largest source of stable and directly available funding for most governments and are therefore at the heart of sustainable development financing. National governments have a primary responsibility to mobilize and make the best use of these public resources. This conference must lead to an integrated approach to the implementation and financing of the new partnership. It will be a question of finding a strong balance between the three dimensions of sustainable development: economic, social and environmental. It is a question of encouraging policy coherence and, above all, clearly defining our commitments and the results that all actors will have to achieve.  We believe that the final document of the conference should be the "means of implementation" component of the post-2015 programme, which will be adopted next September in New York. The outcome of the summit will provide a solid basis for the COP 21 conference of the parties at the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change in Paris in December.  While financial resources remain important, if not essential - national public funds, private funds, innovative financing, international aid - we must also put the non-financial means of implementation at the centre of the game. Creating a development-friendly environment, building institutional capacity, boosting trade and investment, investing in education and encouraging science, technology and innovation are essential.  In addition, this new partnership requires a strong monitoring, accountability and evaluation framework that must be an integral part of the post-2015 agenda. It will be necessary to encompass the national, regional and global levels and involve all government and non-governmental actors in its implementation.  Ladies and gentlemen, the European Union and its Member States are determined to play an active and constructive role in all the processes under way and to ensure their convergence. To this end, the Development Council of 26 May adopted a position on official development assistance, which reaffirms the collective commitment of the EU and Member States to reach the target of 0.7% of gross national income spent on official development assistance within the post-2015 programme deadline, as well as their priority commitment to the least developed countries. It should facilitate the active participation of the European Union and its Member States in the ongoing international negotiations and contribute to their success.  The success of this global partnership depends on our contribution to all. We are committed to playing our full role and cooperating constructively with all interlocutors and, in particular, with the European Parliament in order to be able to establish and implement a post-2015 programme that is ambitious and brings about the transformations and inclusion we need.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, there is only one week to go before the UN Financing for Development Conference in Addis Ababa. Thank you for today’s opportunity to exchange views on this, and also on the related Parliament report on tax avoidance and tax evasion. The Addis conference is a priority for the European Union. We remain fully committed to ensuring its success, as it will be crucial for the outcome of the Post-2015 Summit in New York and the Climate Conference in Paris later this year.  I am particularly grateful for the active engagement of Parliament throughout the preparatory process, and for your resolution on financing for development, as well as on the global post-2015 development agenda. And I am delighted that six of you will be joining the European Union delegation attending the conference.  President Juncker has mandated High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini and me to represent the European Union in Addis Ababa. Together with the representatives from national governments, we will make sure that the European Union and its Member States continue to speak with one voice in these last crucial stages. Let me outline the overall principles and expectations that will guide the EU approach. First, Addis must be transformational. We need an ambitious and coherent engagement and agreement, covering all means of implementation: aid, investment and domestic resources, as well as an enabling policy environment. We need a more strategic, more catalytic role for official development assistance to help leverage other means of implementation and maximise their impact. Second, Addis must promote universality. The old days of North and South, donors and beneficiaries, are over. We need a true global partnership to achieve such a broad agenda. All countries need to act and contribute their fair share – and so does the private sector and civil society. The European Union stands ready to play its full part in implementing the sustainable development goals at home and through our external actions. Third, Addis must embed strong mutual accountability. We need an integrated, transparent and reliable framework to keep track not only of our financial commitments, but also of overall progress towards achieving the sustainable development goals. We all have been working hard for an ambitious Addis outcome document, one that reflects EU aspirations and objectives, and respects the Council conclusions of 26 May. The European Union negotiations have been challenging. The latest draft text is a good outcome for the European Union, but the document is not yet agreed. Differences remain on a couple of issues, including on the exact relationship between the Addis conference and the Post-2015 Summit. Negotiations are still ongoing in New York as we speak, and they may continue in Addis.  The European Union has been well prepared and ready to play its constructive and leading role throughout the negotiations and beyond, including through some concrete figures, for instance, EUR 58 billion for official development assistance. This makes the European Union collectively the world’s largest donor. We have recommitted to achieving the official development assistance target of 0.7% of gross national income within the timeframe of the post-2015 agenda, including an even more ambitious effort for least-developed countries. Regrettably, this commitment has not been followed by other developed and emerging donors. EUR 100 billion is the amount we estimate the European Union can mobilise to finance notably infrastructure investments in partner countries through blending by 2020, leveraged through an EU grant component of up to EUR 8 billion.  More than EUR 16 billion will be dedicated to addressing environment and climate change objectives. And EUR 35 billion is a conservative estimate of the annual value of the exports of the least-developed countries to the European Union, which grants them duty-free and quota-free market access.   Let me now come to Parliament’s report on tax evasion and tax avoidance. The Commission concurs with the general analysis of this very comprehensive report. Having exchanged views with rapporteur Schlein on several occasions, I am well aware of the importance Parliament attaches to these issues. I take careful note of your proposed action plan to support developing countries in mobilising more domestic resources. Improved domestic resource mobilisation can indeed significantly contribute to a more sustainable and reliable sourcing of revenue. Adequate administrative capacity of our partner countries’ tax administrations, and their political will to reform, are key in this respect.  Domestic revenue mobilisation and the fight against illicit financial flows, tax evasion and tax avoidance will have an important role in the Addis and New York conferences. The negotiations on the Addis outcome document have been complex on this point. The latest proposal tabled could in our view be considered as a good compromise and reflects most of the issues and actions contained in Parliament’s report.  There are still difficulties around the UN committee on tax, and its upgrading to an intergovernmental body. We clearly support giving developing countries a stronger voice and participation in the definition of the global tax governance agenda – without necessarily creating yet another intergovernmental body. We should focus on the substance, not on taking decisions on the format at this stage of the process.  The Commission is committed to ensuring that the developing countries which have the ambition for reform are supported in this difficult path. As part of a global partnership initiative, we will be organising a side-event on the margins of the Addis conference and are developing a document as a first basis for discussion under the title ‘Collect More – Spend Better’.  Honourable Members, we are close to achieving a very important result, but we cannot yet take it for granted. In Addis and New York we have a unique opportunity to redefine global development cooperation for the years to come. Let us make it count.

name: Hugues Bayet
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Madam President, I would first like to thank our colleague Elly Schlein for the work that has been done and for taking into account the priorities of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. As we all know, tax evasion is a real scourge. It causes a clear shortfall in state budgets, as much money that could be spent on the vital needs of all populations, namely social security, health care, employment, education, the economy or infrastructure. That is why the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs has focused on three priorities.  First, we believe that we must strongly support the development of tax administrations in the countries concerned in order to effectively levy fair and equitable taxes.  Second, we should focus on increasing the tax base in developing countries, including initiatives such as the CBCR, the BEPS project or revising double taxation agreements.  Thirdly, we could link the European Union's aid to respect for the principles of good governance in tax matters.  I would like to conclude by stressing that, in order to achieve these objectives, the first step must be to set an example at European level. I think that European institutions, such as the EBRD or the ECB, could avoid working with financial intermediaries in tax havens or reluctant to fight tax evasion. This would allow us to create an effective virtuous circle to combat this phenomenon.

name: Paul Rübig
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would also like to thank Mrs Schlein very much for the good relationship and also for the good cooperation. I believe that it is quite simply important to show that we have been making great efforts for many years to set new standards, particularly in development policy. But the failure of many governments around the world makes it important for us to think about where the causes lie. We currently have migration, we have refugees, and, ultimately, it is not the case that we do not analyse where the cause of all these problems is, and that poverty is not analysed either, why people are poor and why they are getting into trouble.  On the contrary, we note that unemployment is exported to Europe and, in return, the money that the migrants partly earn from us and our tax money is returned to these countries. This has to do with the fact that we must, of course, be clear that we are to make trade possible with the WTO regulation 'Everything but arms'. We should see that family businesses are set up. And it is important to promote dual education.  I believe that the crucial thing is not to send money, but to strengthen the concept of cooperation, to strengthen education, to enable energy on the ground – many things that will help us in the future.

name: Linda McAvan
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner and the Minister for what they have said tonight. It is vital we get a deal next week in Addis, and I hope the talks tonight in New York are fruitful, because they are going to set the agenda for New York and for Paris. If we do not get a deal there it will be harder in those subsequent conferences. Now we have already made our position clear on ODA in the Pereira report – Ms Pereira is going to speak in a few moments – but I want to focus on tax tonight. The OECD has estimated that, if we could increase tax revenue by 1% in developing countries, it would be like doubling ODA. So tax is crucial, and that is why we need concrete measures to tackle tax problems. We need companies and individuals to pay their fair share of tax, and some of these concrete measures are in the Schlein report. We need to stamp out illegal practices like trade mis—invoicing, where companies manipulate tax invoices so they do not pay their fair share. Save the Children has published a report with some shocking figures. In Sub-Saharan Africa, EUR 15 billion a year are lost through these unpaid taxes. That is money that would pay for decent healthcare, and it would pay to tackle childhood malnutrition.  I think those who are dodging those taxes need to know that they are literally taking money out of the mouths of babes. To tackle these problems, we need concrete proposals and we have heard some tonight. We need new accountancy rules; we need country-by-country reporting, and it has to be public. Companies must be made to report publicly on what they are doing so that we can track down those who are not paying their fair dues. I hope we will push for that in Addis and in the subsequent talks.

name: Arne Gericke
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, Commissioner Mimica, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. As you have already mentioned, Europe is the world's largest donor of development policy. Nevertheless, we must ask ourselves: do we achieve sufficient targets in relation to our investments with our measures? No! As coordinator of the ECR Group for the ACP delegation, I was at the ACP-EU Parliamentary Assembly. I have spoken to colleagues from the emerging countries. You say that Europe is a difficult partner. We are demanding things that are unrealistic. The best example is the obligation to be a gender commissioner when a developing country wants money. I am all the more pleased that we are discussing the issue of tax avoidance and tax evasion today. That is important. As rapporteur on family businesses in emerging countries, I have spoken a lot with local small and medium-sized enterprises. They are angry. They pay their taxes, but corporations or millionaires pay nothing. One trillion dollars is lost to emerging economies every year, which is one-fifth of the EU's GDP. You can change a lot with that. In my report, I call for a specific 'Devetax 2020' programme with the aim of creating more than 2020 new tax offices and functioning structures in the ACP countries by 2020. I hope you will support you here.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Minister, Commissioner, in September 2012 the President of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, frightened investors betting on the debts of European countries with that famous phrase of 'whatever it takes' — I will do whatever it takes. This sparked many controversies, especially in Germany, where it was argued that a measure such as the announced measure was in breach of the Treaties.  Last June of this year, the Court of Justice of the European Union gave Mr Draghi the reason, claiming that the Treaties authorise the European Central Bank to adopt the bond purchase programme. It was a big step in European construction. And why am I talking about this now? Because next week, when we talk in Addis Ababa about new funding methods; when, as the Commissioner rightly indicated, let us take the opportunity to redefine development cooperation; when we talk about the need to include the private sector in development policies, the importance of SMEs, which generate 90% of jobs; when we talk about the benefits that public-private partnerships can bring to less developed countries, such as innovation or greater efficiency in resource use, or the mobilization of long-term funding; when we talk, in short, about how we are going to pay for the ambitious agenda we have for the next fifteen years, we must not forget the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, in particular Article 208 there, which specifies that the Union's policy in the field of development cooperation will be carried out within the framework of the principles and objectives of the Union's external action , that is, by promoting democracy, the rule of law, and the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms in the rest of the world. That is why I would like to call on the European Union to support the current process of developing a United Nations international instrument for human rights enterprises, which provides for effective solutions for victims in cases where it is clear that national jurisdiction is unable to sanction such enterprises effectively. In short, let us not stop innovating in the search for new solutions to the challenges we face, but let us always do so respecting the path already traveled.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, Mrs Schlein, I agree with Mrs McAvan and other Members that collection and taxes are the key to all this. For example, for every euro that developing countries receive through remittances from immigrants, official development aid or foreign direct investment, they lose two through illicit financial flows of tax evasion, through complex tax engineering structures and tax havens, or by paying interest on external debt. Good words are of no use, nor that we have proclaimed this year the European Year of Development, if we are systematically inconsistent. We must ensure progressive and redistributive fiscal justice both at European and international level and we cannot continue to mortgage people's dignity by paying interest on hateful or illegitimate unsustainable debts. We need to talk about restructuring and taking away sovereign debt, and the international and European moment gives us an opportunity for coherence, but it is a matter of wanting, political will.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – A study also cited in Mrs Schlein's report shows that tax rules in the Netherlands – the country where I come from – cost developing countries between EUR 150 million and EUR 550 million a year. We should be proud to be a major player in the field of development aid in this world, but every penny that leaves Africa because taxes are not paid where the work is done is actually a shame and we cannot make up for giving development aid. I was rapporteur on the report against money laundering, new European legislation. We have called for and arranged for a public register to be put in place to see who is the owner of a company, so that we can pin multinationals on the fact that they do not evade or evade tax. Because society will have to put an end to that. We can talk for a long time in Addis Ababa, but if we continue to allow multinationals to 'shop' to find the place where they pay the least tax, then our development money will never be able to raise health, infrastructure and education in sub-Saharan Africa. So I ask the Commissioner: fight for good tax legislation there.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to begin by congratulating Mrs Schlein on her excellent work on this important report. What Mrs McAvan said is very true: when we talk about so much money, so many billions disappearing and that would be enough, with a good system of combating tax evasion and avoidance, to carry out all the projects we are discussing here, including, precisely, where to find the economic resources to support development. Well, if there was a good level of fight against evasion and avoidance, we would have all those resources. The report is well done, ambitious in some respects, calling for feasible standards and other important elements, such as the country-by-country system, technical assistance to countries, as well as the creation of an intergovernmental body. I agree with what the rapporteur said, hoping that the vote in the Committee on Development will be followed by an equally unanimous vote in this House.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we are one week away from the third international conference on financing development in Addis and of course success in Addis is key to success later in New York in September and Paris in December. That is why today we must repeat the message we sent with the adoption of MP Pereira's resolution in April, which is that the EU should preserve its role as leader and largest donor of development aid, but at the same time should encourage shared responsibility and insist that other high-income countries, as well as emerging economies, assume their commitments to finance development.  So far, only the EU has committed to a contribution of 0.7% of GDP to OFFICIAL DEVELOPMENT ASSISTANCE. In addition, we need a new approach to financing development, as limited and insufficient funds should primarily start investing in productive areas, development engines, additional mobilisation of all types of financial resources, both public and private, domestic and international.  One of the biggest untapped opportunities lies in mobilizing the domestic resources of developing countries through more efficient tax systems. That is why I strongly welcome rapporteur Schlein's report on this topic – combating tax avoidance and evasion in developing countries.  This must also be focused on the new development strategy, on strengthening tax administrative capacity and on fighting corruption. Official development aid remains an important component, but it is insufficient to eradicate extreme poverty and that is why we need a new funding model and, of course, success in Addis.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D).
text: – Madam President, what is at stake at the Ababa conference on development finance, which begins in a few days' time, is very important. And this is this: ensuring the mobilisation of sufficient resources to implement the global development agenda from 2015 to 2030. It is therefore essential that the international community reach an ambitious agreement in Ababa Ababa. The European Parliament has already clearly defined its position, including on the defence of a target of 0.7 % of gross national income for development aid, and also in defence of a timetable. And we all know how, unfortunately, the Council's position fell short of what this House intended. But the preparatory work of the Adis Conference shows an even more worrying scenario, with other partners and donors revealing even less willingness for concrete financial commitments.  The time, therefore, is to address a strong appeal to other developed countries and emerging economies to take on their responsibilities. And in this case, that means making concrete financial commitments.  That is why we need the Adis conference to be the conference on public aid responsibility, but also on fiscal cooperation. That is why we need to support our colleague Elly Schlein's report on international tax cooperation.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, an increasing number of developing countries, especially those with lower middle incomes, are actively declaring that they want to get rid of aid dependency. It can therefore be said that this has also happened, because in Zambia, for example, development aid only accounts for only 2.6% of the budget. However, it is the case that help is also needed to enable developing countries to raise their own resources. We need official development aid in order, for example, to help developing countries improve their tax collection. I hope that there will be a breakthrough here in Addis Ababa and that a concrete programme will emerge on how to make a major step forward.  Now that we have the Luxembourg Presidency, which has fulfilled its own obligations in terms of this official development aid, that is to say, you are indeed a model for most other EU countries, I believe that you want to be even more emphatic in your efforts to ensure that other EU countries also fulfil this obligation. Unfortunately, I have to say that the Nordic countries are blowing a cold wind: Finland has now suddenly decided to reduce its development aid by 43%, and the Danish Government is also planning major cuts. This does not bode well for the EU's common objectives.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, this report seems to me to be barking up the wrong tree, attempting to solve a peripheral symptom of the real problem in developing nations, that of corruption. Nigeria is a prime example of how governmental corruption has nurtured an environment of low investor confidence, which has allowed corporations to abuse the free market by investing in the countries with the most disjointed tax evasion laws and ethos. This report states that transparency is the key in holding tax evaders accountable. But is this realistic? These countries are not blessed with the scale of technological advancements we enjoy. So one could argue that this claim is not just far-reaching but also, frankly, counterproductive. Before the issue of tax avoidance can be addressed properly, corruption must be dealt with in developing nations. If you are going to legislate hard on something, it might as well be the root of the evil, rather than the by-product of that evil.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab 2015 is a key year for financing development policy: a conference on development funding will be held in Addis Ababa in July, and UN members will meet in September to set sustainable development goals to replace the Post-2015 Millennium Development Goals. For several years, however, we have seen the 'scissors effect' resulting from the fact that the needs of poorer people are increasing and official development aid is being reduced due to the economic crisis in donor countries. During the debate, many Members spoke about official development assistance and tax problems, but I would also like to stress that innovative sources of financing for development are an effective way to achieve the Post-2015 SDGs. The activities of UNITAID, an international organisation supported by the UN, point to the usefulness of this model. Thanks to the micro-contribution of solidarity charged to the price of air tickets over the last nine years, UNITAID has been able to finance the treatment of 80% of all HIV and AIDS children, 350 million malaria patients and 2 million tuberculosis sufferers. The Commission and the Council should promote innovative methods of development finance. The proceeds of the financial transaction tax proposed by the European Union are one such mechanism as they can improve the situation in developing countries.

name: Norbert Neuser (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner Neven Mimica, President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has What do Sweden, Denmark, Luxembourg and the United Kingdom have in common? They are the only four countries in the 28 that have so far kept the promise to reach 0.7%. And I am pleased that the Presidency of the Council is actively involved in this in plenary, because not all the presidencies that we have had in the past have shown this interest in development policy.  I believe that a crucial key to financing development cooperation lies with the Member States. I come from a country, Germany, which is not exactly the poorest. But Germany has developed in the ODA ratio from 0.36 to 0.4 in 15 years, so it is virtually not at all forward. I believe that, during the Presidency of the Council, Luxembourg should seize the opportunity, by example, which Luxembourg is showing, and to exert an intensive influence on the nation states, so that we can achieve greater credibility there. How do we intend to be credible in negotiations such as those in Paris, when, for example, we have not reached the ODA quota over 15 years?

name: Joachim Zeller (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Presidency of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. In a few days' time, One of the milestones on the road to new sustainable development goals will have to be decided in Addis Ababa, namely on financing to achieve these objectives. However, in addition to numerous financial measures to which developed countries should and must commit themselves, it is also part of developing and emerging countries to develop and use their own financial resources to end poverty and hunger and to enable their citizens to live healthy and secure lives in their home countries. Developing states are called upon to make efforts to collect their own taxes and levies. Because often these countries are rich: rich in raw materials, rich in young, creative people and rich in considerable potential for sustainable economic development. But the revenues of these countries must not end up in the pockets of a few and the wealth must belong to foreign companies, which then take the profits out of the country. Transparency and fairness in national and international tax systems must finally be created! Public revenue in developing countries must be developed in the long term in order to solve social problems on the ground as well. Subnational taxes and levies should also be used for this purpose. International cooperation on tax matters must be taken forward. Our report provides a major impetus for this. However, they should then also be put into practice.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Among the G77 countries, there is still no agreement on the giminders a week before the Conference in Addis Ababa. As a result, the likelihood of a successful conference has decreased. That is why we Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament are calling on all those involved to reconsider their position and to go to the conference with better offers.  This also applies to the obligation of all industrialised countries to spend 0.7% of their gross national income on development aid. We cannot wait until 2030 to comply with the commitment. As I said today in my speech as rapporteur for the Opinion of the Committee on Development on the 2016 EU budget, the EU also plays a crucial role in financing. At the forthcoming conference on financing for development in Addis Ababa, we must do everything we can to ensure that the results become milestones in development policy.  I wish everyone who is involved in this for the European Parliament, for the Commission, but also for the Presidency of the Council, every success and success!

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I have listened very carefully to the whole debate and let me give you a concrete input. I personally believe that we should offer developing countries clear, concrete programmes and teach them how to collect taxes. I think that, in addition to financial assistance, providing know-how – what the tax administration in a given country should look like, how to combat tax evasion – is an extremely important thing. After all, we are preparing and having similar programmes, as the European Union, for countries that have partnership agreements with the European Union that want to join the European Union, and we are helping and advising them on how the judiciary should work, how the state should work. We should therefore be much more specific in this matter and come and put on the table concrete programmes on how we want to help these countries to combat tax evasion.  And let me make one more point, the fight against tax evasion does not mean the fight against low taxes. Third world countries should have the right to have lower taxes, and we should not deny them that right.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – Congratulations to my colleague Schlein on her report. In recent years, we have seen that excessive debt is not just a problem for developing countries. The combination of domestic populism and irresponsible lending has also brought some European economies to the brink of the abyss. The differences in numbers are huge, but the problem is still the same: disproportionately large debt repayments suck life out of the economy, and it no longer has the strength for the necessary reforms. Debt relief, which is not conditional on a commitment to adopt systemic reforms, leads to further debt. The only way to a solution is through dialogue between creditors and borrowers in order to strike a balance that is a condition for sustainable development. This principle must apply equally to Ethiopia, but also to Greece. However, a key prerequisite is the admission of liability of both debtors and creditors, not referendums rejecting it.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, huge tax evasion and avoidance are major challenges for governance in developing countries. The average ratio of taxes to gross domestic product is particularly low and moves between 10% and 20%. Thus developing countries are unable to tax the profits of multinationals operating profitably on their territory. This means a loss of huge tax revenues, which could be used to finance the state's social actions. For this reason taxes must be paid where the profits are made. But developing countries will not be on the path to growth as much as they are burdened with the burden of their huge public debt. That is why the UN resolution of September 2014 on the write-off of developing countries' sovereign debt must be implemented immediately.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I particularly listened to the speech by the Commissioner, who spoke here about coherent commitments, leverage and the political environment, but also about the universality of the development aid process, saying that 0.7% of this development aid share in GDP is not yet a commitment of all countries.  At the same time, However, I think that we cannot overlook one issue, and that is the issue of human rights violations, because we are often dealing with countries that violate human rights in debates concerning urgent debates on human rights violations. They violate our goals, our values, which we share as the European Union. I believe that we should also make our development aid subject to respect for those principles on which universal agreement is based, that is to say, a universal agreement, the UN Universal Declaration of Human Rights, at least as a standard.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, let me congratulate you immediately at the outset on your ambitious plans and as you said, you want to go to Addis Ababa with ambitious plans and a coherent agenda.  There is no doubt that Europe must remain a leader in helping developing countries because this is how we can act now, at the moment. But we are all aware that this way we will not eradicate poverty.  Therefore, if we really want to eradicate poverty, we need to look for innovative and new ways and approaches. Europe must first and foremost become a leader in the sense that globally all together, all the main partners of the EU and, of course, all those countries that can help, are participating in this project that the EU needs to lead. And of course, on the other hand, we have what Ms. Schlein is saying: the combination of tax havens and tax evasion must also be included in the function of developing all these countries.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for your great interest in the financing for development agenda ahead of the Addis conference, and for your valuable ideas, proposals and opinions. I agree that the European Union must keep up its level of ambition and commitments on ODA, including through the implementation of the development effectiveness principles. I also welcome your comments on issues that go beyond ODA. For me, this is exactly where real progress can be made through the post-2015 framework.  On the question of monitoring and follow-up, we must remain ambitious. The European Union already has a comprehensive annual accountability exercise in place to monitor progress. Indeed, the 2015 edition of the report was published last month. But we should also reflect on how we can strengthen that process, within the context of a wider post-2015 monitoring and accountability framework.   At this stage, we must also reflect on what the European Union will do to support the implementation of the financing for development outcome and the post-2015 agenda. We are carefully considering how the European Union’s policies might need to be reviewed to help promote the new agenda. The principle of policy coherence for development becomes more relevant than ever.  The European Union must be ready to deliver on a solid set of actions to implement the post-2015 agenda. This includes a comprehensive approach to supporting domestic resource mobilisation in developing countries and tackling tax avoidance and tax evasion. We will take the actions proposed in Parliament’s report into careful consideration, and we welcome your continued engagement in this regard.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, I would first like to thank the rapporteur for this report, which has enabled us to have a good debate, which is an important contribution to the preparations for the Addis Ababa and New York meetings. I would also like to highlight the work of the Commissioner and the importance of the fight against tax evasion. The solutions must, in this respect, be absolutely international.  As your speeches have clearly demonstrated and confirmed, the position of the European Union and its Member States on the purpose of this conference is clear. Addis Ababa should not be a conference on the issue of official development assistance alone. The need for an integrated approach to all means of implementation, financial and other, must be emphasized.  It is clear that official development assistance must remain an important source of funding, particularly for least developed countries and fragile states, provided, and has been said, that it is effective and well-oriented, well-used. I think we need to broaden the scope and reflect on what has been said about the creation of development. Education is, of course, a pillar of development policy, but also the creation of jobs and businesses - and I am thinking above all of the social sector, social enterprises. In addition to official development assistance, alternative financing, such as microfinance, must also be supported.  In this spirit, the Presidency, with these results that have been recalled, is fully committed to ensuring that these international negotiations are successful and that we are able to generate a true international partnership.

name: Elly Schlein
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his willingness in these months of work to discuss this report and for his commitment to take our proposals into consideration. I wanted to tell him – he knows this because we have been confronted with this for a long time – that we remain convinced that the creation of a truly intergovernmental body is the only way to guarantee full representativeness to developing countries. Today, the UN Tax Committee has only 25 members. This would be a quantum leap forward for the process of reforming the global system and sometimes, if You will allow me, form is substance. I therefore hope that tomorrow's vote will help to unblock the debate in order to arrive at an ambitious document on this subject in Addis Ababa. I would, of course, also like to thank the Council, as well as Mrs McAvan, for reminding us that country by country reporting is an indispensable tool for a serious fight against tax evasion and avoidance. That is why it is a central point of our action plan and I very much hope that tomorrow all the groups will support it as they did in committee in order to give a strong signal. I would also like to thank all my fellow Members who have contributed to this debate, not forgetting all the aspects which, although not mentioned, are, of course, included in the text of the report. It is not just a question of improving the mobilisation of internal resources: this also leads to a strengthening of governance, transparency and accountability towards citizens, and in this case certainly also the fight against corruption, which is mentioned several times in the text, and therefore, in essence, also to ensure greater independence from foreign aid in the long term. I would like to thank you all once again for your contribution and I hope that the report will obtain the highest possible majority in the vote tomorrow.

name: Preşedinte. –
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 8 July 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa The forthcoming conference on financing development will undoubtedly be one of the most key development developments of recent years in the field of development policy. For the European Union, this will in a way be a poker "check" of its commitments to ensuring high-quality development funding. The agreement agreed in Addis Ababa will form the basis for the September talks on the new Sustainable Development Goals, which cannot be achieved without adequate and stable funding.  In view of the need to ensure stable funding, I am of the opinion that the commitment we will make in Addis Ababa must first and foremost be real. It is therefore also important to take into account the fact that very few Member States are currently able to meet the commitment to allocate 0.7% of gross national income to ODA. I think it is right that the objective of allocating 0.7% of GNI to development policy should be treated globally, that is to say, towards the European Union as a whole, so that the different economic situations of individual countries, as well as different traditions in the field of development policy, can be taken into account.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, development aid aims both to reduce poverty and promote human rights, the strengthening of democracy, good governance and the rule of law. The Union contributes almost 60% of the world's official aid, but poverty and inequality reduction can be achieved by mobilising additional funds. In order to achieve these priorities, we must not forget about the private sector as a major actor and its potential to contribute to effective and long-term development. In this regard, I support the Council's conclusion of 12 December 2014. on the need to strengthen the role of the private sector in meeting future Sustainable Development Goals. In conclusion, development policy cannot achieve its objectives on its own, but must be integrated into a broader framework that combines both foreign and trade policy and other foreign policy instruments. Only then will development funding deliver a long-term and sustainable outcome.
